title: Woman in Paris Cabinet Chooses Female Guard
description: PARIS, Feb. 29 Simone Veil, France's Minister of Health, is the only woman in this country holding full Cabinet rank. Like her colleagues, the 48yearold Mrs. Veil is entitled to a bodyguard. Last week, she picked a new one  a woman.

title: Bridge
description: Of the group of tough New York experts who dominated the national championship scene 30 years ago only one continues to play regularly in New York tournamentsand continues to win. This tireless enthusiast is Alvin Roth, and he won two titles in the first two days of play at the Greater New York championships at the New York Hilton Hotel during the weekend.

title: Sri Lanka Aids Turtles
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, (Reuters)Sri Lanka, worried by the dwindling number of turtles around its shores, has decided to ban their slaughter and the removal of their eggs. It will aslo be an ofense to sell turtle flesh, eggs or shell, according to the Wildlife Conservation Department.

title: BANGOR PUNTA CALLS DAMAGES EXCESSIVE
description: The Bangor Punta Corporation said in a statement yesterday that it questioned the amount of damages the Government was seeking to levy against it as a result of the suit by ChrisCraft Industries ???

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Oil Companies Combined Nets Off 23.6% in 75 From 74 High
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) Combined profits of 25 of the nation's leading oil companies declined 23.6 percent in 1975 compared with the record levels of the year before, according to figures released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Israeli Aide in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 29 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Yigal Alton of Israel arrived here today amid strict security measures on an official visit to Mexico.

title: The Y ale Record, After 3Year Lapse, Is Publishing Again
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 29The Old Owl, the 104yearold symbol of The Yale Record, finally returned today from what the humor magazine's editors called an overextended vacation in St. Croix.

title: Books of The Times
description: In five years, from 1971 to 1975, I directly experienced esp, gestalt therapy, bioenergetics, rolfing, massage, jogging, health foods, tai chi, Esalen, hypnotism, modern dance, meditation, Silva Mind Control, Arica, acupuncture, sex therapy, Reichian therapy, and More Housea smorgasbord course in New Consciousness.

title: OIL LANDS PLEDGE MILLIONS TO CAIRO
description: CAIRO, Feb. 29President Anwar elSadat today returned from a tour of the oilproducing Arab countries of the Persian Gulf with pledges of at least $750 million in immediate aid and a promise of a longerterm multination Arab assistance program to help his economy.

title: World Title In Skating To Kleine
description: HEERENVEEN, The Netherlands, Feb. 29 (AP)Piet Kleine of the Netherlands won the men's world speed skating championship after winning races of 1,500 and 10,000 meters today.

title: Wallace Forces Fail to Unseat Mississippi Democratic Leader
description: JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 29Rearguard forces backing Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama failed at the state Democratic convention here today to unseat Aaron Henry, a black leader and longtime chairman of the loyalist faction, as cochairman of th newly united state Democratic party.

title: StillModern Ritorno di Ulisse Staged by City Opera
CoOp City Strike Rally Held in Hope of Victory
description: Several thousand CoOp City residents rallied yesterday on the community's Greenway at what one resident described as a rehearsal for our victory party to hear a report, of the group's protest against increases in their carrying charges.

title: Bowl for Catfish
description: What with lawsuits, glacial contract talks and padlocked training camps, there is no telling when the game of baseball will get under way this year, but the business of baseball opens today in the Bronx. Starting this morning, tickets will be on sale at the Yankee Stadium box office for a ganie with the Minnesota Twins on Thursday afternoon, April 15, the first athletic contest scheduled for the rebuilt playpen. Maybe the players won't be ready by then, or the owners ready to pay them, but the ball park will be. That brings up a point that hasn't been mentioned out loud: What about the clubs leases on municipal stadiums? From San Francisco Bay to Long Island, most of the teams play in publicly owned parks. In the improbable event that the owners made good their implied threat to call off the whole season, could their landlords still hold them responsible for a summer's rent?

title: CAROLINA WINNER:Richard Petty with his victory smile after the 500 at Rockingham, N.C. Page 20.
description: ROCKINGHAM, N.C., Feb 29 (UPI)  Richard Petty avoided an eightcar pileup today and went on to score a twolap victory in the Carolina 500 stock car race at Carolina Motor Speedway.

title: NEW FRONT SPLITS VIETNAMREFUGEES
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 29 The emergence of a Vietnamese liberation front in exile, led by a former Vietnamese senator who was imprisoned in Saigon for plotting to overthrow the Thieu Government six weeks before the country's collapse, has produced sharp disagreement among refugees here.

title: POLICE FENCES JAIL 100 IN WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (UPI) Agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and District of Columbia law enforcement officers said today that more than 100 personsincluding a Federal prosecutorhad been arrested in a policeoperated fencing operation set up to outsmart thieves.

title: Hanoi Bids Rebels Step Up Efforts in Southeast Asia
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 29 (UPI)  North Vietnam has officially called on underground groups throughout Southeast Asia to step up the fight to overthrow nonCommunist governments.

title: N.C.A.A. Has Date With a Telephone
description: Thursday is the big day for college basketball. That's when the N.C.A.A. will begin naming 15 atlarge teams to join the 17 conference champions that will receive automatic bids to the national championship tournament.

title: Heavy Trucks Fall Behind In Automotive Sales Race
description: DETROIT, Feb. 29Although American automobile executives are pleased by the comeback in sales of 1976 model cars and light trucks, one major segment of their business is still ailing. Big trucks are not showing the sales gains reported in the last five months for cars, pickups, vans and other light trucks.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Joseph Thanhauser 3d Marries Barbara Sonn
description: Barbara Jean Sonn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard M. Sonn of White Plains, was married here yesterday afternoon to Joseph Thanhauser 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thanhauser Jr. of Philadelphia.

title: As Mihajlov Nears Death
description: For over a decade the writer Mihajlo Mihajlov has been struggling to make the freedom of expression promised by Yugoslavia's Constitution a reality. This has led him to criticize his country's oneparty system and controlled press. Unable to publish his articles at home he sent them abroad, where they appeared in a number of European and American publications, among them The New York Times.

title: 10to1 Shot Is Victor
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 29 (UPI)Fascinating Girl, overlooked in the wagering, stunned her betterknown rivals today with a victory by a nose in the $100,000 Santa Margarita Handicap for the mare and filly championship of the Santa Anita meeting.

title: Candidates Spend Sunday Campaigning For Tomorrow's Massachusetts Vote
description: BOSTON, Feb. 29  Sunday was no day of rest for politicians, as the legion of Presidential contenders worked the television shows, the churches and the sidewalks today in pursuit of votes'In Tuesday's primary, which one state official predicted would see a heavy turnout of voters.

title: Additional Racing Days To Be Costly for State
description: TRENTON, March 1In addition to increasing racing dates in New Jersey and possibly opening the way to night thoroughbred horse racing in the state, a bill signed into law last week by Governor Byrne will cost the state $4.9 million in lost taxes.

title: John M. Schiff Marries Josephine L. Fell on L.I.
description: Josephine Laimbeer Fell of New York and Old Westbury, L. I., widow of John R. Fell, was married yesterday to John M. Schiff at the bridegroom's home in Oyster Bay, L. I.

title: TV: Young Pioneers
description: Can two likable teenage newlyweds from a small town in Iowa find ratings and a weekly series with hardships and triumphs in the Dakota wilderness of the 1870's? That is the question being asked by Young Pioneers. a twohour film pilot being shown on ABC tonight at 8. Industry rumor has it that Fred Silverman, ABC's programming chief, is enthusiastic about the project.

title: 1,041 More Meters In Manhattan Going From 10c to 25c
description: The Department of Traffic announced yesterday that it would begin converting more than 1,000 10cent parking meters in Manhattan to 25cent rates today.

title: Regional Planners Seek Heavy Taxes for Car Use
description: A 7centagallon gasoline tax in 12 counties of New York State, a 3centagallon tax in all of New Jersey and a uniforth $1 toll each way at all bridges and tunnels are among ways proposed by the Regional Plan Association to finance subsidies for public transportation.

title: Saturday School Attracts 200 Pupils
description: RIDGEFIELD, Feb. 29Yesterday morning, while many children were playing outside or watching their favorite television shows, 200 Ridgefield youngsters were attending a number of recreational courses, ranging from magic to woodshop, at one of three public schools here.

title: Music:Verdi'sLegnano
description: Verdi always thought highly of his La Battiglia di Legnano. But this early opera, conceived amid the patriotic fervor of 1848 and firit petforrnedsthe following year, has never fared wellthe performance Saturday night at Cooper Union by the Amato Opera was claimed as the American premiere.

title: Reforming Global Disaster Relief
description: MONTPELIER, Vt.  About this time of year, just three years ago, the dying began in earnest in Ethiopia. Wind blew the dust in swirls around the stick and mud houses of Wallo Province. Villages were silent, in the constant heat and haze of midday. Old women in rags gathered dried cornstalks and twigs for the evening's fire. Men hunkered in small groups in the shade, holloweyed, talking in low voices about leaving their families to search for food in the cities. The seeds for next year's crop were already eaten. Many of the children were sick. Some had died. Occasionally, you could hear a quiet coughing or crying from some sheltered place. Over all, it was a peaceful scene. A foreigner might have walked through these villages, and not realized what was happening.

title: O.A.U. Declines to Back Algerians on the Sahara
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Monday, March 1After days of debate and an allnight session, the foreign ministers of African nations decided today against full backing for the Algeriansupported front fighting for control of the Western Sahara.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The New York Times

title: CONFRONTATION OVER NUCLEAR PLANT: Construction union members demonstrated against environmentalists yesterday in Buchanan, N.Y., the site of the
description: BUCHANAN, N.Y., Feb. 29Demonstrators calling for the closing of the Point nuclear power plant outnumbered and outshouted today by union members threatened with the loss of their jobs.

title: Brazil Names Ambassador To the Luanda Government
description: BRASILIA,Feb. 29(AP)Brazil's rightwing military Government, which recognized the Sovietbacked Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola as the government of Angola last November, has appointed its first ambassador to Luanda.

title: HearstCase Jury to Hear a Different View This Week
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Feb. 29In an effort to explain howl a kidnapping victim could take part in a bank robbery with her kidnappers, psychiatrists from around the country have been summoned to examine Patricia Hearst and report their findings to the jury in her bank robbery trial here.

title: Lockheed Sale of Planes To Canada Will Proceed
description: OTTAWA Feb. 29Canada will to ahead with the purchaise of 18 longrange antisubmarine patrol planes from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation at an eventual cost projected at more than $1 billion, the Canadian Department of Defense said today.

title: ISRAELIS WARNED OVER ARAB SHRINE
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 29The Minister of Police, Shlomo Hillel, warned last night that Jews caught praying on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem would be arrested, in deference to Moslem sentiment.

title: Thailand and U. S. Negotiating on American Presence
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 29  Thailand and the United States are locked in a series of negotiations that within the next month should determine the shape and size of the American presence in this key, Southeast Asian country.

title: Over 80 Prisoners in Soviet Reported on Hunger Strike
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 29(Reuters) More than 80 inmates who say they are political prisoners are on hunger strike during the Communist Party congress hero to demand better conditions and an end to repression of dissenters, according to documents ??? from the penal institutions involved.

title: DEMOCRATS AGREE ON WHERE TO CUT THE CREY BUDGET
description: ALBANY, Feb. 29Democratic leaders in the Legislature have agreed on a package of alternative cuts in Governor Carey's budget, including heavy reductions in administrative personnel in the Departments of Education and Mental Hygiene.

title: Democrat Is Favored in Race in Queens
description: The odds in the special election tomorrow for State Senator from the 14th District in Queens greatly favor the Democratic contestant, but he says he will campaign clown to the wire, while his RepublicanConservative opponent says he thinks that he will upset him.

title: NEW LAW TOLIFT SUPPLIES OF RICE
description: The United States is one of the world's smallest growers of rice, accounting for less than 2 per cent of the world supply. It is also one of the biggest exporters, accounting for 25 percent of all rice moving in export trade.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The office of State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkciwitz reports that its Consumer Fraud and Protection Bureau obtained a court order against a Brooklyn lawyer and debtcollection concern directing them to pay back about $163,000 collected from more than 200 debtors for outofstate businesses since Dec. 15, 1972. The office said that the company, Clipper Associates, was dissolved by the Secretary of State on that date but that the company and its attorney, Stanley R. Stern, both with offices at 66 Court Street, continued to take assignments of claims and to sue for default judgments. The court order bars any further suits on behalf of Clipper Associates until the concern is legally incorporated, Mr. Lefkowitz's office said.

title: Mobil Board Plans to Add Clark and Its First Woman
description: The Mobil Oil Coropration announced yesterday that it planned to add Howard L. Clark, chairman and chief executive officer of the American Express Company, and Dr. Eleanor Bernert Sheldon, president of the Social Science Research Council of New York, to its board.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, MARCH 1, 1976

title: Concert: Book of Hours
description: Many contemporary composers flaunt their abilities to make music complex, but Ned Rorem waves an altogether different flag. His Book of Hours, an eightpart piece for flute and harp that received its first performance yesterday at Alice Tully Hall, seemed determined to be uneventful. Its calculated simplicities and unassertive manner recalled the barewalls asceticism of Satie in such works as Socrate, though Mr. Rorem's phrases and colors are more sensuous and do not quite evoke Satie's mood of monastic rigor.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, MARCH 1, 1976

title: Grover C. Loening Dies at 87; A Pioneer Airplane Designer
description: Grover C. Loening, who was taught to fly by Orville Wright and was the sole survivor of his early design team, died yesterday in Miami. He was 87 years old and lived in Key Biscayne, Fla.

title: ALLEGED EXAGENT REPORTED SUICIDE
description: A former engineer for the Mobil Oil Corporation who reportedly sold oil industry information to the Soviet Union and then became a double agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation died yesterday at his home in Southbury, Conn., of what the police said was a selfinflicted gunshot wound in the head.

title: Joseph Wittlin, 79, Author; Wrote Salt of the Earth
description: Joseph Wittlin, Polish poet and novelist best known for Salt of the Earth, which has been translated into 13 languages, died yesterday in the New York University Medical Center. He was 79 years old and lived at 5400 Fieldston Road, Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Need for Restraint
description: For the longer run, major changes will be essential to balance inflow and outflow and protect the integrity of the system. If nothing were done to change the existing pattern of benefits or revenues, payroll tax rates would have to be more than doubled by 2050. This would increase payroll taxes alone to an estimated 22 to 24 percent of income. (divided equally between employer and employee) before any other income or property or sales taxes were collected to meet the other obligations of Federal, state and local government.

title: Madrid Arrests Officer as Member Of Dissident Group
description: MADRID,Feb.29An army captain has been arrested in a continuing effort by the military authorities to stamp out a dissident organization known as the Democratic Military Union. Nine other officers arrested last July, are expected to be courtmartialed in about a week.

title: BOIES PENROSE, 73, TRAVEL HISTORIAN
description: Boles Penrose, author, traveler and collector of books, paintings and English furniture, died Friday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 73 years old and lived in Devon. Pa.

title: ANDREW J. CORCORAN
description: Andrew J. Corcoran, who retired in 1969 as assistant credit manager of The New York Times, where he had been employed since 1922, died Saturday in MidIsland. Hospital, Bethpage, L.I. He was 68 years old and lived at 107 Merritt Road, Farmingdale, L. I.

title: Chris Evert Takes Net Final, 63, 60
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 29 (AP)Chris Evert, seeded only second for the first time in a year, defeated topseeded Evonne Goolagong, 63, 60, today to win a $75,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament. Eight of the 15 games went to deuce, but Miss Evert won the most critical points.

title: A. P. Finds Signs of Progress in Turnaround Effort
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Companyafter having closed 1,400 stores, more than any other American retaller in recent historyis now in the black and showing sales Igains overall as well as irnproved sales productivity in lits individual stores.

title: JERSEY ITS STRIKE PUT OFF FOR A DAY
description: A strike threatened for 12:01 A.M. today by employees on the bus lines of the Transport of New Jersey was deferred last night when union and management representatives agreed to a 24hour extension of their contract as proposed by Federal and state mediators.

title: Carter Now Aims to Win Florida
description: MIAMI, Feb. 29Offering a rare glimpse of his true intentions in this state, Jimmy Carter flatly predicted here yesterday that a victory in the Florida primary would mean the Democratic Presidential nomination for him.

title: Nepotism in Pyongyang
description: Nepotism is an old story in Communist dictatorships, and some who rule in the name of MarxismLeninism have even thought of founding dynasties.

title: Nixons Fly Home to California After EightDay Trip to China
description: TOKYO. Feb. 29 (AP)Richard M. Nixon and Pat Nixon headed hack to California today after an eightday visit to China.

title: Hilde Kahn Weinberg, 71, Headed Handbag Concern
description: Hilda Kahn Weinberg, who founded and was president of the Walhorg Corporation, maker and importer of highfashion handbags, until the company was sold in 1974, died Saturday in New York Hospital She was 71 years old and lived at 180 East End Avenue and in Brewster, N. Y.

title: 2 Defeated Angolan Movements Must Leave Zaire
description: BRAZZAVILLE, Congo, Feb. 29 (Reuters)Two movements opposed to the Angolan Government set up by the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola must leave Zaire immediately under a new agreement designed to normalize relations between the two countries.

title: Bill Paley's Big Secret
description: WASHINGTON  CBS board chairman William Paley has been looking for an excuse to discipline correspondent Daniel Schorr for two years.

title: Russi Hurt in Fall
description: FIESCH, Switzerland, Feb. 29 (AP)Bernhard Russi of Switzerland, the Olympic downhill silver medalist, ??? taken to the hospital after injuring his spine in a fall at the national championships yesterday Russi, who will have to spend several days in a clinic, will not leave with the Swiss team for the season's final World Cup meets in the United States and Canada.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Feb. 17 order of Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Russell E. Train banning most uses of phenylmercurial pesticides is another egregious example of the arbitrary, unreasonable, unscientific manner in which the agency and its Administrator are operating.

title: Few Happy Endings
description: BOSTON, Feb. 29Watching a Powerful performance of Beethoven's Fidelio by Sarah Caldwell and the Opera Company of Boston, I thought again about the singular quality of a great work of artits power to stir our feelings afresh each time we experience it. We lose ourselves in it, letting our usual preoccupations slip away. Or sometimes, we are given flashes of insight into ourselves and our world: Art illuminates life.

title: URANUS MISSION APPROVED BY NASA
description: PASADENA, Calif, Feb. 29When the new space budget was drawn up and there was no money in it for a mission to Uranus, some engineers at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory here would not be denied. They figured a way to take a spacecraft ticketed for Saturn and give it a capability to go the extra distance to Uranus as well.

title: Laughing Gas Eases Coronary Pain
description: In a new use for an old drug, doctors have found that laughing gas can effectively and rapidly relieve the pain from heart attacks, thus improving chances of recovery for some patients.

description: Dr. William Filler Sr., director of obstetrics and gynecology at Terrace Heights and Boulevard Hospitals in Queens, died Saturday at his home in Bayside, Queens. He was 72 years old.

title: Palestine Guerrillas Seek to Close Ranks for War
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 29The Palestinian guerrilla movement is formulating a plan to intensify the struggle against Israel and close its divided ranks, the movement's central publication, Palestine Revolution, said today.

description: HUNTER, N.Y., Feb. 29Henri Duvillard, the former French Olympian from the Alpine community of Megave, proved a master of the touring professional ski troupe again today by scoring his second victory in two days.

description: Efforts to fashion a Democratic nonaggression pact collapsed yesterday, guaranteeing widespread challenges to the petitions that put candidates for delegates to the Presidential convention on the New York ballot.

description: A few weeks ago cough and cold remediesnever a particularly lucrative business for the highprofit drug companiesseetned headed for a bad year.

title: Study Shows College Students Say They Want to Leave State
description: PRINCETON, N. J. Feb. 29 (UPI)Many New Jersey college students are planning to leave the state after graduation because of a lack of jobs, the state's social climate and other reasons, according to renort published today.

title: DEPOSITORY'S DATA ON STOCKS SOUGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (UPI) Senator Lee Metcalf said today that stockholders in major corporations were being denied the right to learn the identity of owners of stock being held in a depository trust controlled by the New York Stock Exchange.

title: BLACK ARTISTS BAND, MACHITO PERFORM
description: Frank Grillo, the veteran Latin bandleader better known as Machito, celebrated a birthday Saturday evening at Town Hall with the Collective Black Artists big band. The meeting was an apt one, for during the 1940's Machito's was one of the first Latin groups to feature improvisations by jazzmen, among them Charlie Parker and Dizzy Gillespie.

title: Cincinnati Five Wins
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 29 (AP) Cincinnati overcame travel fatigue and a halftime deficit for an 8075 college basketball victory over Duquesne today. Cincinnati (22.4) had arrived late last night after an ??? overtime victory at home against San Francisco. Duquesne led, 3027, at the half.

title: Sudan Accuses Ethiopia
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Feb. 29 (Reuters)  The Sudan said today that the Ethiopian Air Force had repeatedly attacked Sudanese border positions and violated airspace, over the past year. A Foreign Ministry statement said Sudan would take all necessary measures to protect its territory.

title: A LAPSE IS CITED OVER 34 TREATIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29(AP) The General Accounting Office has found that Congress was not notified of 34 agreements between the United States and South Korea since Congress enacted a reporting requirement in August 1972.

title: Refugees, Charging a Sellout, Are Pressing Lisbon for Aid
description: TOMAR, Portugal, Feb. 29We've hen sold out and humiliated but all we want is the chance to build a new life, a ??? businessman who fled Mozambique two week ago declared here today.

title: FED TIGHTENING OF POLICY SEEN
description: The Federal Reserve almost certainly shifted toward a less accommodative monetary policy last Friday, many leading credit market analysts concluded after the central bank remained absent from the marketplace and permitted the Federalfunds rate to rise to 5 percent. The move, which came somewhat sooner than many Fed Watchers had expected, pushed interest rates sharply higher.

title: Pacing Series Gives Big Hopes to Small Stables
description: WESTBURY, L. I.  Steve Warrington, a 24  year  old trainer, hitched up one eighth of his harnesshorse stable at Liberty Bell in Philadelphia one morning a couple of weeks ago and headed for Roosevelt Raceway here with a 3yearold pacer in his van and, as he put it, dollar signs in my eyes.

title: Carter Arouses Hostility Among McGovern's Aides
description: BOSTON, Feb. 29The debate over former Georgia Gov. Jimmy Carter's Presidential candidacy is getting nastier among the antiwar liberals who formed Senator George McGovern's campaign in 1972. When Patrick J. Caddell, the onetime McGovern pollster who is now joining the Carter campaign, was quoted in The Wail Street Journal the other day as saying, Jimmy Carter is where America is at, Alan Baron, a political aide to Mr. McGovern, replied, Pat, that's like saying, In 1972, Richard Nixon was where America was at.

title: DR. ANN KEILL
description: Dr. Ann KeiII, a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst here for 20 years, died Saturday of cancer in New York Hospital. She was 51 years old and lived at 350 Central Park West.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 29 (UPI)Elliott Maddox, one of a dozen unsigned NewYork Yankees, is scheduled to fly to Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester, N. Y. tomorrow for a surgical procedure called an arthroscopy.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (UPI) President Ford's plane larided at 7:12 P.M. tonight at Andrews Air Force Base in suburban; Maryland.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) Interior Secretary Thomas S. Kleppe said today that balance must be struck between economics and conservation and he urged Congress to approve President Ford's energy proposals.

title: Drifter Judged Best Pekingese
description: The Drifter, more formally known as Ch. Quilkin The Stringman, drifted into the Hotel McAlpin yestetday and left as best of breed at the 117th specialty of the Pekingese Club of America.

description: The Department of Traffic announced yesterday that it would begin converting more than 1,000 10cent parking meters in Manhattan to 25cent rates today.

title: About New york
description: New York is where people wait. They wait in doctors offices. They wait in banks. They wait to get into a movie. They wait to get out of jail. Sometimes the waiting is solitary and sometimes it is comunal, and often there is nothing anyone can do about it. Some waits, however, are worse than others.

description: Environmentalists have never been angrier, more determined, more articulate about their objectives and assured that at long last, their fellow citizens are beginning to realize that natural resources can no longer be squandered.

title: 3,000 Here Honor I.R.A. Man Who Died in Prison
description: More than 3,000 people marched through midtown Manhattan yesterday and rallied at the United Nations to honor Frank Stagg, the 34yearold Irish republican who died in Yorkshire prison on Feb. 12 after a 61day hunger strike.

title: The Old Vic Shuts Down In Tribute to Founder
description: LONDON, Feb. 29 (UPI)The Old Vic, perh'ps Britain's bestloved theater, shut down last night, the victim both of success and financial crisis.

description: Bea Benjamin's approach to the songs of Duke Ellington, which made up most of her performance yesterday afternoon at Tempo Music, 333 Riverside Drive, put some of Mr. Ellington's most familiar pieces in a fresh and imaginative light.

title: Pressmen Will Make Offer To 3 Baltimore Newspapers
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 29 (AP)The leaders of the union representing 200 pressmen at the two Baltimore Sun newspapers and The News American ordered their negotiators today to return to the bargaining tables with a counteroffer at a meeting tentatively scheduled for March 12.

title: Manhattan Gets E.C.A.C. Berth
description: CENTERVILLE, Mass., Feb. 29 (AP)The University of Connecticut and Manhattan College were named today to fill two of three remaining spots in the Eastern College Athletic Conference's Division I basketball playoffs.

title: Battery Park City's Future Questioned by Levitt Audit
description: ALBANY, Feb. 29  The chances of financial success for Battery Park City, the new town plannedfor 100acres of landfill in the Hudson River, are so uncertain that top state and city officials must decide soon whether the ambitious project should be substantially modified or even discontinued, State Comptroller Arthur Levitt said today.

title: New Hampshire Growth Linked to Tax Rise
description: DERRY, N.H.Here near the farmhouse where Robert Frost wrote his poetry, new brick apartment houses perch incongruously in space cut out from the surrounding birches. And on Route 28 running into Salem, the signs in quick succession read Burger King, Jack in the Box, Pizza Hut, McDonald's, KMart, Salem Plaza, Rockingham Plaza.

title: Abortion in the Campaign: Methodist Surgeon Leads the Opposition
description: BOSTONMethodists, black people and surgeons are not that often associated with the socalled right to life movement that is battling legalized abo'tion. That's why Dr. Mildred F. Jefferson comes as a surprise to a lot of people.

title: 5 Japanese Had Key Roles In Pushing Lockheed Bids
description: TOKYO, Feb. 29The Lockheed bribery scandal has been shaking Japan for three weeks, but its origins go back 18 years to an era when the Japanese were beginning to rebuild their military forces with American assistance.

title: The Urban Red Cross
description: The work performed by the Greater New York chapters of the American Red Cross has particular closetohome significance during this critical year. Additional responsibilities have been assumed in the field of urban social problems. In cooperation with the Fire Department, for example, the Red Cross in December alone answered the call in 300 multifamily fires with personal aid. The city's chapters make the scene even without the big newsmaking disasters: in youth services, in nursing and health programs, in training of social service aides.

title: Regional Planners Seek Heavy Taxes for Car Use
description: A 7centagallon gasoline tax in 12 counties of New York State, a 3centagallon tax in all of New Jersey and a uniform $1 toll each way at all bridges and tunnels are among ways proposed by the Regional Plan Association to finance subsidies for public transportation.

title: An Emotional Issue s Status in the Courts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27Suddenly, abortion is a political issue, a source of debate in the Presidential primaries.

title: Beleaguered Greeks in Istanbul Fearful of Future
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey  The windows of the storefront were covered with browri paper and black grime. Inside a handful of elderly Greeks talked about their life in Istanbul.

title: 2 Possible Successors to Cunningham Mentioned as Party Chief's Hold on Job Weakens
description: Democratic politicians are increasingly predicting that Patrick J. Cunningham's days as DeMocratic state chairman are numbered, regardless of the eventual outcome of Maurice H. Nadjari's investigation of Mr. Cunningham's role, if any, in the alleged sale of judgeships in the Bronx. In fact, two potential successors are already being discussed  Dominic Baranello, the Suffolk Democratic leader who was a Carey supporter long before Mr. Cunningham or any other major county leader, and Gerald Cummins, the parttime $25,000 chairman of the State Thruway Authority, who was Mr. Carey's campaign manager in 1974 and is still a frequent social companion of the Governor.

title: Personal Finance: Income Averaging
description: The income  averaging method of computing taxes is used by many professional athletes, actors, authors and others with fluctuating incomes as a means of saving money. But it can also he used by others if their income last year was considerably higher than in the immediate preceding years.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The Now York Times

title: JERSEY BUS STRIKE PUT OFF FOR A DAY
description: A strike threatened for 12:01 A.M. today by employees on the bus lines of the Transport of New Jersey was deferred last night when union and management representatives agreed to a 24hour extension of their contract as proposed by Federal and state mediators.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Battery Park City's Future Questioned by Levitt Audit
description: ALBANY, Feb. 29  The chances of financial success for Battery Park City, the new town planned for 100acres of landfill in the Hudson River, are so uncertain that top state and city officials must decide soon whether the ambitious project should be substantially modified or even discontinued, State Comptroller Arthur Levitt said today.

title: PAUL SIMON WINS SOLOIST GRAMMYS
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 29 (AP) Paul Simon, who won seven Grammy awards during his years with his singing partner, Art Garfunkel, garnered two more as a soloist last night for his hit album Still Crazy After All These Years.

title: Gerald W. Brownstein, 52, A Lawyer in New Haven
description: Gerald W. Brownstein, a senior partner in the New Haven law firm of Brownstein, Di Pietro & Kantrovitz and a specialist in commercial and bankruptcy law, died yesterday of cancer at his home in New Haven. He was 52 years old.

title: The. Dance: Senta Driver in2 Premieres
description: Senta Driver's company, Harry, has an, original flavor, Intellectual in its approach and manic in its gleeful humor. The company performed Saturday night at the American Theater Labalmost a year after the first concert presented by Miss Driver since she left the Paul Taylor Dance Company.

title: Adam Powell Recalled At Dedication of School
description: In speeches and songs, Adam Clayton Powell, Jr. was recalled as a devoted clergyman and charismatic politician at a dedication ceremony yesterday for an elementary school here that is named for him.

title: J.C. Snead and Nicklaus Tie for Lead
description: LAUDERHILL, Fla., Feb. 29 Jack Nicklaus and J.C. Snead continued their duel today for the Tournament Players Championship lead, each shooting 68 to enter tomorrow's finale at 204, or 12 under par, at the Inverrary Country Club.

title: HARRY OMMERLE, AD MAN, 66, DEAD
description: Harry G. Ommerle, who retired as executive vice president of SSC&B Inc., advertising agency, in December 1970, after 40 years in advertising, television and radio, died Saturday in the Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was. 66 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: Miss Schumacher Wed to Brian Boxer
description: Jeanne Louise Schumacher and Brian Edward Boxer were married here yesterday afternoon.

title: It's the Local Elections That Stir Larchmont
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y.; Feb. 29  Larchmont hasn't changed much over the years, said Ed Leone, who was born here in 1910 and should know. It has just filled in.

title: Constitutional Jails
description: The unusual pitched struggle over confirmation Herman Schwartz as chairman of the State Commission of Correction is really a battle over whether the sheriffs of the State of New York are to be required to raise standards in the county jails to levels of constitutional acceptability.

title: A West Side Bookshop Moves to Upstate Town
description: Parnassus, a cozy, inviting, cluttered bookshop on West 89th Street just east of Broadway, will close its doors today and move to Rhinebeck, N. Y.

title: Collegiate Track Title To Adelphi
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 29 Dorian McRae, a senior, won two events and led Adelphi to its first Collegiate Track Conference indoor championship at Jadwin Gymnasium tonight. Adelphi amassed 71 points, more than twice the number of any other team.

title: Harlem Dance Unit Presents Corsaire And Mitchell Piece
description: Dance Theater of Harlem's first week has been cleverly designed around the unfailing pas de deux, with carefully matched dancers, and colorful ensemble works. Its second program shown. Friday and Saturday at the Uris Theater, featured Paul Russell and Elena Carter and Susan Lovelle with Ronald Perry.

title: Advertising
description: The profit problems the J. Walter Thompson Company suffered in 1973 and 1974 were in a great part due to mismanagement and waste of corporate assets in the Diners/Fugazy Travel and Incentive Company, a former top executive of the advertising agency charges in a suit filed last week in State Supreme Court.

title: Failed Duties
description: The Moreland Act Commission's report on political influence in the nursing home industry provides sharply etched crosssectional picture of many of the factors that have produced such widespread popular disenchantment with government. In this particular scandal almost every public figure involved appeared to have fallen short in performance of basic duties.

title: Social Security Drain
description: After four decades of admirable service to the nation, the Social Security system is in need of major overhaul. Its reserves, though still substantial, require shoring up. Equally important, the country must assess the relationship of Social Security, as cornerstone of its program of retirement protection for the elderly, to all the other burgeoning systems of public and private pensions into which a growing proportion of national income goes.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NILE STYLE A lavish new night spot, Club Ibis (753.3471), offers Egyptian decor and entertainment at 151 East 50th Street (between Third and 1.exington Avenues), the site of the old Versailles, where Edith Piaf once reigned. There's nothing Gallic there now. The burnishedsand atmosphere of the main room, where high, golden palms sprout between big beige mural of the pyramids and Sphinx, ancient Karnak and other landscapes, is enough to make you order an icy drink before settling at a table.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Buy a sofa and get a spare bed, invest in a pair of chairs and get a love seat plus bench seating for six, decide on a hassock and get a game table. The furniture that Frank Amellio designs for the Chelsea Couch Company is nothing if not versatile. Just the thing for small apartments, dens, and country and beach houses.

title: Wool Council Leaving City
description: DENVER, Feb. 29 (UPI)The American Wool Council is moving its headquarters from. New York to Denver, already the base of the parent American Sheep Producers Council. The council said yesterday the move was part of a program intended to expand the domestic sheep industry.

title: Ford Stresses His OntheJob Experience
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 29President Ford, stressing his onthe  job experience in the White House, told Florida Republicans today that his Administration had begun to put America at peace with itself and with the world.

title: Kathryn Hill Wed To R. P. Strickler
description: Kathryn Mardel Hill was married yesterday afternoon to Richard Perry Strickler.

title: Economies, Growing Demand and Fund Raising Help Prep Schools Remain Financially Stable
description: BOSTON  Despite soaring costs and inexorably rising tuition rates, the financial condition of the nation's college preparatory schools, both boarding and day, appears to be relatively stable.

title: Second Sunday Protest Staged Against Concorde
description: Protesting plans to allow supersonic jets at Kennedy International Airport, local residents staged their second consecutive Sunday drivein demonstration at the airport yesterday afternoon, drawing what the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey estimated as 500 slowmoving cars to airport roads.

title: Carter Now Aims to Win Florida
description: MIAMI, Feb. 29Offering a rare glimpse of his true intentions in this state, Jimmy Carter flatly predicted here yesterday that a victory in the Florida primary would mean the Democratic Presidential nomination for him.

title: Rep. Mills Doubts He Will Run; Plans Final Decision by March 9
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 29  Representative Wilbur D. Mills sent word to his district today that barring unforeseen developments, he did not plan to run for a 20th term this year.

title: Rhodesia Reports Killing 17, Losing 4 In Guerrilla Clash
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 29 (Reuters)Rhodesia said today that 17 guerrillas and four members of the security forces were killed in a clash yesterday in what is officially called the northeastern guerrillawar zone.

title: Church Service Turns the Clock to 1776
description: MONTCLAIR, Feb. 29The Spirit of 1776 revisited this community as 800 worshipers jammed St. Luke's Episcopal Church to participate in a Sunday service as it would have been conducted 200 years ago.

title: WORLD'S SPENDING ON ARMS REPORTED AT RECORD LEVELS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 World military spending has risen to almost $300 billion annually and is increasing most rapidly in the developing countries, a study sponsored by private arms control groups reported today.

title: Court to Rule on Restraint Of Vote on School Budget
description: FREEHOLD, Feb. 29On the eve of a school election, a Superior Court judge is expected to rule tomorrow on a restraint Order he issued Friday to present the Monmouth Regional High School District from adopting its school budget or raging money.

title: Environmentalists Call Jobs a False Issue
description: Environmentalists have never been angrier, more determined, more articulate about their objectives and assured that at long last, their fellow citizens are beginning to realize that natural resources can no longer be squandered.

title: GALILEE LAND MOVE STIRS ISRAELI ARABS
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 29  The Israeli Cabinet today approved an urban housing program that involves Government requisition of 2,500 acres of privately owned land in Galilee. Arab villagers in the area promptly protested the Government move.

title: Florence Dwyer,73,Dies; Representative in Jersey
description: Florence Price Dwyer, who retired undefeated at the end of 1972 after eight successive terms in the House of Representatives as a Republican from Union County. N.J., died yesterday in Elizabeth (N.J.) General Hospital. She was 73 years old and lived at 320 Verona Avenue in Elizabeth.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The 18 members of the Seaside Heights Police Department agreed to stop picketing roads leading to the Ocean County municipality and reopen contract negotiations with borough officials. The agreement ended two days of picketing by offduty policemen.

title: Alternative Routes For Jersey Riders
description: Passengers from North Bergen will be able to use the Rockland Coach Line, which supplements Transport of New Jersey buses in that area.

title: Wallace's Victory in Carolina Is Narrow
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 29 South Carolina Democrats gave Gov. George Wallace of Alabama a narrow victory over former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia last night in a caucus race so close that most agreed it was a standoff.

title: 5 Japanese Had Key Roles In Pushing Lockheed Bids
description: TOKYO, Feb. 29The Lockheed bribery scandal has been shaking Japan for three weeks, but its origins go back 18 years to an era when the Japanese were beginning to rebuild their military forces with American assistance.

title: DEMOCRATS AGREE ON WHERE TO CUT THE CAREY BUDGET
description: ALBANY, Feb. 29Democratic leaders in the Legislature have agreed on a package of alternative cuts in Governor Carey's budget, including heavy reductions in administrative personnel in the Departments of Education and Mental Hygiene.

title: MORMONS SELLING HISTORIC CHAPEL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29The Washington chapel of the Church of Jesus Christ of LatterDay Saints is for sale. The parish has been dissolved. The gilded statue of an angel has been removed from the spire. The doors have been locked to all but the few resident caretakers.

title: Lockheed Sale of Planes To Canada Will Proceed
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 29Canada will go ahead with the purchase of 18 longrange antisubmarine patrol planes from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation at an eventual cost projected at more than $1 billion, the Ministry of National Defense said today.

title: Philadelphia Museum Reinvigorated
description: Philadelphia has its own look, its own style and its own pace. It also has its own Mus'eum of Art, which is not quite like any other.

title: Collegiate Chorale in Faure Requiem
description: Those who agree that Gabriel Eaure's Requiem is the most tender, meltingly beautiful of all should have been well content with its lovingly detailed performance by the Collegiate Chorale at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night.

title: Nelson A. Stitt, 60, Dead; Lawyer in Japan Trade
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 Nelson A. Stitt, a lawyer whose career was mainly in the field of economic relations between the United States and Japan, died here yesterday in his home lat the age of 60.

title: $100 Bills Flow at AntiqueGun Show
description: MELVILLE, L.I., Feb. 29'A rich man's hobby, a poor man's business, sighed one collector today, surrounded by pistols, rifles, swords and other souvenirs of war.

title: Soviet Subdues Religion, but Zeal for Atheism Lags
description: LENINGRAD  The magnificent Cathedral of Our Lady of Kazan on Leningrad's Nevsky Prospekt was erected early in the 19th century to the glory of God. But since 1932 it has served an altogether different purpose.

title: WORLD'S SPENDING ON ARMS REPORTED Al RECORD LEVELS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 World military spending has risen to almost $300 billion annually and is increasing most rapidly in the developing countries, a study sponsored by private arms control groups reported today.

title: Sail Ho! 200 Ships Of Past Will Salute Bicentennial Here
description: They will move up the amphitheater of New York Harbor like visions out of the past, a stately procession of tall ships with ghostwhite sails and fluttering ensigns, gliding silently, toward a city of strange towers and 20thcentury anachronisms.

title: Massachusetts: As Voter Mosaic
description: BOSTON, March 1  A string trio played Mozart unnoticed and unheard in the cacaphony of political talk as Massachusetts liberals, who seem to prefer to be called progressives these days, crowded together for an Americans for Democratic Action cocktail party Saturday night in a room in the Boston University Student Union.

title: Yankees Owner Is Reinstated by Kuhn
description: George M. Steinbrenner 3d bcame the first baseball club owner yesterday to win anything this year.

title: COMMONS VOTES SEATBELT Bill
description: LONDON, March 1  The House of Commons approved tonight a controversial measure to make the wearing of auto seat belts compulstry in Britain.

title: S.E.C. IS AWAITING BID ON LOCKHEED
description: WASHINGTON, March 1Roderick M. Hills, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that he expects a request from the Japanese Government this week for information that his agency Was subpoenaed on alleged bribes and payments by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in Japan. Mr. Hills said that he expected to comply with the request.

title: HYLAND UNDECIDED ON DEATH PENALTY
description: TRENTON, March 1State Attorney General William F. Hyland said today that he was reexamining his opposition to capital punishment in the killing of policemen, firemen and pricon guards.

title: IC4A Foes See Chance to Beat Villanova
description: Villanova seems to be the general favorite to win the 55th annual IC4A indoor track and, field championship at Princeton's Jadwin Gym on Saturday and Sunday, mostly because of its strength in middledistance and distance events.

title: Radio
description: Radio

title: High Court Bars Challenge To Hospital Abortion Curb
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 The Supreme Court refused today to hear a challenge to the 1973 statute that permits federally aided private hospitals to decline on either religious or moral grounds to permit abortions and sterilizations.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Up at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, March 1Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: No Nuclear Danger Found In Accident in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, March 1After a week of investigation, the nuclearsafety task force created by Gov. Ella T. Grasso tentatively concluded today that the public was probably not endangered by a leak of radioactive steam last month at the Millstone No. 1 nuclear power plant at Waterford.

title: Justice Agency Accused On Gulf Contributions
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 1 (AP)George R. Packard, a former newspaper editor seeking the Republican nomination fox the Senate, said today that he and his wife had personal assets totaling $88,255.

title: State Charges 3 Oil Companies Divided Pie in Gas Contracts
description: The state accused three major oil companies yesterday of getting together to divide up the pie for millions of dollars of gasoline contracts in the city and state.

title: FORD LISTS 3 POINTS BARRING CUBA TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)President Ford said to day that he foresaw no immediate improvement in relations with Cuba and spelled out three things the Cubans must do before we would even talk to them.

title: Battery Park City Authority Woos a Big Employer
description: The Battery Park City Authority has been negotiating for eight months with a major officebuilding tenant, seeking to keep the tenant, a company with 3,000 employees, in the city after its present leases in scattered lower Manhattan sites moire in 1980.

title: A Confident Wallace Ends Drive With Busing Attack
description: BOSTON, March 1  Confident of making a good showing in tomorrow's Democratic Presidential primary, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama barnstormed across Massachusetts today, decrying forced busing at five airport news conferences and ending up with a fullfledged exposition of his staunch conservatism at a large rally this eve ning in a downtown Boston theater.

title: Forecasts of Rain Cut Wheat Prices; Cattle Also Drop
description: A forecast of a little rain over some of the droughtstricken wheat areas led to some selling of wheat futures yesterday. The July contract, one of the new crop months, closed at $3.98 a bushel, down from $4.06.

title: Obituary 8  No Title
description: Obituary 8  No Title

title: Arizona Equal Rights Fails
description: PHOENIX, March 1 (AP)The proposed equal rights amendment failed on a 1515 tic vote in the Arizona Senate today, ending any possibility that the measure could he approved in the legislature this year. The proposal was killed earlier in the House.

title: Haggadah With a Bicentennial Aspect
description: A new Passover Haggadah that relates the ancient Hebrew quest for freedom to the nation's Bicentennial will be recited next month at a Teaneck temple.

title: Draft of College Players Fails to Arouse Leagues
description: The college basketball draft scene is quieter than usual. The uncertain future of the American Basketball Association and the National Basketball Association's preoccupation with the proposed settlement of the Oscar Robertson antitrust suit have forced the player draft to the background. At such a time in previous years there was talk about the interleague bidding war that raised Bill Walton's salary daily and speculation whether the Atlanta Hawks could afford to sign both David Thompson and Marvin Websten The price tags of players like Kareem AbdulJabbar, Pete Maravich, Bob McAdoo, Ernie DiGregorio and Doug Collins fluctuated like the stock market.

title: GASOLINE PRICES LIFTED BY TEXACO
description: Gyrations of gasoline prices came into play yesterday. Texaco Inc. announced a nationwide increase of onecentagallon on all grades of motor gasoline to retail and wholesale classes of trade and an increase of 1.3 cents to the commercial fleet class of trade. Texaco also announced a reduction of one cent a gallon on all grades of tractor and diesel fuels, No. 1 and No. 2  heating oils and kerosene in selected areas. The company said all changes were in accordance with Federal Energy Administration regulations.

title: State Action Foreseen
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) Representative Kastenmeier predicted the Federal phaseout of research on prisoners would lead to similar action by most states.

title: New Met Season to Reflect Modern Policy
description: The Metropolitan Opera announced its repertory and principal casting for the 197671 season yesterday, and in so doing gave the first formal indication of the more modernist, adventuresome policies of its new ruling triumvirate, Anthony A. Bliss, executive director; James Levine, music director, and John Dexter, director of production.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Special Committee Against Apartheid3:00 P.M.

title: JAMES CUMMING, 72, ADVERTISING AIDE
description: James C. Cumming, a retired vice president of the Chirurg & Cairns advertising agency and author of many books and articles on textile marketing, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 72 years old and lived at 135 The Fellsway, Murray Hill, N. J.

title: High Court Bars Challenge To Hospital Abortion Curb
description: WASHINGTON, March 1The Supreme Court refused today to hear a challenge to the 1973 statute that permits federally aided private hospitals to decline on either religious or moral grounds to permit abortions and sterilizations.

title: A.T.&T. Leads Industry, A Regulated Monopoly
description: An attempt to sell a device supposedly capable of conveying the human voice over metallic wires resulted in the arrest of the seller here a century ago on charges of attempted extortion.

title: Dave Anderson
description: For the New York Rangers, this is suddenly the week that might be. By late Sunday night, they might be only 4 points behind the Atlanta Flames and driving far the thirdplace Stanley Cup playoff berth in the Patrick Division of the National Hockey League; that's what the optimists are hoping. The Rangers also might be 16 points behind the Flames and virtually eliminated; that's what the pessimists are fearing. The Rangers also might be somewhere in between and struggling; that's what the realists are assuming. As for the players, it's difficult to tell which group they're in. After a determined 11 tie with the Montreal Canadiens at Madison Square Garden last Sunday night, the loudest voices in the Rangers dressing room were talking about doughnuts. Your turn to buy the doughnuts, one of the players was shouting. Don't forget to bring the doughnuts to practice tomorrow. Maybe that's a sign of togetherness. Maybe it's a sign of indifference. Perhaps it has no significance at all, other than that a few players enjoy doughnuts. But right now the new coach, John Ferguson, would prefer his players to be chewing nails instead of doughnuts.

title: Yankee Fans Flock to Opening Day
description: Drew Schinelli is a seventh grade student at Mark Twain Middle School in Yonkers. Drew Schinelli wasn't in his classroom when the school day began yesterday. He was at:Yankee Stadiumthe first person in line waiting to buy a ticket for the opening game at the renovated Stadium.

title: BRONX HOUSE FIRE LAID TO FIREBOMB
description: Bronx investigators said yesterday that a fire bomb was responsible for the fire that heavily damaged the home of a black family in a mostly white neighborhood in the Westchester section early Sunday. Two adjoining buildings also were damaged in the blaze, which took nearly an hour to rout out.

title: Australia Wins Doubles for 21 Cup Lead
description: BRISBANE, Australia, March 1 (AP)  Australia took a 21 lead over New Zealand in the Davis Cup tennis Eastern Zone final today as John Newcombe and Tony Roche beat Onny Parun and Brian Fairlie in the doubles.

title: CITY MAY PUT OFF BIG BUDGET CUTS UNTIL THIRD YEAR
description: The Beame adminiftration was reported yesterday to be considering deferral of the larger part of the budget cuts it is facing to the final year of the threeyear austerity plan in the hope that changes in the. National Administration and economy might mitigate some of the city's fiscal pains.

title: G.O.P. Race in Massachusetts Was a Noncanipaign
description: BOSTON, March 1The Democrats were hacking at each other with broadswords here in Massachusetts, but for the Republicans it has been mostly thrust and parry.

title: Rutgers Ends Season at 260
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 1Rutgers was on the brink of its first defeat tonight, but rallied from 7 points back in the last six minutes, beat St. Bonaventure, 8580, and became the first Metropolitan area college basketball team in a quarter century to go through a regular season undefeated.

title: Francis Retires at the St. Louis Fed
description: Darryl R. Francis, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, retired yesterday, stirring speculation about who his successor will be and whether the bank's independent voice, and sometimes controversial points of view, would continue to be heard.

title: France's Tax Time Brings On Fraudulent Accounting in Billions
description: PARIS, March 1  Fiction worth billions of dollars has been submitted to the French Government in recent days as the annual deadline for filing income declarations approaches.

title: Bankruptcy on Africa
description: United States policy for southern Africa has arrived at dead end. The conspicuous failure of Washington's covert intervention in Angola ought to have made this clear to everyone.

title: CALIFORNIA SOUL ENDS 4NIGHT RUN
description: These are perilous times for jazz musicians. Success in the marketplace is a very real possibility, if only the music can be tailored to the tastes of an idealized mass audience. The tailoring usually involves more amplification, rock rhythms, and less improvisation. It can result in pleasant music, but it just as often leads otherwise wellmeaning jazzmen into ludicrous excesses that rock music outgrew several years ago.

title: Newer India Is Thriving, Productive
description: RANCHI, India, Feb. 25Here, in the huge factories, foundries and steel mills ranging over the hills west of Calcutta, is the other India, the heart and muscle of an industrial vitality that people of this country say the world tends to ignore.

title: N.F.L. Defense Ready As Kapp Trial Begins
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 1What would amount to a noharm, nofoul type of defense may emerge from the antitrust trial that began in Federal Court here today regarding Joe Kapp's suit against the National Football League.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Monday.

title: Alaska Gamble
description: Over the strenuous objections of Federal environmental agencies, Secretary of the Interior Kleppe has decided to proceed with the sale of offshore oil and gas leases in the Northern Gulf of Alaska. As a compromise Secretary Kleppe reduced the area to be offered for bids by petroleum companies by 40 percent, from 1.8 million to 1.1 million acres.

title: State Delinquent Center: No Punishment or Reform
description: GOSHEN, N.Y.With his 16th birthday just approaching, Willie Charles has been a shoplifter, a mugger, a drug dealer, a pimp and a hank robber.

title: Money Policy of Fed Lifts Interest Rates
description: Shortterm interest rates climbed sharply yesterday in the wake of the Federal Reserve's apparent shift last Friday toward a somewhat less accommodative credit policy, and Treasury bill rates rose to their highest levels since December. Prices of Treasury notes and bonds and corporate bonds also declined as the credit markets sought to adjust to what they perceived as the central bank's new posture.

title: Books of The Times
description: Just consider the obstacles that Gore Vidal has had to overcome to make his latest book, 1876: A Novel, live up to the witty, entertaining Burr, to which it the sequel. (Actually, as Mr. Vidal reminds us in his Afterword, since two of the imaginary people in 1876 are the forebears of characters who appear in his earlier political novel, Washington, D. C., 1876 forms the third part of a trilogy. Still, 1876 more nearly resembles Burr than it does Washington, D. C.) First, sequels almost never rival their originals, as Vidal himself should know well after trying to follow up Myra Breckenridge with Myron. Second, and more serious, the plot and suspense of 1876 are built on the election of 1876, and everyone who remembers his highschool history will recall the outcome of that: the reformminded Governor of New York, Samuel J. Tilden, was the Democratic nominee, and won a plurality of about 250,000 popular votes; but his total of electoral votes was sufficiently disputed to force the creation by the Congress of special Electoral Commission, which proceeded to give the Presidency to Tilden's Republican rival, Gov. Rutherford B. Hayes of Ohio.

title: Kosygin Says Soviet Tops Western Economic Rivals
description: MOSCOW, March 1Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin asserted today that the Soviet Union had made important gains in its economic competition with capitalism.

title: Public Equity Stock Offering Halted for Lack of Interest
description: The stock offering for the Public Equity Corporation, a vehicle for consumer classaction suits against erring corporations, has been withdrawn for lack of interest.

title: Black Nationalists in Rhodesia Hail New Government Proposals
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 1 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Ian Smith today put forward new proposals in the Rhodesian constitutional talks that were hailed by the black nationalists as a near breakthrough.

title: Jobs Also Promised
description: PHOENIX, March 1 (AP)The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and its competitors made cash payoffs and promised postretirement jobs to United States Air Force colonels in a position to steer foreign military business their way, according to a former Lockheed official.

title: Evers College Officials Assail Proposed Changes as Racism
description: Some officers and faculty members of Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn charged yesterday that a planned reduction of its fouryear program to a twoyear community college sprang from institutional racism and economic class oppression.

title: A.T.&T. Leads Industry, A Regulated Monopoly
description: An attempt to sell a device supposedly capable of conveying the human voice over metallic wires resulted in the arrest of the seller here a century ago on charges of attempted extortion.

title: Stock Service Fees to Rise
description: Service charges are going up 2 per cent a month on stock quotation machines, effective April 1, the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday. The $40 monthly charge for the first such device in an office will rise to $41. Each additional device will rise to.$4.10 a month from $4, the exchange said. It attributed the increase to a need to help defray the operating costs of a new highspeed ticker tape.

title: Primacy of Patent Laid Foundations Of Vast Enterprise
description: Over the last century, few sounds have typified the modern age so much as the ringing of the telephone bell, an all but irresistible summons to instant communication.

title: ANHEUSER BUSCH HIT BY TEAMSTER STRIKE
description: ST. LOUIS (AP)About 8,000 workers at nine Anheuser Busch breweries across the country stayed off the job today, curtailing the production of Budweiser, Busch and Michelob beers.

title: FRANKLIN FLASCHNER
description: NEWTON, Mass., March 1 (UFI)Judge Franklin Flaschtier, chief justice of the Massachusetts district court system, died Saturday of a heart attack while vacationing near Key Biscayne, Fla. He, was VI years old and had been head of the state's 72 district courts since 1970.

title: Maple Leafs Top NOrth Stars, 4 to 2
description: TORONTO, March 1 (UPI) Errol Thompson's firstperiod, powerplay goal at 7:39. was the deciding factor as the. Toronto Maple Leafs fired 50 shots on goal and defeated the Minnesota North Stars, 42, tonight.

title: Jones Calls Mets LilyWhite Club
description: SARASOTA, Fla. March 1Cleon Jones, who was released by the New York Mets last summer, said today that the Mets had become a lilywhite baseball team with a racial problem.

title: AN EXI.R.S. OFFICIAL GUILTY OF BRIBERY
description: A Federal Court jury in Brooklyn yesterday ccnvicted Andrew Jackson, former chief collection officer of the Internal Revenue Service office on Long Island, of conspiracy and accepting bribes in return for favors to taxpayers.

title: Levittown Schools Plan 5Day Layoff
description: LEVITTOWN, L. I., March 1The Levittown School District, which has the highest tax rate in Nassau County, today announced a plan to furtough its 1,200 employees for five days without pay between April 15 and June 30, the end of the school year district in the state to announce a system of furloughs and layoffs to offset an expected budget deficit. The deficit is expected to range between $300,000 and $400,000, and the district is expecting a loss of between $650,000 and $1.2 million in state aid.

title: People in Sports
description: Mitch Kupchak, a 6foot10inch center from Brentwood, L. I., who led the North Carolina Tar Heels to first place during the Atlantic Coast Conference season, has been voted the league's outstanding player in a poll of A.C.C. sports writers.

title: LOCAL CARE URGED FOR MENTALLY ILL
description: ALBANY, March 1  State Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut and other Assembly leaders today called for a complete overhaul of the State Department of Mental Hygiene to shift the focus of mental health care from stateoperated institutions to centers operated by local governments and community groups.

title: Kickbacks Uncovered
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 1 (Reuters)The NCR Corporation announced today that executives in its overseas offices paid out between $300,000 and $500,000 in unauthorized payments to obtain orders between 1971 and 1975.

title: Stage: Arena Troupe Revives Heartbreak House
description: WASHINGTON  Of all Shaw's plays, Heartbreak House is the most telling the most remarkable, the one that comes nearest to equating miraculously the totally realist Shavian critic with the totally mythical Shavian man. It is the play about the death of a civilization. Oddly enough it has often been equated with Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard, but for no good reasonexcept perhaps that they both take place during the course of a summer night in a period of disillusion.

title: Ford Says In Time He Expects To Talk With Nixon on China
description: WASHINGTON, March 1President Ford said today that, in time he will probably talk to former President Richard M. Nixon about Mr. Nixon's journey to China.

title: A LOCKHEED AIDE DISAVOWS BRIBES
description: TOKYO, March 1The man ager of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's office in Japan publicly disagreed with his former superior today on the need to pay bribes to do business here.

Mr. Loening's marriage to the former Marko Truesdaks ended in divorce in MO. In 1947 she was married to A. Felix du Pont Jr. of Wilmington, Del., where they live.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Judge Thomas L. Yaccarino of Superior Court in Freehold refused to halt a vote scheduled for today on the Monmouth Regional High School's budget, rejecting arguments that Eatontown taxpayers would be forced to bear a higher cost per pppil under the state's thorough and efficient education law. Judge Yaccarino retained jurisdiction of the case, however, and will hear arguments April 13 on the constitutionality of a section of the law that requires regional school districts to assess costs on the ratable base of each member municivality rather than on a perpupil basis.

title: SIDNEY W. PELOUBET

title: Map of Vietnam Omits NorthSouth Border
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 1 (UPI)Authorities have issued a new, official map of Vietnam that eliminates the border between North and South for the first time in 22 years.

title: JERSEY BUS STRIKE IS PUT OFF AGAIN
description: NEWARK, March 1A strike by employees of Transport of New Jersey, the state's largest bus company, was put off today at least until after midnight Friday morning.

title: Republicans to Be Focus of Attention Of the Primary in Florida Next Week
description: MIAMI, March 1If tomorrow's Massachusetts primary election is largely a Democratic show, the one in Florida a week later will be largely a Republican one. It could make or break President Ford or his challenger, Ronald Reagan, the former Governor of California, although this week's guessing is that it will do neither.

title: RED FOX, 105, DIES; WROTE ON SIOUX
description: William Red Fox, the selfstyled Sioux chief whose memoirs recalling the 1876 Battle of Little Big Horn and the 1890 Massacre of Wounded Knee led to a major publishing controversy in 1972, died yesterday in Corpus Christi, Tex. He was 105 years old.

title: Ford Won 18 of 21 Delegates In Primary in New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N. H., March 1 (AP)Official vote tabulations from New Hampshire's Presidential primary last Tuesday I released today gave President Ford 18 of 21 Republican convention delegates. Ronald Reagan won the other three.

title: Head of Seaport Museum Resigns in Policy Dispute
description: Peter M. Stanford, one of the group who thought up the South Street Seaport Museum and brought it into existence: during the mid 1960's, resigned yesterday as president of the museum in a policy dispute. He had held the post since the maritime historical institution was incorporated in 1967.

title: 6 Food Spots Are Listed As Health Code Violators
description: The Health Department hasl released the names of six more food establishments charged with violating the city's Health Code. Seven other restaurants have had their second and final inspection. The establishments, and the results follow:

title: Senate at Impasse on New Criminal Code
description: WASHINGTON March 1An attempt by the Senate leadership to end the threeyeardeadlack over a controversial bill that would revise and reform the Federal criminal code has boomeranged and virtually killed any chance that Congress will pass the massive measure this year.

title: State House Officer Warns on Drug Sales
description: TRENTON, March 1 (UPI)  The head of police security at the State House said to day he would arrest anyone  whether a reporter or state officialwho was caught in a marijuana exchange.

title: Stage: Fugard and O'Casey Revivals
description: Revivals of two contemporary plays, Athol Fugard's The Blood Knot and Sean O'Casey's Cock  a  Doodle Dandy"each having something considerable to say about the ignobility of civilization"are brightening the Off Off Broadway landscape.

title: California Robber Colorful
description: LA JOLLA, Calif. (AP)One of the most colorfully dressed men in town made the most news recently. In yellow trousers, a green jacket and red face mask, he held up a Crocker National Bank branch and escaped with $10,000 in cash. The robber, with a companion, carried out the money in a black plastic bag and fled in a white compact car.

title: Government to Ban Medical Research On Federal Inmates
description: WASHINGTON, March 1Norman A. Carlson, director of the Bureau of Prisons, said today that his agency would prohibit future medical research on Federal prisoners.

title: Chess:
description: The 51st Hastings International Tournament ended this year in a triple tie for first prize among Wolfgang Uhlmann of East Germany, Vlastmil Hort of Czechoslovakia and David Bronstein of the Soviet Union.

title: Westchester Will Treat, Not Burn, Its Garbage
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 1Westchester County officials said today that they intended to close down all of the county's incinerators and handle garbage at two new treatment centers.

title: Massachusetts: A Voter Mosaic
description: BOSTON, March 1  A string trio played Mozart unnoticed and unheard in the cacophony of political talk as Massachusetts liberals, who seem to prefer to be called progressives these days, crowded together for an Americans for Democratic Action cocktail party Saturday night in a room in the Boston University Student Union.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Ford Administration will seek Congressional approval of a foreignaid bill of $7.8 billion$1 billion less than it proposes to spend in the current fiscal year, Administration officials, said yesterday. Detailed military and economic aid requests for the new fiscal year are being sent to Congress this week, they said. But no immediate action is expected because Congress has not yet completed legislative action on major portions of the foreignaid bills for the current fiscal year.

title: Bill Blass Evokes the
description: Bill lassent to China a few months ago, and naturally, it shows in his work. No Mao suits or anything as obvious as that. But lots of kimono coats (well, they're Eastern, aren't they?), choppedoff coolie pants, and an interesting white jumpsuit with a sailor collar which, he says, was adapted from the uniforms Chinese sailors wear.

description: There are thousands of old people living alone in New York City who spend most of their days in isolation as if nobody cares whether they live or die. description: WASHINGTON, March 1The General Accounting Office today reported that the New York metropolitan area had lost 53 defense contracts because of a Labor Department ruling that bars contracts to assemblers of parts, rather than manufacturers.

description: MIAMI, March 1They'll be voting in Massachusetts tomorrow and someone will come out on top, but the likelihood is that the primary voting there won't mean as much as it will here in Florida next week.

title: or Sinking It?
description: The United States and West Germany contributed to the Italian crisis by failing to live up to the pledge the industrial countries made to each other at the O.E.C.D. in 1974 not to engage in the beggarmyneighbor policy of seeking to export their petrodollar deficits. It was agreed that every country would carry its own increased oil costs or seek external financing or both. Instead, the United States and West Germany have run huge trade surpluses over the past two years.

title: COMET EXPECTED IN SKY FOR WEEK
description: From tomorrow until Sunday a comet that may prove one of the brightest in this decade is expected to reach maximum visibility in the eastern sky before sunrise.

This compares with a loss for the same period in 1974 of $1.4 million.

description: Francis T. Ward, an advisory director of Morgan Stanley & Company, investment bankers, and a former general partner, died Sunday in Locust Valley, L. I. He was 82 years old.

description: PASADENA, Calif., March 1 American and Soviet physicists have proposed a new space flight technique to verify the existence of the elusive gravitational waves and to use them as a means of probing the interiors of quasars and other explosive cosmic events.

description: After a weak start on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, stock prices moved up enough to post a gain of 0.04 since Friday, as measured by the Amex index, which closed at 103.41. A total of 378 stocks showed gains for the day while 368 had losses.

description: Sheila B. Kamerman's assertion that the number of children who are physically abused by their parents is small [letter Feb. 14] is not supported by existing data, notwithstanding the extent to which the alarming increase of cases may reflect broader definitions and better reporting.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 1Patricia Hearst's defense rested today after losing a fight to have the bank robbery charge against her dismissed on the assertion that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had suppressed photo evidence that tended to clear her.

title: Notes on People
description: Moving north from a Wall Street law firm to become United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, Robert B. Fiske Jr., a Republican, was sworn in yesterday to a jurisdiction that would include prosecution of any fraud charges that might arise from the continuing investigation of the city's sale of municipal bonds. The oath was administered by Judge David M. Edelstein, chief judge of the district. In the $39,000ayear post Mr. Fiske succeeds Thomas J. Cahill, interim United States Attorney since Paul J. Curran resigned Oct. 31.
