description: Governor Carey was installed as Grand Marshal of New York City's 214th annual St. Patrick's Day Parade at a ceremony last night at the Commodore Hotel before an audience of 1,000. The installation was presided over by Judge James J. Comerford, parade committee chairman for the event, which will take place two weeks from today, starting at noon from ??? Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: FORD TOPS REAGAN
description: BOSTON, Wednesday, Marcn 3Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington won the Massachusetts Democratic primary yesterday as voters went to the polls in relatively light numbers amid snow, sleet and cold.

title: Cost of Fishing Ban On Hudson Is Called Much Exaggerated
description: ALBANY, March 2John S. Dyson, the state's combative Commissioner of Commerce, renewed his running battle today with Ogden R. Reid, the Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, charging that Mr. Reid had overstated the financial loss of the closing last week of the. Hudson River to commercial fishing.

title: Dodgers Trade Crawford
description: LOS ANGELES, March 2 (AP)The Los Angeles Dodgers traded Willie Crawford, an outfielder, to the St. Louis Cardinals today for Ted Sizemore, an infielder. Crawford had been with the Dodgers since 1964. The trade brings Sizemore back to Los Angeles, where he broke into the majors as a second baseman in 1969, the year he won rookieoftheyear honors.

title: Seals Miss Tie On Wild Shot
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 2 Hand on hip and ice bag on hand, Bob Nystrom of the Islanders was paying in pain tonight for the blows he had struck against the California Seals in inspiring New York to a 21 victory at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Open Interest
description: (In bushels, 000 emitted) Mon.

title: Budget Uncertainty Is Issue in School Board Elections
description: TRENTON, March 2In an atmosphere of confusion and uncertainty, voters in the state's 64 regional school districts went to the polls today to elect new boards and register their opinions on proposed 1976 77 budgets. Next Tuesday, voters in the 483 municipal and single township school districts will cast their ballots on the same issues.

title: In the U.N. Today The Proceedings
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: House Panel Votes Delegation Of Grain Inspections to States
description: WASHINGTON. March 2The House Agriculture Committee reversed itself again today and amended a provision of a grain reform bill that would have required Federal inspection and grading of all export shipments.

title: Undefeated Rutgers Helps Jersey Forget Its Worries
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 2  New Jerseyans were diveited today from rising prices, tax problems and crime statistics; they had an allwinning basketball team, which ended its regular season last night with a 260 wonlost record.

title: Frank Ellis, 71, Provided Ski Information for Millions
description: TORRINGTON, Conn., Mar. 2 (AP)Frank Ellis, who told millions of people each year what skiing conditions were like throughout the country, died last night at Charlotte Hbngerford hospital. He was 71 years old.

title: On 36c a Day, Rural Indian Thinks Crops, Not Politics
description: BAZIDPUR, India, Feb. 25 Roop Narain Shanti, a sinewy barechested villager who earns 36 cents a day plus one meal by tilling other people's fields, was surprised today to learn of the Government's suspension of civil liberties eight months ago.

title: Challenge Ahead for Rutgers
description: Minutes after Rutgers's 8580 victory over St. Bonaventure Monday night, Gov. Byrne of New Jersey had a prodlamation distributed declaring March Rutgers University Month in the Garden State. Maybe that should be changed to Rutgers University's Most Difficult Month.

title: It Was June in February And Busting Out All Over
description: The roughwinged swallow has been seen in Cold Spring Harbor, Forster's tern is back at Fire Island, and the Chardonnay grape vines are budding in vineyards near Newburgh. Spring has not just arrived, it has barged in unannounced.

title: 7:30 TV Game Shows Losing to Comedy and Music
description: Ever since the primetime access rule went into effect in 1971 barring the networks from using the half hour front 7:30 to 8 P.M., most television stations have taken what broacasters themselves concede to be the path of least resistance: They have largelygiven over the time to syndicated game shows and wildlife series, lowbudget programs that can be depended on for adequate ratings.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, March 2, 1976 Petition filed by:

title: Books of The Times
description: For some people, death comes discreetly. They die quickly, painlessly, perhaps in their sleep, with little previous suffering. For some it comes agonizingly, and the drama is mostly physical. Then there are those like Gramp, the hero of this book, who relinquish body and soul bit by bit, who go through a series of strategic retreats, understood only by themselves, until the contest no longer interests them.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The New York Times/March 3, 1976

title: Secret U.S. Pacts Reported by Sadat
description: WASHINGTON, March 2President Anwar elSadat of Egypt claims that as part of last September's Sinai accord with Israel he concluded secret agreements in which the United States pledged that Israel would not attack Syria and that every effort would be made to insure Palestinian participation in a Middle East settlement.

title: 2 Concerns in Coal Study
description: The Houston Natural Gas Company and Rio Grande Industries announced yesterday formation of a working committee to study the economics and feasibility of forming a jointly owned company to build and operate a slurry pipeline project to move coal from the Rocky Mountains to the Texas Gulf coast. Several utility and natural resource companies have voiced interest in developing slurry pipelines to move Western coal to other sections of teh nation because of coal's cheap price.

title: Wisconsin Primary Ballot
description: MADISON, Wis., March 2 (AP)Backers of Ellen McCormack furnished enough signatures to put the Long Island woman's name on Wisconsin's April 6 Democratic Presidential primary ballot, the State Elections Board said today.

title: State's Criminal Records Criticized as Inadequate
description: Representatives from agencies in the city's criminaljustice system yesterday assailed as inadequate the way the state keeps its computerized criminal records. The criticisms were made at a hearing, held by the State Division of Criminal Justice Services, on proposed rules that would limit access to these files.

title: U.S. Denies Role in Shooting At Soviet Riverdale Site
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 2The United States denied today a Soviet allegation that there was connivance by American authorities in a shooting incident last Friday at the Soviet delegation residence in Riverdale. The incident resulted in some property damage but no injuries.

title: Bullets Defeat 76ers
description: LANDOVER, Md., March 2 (AP)Dave Bing scored 25 points and handed off a seasonhigh 16 assists in leading the Washington Bullets to a 128111 National Basketball Association victory over the Philadelphia 76ers tonight.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Tuesday.

title: Carter and Ford Victors In the Vermont Primaries
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., March 2 Jimmy Carter won Vermont's nonbinding Presidential primary among Democrats today, while President Ford swept Republican voting, unopposed ex cept by writein votes for Ronald Reagan, the conservative challenger who did not put his name on the ballot here.

title: Key Legislators Told of Desire to Let Cairo Purchase C130's
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The Ford Administration has informed key members of Congress in the last 48 hours that to encourage Egypt on a moderate path it would like to lift the longstanding embargo on mlitary sales, beginning by selling six C130 military transport planes to Cairo.

title: Split in Board Is Reported On New City U. Entry Plan
description: The governing board of the City University is split over whether the new admissions standards urged by the chancel for should replace the eighth grade reading requirement it has adopted or should be imposed in addition to it, a board member said yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Milk Support Raised
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI)  Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz announced today a 3.5 cent a gallon increase in Government milk price supports effective April 1.

title: SAMUEL ESTRIN
description: Samuel Estrin, secretary for international affairs of the Jewish Labor Committee for 30 years until he retired in 1970, died Tuesday at his home at 315 Eighth Avenue. He was 82 years old.

title: Strong Organization Held Key to Jackson's Victory
description: BOSTON, March 3In Massachusettsa state where a voter's politics can largely be calibrated by addressSenator Henry M. Jackson won his primary victory yesterday through strong organization work and appeal among elements of the traditional wing of the Democratic Party.

title: The 71 Center Who Doesn't Exist
description: In the computer that compiles National Collegiate basketball statistics, it's as if Robert Parish does not exist.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND COUNTER DIP
description: Stocks on the American Stock Exchange moved down yesterday with the index showing a loss of 0.23 to close at 103.74. Trading volume dropped to 3,931,000 from 4,352,000 share the preceding day.

title: Rev. John Swift, 92, Dies; Oldest Maryknoll Priest
description: The Rev. John F. Swift, the oldest priest in Maryknoll's hisory, died Tuesday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North, Tarrytown, N.Y., after suffering a stroke. He was 92 years old and lived at St. Teresa's Residence in Maryknoll, N.Y.

title: Container Plan Barred
description: The Board of Education yesterday rejected a proposal offered last Thursday as an aid in raising money to help the New York City public school's athletic programs.

title: Grenada Provides Safe Harbor
description: Elmer Eugene Zeek has very likely paid off the authorities for protection in Grenada, according to sources familiar with the Caribbean island's turbulent political climate.

title: ITALIAN SOCIALIST BARS RED TIE NOW
description: De ROME, Maich 3Francesco De Martino, Italy's Socialist leader, said today that for the present his party would not go into alliance with the Communists but would work instead for new relations with the dominant Christian Democrats.

title: Ford Orders a Reduction In Government Red Tape
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) President Ford disclosed today that he has ordered Federal agencies to cut back by July 1 on the tangle of Government red tape demanded of Americans each year.

title: House Votes Wide Powers For Inquiry on Spy Report
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The House investigation into the leaking of the Pike committee's intelligence report gained momentum today as representatives voted overwhelmingly to broaden the subpoena powers that will be used during the inquiry.

title: Dance: A Spicy Carmen
description: Carmen and Jose, a ballet by Ruth Page, is probably the only version in which Georges Bizet's heroine dies with her leg extended to the slide a la seconde.

title: Police Powers Limited
description: TRENTON, March 3 (AP)A state appeals cour ruled today that the police of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey cannot exercise their police powers off authority property. It upheld a lower court's dismissal of drug charges authority police made against a man they arrested in a Fort Lee garage.

title: Two Are Killed in Basque City As Police Battle Demonstrators
description: MADRID, March 3Two persons were killed and 15 wounded today in the Basque city of Vitoria when the police opened fire on demonstrators.

title: Notes on People
description: Julius Rudel, director of the New York City Opera, is programmed for 16 transAtlantic flights by Aug. 1 in order to conduct here, in Paris and Vienna. Ten of the flights have been scheduled during the current City Opera season, which ends April 25, and the tightest timetable of all is this weekend, with three operas on two contiwithin 48 hours: La Forza del Destino Friday evening at the Paris Opera, Turandot Saturday evening at the New York City Opera and Die Meistersinger at the City Opera's Sunday matinee. When Mr. Rudel made the European commitments he was slated for a sabbatical from his duties here but he was dissuaded by the board of the City Opera.

title: China's Press Bids People Join in Drive Against Teng
description: PEKING, March 3 (Agence FrancePresse)  The official Chinese press today called for the mobilization of the masses in the nationwide campaign of criticisms aimed at the senior Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping.

title: An Actuarial Study Finds Mayor's Job Debilitating
description: Mayors of New York, regardless of party and particularly in the last century, died younger than men who were not Mayors, men like City Council Presidents, Borough Presidents and Comptrollers.

title: Bank to Lend $5 Million In Home Mortgages at 8%
description: The Provident Savings Bank, the thirdlargest savings bank in New Jersey, announced yesterday that it would make $5 million available for home mortgage loans at a reduced interest rate of 8 percent.

title: Trenton Proposes $10,000 Sweetener In IncomeTax Plan
description: TRENTON, March 3A proposal to grant homeowners a propertytax exemption on the first $10,000 value of their homes, with an exemption on the first $15,000 value in the case of the elderly, was put before the Assembly today.

title: Massachusetts Poll Hints Deep Democratic Rifts
description: Indications of some basicand potentially damagingdivisions among Democratic voters on the emotional issues of race, social policy and foreign, affairs emerge from the latest New York Times/CBS News survey of primary voters.

title: Massachusetts Primary
description: In the Massachusetts Democratic primary, the busing controversy became the catalyst through which many voters perceived a similarity in various dissimilar discontents.

title: BIGGEST ALLOCATION IS GOING TO JACKSON
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) Fresh from his primary election victory in Massachusetts, Senator Henry M. Jackson received a healthy infusion for his campaign treasury today when the Federal Election Commission certified him for $495,071 in Federal matching funds.

title: Chess
description: Vlastimil Hort recently told me: The idea these days for winning against toplevel competition is to use the secondbest moves in the openings. Everyone studies the best continuation to death, so there is no percentage in playing it, but the secondbest is neglected enough to be valuable.

title: EXPARK OFFICIAL ON L.I. IS INDICTED
description: A former high official of the Long Island State Parks and Recreation Commission was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on charges of extorting more than $30,000 from five towing companies in exchange for giving them franchises.

title: House Passes Foreign Aid Authorization Bill for $4.8 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The House tonight approved a controversial $4.8 billion foreign aid authorization bill that included funds to carry out the Middle East peace accords negotiated last year by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

title: SIMON GIVES ISRAEL VOW ON TRADE AID
description: TEL AVIV, March 3Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon pledged today that the United States would help Israeli businessmen find American investors and customers.

title: Hearst Counsel Bid Court Exclude Tania Interview
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 3The arrest of William and Emily Harris on a San Francisco street by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was recounted in Fderal District Court today as Patricia Hearst's defense sought to exclude from the evidence against her material that was taken from they Harris apartment.

title: PRICES OF BONDS IN MIXED PATTERN
description: After the sharp moves in bond prices and yields late last week and early this week, the credit markets simmered down yesterday. Most bond prices moved upward early in the day and sales of newly offered bond issues perked up, but the advance gave way in the afternoon. At the close, fixedincome security prices showed no overall trend. Treasury notes were down slightly, Treasury bonds were up slightly and corporate bonds and notes posted a mixture of gains and losses. The advance in corporate bond prices early in the day apparently was a reaction to the market's swift shift toward higher interest rates that raised the yield on the Aaarated Texas Electric Service Company bonds marketed Tuesday to 8.75 percent, 41 basis points above the original yield on New Jersey Bell Telephone Company debentures offered for sale Feb. 24.

title: House Votes Wide Powers For Inquiry on Spy Report
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The House investigation into the leaking of the Pike committee's intelligence report gained momentum today as representatives voted overwhelmingly to broaden the subpoena powers that will be used during the inquiry.

title: U.S. Wants Spain Ties Parallel To Those With NATO Nations
description: WASHINGTON, March 3A highranking State Department official told the Senate today that the Ford Administration's new treaty with Spain on military bases was designed to develop a relationship with Madrid comparable to that with NATO members.

title: Distribution of Ashes Marks Beginning of Lent
description: Lent, the penitential prelude to Easter, began yesterday as ashes were placed on the foreheads of the faithful in many Christian churches.

title: P.U.C., Stirred by Outcry, To Audit Utilities Charges
description: TRENTON, March 3Reacting to the growing protest about the cost of gas and electricity, the Board of Public Utility Commissioners announced today that it would make special audits to make certain that consumers were not being cheated.

title: PRIMARY IN STATE GAINS A NEW ROLF
description: The New York Presidential primary next month wilt provide a major test of strength between Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington and Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona after their one, two finish in Massachusetts.

title: Baseball Talks Crumbling Fast
description: The cautious optimism that had seeped out of the baseball negotiations earlier in the week crumbled before hardened positions yesterday.

title: Answers by Miss Hearst in Lie Tests Are Questioned by Former Hogan Aide
description: Nat Laurendi, a retired New York City detective who was District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's liedetector expert, said here yesterday that in his opinion there were indications', of deception in answers Patricia Hearst gave in polygraph tests.

title: HOSPITALS CUTS STIR IF DEBATE
description: The effect of the financial crisis on the city's municipal hospitals was hotly disputed at a hearing held yesterday by the City Council's Health Committee.

title: 3 IN SUIT SAY DRUG PRODUCED CANCER
description: Complaining that they had developed cancer of the cervix because their mothers had taken DES, a drug widely used to prevent miscarriage, three Long Island residents filed $100 million in damage suits and a $1 billion class action for punitive damages in State Supreme Court yesterday against a score of major pharmaceutical companies and five physicians.

title: Security Panel Gets Funds
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) The Senate approved without debate today continued funding of its Internal Security subcommittee. The subcommittee was authorized to spend $195,. 300 in the year ahead, $100,000 less than it requested, for investigations of subversive activities.

title: MICHAEL PARRINO, 61, BRONX LAWYER, DIES
description: Michael F. Parrino, a lawyer who, as an Army major became an authority on mule skinning or drivingdied Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, in his car on a Bronx street. He was 61 years old and lived at 277 Bronx River Road in Yonkers.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: SCOTTO TO HEAD STATE LABOR UNIT
description: ALBANY, March 3Anthony M. Scotto today was named chairman of the advisory committee of the state A.F.L.C.1.0.'s expanded Committee on Political Education, a position that will add to his already substantial political influence in the state.

title: West Virginia Blast In a Jail Cell Kills Couple and 2 Police
description: POINT PLEASANT, W. Va., March 3 (UPI)A young man burst into the Mason County jail last night and later touched off a suitcase of dynamite in a cell, killing himself, his wife, the county sheriff and one of his deputies.

title: Lou Polan, Broadway Actor In Over 50 Plays, Is Dead
description: Lou Polan, a veteran Broadway actor, died yesterday in Freeport, Me., while on a mor toring trip. He was 71 years old and lived at 45 West 69th Street.

title: SCHEUER ACCEDES ON POLLUTION BILL
description: Representative James K. Scheuer of the Bronx, at the request of the Beame administration, yesterday dropped a plan to introduce legislation calling for a fiveyear freeze on autopollution standards.

title: House Passes Foreign Aid Authorization Bill for $4.8 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The House tonight approved a controversial $4.8 billion foreign aid authorization bill that included funds to carry out the Middle East peace accords negotiated last year by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Forward, With Fidel, Anywhere
description: GLENELG, Australia  History was trying to repeat itself in the handling Of the Angolan case by the Ford Administration. This time the tactic could not work, because 1976 is not 1962. In the missile crisis, John F. Kennedy and Nikita S. Khrushchev negoliated on the line of an axisWashingtonMoscowand as if Havana were out of this world.

title: Baseball's Silent Spring Muffles Florida Tourist Season Boom
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3The heaviest tourist season in history was crowding Florida's hotels, highways and beaches today, but the state's No.1 industry fun in the sunwas losing more than a million dollars a day because baseball training camps were still closed.

title: Mrs. Peron Seeks Backing Of Labor for Economic Plan
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 3A new plan to salvage Argentina's economy from inflation and debt was presented for approval today by Minister of Economy Emilio Mondelli to the top Peronist labor leaders.

title: REAGAN TO PRESS ATTACKS ON FORD
description: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif., March 3Ronald Reagan will return to the Florida campaign trail tomorrow, prepared to intensify his attacks on the Ford! Administration as he enters what his strategists agree is the most critical phase of his challenge to President Ford.

title: Schoolboy Vaults 15 Feet 41/4 Inches
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., March 3  Lance Arietta of Tappan Zee broke his New York State indoor record in the pole vault tonight when he cleared 15 feet 4 inches in the Section 9 public high schools track and field championships. The first three finishers in each event tonight qualified for the state finals in Ithaca March 13. Arietta made his record vault on his third and final attempt. The 5foot7inch, 145pound senior had set the mark of 153 earlier this season.

title: CITY, BLUE CROSS SETTLE CONTRACT
description: A year long dispute between the city and Blue Cross of Greater New York over a master contract for hospital insurance covering a million people municipal employees, their dependents and retired workers was settled yesterday.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS BILL TO END SECRECY
description: WASHINGTON. March 3 (UPI)  A House committee, has approved a bill designed to end Government secrecy except in the most sensitive security cases.

title: Freezing Temperatures Tarn Drizzle to Sleet
description: A slight drizzle turned to sleet yesterday morning as temperatures dropped below the freezing point for the first time in nine days. Slippery roads caused traffic jams and a rash of accidents throughout the metropolitan area.

title: TRIAL QUESTIONS ON RACE CURBED
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The Supreme Court ruled today that blacks facing state charges of crimes against whites do not generally have the right to have prospective jurors questioned about their possible racial prejudice.

title: Houston Is Playing at Wild West Again
description: HOUSTON, March 3Once a year, Houston takes off its space helmet, puts its oil deals on hold, unleashes a thundering herd of superlatives and plays cowboy for two weeks.

title: Massachusetts Poll Hints Deep Democratic Rifts
description: Indications of some basicand potentially damagingdivisions among Democratic voters on the emotional issues of race, social policy and foreign affairs emerge from the latest New York Times/CBS News survey of primary voters.

title: Business Briefs
description: Merrill Lynch & Company amiounced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Tax Corporation of America, a preparer of individual tax returns, for Merrill Lynch shares worth about $4 million. The agreement calls for the exchange of one share of Merrill Lynch common for every 30 shares of Tax Corporation. Tax Corporation is the nation's second largest company after H. and R. Block in preparation of tax returns. It reported revenues of $10.3 million in the year ended April 30, 1975.

title: Canucks Tie Rangers, 33, on Blight's Late Goal
N.X.U. Student Is Arrested In Arson At Dormitory
description: A sophomore who lives in then Weinstein Dormitory at New York University has been arrested for allegedly setting a fire there last Jan. 18.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Prison Leaves to Resume Under Stricter Controls
description: TRENTON, March 3  The state's prison furlough program will be resumed on March 20, but under much tighter controls than in the past, Governor Byrne said today.

title: CocaCola Sets Earnings Records for the 4th Quarter and Year
CORRECTION
description: In an article in The New York Times yesterday it was stated incorrectly that the city's new Human Resources Administrator, Henry Smith, would receive a Frederick Douglass Award from the Urban Coalition at a dinner May 6, The award will be given by the New York Urban League.

title: Bill to Put State Lottery Under Tax Agency Stalls
description: ALBANY, March 3An Assembly bill that would place the problemplagued state lottery under the State Department of Taxation and Finance appeared temporarily stalled by the introduction of a vastly different proposal in the Republicancontrolled Senate.

title: 30 Uruguayans Said to Find Refuge in Mexican Embassy
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 3 (AP)  At least 30 Uruguayans have taken asylum in the Mexican Embassy to escape an increasingly severe Government crackdown on leftists, political sources said today. They said that hundreds, perhaps thousands, of other leftists had been jailed.

title: Canarsie Title Hopes Resting With Ladson
description: He may not be the highest scorer or the flashiest performer when Canarsie and Lafayette play Saturday for the Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship, but Ty Ladson will probably be the most important player. The 6footlinch Canarsie senior will handle the ball against a pressing defense, he will take the jump shots to break a zone defense and he will be the leader his teammates will look to as they go for a perfect season of 24 victories.

title: Two Nations at a Glance
description: POPULATION  Mozambique's nine million people are mostly black, with those in the south heavily influenced by Portuguese culture and language. There are Roman Catholic, Islamic and Protestant converts among them. Europeans, Asians and those of mixed ancestry represent about 2 percent of the population, but emigration since Mozambique attained independence makes the figure uncertain.

title: Bethlehem Steel Corp. Studying Allowances on Container Stock
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has notified its customers that it intends to bo competitive with other steelmakers in offering developmental incentive allowances for beer and beverage container stock.

title: GOODYEAR ADMITS PAYMENTS ABROAD
description: AKRON. Ohio, March 3 (UPI) The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company paid at least $845,000 to foreign governments over a sixyear period dating to 1970, according to documents filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: With Thai Elections a Month Off, the Violence Mounts
description: BANGKOK, March 3Just a month remains before Thailand's second national election in little more than a year and the campaign has been marked by assassinations and extreme political rhetoric from left to right.

title: The Gypsies Come to Madison and 86th
description: Madison Avenue at 86th Street has long been surrounded by boutiques, art galleries and bookstores, and by penthouse apartments renting for as much as $2,000. a month. Now that sedate corner of the Upper East Side has something newstorefront gypsies.

title: LOCKHEED ALTERS OVERSEAS SELLING
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday from Burbank, Calif., that all of its international marketing activities, including the operations of the company's overseas offices, would be directed from the home office, effective immediately.

title: Negro Ensemble Stages Eden, a Black Hester Street
Personal Finance: Dividend Investment Plans
description: The recent renewed interest in the stock market has also renewed interest in dividentd investment plansdeveloped almost a decade ago to intensify ties of stockholders with corporations.

title: Coop Residents Prepay Taxes to Help the City
description: The residents of Penn South Houses yesterday joined the list of those helping the city by paying their realestate taxes earlybut with an altruistic distinction.

title: Houston Is Playing at Wild West Again
description: HOUSTON, March 3Once a year, Houston takes off its space helmet, puts its oil deals on hold, unleashes a thundering herd of superlatives and plays cowboy for two weeks.

title: Prague Bars a Dissident
description: PRAGUE, March 3 (Reuters) A dissident Czechoslovak playwright, Vaclav Havel, said today that he had been refused permission to go to Italy for a first night of one of his plays.

title: Senate Panel Likely to Urge Strong Curbs on Domestic Spying
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The draft of the final report of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence will contain strongly worded recommendations to control the domestic intelligence activities of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the electronic eavesdropping capabilities of the National Security Agency, Congressional sources familiar with the draft said today.

title: Hanson Is Seeking the Shares of Hygrade
description: Hanson Industries, the United States subsidiary of Hanson Trust Ltd. of Britain, announced yesterday that it would proceed with its plan to acquire any and all shares of the Hygrade Food Products Corporation that it does not already own for $30 a share. Hanson, which owns 48 percent of all Hygrade shares, said it that would seek the remaining 52 percent of Hygrade's shares, or a total of about 500,000 shares. Hanson Industries said that a commission of 60 cents a share for each share purchased would he paid to the soliciting dealers. The company said if considered it would be entitled to Hygrade's 25centashare quarterly dividend, which is payable April 9 to holders of record March 26. For shares tendered after March 17, which are not transferred to Hygrade's books by March 26, Hanson will deduct the amount of the dividend from the net price payable.

title: LOCKHEED AFFAIR ROCKS MARUBENI
description: TOKYO, March 3 (AP)A big Japanese trading company trying to repair an image hurt by the Lockheed payoffs scandal shuffled its top executives today and said it would not do any new business with Lockheed.

title: Inside Church's Bunker
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The atmosphere in Senator Frank Church's intelligence subcommittee is that of a bunker under siege. Senators and staffers furtively dart about, clutching parts of the forthcoming threevolume report to their palpitating bosoms, worried lest leaks make the Senate appear as unable to keep secrets as the House.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article in The New York Times yesterday it was stated incorrectly that the city's new Human Resources Administrator, Henry Smith, would receive a Frederick Douglass Award from the Urban Coalition at a dinner May 6. The award will be given by the New York Urban League.

title: Aware Mayor
description: It is good to learn from City Hall that Mayor Beame does indeed recognize the urgent need for reform of the city's unworkable rentcontrol program. In an editorial yesterday, we took as evidence of mayoral complacency on this issue Mr. Beame's recommendation last weekend that the City Council extend the existing rentcontrol law without change.

title: Jackson's Victory Spurs Lagging Florida Campaign
description: MIAMI, March 3Senator Henry M. Jackson's plurality in the Massachusetts Presidential primary yesterday has strengthened his lagging Florida campaign.

title: A New Look at Chicago Architecture
description: Chicago is generally considered a place of extraordinary architectural singlemindednessa city in which one stream of development dominated all. This stream was expressed in skyscrapers; it began with the Chicago School of Louis Sullivan, John Wellborn Root and others, moved on into the Mies van der Rohe era of steel and glass and continues today in the work of such firms as Skidmore, Owings & Merrill.

title: Spain After Franco Is Torn by Disorder He Fought
description: MADRID, March 3  Three months after the death of Francisco Franco, who prided himself on 40 years of peace and order, Spain is a disputatious country that is full of grievances and has quickly shed its inhibitions about expressing them.

title: Advertising
description: Back in 1969 after a year as president of Compton Advertising, Milton Gossett admitted that the image of the agency was summed up by the words square, dull and gray. These days the recently named chief executive is convinced that square means good.

title: On East Side, Fortune May Be Found in Cards
description: I can see that you are a strong woman with a streak of stubbornness, said the young woman, deftly laying out a pack of tarots. You could love the right one deeply, but your mind and heart work separately. Your life has not been easy. Other people have troublesyou have tragedies.

title: REAGAN TO PRESS ATTACKS ON FORD
description: PACIFIC PALISADES; Calif., March 3Ronald Reagan will return to the Florida campaign trail tomorrow, prepared to intensify his attacks on the Ford Administration as he enters what his strategists agree is the most critical phase of his challenge to President Ford.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Fingerprints found on the scenes where two Bergen County women had been murdered have led to the arrest of a 16yearold Englewood youth, according to authorities. Joseph C. Woodcock Jr., the Bergen County Prosecutor, said the youth arrested at his home had been charged with the murders in their homes of 36yearold Mrs. Ellen Bindman last June and 62yearold Gwen Esther Perren on Feb. 11. Four sexual assaults were also charged to the teenager, who's name was not made public because of his youth. Mr. Woodcock said he had no previous arrest record.

title: Connally Scores Congress For Political Ambition
description: LONGVIEW, Tex., March 3 (UPI)Former Texas John M. Connally says the cue. rent Congress is the worst ?? has ever seen because members put their political ambitions first.

title: In Memoriam
description: LIEBERMANAlbert, born March 4th. Dearest Daddy, I will always cherish you.

title: PRIMARY IN STATE GAINS A NEW ROLE
description: The New York Presidential primary next month will provide a major test of strength between Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington and Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona after their one, two finish in Massachusetts.

title: Merger Stress Out For Savings Units
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The Federal Home Loan Bank Board formally abandoned today a policy of encouraging mergers of savings and loan associations and at the same time made it more difficult for industry executives to profit personally from such transactions.

title: Soviet Pair Keeps Title In Skating
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, March 3 (AP)Irina Rodnina, the Soviet Union's first lady of figure skating, and her partner, Aleksandr Zaitsev, won their fourth world pairs title today.

description: (Reports are supplied by resort owners.)

title: Frederick Tetens Is Dead; AntiNazi Author Was 77
description: Frederick T.H. Tetens, author and critic of Nazi Germany, died Sunday at Englewood Hospital in New Jersey. He was 77 years old and lived in Hackensack, N. J.

title: KISSINGER PHONED NIXON ABOUT TRIP
description: WASHINGTON, March 3Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, acting without the knowledge or prior approval of President Ford, spoke to former President Richard M. Nixon by telephone on Monday to arrange for a written report on Mr. Nixon's trip to China, the White House disclosed today.

title: Police Study a Gang Link in Shooting of 4 in Queens
description: Three rival street gangs were cited by the police in Queens yesterday as possibly having been involved in the shooting of four men Tuesday night in the crowded lobby of a public school in Springfield Gardens.

title: Exemption Doubled on New State Tax
description: The elderly in New Jersey and others living on fixed incomes who had waged a vigorous fight to have the new state unearned income tax amended received some good news yesterday.

title: Distribution of Ashes Marks Start of Lent
description: Lent, the penitential prelude to Easter, began yesterday as ashes were placed on the foreheads of the faithful in many Christian churches.

title: S.E.C. Chief Refuses to Take a Position On Public Disclosure at Bribe Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 Roderick M. Hills, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission resisted efforts at a Congressional hearing today to force him to take a position on public disclosure of the names of recipients of bribes paid by American companies overseas, including bribes paid by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Effort to Draft New Constitution For Ulster PowerSharing Ends
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 3Efforts to draft a new constitution for Northern Ireland to allow participation in government by the Roman Catholic minority ended in apparent failure tonight, and it appeared that direct rule from London would continue for some time.

title: Schwartz Appears Headed for Defeat As Correction Chief
description: ALBANY, March 3  The State Senate Committee on Crime and Correction, deadlocked 6 to 6 on the confirmation of Herman Schwartz as chairman of the State Commission of Correction, forwarded his name today without recommendation to the Senate Finance Committee.

title: Iranian Assails Unethical Foreign Concerns
description: TEHERAN, Iran. March 3Iran's Prime Minister, addressing a group of United States financial leaders today, denounced unethical foreign companies for exporting a lack of morality to Iran.

title: Bishops Ask Catholics to Pray On Behalf of the Jews in Syria
description: The United States Catholic Bishops' Conference has for the first time asked parishes across the nation to offer prayers on behalf of Jews living in difficult circumstances.

title: Books of The Times
description: It's certainly no surprise that Robertson Davies has produced, in World of Wonders, yet a third novel in the series that began with Fifth Business and The Manticore. After all, the seductive charms of the first two novels have helped to focus international attention on the distinguished Canadian man of letters who in his time has been an actor, a playwright, a newspaper editor, a book reviewer, and a literary critic, and who has fashioned some 26 published volumes from his various writings. And the first two novels in the trilogy left many mysteries still to be cleared upespecially the ones surrounding that pink granite stone that is found in the mouth of the Canadian business tycon Boy Staunton after he has died in an automobile accident at the end of Fifth Business.

title: Barrera Family Welcomes New Name to Stakes Class
description: Laz Berrera tried all could do to keep him out of the business, but Albert Barrera wouldn't listen to his father. Instead, the 21yearold son of one of the leading trainers in the country set up a stable here this winter. And yesterday at Aqueduct, with his father proudly watching, Al Barrera saddled the first stakes winner of his twomonth career, a 3yearold filly whose breeding does not appear as fine as her trainer's. Though Elsie, a New Yorkbred daughter of Sky Wonder who began her racing career a week after Al Barrera started; his, scored a 2length victory in the $39,350 Cicada

title: French Film Show to Start Today at Modern Museum
description: A program of 12 new French feature as well as two collections of French short subjects will start today and continue through March 27 at the Museum of Modern Art.

description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 3Mozambique closed its borders and cut all links with Rhodesia today and mobilized for defense against what it asserts is aggression from Rhodesia.

title: In Patna, Once Center of Indian Opposition, Authoriterian Quiet Prevails
description: PATNA, India, Feb. 27Brilliant red bougainvillaea vines still arch across the terrace where Jaya Prakash Narayan loved to stroll, but his office is padlocked now, and inside it the mementos of a lifetime of opposition are gathering dust.

title: Israel's founding mothers look at kibbutz women today with resignation and disillusionment. For there is a return to domesticity, and the kibbutz women seem to want it that way.
description: KIBBUTZ HAREL, IsraelKibbutz women aren't interested in equality, they're interested in children. The speaker was 22yearold Ilana Dorfman, a kibbutz woman herself, who lives in the small and strugging settlement of Kibbutz Harel, in the foothills of the Judean mountains.

title: Scranton Is Confirmed By Senate in U.N. Post
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (Reuters)The Senate today confirmed William W. Scranton as chief delegate to the United Nations, Robert StrauszHupo as representative at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and Edward W. Mulcahy as Ambassador to Tunisia.

title: Liberal Strategy
description: While the Republican voting in Massachusetts followed a familiar local pattern, the Democratic race was remarkably scrambled. President Ford carried nearly twothirds of the vote while former Governor Reagan won more than onethird, which is the same division that has normally prevailed in past state G.O.P. primary races between the predominant progressivetomoderate faction and the reactionary minority faction. But the crowded field of Democrats trampled across the usual categories that analysts employ to understand an electorate's behavior.

title: John Jay College Cites Special Tasks In Countering Plan for Closing School
description: So you think New York has a future, then? the older man said to the younger. That's nice to hear. Because I see it getting worse and worse. I guess I'm just too close to it.

title: At Viking Control, the First Landings on Mars Are Being Experiencedin Simulation
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 2Their spacecraft are still millions of miles from Mars, cruising quietly in the cold, black interplanetary medium, but Viking Project engineers and scientists keep getting the strange feeling that they have already done it allthe orbiting of Mars and the landing, photographing the Martian surface and sampling the soil in search of life.

title: The IDA Disgrace
description: Representative Otto Passman of Louisiana, who has made a career of hacking up foreignaid measures, is in the process of making a senseless cut which will embarrass the United States and cause acute pain overseas.

description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) Senator Henry Jackson, Democrat of Washington, today sent a cablegram to President Tito of Yugoslavia urging that Mihajlo Mihajlov, the dissident writer, be released from prison.

title: Voters in 46 Districts Reject School Budgets
description: Voters in 46 of 64 regional school districts in New Jersey rejected their school budgets. Tuesday, according to figures compiled yesterday by the New Jersey School Boards Association.

title: EARL H. LUNDIN, 74, ARCHITECT, DEAD
description: Earl H. Lundin, an architect who designed a number of prominent midtown buildings, died Monday in Naples, Fla. He was 74 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Music: Pianistic Strength
description: There was nothing minor or insubstantial about. Ena Bronstein's recital program at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night. Miss Bronstein, who was born in Chile and now is on the piano faculty of California State University at Fresno, announced her serious intentions by offering Beethoven's 15 Variations and Fugue (Op. 35), the Brahms Sonata in F sharp minor (Op. 2) and Chopin's 24 Preludes (Op. 28). Not many breathers there, except for a famous few moments during the Chopin, that all amateurs bang away at.

title: John B. Armstrong Dead; Bookseller Here 20 Years
description: John Byron Armstrong, a wellknown bookseller for more than 20 years, died Sunday of cancer at Bellevue Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 308 East 38th Street and Davis Park. Fire Island. N.Y.

title: Ending of Jobless Pay for Strikers Urged

title: Criticism at the Soviet/ Party Congress Is Limited to the Economy

The strict norms of political behavior, that control and channel criticism have been on display for nine days as the 25th party congress, meeting in the Kremlin, has heard speaker after speaker address the successes and problems of the country.

He was 69 years old and had homes at 15 West 81st Street here and in CrotononHudson. N. Y.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 3 (Agence FrancePresse) About 20 per cent of Saigon's illiterate have been taught to read since the installation of the Communist regime last April, the official newspaper, Giai Phong, reported here.

description: LONDON, March 3Thirteen years after Lord GeorgeBrown came within 41 votes of leading the Labor Party, the former Cabinet official has abruptly severed his ties to the party after a controversial career.

The immediate effects of President Samora Machel's decision will probably be felt more in the economic area than in military action; but this will be of little comfort for the more discerning among Rhodesia's 270,000 whites.

description: Two large German shepherd dogs that have been running loose for more than a year have created an atmosphere of terror and hostility in quiet residential community of Queens by biting anywhere from 20 to 50 persons, mainly children, in recent weeks.

title: Bridge

title: Key Legislators Told of Desire to Let Cairo Purchase C130's
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The Ford Administration has informed key members of Congress in the last 48 hours that to encourage Egypt on a moderate path it would like to lift the longstanding embargo on mlitary sales, beginning by selling six C130 military transport planes to Cairo.

title: WHEAT FUTURES MAKE SMALL RISE
description: Holders of short positions bought yesterday to take profits in wheat, and futures rose a little. The July contract, a new crop month, gained 2 cents a bushel to close at $3.84. Many had profited from a sharp drop on Tuesday as a result of rain over some of the droughtstricken winter wheat areas.

title: People in Sports

The 39yearold slugger from Payette, Idaho, will become a color commenlater on the Minnesota Twins games for an independent television station, WICN, in the Minneapolis area.

title: TV: McNaughton's Daughter, Easy Conformity
description: Television's biggest swimdle could be entitled The Case of the Dumb and/or Decimated Script. The typical form is as rigid as any TV format: A situation is contrived with intense care, several strands of the story are stretched into audiencegrabbing development, and the solution is thrown at the audience as quickly as possible to reduce the possibilities of thought or questioning.

title: Ginger Rogers at Waldorf, Gracious and Predictable
description: First things first. How does Ginger Rogers look in her new act at the WaldorfAstoria? Fine. Her figure is trim, sheathed in an array of stunning gowns. The legs that glided alongside Fred Astaire in those movie musicals are still beautiful. And Miss Rogers still dances, now flanked by four limber young men, like an angel.

title: Film: 'Beyond the Grave':4 Episodes Delve Into a Nether World
description: In the decrepit antiques shop that links the four episodes of "From Beyond the Grave" the rule is: count your change carefully. Not because the cadaverous properitor, a man with all kinds of spooky and disagreeable resources at his command, will cheat. But dreadful things happen to customers who try to cheat him. The movie, which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, demonstrates them.John Collier used to write lovely short stories about this kind of thing, drawing odd and ironic genies out of his old bottles. The episodes in "Grave," based on stories by R. Chetwyn-Hayes, are crude and obvious. Each punch is telegraphed, each twist is a stranglehold. They overcompensate with blood for their lack of deftness. And the blood is rotten quality: dark, transparent stuff.However, the producers have hired some distinguished and underworked British actors for several of the parts. In spite of the blood, none of the episodes goes much below a certain harmless tedium. And in one or two cases the actors bring in a real if momentary liveliness.By far the best is "The Elemental," and the reason is the late Margaret Leighton. She is a medium brought in to exorcise a nasty spirit that has embedded itself in the stuffy left shoulder of a businessman, played by Ian Carmichael.In yellow wig and dark glasses. Miss Leighton hasand bestowsa hilarious time wrestling the spirit all over a prim and proper Surrey cottage, filling the air with feathers, smashed crockery and outraged exclamations.In "An Act of Kindness," Ian Bannen has some good moments as a long-suffering husband getting rid of his shrewish wife. As the wife, Diana Dors is also fine. I particularly liked herafter her husband has stormed from the dinner tableuprighting the upset sauce bottle and continuing to chew.The other two episodes, "The Gate Crasher" and "The Door" are pure stodge. If people still traveled much by railroad, "Grave" might be something to see between trains.

title: Yale Women Strip To Protest a Lack Of Crew's Showers
description: NEW HAVEN, March 3Nineteen members of the Yale women's varsity crew stripped, naked this afternoon in the office of Joni Barnett, director of physical education, to protest the lack of shower fa cilities at Derby, Conn.

description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration said today that more than 1,600 dental Xray machines across the country were being refitted to prevent unnecessary radiation.

title: Schwartz Appears Headed for Defeat as State Correction Chairman
description: ALBANY, March 3  The State Senate Committee on Crime and Correction, deadlock 6 to 6 on the confirmation of Herman Schwartz as chairman of the State Commission of Correction, forwarded his name today without recommendation to the Senate Finance Committee.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Security National Bank and three of its top officers went on trial in Federal Court in Brooklyn on charges of funneling more than $200,000 in bank funds to various political campaigns, including those of former President Richard M. Nixon and Mayor Beame. Jury selection begins in midafternoon after Judge Mark A. Costantino rejected a motion by the bank to plead nolo contendere, or ?? contest, which does not carry an admission of guilty. The judge said that to accept the plea could prejudice any pending civil actions by shareholders. On trial, in addition to the bank, are its former president and board chairman, Patrick J. Clifford; its former senior executive vice president, David Dowd, and its former executive vice president, Frank B. Powell.

title: Unit of Bankrupt Pennsy Planning a $60 Dividend

title: TV News Slumps in Aftermath Of Watergate, Survey Reports

But a survey of radio and television news by the Alfred I. duPontColumbia University program, issued yesterday, has found that the Watergate aftermath has instead produced a news slumn.

Udall of Arizona.
