description: WASHINGTON, March 3Richard H. Wilmer, a Washington lawyer since 1949, died at his home today. He was 83 years old.

title: OIL REFINERIES HIT 90.1% OF CAPACITY
description: The nation's petroleum refineries operated at 90.1 percent of their capacity in the week ended Feb. 27, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. This compared with an 89.1 percent rate in the preceding week and 83.6 percent in the week ended Feb. 28, 1975.

title: Sale of More Magazine Being Negotiated
description: Michael Kramer, a 30yearold contributing editor of New York magazine, is negotiating to buy More, the journalism review, and take over as its publisher.

title: The Pop Life
description: It's a tempting generalizationtoo tempting, no doubt  to suggest that if men. were the innovative shapers of pop music in the 1960's, women have taken over that role in the 1970's.

title: Keepers of la Langue Francaise Open Their Doors to a 39th Immortal
description: PARIS, March 3  The most exclusive club in the world, and one of the oldest. has just admitted a new member.

title: Shopping Center Pickets Limited by High Court
description: WASHINGTON. March 3Rejecting the more expansive view of the Constitution that it hed taken in a similar case in 1968, the Supreme Court ruled, 6 to 2, today that striking union members have no First Amendment free speech right to picket inside a shopping center to advertise their strike agaibst the owner of one of the stores.

title: MILES SHEROVER, INDUSTRIALIST, 80
description: Miles M. Sherover, who rose from New York's Lower East Side to become a leading industrialist of Venezuela and Israel, died yesterday at his Jerusalem home. He was 80 years old and had been suffering from a heart ailment.

title: 64th Appeal for the Neediest Closes
description: The 64th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ended this week with a total of $1,019,405 in contributions from 10,664 donors.

title: Audiences to Watch Taping Of SillsBurnett Met Show
description: Beverly Sills, the soprano, and Carol Burnett, the comedienne, will perform in a television special that will be videotaped at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday and Tuesday for telecast on CBS on Nov. 25 from 10 to 11 P.M.

title: Rigney Giants' Manager
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 3 (AP)It's good to be back, said Bill Rigney, the former Giants player and manager, moments after the new owners of the San Francisco team introduced him today as their new manager.

title: Moscow Asserts U.S. Fails To Protect Soviet Personnel
description: MOSCOW, March 3 (Reuters) The Soviet Union today accused the United States of fail. Ing to take effective measures to prevent rude provocations and bandit actions against So. viet personnel and institutions in New York.

title: HIGH COURT RULES ON PACTS FOR GAS
description: WASHINGTON, March 3(UPI)  The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 0 today that the Federal Power Commission might authorize natural gas producers to enter into longterm supply contracts that can be abandoned after a fixed, time without further F.P.C. hearings.

title: How the Bayh Race Deteriorated
description: WASHLNGTON, March 3The rapid deterioration of Birch Bayh's campaign for they Democratic Presidential nomi nation seemed a bewildering ?? today to many of the ambitious politicians and cormmined young people who had backed it. To other onlookers it provided lessons in the inexact science of politics.

title: IRWIN FLASTER, DIES; INSURANCE AGENT, 60
description: Irwin M. Flaster, president of Security Life Associates Inc., an insurance agency in East Orange, N.J., died Tuesday in East Orange General Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in the Claridge House in Verona, N.J.

title: 2 COMPANIES ADMIT MESSAGE COPYING
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) Top officials of two international communications companies acknowledged today that their concerns had cooperated with the National Security Agency's interception of foreign government messages.

title: S.E.C. Seeks Ideas On Composite Book
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The Securities and Exchange Commission sought suggestions today about how to proceed with development of a key element in a plan to create a national system for making securities transactions.

title: The Humphrey Factor
description: BOSTON, March 3While many were watching other states and other candidates, Henry Jackson walked off with the biggest prize so far in the 1976 Democratic race. But the real beneficiary of the Massachusetts primary may eventually turn out to be another fellow: Hubert Horatio Humphrey.

title: Record of Annual Appeals
description: The fund for The New York Times Neediest Cases was started in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was publisher of The New York Times until his death in 1935. Contributions to the 65th annual appeal, which begins Dec. 6, can be sent to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, P. 0. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N. Y. 10242.

title: N.Y.U. Raising Tuition 7.5 %
description: New York University yesterday announced a 7.5 percent increase in undergraduate tuition for the 197677 academic year. The increase brings the tuition from $3,300 to $3,550. The cost of graduate credits will rise from $100 to $108 a credit. According to John C. Sawhill, president of the university, the increases were necessary to maintain educational quality.

title: 4 Lawyers Indicted After Inquiry Into Schemes for Evading Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, March 4The Department of Justice announced today the indictment of four Illinois lawyers in the first major charge stemming from a national investigation through secret bank deposits in the Bahamas and other Caribbean and. LatinAmerican countries.

title: Medal of Honor Given To Four by President
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)  President Ford awarded the Medal of Honor today to four veterans of Vietnam, including three former prisoners of war.

title: Britain's Commissioner In Nigeria Withdrawn
description: LONDON, March 4 (Reuters)Britain today withdrew its representative, High Commissioner, Sir Martin le Qitesne, from Lagos because of his personal unacceptability to the Nigerians, the Foreign Office here said in statement.

title: U.S. Renews U.N. Effort for Political Prisoners
description: GENEVA, March 4 The United States renewed its attempt today to win United Nations support for a worldwide amnesty for political prisoners.

title: GULF ASKS RETURN OF ILLEGAL GIFTS
description: PITTSBURGH, March 4The Gulf Oil Corporation said today that it had asked politicians who accepted its illegal campaign contributions to return the money.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Restaurant Review
description: Almost no one who has ever eaten at Palm feels lukewarm about it. This 50yearold landmark with its plain piperack decor, sawdustcovered floors and celebrity cartoons painted on the walls seems to inspire either rapt devotion or a total turnoff.

title: Hiss Hearst Notes On Possible Bomb Put Into Evidence
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 4The Government put into evidence today notes in Patricia Hearst's handwriting that appeared to list parts for a bomb and bore the notation meet to talk about shooting/9:00.

title: in Job Safety
description: President Ford's admonition to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration to treat businessmen as friends, not enemies is apparently having its desired preelection effect: a slowdown in enforcement of safety rules that were underenforced to start with.

title: Books of The Times
description: Few Americans of the last 50 years have so perplexed and perturbed their countrymen as Charles Augustus Lindbergh. Attaining instant celebrity amounting to adulation as a hero for his New York to Paris flight in 1927, he plummeted to almost equally instant obloquy in 194041 for espousing nonintervention in World War II in such a fashion that many beheld him as proNazi. In later years he emerged from a selfimposed obscurity as a vigorous champion of conservation and opposition to supersonic airplanes.

title: Landmark Hotel Faces Demise in Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 4The Ambassador Hotel, the resort's secondlargest, faces demolition after being idle for the last nine years.

title: Islanders Tie Canucks,33; Marks Broken by Trottier
description: UNIONDALE, L.I. March 4 The New York Islanders skated to a 33 tie tonight against the Vancouver Canucks the team they might fide in the opening round of the Stanley Cup playoffs. The score was the same in Vancouver's game last night with the New York Rangers. The Islanders scored all their goals in the middle period and made up a 31 deficit.

title: Notes on People
description: With Cabinet and Congressional figures, President Ford joined delegations from Arkansas and Oklahoma to honor Senator John L. McClellan Wednesday night at a combined 80thbirthday party and a salute to his efforts toward the 450mile McClellanKerr Arkansas River Navigation System. The waterway, named also for the late Senator Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma, opened Oklahoma to the sea by way of the Mississippi River.

title: Klan to Emulate N.A.A.C.P. To Press Rights of Whites
description: JACKSON, Miss., March 4 (UPI)The king kleagle of a new chapter of the Ku Klux Klan received the group's state charter yesterday as a nonprofit corporation and said that to regain the rights of whites the Klan planned to emulate tactics of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: Social Security a Major Issue In Florida as Primary Day Nears
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4It was payday yesterday here in Pinellas County. More than 220,000 people, a third of the county's population, received their monthly social Security benefits in the morning, a payroll of more Than $40 million.

title: $44 Million Suit Filed
description: HOUSTON. March 4 (AP) Two shareholders today filed a $44 million state damage suit against Lockheed, seeking to recover money that they asserted the company spent on illegal payments. The suit by James Fitpatrick and his wife, Lois, is virtually the same as one they filed last month in a Federal court.

title: Brooks Is Promoted
description: TULSA, Okla., March 4 (AP)  Bob Brooks, sports information director and vice president for business affairs at Oral Roberts University, was named athletic director today. Brooks succeeds Bob Vanatta, recently named commissioner of the Ohio Valley Conference.

title: French Riot Over Wine Imports
description: PARIS, March 4  Rioting winegrowers, angered by importing of cheap Italian and Spanish wines, clashed with the police today in southern France, and a policeman and a demonstrator were killed.

title: U.S. Materiel to Egypt
description: The Ford Administration will follow up the sale of six military C130 transports to Egypt with other military equipment if Congress does not strongly object, according to Administration officials. Page 3.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Alarmed over what they view as the possible ruin of their close and civically active community, more that 50 members of a Bronx Roman Catholic parish are flying to Minneapolis today try to persuade a Benedictine abbot not to recall four monks who have been serving the church.

title: Virginia, Maryland, Clemson Win
description: LANDOVER, Md., March 4 (UPI)  Wally Walker scored 25 points and sparked the underdog Virginia Cavaliers to a 7563 upset of North Carolina State today and Maryland was extended but defeated Duke, 8078, in overtime in the opening round of the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament.

title: CAMBODIA SHOWS A BOMBED TOWN
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 4Cambodia reported today that its Deputy Prime Minister had conducted foreign diplomats on a tour of the northwestern Cambodian town that it said was bombed by American planes last week.

title: Carter Unit Executive Joining Della Femina
description: Barrett Welch, former president of the Carter Products division of Carter Wallace and a wellknown figure in advertising circles, this week joined Della Femina, Travisano & Partners.

title: Priorities in Albany
description: Members of the State Legislature who are attempting to rewrite Governor Carey's tough austerity budget to eliminate cuts in local aid and other pet programs are risking a debacle that could be far more damaging to their own communities  and to the state itself than the relatively modest reductions that Mr. Carey has proposed.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 5, 1976 GENERAL ASSEMBLY, Subcommittees of decolonization committe3 P.M.

title: South Africa Seems Cool To Rhodesians in Crisis
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 4Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa gave little encouragement today to Rhodesia in a statement on Mozambique's closing of its border with this landlocked country.

title: 2 AW ARDED $42,700 IN SUBWAY ATTACK
description: The Court of Claims awarded a total of $42,700 damages yesterday to two women who were assaulted in 1972 by a mental patient just released from Pilgrim State Hospital in West Brentwood, L. I.

title: Getting Better Judges
description: It is beyond dispute that our courts are in serious difficulty. While many complex factors have fueled this crisis, perhaps the most fundamental is the caliber of our judges.

title: Rodino to Head Democratic Convention Delegates
description: TRENTON, March 4New Jersey's 21 county Democratic chairmen have picked Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. of Newark to head the state's delegation to the National Convention in New York next July. The state Democratic chairman, James P. Dugan of Bayonne, said that Governor Byrne had not been picked to head the delegation because he was too busy with the state's fiscal problems.

title: 17 SEOUL GRITICS SAID TO BE HELD
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 4The wife of a former South Korean president, Mrs. Yun Po Sun, and 16 other Christians were reportedly being held today in connection with a statement that some of them signed Monday, asking that President Park Chunk Hee step down.

title: Now It's Stop Carter
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 4We've sent them enough messages, Jimmy Carter has been telling Florida voters. Now let's send them a President.

title: Knights, Redmen N.C.A.A. Bound
description: Rutgers will oppose St. John's tomorrow afternoon at Madison Square Garden and the penalty for the loser will be a game against unbeaten Indiana, the nation's topranked team, in the opening round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament next Saturday.

title: 500 at Rally Protest Proposal To Make York 2Year College
description: An audience of 500 people filled Hillcrest High School in Queens last night to protest a proposal to convert York College from a fouryear liberal arts institution into a twoyear college.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES FELL IN FEBRUARY; FOOD KEY FACTOR
description: WASHINGTON, March 4Further progress in slowing the nation's inflation rate was recorded today as the Labor Department said the Wholesale Price Index declined by fivetenths of 1 percent in February.

title: High Rate of Job Attrition Helps City Reduce layoff
description: The Beame administration in dicated yesterday that it expected the current high rate of employee attrition to con tinue for the next two years, so that the bulk of payroll cutbacks under the austerity plan would probably not have to be met with largescale layoffs.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, March 4, 1976 (In bushels, 000 omitted) Wed.

title: Pan American Indicted In Crash at Logan Field
description: Pan American World Airways and three other corporations said, yesterday they would not contest a charge by a Federal grand jury that they were guilty of criminal negligence that contributed to the crash of a cargo plane at Boston's Logan Airport in 1973. All three crew members on the plane, a Boeing 707, perished.

title: Justice Officials and Politicians Rally to John Jay College Drive
description: Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd and former United States Attorney General Ramsey Clark yesterday joined with other public officials to lend their support to the campaign for keeping the John Jay College of Criminal Justice alive as an autonomous institution in the City University.

title: U.S. Plans to Sell Egypt Wide Range of Materiel
description: WASHINGTON, March 4The Ford Administration will gradually follow up the sale of six C130 military transports to Egypt with a range of other military equipment, none of it weaponry, it Congress does not object strongly, Administration officials said today.

title: UNION AT MET OPERA TO MEET ON STRIKE
description: Metropolitan Operamembers of the American Guild of Musical Artists, who on Wednesday voted not to call a strike against the company, will meet again in a few weeks to hear further reports on union negotiations with the Met and perhaps reconsider the strike vote.

title: Pole Position to Hunt
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa. March 4 (AP)James Hunt of Britain recorded the fastest official training time today on the Kyalami Circuit and gained the pole position for Saturday's South African Grand Prix. Hunt was credited with 1 minute 16.10 seconds for the 4.104kilometer circuit.

title: Elderly Artists Display Their Works at Morven
description: PRINCETON, March 4'I wish I had some talent, Governor Byrne told John M. T. Billson of Upper Saddle River today as they viewed paintings by elderly artists at an exhibition at Moryen, the Governor's home.

title: Reagan, in Direct Attack, Assails Ford on Defense
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 4Ronald Reagan charged today, in his most direct attack on President Ford, that the President had failed to provide the United States with vision and leadership and that under his tenure the nation had fallen militarily behind the Soviet Union.

title: Parish Protests Loss of Monks
description: Alarmed over what they view as the possible ruin of their close and civically active community, more than 50 members of a Bronx Roman Catholic parish are flying to Minneapons today to try to persuade Benedictine abbot not to recall four monks who have been serving the church.

title: Conferees Agree on Bill To Tap 3 Navy Oil Fields
description: WASHINGTON, March 4House and Senate conferees reached agreement today on a bill authorizing fullscale oil production at three of four naval petroleum reserves, inluding Teapot Dome in wyoming.

title: Jackson, in Florida Primary Drive, Questions the Credibility of Carter
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, March 4Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington barnstormed around Florida today accusing Jimmy Carter, the former Governor of Georgia, of saying one thing in the snow and something else in the sunshine.

title: Jaspers Suffer 8357 LossNiagara Wins
description: SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 4  Syracuse University embarrassed Manhattan College in the Manley Field House tonight and gained the final round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference upstate basketball playoffs. The final score was Syracuse 83, Manhattan 57.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The New York Times/Neal ??

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Thursday

title: Miss Hearst Notes On Possible Bomb Put Into Evidence
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 4The Government put into evidence today notes in Patricia Hearst's handwriting that appeared to list parts for a bomb and bore the notation meet to talk about shooting/9:00.

title: Sabres 6, Black Hawks 3
description: BUFFALO, March 4 (UPI)  Rick Martin scored two goals in the first six minutes and added another in the third period to power the Buffalo Sabres to a 63 N.H.L. victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight. His French Connection linemate, Rene Robert, added a goal and four assists and Gil Perreault had four assists for the Sabres. John Marks scored twice for Chicago.

title: ShortTerm Rates of Interest Climb Across Board
description: The nation's money supply dropped sharply in the week ended Feb. 25, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

title: Pound Sinks to a Record Low; Dollar Up in Trading Abroad
description: BRUSSELS, March 4 (UPI)The British pound dropped more than a cent in value today and recorded a new low against he dollar.

title: BENJAMIN GERIG, 82, A FORMER U.N. AIDE
description: Dr. Benjamin Gerig, a former State Department official, who served as director of the Office of Dependent Area Affairs and as deputy United StatesRepresentative to the Trusteeship Council of the United Nations, died Feb. 26 in Venicei, Fla. He was 82 years old.

title: City Refuses to Lease Site For a 2d Ave. Shop Plaza
description: Responding to vociferous protests of businessmen and residents who work or live near Second Avenue and 59th Street, the Board of Estimate refused yesterday to approve the leasing of a strip of cityowned land there to a developer for the construction of $2 million complex of food shops, boutiques and movie theaters.

title: Supermarketson L.I. Must Keep Stamping The Prices on Goods
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 4Consumers on Long Island won a major victory today when the Consumer Affairs Commissioners of Nassau and Suffolk Counties promulgated regulations that require that prices be stamped on virtually all items sold in supermarkets.

title: City U., Forced to Cut, Trying toy Maintain Quality and Range
description: In facing up to the need to curtail sharply its scale of operations, the City University is doing what other universities and colleges across the country are also doing: revising optimistic projections of the last decade and coming to terms with a no growth mentality. Like other educational institutions, the City University is also being forced to reexamine its basic operating principles. What makes the situation liere unique is the sheer magnitude of the financial crisisand thus the changes requiredand the boldness of openadmissions and other policies that are now coming under fire.

title: SENATOR BELLMON RETAINS HIS SEAT
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) The Senate voted unanimously today to seat Senator Henry Bellmon, a Republican, after narrowly passing a motion to postpone indefinitely action on a resolution ordering a new election in the disputed 1974 United States Senate race in Oklahoma.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the minor mysteries of bidding theory is the exact meaning of a jump raise of partner's majorsuit response.

title: Pound Sinks to Low
description: The British pound dropped more than a cent in value yesterday and recorded a new low against the dollar on European markets. The American currency resumed an upward trend while the price of gold remained virtually unchanged. Page 43.

title: Laura Glekel Wed To Michael Sirkin
description: Laura Glekel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Newton Glekel of New York. was married yesterday to Michael S. Sirkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Sirkin of Hillsdale, N. J. Rabbi Mark Goodman performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

title: $284,000 APPROVED FOR FORD CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI) The Federal Election Commission authorized $284,000 more today in public campaign funds for President Ford's Presidential campaign, oringing his, total of Federal matching money this year to $1.3 million.

title: Belgrade Denounces U.S.
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 4  Yugoslavia today condemned the United States, accusing it of having bombed the Cambodian town of Siem Reap.

title: PRICE INCREASES IN SUGAR FUTURES
description: The Soviet Union was the big factor in higher prices for sugar and wheat yesterday in futures trading, as rumors abounded that it had ordered, large amounts of both commodities. Traders pushed prices up.

title: Portugal Releases ExSecurity Chief Implicated in Plot
description: LISBON, March 4Portugal's former military security chief, who was arrested last month on charges of conspiracy, was released last night on personal bond, the army high command announced today.

title: Man Pleads Guilty in Bar Slaying
description: A 47yearold Teaneck man pleaded guilty to murdering a bartender by hitting him with the top of a toilet tank after the bartender made fun of him and refused to give him a drink, The man, John Salem, changed his plea from not guilty to guilty in connection with last. December's seeonddegree murder of William Tomcavage, 52, of Teaneck.

title: An ExAtlanta Radio Official Is Convicted in Payola Case
description: NEWARK March 4 (UPI)A onetime program director for an Atlanta radio station was given a oneyear suspended sentence today for accepting money and gifts in return for playing records on the air.

title: Kapp Testifies Rozelle Kept Him From Playing
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 4 (UPI)Joe Kapp, testifying in his damages trial against the New England Patriots and the National Football League, insisted on the witness stand today that he had every intention of honoring his commitment to play football but was prevented from doing so by Commissioner Pete Rozelle.

title: A Sulky Curb at Yonkers
description: When Yonkers Raceway opens its spring meeting next Monday night, a new policy will limit the amount of experimenting that can be done with modified sulkies. The modified sulky, made of metal, is narrower than standard wood sulkies. It has been used with success at Roosevelt Raceway, whose 69night winter meeting ends tomorrow.

title: F.C.C. issues Two Ruling on Political Primaries
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday acted on two complaints concerning television and the political primaries ruling that WGNTV in Chicago could not limit the length of political commercials would accept for broadcast and that WCKT in Miami did not have to grant equal time to Ronald Reagan for carrying a series of interviews with President Ford in its newscasts.

title: CONGRESS PUSHES RAILROAD TALKS
description: Congress yesterday added its voice to the growing concern over the prospect of a giant new Governmentbacked Consolidated Rail Corporation with virtually no competition in the Northeast.

title: Layle Lane, Rights Leader, Teachers Union Officer, 78
description: Layle Lane, a civilrights leader for more than three decades and a former vice president of the American Federation of Teachers, died Feb. 2 in Cuernavaca, Mexico. She was 78, years old.

title: RipOff in the Mines
description: House approval this week of an expensive program of disguised pensions for coal miners and their families was an exercise in profligacy, not liberalism.

title: Retiring Senate Leader
description: WASHINGTON, March 4To visitors leaving his Senate majority leader's office, Michael Joseph Mansfield, in his laconic way, often says in farewell: Tap er light It is an expression he learned as as a young man in the copper mines of Montana where the oldtimers would advise him to tap the stick of dynamite lightly into the hole. To his associates, the expression came to typify Mr. Mansfielda gentle yet sometimes stubborn man who firmly believed that a friendly tap on the back was more effective than armtwisting or cajoling in directing the course of the Senate.

title: Native Norwich Is Ignoring Benedict Arnold
description: NORWICH, Conn., March 4Like a prophet without honor in his own land, a man who was both hero and villian of the American Revolution will be without celebration in his hometown this year.

title: 31 % Bay State Turnout
description: BOSTON; March 4 (AP)Thirtyone percent of the eligible voters cast ballots in the Massachusetts Presidential primary Tuesday, according to Paul Guzzi, state secretary. He reported yesterday, based on returns from 99 percent of the precincts, that 902,697 persons had voted. Total registration is 2,872,483. The turnout was 6 percent higher than the 1972 primary. He said that 720,595 persons voted in Tuesday's Democratic primary and 182,1102 in the Republican contest.

title: Sotheby's Class: It's Exclusive and Serious
description: LONDON, March 4The most exclusive school in town these days takes up half a dozen rooms on the second floor of an unmarked commercial building off Oxford Street. There are only three teachers and 50 students. But the presence of one of themCaroline Kennedyhas made the school the source of dinnerparty conversation and widespread curiosity.

title: Britain Doubts Cuban Moves
description: LONDON, March 4The Foreign Office said tonight that it had no knowledge of any moves of Cuban forces in Angola into the Rhodesian dispute. A British official said that Mr. Kissinger's remarks simply echoed widely held fears and did not necessarily indicate foreknowledge of new moves by the Cubans.

title: Limitless Atomic Power Sought In U. of Rochester Laser Project
description: With Government and industry support, the University of Rochester is undertaking the most ambitious known American effort to prove that unlimited energy can be derived through the fusion of pellets of nuclear fuel by crushing the pellets with laser beams.

title: U.S. Matriel to Egypt
description: The Ford Administration will follow up the sale of six military C130 transports to Egypt with other military equipment if Congress does not strongly object, according to Administration officials. Page 3.

title: U Conn 73, U Mass 69
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 4 (UPI)Joe Whelton hit an 18foot jumper with three seconds left tonight as Connecticut upset topseeded Massachusetts, 7369, in an opening round game of the New England E.C.A.C. regional tournament.

title: Puerto Rico Says Jackson Has 4 Convention Delegates
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., March 4 (AP)Puerti Rico's Democratic Party certified today that Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington had won four of the island's delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

title: Cold Tablets Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration yesterday ordered the recall of 93,600 boxes of Brand 666 cold tablets for failing to carry a warning that they contain a laxative ingredient.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Two of your Feb. 13 editorials: One a compassionate apologia for the action of the 44 Federal judges suing the Congress for what amounts to a raise; the other, an acid comment on the New York City Board of Education's current budget request, which you view as stemming from the United Federation of Teachers unreasonable contract demands.

title: Reagan, in Direct Attack, Assails Ford on Defense
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 4Ronald Reagan charged today, in his most direct attack on President Ford, that the President had failed to provide the United States with vision and leadership and that under his tenure the nation had fallen militarily behind the Soviet Union.

title: Life in Lagos Slowly Returning to Chaotic Normal
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, March 4An American visitor stepped into a taxi here the other day and was inching through teeming back streets when suddenly her cab was engulfed by an angry mob.

title: EVIDENCE ACCEPTED FOR HARRISES' TRIAL
description: LOS ANGELES, March 4 (AP) Evidence seized at Patricia Hearst's San Francisco apartment may be introduced in the trial of William and Emily Harris, members of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army, a judge has ruled.

title: Construction of Housing Below 1932 Level Here
description: The pace of housing eonstruction in New York. City plunged last year to an even lower level than during the worst years of the Depression of the 1930's, according to buildingpermit figures made public by the state yesterday.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Thursday. London: Morning fixing $132.00, down $0.25; afternoon fixing $132.25, unchanged.

title: Prayers to Be Offered in U.S.
description: Prayers for Lee Oo Chung, president of Church Women United of Korea and a prominent human rights activist, will be offered today in this country at services marking World Day of Prayer, sponsored annually by Church Women United in the U.S.A.

title: British Laborites Win Election, Keep Control
description: COVENTRY, England, Friday, March 5 (UPI)  The Labor Government retained its thin majority in Parliament yesterday with a victory in a strongly contested election in the industrial city of Coventry.

title: Suharto Dismisses Chief Of Floundering Pertamina
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 4President Suharto of Indonesia has ousted the head of the nation's faltering state oil company and dissolved the board of directors.

title: BERNHARD CANCELS TWO TRIPS IN INQUIRY
description: THE HAGUE, March 4 (AP) Prince Bernhard of the Netherlanss, under investigation in the Lockheed scandals, has canceled a trip to Hot Springs, Va., in April, when he was to have presided at the Bilderberg Conference. He will also skip a planned trip to Latin America.

title: Seaway Official Sworn
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) David W. Oberlin, who has been administrator of the St. Lawrence Saway Development Corporation since 1969, was sworn in for a sevenyear term today in ceremonies at the Deoartment of Tranportation. Mr. Oberlin was nominated by President Ford after Congress passed legislation last year prescribing a sevenyear term for the administrator.

title: Razslle to Address Player Union
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)Pete Rozelle, commissioner of the N.F.L., will open the annual meeting of the National Football League Players Association, which begins tomorrow. Rozelle will speak during an opening luncheon of the fiveday meeting.

title: Simon in Abu Dhabi Talks
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, March 4 (Reuters)Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon started talks here today aimed at increasing American financial and economic cooperation with the United Arab Emirates.

title: Capitol Hill's Odd Couple: Bronxite and Jersey Lady
description: The South Vietnamese talked about a terrible bloodbath if funds were cut off, Mrs. Abzug recalled. I said that the bloodbath was so terrible now that it couldn't get any worse. Millicent Was concerned.

title: Nixon Gives His View of the Resignation
description: WASHINGTON, March 4Richard M. Nixon resigned the Presidency lest a weak political base in Congress and a protracted impeachment trial by the Senate deprive America of the leadership it needed, he has written in his first published explanation of his abdication in 1974.

title: New Approach Is Urged In Teaching of Theology
description: The country's top indepen dent theological schools should intensify study of specific religious traditions and downgrade general approaches to religion, a newly released Rockefeller Foundation report says. It is the first report of its kind ever to be prepared by the Foundation.

title: WHOLESALE PEES FEU IN FEBRUARY; FOOD KEY FACTOR
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 Further progress in slowing the nation's inflation rate was recorded today as the Labor Department said the Wholesale Price Index declined by fivetenths of 1 percent in February.

title: MG CHAIN STORES SET RECORD SALES
Lockheed Reported Barring Inspection By G.A.O. of Data
description: WASHINGTON, March 4The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has refused to allow the General Accounting Office to inspect its records relating to foreign payments, even though the G.A.O., as the Congressional investigative agency, is required by law to make a detailed audit of all accounts of the aircraft company.

title: Appellate Court Upholds Ruling Nullifying Election of 3 Regents
description: ALBANY, March 4The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court today upheld a lower court's ruling that found invalid the disputed election a year ago of three members of the Board of Regents by Assembly and Senate Democrats.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch in The New York Times Wednesday incorrectly identified William R. Carden, president of Translinear Inc., as William R. Garden.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: Las Vegas, Nev.Lero, Jones, 26 pounds. ?? ?? out Jody Ballard 204, ?? 4 rounds.

title: SANCIOUS JAZZROCK LIVENED BY HUMOR
description: David Sancious, who is appearing this weekend at the Other End, was first heard here as a member of Bruce Spring: steen's E Street Band. As a jazzoriented musician whc owes his current visibility ?? exposure with a wellknown pop group, his task is twofold He will have to prove his wortl as a creative player, and while doing so he will have to please the fans who are following hin because of the Springsteen as sociation.

title: Scaasi's Madly Flattering Ideas
description: Jane Pickens Langley sat in the front row at Arnold Scaasi's summer collection and tried to see through some of the couturier's magic tricks. Weren't those delicious floaty things just scarves cleverly pinned on? Couldn't she, perhaps, paint her own chiffons and save a bundle? Mrs. Langley was joking, of course, saying, I've spent so much money here, I ought to get some free ideas.

title: F.C.C. Study Finds New Jersey in Need of More Local TV Service
description: WASHINGTON, March 4The Federal Communications Commission today announced that an investigation it had made showed New Jersey in need of additional locally oriented television program service. But the commission has not yet decided the best way to provide it.

title: 50,000 Bird Deaths Feared From Oil Spill Off Coast
description: SEATTLE, March 4 (AP)Heavy, lowgrade oil washing ashore along the Oregon and Washington coasts may be killing as many as 50,000 birds, the Washington Game Department says.

title: 2D REGION STUDIED FOR BIRTH DEFECTS
description: The National Center for Disease Control is studying a second region of the country where exposure to vinyl chloride from a chemical plant may be related to a higher than expected rate of birth defects among children born in the area.

title: GULF ASKS RETURN OF ILLEGAL GIFTS
description: PITTSBURGH, March 4The Gulf Oil Corporation said today that it had asked politicians who accepted its illegal campaign contributions to return the money.

title: Trading of Big Blocks Off Sharply in February
description: Trading volume of big blocks of stock10,000 shares or more at one time fell sharply in February, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday, pointing to a decline in activity by leading financial institutions.

title: Job Discrimination Charged by Women Workers
description: An organization whose aims are to upgrade the role of women clerical workers announced yesterday that it had filed complaints of loge and Sec discrimination agaimst five employment agencies and the New York State Employment Service.

title: Mansfield, 24 Years in Senate, to Retire
description: WASHINGTON, March 4Mike Mansfield of Montana, who has been the majority leader of the United States Senate for the last 15 years, longer than any other person, announced today that he would not seek reelection in November.

title: MISS COHEN DANCES MOTHERS OF ISRAEL
description: The other shoe dropped, metaphorically, Wednesday evening when Ze'eva Cohen presented the second haf of Mothers of Israel, the first parts of which she showed last spring. The portraits are beautifully realized capsule portraits of biblical matriarchs Sarah, Rebekah, Leah and Rachel. The concert was at the American Theater Laboratory.

title: The Cast
description: THE BOSS by Edward Sheldon. Directed by Edward Gilbert; settings by Lawrence King; costumes by Carrie F. Robbins; lighting by William Mintzer; isrocluetlon stage manager, Bob Jaffe. Presented by the Chelsea Theater Center of Brooklyn, Robert Kalfln, artistic director. At the Brooklyn Academy of Musk, 30 Lafayette Avenue.

title: CITY U. STUDENTS FACE CUT IN ROLLS
description: The City University of New York would have 30,000 fewer students in three years if the university restructuring plan is put into effect, the school's chancellor, Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, said yesterday.

title: House Rejects Ford Plea
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) President Ford's request for Congress to postpne spending $15 million on juvenile delinquency prgrams was rejectd by the House today. The voice vote by which the House adopted a resolution of disapproval killed Mr. Ford's proposal to delay spending the authorized funds.

title: Syria Rebuffs P.L.O. At U.N. Over Issue Of Mideast Inquiry
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 4The Palestine Liberation Organization suggested today that a new United Nations committee send a factfinding group to the Middle East, but was at once rebuffed by Syria.

title: Luxor Baths Being Secretly Converjed Into a 9Story Luxury Massage Parlor
description: The ninestory Luxor Baths, long a famous Times Square gathering place for men in show business, the sporting set and the garment industry, is being converted secretly and illegally into one of the most lavish massage parlors in the country.

title: Federal Panel Bans Most Firecrackers Beginning Next Fall
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI)The Consumer Product Safety Commission issued a nationwide ban today against all but the smallest firecrackers and put manufacturers of other fireworks on notice that they will have to meet stiffer safety requirements.

title: Pennsylvania Coal Rule Is Opposed
description: The state's top environmental official said he opposed proposed Pennsylvania legislation to ease sulfur content standards for coal. In testimony submitted in writing to the Pennsylvania House Committee on Mines and Energy Management, David J. Bardin, the New Jersey Commissioner of Environmental Protection, said the legislation would replace presently unsatisfactory sulfur standards with thoroughly inefficient and unworkable provisions.

title: High Rate of Job Attrition Helps City Reduce Layoffs
description: The Beame administration indicated yesterday that it expected the current high rate of employee attrition to continue for the next two years, so that the bulk of payroll cutbacks under the austerity plan would probably not have to be met with largescale layoffs.

title: Rangers Call Up Holst, 22, a Center
description: The Rangers have recalled Creg Holst, a 22yearold center, from the Providence Reds of the American Hockey League, the New York club announced yesterday.

title: 4 Is Double Lucky for Lottery Winner
description: The number 4 proved lucky again for Harold J. Muhs yesterday as the 69yearold retired bartender from Trenton won the New Jersey weekly lottery's Jersey Jackpot $250,000 prize. On Jan. 4, 1973, Mr. Mulls won the top prize of $50,000 in the old weekly lottery. And yesterday, March, 4, he won $25,000 a year for the next 10 years. In the final drawing, in South Plainfield, Mr. Muhs drew Post Position 4.

title: Baseball: Salaries To Rise?
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4Willie Stargell hit a home run off Tom Seaver today in the season's first baseball game for exiled players. But the exiles indicated they were really marking time for three imminent developments: another attempt to settle the reserve clause in contracts, a Federal Court of Appeals decision and a revolution in salaries.

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Stock prices on the American Stock Exchange drifted lower yesterday on moderate volume of 3,670,000 shares. The market value index lost 0.36 to close at 103.18. Declines shown by 491 stocks were almost double the 261 stocks that advanced.

title: Business Briefs
description: Planned capital expenditures by the nation's 1,000 largest manufacturers rose 22 percent in the final quarter of 1975 compared with the previous three months, the Conference Board said yesterday. The private research group said the manufacturers set aside $12.84 billion, adjusted for seasonal factors, for new plant and equipment during the quarter. It was the largest appropriation since the third quarter of 1974, the board said.

title: Shriver Staying in Race; Vows to Do Best in Illinois
description: CHICAGO, March 4Sargent Shriver, despite predictions that he will do as poorly in the Illinois primary March 16 as he did in Massachusetts this week, said today that he was not withdrawing from the campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The number 4 proved lucky again for Harold J. Muhs yesterday as the 69yearold retired bartender from Trenton won the New Jersey weekly lottery's Jersey Jackpot $250,000 prize. On Jan. 4, 1973, Mr. Muhs won the top prize of $50,000 in the old weekly lottery. And yesterday, March 4, he won $25,000 a year for the next 10 years. In the final drawing, in South Plainfield, N. J., Mr. Muhs drew Post Position 4.

title: Bullets Top Rockets for 5th Straight
description: HOUSTON, March 4 (AP)Phil Chenier pumped in 30 points to lead the Washington Bullets to a 113106 victory over the Houston Rockets tonight in a National Basketball Association game. It was the Bullets fifth victory in a row and their 11th in their last 13 games.

title: Week's Retail Sales Rise
description: WASHINGTON, March 4The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $984 million, up 14 percent from the yearearlier $861 million. Total retail store sales were $12.23 billion, up 12 percent from $10.96 billion.

title: 2 Hudson Bus Companies Are Struck; Transport of Jersey Walkout Deferred
description: Continued From Page 65 Col. 8 a problem for homewardhound commuters, including 3,000 riders of the Hudson Bus Company's Route 99 and, Route 99S. which carry commuters from Manhattan to Journal Square in Jersey City and then south to Bayonne and Staten Island.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: A TV Set Is Traced And 2 Are Arrested In Slaying on L.I.
description: MINEOLA, L.I., March 4Two Hempstead men were arrested today and charged with the murder of a 75yearold woman during a robbery that reportedly netted them $16.25.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: DrinkingAge Bill Passed
description: ST. PAUL, March 4 (AP)A bill to raise Minnesota's minimum drinking age from 18 to 19 was approved today by the State Senate and sent to Gov. Wendell R. Anderson for signature. He is expected to sign the bill, which will take effect Sept. 1.

title: 80 Americans Appeal to India To Restore Fundamental Rightsi
description: More than 80 Americans, most of them widely known, are issuing a joint appeal today expressing distress at repression in India and calling for the restoration of fundamental human rights there.

title: Hawks 103, Celtics 98
description: ATLANTA, March 4 (AP) Atlanta blew a 16point fourthquarter lead, but came back in the last minute on Lou Hudson's conversion of a technical foul on Tom Heinsohn, Boston's coach, snapping a tie and leading the Hawks to a 10398 N.B.A. victory over the Celtics tonight. Hudson, who finished with 42 points, led the Hawks, who snapped a fivegame losing streak.

title: A Franklin and Jefferson Package at Met
description: With the opening today of the exhibition called The World of Franklin and Jefferson, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has an unmistakable hit on its hands.

title: Yunich Sees Transit Increase Unless 4 Conditions Are Met
description: David L. Yunich raised the specter of another transitfare increase yesterday, saying four conditions must be met this year, including a $45 million loan and continuation of the constrains of the existing wave freeze.

title: PAN AM INDICTED IN BOSTON CRASH
description: In the first criminal indict ment of an airline stemming from a crash. Pan American. World Airways was charged by a Federal grand jury yesterday with criminal negligence that contributed to the crash of one of its cargo planes at Boston's Logan Airport on Nov. 3, 1973. The plane's threeman crew was killed.

title: Israeli Command Reports Raid Across Lebanon Line
description: TEL AVIV, March 4 (AP)Israeli troops penetrated half a mile into Lebanon on an antiguerrilla raid and blew up an Arab house used as a terrorist base, the military command said today.

title: CrimeAgainstWomen Parley Opens in Brussels Without Men
description: BRUSSELS, March 4An International Tribunal on Crimes against Women opened in Brussels today, with no men allowed.

title: NADJARI PRESSES A COURT INQUIRY
description: Maurice H. Nadjari's office contended yesterday that Thomas I. Fitzgerald, who retired Monday as public administrator in the Manhattan Surrogate's Court, might have important evidence for a special grand jury that is investigating possible corruption in that court and others in Manhattan.

title: City Hall Regression?
description: There have been disturbing reports from City Hall denied by some key mayoral aides that the Beame administration is considering deferring major budget cuts until the final year of the threeyear austerity plan in hope of more help from Albany and from a new Administration in Washington.

title: State Expects City Banks To Buy $1 Billion in Notes
description: ALBANY. March 4Eleven major New York City commercial banks are expected to agree to purchase $1 billion in shortterm state notes for their own portfolios this spring a step that would provide a significant boost for the state's drive to meet its critical financing needs this year.

title: Big Board Seeks Foreign Listings; Carlisle Pact Set
description: Special stanards to encourage major foreign corporations to list their shares on the New York Stock Exchange were adopted yesterday.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EN GARDE Art Swords of Japan: the Walter A. Compton Collection is today's new show at Japan House, 333 East 47th Street (between First and Second Avenue), where 94 weaponblades and furnishings are having their first American exhibition, reflecting an ancient Japanese art. The treasured obiects have long been cultural properties of Shinto shrines or of Japanese families, valued for their form, color and refined construction.

title: PETER B. YATES, 66, WRITER ON MUSIC
description: Peter B. Yates, who organized a contemporarymusic series in Los Angeles and was a writer on music, died Feb. 25 after a heart attack in his home. He was 66 years old.

title: KISSINGER ADVISES MA TO BE WARY IN AFRICAN MOVES
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger warned Cuba today to act with great circumspection in southern Africa.

title: Beame Urges State Curb on Handguns
description: Mayor Beame and David W. Brown, chairman of the State Commission of Investigation, yesterday urged state legislation to restrict the ownership of handguns.

title: Ray Gilbert, Song Writer, Dead; Won ZipaDeeDooDah Oscar
description: LOS ANGELES, March 4 (UPI)Ray Gilbert, the composer and song writer who won an Academy Award for best song in 1947 for ZipaDeeDooDah in Walt Disney's movie Song of the South, died yesterday at the University of California medical center here after heart surgery. He was 63 years old.

title: A Price War in Steel Cans Appears to Be Developing
description: A price war of sorts appears to be breaking out in the beer and beverage container industry.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Testifying before the House Committee on International Relations, Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger warned Cuba yesterday to act with great circumspection in southern Africa. Noting the intervention of 12,000 Cuban troops in the Angolan civil war and the cutoff of American aid to forces that opposed the victorious Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, Mr. Kissinger said that our actions cannot always be deduced by what we did in Angola. He declined to say how the United States might retaliate against future Cuban military thrusts. [Page 1, Column 5.]

title: Bombing in Paris
description: PARIS, Friday, March 5 (Reuters)A bomb exploded early today outside the apartment here of the former Interior Minister Raymond Marcellin, injuring one person, the police reported. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the blast. It was not known if Mr. Marcellin, Interior Minister from June 1968 to February 1974, was in the apartment at the time.

title: Knights Victors by 28 Points, Redmen by 7
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 4 Rutgers and St. John's, who have been on a collision course all season, will finally meet at Madison Square Garden Saturday for the college basketball championship of the New YorkNew Jersey area.

title: Pilobolus Dancing Its Way to Togetherness
description: Everything about Pilobolus Dance Theater, which opens tonight at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is unusual.

title: An Odd Couple on Capitol Hill: Daughter Of the Bronx and WellBred jersey Lady
description: WASHINGTON, March 4One is a woman of privilege, the daughter of a bankerambassador, a millionairess from New Jersey's fashionable foxhunt country who speaks in a cultured voice, an old friend of the Rockefellers and Dilions, editor of Vogue's 1948 Book of Etiquette mid former fashion model for Harper's Bazaar on whose svelte figure designer clothes hang gracefully.

title: Cholera Found in 5th Herd of Swine
description: A fifth herd of swine has been found to be infected with hog cholera, a spokesman for the State Department of Agriculture said. The spokesman said that the herd, of about 2,000 swine in Deptford Township, brought the total number of infected hogs in Gloucester County to approximately 8,000.

title: N.E.A MAY FORM A NEW STATE UNIT
description: The National Education Association is planning to establish a new statewide teachers organization here if its current affiliate, the New York State United Teachers, formally votes today, as expected, to sever its ties with the association.

title: Native Norwich Is Ignoring Benedict Arnold
description: NORWICH, Conn., March 4Like a prophet without honor in his own land, a manwho was both hero and villian of the American Revolution will be without celebration in his hometown this year.

title: Bucks 99, Kings 95
description: MILWAUKEE, March 4 (UPI)Elmore Smith snapped an 8484 tie with 5 straight points tonight and the Milwaukee Bucks went on to defeat the Kansas City Kings, 9995. The victory enabled Milwaukee to increase its lead in the Midwest division of the N.B.A. to 2 games over Detroit.

title: Three Grain Companies Fined in Thefth
description: WASHINGTON, March 4A Federal grand jury in New Orleans inditted two large corporations and an affiliated company today on charges of systematic thefts and misgrading of grain.

title: Say It Ain't So, Mike!
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 In the last few months, eight members of the United States Senate and 19 members of the House of Representatives have decided to retire, but none of these has saddened the capital more than the decision of Mike Mansfield to give up the Democratic leadership of the Senate.

title: Chamber President Quits
description: Thomas N. Stainbacic nas resigned as president of the New. York Chamber of CDMmerit( to become president and chief executive officer on June 1 of Paul Smith's College, a twoyear college on Lower St. Regis Lake in the Adirondacks, Paul Smith's, Mr. Stainback's alma mater, is known for its Schools of Forestry and Hotel Manage. ment.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 2.2 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of footstuffs and industrial materials fell to 193.7 from 195.9 last week.

title: J. AUSTIN NORRIS
description: PHILADELPHIA, March (UPI)J. Austin Norris, lawyer, editor and civilrights leader, died Tuesday, apparently of heart attack, in Graduate Hospital. He was 86 years old.

title: MINORITY CAUCUS BIDS STARR QUIT
description: The City Council's sixmember black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus called yesterday for the resignation of Roger Starr, the Housing and Development Administrator, for advocating the planned shrinkage of lowincome and minoritygroup communities.

title: Housing Construction Below 1932 Level Here
description: The pace of housing construction in New York City plunged last year to its lowest level since World War H, and was even lower than in the Worst years of the Depression of the 1930's, according to figures made public yesterday by the state.

title: Moonlight Trades Spur Rebound by Treasury Issues
Miss Navratilova, Miss Wade Upset
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 4 (UPI)Terry Holladay upset thirdseeded Martina Navratilova, 6.4, 16, 61, today in the $75,000 Virginia Slims women's tennis tournament, to gain the semifinal.

title: KISSINGER ADVISES CUBA TO BE WARY IN AFRICAN MOVES
description: WASHINGTON, March 4Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger warned Cuba today to act with great circumspection in southern Africa.

title: McCloy Scores U.S. for Failing to Act On Politicians Accepting Illegal Funds
description: The failure of the United States Government to prosecute or even condemn American politicians who have received illegal political contributions from corporations is unfair and hypocritical, according to John J. McCloy, a prominent New York lawyer who recently conducted an investigation into the Gulf Oil Corporation's illegal political activities.

title: jargon, a Small Press, Is One Poet's Way of Helping Other Poets
description: It's a cottage industry, Jonathan Williams was saying the other day about smallpress publishing. He was speaking shortly after a mammoth party at the Gotham Book Mart to celebrate the 25th anniversary of Jargon, Mr. Williams's own small press one that concentrates on contemporary forays into experimental prose and photographic books.

title: About New York
description: March is a month for changing the lunch habit, particularly for working New Yorkers. The days vary, one day warm and sunny, another cold and damp. on ?? days, the winter lunch style remains, finding a place where one can sit down for the whole noontime break and holding the table until it is time to 20 back to work. On nice days, the urge is to eat quickly and then go out and stroll or sit in a plaza.

title: V.M.I. 41, Richmond 33
description: GREENVILLE, S.C., March 4 (AP)Virginia Military Institute, with a fourcorner offense and a ballhawking defense led by Kelly Lombard, won its first Southern Conference basketball tournament crown In 12 years tonight, defeating Richmond, 4133. V.M.I. will represent the conference in an N.C.A.A. playoff game March 13 at Charlotte, N.C., against the yet to be determined runnerup in the Southeastern Conference.

title: People and Business
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday the appointment of John J. Scanlon as chairman of the National Market Advisory Board.

title: P. F. Cohalen Opens Drive For House from L.I. Area
description: BOHEMIA, L.I., March 4Peter Fox Cohalen, Supervisor of the Towh of Islip for the last five years, today announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination to run against representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of the Second Congressional District.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Testifying before the House Committee on International Relations, Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger warned Cuba yesterday to at with great circumspection in southern Africa. Noting the intervention of 12,000 Cuban troops in the Angolan civil war and the cutoff of American aid to forces that opposed the victorious Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, Mr. Kissinger said that our actions cannot always be deduced by what we did in Angola. He declined to say how the United States might retaliate against future Cuban military thrusts. [Page 1, Column 5.1

title: 5Month Inquiry Foreseen In Leaking of Pike Report
description: WASHINGTON, March 4Representative John J. Flynt, chairman of the House Ethics Committee, said today that his committee's investigation of the leaking of the Pike report could take five months and might branch out into the reported loss of 232 secret documents that the Central Intelligence Agency had lent to the House Select Committee on Intelligence.

title: Supermarketson L.I. Must Keep Stamping The Prices on Goods
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 4Consumers on Long Island won a major victory today when the Consumer Affairs Commissioners of Nassau and Suffolk Counties promulgated regulations that require that prices be stamped on virtually all items sold in supermarkets.

title: Aid to Mozambique Weighed
description: LONDON, March 4Britain and her 35 Commonwealth partners discussed here today how best to help Mozambique so that it would not lose financially by the imposing of United Nations sanctions on Rhodesia. It will not be military aid, a senior Commonwealth official said.

title: HAMMER ENTERS 2D GUILTY PLEAS
description: LOS ANGELES, March 4Armand Hammer, chief executive officer of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, left a hospital bed today to plead guilty a second time to three counts of making and concealing $54,000 in illegal contributions in 1972 to the reelection campaign of President Richard M. Nixon.

title: M. Richard Altchek, Internist, 54, Dead; HeartLung Expert
description: Dr. M. Richard Altchek, an internist who specialized in heart and lung diseases, died of leukemia Wednesday night at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived at 135 Eastern Parkway. Brooklyn.

title: St. Barnabas Asking the State For Aid on Opening Burn Unit
description: LIVINGSTONSt. Barnabas Medical Center is awaiting approval from the State Health Department of a request for additional funds and a certificate of need to open a 12bed burn unit here, which would be the only facility of its kind in the state.

title: Mansfield, 24 Years in Senate, to Retire
description: WASHINGTON, March 4Mike Mansfield of Montana, who has been the majority leader of the United States Senate for the last 15 years, longer than any otner person. announced today that he would not seek reelection in November.

title: Ford's Reaction
description: WASHINGTON, March 4President Ford and his campaign chairman, Howard H. Callaway, dismissed today as unfit for reply Mr. Reagan's sharp attack on the President's foreign policy.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Many parents find it more natural to hand 7yearolds a pencil for creative drawing than to hand it to them for creative writing, perhaps because children appear to have so little control over words.

title: Sale Success (If Too Late) for Grant
description: CLARK, N. J., March 4Which way to the Grant's store? laughed the toll collector on the Garden State Parkway. Just keep going straight until you hit the traffic.

title: Anguilla in New Phase As Elections Approach
description: THE VALLEY, Anguilla, The revolution is over, Ronald Webster said. We revolted for separate status and, our; own constitution and we, have achieved it. Now we are looking forward to development.

title: Suspected Double Agent Buried at Undisclosed Spot
description: SOUTHBURY, Conn., March 4 (UPI)Norman John Rees, who apparently committed suicide after published reports identified him as a double agent, has been buried at an undisclosed location.

title: Racquets' Elite Compete. Behind a Closed Door
description: There may be Seven Deadly Sins and the Ten Commandments and Catch22, but in the tight little world of racquets all that matters these days is Rule 12.

title: Yugoslav Collision Of 11
description: CACAK, Yugoslavia, March 4 (Reuters)Eleven persons were killed and 15 seriously injured today when a crowded local bus and a locomotive collided at a crossing in this town 60 miles south of Belgrade, the news Agency Tanyug reported.

title: HONEYINELL INC. WILL BUY SHARES
description: Honeywell Inc. announced yesterday that it was buying back a 6.8 percent interest in Honeywell Information Systems, its computer operation, from the General Electric Company for Honeywell stock valued at about $44 million. Honeywell said that General Electric would exercise an option to reduce its interest in Honeywell Information Systems from 18.5 percent to 11.7 percent for 800,000 shares of Honeywell common stock. The additional shares of Honeywell stock, it was said, would be issued this month.

title: Ambassador Hotel, a 57YearOld Atlantic City Landmark, Is Facing Demolition
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 4The Ambassador Hotel, the resort's secondlargest, faces demolition after being idle for the last nine years.

title: Brooks Brothers Heir Admits Welfare Fraud
description: Frederick Claiborne Brooks, the 58yearold grandson of a founder of the Brooks Brothers clothing stores, pleaded guilty in Nassau County Court yesterday to charges that he had illegally received $2,600 in welfare assistance.

title: 2 BUS COMPANIES STRUCK IN HUDSON
description: TRENTON, March 4  The Amalgamated Transit Union struck two Hudson County bus lines today, interrupting service for 30,000 commuters traveling between Bayonne and North Bergen and New York, but postponed a scheduled walkout against the giant Transport of New Jersey Bus Company for 72 hours.

title: Red Smith
description: On four successive weekends last summer, Steve DiMauro saddled horses for four stakes. Dearly Precious, the best 2yearold filly in America, won the Sorority Monmouth Park. Wajima, who was sold by the carat as yearling, took the Monmouth Invitational. Pass A Glance was second to the champion Susan's Girl in the Delaware Handicap and collected $21,820. Wajima ran away from his field in the venerable Travers at Saratoga, and that night DiMauro bought 24 dinners for the colt's owners and their guests. That was one of the reasons Penny Tweedy went after The DiMauralizer when she needed a new trainer for Meadow Stable; the way he got on with that JapaneseAmerican cartel suggested that he was just the guy for a new partnership of Mrs. Tweedy, her brother, sister and Elizabeth Ham. Wajima, who cost a record $600,000, just ate and ate and didn't earn back an oat until late September of his 2yearold season, yet his trainer had the patience to wait with him and the tact to make the owners hold still, too.

title: Rabin Stresses Balance
description: TEL AVIV, March 4Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin said today an American arms sale to Egypt could create an absurd situation.

title: Workers in Portugal Release 2 Americans
description: LISBON, Friday, March 5 (AP)Two American executives were released unharmed early today after being held 80 hours by leftist workers at the Firestone Tire & Rubber Company plant at Alcohete, 30 miles east of here.

title: MOSCOW CONGRESS VOTING ON LEADERS
description: MOSCOW, March 4 (UFOTop Soviet Communists met today in a closed session to choose a leadership. Few changes were expected in the hierarchy.

title: Music
description: This has been a remarkable season for collectors of performances of the Dvorak Cello Concerto. Not long ago we had a great one from Mstislav Rostropovich, and on Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall it was Janos Starker's turn. It would be difficult to imagine two more divergent views of this score, each on its own terms incomparable.

title: Union Strikes Two Bus Companies in Hudson County
description: TRENTON, March 4  The Amalgamated Transit Union struck two Hudson County bus lines today, interrupting service for 30,000 commuters traveling between Bayonne and North Bergen and New York, hut postponed a scheduled walkout against the giant Transport of New Jersey Bus Company for 72 hours.

title: Philippines Bans Traveling By Foreigners in Mindanao
description: MANILA, March 4 (Agence FrancePresse)The Philippine Government has imposed a ban on travel by foreigners in provinces on the island of Mindanao after intensified ambushes and kidnappings by Moslem rebels, military officials have announced.

title: STOCK PRICES SLIP AS TRADING EASES
description: The stock market, turning somewhat jittery over the uncertainty of the Federal Reserve Board's monetary policy, slumped again yesterday despite encouraging signs on the inflation front.

title: and on the Rails
description: The benefits the country should derive from reorganization of the debtencumbered Northeast railroads will be greatly reduced if Conrail operates as a monopoly, without the strengthened competition from solvent roads which Congress contemplated.

title: Advertising
description: Quite a few fat cats inhabit the new TV commercials for Paine Webber, the brokerage firm. In one 60second spot, for example, there is the obviously affluent chap looking over his new antique car; the goodlooking woman in her sable coat; the fellow checking his wellstocked wine cellar; the guy who has just presented his girlfriend with a large diamond ring the couple leaving on a cruise; the chairman addressing the board; the bubblebather in her tub; the father of the fresh college graduate; the dowager with her wellappointed tea service, and George

title: U.S. Appeals Court Upholds MortgageCase Convictions
description: A United State appellate court affirmed yesterday the conviction of Harry Bernstein, his wife, Rose, and three other defendents, in a mortgageinsurance case:

title: 3 DEATHS IN SPAIN BRING PROTESTS
description: VITORIA, Spain, March 4This busy northern industrial center lay stunned and silent today after hours of violence that caused the death of three persons and scores of injuries.

title: Kiss me, she cried.
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind.It strikes me as a calamity that when the novel died the American novelist did not die too. It would have saved us time, money, perhaps even a few redwoods.

title: Some Mild Bannter Eases Pomp at Soviet Congress
description: MOSCOW, March 4 The 25th Cornmunist Party Congress, expected to wind up tomorrow, has been distinguished more by proletarian pomp than any spontaneity. SO far, it has followed the scenario. Yet a few informal touches have intruded, not the least from the party's leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: BAYH SUSPENDS NOMINATION RACE
description: Short of money and votes, Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana withdrew from the Democratic presidential race yesterday.

title: BAH SUSPENDS NOMINATION RACE
description: Short of money and votes, Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana withdrew from the Democratic Presidential race yesterday.

title: Princeton Takes East Swim Lead
description: NEW HAVEN, March 4Princeton, winning three of five events, took a strong lead tonight in an effort to ?? its fourth straight intercollegiate swimming and diving championships.

title: Conferees Agree on Bill To Tap 3 Navy Oil Fields
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 House and Senate conferees reached agreement today on a bill authorizing fullscale oil production at three of four naval petroleum reserves, including Teapot Dome in Wyoming.

title: F.C.C. Study Finds New Jersey in Need of More Local TV Service
description: WASHINGTON, March 4The Federal Communications commission today announced that an investigation it had made showed New Jersey in need of additional locally oriented television program service. But the commission has not yet decided the best way to provide it.

title: State Expects City Banks To Buy $1 Billion in Notes
description: ALBANY, March 4Eleven major New York City commercial banks are expected to agree to purchase $1 billion in shortterm state notes for their own portfolios this spring a step that would provide significant boost for the state's drive to meet its critical financing needs this year.

title: An Odd Couple on Capitol Hill: Daughter Of the Bronx and WellBred Jersey Lady
description: WASHINGTON, March 4One is a woman of privilege, the daughter of a bankerambassador, a millionairess from New Jersey's fashionable foxhunt country who speaks in a cultured voice, an old friend of the Rockefellers and Dilions, editor of Vogue's 1948 Book of Etiquette and former fashion model for Harper's Bazaar on whose svelte figure designerclothes hang gracefully.

title: An ExAtlanta Radio Official Is Convicted in Payola Case
description: NEWARK, March 4 (UPI)A onetime program director for an Atlanta radio station was given a oneyear suspended sentence today for accepting money and gifts in return for playing records on the air.

title: Catholic School Union Case
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI) The question of whether a union can act as the collective, bhrgaining agent for laymen teaching at Roman Catholic high schools will be considered by the National Labor Relations Board later this month, the N.L.R.B. announced today. The beard scheduled oran arguments March 15 on the case involving lay teachers at Catholic high schools in the Los Angeles area.

title: House Appropriates $5.39 Billion for Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Mgrch 4 (AP) The House tonight passed by a vote of 214 to 152 a $5.39 billion foreign aid appropriation bill with a rider that opponents said could cut off Israel, Egypt and many other countries from receiving its benefits.

title: Dissent in Moscow
description: About 100 foreign political groupsCommunist parties and allied leftist factionshave been in attendance the 25th Soviet Communist Party Congress. Of these a handful  notably the Rumanians, Yugoslays, Italians, British and Frenchhave attracted worldwide attention by sounding an independent note in the speeches their representatives have given to the congress.

title: Lutz Takes First Match At Cup Net
description: HARTFORD, March 4As if Bob Lutz had been waiting for a sign, he was given one tonight in the ninth game of the second set against John Alexander. The sign said Australia, and it fell at Lutz's feet.

title: Federal Panel Bans Most Firecrackers Beginning Next Fall
description: WASHINGTON. March 4 (UPI)The Consumer Product Safety Commission issued a nationwide ban today against all but the smallest firecrackers and put manufacturers of other fireworks on notice that they will have to meet stiffer safety requirements.

title: White in Florida
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 4 (UPI)Roy White joined the slowly increasing number of New York Yankees in town today saying he could not, wait any longer to begin workouts.

description: ATLANTA, March 4 (AP)Atlanta was chosen today to host the sixth annual Martin Luther King Jr. International Freedom Games track and field meet on May 22.

title: Curry Wins Title In Figure Skating
description: GOTEBORG. Sweden. March 4 (AP)John Curry of Britain tonight won his first world championship in figure skating. Added to the recent Olympic gold medal he earned, tonight's victory gave him a sweep of the sport's major titles this season.

title: Nearly Eight Billion Population By 2010 Projected by the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.. March 4The world's population, 3.89 billion in mid1974, would double by the year 2010 if the latest growth rate of 1.9 percent annually was maintained, the United Nations reported today.

title: Kodama Questioned in Japan
description: TOKYO, March 4 (AP)Prosecutors today questioned Yoshio Kodama, allegedly the former secret sales agent for Lockheed in Japan, but gave no details of his testimony.

title: French Riot Over Wine Imports
description: PARIS, March 4  Meting winegrowers, angered by importing of cheap Italian and Spanish wines, clashed with the police today in southern France, and a policeman and a demonstrator were killed.

title: Flyers 6, Scouts 1
description: KANSAS CITY, March 4 (AP)Bernie Parent, starting only his third game in goal this season stopped all but one Kansas City shot as the Philadelphia Flyers coasted to a 61 N.H.L. victory tonight over the Scouts.

description: Associated Press

title: G.T.E. DISCLOSES PAYMENTS ABROAD
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation disclosed yesterday that some of its employees appeared to have made payments totaling $2.21 million to foreign government officials over a fiveyear period.

title: Wife of Mao Appears to Play. Key Role in Ideological Drive
description: PEKING, Friday, March 5 Chiang Ching, the wife of Chairman Mao Tsetung and a leading radical force in China's Cultural Revolution of 1966 to 69,appears to oe playing a Key role in the current struggle against capitalist roaders.

title: 50State Parade Planned
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 4 (UPI)Marching units from all 50 states will participate in a sixhour parade as part of the Bicentennial Fourth of July celebration, according to Richard C. Bond, chairman of Philadelphia 76 Inc., which directs this city's Bicentennial celebration. He said yesterday that 50,000 to 70,000 persons would take part in the parade.

title: DR. JOSEPH J. DRAGO, PHYSICIAN IN QUEENS
description: Dr. Joseph J. Drago, medical director and former president of the board of directors of Astoria General Hospital, died yesterday at Newark BethIsrael Hospital in Newark. He was 73 years old and lived at 2637 12th Street, Astoria, Queens.

title: STORES SALES UP FOR CITY AND AREA
description: Retail sales in New York City and the metropolitan area continued to show strength in February according to a spot check yesterday. Department stores in the city topped the yearearlier month by 4.5 percent, while department stores in the metropolitan area showed a gain of 7 percent.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 the Association of American Etailroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.5 billion tonmiles, 2.8 percent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 466,648 cars, 1.6 percent above last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 13.8 percent above last year.

title: Mike Hill, Hayes Share Lead
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 4Sandra Hill's golf is no better than average, but she does recognize a breaking left wrist when she sees one, and as a result, her husband, Mike, is putting better these days. Scoring better too: Today Mike shot a 65 and shared the lead with Mark Hayes in the opening round of the Florida Citrus open.

title: Music: Impressive Score by Sessions
description: Although it was finished in 1957, the Third Symphony by Roger Sessions had not had a New York performance until last night in Fisher Hall.

title: Stage: Sheldon's The Boss Revived
description: In the early 1900's Edward Sheldon was a celebrated Broadway playwright, but in recent years he has been widely neglected. As a Bicentennial tribute, the Chelsea Theater Center has sought to rectify the oversight with a production of The Boss. This melodrama, which was first staged in 1911, opened yesterday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Fate of Palisades Tract Held Up at Least a Week
description: TENAFLY, March 4  The question of whether a controversial 274acre tract of woodland atop the Palisades will remain in its natural state or be converted ito a highdensity housing investment by its owner, a Texas development company will remain unanswered for at least another week.

description: PHILADELPHIA, March 5 (AP)The Philadelphia police department has agreed to hire 100 women by the end of the year for assignment as beat patrol officers.

title: RUSSIANS' DEFICIT IN TRADE WIDENS
description: The first Soviet trade figures for 1975 acknowledge that Moscow's trade deficit with the West deepened last year as reduced demand for Soviet goods in the recession combined with a surge in Western shipments of modern machinery.
