description: Selected world sold prices Friday.

title: Deaths
description: ALTCHEKM. Richard. M.D. Death exdinguished a beautiful flame with the passing of our good friend, whose proudest possession was his silver button shinffyIng his Position as an Honorary Member of the New York Turf Writers Association. General Douglas MacArthur once said, only those fit to live are not afraid to die, a phrase that best describes our departed member who was a veritable mother hen to denizens of the Press Box. He not only cared for our medical needs but also was our father  confessor. He knew well that his dreaded leukemia would take him away soon but he never wavered along the way as he went through the stretch run smiling and spreading cheer. We have lost a great man.

title: Comptroller Bars a Study Of Office by House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The Comptroller of the Currency, James E. Smith, rejected late today a proposal that would permit a House subcommittee to supervise a detailed study of the effectiveness of his office in the examination of national brinks.

description: Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., has warned the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that the West's task in the years ahead is managing global Soviet power.

title: CON ED FILES A PLAN FOR STORM KING UNIT
description: The Consolidated Edison Company submitted yesterday to the New York Public Service Commission a detailed report confirming its earlier conclusions that the proposed Cornwall pumped storage project on the Hudson River at Storm King Mountain was a necessary and desirable component of the state's future power generation program.

title: JACQUES MALINIAC, A PLASTIC SURGEON
description: Dr. Jacques W. Maliniac, a former plastic surgeon here, who was known for his research and writing on breast surgery, died yesterday in Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Miami.

title: Ashe Wins; U.S. Loses In Doubles
description: HARTFORD, March 5John Newcombe approached his snatch with Arthur Ashe tonight as if it were a challenge match; he planned to dare Ashe to beat him: If he can hit enough winners, he can have the match. But I don't think he can.

title: Rhodesia Defense Chief Thanks Kissinger for Warning to Cuba
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 5Rhodesia expressed thanks today to Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger for his warning to Cuba yesterday against possible intervention in the conflict between Rhodesia's white minority Government and African nationalists.

title: Chilean Cabinet Resigns
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 5 (Reuters)The entire Chilean Cabinet resigned tonight to give President Augusto Pinochet a free hand to reshuffle his ministers, a communique announced.

title: 2d Woman in Gridiron Club
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI)Frances Lewine, White House correspondent for The Associated Press, was elected today as a member of the Gridiron Club, formerly an allmale newspaper organization. She joins Helen Thomas, White House reporter for United Press International, as the first women members of the organization. Miss Thomas was elected last year.

title: BRITAIN GIVES UP ON ULSTER TALKS, WILL RETAIN RULE
description: LONDON, March 5The British Government, faced with the collapse of efforts to politically reconcile Protestants and Roman Catholics in Northern Ireland, announced plans today to run the province indefinitely.

title: 76ers Rally to Victory Over Pistons, 123112
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 5 (UPI)Doug Colins scored 11 points in the fourth period tonight to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 123112 comeback victory over the Detroit Pistons.

description: Lawrence K. Roos, executive vice president and director of the First Natfonal Bank in St. Louis yesterday was appointed president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, known for its independent point of vfew and qualfty of its monetary research.

title: FourYear Notes Sold At Treasury Auction
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The Treasury sold today $2 billion of fouryear notes at an average return of 7.54 percent. The Treasury recalved $5.4 billion of tenders for the notes, which will carry a coupon interest rate of 7 percent.

title: Flames Strike Quickly And Rout Rangers, 83
description: ATLANTA, March 5The slim playoff hopes of the New York Rangers went up in smoke tonight when the team they had to beat beat them instead, 83.

title: The City Kid from the Virgin Islands
description: In the gaudiest college basketball game between two local teams since shaving without a razor was declared improper by the District Attorney's office 25 years ago, unbeaten Rutgers opposes unawed St. John's at Madison Square Garden today for the Eastern College Athletic Conference Metropolitan championship, a neighborhood prelude to the N.C.A.A. tournament. All the city kids will be showing how they play what is known as the city game. But the outcome might be decided by a 6foot4inch St. John's guard, Glen Williams Jr., from a city known more for bay rum than basketball. Glen Williams grew up in Charlotte Amalie on St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands, but he leads the Redmen in scoring with an average of 14.5 points. With 25 points against St. Peter's in the Redmen's 7567 victory in Thursday night's semifinal, the bambooslim junior now has 1.024 points. Six more and he will surpass Harry Boykoff, a towering center three decades ago, among the top St. John's career scorers. But the Harry that Glen Williams is usually compared to is Belafonte; he talks with the lilt of the Caribbean, prefers yellowtail fish to steak and listens to Reggae music, a mixture of rock and calypso. His teammates call him Reggae but he grew up playing basketball to the sound of the same beat that the city kids do. The sound of a basketball bouncing on a playground court.

title: ??im Walsh, Basketball Star, Led U.S. to Olympic Medal
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 5 (UPI)  Jim Walsh, former Stanford star who was captain of the 1956 United States Olympic basketball team, which won the gold medal, died yesterday. He was 46 years old and had been hospitalized several weeks after having recently undergone two carious stomach operations.

description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 5 (UPI)A sevenwoman, five man jury will hear the trial of Sandra Good, who is accused of conspiring to mail death threats and of making threats in telephone calls.

description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 5Senator Jackson of Washington broadened his attacks on Mr. Carter, today, accusing him of favoring a weak defense.

title: GRAFT BY POLICE IS SAID TO DECLINE
description: A Police Department study of its own corruption situation has found that the integrity level within this department is the highest that it has ever been and that there is no evidence of organized graft.

description: BUENOS AIRES, March 5The Argentine peso was devalued nearly 70 percent and a 180day truce in wage and price increases was announced tonight as part of an emergency plan against inflation and foreign debt.

title: Jones, Phil Mahre 1,2 in Giant Slalom
description: COPPER MOUNTAIN, Colo., March 5 (AP)Greg Jones and Phil Mahre of the United States, in an unusual showing against the world's greatest skiers, swept the first two places today in the men's giant slalom, and Rosi Mittermaier of West Germany moved closer to her first world championship in the first World Cup stop since the 12th Winter Olympic Games at Innsbruck, Austria.

title: Inspector Is Guilty Of Taking Bribes From Grain Dealer
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 5The former chief inspector for a grain elevator here pleaded guilty today to accepting bribes from a company whose export grain shipments he was supposed to supervise.

title: U. S. LEADERSHIP A WORRY TO BONN
description: BONN, March 5The West German Government is worried about what Chancellor Helmut Schmidt sees as a leadership crisis in Washington, according to his close aides. They say that he was also mildly annoyed at President Ford for appearing to cast doubt on the Western policies of dtente in a campaign interview last Monday.

title: GROUP IN SAHARA NAMES GOVERNMENT
description: ALGIERS, March 5 (Reuters) The western Sahara independence movement known as the Polisario Front tonight named an eightman government for its newly proclaimed Saharan Arab Democratic Republic.

title: Teacher Group in State Leaves National Education Association
description: The New York State United Teachers voted yesterday to disaffiliate from the National Education Association, a move that is certain to lead to the withdrawal of some N.E.A. loyalists from the 211,000member state union. The vote was 157,400 to 37,729.

title: BAILEY CHARGES BID TO FIX CASE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 5Patricia Hearst's chief defense lawyer, F. Lee Bailey, roared at a Government witness today, Did you go and try to fix this case behind my back?

title: Triumph Follows Tragedy As Meeting Ends at Hialeah
description: MIAMI, March 5Closing day at Hialeah supplied tragedy and triumph, in that order, for Steve DiMauro today. At 10 o'clock this morning the trainer watched Sharhazad, a highly promising Damascus filly, work fiveeighths of a mile. Mr. and Mrs. W. M. Hackman, who own the 3yearold, were with DiMauro.

title: Screen: Man Friday
description: Some good people, including Peter O'Toole and Richard Roundtree, the stars, and Jack Gold, the director, have entered into a collaboration that brings out the worst in each of them. It's called Man Friday and it opened yesterday at Loews Astor plaza and Tower East Theaters.

title: Pilotless Train
description: All the tortuous efforts to restore New York City solvency will come unhinged unless the wage line held in the crucial negotiations now limping along for a new contract covering the city's subway and bus employees.

title: (Re)building OldNew Jerusalem
description: CAMBRIDGE, MASS. FIVE YEARS ago, the original plan for the future development of Jerusalem, reflecting the conventional wisdom of the 1960's, stressed the cleaning of large areas, the construction of expressways, the tearing down of the old central business district and the substitution of more modern (and therefore, by definition, higher) buildings. Soon, thereafter, fortunately, there was a period of intellectual withdrawal from the biggerisbetter syndrome, and we could benefit from the perceived mistakes of the old planning theories as already applied in the metropolitan centers of the United States and Europe.

description: BASKETBALL

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HIGH FLYING Sonja Henie is a name seldom mentioned these days amid all the movie nostalgia. For that matter, the iceskater's films don't often appear on television anymore. The Sky Rink, that perennial midtown haven for icecutters, tonight is featuring a musical Salute to Sonja Henie with a jazzband performance, including a number of songs from the skater's movies.

Cunningham, the state Democratic chairman, filed an extensive motion yesterday with the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, attacking the authority and motives of Maurtce H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, in seeking his appearance before a special grand jury investigating the alleged sale of judgships in the Bronx.

title: Business Briefs
description: A suit that an aerosol company had filed against the public relations firm of Ruder & Finn was dismissed yesterday by Judge Richard Owen in Federal District Court here.

title: Big Day for Turcotte: Six Aqueduct Winners
description: Ron Turcotte became the sixth jockey in New York major thoroughbred racing history to ride six winners in one day, accomplishing the feat yesterday at Aqueduct. Among his winners was Samuel Lehrman's Campaign Donation, who won the $20,000 feature by two leneths.

title: Angola Faction Announces SteppedUp Guerrilla Drive
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, March 5 (Reuters)Dr. Jonas Savimbi, leader of the National Union for the Total Liberation of Angola, has announced a steppedup guerrilla campaign against Cuban and Government forces in Angola.

title: A Victory for Guns
description: A subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee brought a tepid little guncontrol compromise to the full committee and learned a lesson it should have known all along: that the gun lobby will scream as loudly at craftily designed halfway bills as it will at guncontrol legislation with teeth.

title: Group in Englewood Joins Drive to Buy East Hill Site
description: TENAFLY, March 5  The Jewish Community Center of Englewood has offered $1 million for 29 acres of the 274acre East Hill woodlands to help Tenafly preserve the remainder of the tract from a housing development, Mayor John G. Manos announced today.

title: Article Divulges Details of Kissinger Mideast Talks
description: WASHINGTON, March 5Extensive details of Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's hitherto secret discussions with Middle East leaders have been divulged in an article just pubfished.

title: Seaver Warns Mets of Jump
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5Tom Seaver, seeking a threeyear contract for $800,000, said today that the New York Mets could have made a hell of a deal with me two months ago but that his price would be higher now to keep him from jumping to another club.

title: G.O.P. KICKBACKS ARE CHARGED TO 8
description: MINEOLA, L.I., March 5Federal and Nassau County grand juries investigating allegations of 1 percent kickbacks to the Nassau Republican Party returned a total of nine indictments today against the administrative assistant to the Nassau Republican chairman and seven present or former officials of the Town of Hempstead.

title: Connecticut Bonds
description: Moody's Investors Service has reduced Connecticut's bondcredit rating from AA to A1, the second such reduction in a year, Gov. Ella T. Grasso announced. Page 52.

title: A Recall Is Sought Onlnfant Pacifiers After Baby's Death
description: NEWARRK, March 5Federal and state consumer agencies were attempting today to recall more than 150,000 baby pacifiers of the type that caused the death by asphyxiation of a 5monthold infant in the Bronx on Feb. 16.

title: $218.9 Million Loss Is Listed by Pennsy
description: The Penn Central Transportation Company reported yesterday that despite a narrowing of its December loss from a year before, the country's largest railroad lost a record of $218.9 million in 1975, up from $178.2 million in 1974.

title: 3 WHITES INDICTED IN '57 BLACK DEATH
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 5Three white men, identified by a colleague as onetime members of the Ku Klux Klan, were indicted by a grand jury today on a charge of first degree murder in connection with, the drowning death of a young black man 19 years ago.

title: Elevator Concern Accused In Explosion Fatal to Five
description: LANSING, Mich. March 5 (UPI)The State Labor Department concluded today that a spark from a welding torch set off a grain elevator explosion that killed five workers in Milawukee and cited the elevator operator for three willful safety violations.

title: Imports of Cotton From China Soar
description: Imports of cotton textiles from China have climbed sharply in the fourth quarter of 1075, bringing cries of alarm from the United States textile industry.

title: Israel Objects to Sale Of U. S. Planes to Egypt
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (Reuters)Israel formally objected tonight to the proposed United States sale of six C130 transport planes to Egypt, saying it was opposed to any militarysupply relationship between Washington and Cairo.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A woman employed as a Police Department administrative aid has been suspended from the force for failing to tell her commanding officer that she had been arrested three weeks ago on a charge of cheating on welfare payments. A polite spokesman said that the aide, Yvonne Price, who had been assigned to clerical duties at the 10th Precinct, was arrested on Feb. 18 and accused of collecting $3,316 in welfare payments in the last year while employed by the department. She became a police administrative aide in August 1973.

title: 7 of the Democratic Delegate Candidates: Why They Run
description: For the first time in many years, the New York Democratic Presidential primary will be a crucial part of the process of winnowing out Presidential hopefulsa procedure that began in New Hampshire last week.

title: U.S. TO URGE PACT IN U.N. TO COMBAT CORPORATE BRIBES
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The United States today proposed an international pact to to combat corporate bribery and promised to answer eventually those governments seeking the identities of officials bribed by Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Art: Portraits by Richard Yarde Evoke Black Heroes
description: Nothing is more difficult nowadays than to paint a portrait of a legendary figure of history, and make it pictorially as well as historically credible. Contemporary taste is suspicious of the kind of pictorial rhetoric that is called for in the portrayal of legendary personalities, and contemporary painting provides few useful precedents for its realization. The obvious temptation is to retreat into a pastiche of some earlier historical style, but the results are usually pious than persuasive.

title: Miss Krapsak Favors Talk of Her Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, March 5Mary Anne Krupsak said today that I do not discourage speculation that she might be nominated for the Vice Presidency by the Democrats this year.

title: Response Is Mixed to Request By Gulf for Return of Payments
description: PITTSBURGH, March 5 (AP) Initial response to the Gulf Oil Corporation's request that politicians who accepted illegal corporate campaign contributions return the money has been mixed. a check shows.

title: Birth Rate Declines For Fifth Year in Row
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)The country's birth rate declined in 1975 for the fifth consecutive year and slowed appreciably during the second half of the year, the Government said today.

description: BILLIEIn memory of a great lady who was my heart, my life, my love. May 1, 1941.

title: City's Outlook Viewed as Good For a Place to Run a Business
description: Cities, basically, are places to exchange information, goods and services, and New York still provides richer opportunities for these exchanges than any other city, Prof. Eli Ginzberg of Columbia University said yesterday in an assessment of New York's economic future for leading business and public officials.

title: At 100, Legal Aid Strives to Live Within Budget
description: Founded 100 years ago by merchants who hired one parttime lawyer to give free legal advice to worthy German immigrants, the Legal Aid Society has emerged as a central force in the city's criminalJustice system.

title: In Denmark, Child Custody Case Stirs a Major Dispute
description: COPENHAGEN  Birgitte Jensen was born on June 26, 1972, but spent only three days with her parents. A social worker said that the infant's parents seemed unable to care for her, so the child was placed in an institution.

title: Recall of Infant Pacifiers Sought After Baby's Death
description: NEWARK, March 5Federal, and state consumer agencies were attempting today to recall more than 150,000 baby pacifiers of the type that caused the death by asphyxiation of a 5monthold infant in the Bronx on Feb. 16.

title: Maryland Is Upset By Virginia
description: LANDOVER, Md., March 5 (AP)Phil Ford scored 14 firsthalf points tonight as North Carolina opened a big lead and defeated Clemson, 8274, in the semifinals of the Atlantic Coast Conference baketball tournament.

title: Rifkind Gives Plan to End Impasse on Transfer Tax
description: Former Federal Judge Simon It Rifkind, responding to a state call for assistance, was reported yesterday to have found a way to neutralize the state's controversial stock transfer tax and to hall the flow of Wall Street brokers to New Jersey.

title: TV Auction to Aid 7 Arts Institutions In Brooklyn Tonight
description: Television viewers will be able to bid tonight for such things as honorary ownership of the Brooklyn Bridge for a day, an organically homegrown luncheon for two in Stewart Mott's penthouse garden, a party for 30 on an antique Chinese junk or their own wedding ceremony at the Cloisters.

title: Catholics Changing Concept and Practice of Confession
description: For Roman Catholics, as for most churchgoers, being a Christian sometimes means having to say you're sorry. And for seven centuries Catholics have been expected to follow a set procedure for confessing mortal sins by speaking to a priest who is behind a screen in the confession box.

title: Sketches of Three Promoted in Soviet
description: Grigory V. Romanov

title: Citibank Rate Steady
description: Citibank announced yesterday that It was keeping its prime rate at 8 percent. The rate had been raised from 8 percent on Feb. 27.

title: Reported Exchanges Between the U. S. Secretary of State and Middle East Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, March 5Following are excerpts from what are described in the spring issue of the quarterly magazine Foreign Policy as verbatim conversations held by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger with the late King Faisal of Saudi Arabia in Riyadh in November 1973 and with Israeli officials in March 1975. Mr. Kissinger said today that the material appeared to be based on memorandums of conversations, but denied that the text was a verbatim transcrip.

title: JELL0 TEST FINDS LIFELIKE SIGNAL
description: An Ontario neurologist Made a brain wave analysis of a blob of lime Jello and obtained readings that he said could be mistaken as evidence of life.

title: Smalley Resigns As Coach of Navy
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 5 (AP)Dave Smalley, head basketball coach at the United States Naval Academy for the last 10 years, resigned today effective May 31 to devote full time to other academy duties.

title: Radio
description: 68 A.M., WQXR: Symphony No. 39, Mozart; Suite Pastorale, Atterberg; King Stephen Overture, Beethoven; Autumn from symphony No. 2, Hadley; Violin& Concerto, Sibelius; Dance from The Oprichnik. Tchaikovsky; Summer Night on the River, Delius; Excerpts from Les Rendezvous, AuberLambert; Inferno from Dante Symphony, Liszt.

title: TOTAL EMPLOYED ROSE IN FEBRUARY TO JULY 1974 PEAK
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 The Labor Department reported today that the employment situation continued to improve in February, but that the advances in the broad categories of jobholding and unemployment, were slight.

title: Value of the Pound Drops Below $2 for First Time
description: LONDON, March 5  The British pound, once the pillar of the world's economy, fell below $2 for the first time today. For the last six months, the pound had come close to falling through the psychological barrier. Today, it closed at $1.975.

title: PROF. HARRY HOIJER, ANTHROPOLOGIST, 71
description: Harry Hoijer, professor emeritus of anthropology at the University of California in Los Angeles, died Thursday in a Santa Monica hospital after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived in the suburb of Brentwood.

title: Light Bulb Costing $10 May Last for 10 Years
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI)The Energy Research and Development Administration today announced plans for commercial production of a revolutionary new light bulb that consumes 70 percent less electricity and may not burn out for 10 years.

title: When Anxious Over Decorating, Eight Heads Are Better Than One
description: The five women sat on the floor earnestly discussing their problems, with occasional interruptions and suggestions from the leader.

title: PENSION TAX RISE SEEN LESS LIKELY
description: WASHINGTON, March 5A House subcommittee supplied more evidence today that Congress would not raise the Social Security tax rate this year, as requested by President Ford.

title: Screen: Man Friday
description: Some good people, including Peter O'Toole and Richard Roundtree, the stars, and Jack Gold, the director, have entered into a collaboration that brings out the worst in each of them. It's called Man Friday and it opened yesterday at Loews Astor Plaza and Tower East Theaters.

title: Jersey Lists Instant Lottery
description: New Jersey will start a third Instant Lottery contest this summer with a grand prize in excess of $1 million, according to Henry Luther, director of the lottery commission. The present instant game, the 1776 Lottery, is scheduled to end Wednesday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Lee Morganstein, an 18yearold youth from Teaneck, was found guilty early yesterday of premeditated murder in the fatal shooting last July of Kimberly McIntosh, a Teaneck beauty queen and professional model. He showed no reaction as the foreman of the sevenwoman, fiveman jury announced the verdict in Superior Court after eight and a half hours of deliberations. Judge Fred Galda ordered Mr. Morgenstein held in the Bergen County Jail and scheduled sentencing for April 30. The conviction carries a mandatory term of life imprisonment.

title: Listing of Prices for Contracts in Futures of Commodities
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 5, 1976

title: Arkansas Rights Figure Dies
description: Lothaire Scott Green, a retired teacher whose son Ernest was the first black graduate of Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., died Wednesday at her home there. She died two days before her 77th birthday, but last Monday 750 people, including national civilrights leaders, honored her at a prebirthday party in New Orleans.

title: 1,500 Detroit Employees To Be Laid Off April 1
description: DETROIT, March 6 (AP)From 1,500 to 2,000 city employees will be laid off April 1 to help cut Detroit's budget deficit, according to Deputy mavnr William Beckham Jr.

title: State Police in Iran End U.S. Advisory Assistance
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 5 (AP)Iran has formally ended the services of the United States advisory mission to its state police after 34 years of assistance.

title: Carter Charges Jackson With Lies and Distortions
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 5After his canvassers found recent erosion among his supporters, Jimmy Carter dramatically altered the tone of his Florida campaign today by accusing Senator Henry M. Jackson of using lies, distortions and scare tactics to enhance his own Presidential pursuit.

title: 3 Injured in Explosion On Wards Island Tower
description: An explosion ripped through the walls of a water tower atop a 19story psychiatric hospital on Wards Island yesterday morning, critically injuring a workman and sending chunks of brick and mortar the size of footballs through the ceiling of the infirmary. The debris narrowly missed 18 patients.

title: Welshmen Think Twice, or Thrice, About Home Rule
description: NEATH, WalesThe night before, R. Gwyn Jones, a school principal here, had been sitting in a pub on the edge of Swansea Bay, drinking a pint of lager and facing as Weistunen love to dothe question of his Welshness. In the end he seemed to decide that while he was British too, that Wales was inextricably linked to the rest of the United Kingdom, and that people who had thrown their souls into the task of rebuilding a separate Welsh identity had their priorities a bit wrong.

title: BAILEY CHARGES BID TO FIX CASE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 5Patricia Hearst's chief defense lawyer, F. Lee Bailey, roared at a Government witness today, Did you go and try to fix this case behind my back?

title: FUTURES PRICES OF SUGAR ADVANCE
description: Sugar futures continued to move up yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange with the May delivery closing at 14.94, up from 14.75 cents a pound. There was no confirmation of previously rumored Soviet buying, but yesterday Brazil declared a force majeure on sugar.

title: Union to Vote on Bus Company's Offer
description: TRENTON, March 5Union officials were reported today to be split over whether 3,400 drivers and other employees of Transport of New Jersey would approve the last contract offer by the company.

title: Cancer Death Rate Grew Sharply in Last Two Years
description: WASHINGTON, March 5Government experts on health statistics now estimate that the United States death rate from cancer rose more sharply last year than in any previous year since World War II.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Skaggs Companies, a Salt Lake Citybased retail drugstore chain, yesterday said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed sale of 1 million common shares through underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc.

title: 7 of the Democratic Delegate Candidates: Why They Run
description: For the first time in many years, the New York Democratic Presidential primary will be a crucial part of the process of winnowing out Presidential hopefulsa procedure that began in New Hampshire last week.

title: Open Interest
description: Friday, March 5, 1976

title: Miss Cain Captures Collegiate Ski Race
description: BOYNE FALLS, Mich., March 5 (AP)Mitzi Cain of Middlebury College was first in the 7.5kilometer crosscountry race at Boyne Mountain today, as the first national collegiate women's ski competition got under way.

title: Notes on People
description: Toppled from his Congressional power by alcoholism and public incidents with a striptease dancer, Representative Wilbur D. Mills called it quits yesterday and said he would not run for a 20th term.

title: Gravediggers Union Threatens to Strike
description: The gravediggers union in the metropolitan area has threatened to strike 48 Catholic, Jewish and nonsectarian cemeteries at 7 A.M. Monday unless an agreement is reached on a new threeyear contract.

title: Shakeup by Air Force Eliminates 2,610 Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI)The Air Force has announced a tactical air control reorganization that will eliminate 1,020 active duty jobs, 1,534 Air National Guard positions and 56 civilian posts.

title: Reagan Declares He's in Race to the End
description: VENICE, Fla., March 5Ronald Reagan campaigned down the West Coast of Florida today and reassured supporters at shopping center malls and retirement villages that a defeat in next Tuesday's primary (would not force him to abandon his challenge to President Ford.

title: EXJUSTICE JONES OF CLAIMS COURT
description: AMARILLO, Tex., March 5 (AP)Marvin Jones, former Chief Justice of the United States Court of Claims, former chairman of the House Agriculture Committee and an instrumental figure in much of the New Deal's farm legislation, died yesterday. He was 94 years old.

title: Zarley Leads Golf by 2 Shots
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 5Kermit Zarley, who returned to golf competition in January after a chancy operation to fuse discs in the vertebrae of his neck, zoomed past the opposition today and took the lead in the second round of the Florida Citrus open.

title: 11 Lawyers Leave Firm Being Investigated by U. S.
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 5 (AP)Eleven attorneys have resigned from a major Philadelphia law firm that has been the target of a Federal investigation in New Jersey.

title: Books of The Times
description: This selective autobiography by the other Nabokov is concerned only occasionally with balletit touches more upon social historybut it is, written by a composer whose career can be identified with three controversial landmark ballets.

title: Whooping Cranes Stir Hope
description: MONTE VISTA, Colo., March 5 (UPI)  Wildlife biologists hope that four young whooping cranes will form the nucleus of a new flock of the endangered birds. The birds, born in Idaho last summer, flew into a wildlife refuge near Monte Vista recently after spending the winter along the Rio Grande in central New Mexico.

title: Flu and Pneumonia Hit Epidemic Levels In All U.S. Regions
description: ATLANTA, March 5 (AP)Deaths linked to influenza and pneumonia reached epidemic levels in every region of the nation last week for the first time this year, the Center for Disease Control reported today.

title: Strike Spree for Bowler
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, March 5 (UPI)  John Pezzin, a 46yearold Perrysburg, Ohio, bowler rolled 33 consecutive strikes last night in a sanctioned bowling league. Pezzin rolled games of 259, 300 and 300 for an 859 series.

title: Another Mandate?
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization leader, Yasir Arafat, is reportedly interested in the possibility of a United Nations trusteeship over the Jordan West Bank and Gaza Strip, pending an ultimate political settlement for the Palestinians of the two Israelioccupied areas. The notion might well be dismissed by neutral observers as a mere trial balloonor, by Israeli partisans, as a Trojan horseor, by some Arabi, even as a red herring. But, whatever the metaphor, it is at least a fresh element in a diplomatic morass, out of which some possibly useful discussions might emerge.

title: 8 on L.I. Accused of G.O.P. Kickbacks
description: MINEOLA, LI., March 5Federal and Nassau County grand juries investigating allegations of 1 percent kickbacks to the Nassau Republican Party returned a total of nine indictments today against the administrative assistant to the Nassau Republican chairman and seven present or former officials of the Town of Hempstead.

title: Malverne Quintet, Freeport in Final
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 5Freeport defeated Lynbrook, 7372, and Malverne overcame Westbury, 6043, today at the Nassau Coliseum and gained the final of the Nassau County scholastic basketball tournament.

title: DEMOCRATS ALTER WISCONSIN VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The Democratic Party stretched its own rules today to make the Wisconsin Presidential primary election on April 6 a binding test that will select 68 national convention delegates as well as serving as a popularity contest for Presidential candidates.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: People in Sports
description: Although he did not receive the $200,000 salary that he had been aiming for, Pete Rose signed a contract with the Cincinnati Reds yesterday and said he was pleased with it.

title: Byhre Gets Coaching Post
description: RICHMOND, Ky March 5 (UPI)Ed Byhre, an assistant basketball coach the last three seasons at Eastern Kentucky, was elevated to the head coaching job today at the Ohio Valley Conference school. Byhre replaces Bob Mulcahy, who resigned earlier in the season.

title: Rights of Spring
description: With only a few days to go before the first scheduled exhibition game and little more than a month before opening day, winter's hotstove league has been extended and spring training has not yet started for professional baseball in North America. Most of the sliders and doubleplays are taking place In hotel rooms where the player representatives and the club owners are trying to interpret for the umpteenth time the meaning of the reserve clause that binds players teams forever and a day. Until a compromise is worked out, the club managements have padlocked the ballfields.

title: N.Y.U. Leads Penn In Eastern Fencing
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 5 New York University, the defending team champion, held a narrow 5352 lead over the University of Pennsylvania at the end of the first day of competition in the 79th annual Intercollegiate Fencing Association championships at the United States Naval Academy.

title: Adm. Herbert Knowles, 81, Early Submarine Leader
description: ELIOT, Me., March 5Rear Adm. Herbert B. Knowles, a retired Naval officer in both World Wars and a pioneer submarine commander, died Wednesday at the Maine Medical Center in Portland. He was 81 years old.

title: Finnish Skier Is First
description: LAHTI, Finland, March 5 (AP)Juha Mieto of Finland won the 15kilometer (9.3 miles) crosscountry race at the International Lahti ski games today in 40 minutes 16.98 seconds. Yevgeny Belyayev, an Olympic silver medal winner from the Soviet Union, was second in 40:49.07 and Srto Koivisto of Finland, an Olympic bronze winner, was third in 40:52.95. No Americans were entered.

title: York College Fights Conversion to a 2Year Status . . .
description: Michael Fine, a senior at York College in Queens, lives in the shadow of Brooklyn College. There else 50,000 students at Brooklyn, he said yesterday. I wanted something more personal, something I could be a part of.

title: Carter Is Praised by Auto Workers Chief
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5I like a man who has the courage to discuss the simple verities, said Leonard Woodcock. I like a man who can say with simple grace, God bless you. We need a man with vision to pull this country together.

title: Miss Hamill Leading in Title Skate
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, March 5 (UPI)The only hope for a United States gold medal in the world figure skating championships lies with Dorothy Hamill, 19 years old, the Olympic's champion, who moved up to first place today after winning the women's short program with an almost perfect performance that earned her 87.36 points and 14.5 ordinals.

title: TOTAL EMPLOYED ROSE IN FEBRUARY TO JULY 1974 PEAK
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The Labor Department reported today that the employment sits nation continued to improve in February, but that the advances in the broad categories of jobholding and unemployment, were slight.

title: Still Too Few Jobs
description: The number of people with jobs in this country has climbed back to its prerecession peak of 86.3 million. That is welcome evidence of recovery from the worst economic slump in nearly four decades. But the sharp growth in the labor force in the last year and a half means that the army of jobseekers is still above seven million, an intolerably high figure.

title: Roosevelt Entries
description: Horses listed in order or post Positions, Letter designates OTB listing. FIRST$6,000, pace, Class C2, mile.

title: Pilot Killed in Plane Crash
description: READING, Pa., March 5 (AP) A twinengine plans crashed in the woods near the Berks County village of Knauers yesterday, killing the pilot, Silvio Adamo, 52 years old, of Chambersburg.

title: ARCO HAS BEGUN TALKS WITH PETRO
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company announced yesterday that it had entered discussions with Petro Canada, a wholly owned Canadian Government company, contemplating the sale of Atlantic Rich field's wholly owned subsidiary, Atlantic Richfield Canada Ltd. for a price of about $400 million. The price, it was said, is based on Arco's reserve evaluations and is subject to certain adjustments. PetroCanada has a 90day period to review and verify the data furnished on the properties and other assets held by Atlantic Richfield Canada and to carry out an independent appraisal.

title: Murphy Decries President's Policy on Ocean Dumping
description: Representative John M. Murphy, Democrat of Staten Island, said yesterday at the end of a series of legislative hearings that the Ford Administration's handling of the Ocean Dumping Act is a national disgrace.

title: Archbishop Bartoletti Dies
description: ROME, March 5 (UPI)Msgr, Enrico Bartoletti, secretary generas of the Italian Catholic Bishops' conference and former Archbishop of Lucca, died to day of a heart ailment. He was 59 years old.

title: Mrs. Meir Resumes Role In Her Party's Leadership
description: TEL AVIV, March 5Golda Meir came out of political retirement today to resume an active role in the leadership of Israel's governing Labor Party and help the hardpressed Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin.

title: Rutgers, St. John's To Clash
description: Rutgers and St. John's basketball players and their fans, who have long anticipated a shootout at Madison Square Garden, will have it today this afternoon at 3 o'clock in the final of the Eastern College Athletic Conference metropolitan regional playoff.

title: Nebraska Agency and NBC Settle Dispute on Logotype
description: LINCOLN, Neb., March 5 (AP) Nebraska's Educational Television Commission voted toilay to accept $500,000 worth of new and used television eclitipment from the National Broadcasting Company as part of a legal settlement ending a dispute over rights to a television logotype.

title: Boeing Notes In Overseas
description: SEATTLE, March 5 (AP)The Boeing Company has made commission payments of $70 million in its overseas sales work during the last five years, the company acknowledged today. A spokesman said the payments to sales agents and subcontractors were all legal.

title: Leopold Balleisen, Engineer, IndustrialRelations Expert
description: Leopold L. Balleisen, a civil engineer and industrialrelations consultant here for more than half a century, died Wednesday in a hospital in Louisville, Ky. He was 80 years old and lived in Louisville.

title: U.N. Group Urges U.S. Insure Safety Of Foreign Aides
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March, 5A United Nations committee, prompted by a recent shooting in the Soviet diplomatic residence in Riverdale, adopted a resolution today urging the United States to insure the security of foreign official missions and their personnel here.

title: JERSEY SENATORS ASSAIL F.C.C. TV STEP
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI) A decision by the Federal Communication Commission to seek further comment on how to improve television coverage of New Jersey is little more than continued stalling, according to both New Jersey Senators.

title: Whose Primary?
description: The New York Democratic primary has almost nothing to do with democracy and almost everything to do with the retention of power by the party's political bosses this statebecause of the most complicated, undemocratic and expensive primary rules imaginable.

title: Recital
description: A dark vein of satire runs through Russian literature, early and late, and has been faithfully reflected in Russian music. Mussorgsky wrote some of the more biting songs in all music, Prokofiev's caustic wit became his bench mark, and Shostakovich was their most prominent heir in this respect. Unfortunately, musical satire is a product that does not travel terribly well as a rule, especially when it is linked to words. Muscovite satire is probably what closes in Tbilisi, and the other way around.

title: Emigre Body Lists Aides At U. N. as Soviet Agents
description: Four European migr organizations have sent to nonCommunist United Nations delegations lists of names and addresses of Soviet and Polish officials here they say are secret agents of the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence and internal security agency. They asked for expulsion of the officials.

description: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n

title: Value of the Pound Drops Below $2 for First Time
description: a result of factors beyond Britain's direct control. Rumors have been rife in Europe for weeks that another troubled currency, the French franc, could be devalued at any moment. If so, a chain reaction would rumble through many other currencies, forcing them to realign with the franc.

title: SUBWAY STATION SCORED AS UNSAFE
description: Representative Bella S. Abzug and members of Community Planning Board 7 toured the 72d Street IRT subway station yesterday, pointing out allegedly unsafe conditions.

title: Television
description: 5:30 (4)Agriculture, U.S.A.

title: BRITAIN GIVES UP ON ULSTERR TALKS WILL RETAIN RULE
description: LONDON, March 5The British Government, faced with the collapse of efforts to politically reconcile Protestants and Roman Catholics in Northern Ireland, announced plans today to run the province indefinitely.

title: Post Office Closings Permitted If Service Abides by the Rules
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI)A Federal judge ruled today that the United States Postal Service had the right to shut down 600 rural post offices, provided it gave a 90day notice and surveyed the effect on mail users.

title: Airplane Noise Challenged in Coast Case
description: SAN FRANCISCOA littlenoted suit pending in United States District Court here is looked to by environmental lawyers as the possible key to resolving a virtual governmental deadlock over reducing airplane noise.

title: ...While Hostos College Resists Its Elimination
description: Lucila Caranton speaks little English, works nights at a garment factory in Long Island City, Queens, and came to this country five years ago from her native Colombia, to battle alone.

title: Two New Disturbances Break Out in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, March 5  As Palestinian and Lebanese troops took up new policing duties in Beirut today, disturbances were reported in two areas following a chain of violet incidents yesterday.

title: HOUSING ACTIVISTS RELATIVELY QUIET
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The problem of housing the nation's poor, always difficult but considerably worse during the recent recession, has produced none of the stirring calls for remedial action that might be expected in a Presidential election year.

title: The Value of U.S.Brazilian Consultation
description: DURHAM, N.H. SECRETARY of State Henry A. Kissinger's agreement to consult Brazil on all major events of international significance should be taken seriously, because Brazil is South America's dominant power and will wield increasing influence on the African side of the South Atlantic basin. A United States policy that recognizes regional preeminence is realistic and serves our national interest by preserving a friendship that is as utilitarian as it is mutually attractive.

title: COPIERDUPLICATORS INTRODUCED BY I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation's Office, Products division introduced two models of its I.B.M. Series III copierduplicator in Chicago yesterday. The new models are reportedly much faster than the previous line and feature an advanced document feed, completely automated duplexing and a rated speed of 4,500 copies an hour. Optional with both models, designated Model 10 and Model 20, are one of two collators, each with 20 bins.

title: Ford Nominates Two Men To the Federal Court Here
description: President Ford has nominated Federal Magistrate Gerard L. Goettel and Charles S. Haight Jr., an admiralty lawyer, to be judges of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: 4 Wallace Delegate Slates Off State's Primary Ballot
description: Four slates of delegate candidates pledged to Gov. George C. Wallace have been tentatively removed from the New York Presidential primary ballot because of irregularities in filing petitions. And two other slates are under investigation for alleged fraud as part of a challenge that could eliminate the Alabamian as a significant factor in the April 6 primary.

title: DR: DOROTHY K. NASH, NEUROSURGEON, DIES
description: PITTSBURGH, March 5Dr. Dorothy Klenke Nash, who is said to have been the only woman neurosurgeon in the United States from 1928 to 1960, died today at a nursing home. She was 77 years old.

title: President, in Illinois, Proposes Doubling Individual Exemption in Inheritance Tax
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 5 President Ford proposed here today that Congress more than double, to $150,000, the amount of an individual's estate that is exempted from Federal inheritance taxes. The exemption is now $60,000.

title: Value of the Pound Drops Below $2 for First Time
description: LONDON, March 5  The British pound, once the pillar of the world's economy, fell below $2 for the first time today. For the last six months, the pound had come close to falling through the psychological barrier. Today, it closed at $1.975.

title: RUSSIANS' DEFICIT IN TRADE WIDENS
description: The first Soviet trade figures for 1975 acknowledge that Moscow's trade deficit with the West deepened last year as reduced demand for Soviet goods in the recession combined with a surge in Western shipments of modern machinery.

title: 2 BROKERS FOUND GUILTY OF FRAUD
description: Two stockbrokers, Edwin Mendlinger and Stanley Snyder, have been convicted of conspiracy and stock fraud in a scheme that included illegal payoffs disguised as payments to charitable institutions.

title: Market Place
description: Some traders and investors who are beginning to feel comfortable with listed option market calls are moving to new strategies in their search for profits.

title: Lead Taken By Wyoming In Title Ski
description: BETHEL, Me., March 5Paced by Mike Meleski, a 145  pound freshman who learned to ski and race in the flat country of central Minnesota, the University of Wyoming today replaced Dartmouth as the leader in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championships.

title: Giscard: II  European
description: PARIS FRANCE makes no secret of the fact that it is seriously concerned about a growing appearance of paralysis in United States foreign policy, as recently displayed in Africa and even Europe. This is not a matter of conflict between Paris and Washington, only of preoccupation here.

title: 4 Killed in Illinois Blaze
description: DAKOTA, Ill., March 5 (UPI) A fire that burned through a twostore frame home early today killed four members of a family and injured two others, the authorities said. Sgt. Dennis Lamcreaux, 36 years old, of the Stevenson County Sheriff's Department, and his wife, Beverly, 28, and their two children, Todd, S, and Shawn, 17 months, were pronounced dead at their home in this rural community, which is about 15 miles northeast of Freeport in northern Illinois. Two older children were in satisfactory condition.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
description: WESTBURY, L.I. (OTB payoff subject to 5% State tax.)

title: MODERN ART TOWER HIRES AN ARCHITECT
description: Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, a large St. Louisbased architectural firm with offices here, has been named to do preliminary designs for the proposed condominium tower to be built atop an addition to the Museum of Modern Art.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 6, 1976

title: PRIEST IS QUERIED IN LOCKHEED CASE
description: TOKYO, March 5Japanese police questioned today a Spanishborn Catholic priest, who is a naturalized Japanese citizen, about his alleged role as a channel for secret Lockheed funds coming into Japan.

title: Bowater Names Executive
description: John P. Fucigna has joined Bowater Inc. as its treasurer, the company announced yesterday. It is the management company for all Bowater pulp and paper interests in North America. Mr. Fucigna had been with the MartinMarietta Corporation 12 years.

title: Polyarisky Up From Farm to Politburo And Down After a Harvest Disaster
description: MOSCOW, March 5Born on Nov. 7, 1917, the very day the Bolsheviks took power, Dmitri Stepanovich Polyansky rose rapidly through the ranks of Communist politicians, hovered for a while at the fringes of substantive power, then began a long fall that culminated today in his ouster from the ruling Politburo. It was a career shaped and bruised by the roughandtumble world of Soviet politics.

title: 2 AMERICANS FREED BY LISBON WORKERS
description: LISBON, March 5 (UPI)Striking Communistled workers today treed two American tire executives they had kept locked in their factory since Monday in Lisbon's industrial Red Belt.

title: South Korea Frees One Critic of Park But Seizes Another
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 6South Korean security officials continued their investigation yesterday of a group of dissidents who criticized the Government last Monday and called on President Park Chung Hee to step down.

title: Connecticut's Bond Rating Reduced 2d Time in Year
description: HARTFORD, March 5Moody's Investors Service has reduced Connecticut's bond credit rating from AA to A1, the second such reduction in a year, Gov. Ella T. Grasso announced here today.

title: Bank Bandits, Doused With Dye, Drop Money
description: LIVONIA, Michigan, March 5 (UPI)When six machine guncarrying bandits took a money bag from a Livonia branch of the Michigan National Bank yesterday, an electronic triggering device doused them in red dye, Livonia Police Chief Robert Turner said. They dropped the money bag and fled.

title: STOCKS END WEEK ON UPWARD NOTE
description: Stock prices closed out tne first week of March with a modest gain yesterday in comparatively light turnover as the list appeared to extend its cut? rent consolidation period following the large advance registered in January and February.

title: American Motors Again Cuts Output For Pacer Model
description: DETROIT, March 5Because of disappointing sales and high stocks, the American Motors Corporation said today it was cutting back Pacer production 25 percent more in a move that will indefinitely lay off another 1,000 workers at its Wisconsin plants.

title: Plane Flown Off Mountain After DrugCargo Seizure
description: CEDARTOWN, Ga., March 5 (AP)The fourengine plane that landed on a perilous moutttain airstrip last August with a load of marijuana has been flown out safely.

title: Sentenced in Kidnapping
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 5 (AP)  Kenneth J. Royce, 18 years old, and John Szynwelski, 20, both of Ann Arbor, yesterday were given 20year to 40year, jail terms for the Sept. 29 kidnapping of the family of William Schulenberg, 50, an executive at the General Motors Hydramatic plant in neighboring Ypsilanti. Mrs. Schulenberg and three sons were held overnight in the trunk of the family car until Mr. Schulenberg raised $54,000 ransom money the next day.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Companies Report sales and Earnings
description: For pariods ended December 31 unless otherwise Indicated.

title: Florida's Elderly Raise Hopes of Ford and Jackson
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5If President Ford defeats, Ronald Reagan in the Republican primary in Florida next Tuesday, it will be largely because the President seems to have a lock on the elderly vote, according to politicians, pollsters and other political analysts.

title: The Trenton Times Is Limited by Court. In Covering a Trial
description: TRENTON. March 5A Mercer County judge yesterday ordered The Trenton Times to limit its coverage of an ongoing murder trial to the evidence taken in the presence of the jury.

title: The Dance: Harlem Troupe at Its Best
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem, now finishing the second of its five weeks at the Uris Theater, came up with an exciting program and some of its best dancing Thursday night.

title: Up to 1,000 in the Race For 205 Delegate Posts
description: As many as 1,000 Democrats will be running for the 205 district delegate posts to be filled in the April 6 primary. Sixtynine additional delegates will be selected by the Democratic State Committee and apportioned to each candidate on the basis of the primary returns.

title: First Ugandans Fly MIG's
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 5 (AP)The first Uganda pilots trained to fly MIG21's by Soviet experts in Uganda have made their initial solo flights in the jets, the Uganda radio announced. The broadcast said President Idi Amin saw the flights at Entebbe Airport on Wednesday and praised the Russians for helping black Africans.

title: U. S. TO URGE PACT IN U. N. TO COMBAT CORPORATE BRIBES
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The United States today proposed an international pact to to combat corporate bribery and promised to answer eventually those governments seeking the identities of officials bribed by Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Senate Democrats Seek Leaders' Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The maneuvering among Senate Democrats to choose new leaders next January intensified today as active contests developed for the party's two top Senate leadership posts.

title: Baseball Players Reported To Have Toughened Stand
description: Rule of thumb for figuring out the baseball dilemma: the shorter the negotiating session the farther away spring training is.

title: Dance: Pilobolus Images
description: The ways of destiny are mysterious. The Pilobolus Dance Theter has existed, happily even triumphantly, for nearly five years. It has appeared around town, been praised in the United States and in Europe. Yet I had never seen it until last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Everyone had told me about the company, but the uncertain trajectory of our schedules had somehow never coincided, It was clearly my loss.

title: Robert Cottingham's Photorealist Paintings
description: Photorealist painting in general is no place to go for the pleasures of the imagination. But in the case of Robert Cottingham, whose new paintings are on view at the O.K. Harris Gallery, 383 West Broadway, through March 20, there are at least signs that a shaping intelligence is at work.

title: Nets Put Squires To Rout
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 5The dispirited Virginia Squires wrote another chapter in their nowhere season here tonight, losing to the New York Nets. 127108.

title: Trenton to Weigh PropertyTax Relief
description: TRENTON, March 5  The Assembly Taxation Committee sent to the floor today a series of bills aimed at providing local property  tax relief through homestead exemptions and a staterevenuesharing plan.

title: Carey Signs Bill To Bar Concorde At Kennedy Airport
description: Governor Carey, who has vowed to try to keep the Con corde supersonic airliner from operating to Kennedy. International Airport, signed a bill yesterday representing one move in that direction.

title: Connecticut Bonds
description: Moody's Investors Service has reduced Connecticut's bondcredit rating from AA to A1, the second such reduction in a year, Gov. Ella T. Grasso announced. Page 52.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1976, by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Friday, March 5, 50th day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: A. & P. Begins Retraining All Its Employees
description: From stem to stern, from top to bottom, from upper management to the checkout counter, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company is being retrained. The vast program, involving all of the 85,000 employees in the company's 2,200 stores, is aimed at turning around the company, which two years ago surrendered its No. 1 position to the Safeway Stores Corporation, of Oakland, Calif.

title: Chile Leads Argentina
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 5 (UPI)Chile took a 10 lead over Argentina today in the Davis Cup South American zone final. Argentina's ace Guillermo Vilas, was on the brink of winning the day's second singles match over Patricio Cornejo when it was suspended until tomorrow.

title: Bridge:
description: Covering honors with honors is a more complex subject than one might think, and there are times when the play that appears right is wrong and vice versa.

title: Princeton Weekend Host Of IC4A Championships
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 5Villanova and Maryland are cofavorites for the team title as the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America holds its 55th indoor track and field championships at Princeton's Jadwin Gymnasium tomorrow and Sunday.

title: Cancer Death Rate Grew Sharply in Last Two Years
description: WASHINGTON, March 5Government experts on health statistics now estimate that the United States death rate from cancer rose more sharply last year than in any previous year since World War II.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 6, 1976

title: Winegrowers in France Mourn Casualties
description: NARBONNE, France, March 5Deeply shocked and angry, the wine growers of this area observed a day of what one called dignified mourning after a gun battle with the police that left two dead and 29 wounded yesterday.

title: Nuclear Plant Generates Wealth for Town
description: CANTON  The ultramodern brick grammar school two blocks from Capriotti's general store stands in stark contrast to the old frame homes and farmsteads that constitute the rest of this unincorporated community of some 300 people in rural Salem County.

title: Vaccination Refusal A National Problem
description: CORTEZ, Colo., March 1Is any sick among you? Let him call for the elders of the church; and let them pray over him ... and the prayer of the faith shall save the sick ...  Peter, 1:14.

title: WILLIAM D. CRANE
description: William D. Crane, founder and former headmaster of the Crane County Day School in Santa Barbara, Calif., died Thursday in Debray Bach, Fla. He was 84 years old and lived in Southport. Conn.

title: Canarsie P. S. A. L. Victor
description: Canarsie High School did yesterday what had been expected throughout this basketball season: It won the Public Schools Athletic League championship. The Chiefs from Brooklyn defeated Lafayette, 7463, before 5,400 fans at St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens, and repeated its feat of the 197172 season with a 240 wonlost record and the city title.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: American and Soviet physicists have proposed a new space flight technique aimed at verifying, perhaps within the next decade, the existence of gravitational waves that scientists believe could lead to greatly expanded understanding of the universe.

title: 5 Atom Olympic Hopefuls to Train in Warmer Climate
description: Fred Thompson will travel to Tempe, Ariz, this week with five members of the Atoms Track Club of Brooklyn, which he coaches. They won't be back until after the Olympic Trials in late June. the Olympic Trials in late June.

title: Marriage Announcement 11  No Title
description: Engagethents

title: ART
description: AN exhibition of children's chairs might not sound like an appealing bill of fare to museum browsers. The only such chairs that most of us recognize or know about are the high chair and the potty chair, and who wants to spend time looking at a selection of them?

title: N.Y.U.Loses In Fencing To Penn
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 6  Penn, the Ivy League champion, dethroned New York University today as the team champion in the 79th annual Intercollegiate Fencing Association tournament at the United States Naval Academy.

title: Snuff Is Pure Poison
description: There is a patch of antimatter on Times Square into which not only public decency disappears, but reality as well. It is a repulsive puton film called Snuff, and it is housed at the National Theater.

title: SAIGON AIDE SEES ECONOMY KEEPING A PRIVATE SECTOR
description: MOSCOW, March 6South Vietnam, still struggling against a severe wartime legacy of economic and human disruption, has developed a longrange plan for a more privately, oriented economy than North Vietnam, according to Saigon's Foreign Minister.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: THE warehouse sale, a weekend rite that requires virtually as much stamina and advance logistics as a search and destroy mission  and certainly as much ruthlessness  is relatively new to New Jersey.

title: Fords for Ford
description: In the years before Gerald R. Ford dramatically replaced Richard Nixon, it never crossed his mind that one day he would be relying on Betty Ford and their rather handsome, wholesome children to help him win the Presidency. Ford pretty much went alone when he campaigned for his Congressional seat in western Michigan; Betty Ford was not yet discovered; the Ford offspring then were in nascent, prepuberty years, hardly subjects for national discussion.

title: 116107 Victors Over Bullets
description: The Knicks carried over enough scoring punch, from three hotshooting quarters into the final period last Might and slowed the torrid Washington Bullets, 116107, at Madison Square Garden. New York's triumph before a crowd of 17,884 was only the Bullets third defeat in 14 games., The loss also snapped the National Basketball Association's Central Division pacesetters fivegame winning streak.

title: Notes: On Booking a Slow Boat
description: While interest in ship travel in general has declined in the face of competition from jet airliners, one segment of the vacationing public remains fiercely devoted to the high seas freighter passengers.

title: Byrne Promises To Continue Fight On TV for Jersey
description: TRENTON, March 6Governor Byrne said today that despite rejection by the Federal Communications Commission of proposals to grant a VHF television channel to New Jersey he would continue to fight fox television service geared toward the state.

title: City Studies Charges on Leasing of Bronx Market
description: The city's Economic Development Administration moved late last week to explore charges that its leasing of the Bronx. Terminal Market has brought about a decline in employment, there, rather than the increase promised.

title: Typhoid Fever Hunt
description: The oftentimes tedious search for a carrier of typhoid fever began last Jan. 15 at Patricia Murphy's Candlelight Restaurant, a tourist favorite at 12 East 49th Street, after patrons from Massachusetts and Connecticut were stricken with the disease.

title: The British Turn Out Dogs, Too
description: With the best of British television, from Upstairs, Downstairs to The World at War, prominently displayed on America's home screens, it is difficult to explain that overall the British product is probably as mediocre as our own. Contrary to distorted impressions, English viewers are not red a steady diet of elevating entertainments, splendidly mounted and impeccably acted. The bulk of their TV fodder is second to none in banal exploitation. There is good reason for the U.S.'s Kojak having become the No. 1 program in Britain. Slickly produced and crisply written, at least in the first season or so, the series makes most of the British domestic competition look silly.

title: Tristate Good Intentions
description: Everyone was in favor of regional cooperation to alleviate ecomomic distress at a tristate planning conference lust week, but that doesn't mean there will be effective togetherness now any more than there has been in the past.

title: U.S. WELFARE AID STILL STATE ISSUE
description: For nearly three years the state has been trying to collect $763 million in Federal reimbursement for socialservice programs while resisting Federal contentions the state has been overpaid $357 million.

title: Dialysis or death
description: Three afternoons a week, on Monday, Wednesday and Friday, an attractive young woman in her middle 20's named Judy Burgio goes to a special upstairs room in her home near Petersburg, Ill., and sorts out an array of plastic tubes, coils, syringes, needles, rubber gloves and chemicals with the skill of a professional nurse. About an hour after she begins, her husband, Charley, comes home from his job as a publicschool teacher to perform a crucial operation: He inserts two needles, each the size of a pencil lead, into a swollen halfinch vein in her forearm. The vein is enlarged because it has been sewn directly to an artery, and the blood rushes through this fistula so fast it can be heard to buzz. For the next four hours, Judy's blood surges out of her body and through a contraption that resembles a washing machine in size and shape that rids it of wastes and several pounds of water. While her blood is washed, she reads, watches TV, and eats the meal she has prepared beforehand. Without the regular assistance of this machine, Judy Burgio would, in a matter of weeks, die.

title: BUCKLEY DIFFERS WITH ROCKEFELLER
description: WASHINGTON, March 2Senator James L. Buckley and Vice President Rockefeller agreed today that they had met several months ago to discuss state and national politics, but they disagreed on the substance of the meeting.

title: The U.S. Arab Commitment
description: In two new disclosures, the extent of the United States commitments to Arab nations has been opened to question. President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said last week that during negotiations for a second Sinai disengagerent last fall secret agreements were reached between Cairo and Washington. In an article In the mega. zinc Foreign Policy, former President Nixon is said to have told Arab leaders that the United states favored returning to Egypt all the territory captured by Israel In 1967.

title: Famous Names, but Just Students
description: PERCHED on the top step of Princeton's Student Center, she sipped coffee from a Styrofoam cup and greeted her classmates as they passed by. Dressed in jeans, with a golden medallion around her neck, she talked about her favorite plays, places and people  typical talk for a popular coed holding court in the noonday sun.

title: DINING OUT
description: Mandarin, 6 Willowbrook Boulevard, West Belt Plaza, Wayne. (201) 2563726.

title: Mr. Watson, Come Here...
description: He was the son of a livery stable foreman and quit school at 13. He owned 10 percent of the most valuable patent in the history of the world. He was an inventor and the founder of a major company. When all that was lost, he supported himself on the stage.

title: One Way or the Other, Social Security Will Need Help
description: WASHINGTONAmerican workers and employers will pay $72.3 billion in Social Security payroll taxes in 1976. The Social Security Administration will pay other Americans. 32 million of them, $78 billion in benefits.

title: How to Get Balled in Berkeley
description: How to Get Balled in Berkeley, can be opened anywhere and read in any direction without experiencing any loss of continuity or comprehension. Since it is pumped out of a verbal fog machine, the usual coordinates don't matter. One can be just as lost in the middle as at the beginning; but if by chance you dig the jive, then the joy is in the sound and not the sense, in which case it's a feast of plenty.

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: SOME members of the Legislature are beginning mutter darkly that the state's school teachers are getting too big for their britches. Indeed, the New Jersey Education Association does incline to be a little bit overbearing at times.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Harlem School to Gain
description: The annual benefit performance of the Harlem School of the Arts will be held at Alice Tully Hall the evening of March 16. The program will consist of two ballets and a oneact opera, and performers will include members of Dorothy Maynor's master voice class at the school. Tickets, at $100, $50, $25 and $10, are available from Mrs, James J. Rorimer, 1000 Park Avenue.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: If you think of a Federal office building as a place where architecture and offices have been raised, or lowered, to an environment of consummate ennui, you are right. It Is a world of corridors by Kafka and rampant mediocrity. It reaches this entirely predictable state, as a rule, through a consortium of collaborating architects who are clearly political bedfellows. Faced with stultifying contracts and AliceinWonderland regulations and a factor that might be called bureaucratic terror, they produce lineofleastresistance architecture, or have any try at something better summarily pulled down to that level. It has become a hohum state of affairs.

title: Bit of Monkey Business
description: ZIPPY is getting ready to take his rollerskating, pianoplaying, watergun  squirting, rideabike show on the theatrical road. But being a chimpanzee, he needs a couple of humans to do those things chimps can't do.

title: The Legislature Today
description: THE State Legislature is celebrating 10 years of freedom from bossism, but it apparently doesn't know what to do with itself. No one has emerged as a real power to replace the Frank Hagues, who used to pass or kill proposed laws in New Jersey by a flick of their long Cuban cigars; however, it is the judgment of many longtime Legislature watchers in Trenton that county cliques may now be forming, even though many of the individual lawmakers may not yet be aware of it.

title: ANIMALS' RESCUE IS SET IN PANAMA
description: Operation Noah II will move into action in Panamanian jungles March 15 to save thousands of wild creatures from drowning or starving when a new hydroelectric dam starts flooding their homeland.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on motion to table a resolution calling for a new election to fill the disputed Oklahoma Senate seat. Resolution tabled, 47 to 46. March 4.

title: Board and seize
description: It is one of those routine summer days in the Gulf of Alaska, a place where people put to sea only for profit or duty. The sky hangs tow, the gray sea rolls in sluggish swells six feet high, a 40knot wind kicks whitecaps off the wave crests, and the driven rain angles into every unsealed crevice. In a slippery, pitching open boat, seven men hunch into bulky orange lite jackets as cold water trickles down their necks. Nearby, the 378foot Coast Guard cutter Boutwell lies in attendance, her sleek white bow curying from the water like a shot trajectory. Several hundred yards away rides a blackhulled ship 300 feet long, with oriental characters and a name ending in Maru printed on the side. The word Maru identifies the vessel as Japanese, while heavy Hshaped towers and a stern that breaks open into a wide chute proclaim it to be a fishing trawler. In the motor surfboat are a crew of three seamen, plus a radioman who once served in Japan, a young Coast Guard officer, an agent of the National Marine Fisheries Service and myself, a civilian observer. The latter four are headed for a courtesy boarding to inspect the trawler, which lies more than 12 miles off the U.S. coast. Their authority to do so is based on fishing agreements between the U.S. and Japan.

title: Best Seller List
description: General

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The average collector's desire to own an officially issued, original piece of Americana is undoubtedly stronger in this Bicentennial year than it has ever been. The most soughtafter items are those that reasonably qualify as early Americana  preferably at least 100 years old or at the very least dated prior to the turn of, the century. The Federal Government (specifically the General Services Administration) has approximately one million such souvenirs stored away in vaults, and many collectors are still awaiting a chance to acquire some of them. We are referring, of course, to the Carson City (CC mintmark) silver dollars minted in the 1870's and 1880's, which the G.S.A. offered to the public in a series of mail bid sales in 1973 and 1974.

title: GOVEHOR BACKED ON MEDICAID CUTS
description: A new statewide group of health and welfare leaders has endorsed most of Governor Carey's proposed Medicaid cutbacks as realistic in the state's current financial emergency. On balance, the group said, the proposals were calculated to hurt people the least.

title: FLORIDA PRIMARY TUESDAY TO TEST FATE OF LEADERS
description: MIAMI, March 6The Florida Presidential primary elections to be held Tuesday have become tests of survival and momentum for Ronald Reagan, the Republican challenger, and Jimmy Carter, one of the leading Democratic candidates.

title: Industry: Will It Spend More?
description: So far, consumers have been the heroes of the 10month old American economic recovery. They are making more money spending more of it, saving less, and lifting the spirits and the profits of retailers throughout the nation.

title: FineFeathered Newcomers Settle at a New Mexico Wildlife Refuge
description: The Bosque del Apache has long been a magnet for travelers from far and (in my case) near, what with free admission, daily visiting hours from dawn to dark and a spectacular population of wild animals and birds. Last year, two superstars arrived.

title: Jodie Foster's Rise From Disney To Depravity
description: One of the most compelling characters in the movie Taxi Driver is Iris, a 12yearold hooker played by Jodie Foster, who was exactly 12 when she made the film. Her Iris is a streetwise, husky voiced runaway from Pittsburgh who is all spindly legs that emerge from formfitting hot pants, tottering on sixinch platform heels as she walks Manhattan's mean streets, her eyes so heavily made up in dark circles that they look like raccoon's eyes.

title: J. D. Monzack Fiance of Miss Solomon
description: Judith Susan Solomon and Jason Dennis Monzack, a lawyer with Halpert & Scoliard, Providence, R.I., law firm, plan to be married May 23 in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Burmese Defense Minister Resigns From Government
description: RANGOON, Burma, March 6 (Reuters)  Burma's Defense Minister and Chief of Staff, Gen. Tin U, has resigned, the Government said today.

title: The Deserts Are Growing
description: Many of the world's deserts are expanding, and though climatic change may be a factor, the principal cause appears to be agricultural practices resulting from increased population.

title: The making of a good German
description: By anybody's standards, Willy Brandt's career has been among the most interesting of the postwar period whether for its beginnings, its middle, or its apparent end with his resignation from the West German chancellorship in May 1974.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
description: John Rockwell's article, A Sense Of Self in Pop Music, on Feb. 22, was good reading but lacked any answers to the obvious questions posed. Those being, What is the music scene on Long Island, Is there really something happening, and Should it be examined more thoroughly by the industry?

title: Seeking an Identity Instead of a Drink
description: JUDY used to wait until after breakfast. Then, while the children were at school and her husband was at work it was safe to rush off to the liquor cabinet and drink gin.

title: Notes: In Search of Solid Hits
description: After three days of screening his pilot show in a suite et the Fairmont Hotel in San Francisco, during the recent national conference of TV program directors, a television distributor emerged to announce: It's go.

title: Anthony Beats Hudson in Pin Final
description: TAMARAC, Fla., March 6 (AP)Earl Anthony of Tacoma, Wash., defeated Tommy Hudson of Akron, Ohio, 246195, today and won the $14,000 top prize in the Professional Bowlers Association's $100,000 Dick Weber Five Star open bowling tournament.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Winners and Losers ...
description: As intense believers in the value of individual competition, Americans try to identify winners and losers in almost every human activity. Transposed into Presidential politics, this characteristic national attitude converts every primary election, however insignificant, into a crucial showdown. The winner, no matter how small his proportion of the total vote or how thin his plurality, becomes this week's frontrunner.

title: YANIANI REPORTED IN FLORIDA TALKS
description: A secret meeting reportedly attended by Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yemeni, the Saudi Arabian Minister of Petroleum Affairs, and representatives of Amer ican oil companies appeared to be under way under tight secucity last night in Panama City, Fla., a Gulf Coast community in the state's panhandle.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Into The Long Season
description: The Massachusetts primary has established Senator Henry, M. .Jackson of Washington as a serious candidate for the Democratic nomination and distinguished Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona from the selfdesignated liberal field in the way that matters: through voter endorsement.

title: Red Smith
description: James Ronald Ryun, a truly great miler who couldn't always win and couldn't learn to lose, says, God told me I had fought a good fight and run a good race, but I was through now. God was right, although a bit tardy about it.
