description: ALMOST anybody who has gone to high school can recall the war of nerves between a hastily called substitute teacher and a hostile set of children.

title: Coming To Grips With The State's Identity Crisis
description: I WAS born and raised in Belleville, and so I have a right to talk. I don't care what it says on my license plates, New Jersey is not the Garden State. New Jersey is, by all accounts, in the midst of an identity crisis, and it can't help our selfimage to call ourselves by an inaccurate nickname.

title: Politics And the Nervous Traveler
description: My wife and I wanted a place to bake in the sun for a week, to play tennis, swim, dine graciously. Well, the travel agent stuttered uncertainly, there's a lovely place up in the hills over Montego Bay, Jamaica ... Montego Bay Racquet Club ... but... A long pause. But what? Uh . . well ... there's a little trouble down there ...political ... you know ....

title: The Gourmet's Choice of Seeds
description: The joys of gardening are boundless. And the first, in a chronological sense, is perusal of garden catalogues while envisioning horticultural triumphs growing in one's backyard or terrace.

title: Fund Will Honor Memory Of Worker Killed at Times
description: The Arthur Hays Sulzberger Lodge of the Knights of Pythias has organized a foundation in memory of Charles Joseph Esposito, assistant foreman in The New York Times delivery department who was killed in an accident at The Times plant on Feb, 1, Jacob Levine, special deputy grand chancellor of the lodge announced yesterday.

title: An AvantGardist Toys With the Past
description: If one were to poll the film critics who write regularly for mass  circulation newspapers and magazines in this country, asking them to compile a list, of significant new American filmmakers, they would probably agree on the names of Martin Scorsese (Taxi Driver, Mean Streets'), Francis. Ford Coppola (The Conversation, The Godfather), and Terrence Malick (Badlands). It is unlikely that the name of Ken Jacobs would appear on anyone's dist, because most of the critics questioned would never have seen his work.

title: Miss McMahon, Teacher, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. McMahon of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mr. McMahon's daughter, Claire Ellen McMahon, to James E. Clair Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clair of Weston, Mass. and Sebago, Me. Miss McMahon is a daughter also of the late Mrs. McMahon, the former Margretta A. McGarey.

title: CONTRACTORS GET APPEAL FOR UNITY
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Organized labor took a step toward reconciliation with the construction industry today when the head of the building trades unions addressed the convention of the Associated General Contractors here and appeared to offer them a hand of peace.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: JUST two weeks from now, spring will blossom officially on the calendar, but there have already been some glorious foretastes of it in nature and in several sectors of the American economy.

title: Strike Is Certain On Jersey Bus Line, Union Official Says
description: A strike of the Amalgamated Transit Union against Transport of New Jersey, the state's largest bus line, was described yesterday by a union official as a certainty beginning at 12:01 A.M. Tuesday unless there was an acceptable offer from the company.

title: CLARA B. FAYETTE, 88, A GIBSON GIRL MODEL
description: Clara Buckhout Fayette, a model for the famed Gibson Girl illustrated by Charles Dana Gibson, died Friday at a nursing home in the Bronx. She was 88 years old and had lived in Pleasantville, N. Y., until three years ago.

title: Design
description: This house in the grapegrowing Napa Valley north of San Francisco was created out of a client's concern for conservation and ecological preservation. Ten years previously, the architect, Michael Wolfe Siegel, had designed a redwood house in the Berkeley hills for the same client, a retired designer and manufacturer of computer software. In the intervening time. the client's heightened environmental awareness had made him determined to practice for his retirement home what he now actively espoused. At the least, he did not want more redwood trees cut into lumber for his projected new house.

title: Music Notes: Resurrecting Some Operatic Rarities
description: Conductor Eve Queler's Opera Orchestra of New York is making history as usual this season with concert performances of two operas so rare as to be considered almost extinct. Massenet's Le Cid, last seen at the Metropolitan in 1897, will be heard at Carnegie Hall tomorrow night, and Donizetti's Gemma di Vergy follows on March 14. Mrs. Queler's aim as it has been since her first season five years agois to resurrect great works which have been withheld from the repertory because they are difficult to sing or impossible to stage, she points out. I'm trying to do these works with the kind of voices the composers had in mind. That is why we engage singers of international caliber. The cast of Le Cid (which will be recorded live by Columbia Records) is headed by Grace Bumbry and Placido Domingo, and that of Gemma di Vergy by Montserrat Caball

title: FOOD
description: WITH coffee and tea prices at record highs, it would be logical to assume that Bean's, a tiny shop in Montclair that specializes in choice, freshly ground coffees, rare teas and exotic spices, might be foundering. Logic to the contrary, Bean's, which opened at 42 Church Street three years ago, is thriving.

title: Barbara Mallow Is Heard in Cello Recital
description: There were a few flaws to Barbara Stein Mallow's cello recital at Alice Tully Hall yesterday afternoona recurrent mild pitch insecurity in the upper positions, a tendency for the cello to be overpowered by the piano, and so forth. But Mrs. Mallow is still a cellist of distinction.

title: Dr. John Pinckney to Wed Janet Barker
description: The engagement of Janet Stephens Barker to Dr. John Edorle Pinckney has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Harold G. Barker of Rye, N. Y., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Louise E. Pinckney of Southbury, Conn., and Robert T. Pinckney of Chicago.

title: Miss Mittermaier Is Victor
description: COPPER MOUNTAIN, Colo., March 6 (AP)Rosi Mittermaier of West Germany, who won three medals at the Olympics last month and then said she thought winning the World Cup skiing title was her goal this season, captured a special slalom today and achieved her objective.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: COPENHAGEN The curtain rises. A girl standing with her back to the audience. She is wearing red and white striped kneelength stockings and a red hat. Casually, but provocatively, she rubs one leg against the other with an insinuatingly feline movement. She turns roundvery nakedgrins and starts to dance.

title: Maryland Freshman Wins Long Jump in IC4 A Meek
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 6Dennis Ivory, a 19yearold University of Maryland freshman, jumped 25 feet  inch and upset his teammate, John Davenport, In the long Jump today as the Indoor track and field championships of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America got under way at Princeton's Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: Kleine Sets Skate Mark
description: INZELL, West Germany, March 6 (Reuters)  Piet Kleine of the Netherlands set a world record of 165,816 points for the men's lesser fourevent combined in a speed skating tournament today. It was Kleine's second world record of the tournament. Yesterday he posted a time of 7 minutes 4.86 seconds for the 5,000 meters.

title: Paperbacks
description: THE SERENGETI LION, by George B. Schaller. (Chicago. $7.95.) The behavior of the freeliving lions of Africa's Serengeti National Park among themselves and toward the wildebeest, zebra and gazelle upon whom they prey: a handsomely illustrated, well documented study that won a National Book Award.

title: Connecticut Stuns Providence
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 6 (AP)Joe Whelton and Al Weston combined for 19 field goals and 44 points as Connecticut stunned Providence, 8773, today and won the Eastern College Athletic Conference New England Regional playoffs. The victory advanced U Conn to the first round of the National Collegiate Eastern regional playoffs against Hofstra, the East Coast Conference champion, next Saturday in Providence, R. I.

title: Soviet Gerontocracy
description: Gerontocracy is alive and well in the Kremlin. That is the indisputable lesson taught by the impact of the 25th Soviet Communist Party Congress on the Moscow leadership. The clique of elderly gentlemen that has ruled the Soviet Union so tar during the 1970's remains in control.

title: Faulty Irrigation Hurts Poor Nations
description: ALEXANDRIA, EgyptImproper irrigation procedures are destroying vast areas, of oncefertile land, particularly in poor countries according to an international symposium of scientists meeting here.

title: Miss Huckins Wed To P. B. Campbell
description: Susan Catherine Huckins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Huckins of Princeton Junction, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Patrick Benjamin Campbell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bill B. Campbell of York, Pa.

title: Marriage Announcement 4  No Title
description: Belinda J. Dorfman Planning Marriage

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times last Sunday on United States relations with India should have stated that Orville L. Freeman, former Secretary of Agriculture, was in India recently as chairman of the American side of the IndoU.S. Business Council, not in his role as president of Business International, a publishing, research and counseling organization.

title: Recital: Miss Von Stade
description: In an interview that appeared in The New York Times last Sunday, Frederica von Stade was reported to have said that sh,e would never again undertake a season as highly charged as her current one here in New York. The young mezzosoprano was speaking of her assignments at the Metropolitan Opera, but she could also have included the recital she gave at Carnegie Hall on Friday night.

title: REACAN ATTACKS FOED'S TIMDITY
description: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla., March 6  Ronald Reagan stepped up his attack today on President Ford's management of foreign affairs by declaring that former President Richard M. Nixon was recently invited to China because of Peking's loss of confidence in the Ford Administration.

title: Time to Prune Fruit Trees to Keep Them Bountiful
description: TIME TO PRUNE The best time to prune most kinds of fruit trees is in early spring before the leaves appear. Water sprouts and dead or diseased branches that may have been missed at the time of the spring pruning may be removed during the summer, but, as a general practice, summer pruning is not reccommended.

title: U.S. Set for Talks On Giving Countries Data About Bribes,
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI)State Department officials said today that the United States would begin negotiations immediately to begin giving information to foreign governments about alleged corporate bribery.

title: New Jersey a Testing Place for Tenant Power
description: Tenant activists have achieved victories in scattered parts of the country in the last few years, but nowhere more so than in New Jersey. There, since 1969, they have been instrumental in the enactment of nine statutes protecting or enlarging the rights of apartment dwellers. Nor is that all. At the behest of tenant groups, more than 100 cities and towns in the state have adopted rent controls.

title: Yankee Stadium: Modern Comforts And Hairdryers
description: From the $30,000 luxury suites to the $3 million computerized scoreboard, from the colorcoded bathrooms to the red, white and blue player lockers with the electrical outlets for the players' hairdryers, Yankee Stadium is new.

title: Does Orr's Return To Hockey Matter? 5 People Say Yes
description: In regards to Stan Fischiers article (Bobby Orr's Return: Does It Matter? Feb. 15), the author is totally mistaken in his facts. Bobby Orr is the greatest hockey player the game has known. Fischler has never coached, participated in or had any involvement with professional hockey. He therefore does not know what it is like on the ice. The play is rougher than any other sport. When a player plays with Orr's intensity, he is bound to get hurt.

title: Fashion
description: There is a group of designers, 20 to 30 years old, who have in common their Spanish language and a commitment to their own businesses. There's not a common denominator of styling, but there is a firm desire to keep their individuality and not to be part of Seventh Avenue. Their clothes are as varied as their Cuban, Spanish and Puerto Rican backgrounds. Julio Espada, 20, born in Barcelona, creates designs with a touch of the couture in their sophistication. Their fluid shapes look like abstract art in his modern stark white store. Hector Torres, 30, a Puerto Rican, designs bright, sexy clothes that seem to reflect his playful personality. Betsy Gonzales, 25, also from Puerto Rico, likes clothes with simple shapes in rich colors that can mix in multiple ways. Mayda and Antonio Fidalgo, 23 and 30 respectively, are a Cuban husband and wife team. Antonio, a painter and sculptor, and Mayda design clothes with a bold silhouette.

title: Builders Fight Laws Preserving Wetlands
description: Throughout the tristate region, builders who want to develop the area's remaining tidal wetlands are challenging environmental legislation that requires their preservation.

title: Defenders of the Law
description: WHEN two Nassau County policemen stopped to question a man they suspected was selling liquor to minors at a Seaford elementary school, the suspect threw a book in the face of one of the officers and began to fight with them. In the scuffle, one of the officers was injured in the nose and neck and had a concussion. The other was kicked in the stomach and groin.

title: Soviet Diplomats As the Targets
description: The Soviet Union's mission to the United Nations has filed a complaint concerning a recent shooting at the mission residence in Riverdale, N.Y. It is the third reported shooting at Soviet buildings in the New York area since October, 1971, the other two occurring at the mission at 136 East 67th Street.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market moved Into what professionals regarded as a consolidation phase last week on reduced trading volume. In the credit markets, meanwhile, prices moved down as shortterm interest rates, in particular, turned higher.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Richard Burton bath done this thing simply to drive theaterlovers lunatick. (The spelling is Elizabethan, and so, dammit, is he.) Returning to the stage after an absence of 10 or more years to appear in a play already teeming with ironies, he has compounded the ironies of Equus to the nth power, overwhelming the audience not with his performance alone but with its implications. Consider some or them.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Hang In There

title: Letters: Guidelines For a New Guidebook
description: To the Editor:

title: Rutgers Tops St. John's
description: The Rutgers basketball team stayed unbeaten by defeating St. John's, 7067, in the final of the Eastern College Athletic Conference metropolitan playoffs here. Both teams will go to the National collegiate championship tournament next Saturday. Details in Section 5.

title: Mrs. Onassis Arrives In London on a Visit
description: LONDON, March 6 (AP)Jacqueline Onassis flew into London early today from New York, but the reason for her visit remained secret.

title: FILM VIEW
description: From 30's Porn To 70's Corn our new films: two pretty good, and two duds. That's not bad for the FebruaryMarch. period when movie distributors, having given us their blockbusters for Christmas and still sitting on their Easter releases, assume that the only people going out want to see thirdrate horror movies. Because these new films have little in common except sprocket holes, I'll make no attempt to find a trend. They are listed individually and in alphabetical order.

title: Attrition Is Saving Other City Jobs
description: Now that New York City's daytoday crises have subsided, attention is on the future.

title: SovietCape Verde Accord
description: MOSCOW, March 6 (Reuters) The Soviet Union and the Cape Verde Islands in the Atlantic have signed a merchantshipping agreement to insure favorable treatment for ships in each other's ports, the press agency Tass reported today.

title: Indian Government Is Pressing a Campaign to Clear the Streets of Bombay of Thousands of Beggars
description: BOMBAY, March 4  In a series of police roundups, Bombay is trying to sweep away the thousands of beggars who spend their lives roaming its streets.

title: 2 Unknowns Who Virtually Run the State Budge Process
description: Albany, March 6  During these crucial weeks, as the Legislature and the Governor's office strive to put togetheri a state budget quickly enough to convince the bankers that New York is worthy of credit. two of the most important people in the state are men whose names are all but unknown outside the Capitol. And their innocuoussounding titles scarcely provide a clue to the power they wield.

title: East, Midwest Meet In JazzRock Beat Of the Lake Quartet
description: No separation, Oliver Lake proclaimed in a poem he read during his performance at Studio Rivbea Friday evening. Miles Davis and Muddy Waters are the same. This emphasis on the roots shared by Mr. Davis, the jazz trumpeter, and Mr. Waters, the blues man, indicated the character of the music performed by Mr. Lake, who is a saxophonist and composer from St. Louis.

title: How to be like Rust Hills
description: About a third of the way along, the author writes: Friends who used to see me at parties, back in the days when I got invited to parties, would flinch visibly whenever they heard me say the words value vacuum.

title: BRIDGE
description: If Scotland, together with its North Sea oil, ever achieves independence of England, as many of its voters seem to want, the Scottish Bridge Union will at the same time win a battle it has waged for two decades. Scotland has always been totally selfgoverning in a bridge sense, but repeated attempts have failed to convince the European Bridge League that she should be entitled to separate representation in the European Championships.

title: Marine Recruit Abuse Continues
description: PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., March 6  Pvt. Harry W. Hiscock does not want to be one of those few good men the Marine Corps advertises for any more.

title: Schoolboy, Spiked on Heels, Ties Mark
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., March 6Walt Kirkland, a Mount Vernon senior, tied his New York State indoor record for the 600yard run last night with a winning time of 1 minute 11.7 seconds in the Section I qualifying track meet for the schoolboy state championships next week in Ithaca. But Kirkland was spiked on both heels during the race. The wounds required nine stitches and he will not compete in the Eastern States championships tomorrow at Princeton, N.J., where he was one of the favorites. Steve Strother of New Rochelle ran the fastest 300yard run in the country this season when he won in 31.3 seconds. He also took the 60yard dash in 6.3 seconds.

title: 3 Special Juries Here Endorse Decriminalizing Marijuana Use
description: The removal of criminal penaides for the personal use of marijuana has been called for here by three special narcotics grand juries.

title: Gloomsayer or Doomsayer?
description: PARISOne astonishing aspect of the Soviet system is the way it turns against itself so many of its brilliant members by seeking to fetter their minds and punish their, hearts. One has but to think of the musician Rostropovich or the scientist Sakharov to see how much the U.S.S.R. is consequerrtly deprived.

title: T'ing Pei Weds Marianne Magocsi
description: Marianne Margaret Magocsi, executive assistant to the president of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, was married yesterday noon to T'ing Chung Pei of New York, vice president of the Sefrius Corporation here.

title: Entrechats Among the Ingots
description: Pittsburgh's steel industry took the center stage here recentlyas the subject of a new ballet, The Steel Symphony.

title: Cost of Italy's Strikes
description: ROME (AP)Italian statistics show strikes cost the country 179,692,000 working hours in 1975, an increase of nearly 25 per cent over the year before.

title: WHITLAM ENGAGED IN A NEW DISPUTE
description: SYDNEY, Australia, March 6A political storm is again swirling about former Prime Minister Gough Whitlam, this time ??r charges that his Labor Party tried to raise campaign funds from Iraq.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: I TAKE serious issue with Francis M. Conlon's article, Whither Quality Education? I have been a teacher in Suffolk County for 18 years and I find Mr. Conlon's indictment of parents and teachers to be unfair and provincial.

title: Mateo Stops Licata in 8th in Paris
description: PARIS, March 6 (AP)  Jean Mateo, an unranked Frenchman who learned boxing in Stockton, Calif., floored Tony Licata three times and then knocked out the topranked American middleweight in the eighth round of their scheduled 10rounder at the Hionodrome tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Hughes Ordered to Court
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 6 (AP)  Howard Hughes, the billionaire recluse, was ordered yesterday to appear Monday in Washington for a deposition in a case involving his Summa Corporation. Federal District Judge Alfonso Zirpoli directed Mr. Hughes to give a deposition to Securities and Exchange Commission lawyers in the S.E.C.'s $45 million lawsuit.

title: Early lilt. V. P. Vote Skips Scarlet Star
description: For an hour after the metropolitan area's biggest college basketball game in years, Phil Sellers sat in the Rutgers dressing room under the Madison Square Garden stands, patiently answering questions.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: March 9Madison Avenue Sports Car Driving and Chowder Society meeting and luncheon at Frank's Place, 41 East 58th Street, noon. Information: Bruce Wennerstrom, phone (212)2688063.

title: Florida FunkHot Stuff From Hialeah
description: It would be hard to imagine a more unlikely location for a major recording center than Hialeah, Fla. Nestled between Miami and the Everglades, a racetrack its bestknown cultural attraction, this sleepy tropical town of 100,000 is far removed from the New YorkLos AngelesNashville axis around which the music business revolves. Despite its isolation, or perhaps because of it, Hialeah has given birth to an extremely popular, elemental rhythm  and  blues sound which is at odds with the slick stringladen soul music produced elsewhere. In the past 18 months the Miami Sound, as it is known, clattering, boisterous, hotblooded, has become a fixture in discos around the country and at the top of the national charts.

title: Comrades
description: It was my socialism that attracted the viceroy's wife. You love me for my doctrine, I said. I am not good, and never have been, at intimacies. at the kind of love she wanted. I love like a true Marxistin general: I love the masses.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONBlood is a product that is not very different from other consumer goods. No blood is free even if given voluntarily or altruistically.

title: Kennedy to Oppose Long In Fight for Tax Reform
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts is preparing to challenge the power of the Senate Finance Committee and its chairman, Russell B. Long of Louisiana, over the issue of tax reform.

title: Island Pays For City Debt
description: ITEM A Nassau County village refuses to pay the high interest rates that investors demand on a smallnote issue and instead sells the notes to its own taxpayers.

title: Ford, Stumping in Illinois, Cites Proven Leadership
description: CHAMPAIGN, III., March 6President Ford crossed Ronald Reagan's native state today, asserting that knowledgeable leadership would solve more of the nation's problems than the rhetoric of those who would hide behind a blanket denunciation of our national Government.

title: Miss Hegierski Wed to Louis Salemno
description: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Kathleen Hegierski, a mezzosoprano with the New York City Opera Company, and Louis Salemno, an assistant conductor and prompter at the Gran Teatro del Liceo in Barcelona, Spain. The Rev. Kenneth Jadoff performed the ceremony.

title: City an Example in Control Dispute
description: When rent control is discussed in various cities, New York's experience is invariably citedby real estate people who contend that rent control has been disastrous for New York and a cause of its fiscal crisis, and by control advocates who maintain that the negative effects have been severely exaggerated and that New York is so different from their communities that there is no possible precedent.

title: Flyers Rout Red Wings, 61
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 6 (UPI)  Orest Kindrachuk scored three goals today as the Philadelphia Flyers overwhelmed the Detroit Red Wings, 61, in a National Hockey League game marred by a brawl that held up the game for 15 minutes.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Lefty Driesell, Maryland basketball coach, referring to Southern fans coming north for the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament: They all stick together like flies on rice. No, make that flies on grits.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ACTOR'S CAFETHEATER. 263 Central Avenue, East OrangeDeath of a Salesman. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. Opens Friday (through April 10). $3.50$4.90; students and the elderly, $3.50$3.90; group rates. (201) 6751881.

title: Book Ends
description: Reverse English. Although British firms such as British Airways, with its jolly ads proclaiming Come homeall is forgiven, are hopeful that this country's Bicentennial activities will spill some business their way, several English reviewers recently evinced a distinct Zack of hospitality, to one of this country's most lauded books of 1975, E. L Doctorow's Ragbime. When the English edition was published over there in January, the critics pounced on It with derisory war whoops in a sort of Boston Tea Party in reverse.

title: Peking Steadily Intensifies Attack on Teng
description: HONG KONG, March 6The monthold campaign against alleged rightists in China has intensified steadily, edging ever closer to an open official attack on Teng Hsiaoping, the senior Deputy Prime Minister, and throwing into doubt China's current emphasis on stability and economic development.

title: Picture credits
description: 1EVELYN HOFER

title: Long Island/This Week
description: ART

title: Does it serve women writers to be a class apart?
description: Ellen Moers's Literary Women is a mixture of social history and literary observation. Like many books on women's literature, it is indulgent, embracing in the name of its cause the good, the bad, the indifferent. My tale is one of triumph, Moers writes, not quest for failure, and literary women provide no evidence of female passivity, for if there is one ruthless activity that seeks to dominate and shape life itself, it is writing.

title: A Moisture Monitor From the Grave
description: The plight of the droughtstricken winter wheat crop has triggered more interest in weather reports. Meteorology, the study of weather, involves some highly sophisticated instruments and interpreting. However, the state of Wisconsin's Statistical Reporting Service, a part of its agriculture department, has for some 15 years been collecting data about snow and frost depths throughout the state relying on a downtoearth groupgrave diggers.

title: Lauda Victor in South Africa Race
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 6 (AP)Niki Lauda of Austria led all the way in winning the South African Grand Prix Formula One auto race today in a Ferrari 312T. It was the ninth grand prix triumph in his career.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Columbia's Rowing Death/Ivy Basketball/Scholarships
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Levittown Cuts Back on Schools
description: The Levittown, school district, has become the first in the stateaside from New York Cityto announce major cutbacks in its school system, including payless furloughs and layoffs of teachers and employees.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Regional Unemployment.
description: All rates, including national, are unadjusted. PostChristmas layoffs account for the sharp rise in January.

title: CORRUPTION CASES SPREADING IN IRAN
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 6A wave of arrests for corruption here has extended to the huge citycenter construction project known as Shahestan Pahlevi  Shah Pahlevi Town.

title: The Chunnel
description: Talk about building a railroad tunnel under the English Channel to link France and England went on intermittently for 200 years until, in November 1973, the two countries agreed at last to start preliminary work. But by January 1975, after Gigging that extended a mile and a half on each side, the channel tunnelor Chunnel, as it had come to be calledwas once again all talk and a mere dream.

title: Big Industry Gun Aims at the Hill
description: WASHINGTONOne day a few months ago, Robert S. Hatfield, the chairman of the Continental Can Company, dropped in on Representative John Seiberling, Democrat of Ohio, to explain his opposition to an antitrust bill then in committee.

title: City Trash Pickups at a Critical Stage, Officials Assert
description: Heavy personnel cuts prompted by the city's fiscal crisis have seriously diminished the Department of Sanitation's ability to pick up the garbage from city streets, demoralized its workers and blocked implementation of new programs designed to meet increasing future needs, according to sanitation officials.

title: Galanes Captures CrossCountry Ski

title: Noise on the Job

title: A Centennial novel for the Bicentennial
description: Gore Vidal's and my generation (he was born at West Point, Oct. 3, 1925) was particularly distrustful of patriotic rhetoric. Growing up we were apt to snicker over the tremolo of the World War I vets in bedizened V.F.W.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Forsberg of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kristin Forsberg, to John Edward Williams of Washington, son of Edward C. Williams of McLean, Va., and the late Mary Griffin Williams.

title: If You Go . . .

It's about a fourhour trip, but much faster and easier than flying to Munich and driving or busing from there. You do not need a car in St. Anton; nearly everything is within walking distance, and there are taxis for those restaurants on the outskirts of town.

title: Canada and India Said to Agree

We have a Jimmy Carter, a Mo Udall, a Scoop Jackson, a Sarge Shriver, and of course, a Jerry Ford, all of whom think there are votes in these affectionate nicknames.

PETERSBURG, Fla.Ronald Reagan's lastminute violation of his own Eleventh Commandment in his foreign policy attack on Gerald Ford may just barely give him some sort of victory in the Florida primary. But the attack itself is a dead giveaway that Mr. Reagan and his advisers are desperate, the big lead they once boasted here lost to an effective Ford counterattack.

Noting that the Socialists, who control the suburban government, are seeking votes in local elections this Sunday, the man said: They must think we are really stupid.

title: Six Coast Shows in Top 10
description: Of the top 10 shows in 1975 based on entries, the Golden State had six, including the No. 1 fixtureSanta Barbara. Since 1973, when Santa Barbara displaced Trenton as the largest dog show in the United States, it has held that spot. But whereas many of the other fixtures in the top 10 slipped in entries last year, Santa Barbara continued to forge ahead. In 1973 it drew 3,935 dogs and the next year 4,228. In 1975, it came up with 4,442, only 14 fewer than the national record set by Morris and Essex of Jersey in 1939.

description: Austin Clarke, the Irish poet, was born in 1896. He died in 1974, and now hardly anyone outside Ireland knows his work; even inside Ireland he was recognized only tardily and grudginglyfor reasons that we need to understand if we're to get our bearings on one of the strangest and most original Englishlanguage poets of this century.

This was an inevitable evolution, following last year's Sinai disengagement agreementspart of the price which the United States undertook to pay, in full consultation with the Israeli Government, to bring about the historic separation of Egyptian and Israeli forces.

Miss Young, 25 years old, led at the halfway mark of the competition with 87.150 points.

title: With No Other Choice, Moscow Hears Out Rebels

One by one, representatives of the Italian, French and British Communist Parties rose to declare that their parties had embarked on national roads to socialism and would work through the democratic process with due respect for human rights. The Rumanian and Yugoslav speakers, while passing over the issue of personal liberties, joined in the chorus for Marxist Pluralism.

Both places offer free coffee. At St. Peter's, you're also invited to bring your own lunch.

title: WARNING SOUNDED BY POSTAL CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, March 7Postal service in the United States must be reshaped to conform to new economic reality or the vast system will be destroyed, Postmaster General Benjamin F. Bailar says in a speech he is to make tomorrow.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, Monday, March 8 (AP)A former South Korean presidential candidate Kim Dae Jung and his wife were arrested today, aides to Mr. Kim said.

title: Scout Leader's Glass Crusher Gives Troop a Break
description: TEANECK, March 6Fifteen and a half tons of glass were taken to a recycling plant in North Bergen today by Boy Scouts of Troop 106 in Teaneck. The total raised to 435 tons the amount of glass recycled in a fiveyear project that started as part of a Scout's requirements for his Eagle Badge and has been accelerated by the devising of machines that smack of either Yankee ingenuity or a youth devoted to Rube Goldberg cartoons.

title: Tinderbox Tokyo Is Mobilized Against Fire Threat
description: TOKYO, March 7Sachiko Kojima cannot expect her husband to be home much these days. And neither can Kozue Ogata, because this is March and in Japan the wife of every fireman knows well what March means.

title: Screen: About Failure:'Vincent, Francois' Is New Sautet Story
description: "Vincent, Franois, Paul and the Others," Claude Sautet's new French film, is about the sustaining friendship of three middle-aged, middle-class men whose lives in almost every other respect are failures.Vincent (Yves Montand) is separated from his wife, losing his mistress and in the process of going quietly bankrupt. Franois (Michel Piccoli) is a society doctor whose wife sleeps around with his tacit, exhausted approval. Paul (Serge Reggiani), a successful newspaper writer, has been unable to bring himself to finish the definitive World War II novel for almost 20 years.Every Sunday afternoon, Vincent, Franois, Paul, as well as a younger comrade named Jean (Gerard Depardieu), with their wives and mistresses, meet at Paul's country house. The friends drink, argue, play football, eat. Usually they reassure one another, but sometimes they explode in impotent rage. The failure of one is often intolerable to one or more of the others.On the Sunday afternoon that opens "Vincent, Franois, Paul and the Others," the flames from a pile of burning leaves set a tool shed on fire. For a few minutes there is pandemonium in the yard. Someone remembers a cylinder of cooking gas in the shed. There is the danger of an explosion. Mothers pull their children away. One man goes into the shed and finds the cylinder (which turns out to be empty).The fire is put out amid a lot of laughter and joking and good humor. At the same time we realize that something terrible could have happened  something irretrievable. The menace has been contained, at least for the moment.Mr. Sautet, a director who is highly thought of in France, is a film maker about whom I have very mixed feelings. It's not only that he regards the bourgeoisie with solemnity unrelieved by any humor, but also that he seems as fascinated by the quality of their houses, the cut of their clothes, the make of their automobiles and the decibel range of their stereos as by the state of their emotional lives. Our envy of the good things of their lives competes with our sympathy and sometimes squashes it flat.Of the three Sautet films I've now seen, "Vincent, Franois, Paul and the Others" is the most successful in keeping a decent balance between these interests. Though the director indulges his taste for fancy photography  romantic, shimmery images often shot through windshields or as mirror reflectionsthe film is haunted by a genuine feeling of menace barely contained, of love that's run out, of futility, which have the effect of defining the meaning of friendship. It's not love, but it's better than nothing.Mr. Montand is fine in the key role, his face seeming to collapse from middle age to old age in the course of the film. Mr. Piccoli, too, gives a strong performance as the doctor, though we never know as much about him as Mr. Sautet thinks we do. As the youngest member of the group, Mr. Depardieu is forceful and funny, though we suspect that his life will not  ultimately  be much different from those of his friends: barren but well-upholstered.The women are largely dcor since the film is, after all, about friendship not love, though Stphane Audran has one superb scene. It's mostly one long, agonized reaction shot when Vincent, floundering from one false hope to another, asks her to reconsider their separation and divorce.It's curious that friendship, something that is so important in all our lives, is so difficult to dramatize effectively. Perhaps that's because in our romantic way we assume it to be some lesser breed of relationship, one that, execpt in war or on the football field, must always be suspect. In this ornate but thoughtful film, it is taken seriously."Vincent, Franois, Paul and the Others" opened yesterday at the Regency and D. W. Griffith Theaters.

title: Col. James V. Demarest, 86, Leader in American Legion
description: Col. James V. Demarest, a past commander of the New York County and the New York State American Legion, and president of the local corporation that arranged for its 1952 national convention here, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 40 Park Avenue.

title: Prison Experiments

description: DETROIT, March 7With the improving economy, people are losing their fear of making major purchases like cars, an auto executive remarked the other day. And for many buyers, that, purchase is apt to be a largersize car.

title: Tampa Tribune Backs Ford
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 7 (UPI) The Tampa Tribune editorially endorsed President Ford today in Tuesdays Florida Republican primary, but recommended that Democrats vote no preference. Among the Democrats, we find none who stands out as a potential President, the newspaper said.

title: Britain and Rhodesia
description: LONDON, March 7The prospect of racial warfare in Rhodesia has confronted the British Government with its most painful foreign policy dilemma in years. Prime Minister, Harold Wilson and his advisers are certain that Rhodesia's white, many of whom are related to British subjects, will be overwhelmed if attacked by black Rhodesian guerrillas from staging areas in neighboring black, nations, including Mozambique. This could lead to political repercussions here.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times on March 1 reviewing the Lockheed bribery case in Japan stated incorrectly that the newpaper Yomiuri Shimbun and its late publisher Matsutaro Shoriki had come out in favor of Lockheed and had campaigned for Japanese purchase of Lockheed aircraft. The paper did not take any editorial position on the matter.

title: U.S. Businesses Reported Remaining in South Africa

In the year ending last June, more than $10.5 billion of military equipment or services were sold or given away to 71 countries, a fivefold increase in four years.

title: Why a Bill With Ardent Backers and Firm Opponents Has Gone Nowhere in 5 Weeks
description: ALBANY, March 7It will be five weeks ago Tuesday that the Senate gave final passage to the socalled Stavisky bill, a highly controversial measure that requires New York City to spend the same proportion of its overall budget on the city schools during the next three years as it spent during the three years before the eruption of the fiscal crisis. On the day of the Senate vote, and several times since, Governor Carey said he would veto the bill on the ground that it threataned the city's emergency fiscal plan by staking out untouchable areas in the city's budget. In return, the bill's chief sponsor, Assemblyman Leonard P. Stavisky, Democrat of Queens, vowed to try to override the Governor's vetoan effort in which, given the electionyear emotionalism of the issue; he might well succeed, to the disconfiture of all concerned.

title: Floridians Not Impressed By the Primaries to Date
description: ORLANDO, Fla.. March 6Jim Cinnamon, an assistant principal at Edgewater High School here, was impressed by the results of the New Hampshire primary but discounted Massachusetts. The reaction of Linda Romigh, an English teacher, was the reverse. When Mr. Cinnamon was first interviewed here a week before the New Hampshire balloting, he expressed an inclination to support Jimmy Carter. When he was reinterviewed after the two primaries he said that New Hampshire proved to him that Mr. Carter's Southern origins were no liability in the North.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 7 (AP)Royal Glint, a 61 shot, held off a stretch drive by Ancient Title and won the $255,900 Santa Anita Handicap by a nose today.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two employees or an Ocean County perfume factory died yesterday after they apparently had been overcome by toxic fumes inside a large chemical tank, the police reported. The police said the victims, identified as Juan Calo, 22 years old, of Lakewood, and Teofil Bartnicki, 39, of Bricktown, had been pronounced dead on arrival at Paul Kimball Hospital here.

title: Saigon Trains Tour Guides
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 7 (Reuters)  South Vietnam will begin training tourist guides at a special school to cope with an expected rush of international travelers.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities

title: Bunny Borinstein Wed to Jesse Mautner
description: Edna Borinstein, president of Gallery Passport Ltd., an organization that conducts art tours to museums and galleries here and out of town, was married yesterday afternoon to Jesse J. Mautner, chairman of the Mautner Company Inc., Yonkers and Buffalo manufacturer of jewelry boxes and displays.

title: Issues and Debate
description: WASHINGTON  In the opening phase of the 1976 Presidential campaign, President Ford and Ronald Reagan, as well as some Democratic candidates, have raised an issue that has profound implications for the Federal Government's role in overseeing the use of the billions of dollars it annually allots far a broad range of domestic programs.

title: WHITLAM ACCUSED OF BAD JUDGMENT
description: CANBERRA, Australia, March 7 (Reuters)The national executive of Australia's Labor Party today condemned Gough Whitlam, the party's leader in Parliament, for involvement in a proposal to raise $500.000 from Iraq for party election funds.

title: FALLING LIGHT POLE HITS GIRL ON HEAD
description: A 17yearold girl out for a Sunday stroll was critically injured here yesterday afternoon when she was struck on the head by a 500pound steel light pole that collapsed on its corroded base and crashed to the sidewalk at an upper East Side housing project.

title: Smoke From Pier Covers Wide Area
description: A fouralarm fire in which a section of an abandoned 200footwide pier collapsed blanketed sections of lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon with clouds of smoke.

title: Circle in the Square, at 25, to Stage a Gala
description: In 1951, six neophytes in search of a theater, waving a total bankroll of $320, bravely signed a lease on an abandoned nightclub, the old Greenwich Village Inn.

title: Girl Scouting, 64 Years Old, Is Changing
description: In 1913, one year after the founding of the Girl Scouts of America in Savannah, Ga., the group's first handbook noted that girls need not wait for war to break out to show what heroines they can be.

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: Linda Siegelman, 18, Registers With N.Y. Sets, Not College
description: ROSLYN, L.I., March 7 Linda Sielgelman passed up college because, she said, I'm not a student.

title: A Farming Center in Portugal Says the Revolution Has Brought Hard Times
description: OLALHAS, Portugal, March 2The day was warm and the cherry trees were in bloom but this prosperous old farm center in central Portugal appeared deserted.

title: Mrs. Morrison's Dog Best Bearded Collie
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 7Although the bearded collie has been known in Scotland since the 16th century, the first litter in this country wasn't whelped until 1967. We know of 1,001 in the United States, said Dr. Thomas Davies, the, president of the Bearded Collie Club of America.

title: Tapestry, Tapestry, On the Wall...
description: The women's faces, with their huge, brooding eyes, look down at the lunchers in Serendipity's upstairs dining room. Bigger than lifesized, they are mysterious and still oddly familiarone recognizes Twiggy and Catherine Deneuve. They aren't painted portraits, as they seem at first glance, but tapestries.

title: Loughlin, Power Gain. C.H.S.A.A. Semifinals
description: Bishop Loughlin and Power Memorial, the topseeded teams, advanced to the semifinals of the Catholic High School Athletic Association basketball playoffs yesterday by scoring quarterfinal victories at St. John's University in Oueens.

title: EGYPT IS SEEKING DEFENSIVE ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (Reuters)Egyptian leaders have told a United States Congressional delegation that Cairo wants defensive arms from the United States and would be satisfied with 40 percent of what America supplies to Israel.

title: Books of The Times
description: It is no exaggeration to speak of the Romance languages as being something of a miracle, remarks the philologist Mario Pei in the Introduction to his latest book,

title: Time Trying NonPostal Delivery
description: Time Inc., which expects to be paying as much as 8.2 cents postage for average issues of Time magazine and Sports Illustrated in certain postal zones in 1979, is now paying as title as 5.5 cents a copy in a test of alternative delivery systems for Time.

title: CONFLICT IS SEEN ON U.S. BANK POST
description: WASHINGTON, March 7A Senate committee is scheduled to vote Tuesday on whether to approve as chairman of the Home Loan Bank Board a California savings and loan executive whose decisions while a Federal official ultimately could affect the value of his $2.5 million worth of savings and loan stock.

title: Bridge:
description: Writing a bridge book for beginners is a surprisingly difficult task, and it is doubtful whether any of the attemptsperhaps two or three a yearhave ever been totally successful.

title: Large Wallace Vote Reflects Depth of Antibusing Sentiment in Boston's WorkingClass Neighborhoods
description: BOSTON, March 7I cried for his brothers, Flossie O'Keefe was saying of Senator Edward M. Kennedy a few days before the Masschusetts primary last Tuesday. But today I'd dance on his grave.

title: STATE EMPLOYEES SEEK MEDIATORS
description: The State Civil Service Employees Association, charging that state officials had not been negotiating in good faith on a new threeyear contract, declared impasses last week in separate negotiations involving three units representing 104,000 state employees.

title: Jary Taken Off Street But Still Can't Agree
description: RIO VISTA, Calif., March 7 (UPI)  Forty prospective Jurors had been called for the trial of Gerald Thomsen, 28 years old, charged with drunken driving. But some were excused for hardships. Others were challenged, and two said they could not be impartial because they had been charged with a similar offense.

title: Advertising
description: What works for mousetrap inventors doesn't necessarily work for ad agencies. Better workat least what they think is better workdoesn't always attract clients.

title: Nets Top Spurs by 118109
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 7 The New York Nets, who have spent most of this American Basketball Association season in second place, staved off the most serious challenger for that spot tonight with a 118109 victory over the San Antonio Spurs at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Irish Bombing Kills One
description: CASTLEBLANEY, Ireland, March 7 (Reuters)One man was killed and 17 were injured when a bomb exploded outside a crowded bar here tonight, the police said.

title: Darkness Halts Golf Playoff
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 7  The Professional Golfers' Association and NBC Sports collaborated on an elegant blooper today by arranging a schedule based on Daylight Saving Time, which has not yet materialized. The result was that a suddendeath playoff to determine the winner of the Florida Citrus open was called on account of darkness after two holes.

title: Mihajlov Improving
description: BELGRADE, March 7 (UPI)The Yugoslav dissident writer Mihajlo Mihajlov, on a hunger strike while serving a sevenyear jail sentence, is in good spirits and receiving vitamin injections, his lawyers said today. His physical condition is better than two weeks ago, the lawyer said.

title: SALES OF HOMES BY RACE ALLEGED IN A BERGEN SUIT
description: A coalition of openhousing advocates that includes an entire Bergen County municipality, Englewood, will file a class action civil complaint in Federal District Court in Newark today accusing most of the county's realestate brokers of perpetuating a racially segregated suburban housing market.

title: A Significant but Eccentric Race
description: MIAMI, March 7In Orlando the other night, the host of a radio talk show cleared his throat, took his cue, leaned into his microphone and introduced his guest.

title: Juilliard Theater Orchestra Performs
description: The second concert in the current Celebration of Contemporary Music at the Juilliardi Theater on Saturday night enI listed the Juilliard Theater Orchestra under the direction of Walter Hendi. This is Juilliard's secondline orchestra (the first is Sixten Ehrling's group), and it didn't really muster the sort of fullthroated tone that major symphonies command. But otherwise its work was exemplary.

title: Cecotto Wins Florida Motorcycle Test
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 7 (AP)A 19yearold Venezuelan, Johnny Cecotto, won a battle with Kenny Roberts and excessive tire wear today to capture the 35th annual Daytona 200, motorcycling's leading race.

title: New Bible Translation Is a Chinese Version
description: The United Bible Societies has published a new translation of the New Testament in contemporary Mandarin Chinese, the first since 1919.

title: Saving John Jay
description: There is nothing so much worth as a mind well instructed. These words of wisdom from Ecclesiasticus should alert the City University Chancellor Robert J. Kibbee to the tremendous loss this city would suffer if John Jay College of Criminal Justice were to close its doors. Seekers of a good education would be victimized by a chancellor who is more interested in playing politics than in preserving lowcost, highquality education.

title: Nam 11, 62, of North Korea Dies; Signed Panmunjon Truce Pact
description: TOKYO, Monday, March 8 (Reuters)Deputy Prime Minister Nam II of North Korea was killed yesterday in an accident, the Japanese news agency Koyodo reported today. He was 62 years old.

title: Morocco Breaks Ties With Algeria In Sahara Dispute
description: RABAT, Morocco, March 7 (Reuters)The Moroccan Government announced to day it was breaking off diplomatic relations with Algeria. The action came after a prolonged dispute between the two nations over the future of Western Sahara.

title: Ford Expected to Back Scenic River Plan Saturday on North Carolina Trip
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 The White House and the President Ford Committee have nearly completed their plans for a Presidential swing through several cities in North Carolina next Saturday, 10 days before the state's Presidential primary.

title: Ehrlichman Says Fair Trial Was Denied in Watergate
description: BELLEVUE, Wash., March 7 (UPI)In a handwritten letter to the editor published In The Bellevue American today, John D. Ehrlichman asserted that Watergate defendants in Washington, D.C., had been deprived of a fair trial.

title: E. Joan Blum Bride Of H. D. Hassenfeld
description: E, Joan Blum, a firstyear student at the Columbia University School of Law, was married yesterday afternoon to H. Daniel Hassenfeld, a secondyear student there. Rabbi Norman Cohen performed the ceremony at Temple Agudath Sholom in Stamford, Conn.

title: Rabin Opposed to Sale
description: TEL AVIV, March 7Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin today strongly opposed the United States proposal to sell arms to Egypt.

title: THE BRITISH SOUR ON CIVIL SERVANTS
description: LONDON, March 7For many an ambitious wellschooled Briton, there is no higher calling than a career behind the imperial limestone walls of Whitehall, the 9to5 bastion of the British Civil Service.

title: Protests Rising on Curbs in India
description: Gradually and apprehensively, a growing number of citizens of India who live In the United States are speaking out against restrictions in their homeland imposed by the Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: U.S. Team's Cup Victory Ends at 61
description: HARTFORD, March 7The World Cup in tennis is a fourofseven match competition, a format similar to baseball's World Series and the final round playoffs in pro basketball and hockey. In baseball, basketball and hockey, once a team wins four games, the show is over. In tennis it's different. Even after a champion is declared, the show goes on  which might be called cruel and unusual punishment in Australia.

title: Miss Young Skates To 3d Sprint Title
description: WEST BERLIN, March 7 (AP)  Sheila Young, the Olympic gold medalist from Detroit, won the 500 and 1,000meter races again today for a sweep of all four races in the women's world sprint speedskating championship. Miss Young has won the title two years in a row and three of the last four.

title: Wright Patman, 82, Dean of House, Dies
description: WASHINGTON, March 7Representative Wright Patman of Texas, the dean of the House of Representatives and former chairman of its Committee on Banking, Currency and Housing, died today of pneumonia at the Bethesda Naval Medical Center in Maryland. He was 82 years old.

title: A Wider Area Tests NOW Accounts
description: BOSTONA revolutionary change in money and banking is under way in traditionally conservative New England financial institutions.

title: Udall Gives Wisconsin Priority for Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, March 7Representative Morris K. Udall's first move as the selfstyled leader of the progressive wing of the Democratic Party in the Presidential race was a tactical retreat this weekend from the New York primary on April 6 and a redoubled commitment to the Wisconsin primary on the same day.

title: People
description: Robert Taylor has been elected a senior vice president of the J. Walter Thompson Company, Chicago.

title: 25 Blaschka Glass Models to Be Seen Here
description: The red maple, the seven angled pipewort, the northern panicum and the noble liverwort already had been uncrated and set up, and William A. Davis was gently withdrawing long sprays of apricot and wild peach blossoms from another packing case.

title: STRIKE POSTPONED BY GRAVEDIGGERS
description: A strike threatened for 7 AN. today at 48 metropolitanarea cemeteries was postponed last night when unionized gravediggers accepted an appeal by Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, for renewed contract bargaining in his office at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

title: Corn Sweetener Industry Is Expanding Its Share of the Market
description: The nation's consumers, long at the mercy of foreign suppliers and the fluctuating production of domestic cane and beet producers, may soon become independent of these fickle sources, thanks to the dramatic growth of the corn sweetener industry.

title: Islanders Set Back Penguins
description: PITTSBURGH, March 7On superb penaltykilling at a twoman disadvantage, tough goaltending by Bill Smith in the final period and the return to form of Denis Potvin, the New York Islanders defeated the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight 53. New York has played the last eight games without a loss.

title: Reagan Says Committed Voters Favor Him in Florida Primary
description: TITUSVILLE, Fla., March 7Ronald Reagan said today that he held the lead in Florida among committed Republicans in Tuesday's primary, but he conceded that the number of undecided voters was large enough to swing the election, to President Ford.

title: Election Reprieve
description: The Supreme Court has provided Congress with a muchneeded reprieve by extending the life of the Federal Election Commission until March 22. During this time Congress can not only reconstitute the commission as a Presidentially appointed board but also significantly strengthen the law.

title: Practice Makes Carnegie Program Perfect for 1977
description: Julius Bloom always excelled at mathematics and logic, and so it has been relatively easy for him to reduce the universe to three legalsized pages of graph paper that he keeps neatly folded in his breast pocket wherever he goes.

title: French Left Reports Gain in Local Voting
description: PARIS, March 7The French leftist opposition appeared today to have made some political gains in nationwide local elections.

title: CRITICS TO DEBATE CITY U. CLOSINGS
description: More than 100 people have asked to speak at the Board of Higher Education hearing this afternon, generally in opposition to proposals by Chancellor Robert J. Kibbee for the closing of colleges and the tightening of other controls in member institutions of City University.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Adirondack Park Agency, accused by residents of the sixmillionacre upstate tract of stifling its development and wrecking the local economy, has issued a report aimed at showing that this is not so. The survey indicates that most of the requests for development and building permits have been approvedalbeit in most cases with provisions  and that much land already approved for sale to builders has still not been taken, despite arguments from would be developers and landowners that the agency's strict landuse rules is keeping their land off the market.

title: New Team to Unify E.R.A. Campaign
description: WASHINGTONOne is a Democrat, the other a Republican. That is their biggest difference, but from there on, Liz Carpenter and Elly Peterson have ?? in common: They are articulate, sliverhaired and matronly  looking. They are feminists, but not the shrieking and shouting kind. And they are longtime party warhorses with a lot of outstanding political debts owed to them.

title: Extortion Hearing Friday
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., March 7 (UPI)A preliminary hearing has been scheduled for Friday for two men charged with trying to extort $500,000 by threatening to blow up several Sears Roebuck & Company stores. The two suspects, both of Hazleton, Pa., were identified as Richard W. Allgaier, Jr., 28 years old, and George Lesh, 20. They were arraigned before United States Magistrate Raymond Durkin on extortion charges.

title: Jackson Scores Planned Sales to Egypt
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 7Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington sharply denounced today recent Ford Administration proposals that military matriel be sold to Egypt.

title: Track Title to Farrell
description: Msgr. Farrell High School scored 93 points and won the Staten Island Catholic Track Conference indoor championship yesterday at the St. Peter's gymnasium.

title: SIMON COMMENDS SADAT ON ECONOMY
description: CAIRO, March 7Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon praised President Anwar elSadat of Egypt today as a man of tremendous vision and courage for having broken with the Soviet Union and liberalized Egypt's economy.

title: Pension Plans Canceled By 5,500 Small Companies
description: LOS ANGELES, March 6Until recently, Roy Saiki, 34yearold employee :of: the Hawaiian Papaya. Company. here, could look forward to his old age with two financial propshis Monthly Social curity check and a check from his company Pension plan.

title: Swede Victor in Slalom
description: COPPER MOUNTAIN, Colo., March 7 (AP)  Ingemar Stenm ark of Sweden strengthened his lead in the World Cup ski standing by winning the men's slalom today and Steve Mahre capped the United States best cup performance by taking second place.

title: Ford, in Turnabout, Now Seems To Lead Reagan in Florida Vote
description: MIAMI, March 7No one, of course, can say for sure who will win Tuesday's Republican Presidential primary between President Ford and former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California.

title: Firemen Seize Suspect In a Brooklyn Mugging
description: Firemen returning from a onealarm blaze in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn last night apprehended one of two youths seen mugging two young women on Marcy Avenue near Madison Street.

title: Medicaid Controls Outside City Found Subject to Abuses
description: A survey of counties outside New York City where doctors, pharmacies and others dispense health services under Medicaid indicates little or no control procedures for detecting fraud or abuse, according to the State Welfare Inspector General.

title: Egyptian Airline Receives The First of 8 Boeing 737's
description: CAIRO, March 7 (AP)Egypt received the first of eight Boeing 737 passenger planes today that were purchased by the United Arab Emirates as a gift for Egyptair, the national airline.

title: Mohtadi Squash Victor
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., March 7 (AP)Phil Mohtadi of Western Ontario won the individual title and Princeton edged Penn for team honors today at the 44th National Intercollegiate squash championships. Mohtadi, seeded No. 2, defeated a Princeton freshman, Tom Page, 158, 156, 158, in the final.

description: Gradually and apprehensively, a growing number of citizens of India who live in the United States are speaking out against restrictions in their homeland imposed by the Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

description: LANDOVER, Md., March 7  Before the Knicks and Washington Bullets went on national television today, the game should have carried the warning, The following program is for mature audiences; parental discretion should be used.

title: WARNING SOUNDED BY POSTAL CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 Postal service in the United States must be reshaped to conform to new economic reality or the vast system will be destroyed, Postmaster General Benjamin F. Bailar says in a speech he is to make tomorrow.

title: The C.I.A. SovietDiaper Blunder
description: As a former United States newsman in Moscow I would like to register a complaint. During all those years when the Central Intelligence Agency was recruiting United States foreign correspondents as intelligence sources, I was totally and incomprehensibly ignored by the agency. In fact, I believe the C.I.A. was discriminating against me by not permitting me the opportunity to serve as a simple soldier in the cold war.

title: Man, 69, Shot to Death
description: A 69yearold Brooklyn man was shot to death yesterday by a 58yearold woman with his own gun after he reportedly had pointed the weapon at the woman, who then felled him with a karate chop, took the gun from him and shot him. The dead man was identified as John H. Oliver of 1271 Bedford Avenue. The shooting occurred In the apartment of the woman, Bula McMillan, at 1151 Pacific Street in the BedfordStuyvesant section.

title: Envoy Touring Cambodia Finds a NoWage System
description: PEKING, March 7Cambodia's people are working under total mobilization to create the most radical communized society in the world, according to Sweden's Ambassador to Peking, who is the first Westerner to tour Cambodia since the Communist takeover last April.

title: John P. Doyle, Lawyer, Dies; ExMayor of Mount Kisco
description: John P. Doyle, a former Mayor of Mount Kisco, N. Y., and a lawyer there, in White Plains, New York and Southampton, L. I., for more than 40 years, died yesterday in Southampton Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Southampton.

title: Concert: Ingrid Haebler
description: Ingrid Haebler is regarded by many people, including many Viennese, as the quintessential Viennese pianist. She exudes gemiltlichkeit, that peculiar blend of geniality and warm sentiment that is as much a part of legendary Vienna as unsentimental toughness is part of legendary Brooklyn. At Hunter College yesterday afternoon, Miss Haebler gave a persuasive demonstration of the softedged Viennese style as it can be applied to composers as diverse as Mozart, Schubert and Debussy.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, MARCH 8, 1976

title: Red Smith
description: Never in memory has there been a propaganda campaign in sports to compare with the one being conducted by the men who own baseball. Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner, has a press agent, each league president has his, the Player Relations Committee has another and all are flooding the players, press and radiotelevision with prose explaining what a blessing it is to be owned by one's employer. Without the reserve system, one learns, baseball, as we know it today, could not have developed into the national pasttime it has become nor could it have grown in esteem over the decades....The greatness of baseball, its deep hold on the American public, its development into the country's national pasttime is directly attributable, in great part, to the reserve system which has engendered loyalties of the public to players and teams alike. The last presumably, refers to the loyalties of the public Brooklyn and Washington to Walter O'Malley, Calvin Griffith and Bob Short, and vice versa.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, MARCH 8, 1976

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Einstein, New Wilson Opera, Taking Shape
description: Robert Wilson has called his sprawling, mixedmedia events operas for several years now. But his new work, Einstein on the Beach, is more legitimately an opera than anything he has done so far. The reason is that Philip Glass, a composer whose credentials in the world of experimental music rival those of Mr. Wilson in experimental theater, has provided nearly five hours of continuous music to accompany the action.

title: Shah Visiting Pakistan
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, March 7 (Agence FrancePresse) The Shah of Iran arrived here today for a fiveday visit, his first since Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto came to power. The Shah was to have two discussion sessions with the Prime Minister.

description: Ralph H. Meyer, a former director and vice president of the Engelhard Minerals & Chemicals Corporation, died of a heart attack Saturday on a trip to St. Moritz, Switzerland. He was 57 years old and lived here.

description: Dogooders were once assumed to do good, ennobling themselves by proclaiming benevolence toward the dependent. Now they are assumed to do mischief, and claims of benevolence often seem the transparent cloak for a body of prejudices and fears.

description: William Schimmel, who shared a program entitled Basic Music with a fellow composer, Timothy Thompson, at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday, is an artful musical collagist with a sense of humor. His Modernestucke, for solo accordion, gleefully poked fun at the instrument's associations while stringing together fragments of pop songs, overripe romanticism. Wagnerian bombast and only Mr. Schimmel knows what else.

J., March 6 The daughter of Thomas Alva Edison sat in the library of the Victorian mansion here and recalled an evening at the turn of the century when she and her two brothers were hauled from our cribs to hear the young Polish pianist Josef Hoffmann play in the drawing room down the hall.
