description: The identification of curare in a patient involved in the Dr. X case resulted from an extraordinary collaborative effort by doctors and scientists in New Jersey and New York who tested specimens from bodies that had been exhumed 10 years after deathone of the longest intervals known to pathologists.

title: Carey Honors Temple Given Landmark Status
description: Governor Carey unveiled a bronze plaque yesterday designating Central Synagogue as a national landmark and later, in a brief talk inside the temple, told a congregation numbering more than 1,000 that in periods of tribulation it becomes important to seek a sense of permanence.

title: CITY URGED TO CUT TRANSIT, COLLEGE ANP HOSPITAL AID
description: The Citizens Budget Commis. sion proposed yesterday cutting $400 million in city spending for transit subsidies, the City University and municipal hospitals rather than making acrosstheboard cuts that might affect police and fire protection, sanitation, health and public schools

title: Edison House Relives Past
description: LLEWELLYN PARK, N.J. March 6The daughter of Thomas Alva Edison sat in the library of the Victorian mansion here and recalled an evening at the turn of the century when she and her two brothers were hauled from our cribs to hear the young Polish pianist Josef Hofmann play in the drawing room down the hall.

title: High Bonn Official Underlines Concern Over U.S. Resolve
description: BONN, March 7 (Reuters)West Germany's Foreign Minister, HansDietrich Genscher, expressed disappointment tonight with United States reaction to Communist interyention in Angola.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: BILL PUTS CEILING ON STATE SPENDING
description: TRENTON, March 8A bill to put a 5 percent ceiling on increases in state spending for general operations was approved today by the Assembly Taxation Committee.

title: GOLD
description: Handy & Harman base price, New York: $132.90, down $1.05.

title: Quednau Will Switch to the Mile Run
description: When Doug Quednau of New York Tech won the 1,000yard run at the IC4A track and field championships at Princeton on Sunday, not everyone was thunderstruck.

title: Signing of Sarnoff As RCA Consultant Disclosed in Proxy
description: The RCA Corporation disclosed yesterday that it had signed a contract with its former chairman and chief executive officer, Robert W. Sarnoff, for him to furnish consultation and advice to RCA and the National Broadcasting Company on matters with respect to which he has special competence.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Dilemma
description: BOMBAYIn its 29 years of independence, India has increased its population more than the United States has in all the 200 years of its history. To its 628 million people it is currently adding some 13 million annually, which is equivalent to absorbing an Australia a year.

title: CLIFFORD W. MICHEL, INVESTMENT BANKER
description: Clifford W. Michel, an investment banker, died Monday at his home at 35 East 76th Street. He was 64 years old.

title: Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Lilco's Petition on HigherSulfur Oil Is Rejected by Environmental Agency
description: The Long Island Lighting Company was told yesterday that it would not be able to use cheaper, highersulfur oil in two plants in Nassau County because the resulting emissions would contribute to violating Federal sulfur dioxide standards in New York City.

title: 2 Uganda Pilots Pregnant; Amin Urges. SelfControl
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 8 (AP)President Idi Amin of Uganda has urged women pilots of the Uganda Air Force to exercise selfcontrol, after disclosure that two of the seven being trained are pregnant.

title: Control Board Chief
description: When Stephen Berger was working only 12 to 14 hours a day as the manager of some sharpelbowed political operations, people who telephoned his home would hear his recorded voice tell what had happened on that date in the Civil War. After enduring the history lesson, they could leave their message. No history these days, he said regretfully yesterday. No time.

title: Philadelphia College Struck
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 8 (AP)A faculty strike started today at Philadelphia Community College, suspending classes for some 11,000 students. The dispute centers on wages and equalization of work loads, according to the American Federation of Teachers, which represents the strikers.

title: JERSEY PLANNING STEERING INQUIRY
description: TEANECK, N.J., March 8Joseph P. Merlino, the Democratic majority leader of the State Senate, disclosed tonight that he would conduct a legislative investigation into alleged racial steering in the suburban housing market in Bergen County.

title: 8 Killed as Car Hits Group of 50 Youths At Ohio Intersection
description: MARIA STEIN, Ohio, March 8 (AP)A car plowed into about 50 high school pupils standing at a rural intersection last night after they had halted their car caravan on the way to a dance. Eight of them died and four others were injured, the authorities said.

title: Stocks Register Strong Gains; Rates of Interest Edge Lower
description: Interest rates declined slightly yesterday in the wake of the Federal Reserve injection of reserves into the banking system last Friday only shortly after it had indicated it would likely be draining funds.Threemonth Treasury bills were auctioned at an average rate of 5.06 percent, down from 5.26 percent a week earlier, and the Treasury's new fouryear notes moved down in yield to 7.42 percent from 7.54 percent.

title: BERGER IS NAMED TO REPLACE ELISH ON CONTROL BOARD
description: Governor Carey yesterday appointed Stephen Berger, the State Commissioner of Social Services, to replace Herbert Elish as the chief administrator of the Emergency Financial Control Board, the state panel overseeing the city's fiscal reform.

title: Women in Peking Assail Teng as Male Chauvinist
description: PEKING, March 8 (Reuters)Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping, already under fire for being a capitalist roader, was today accused by the women of Peking of being a male chauvinist.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The city warned the New York Yankees yesterday that a labor dispute involving the baseball team's concessionaire could jeopardize the scheduled opening of the refurbished Yankee Stadium April 15.

title: Inquiryon Steering Proposed in Jersey
description: TEANECK, N.J., March 8Joseph P. Merlino, the Democratic majority leader of the State Senate, disclosed tonight that he would conduct a legislative investigation into alleged racial steering M the suburban housing market in Bergen County.

title: Adam Smith's Economics Revived in Election Year
description: Two revolutions were begun in 1776.

title: Rockefeller U. at 75
description: Rockefeller University's current celebration of its 75th anniversary Is an event of international significance. Before the founding of what was initially the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, biological and medical investigation was essentially a cottage industry dependent upon the accidents of genius and circumstance that permitted the achievements of a Pasteur or a Koch. What John D. Rockefeller did was to create an institution for systematically fostering research genius by bringing together superlatively able scientists and providing them ideal conditions in which to work. It is impossible to conceive of modern medicine or biology without the remarkable contributions made by Rockefeller University scientists.

title: M'BRIDE, A U.N. AIDE, CHIDED BY WALDHEIM
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 8 (AP)Secretary General Kurt Waldheim has ordered Sean MacBride, the United Nations Commissioner for Namibia, or SouthWest Africa, to coordinate future statements with headquarters, a United Nations spokesman said today.

title: Radio
description: 67:25 A.M, WNYCFM. Suite from The Seasons, Glazunov; Divertissement, Ibert; Rapsodia Portuguese, Halffter; Symphony No. 4, Roussel.

title: Planned City U. Cuts Spur Protest
description: A parade of speakers at public hearing of the Board of Higher Education yesterday attacked a plan to restructure the City University, calling it morally bankrupt, shortsighted and a surrender to budgetconscious bureaucrats.

title: A Foreign Service Leader Censured for Testimony
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI) Board members of the American Foreign Service Association voted today to censure the association's president for criticizing some Foreign Service officers before a Senate committee.

title: $100,000 Women's Event
description: LONDON, March 8 (AP)Women's tennis in Britain received a lift today with a new $100.000 glass tournament at Eastbourne June 14 to 19, the week before Wimbledon.

title: Final College Conference Standings
description: KNICKERBOCKER

title: BLACK RHODESIANS SEEK U.S SUPPORT
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 8Joshua Nkomo, a Rhodesian black leader who is negotiating with Prime Minister Ian Smith for majority rule in Rhodesia, called on the United States today to state very categorically they will not support in any way a white minority regime, and support majority rule now.

title: Old Age, a New Problem, Troubles Indian Families
description: BOMBAY, India, March 8 In a small, sunny parlor in a middleclass suburb of Bombay, two dozen old men gather for an hour or so at the end of every day to discuss their common problems.

title: In Brazil, the Women Boast About Their Plastic Surgery
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 5If someone wants to buy fine glassware he goes to Czechoslovakia, Altamiro da Rocha Oliveira, a leading surgeon here recently noted. If he wants the best wine, he goes to France. But everybody knows that for plastic surgery you come to a Brazilian.

title: Nader Settles a Lawsuit Over Dannon'sRon Raider
description: WASHINGTON March 8 (UPI) Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, announced today that he had accepted $15,000 to settle a lawsuit he filed against the makers of Gannon Yogurt and its advertising agency.

title: DALE FABYAN
description: Dale Fabyan, an assistant vice president with the First Boston Corporation died early Monday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 34 years old and lived at 170 East 79th Street.

title: NAVY ORDERS HALT ON AN LTV PROJECT
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)! The Navy said today that it had ordered the LTV Corporation to stop all development! work on a sealaunched cruise missile because of a cost overrun. The action may drop LTV from competition for a poteni tially big program unless the General Dynamics Corporation fails in an important test of its version of the missile.

title: State Senate Acts to Aid Truant Voters
description: ALBANY, March 8  The Senate approved and sent to the Assembly today a bill that would allow an estimated total of 200,000 people in New York City, whose eligibility to vote would ordinarily would have lapsed, to vote in two primaries and one election this year.

title: British Soccer Standing
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE FIRST DIVISION

title: John Devlin, Police Officer, Set Longevity Record, 90
description: ELMIRA, N.Y. March 8 (AP) John J. Devlin, said to be the country's oldest police officer when he retired in April 1974, died here yesterday. He was 90 years old.

title: British Pound Falls Again; Hits a New Low of $1.94
description: LONDON, March 8 (UPI)The British pound fell to record lows today, hitting $1.92 before the Bank of England came to its rescue.

title: New Kodak Camera Due
description: ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 8 (UPI)A new TeleInstamatic Kodak camera that can take either normal or telephoto pictures with two builtin lenses was announced today by the Eastman Kodak Company. It will be available in May and sell for $110,50. It will use 110size film and will have an electronic shutter and silicon cell exposure control.

title: Born '63. Graduated '74. Elected '76.
description: I was past middle age when the Free Speech movement exploded on the Berkeley campus in 1964. Like most older people I was outraged by the sight of history made by juvenile delinquents. Yet, from the beginning, part of me was straining for a detached view. I became interested in the role the young had played in history, and it did not take much research to show me that we can hardly know how things had happened in history unless we keep in mind that much of the time it was juveniles who made them happen.

title: Unseld XRays Negative
description: LANDOVER, Md., March 8 (UPI)The Washington Bullets announced today that Xrays taken on Wes Unseld's sprained right foot proved negative and that the 6foot7inch center would play in the National Basketball Association club's next game, at Boston on Sunday. Unsaid sprained his foot yesterday in the Bullets' victory over the Knicks.

title: Workers Yield Paper
description: LISBON, March 8 (Reuters) Radical leftwing workers who seized the Socialist newspaper Reptiblica last May handed the keys back to its owners today, the former editor, Raul Rego, said.

title: Alabama Triumphs For S.E.C. Title
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 8 (AP)Reginald King scored 8 points in overtime to lead eighthranked Alabama to an 84777 victory over Vanderbilt tonight and the Southeastern Conference basketball championship. It was Alabama's first recent outright S.E.C. championship. The Crimson Tide shared the crown with Vanderbilt and Kentucky, respectively, the last two seasons.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, March 8, 1976

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 9, 1976

title: Fiscal Crisis Mutes Albany's Usual Drama
description: ALBANY, March 8  March had figured to be a month of high drama in Albany, the culmination of the yearlong fiscal crisis and the ultimate test of the state's solvency. Governor

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1976, by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Monday, March 8. 51st day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: A Film Depicts Home Care for the Elderly
description: ELIZABETHA film demonstrating how visiting nurses help the elderly to maintain their health and avoid costly institutional care has been produced for the New Jersey Nurses Association.

title: REAGAN DOUBTFUL ON FLORIDA VOTING
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 8Ronald Reagan departed from Florida today on the eve of the vital primary here to go on to campaign in Illinois, and the candidate was uncharacteristically downbeat on his chances to defeat President Ford in either state.

title: ExHousing Aide, Cleared of Bribery, Collapses in Court
description: A 50yearold former housing inspector collapsed in State Supreme Court yesterday as a jury acquitted him of accepting $30 in payoffs from an undercover police sergeant to overlook building violations in a midtown masage parlor.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption that appeared on page 1 in The New York Times of March 4 incorrectly stated that an unidentified woman in a photograph was about to kiss Representative Morris K. Udall as he campaigned here. The woman was trying to show Mr. Udall a button that indicated her support of Senator Birch Bayh.

title: RAYMOND LIDDY DIPLOMATIC AIDE
description: Raymond G. Leddy, a retired foreign Service officer who specialized in Latin American affairs, died Friday on vacation in Punta Gorda, Fla. He was 63 years old and lived in Carlisle, Pa.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market finished higher yesterday in moderate trading.

title: Nigeria Says Ousted Briton Sent Bill During Mourning
description: LONDON, March 8 (UPI)Nigeria said today that it had demanded the recall of Britain's diplomatic representative because he presented a bill for damage to his office before the mourning period had ended for Nigeria's slain head of state.

title: A.B.A. Head Asks More Bank Disclosure As Way to Stem Erosion of Confidence
description: ATLANTA, March 8The head of the American Bankers Association called today for greater disclosure by the nation's banks to stem what he called an erosion of confidence in the banking system.

title: Duke of Leinster Is Dead at 83; Was Premier Peer of Ireland
description: LONDON, March 8 (Reuters) Ireland's premier peer, the seventh Duke of Leinster, who might have been one of Britain's wealthiest men, died penniless here tonight in a tiny tworoom apartment. He was 83 years old.

title: Owners, Players & Money
description: From the penthouse bar of the St. Petersburg Hilton an itinerant reporter peered down expectantly the other day to see the Mets at play in Al Lang Field. But not only were the Mets not there, Al Lang Field wasn't either. The latter vacancy is apparently redeemable, since St. Petersburg is rebuilding the old playground, which now resembles a bomb crater. The absence of the Mets, alas, may be more serious.

title: Split With Gov. Askew Seen as Hurting Carter
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., March 8 When asked for his opinion of the recent New Hampshire primary, Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida said it was a case of Jimmy Carter shaking 50,000 hands to get 25.000 votes.

title: Chicago Board Options Exchange
description: MONDAY, MARCH 8, 1976

title: Dissident I.R.S. Aides Contend They Felt Pressures to Retire
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 Two former Internal Revenue Service officials and one present official have told House investigating committee members that pressure had been unfairly put on them to retire because their policies did not suit Donald C. Alexander, the I.R.S. Commissioner, Congressional sources said today.

title: Binkley, Goalie, Retires
description: TORONTO, March 8 (AP)The Toronto Toros said today that their 42yearold goaltender, Les Binkley, had left the World Hockey Association team for medical reasons and retired.

title: State Department Pledges Discipline in Mideast Leak
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The State Department said today that it would discipline the official who provided secret material on Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's conversations with Middle East leaders that was included in an article iust published.

title: Luxor Baths Owner Rules Out Criminal Action on Prostitution
description: The city called yesterday upon the head of a huge realestate organization to take trespass action against the occupants of Luxor Baths, who are allegedly converting the ninestory building in the Times Square area into one of the most lavish massage and prostitution establishments in the nation.

title: Yonkers Results
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax.) FIRST$7,500, trot, mile.

title: Rise in Port Traffic Seen
description: ALBANY (AP) The State Department of Transportation has predicted that freight traffic at five upstate ports may double in the next few years. Named in a study by the department were the ports of Albany, Buffalo, Ogdensburg, Oswego and Rochester.

title: ARANICO GUARDED ON FLORIDA TALKS
description: The Arabian American Oil Company declined to say yesterday whether a definite agreement on the takeover of Aramco by the Saudi Government would be announced following a meeting between the Aramco partners being held in Panama City. Fla.

title: BANKRUPTCY STEP TAKEN BY TRUST
description: Financially troubled Continental Mortgage Investors, the nation's second largest real estate investment trust last year, filed yesterday for reorganization under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The petition was filed in bankruptcy court in Boston where the trust maintains offices.

title: Unemployment a Way of Life in One Connecticut Valley
description: DANIELSON, Conn.Unemployment is not a passing, phenomenon in Windham County. The people who live on the gentle slopes in the rustic northeastern corner of Connecticut or alongside the aging Redbrick mills on the winding Quinebaug River have endured hard times for 30 years.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 8Consumer installment credit rose strongly in January, showing the largest growth for a month since August 1974, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The January increase in credit outstanding was $1.29 billion, well above the growth of $894 million December, which in turn was the largest for any month last year.

title: Exxon Disputes California's Rules on Offshore Oil
description: LOS ANGELES, March 8In the first confrontation between the petroleum industry and a state over conditions of new offshore oil development, a major oil company vowed last week to do its initial processing at sea rather than meet state requirements for onshore operations.

title: Dowling Is Beaten In N.A.I.A.
description: KANSAS CITY (AP)Joe Pace's gamehigh 29 points and 14 rebounds today enabled ninthseeded Coppin State to post a 7855 victory over Dowling College of Oakdale, L. I., in a firstround game at the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball tournament.

title: 3 Deer Dead After Crash
description: WARREN, Pa., March 8 (AP) A deer was struck by an automobile at a street intersection today, then jumped through a restaurant's plate glass window and gave birth to twins, this police said. One fawn was stillborn. The police said the doe's stomach was slashed by the broken glass and she was destroyed. The other fawn died a short time after birth.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: DAVID CHURCH, LED FUNDRAISING UNIT
description: David M. Church, the first fulltime paid chief executive of the American Association of FundRaising Counsel, died yesterday in North Penn Hospital in Lansdale, Pa. He was 82 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: CONNECTICUT GETS UNCHANGED RATING
description: HARTFORD, March 8Connecticut was given a strong measure of reassurance today when Standard & Poor's rating service decided to retain the state's AA bond rating.

title: People in Sports
description: Arthur Ashe, fresh from his victories in the World Cup, was in town yesterday to pick up an award as the Martini & Rossi tennis player of the year. The award included a check for $7,500. Ashe indicated he had patched up his differences with Jimmy Connors, whom he called a very charming guy and the biggest male attraction in tennis.

title: Chess:
description: When David Bronstein offered me a draw after 25 moves of our game in the Alekhine Memorial Tournament in Moscow in 1971, was quite willing to accept. The position had become a tortuous tangle of backward pawns and weak squares on both sides and, if anyone had the advantage, it was a mystery to both of us.

title: Waldman Violin Recital
description: It would be hard for a violinist to select a braver program ?? Yuval Waldman chose for his recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night: three works, all unaccompanied and all packed with technical and interpretative problems calling for the highest level of virtuosic playing.

title: Federal Aide Asks Congress to Study Auto Parts Prices
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI)Congress should look into whether auto manufacturers and dealers are inflating prices on replacement parts to make up for lost sales and to put pressure on customers to buy new cars, a Federal consumer official said today.

title: Tracer of Eichmann Says Here That 62 Nazis May Be in U.S.
description: Simon Wiesenthal, who has spent most of his life pursuing Nazi war criminals and who played a prominent role in the discovery of Adolf Eichmann in Argentina, said last night that maybe in a few months we'll have something on 62 suspected war criminals who are believed to be in the United States.

title: Denial of Job for Woman Priest Reportedly Investigated by U.S.
description: The United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission is reported to have accepted jurisdiction in a complaint by a woman who was ordained to the Episcopal priesthood but denied employment as a priest by her Bishop.

title: Lois Replacing J.W.T. At Publicker Distillers
description: Publicker Distillers Products didn't take long to find a new agency to replace the J. Walter Thompson Company for its Inver House Scotch. It announced on Feb. 23 that it would be looking for a new agency. Yesterday it announced it had one, Lois, Holland, Callaway, which lost Cutty Sark to Scali, McCabe, Sloves in January.

title: Planned City U. Cuts Spur Protest
description: A parade of speakers at a public hearing of the Board of Higher Education yesterday attacked a plan to restructure the City University, calling it morally bankrupt, shortsighted and a surrender to budgetconscious bureaucrats.

title: SONG RECITAL GIVEN BY GABRIELLA TUCCI
description: Gabriella Tucci, a soprano from Rome, enjoyed a busy, if not always wildly successful, ??cade at the Metropolitan Opera that ended rather abruptly two years ago, Sunday night, she returned for a Carnegie Hall recital, and the results weren't too happy.

title: People and Business
description: Howard R. Hughes, the reclusive billionaire, did it again yesterday. He failed to appear before the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington to give a deposition in connection with the Government agency's suit against him, several of his companies and some of his associates.

title: The Farm Vote . . .
description: In Illinois, where an important Republican primary will be held one week from today, President Ford has been energetically trying to rebuild his support among farmers.

title: BUS UNION BEGINS JERSEY WALKOUT
description: The Amalgamated Transit Union began a strike at one minute after midnight today against Transport of New Jersey, after its members voted to reject the final offer made by the state's largest bus company, which serves 450,000 riders daily.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Dr. Milton Helpern, former New York City Medical Examiner and one of the nation's leading experts in forensic pathology, has been engaged by the family of Karen Ann Quinlan to determine how the 21yearold woman slipped into a coma last year, Paul Armstrong, the family's lawyer, said. Mr. Armstrong said Dr. Helpern would review an autopsy that will be performed when she dies. Miss Quinlan, who lost consciousness after taking a mixture alcohol and tranquilizer last April, has been in St. Clare's Hospital in Denville in a vegetative state. Medical authorities have said there is no chance the woman will recover from the massive brain damage she suffered.

title: Doctor Calls Miss Hearst Willing Bandit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 8An expert witness for the prosecution testified today that in his opinion Patricia Hearst voluntarily joined her revolutionary captors within four weeks of her kidnapping and then took part willingly in the bank robbery for which she is on trial.

title: Bomb Is Set Off At 5th Ave. Office Of Soviet Airline
description: A small bomb exploded with a reverberating roar last night outside a Fifth Avenue building housing the Soviet and Czechoslovak national airlines.

title: Notes on People
description: The nation's first woman major general, Jeanne M. Holm, was appointed by President Ford yesterday to be his special assistant for women's affairs. Miss Holm, aged 54, retired from the Air Force last June as director of its personnel council. From 1965 to 1972 she was director of women in the Air Force.

title: Slates for Wallace Facing Elimination From State Ballot
description: With his delegate candidates rued off the ballot in 13 Congressional districts and facing the same fate in 11 other districts, Goy. George C. WalIace of Alabama is in danger of being eliminated as a factor in the April 6 New York Democratic Presidential primary.

title: Congress Is Viewed as Unlikely to Meet High Court's Deadline for Keeping Election Commission
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 Despite steppedup activity, Congress appears unlikely to reach agreement on new changes in the Federal campaign law in time to meet the second deadline imposed by the Supreme Court.

title: Retreat in Trenton
description: Governor Byrne's willingness to face the political storms in his persistent advocacy of a badly needed New Jersey income tax has justly won him many admirers. But his latest official action in this respect is so contrary to his earlier principled stand that it must bewilder friend and foe alike, and cast a further shadow over the prospects for a Jersey income tax.

title: Cuba's African Role
description: Secretary of State Kissinger's concern over Cuban military adventures in Africa is well taken and is widely shared by others, including some black African Governments. The 12,000 Cuban soldiers who helped the Popular Front win the civil war in Angola are said to constitute more than ten percent of Fidel Castro's army; there are Cuban military missions of varying sizes in at least six other African or Arab countries.

title: Defense Minister Out
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 8 (Reuters)  President Isabel Martinez de Pern has accepted the resignation of Defense Minister Ricardo Guardo, it was officially annouced tonight.

title: Standard & Poor's Gives Connecticut Unchanged Rating
description: HARTFORD, March 8Connecticut was given a strong measure of reassurance today when Standard & Poor's rating service decided to retain the state's AA bond rating.

title: Wallace Pushing Hard For Wide Florida Vote
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 8Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama toured the length of the Florida peninsula by plane today in a lastminute push for every possible vote in tomorrow's Democratic Presidential primary.

title: Borg Wins by Default
description: KEAUHOUKONA, Hawaii, March 8 (AP)Bjorn Borg won the $10,000 Avis Challenge Cup match by default today when Raul Ramirez of Mexico suffered a pulled leg muscle and had to quit in the fourth set. The Swede was leading, 63, 46, 60, 30.

title: South Africa to Let Blacks Drink in Homes of Whites
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, March 8 (AP)  Whites will be able to serve liquor to their black guests under legislation published today.

title: Egypt Says 7 Libyan Soldiers Admit Kidnapping Plot in Cairo
description: CAIRO, March 8Egypt accused Libya today of having sent seven soldiers in civilian clothes to Cairo to kidnap two dissident Libyan politicians and commit other acts of violence.

title: 2,000 ON OTB STAFF THREATEN STRIKE
description: The union representing 2,000 clerks and cashiers at Offtrack Betting Corporation offices throughout the city threatened a strike for 7:30 A.M. tomorrow unless their salaries and those of branch managers were deferred on an equal basis.

title: Hollace Shaw, Radio Singer, Symphony Soprano, Is Dead
description: Hollace Shaw, who sang her way to fame in the 1930's and 40's as a soloist with the CBS radio network here, died in Los Angeles last Tuesday. She was 62 years old and lived in Fall River Mills, Calif.

title: 7 Jersey G.OP.. Leaders Form Special Unit for Ford
description: TRENTON, March 8 (AP)Six of New Jersey's top Republican officeholders and the most recent gubernatorial candidate got on President Ford's bandwagon today.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: BERGER IS NAMED TO REPLACE ELISH ON CONTROL BOARD
description: Governor Carey yesterday appointed Stephen Berger, the State Commissioner of Social Services, to replace Herbert Elish as the chief administrator of the Emergency Financial Control Board, the state panel overseeing the city's fiscal reform.

title: EDWARD J. WINTERS
description: Edward J. Winters, a retired investment broker, died Saturday in Frederiksted, St. Croix, Virgin Islands. He was 82 years old.

title: Dissident I.R.S. Aides Contend They Felt Pressures to Retire
description: WASHINGTON, March 8Two former Internal Revenue Service officials and one present official have told House investigating committee members that pressure had been unfairly put on them to retire because their policies did not suit Donald C. Alexander, the I.R.S. Commissioner, Congressional sources said today.

title: Unions Vow Peace For Battery Housing
description: In an effort to spur the long delayed Battery Park City, the city's construction unions an nounced yesterday that they had promised labor peace to the builders of the $1.5 billion development to go up on landfill in the Hudson River.

title: Save Our Sports and Kids Like Roberto
description: His football coaches at DeWitt Clinton High School remember Roberto for what he accomplished off the field, not on it. He wanted to be a wide receiver but he wasn't fast enough or big enough. But the coaches never cut anybody. If a youngster wanted to cut himself by no longer practicing with the team, that was the youngster's business. The coach didn't cut him from the squad as long as he showed up for practice. Roberto always showed up. He also read instructional books on football. He didn't read that well but slowly his reading improved. So did his marks. So did his poise. When he was graduated, he went on to college. He's in law school now. His coaches are convinced that if it hadn't been for football, Roberto might be on the streets now, maybe on drugs, maybe in a jam with the police. His name happened to be Roberto and he happened to be Hispanic but there are thousands of public high school youngsters like Roberto for whom sports provide a motivation to study. Many of those high school sports programs are jeopardy because of the city's financtal distress. But the Board of Education has rejected an offer by the BristolMeyers Company to save high school sports by restoring nearly $1 million that the city has slashed from Its annual budget. According to the Board of Education, legal problems and its policy prompted its decision. Apparently the BristolMeyers offer was too commercial. Actually it's probably too sensible.

title: 3,500 Chant Outside 42d St. Hearing
description: A chanting crowd of demonstrators, estimated by the police at 3,500, gathered outside the Graduate Center of the City University on West 42d Street yesterday as the Board of Higher Education held its public hearing on Chancellor Robert J. Kibbee's proposals for restructuring the university.

title: WHEAT AND CORN OFF DESPITE RAIN
description: Rain of threequarters to an inch over wheat areas of central and western Oklahoma surprised grain traders yesterday at the Chicago Board of Trade. The panhandle region of Texas and parts of Kansas also received rain, described as sparse and no more than twotenths of an inch.

title: U.S. Jews Warning Ford On Selling Planes to Egypt

title: Portuguese Socialist Presses Drive With 20 Rallies in Two Days
description: ALVOCO DAS VARZEAS, Portugal, March 8We defeated a Communist move to set up a dictatorship and we're going to fight just as hard to prevent a return of the fascists, the Socialist leader, Mario Soares, told a crowd of several hundred farmers in this modest village 200 miles northeast of Lisbon.

title: Uncommitted Block Ahead In Carolina Democratic Vote

description: ALVIN, Tex. March 8 (AP) At least 14 persons were injured and several homes and businesses damaged this afternoon when a tornado moved across this southeast Texas city of 12,000.

description: With his delegate candidates ruled off the ballot in 13 Congressional districts and facing the same fate in 11 other districts, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama is in danger of being eliminated as a factor in the April 6 New York Democratic Presidential primary.

title: Glass Forms of Today Hark Back to Yesterday
description: The glass exhibition now being held in the lobby of Lever House is a rainbow experience. The more than 250 pieces are brilliant jewels in a vast spectrum of color and pattern. But with all the open expanse in the building at Park Avenue and 53d Street, the works are so squeezed together into cases in a few spots in the lobby that you will have to work rather hard to discover what's there.

title: Philippines Faces a Sugar Crisis
description: BACOLOD, the Philippines, March 8 (AP)School gymnasiums, swimming pools and churches In this sugar bowl of the Philippines have been turned into emergency sugar storehouses in what trade sources say is a gamble by the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos to force up the sagging world sugar price.

title: Showdown on Clean Air
description: Four members of Congress from the metropolitan area appear to hold the key today to a House Commerce Committee vote that could significantly affect the quality of air New Yorkers breathe.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DOW N SOUTH One of the joys of the teeming business area just below City Hall is the relaxing haven of quiet and historical interest provided by St. Paul's Chapel in venerable Trinity Church.The church, once the tallest building in New York, and its picturesque graveyard occupy the block between Broadway and Fulton, Church and Vesey Streets, with the 210yearold spire now dwarfed by the World Trade Center. Open daily from 7 A.M. to 6 P.M., the chapel is a favorite visiting spot for tourists and office workers.

title: Surtees Keeps Title In Racquets Singles
description: Bill Surtees of Chicago successfully defended his national men's racquets singles crown Sunday at the Racquet and Tennis Club by defeating David McClernon of Montreal in the final, 159, Canadian champion, was seeded second.

title: Mrs. Hiavaty Victor
description: BOZEMAN, Mont., March 8 (AP)Jana Hiavaty of Chicago, an Olympian, won the women's 10kilometer ski race today at the United States Ski Association's senior Nordic championships. Kevin Swigert of Sun Valley, Idaho, edged Stan Dunklee of Brattleboro, Vt., in the men's 30kilometer.

title: QUAKER OIL SETS MERGER ACCORD
description: The Quaker State Oil Refining Corporation of Oil City. Pa., and the Valley Camp Coal Company of Cleveland, will merge through an exchange of stock, it was announced yesterday. Quaker State will exchange 3.625 shares of its stock for each share of Valley Camp. With 870,760 shares of Valley Camp common shares outstanding, Quaker State will provide 3,069,429 shares worth about $57.5 million to effect the merger.

title: Adam Smith's Economics Revived in Election Year

title: Islander Ticket Policy Drawing Fans' Interest
description: New York Islander seasonticket holders who have bought the first strip of playoff tickets  a possible total of six home games in rounds one and two  are complaining because the hockey club will not refund their money should the team be eliminated early.

title: Soliah Trial Put Off for a Day; Press to Hear Selection of Jury
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 8 (AP)A Federal court judge today postponed the start of the Stephen Soliah bank robbery trial for one day after refusing to bar the press and the public from the questioning of prospective jurors.

title: Yonkers Fears Jersey Track
description: YONKERS, March 8 While people were traveling to Yonkers Raceway tonight perhaps they noticed New Jersey, the state across the river, and even admired the Palisades.

title: Circle in Square Notes 25th Birth day
description: Mayor Beame sat on one side of the aisle; the actor George C. Scott sat across from him on the other. Both wer ewaiting to go on. Art and politics and a hefty amount of money were joined last night in celebrating the 25th anniversary of the Circle in the Square Theatre.

title: FED TARGET WIDER AT JAN. 20 MEETING
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee decided at its January meeting that the course of the nation's money supply had become so mystifying that it established an unusually wide target range for growth of money in the period ahead, it was disclosed today.

title: TV: Song of Myself, Effective Portrait of Whitman
description: CBSTV's American Parade series, keyed to the Bicentennial, reaches its most artistically successful level tonight, at 10 o'clock, with Song of Myself, an impressionistic, rather sketchy but generally effective portrait of Walt Whitman. Jan Hartman's quite admirable script focuses on Whitman as poet, son, brother, wanderer, eccentric and, with unusual but unsensational candor, homosexual.

title: Options Available in Bus Strike
description: NEWARK, March 8Officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey expected commuter rail lines today to meet much of the demand for alternative service to New York in the event of a strike against the Transport of New Jersey Bus Company.

title: Canada to Decide by April On Deal With Lockheed
description: OTTAWA, March 8 (AP) Canada will decide by the end of this month whether to go ahead with a $1 billion purchase of 18 longrange patrol airplanes from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation. Supply Minister JeanPierre Goyer said today.

title: New Fossil Discoveries Indicate That an Advanced Man Had Evolved by 3.75 Million Years Ago
description: WASHINGTON, March 8Recent fossil discoveries in East Africa have yielded strong evidence that the form of early man that had evolved by 3.75 million years ago was anatomically much more like modern man than had been supposed.

title: It's Almost Over in Florida, So Candidates' Strategists Look Ahead
description: MIAMI, March 8Today was the day before the day that counts in Florida, and while the candidates made their final appeals for votes in tomorrow's Presidential primary, their strategists' thoughts turned to the future.

description: MIAMI, March 8The candidates scouring Florida for votes in tomorrow's primary election have found a state that has changed since the last Presidential primary in 1972. The leaders here are looking in a new direction.

description: POTOMAC. Md., March 8 (UPI)The five bodies found In a shallow North Carolina grave last week were the imother, wife and three sons of la missing State Department official, authorities said today.

Admission for the exhibition, which will begin at 6:45 P.M., is $17,50 for contestants and $1.60 for spectators.

title: Music: Bartok Quartet
description: Surprisingly enough, the performances Friday and Sunday of the Bartk Quartet at Alice Tully Hall, presented under the auspices of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, constituted the group's first New York performances in a major hall. There had been an obscure college date a few years back. But despite a major reputation through records and several American tours, this was the Hungarian string quartet's first important New York date.

title: Homebound Find Help From the Easter Seals
description: A steady diet of four walls can have a devastating effect on the homebound. This is the great concern of The New York Easter Seal Home Service. It keeps the handicapped child and adult in touch with the outside world through visiting volunteers, craft sessions, excursions, a monthly publication, annual special events, art shows. Your support of The 1976 Annual Easter Eeal Appeal will assure the continuance of this vital program. Please send your contribution to The Easter Seal Society, 185 Madison Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10016.

title: Body Found on Expressway
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., March 8 (AP)Three Suffolk County police today asked the public to help identify the body of a white male found fully clothed but wrapped in a blanket at Long Island Expressway Exit 69 in Manorville. They said the man had been shot in the chest and also showed marks from an old bullet wound in the right thigh. The middleaged man was 5 feet 3 inches, weighed 138 pounds and was dressed in red shirt and trousers and a brown leather jacket.

title: Books of The Times
description: There is no such thing as a free child, according to John Rothchild and Susan Berns Wolf. When I read this line, I felt as if I had been waiting for years to hear someone say that. As one of my favorite poets observed, Each prison opens on another. A child today is trapped between the stereotypes of convention and rebellion. If he has too little freedom, his personality is squashed, as if by a garbage compressor; if he has too much, he is simply blown away. Finding the right degree of freedom for a child today is rather like the medieval alchemist's search for the philosopher's stone.

This will he the best session of the Legislature ever, the 47yearold Democrat of Bayonne said.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 9, 1976

title: 'Confrontation,' a Swiss Film on Nazis and Numbness
description: Like Oran in Camus's "The Plague," Zurich is sick. It is sick with the sickness of history: apathy and disconnection while horrors take place all around. Just over in Germany, Hitler is putting together a formidable method out of madness."Here it is like living under the rim of a cheese dish," a Zurich Jew says, trying in vain to stir up his fellow Jews at a kosher restaurant. They are alarmed but calm; optimistic not from evidence but from need. They worry, they eat, they joke.In "Confrontation," which is being shown at the 68th Street Playhouse, the Swiss director Rolf Lyssy films numbness virtually in physical form, as if it were architecture or statues.Into this numbness of the normal comes the abnormal agent. He is Frankfurter, a Yugoslav Jew who leaves his medical studies in Germany when the pressures begin to build up and seeks a haven in Switzerland. He finds companions, a girlfriend and peace; or at least he would have peace if he didn't also have an extraordinary sensitivity to evil in the air. The evil is Nazism.Frankfurter has a wasting illness that requires numerous operations. Mr. Lyssy preserves the ambiguity or the irony: Is Frankfurter's sensitivity a part of his illness, or is it sanity, and sanity a kind of illness in a sick world?Frankfurter notices symptoms and is obsessed by them. He notices the headlines in a Zurich Nazi paper; he notices the swastika in the lapel of a passer-by. He retreats from his friends and from his studies, and one day he buys a gun, goes to the house of a local Nazi leader and kills him. He is arrested, tried and jailed.Mr. Lyssy has made a highly intelligent movie but perhaps not a very successful one. He has adopted a flat and deliberately uninflected style, which has some hint of the work of Jean-Marie Straub. The sequences move rapidly, abruptly, bitten off at the end, and almost without transitions. This is effective, in fact; what does not work so well, and turns an original and disturbing film into something of a political pamphlet, is the long trial scene.Mr. Lyssy wants to show the imperviousness of the mechanisms of society to genuine moral questions. He lays out in full the speeches of counselthe state prosecutor, the Nazi lawyers representing the widow, the old defense lawyer who reads endlessly from articles about Nazism in an attempt to justify his client.They are boring, they are mechanical, and they miss the moral point that is mutely reflected on the face of Frankfurter, magnificently played by Peter Bollag. It is not just evil that is banal, the film suggests, but good, or at least the narrow kind of good that society conceives itself as upholding.The trouble is that this banality, this thickness is not merely stated or suggested. It plays on and on in the courtroom until we, like some of the courtroom public, feel like getting up and leaving.Here too, of course, Mr. Lyssy makes his point; we show a callousness that could spawn new monsters if we, like those in the courtroom, get bored with the mumbled reading-out of Nazi atrocities. Except we are not in a courtroom; we are at a movie. Our moral obligations are vastly different. Our freedom is different.It is too long, it is hard to take, and the ending pulls it out of shape. But on the way Mr. Lyssy accomplishes some remarkable things. There is a marvelous, laconic scene, for instance, showing Jews in an old-age home in Germany. Through the windows come the chants of a Nazi rally. The old men feebly discuss Hitler; is he a real danger or a momentary thing? Finally one patient says simply, "They'll elect him Chancellor." He collapses tiredly onto his pillow and suddenly the rambling conversation becomes tragic.

description: NEWARK, March 9Stewart G. Pollock, who left his post last week on the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, believes that nuclear electric power would be most economical for New Jersey's growing energy needs within the next decade.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Dutchess County grand jury indicted Raymond Jackman, a 25yearold Poughkeepsie schoolteacher, on assault, unlawful imprisonment and conspiracy charges growing out of his alleged attack on a 17yearold youth he suspected of stealing photographic equipment from his apartment. A second man, Edwin Hellstrom, 26, also Poughkeepsie, was indicted on the same charges. The unnamed victim was allegedly lured to Mr. Jackman's apartment on Feb. 26, tied to a chair, punched and burned with a cigarette by the two men and another 17yearold who reportedly pleaded guilty to attempted assault after being granted youthful offender status.

Spring in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The first signs of spring in Washington are the yellowgreen willows along the Potomac, the tulip trees in the park behind the Interior Department, and the lovely star magnolia at the northwest gate of the White House. And every time this miracle happens in the spring, reminding us of the renewing rhythms of life, we get wintry blast from the north. So it has been this week in Washington: The snow drifted over the Blue Ridge and buried the daffodils.

title: Impact of Florida Vote
description: MIAMI, March 9President Ford's victory over former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California in Florida's primary today does not guarantee his nomination, but it drastically reduces Mr. Reagan's prospects. If the Californian, even with fierce attacks on th' President's policies and leadership, can still go down to defeat in a state once so favorably disposed toward him, it is difficult to think of major states where he has already downgraded his chances in Illinois, his native state, which holds its primary next Tuesday.

title: Power Five, Toleritine Gain Final
description: Some old familiar faces stand between Power, Memorial and the basketball championship of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association. Power defeated Rice, 6766, last night in a semifinal game at St. John's University in Queens, following Tolentine's 6564 victory over Loughlin, the defending champion. Power and Tolentine have split two decisions this season.

title: Pension Realities
description: The cost of civil service pensions and other retirement benefits has doubled in the last five years to statewide total of $3.5 billion for 1976. The steepness of that rise is contributing to the push of New York State and many of its localities, especially New York City, toward bankruptcy. Unless these costs are brought under control, there is little chance that either state or city can achieve balanced budgets at levels taxpayers can afford to sustain.

title: 2 Hostages Attack Frankfurt Gunman And Overcome Him
description: FRANKFURT West Germany, March 10 (UPI)Two hostages being held by a young gunman demanding $390,000 and plane to fly him to Cuba jumped their captor, grabbed his gun and shot him today.

title: SPAIN CONVICTS 9 AS ARMY REBELS
description: MADRID, March 10A military court today sentenced nine) Spanish officers to prison terms ranging from two and a half to eight years on charges of having conspired to rebel.

description: Robert C. Baker a Washington banker, died yesterday while vacationing in Nassau, the Bahamas. He was 73 years old and a resident of Washington.

title: Lebanese Strife Worries Christians in Arab World
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 10 The bloody 10month confrontation of Moslems and Christians in Lebanon has sent ripples of tension into other corners of the Arab world, where adherents of Islam and Christianity have lived in harmony.

description: BANGKOK. Thailand, March 10 (AP)A Laotian officer has flown a lightobservation aircraft into Thailand in the second airborne escape from Communist Indochina in two days, the Thai Interior Ministry said today.

description: TRENTON, March 10Representatives of the British and French governments buttonholed startled legislators today in the halls of the State House and on the Assembly floor for support of flights to the United States by the Concorde supersonic jet transport.

title: Many in Montclair Are Uneasy About Plans for Shopping Plaza
description: MONTCLAIR  While the town's commissioners grapple with a plan to create a $90,000 shopping plaza described by its proponents as a major step toward stemming decay in the downtown business area, the residents of this Essex County community are similarly uncertain about the ramifications.

title: MOSLEM SOBS IN LEBANON SEIZE 3 MORE GARRISONS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 10  Large numbers of Lebanese Moslem soldiers were in open revolt against their commanders today. The head of the army proclaimed a general amnesty for deserters and urged them to return to their units.

title: BUSING IN DALLAS IS SET BY JUDGE
description: DALLAS, March 10A moderate desegregation plan calling for the busing of 20,000 students and the division of the city into five subdistricts to achieve racial integration in Dallas schools was ordered by a Federal court here today.

title: Lord Camoys Dies 2 Months After Leaving Family Home:
description: LONDON, March 10 (UPI)Lord Camoys died yesterday, two months after moving from Stonor Park in Oxfordshire, the family home for 900 years. He was 62 years old.

title: Dave Anderson
description: When the Cincinnati Reds won the World Series last year, Pete Rose said, I wish next season was starting tomorrow. When he came to New York to receive one of his many awards in the offseason, he told his wife, Karolyn, I wish this plane was going to the Winter League instead. When he talked about spring training, he said, I can hardly wait to go there as a world champion and work on being a better third baseman. Pete Rose enjoys baseball in the purest sense. And now, as baseball's labor dispute lingers, Pete Rose naturally is frustrated. I sit here in a sweatsuit, he says of the informal workouts in Florida, watching a beer league game going on. I can't even wear the Cincinnati Reds uniform. And the $190,000 sparkplug of the Big Red Machine talks about how Marvin Miller, the executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, has done a tremendous job for the players in the past, but I don't like the way he goes about it. Johnny Bench, the $200,000 catcher of the Reds, talks about how a lot guys don't realize how good they have it. And even Bill Plummer, the Reds virtually invisible catcher behind Bench, agrees. What happens if 1 don't sign and I can't find anyone who wants me? Plummer says of the possibility of becoming a free agent. What if the owners wanted to make an example of someone? description: WASHINGTON, March 10Former President Richard M. Nixon has renewed his contention that the public disclosure almost seven years ago of the secret United States bombing of Cambodia forced him to stop the bombing at the cost of countless American lives.

title: Reagan Will Stay in Race; Denies Ford Won Triumph
description: JOLIET, III., March 10Insisting that he will not succumb to pressure to withdraw from the race for the Presidency, Ronald Reagan said today that President Ford could not take pleasure in the outcome of yesterday's Florida primary.

title: 4 Shorts by Ken Jacobs at Whitney
description: As an esteemed avantgarde moviemaker and teacher (Harpur College), Ken Jacobs illustrates independence and a provocative personal style in the four films ranging from deceptively simple home movies to 3D that opened at the Whitney Museum yesterday. That this is an uneven, occasionally selfindulgent program, does not essentially detract from the overall professionalism evident in the largely affectionate treatment of most of his subjects.

title: Recital
description: Since few cellists can play unaccompanied Bach works beguilingly in public, Yehuda Hanani's accomplishment at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night was noteworthy, to say the least.

title: SELECTION OF JURY BEGINS FOR SOLIAH
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 10Jury selection began here today in the trial of Steven Soliah, companion of Patricia Hearst for a time while she was a fugitive. He is accused of taking part in a $15,000 bank robbery in the Sacramento suburb of Carmichael last April.

title: 11 Critics of Regime Are Seized in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 10The oppos'tion party's most recent presidential candidate and 10 other critics of South Korea's leadership have been arrested and charged with agitating to overthrow the Government of President Park Chung Hee.

title: WHEAT FUTURES DECLINE SLIGHTLY
description: Wheat futures dropped slightly yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, despite Government report late Tuesday that exports would not be off as much as many traders had expected.

description: WASHINGTON, March 10Jnstice Department and other knowledgeable Government officials disputed today an assertion by former President Richard M. Nixon that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had wiretapped an unnamed British newspaperman for several years before Mr. Nixon took office in January 1969.

description: Gov. Ella T. Grasso of Con necticut and legislative leaders rode into town yesterday on a Greyhound bus and made a brief foray into the Wall Street area in search of buyers and low interest rates for $100 I million of her state's bonds.

title: Phony Health Issue
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 10 Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama said today that a phony health issue had been instrumental in his secondplace finish in yesterday's Florida primary, and he began considering a new strategy to persuade voters that he was in Rood physical condition.

title: Mary Petty, Cartoonist, Dead; Chided Wealthy in New Yorker
description: Mary Petty, the cartoonist for the New Yorker.. whose drawingsof bloodless patricians frozen in the prewar world of croquet and tennis and the graceful picnic are compared with the illustrations of Daumier and Hogarth, died Saturday. She was 77 years old, lived at 12 East 88th Street and had been staying at the Pine ReSt Nursing. Home, Paramus, N.J.

title: 3 Oil Companies Are Cleared Here In Antitrust Case

title: DIVORCE MEASURE IN ALBANY REVISES ALIMONY CONCEPT
description: ALBANY, March 10A b!!1 that would scrap the current legal distinctions between husband and wife in divorce actions and mandate an equitable division of the assets of marriage was introduced in the Legislature today with broad bipartisan support.

title: PROFITS STILL GO TO MOZAMBIQUE
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 9Mozambique has been the most vocal African opponent of white minority governments in the southern part of the continent, but until it closed its border with Rhodesia last week it did business with the Rhodesians.

title: Affiliates Committee of CBS Radio Urged Dismissal of Schorr
description: A few days before CBS News suspended its correspondent Daniel Shorr for giving the House Intelligence Committee's secret report on the Central Intelligence Agency to The Village Voice for publication, Op officials of CBS News received a telegram from the affiliates executive committee of CBS Radio asking that Mr. Schorr be taken off the air.

title: Telephone, at 100, Looks to Future
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 10The 100th anniversary of the first telephone call between Alexander Graham Bell and Thomas A. Watson was celebrated here today by a great deal of talking. The talk focused less on the 'telephone's pervasiveness in the past than on the likelihood of an even more total penetration of daily life in the future.

title: Abbott Labs Paid $500,000 Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI)Abbott Laboratories reported today that it had paid more than $500,000 to officials in unidentified foreign countries in the last three years.

title: Notes on People
description: Tobin Armstrong, husband of the new Ambassador to Britain, Anne Armstrong, has been named by the Department of Agriculture as nonsalaried consultant to promote European sales of American grains and other farm products. The millionaire Texas rancher will be paid standard Government travel and expense allowances on assignments but a department spokesman expressed doubt that the amount would come to more than $4,000 or $5,000 a year. Mr. Armstrong is expected to be designated as special assistant to Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, through whom the appointment reportedly was arranged.

title: Plans to Construct Mills Delayed
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 10Iran's ambitious goals for expansion of its steel industry are likely to fall far short because of lagging oil revenues, manpower shortages and other economic factors, wellplaced business informants say here.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey School Boards Association said yesterday that half of the state's school districts were on the brink of chaos, as it reviewed the results of local school budget elections. The association said its figures showed that 267 of 479 school district budgets voted on Tuesday had been defeated. It noted that budgets in 47 regional districts also went down to defeat last week.

title: ITALY AUSTERITY URGED BY SIMON
description: ROME, March 10William Simon, the Secretary of the Treasury, today prescribed austerity as a remedy for Italy's economic problems and said that the failure to solve these problems would help bring the Communists into power here.

description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI)Senator Frank Church said today his Subcommittee on Multinational Corporations has been unable to prove that the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation tried to bribe West German officials in the'early 1960's to influence the sale of F104 Starfighters.

But the exiled players, riding a winning streak in the Federal courts, suggested that the club owners had played out their legal options and would soon have to come to terms.

description: MOSCOW, March 10Ernst Neizvestny, the sculptor who gained attcntion in 1962 for his shouting match with Nikita S. Khrushchev over modern art, emigrated from the Soviet Union today in a search to expand his creative horizons.

description: OSLO, March 10 (AP)Bill Koch of Guilford, Vt., failed to pass his physical today and will not compete in the Holmenkollen Ski Festival startina tomorrow.

description: LONDON, March 10 (AP)Prime Minister Harold Wilson's Labor Government was defeated by 28 votes tonight in the House of Commons on its controversial plan for a $6 billion cut in public services.

title: Too Slow in Spain
description: Unless the Government of King Juan Carlos steps up the pace of political and industrial reform in Spain will find itself increasingly rocked by bloody riots, ruinous strikes and widespread alienation. The clashes in Basque cities between workers and police that resulted in seven deaths and brought a halfmillion people into the streets to protest were merely the latest in a series of warnings to the Government by Spaniards convinced that they have waited long enough for fundamental freedoms.

Luccy today signed a bill requiring a 48hour delay period in the purchase of handguns, He said Ors Legislature and citizens shoul recognize that the new law wa only a piecemeal effort by P. single state to control a problem which is national in scope.

description: NEWARK, March 10State Transportation officials have ordered a study of the impact on innercity residents of the strike that began Tuesday by the Amalgamated Transit Union against the Transport of New Jersey bus company, Alan Sagner, State Transporta tion Commissioner, disclosed today.

title: Wyler Gets Film Institute Life Award
description: LOS ANGELES, March 10 William Wyler, the film director, whose work spans almost 50 years and ranged from silent westerns to Mrs. Miniver, The Best Years of Our Lives, BenHur and Funny Girl, received last night the fourth Life Achievement Award of the American Film Institute,

title: 11 Critics of Regime Are Seized in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 10The opposition party's most recent presidential candidate and 10 other critics of South Korea's leadership have been arrested and charged with agitating to overthrow the Government of President Park Chung Hee.

title: VOTING REFLECTS SHIFT IN FLORIDA
description: Jimmy Carter's plurality in the Florida primary Tuesday was a reflection of the more moderate brand of politics emerging in the new South and of the massive influx of newcomers that is changing the social and economic complexion of the state, analyses of The New York Times/CBS News primary poll and of actual voting patterns indicate.

title: Northrop Given Contract
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The Defense Department announced today that the Nrorthrop Corporation had been awarded a $1.6,billion contract for training, construction, per sonnel support aind services In connection with the modernization of the Saudi Arabian Air Force.

title: DIVORCE MEASURE IN ALBANY REVISES ALIMONY CONCEPT
description: ALBANY, March 10A bill that would scrap the current legal distinctions between husband and wife in divorce actions and mandate an equitable division of the assets of marriage was introduced in the Legislature today with broad bipartisan support.

title: HENRY H. NORDLINGER
description: Henry H. Nordlinger, a retired lawyer, died yesterday at his home at 115 Central Park West. He was 82 years old.

title: People in Sports
description: A former coach of the Detroit Pistons, Ray Scott, was given a fouryear contract yesterday to coach Eastern Michigan University's basketball team. Scott, who was dismissed from the Pistons job last Jan. 26, said, After 15 years in the game  as player and coach  I think I know the game.

title: Singer Will Do Own Sewing Ads
description: The financially troubled Singer Company confirmed yesterday that it planned to begin doing its own advertising for the United States Sewing Products division.

title: CAREY QUESTIONS RISE IN REVENUE
description: ??BANY, March 10cover no Carey insisted today that he could not possibly accept the upward revisions in state tax revenue estimates proposed by the Legislature to soften some of his budget cuts.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, March 10, 1976

title: Manson Sent to Folsom
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., (UPI) March 10Charles Manson, the, convicted murderer, has been transferred from San Quentin, to Folsom State Prison. A Folsom spokesman said yesterday the decision to move Mr. Man son was made oq the bank of his age and because the section in which he Was housed at San Quentin had recently been closed.

title: U.S. JUDGE DISMISSES SUIT. BERGMAN FILED
description: A Federal judge has dismissed a suit that Bernard Bergman, the nursinghome operator, filed against an AsIsemblyman, a state official and a reporter for The New York Times.

title: 7 Go on Trial in Netherlands for Slaying on Train
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, March 10Seven youths who captured a Dutch train and; killed three passengers last December went on trial for, murder today in this northern Dutch town under tight security.

title: Assembly Unit Completes Work on IncomeTax Bill
description: TRENTON, March 10  A statewide personal income tax took a faltering step closer to a vote in the Legislature tonight when the Assembly Taxation Committee approved a bill designed to raise $900 million to pay for propertytax relief and provide money to finance the Education Act of 1975.

title: 'Killer Force,' African Adventure
description: This was a passable adventure picture about some crooks trying to smuggle diamonds from a formidably defended South African mine. Then someone hit it with a load of moral ambiguity, and it all caved in.Twenty years or so ago there was a great fad for wine cookery. The idea floated over from Europe: the execution  literally  was thoroughly American. Pour wine, cheap wine, on any old mess. Pour it on TV dinners. The result was gourmet cooking.Nowadays moral ambiguityalso. Europe-bornhas trickled down into cheap action films. It swamps them. It's all right to have a switch or twoa hero who turns out to be a skunk or a villain who is really working for the March of Dimes. But with much more moral complication than that, the attention is sidetracked from the actionthe film's whole purpose in the first placeand focused relentlessly on the characterization. Since there isn't any, you sink.For about half of its length, "Killer Force," which opened at Showcase Theaters yesterday, is a bumpy but entertaining story about a mine security agent, played by Peter Fonda, assigned to penetrate and foil the efforts of an outside gang to break into the mine camp and steal diamonds.Mr. Fonda has a girl (Maud Adams) who loves him and a boss (Telly Savalas) who hates him. He has a mystery to crack: Someone inside the camp is working with the robbers.There is some excitement at the start, and the security precautions at the diamond mine are interesting and perhaps authentic. Mr. Fonda's tendency to languid skittishness is held in check for a while by a beard and a few good lines.The unmasking of the inside man at the mine manages to be a surprise: Unfortunately, it also wrecks the movie's framework. It would be difficult to say who wins out in the end; the good guys or the bad. It would be even harder to care.In the role of camp security chief, Mr. Savalas is a curiosity. His face is designed expressly for television. On a small box you miss nothing of his exaggerated features and expressions, even when the reception is bad. On a movie screen he looks like an enlargement.

title: Poll Based on Interviews After Voting in Florida
description: The New York Times/CBS News poll is based on interviews with a random sampling of Florida voters as they left the voting places Tuesday. Fifteen voting precincts throughout the state were selected and, within each precinct, each voter had an equal chance of being interviewed.

title: Jackson Abortion Stand Is Disputed by His Wife
description: ASHEVILLE, N.C., March 10 (AP)The wife of Senator Henry M. Jackson, the Democratic Presidential aspirant, said today that she and her husband disagreed on the issue of abortion.

title: Stronger Ford
description: On the Republican side, the returns from Florida indicate that Ronald Reagan has achieved what seemed unattainable at the beginning of the year. He has forced President Ford to become a competent national candidate.

title: Usery's Expertise as a Labor Mediator to Be Tested in a Series of Critical Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The Administration Is counting on William J. Usery, the new Secretary of Labor, to use his skills as a mediator in a halfdozen critical labormanage ment negotiations.

title: U.S. Cited Violations Before Mine Blast
description: WHITESBURG, Ky., March 10Less than 24 hours before a methane gas explosion ripped through a section of the Scotia Coal Company mine yesterday, killing 15 miners, a Federal mine inspector issued three safety violation notices in the section.

title: Drugstore Liberal
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Every Tuesday is another election day, which is a warning to pundits not to interpret Florida's primary vote as the certain springtime of Jimmy Carter or the unbreakable fall of Ronald Reagan.

title: Israelis Fire Into the Air In Unrest on West Bank
description: TEL AVIV, March 10 (AP)Israeli troops fired into the air today to disperse stonethrowing Arab rioters on the West Bank of the Jordan River, a military spokesman said.

title: ExComptroller of Hempstead Named in L.I. Kickback Case
description: MINEOLA, March 10The Nassau County District Attorney today identified William Smith, former Comptroller of the Town of Hempstead, as one of five present or former town officials indicted on charges of soliciting money for the Republican County Committee.

title: Bridge:
description: The first major bridge charity effort of the Bicentennial year will be played across the continent next Wednesday. The focus of the event will be the Spring Nationals In Kansas City, Mo., but there will be games at more than 500 other centers, with most of the proceeds going to the Arthritis Foundation.

title: Ehrling Leads 3 U.S. Works at Juilliard
description: The overall intent of the Celebration of Contemporary Music, a nineday festival currently making the Juilliard School ring with new and newish sounds, is to impress upon us the international stature of American works by placing them side by side with pieces from other countries. A plausible bit of reasoning, though such cosmopolitan programs are not unknown in New York, or elsewhere.

title: judge of Terriers Uses Bench Logic
description: Five days a week, David C. Merriam presides over a San Bernardino County Municipal Court in Ontario, Calif., where he is a judge. On weekends, he presides over rings in various parts of the country as a judge of dogs. On Saturday he will be seen at Harrisburg, Pa., ruling on a dozen terrier breeds.

title: Article  No Title
description: STADLERWatter H. March 11, 1968. Remembered always with love. MILLIE ROTHENBERGSidney Shale. Your YehrtzeIt today. Deeply missed and beloved forever. ADELE

title: Ford Is Expected To Offer Japanese Data on Lockheed
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)President Ford will send a private letter to Japan in the next few days in which he is expected to promise that Japanese authorities will be granted conditional access to United States information about Lockheed Aircraft Corporation payoffs, United States officials said today.

title: Most for the Coast
description: The House of Representatives is scheduled to take up today a measure that could go far to relieve fears about the impact that offshore oil drilling can have on the American coast. The bill, amending the Coastal Zone Management Act, would give the states enough money, time and authority to plan and enforce protection their shore areas from the potentially damaging effects of exploitation of the Outer Continental Shelf. In addition, it would specifically encourage thestates to acquire more beaches for public use.

title: Wisconsin Liver Cancer Cases Linked to Use of an Insecticide
description: An unusual cluster of cases of a rare liver cancer among residents of Wisconsin has suggested that farmers exposed to arsenicbased insecticides may be at risk of developing this cancer.

title: Contract Version For Kapp Told
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 10John Elliot Cook, the 77yearold attorney who is a key figure 'n Joe Kapp's antitrust suit against the National Football League because he is the one whose advice Kapp followed, took the stand today in United States District Court. Under direct examination, Cook explained why he told Kapp not to sign the standard players contract with the Boston Patriots.

title: Reagan Will Stay in Race; Minimizes Florida Results
description: JOLIET, ??? March 10Insisting that he will not succumb to pressure to withdraw from the race for the Presidency, Ronald Reagan said today that President Ford could not take pleasure in the outcome of yesterday's Florida primary.

title: Democrats Urge More Spurs to Economy
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The Democratic majority of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee assailed President Ford's economic policy today and called for a larger budget deficit to spur the economy more rapidly toward full employment.

title: VOTING REFLECTS SHIFT IN FLORIDA
description: Jimmy Carter's plurality in the Florida primary Tuesday was a reflection of the more moderate brand of politics emerging in the new South and of the massive influx of newcomers that is changing the social and economic complexion of the state, analyses of The New York Times/CBS News primary poll and of actual voting patterns indicate.

title: House GroupAdds $2 Billion for Arms
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The House Armed Services Committee recommended today that the Administration's defense budget be increased by about $2 billion, primarily to finance an expanded naval shipbuilding program.

title: Patrolman Slain Over Ticket
description: CHAMBERLAIN, S.D., March 10 (AP)An unemployed rain, who was said to harbor bad feelings over an earlier traffic charge, shot and killed a state highway patrolman and then killed himself hours after getting another ticket, a state's attorney said today.

description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 10 (AP)On March 20 Cambodians will elect a 250member People's Assembly of farmers, workers and soldiers that will be the lawmaking body of the country, Radio Phnom Penh said today.

description: 1 WHITESBURG, Ky., March 10 Less than 24 hours before a methane gas explosion ripped through a section of the Scotia Coal Company mine yesterday, killing 15 miners, a Federal amine inspector issued three safety violation notices in the section.

description: PRINCTON, N.J., March 10The New Jersey Board of Medical Examiners, which licenses physicians, deferred action today in the case of Dr. X, the surgeon now under investigation in connection with the death of nine or more patients at Riverdell Hospital a decade ago.

title: Rhodesia Leader Denies Giving New Proposals to Nationalists
description: SALISBURY Rhodesia March 10 (AP)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith today dealt a blow to black nationalists hopes for an early constitutional settlement by denying that he had produced a new set of proposals for study.

title: Big Savings on the Big Seven.
EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of 325,000 common shares of the Green Mountain Power Corporation, at $10.25 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: MOSLEM SOLDIERS IN LEBANON SEIZE 3 MORE GARRISONS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 10 Large numbers of Lebanese Moslem soldiers were in open revolt against their commanders today. The head of the army proclaimed a general amnesty for deserters and urged them to return to their units.

title: Centuries of Feminism Show Common Theme
description: In his 1558 edition of what was to be the earliest collection of women's biographies, Giovanni Boccaccio proclaimed that if men should be praised whenever they perform great deeds how much more should women be extolled. With this sentiment in mind, the Barnard College Library and Women's Center opened yesterday an exhibition of rare book, and manuscripts entitled Five Centuries of Feminism.

title: WORLD STUDY URGED OF AIR CHARTER ROLE
description: The director general of the International Air Transport Association, Knut Hammarskjold, yesterday urged that the governments of the world meet to review the whole concept of economy charter air flights.

title: Spirits Top Nets, 99 to 95
description: ST. LOUIS, March 10 (AP)  Marvin Barnes blocked seven shots and scored 23 points as he led the Spirits of St. Louis to a 9995 victory over New York despite Julius Erving's 39point performance for the Nets in an American Basketball Association game tonight.

title: Esther Tipple, 86, Daughter Of CoInventor of Telephone
description: ROME, Ga., March 10 (AP)Esther Watson Tipple, daughter of Tom Watson, coinventor of the telephone, died today in a nursing home on the 100th aniniversary of the invention. She was 86 years old.
