description: LYNDHURST, March 10The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission accepted a proposal today for the construction of a $28.4 million system for producing fuel, ferrous metals and clean landfill for more than half of the garbage being poured into the commission's waste disposal dumps.

title: Moscow Assesses Ford's Rejection Of Word Detente
description: MOSCOW, March 10 (Reuters)A Soviet commentary on President Ford's decision to stop using the word dtente today questioned Its real sigmficance and said it was not the same as rejecting the policy.

title: Still Afloat
description: New York City's decline is not inevitable. Properly managed, retrenchment can lead to redevelopment rather than ruin. By the early 1980's, the city's economy should begin to recover provided the city government soon undergoes a revolution whereby its policy and management processes finally are placed in a compatible rather than incompatible relationship with the larger economic forces shaping the city's future.

title: Explosion Kills Oiler
description: A 56yearold oiler was killed last night when a steam turbine exploded aboard a Formosan cargo vessel, the Allison Conway, at a pier at North First Street in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, the police reported. He was identified as Yui Lin Chum of Hong Kong.

title: Owner Sells Luxor Baths, Dropping Eviction Move
description: The Durst Organization, owner of the Luxor Baths, yesterday withdrew its eviction action against the occupants of the ninestory building at 121 West 46th Street, who have allegedly been converting the building into one of the most lavish massage and prostitution establishments in the country

Webster, president of the Horticultural Society of New York, and Mrs. Erastus Corning 2d examining an exhibit in the society's library, 128 West 58th Street, yesterday. The flower show may be viewed today tomorrow, April 21. May 12 and June 16. Below: three of the major entries in the

title: AntiTeng Campaign Is a Puzzle to the Chinese, Too

To judge from some reports in the Chinese media, and accounts of travelers from China, the Chinese people themselves are uncertain and wary about the attacks on Teng Hsiaoping, the senior Deputy Prime Minister, and other unrepentant capitalist roaders within the may.

title: Admissions Tests: Forum on a Thorny Issue
description: Why does my young child have to take a test given by a stranger to get into school? How can it possibly measure his capabilities? How can Trepare him (or her) for it? What if he takes on a day he's not feeling well? How can the school judge a child on the basis of a test anyway?

title: John Michael Kelly, 90, Dies; 13 U.S. Decathlon Champion
description: John Michael Kelly, an American national decathlon champion in 1913, died Tuesday in Leominster. Mass. His age was 90.

Kissinger, then his national security adviser, who supplied the Federal Bureau of Investigation with the names of the original targets of the program.

description: A threejudge Federal court yesterday reaffirmed and broadened a decision it handed down in 1972 that barred New York State from withholding Medicaid reimbursement for voluntary abortions. As a result, patients may now apply for such reimbursement for the first time.

description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., March 10 (AP)The New York Giants are trying to trade Ron Johnson, the only 1,000yard season rusher in their history.

description: The Levittown School Board adopted a controversial plan last night to furlough its 1,200 employees, including 725 teachers, for five days without pay to help cut the Nassau district's budget deficit.

title: L. E. SISSMAN DIES; POET, ESSAYIST, 48
description: L. E. Sissman, a poet who Made successful careers in literature and advertising, died yesterday at New England Deaaness Hospital in Boston. He vv'es 48 years old and had suffered since 1965 from Hodgkin's disease.

title: Hopes for City Growth
description: After a long neglect that has proved to be the opposite of benign, New York City's problem economy finally is getting the broad public attention it deserves. Hardly a week goes by without the promulgation of some new strategy to reverse the economic decline of the city, decline that is measured by the oftcited, but still shocking, loss of more than 500,000 jobs since 1969.

title: Music: Pianist at the Y
description: it was good that Joseph Kalichstein ended his recital Tuesday night at the 92d Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association with a Chopin group, because in so doing he redeemed somebut not allof the problems that had plagued his playing earlier in the evening.

Larry F. Taylor, warden of the center, said that Favio Ochoa, 41 years old, of Queens, and two unidentified companions were arrested by the F.B.I. on Sunday when a metal detector disclosed that Mr. Ochoa was carrying clip of automaticweapon ammunition that he allegedly was trying to smuggle into the center.

title: The Pop Life
description: Every monthor is it week?seems to bring a new rock band from Britain, eager to catch a few leftover crumbs from the Anglophilia of the 1960's. Most fail completely: others latch onto an FM cult success; a very few, unpredictably, make it bigElton John (if he can be counted British act anymore), Led Zeppelin, Bad Company.

title: Spending Cutbacks Show Results
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 10The Iranian Government, cutting back on expenditures, has piled up $2 billion in surplus revenues during the 10 months that ended with January, wellplaced members of the Teheran business community have reported.

title: 11 ARE ABDUCTED IN ARGENTINE CITY
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 10Armed groups, apparently linked to security forces, have unleashed a wave of violence against political extremists and labor groups opposed to President Isabel Martinez de Peron.

title: Theater: A Rat's Mass
description: Adrienne Kennedy is a fantasist. Her plays are short, nonlinear nightmares populated by mythic, symbolic figuresreal and imagined. They are difficult plays to read, to watch and to understand. Leaping from word picture to visual image, they lend themselves to directorial interpretation.

title: Governor I Saw You With Last Night?
description: The man was sitting with three friends in the crowded back room of Jimmy Weston's, an East Side supper club, his two bodyguards a discreet distance away. A woman, onequarter of two couples two tables away, rose and walked over to the man and touched him on the shoulder.

title: Unprovoked
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 Administration officials refused to take sides publicly today between Prime Minister Rabin and President Sadat over whether the United States had pledged to Egypt that Israel would not attack Syria.

title: DOW AGAIN FAILS TO STAY OVER 1,000
description: The Dow Jones industrie. average tiptoed briefly into the terrain above 1,000 yesterday, but it soon retreated in a performance that resembled Tuesday's market.

title: Brooklyn Man Arrested in Airline Bomb Threat
description: A 26yearold unemployed Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and charged with telephoning a bomb threat against United. Airlines and demanding $10,000. The suspect, Stephen Jackson of 1722 Caton Avenue, was seized at a Brooklyn subway

title: World Rotary Nominee Called ExNazi
description: An Austrian industrialist who is the sole nominee to be the next president of Rotary International was accused yesterday of having been a Nazi party member and a storm trooper durinz World War II.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Vance Comerford, a suspect in a Bronx murder, was incorrectly identified in an article in The New York Times Tuesday as a student at the College of New Rochelle.

title: POUND DECLINES TO ANOTHER LOW
description: LONDON, March 10 (AP)The British pound dropped to a new low today under heavy pressure from selling when New York orders hit the market late in the afternoon.

description: Yale University's women crew members who disrobed in their athletic director's office last week to protest lack of showers where they practice in Derby Conn., are to get a private locker room.

title: White House Alerted By Briefcase at Gate
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)A man left a black briefcase at the main gate to the White House today and ran away and the police cleared Pennsylvania Avenue for 20 minutes while a bomb squad opened the caseto find only papers and personal effects. President Ford was having lunch at the time. Within two hours of the incident, a man was apprehended and taken to St. Elizabeths Hospital for observation.

title: Attilio Piccioni, 83, CoFound er Of Christian Democrats, Is Dead
description: ROME, March 10 (AP)Senator Attilio Piccioni, a cofounder Of the Christian Democratic Party and a member of the Italian Cabinet before his politidal career was eclipsed when his son was involved in a sex and, death scandal that rocked Italy in the 1950's, died here today. He was 83 years old.

title: I.T.T. Net Up in Quarter, Off for Year
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday that its fourthquarter 1975 net income rose by 21 percent but profits for the full year declined 11.7 percent from 1974.

title: Senate Intelligence Panel Is Given an Extra Month
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI)  The Senate approved today a resolution giving its Select Intelligence Committee. an additional month to cornplete a report on the Central Intelligence Agency and other intelligence agencies.

title: New Rider at Big A Hopes to Ride High
description: Pat Day has Worked oil rigs ridden broncos and bulls in the rodeo, managed a gas station and has been a cowbciy. But when the 22yearold jockey ended a honey

title: COMPANY PROFITS UP 3% IN QUARTER
description: Fourthquarter net income of 1,727 companies increased 3 percent to $13.8 billion from the third quarter last year and 6 percent from the final quarter of 1974.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 10President Ford decided today to grant relief from import competition to United States producers of asparagus. The International Trade Commission had divided 33 on the issue of whether domestic producers were being damaged by imports. Under the law, in cases of a divided vote the President can accept either finding.

title: JURY DELIBERATING ON ZEBRA
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 (AP)  After hearing months of testimony and receiving instructions on 74 possible verdicts, jurors began deliberating today in the yearold trial of four black men accused in the random Zebra killings of whites.

title: Weaker Wallace
description: Time is running out for George C. Wallace.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 11,1976

title: Excerpts From Nixon Deposition About Security Wiretaps in the Halperin Case
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Following are excerpts from the first public testimony by former President Richard M. Nixon on the use of national security wiretaps during his Administration. The former President gave the deposition in San Clemente, Calif., in January in connection with a civil action now before the Federal Court here.

title: PARKING
description: Motorists will be able to park their cars today on both sides of those streets where alternate side of thestreet regulations are normally in regulations. The regulations have been suspended because of snow. However, other parking and standing restrictions Mill apply.

title: Shifts in State Regulation Of Utilities Are Drafted
description: ALBANY, March 10The Assembly Democrats today presented what they described as an electionyear package of bills to reform the state's utility industry and to make the deliberations of the Public Service Commission more accessible to the public.

title: Denver Ski Train: Timetable of Past
description: DENVER, March 10Longtime ski enthusiasts still recall with nostalgia the ski train days in the East's leaning 30's, when weekend skiers would pile into the cars at New York's Grand Central Station or Boston's North Station and head for the Adirondacks, the Berkshires or the White Mountains. Improved highways and the lower costs that went with pooled automobile rides were factors that caused the Eastern ??? train to go the way of the beartrap binding, the laced ski boots and balloon pants. Qut in these Western precints, however, there's an old Iti train run that's more popular than ever

title: Presidents of 2 City University Colleges on Staten Island Offer Rival 4Year Programs for Borough
description: Rival plans for a fouryear program of public higher education on Staten Island have been put forward by the presidents of the two City University units there, at least one of whom would presumably have to lose his post.

title: Primaries Put Humphrey in New Democratic Focus
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota, the everbuoyant noncandidate for the Presidency, looked to many studious leaders of the Democratic Party today like the passive centerpiece of a stop everybody movement. More than ever, he looked very much afloat as a compromise candidate himself.

title: Chess:
description: Is it the sneaky, underhanded, diabolical quality implicit in a trap that blinds us to the opponent's resources in extricating himself? Perhaps, delighted with our own cleverness, we exaggerate and suppose we enjoy a monopoly of it.

title: FORD NOMINEE TELLS OF ROLE IN 72 RACE
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)Calvin J. Collier, President Ford's choice to head the Federal Trade Commission, acknowledged today that he hid been a contact man in the C'pnunerce Department for Operation Responsiveness run by aides to former President Richatd M. Nixon.

title: POVERTY UNIT HEAD IS REPORTED OUSTED
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)  Bert A. Gallegos has been ousted by President Ford as director of the Community Service Administration, the much investigated surviving unit of the antipoverty programs 'f the 1960's, administrative and Congressional sources said today.

title: Robin Hood Gets Older at Music Hall
description: Robin Hood has grown somewhat stocky with age. H,is beard is graying. He's still vigorous, but physical combat now requires more effort, and the satisfactions of winning are fewer. King Richard the LionHearted, always an ambiguous herofigure, has gone quite mad, his love of battle turned into simple, uncomplicated bloodlust. Maid Marian. abandoned by Robin when he took off with Richard on a Holy Land crusade, first tried suicide, failed, then turned to God. She is now Mother Jennet, abbess.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 12, 1976

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The National Cancer Institute says it will conduct statewide study of cancer rates here to determine whether the disease is linked to environmental factors. The institute originally planned to limit its study to bladder cancer, but has, since decided to study all kinds of cancer. Salem County has the nation's highest rate of bladder cancer.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., March 11Horsemen at Garden State Park will consider boycotting the track in a dispute over $290,000 in underpaid purse money at a meeting here Saturday morning. Involved is retroactive revenue from recently passed legislation raising purses to 4.24 percent the parimutuel tax. The track has withheld the money cover $189,000 in purse overpayments for the 1975 meeting that was held in conflict with nearby Keystone Race Track.

title: WARNING IS ISSUED BY OTB UNION HEADS
description: Leaders of teamsters Local 803, which represents branch managers of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, walked out of a factfinding hearing yesterday and warned that thy would take economic action ff their pay deferral arrangement was changed.

title: Bridge. Spring Tourney to Feature Women's Knockout Teams
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 11A new event will be played during the Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League, which begin here tomorrow at the Radisson Muehlebach Hotel.

title: Louisiana Strike Ends
description: CHALMETTE, La., March 11 (AP)Workers at the nation's secondlargest sugar cane refinery voted overwhelmingly today to return to work after striking the Amstar Corporation plant for a month. By a vote of 34246, members of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Worker's Local 1101 accepted a contract giving them a 38 percent wage increase over three years. Base pay at the plant is $4.61 an hour, ranging up to $5.53 for toprated skilled workers.

title: PRIMARY BALLOTS IN STATE TO NAME RIVAL DEMOCRATS
description: ALBANY, March 11 Governor Carey signed into law today a bill, unanimously passed minutes before by the State Assembly, allowing the names of Democratic Presidential candidates to be listed on the state's April 6 Presidential primary ballot.

title: Retail Store Sales UP 13%
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated. $1 billion, up 6 percent from the yearearlier total of $946 million. Total retail store sales were about $12.38 billion, up 13 percent from last year's $10.93 billion.

title: South Korea Dissidents Tell of Threats and Fear in Days of Nonstop Grilling by Intelligence Agents,
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 11Dissidents just released from custody here told friends today that they had undergone days of incessant interrogation by teams of Government intelligence agents, shouting matches and open threats that had left them exhausted, frightened and in some cases hospitalized.

description: MARIGOT, St. MartinOnce it was receptions In the Governor's mansion in Little Rock, society balls, politics, charity work and weekends on the farma rustic little 27,000acre spread stocked with prize Santa Gertrudis cattle.

title: Beirut General Acts to Oust the Leaders
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Friday, March 12  The commander of the Beirut military garrison proclaimed himself military governor of Lebanon last night and demanded the resignations of both the President and the Prime Minister within 24 hours.

title: Hussein Holds Talks in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, March 11  King Hussein of Jordan and Prime Minister Takeo Miki declared here today that a withdrawal of Israel from territories it occupied in the 1967 war was essential to peace in the Middle., East.

description: Just about the only incontrovertible fact about SoHo is that many of its best galleries are directed by clever, goodlooking, committed and combative young women.

title: Social Security Tax Rise Rejected by House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI)The House Ways and Means Committee rejected any increase in Social Security taxes for the fiscal year 1977 today, thus apparently killing Pre'ident Ford's plan to raise the payroll levies beginning next year.

title: Port Authority Bans SST; Flight Was Due Next Week
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey voted yesterday to ban for now any flights of the Concorde supersonic airliner here. The agency acted promptly after it was notified by British Airways and Air France that they intended Ito start Concorde passenger service to Kennedy International Airport about April 10 and training flights next week.

title: Europe's Left Trend
description: The left political trend in southern Europe, which could bring Communists into governing coalitions for the first time since 1947, has received new confirmation in France's local elections this week. It has also been evident at a national congress of the Socialist Party in Italy.

title: 5 Shorts by Bruce Baillie at Film Forum
description: Bruce Baillie makes avant-garde films with the gifts of a painter and the objectives of a sign painter. A visual sensibility and a delicacy in balancing images founder in a determination to hammer these elements into sweeping and often crude social messages.In five films, made in the 1960's and being shown this week and next at the Film Forum, Mr. Baillie gives evidence both of his talent and the distance by which it outruns his artistic judgment.As for the talent, take the first of the five films, a tiny and beautiful piece entitled "All My Life." The soundtrack has Ella Fitzgerald singing the song that gives the film its name. The camera travels along masses of brilliant red flowers growing against a fence under a blue sky.It is very simple, and it would simply be a pretty thing to watch except that Mr. Baillie has struck upon a visual correlative of the singing that goes much further.The flowers are wild and unkept, amid weeds and overgrown scrub, in the back lots of a slum somewhere on the edge of town. They are dusty flowers. It is obvious that there is broken glass and bits of rusty tin in the underbrush. Flaming red and a tenement roughness: Ella Fitzgerald has been remarkably seized and set to film.The two major pieces in the program, "Mass for the Dakota Sioux" and "Quixote," show moments of the same lilting use of the camera. Both pictures are roughly similar: long assemblies of bits and pieces of American life, some seen plainly; others blurred, abbreviated or superimposed for complexity of mood. They are aimed in their whole at conveying a sense of emptiness, of cheapness, of violence, of futility."Mass" is done with more subtlety; and for the first third or so it promises to embody hauntingly the lament of Chief Sitting Bull that serves as epigraph: "No chance for me to live, Mother." But it goes on too long. There is a sameness and, by now, a triteness in juxtaposing advertising slogans, battleships firing, politicians making speeches and high school parades and filming it darkly and blurrily to suggest oppression."Quixote" is much the same, but much longer. Forty-five minutes is excessive for this continual hammering of weighted images. And the weighting is even cruder. Mr. Baillie shoots a Rotary-style banquet and intercuts the diners' faces with views of pigs at a trough. Or he shows a high-school basketball game.Now the movements in a basketball game, however little interest you take in the sport, are by any conceivable judgment buoyant, cheerful and often of considerable grace. Mr. Baillie edits and chops so it is all sharp elbows and gaping expressions. It becomes jerky and violent.Similarly we see a horse on the ground, apparently dying. No, it is not dying; it is getting up. Projected at a certain speed and cut in a certain fashion life becomes death. Out of this, all possible messages can be made; and when they are, none commands belief or respect.

description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) Air Force Secretary Thomas Reed announced today a new round of politically sensitive military base cutbacks and a reduction of 14 B52 bombers to save money,

After watching them in morning works, Philpot told one, a 90pound youngster from Texas, that he would never make a race rider. He turned him loose and signed the other as an apprentice. We all make mistakes. description: WASHINGTON, March 11William J. Usery, Secretary of Labor, denied today that he or the department official responsible for developing industrial exposure standards for millions of workers had been subjected to political pressure about these standards.

title: 17 Cubans Reported Killed By Firing Squad in Angola
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, March 11 (UPI)An allwoman guerrilla firing squad has executed 17 Cuban soldiers with their own guns for rape and murder while fighting to install a communistbacked regime in Angola, a proWestern faction has reported.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 14.8 billion tonmiles, 0.1 percent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 444,754 cars, up 0.1 percent from last year.

title: House Votes More Aid to Coastal States To Ease Impact of Energy Development
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The House approved today, by a vote of 370 to 14, a bill that would greatly increase Federal aid to the 30 coastal states to enable them to deal with the financial and environmental impacts of energy development off their shores and along coastal areas.

title: Spending Curb Placed on City U. Board
description: The city has notified the Board of Higher Education that, effective this month, it will be placed on a strict monthly cash allowance because it overspent by $2.3 million the February allocation of $34.1 million by the State Emergency Financial Control Board.

The approachbased on the old saw that the Russians respect power and nothing elsehas brought us an arms spiral that won't stop and a military Establishment that eats up 26 percent of our national budget.

description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI)The Senate gave final approval tonight to legislation that would increase the government s temporary debt limit by $32 billion to $627 billion through June 30.

description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP)A former aide to Senator James 0. Eastland acknowledged today that he had supplied information to Soviet agents for about seven years, but he said he had been a double agent following instructions from the Federal Bureau of Investigation for the entire period.

description: The indictment yesterday of the majority leader, Albert Blumenthal, on fresh charges involving bribery and perjury casts a darkening cloud over the State Assembly's Democratic leadership. Nixon's chief of Staff, has testified that he found nothing improper in the White House's use of information cleaned from a national security wiretap to prepare al counterattack on a critic of the Nixon Administration's policy in Vietnam.

title: P.S.C. REJECTS BID ON QUEBEC ENERGY
description: The Public Service Commission refused yesterday to reconsider a Feb. 6 order delaying construction of a power line from the Quebec border to central New York, citing environmental grounds. The action was denounced by the State Power Authority.

title: Egypt Dismantling Ancient Temple On Nile Isle Flooded by Aswan Dams
description: ASWAN, Egypt  According to legend, the Egyptian god Osiris was hacked into 14 pieces by his spiteful brother, Seth, who then buried the remains in different places. The goddess Isis tracked down the fragments and reassembled her husband, thus performing one of the first acts of resurrection.

title: MARTIN FISHER, 74, BUILDER, IS DEAD
description: Martin Fisher, one of the Fisher Brothers, developers of some of New York's biggest and bestknown postwar office buildings, died yesterday in Miami. He was 74 years old and had homes here, in Palm Beach, Fla., and on Manursing Island, N.Y.

title: Cunningham Asserts Obeying Subpoena Would Cost Party Job
