title: LETTER FROM FORD SENT TO JAPANESE
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (Reuters) President Ford today wrote a letter to Japanese Prime Minister Takeo Mild outlining the United States policy for turning over information on the Lockheed Aircraft corporation scandal.

title: Connors Easy Victor Over Waltke, 62, 61
description: HAMPTON, Va., March 11 (AP)  Topseeded Jimmy Connors hardly felt challenged tonight as he breezed to a 62, 6.1 victory over Trey Waltke of St. Louis in the first round of the $50,000 International Players Association tennis tournament.

title: SKYSCRAPER FACES A BANK TAKEOVER
description: Foreclosure proceedings have been started against the skyscraper at 1166 Avenue of the Americas, between 45th and 46th Streets, an action that could result in what it is believed would be the greatest realestate loss on an individual property in the city's history. The building is virtually vacant.

title: NIXON DECLARES HE SOUGHT TO BAR ALLENDE ELECTION
description: WASHINGTON, March 111 Former President Richard M. Nixon said in a sworn statement made public today that he ordered the Central Intelligence Agency to try to keep Dr. Salvado r Allende Gossens from becoming the President of Chile in 1970 but that he did not recall knowing that the C.I.A. attempted to foment a military coup d'etat that year.

title: JACK GRIFFIN
description: CHICAGO, March 11 (AP)Jack Griffin, an awardwinning Chicago SunTimes sports columnist, died Wednesday night of cancer. He was 58 years old.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev  Mike Nixon, 157 1/2 pounds, Glendsle, Con, outpointed Mike Avails, 152 1/2 Phoenix, Ariz 10 rounds.

title: NESTLE CALLS TIE WITH LIBBY NEAR
description: Nestle Alimentana S. A., the giant Swissbased focd comparry, disclosed here yesterday that it expected that the proposed merger of Libby, McNeil & Libby, the large Ameri

title: 10 More Reported Trapped Where 15 Died in Mine Blast
description: WHITESBURG, Ky. Friday, March 12  Ten miners were reported trapped early today in an explosion at a mine where 15 workers died in a blast earlier this week, the state police said.

title: Rotary Directors Here Oppose Wick Nomination
description: The board of directors of the Rotary Club of New York voted unanimously yesterday against the choice of an Austrian industrialist with an acknowledged Nazi background as the sole nominee to be the next president of Rotary International.

title: Juilliard Players Perform Inane, Poetic Soliloquy
description: An oddly assorted halfdozen pieces made up the Wednesday night concert in the Juilliard Theater of the current Celebration of Contemporary Music. It ended, for one thing, with a throwback. This was Aribert Reimann's Inane, a monologue for soprano and orchestra, strongly reminiscent of Schoenberg's 1909 monodrama. Erwartung.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Bicentennial Spurs Restoration Of RevolutionaryEra Buildings
description: PRINCETON,  With one eye on the Bicentennial and the other on their property values, community groups across the state are focusing on restoring Revolutionaryperiod homes and other buildings endangered by decay or demolition.

title: Stein Enters the Race for U.S. Senate
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein, who won wide attention as an investigator of nursinghome abuses, declared for the United States Senate yesterday and depicted himself as the people's candidate.

title: U.S. Says It Intends To Continue Cutting Forces. on Taiwan
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI)The United States intends to continue reducing the number of its military personnel on Taiwan, the Chinese Nationalist stronghold, the State Department said today.

title: Stein Enters Race To Oppose Buckley For Seat in Senate
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein, who won wide attention as an investigator of nursinghome abuses, declared for the United States Senate yesterday and depicted himself as the people's candidate.

title: Business Briefs
description: The UMET Trust, another financially troubled real estate investment trust, announced yesterday in Beverly Hills, Calif., that the Michigan National Bank of Detroit had filed suit in Federal court there seeking payment $2.8 million plus interest allegedly due under a promissory note dated Aug. 6, 1974. The trust, which has defaulted twice in the last seven months on a $116 million loan package, said the amount was in dispute and that only owed $700,000 plus interest.

title: PRIMARY BALLOTS IN STATE TO NAME RIVAL DEMOCRATS
description: ALBANY, March 11  Governor Carey signed into law today a bill, unanimously passed minutes before by the State Assembly, allowing the names of Democratic Presidential candidates to be listed on 'the state's April 6 Presidential primary ballot.

title: State Aide, a Veterinarian, Bridles at Bill to Save Stray Animals
description: TRENTON, March 11Under a proposal pending in the State Legislature, the state could be overrun with wild dogs or end up spending as much as $100 million

title: New Books
description: Alan Watts, by David Stuart (Chilton Books, Radnor, Pa., $8.95). A biography.

title: Private Business Offers P.S.A.L. Aid and Plan
description: Gulf and Western Industries has made a nostrings attached offer to contribute $100,000 toward the $1million needed to restore cuts made in New York City's high school sports activities. The cuts have seriously affected Public Schools Athletic League teams.

title: Korean Democracy
description: We're much better than Spain, said a senior South Korean official a few months ago, attempting to impress a visitor with the democratic trappings of President Park Chung Hee's regime. After the murky events of the past few days in Seoul, even that questionable claim seems inappropriate.

title: At 19, He's a SchoolBoard Member
description: SAYREVILLE, March 11 Thomas DeCaro is a new member of the Board of Education here. He is 19 years old.

title: Dow Closes Above 1,000 For First Time in 3 Years
description: The Dow Jones industrial average closed above the psychological barrier of 1,000 yesterday in a dramatic finish that provided an important prop to the nation's brightening business scene.

title: Most Illinois Voters Reside in Two Areas
description: CHICAGO, March 11 Looking at a population map of Illinois, you could easily imagine that someone had picked up this arrowheadshaped state by its southwestern corner and rolled all the people into its northeastern corner.

title: Larry Gardner, Infielder On American League Teams
description: ST. GEORGE, Vt., March 11 I(UPI)William Lawrence Gardner, a former baseball player, died early today at the home of his son, William Lawrence Gardner. Jr. He was 89 years old.

title: Egypt, in U.N., Asks Independent Palestine Entity
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 11Egypt called today for the establishment of an independent Palestinian entity, strongly backed the Palestine Liberation Organization and reiterated its earlier requests that! the Geneva conference on the Middle East be reconvened.

title: NIXON DECLARES HE SOUGHT TO BAR ALLENDE ELECTION
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Former President Richard M. Nixon said in a sworn statement made public today that he ordered the Central Intelligence Agency to try to keep Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens from becoming the President of Chile in 1970 but that he did not recall knowing that the C.I.A. attempted to foment a military coup d'etat that year.

title: Planned Closing of P.S. 144 Protested
description: Nearly 1,000 people took part yesterday in a demonstration protesting the planned closing of Public School 144 in Harlem, which is highly praised by Parents and its staff.

title: Arnold Petersen Service
description: A memorial service for Arnold Petersen, who had been national secretary of the Socialist Labor Party for 55 years, will be held Sunday at 3 P.M. in the penthouse of the Best Western Skyline Motor Inn at 10th Avenue and 50th Street. Nathan Karp, now national secretary of the party, is to speak. Mr. Petersen, who retired in 1969, died Feb. 15. He was 90 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Seventy years after he made his American debut in Carnegie Hall, Arthur Rubinstein unveiled a bust of himself there yesterday. The 89yearold pianist, scheduled to play a recital there Monday, was described by Isaac Stern, the violinist and president of Carnegie Hall, as the person who has contributed more than anyone else to this house. A spokesman said Mr. Rubinstein had played there at least once a year since his first appearance. The pianist said he loved the bust, sculpted by Nathan Rapaport, because it doesn't look like me but the way

title: Savings Banks Report Strong February Inflow
description: The nation's mutual savings banks reported a strong net deposit inflow of $760 million in February, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday. Preliminary figures for the month came close to the February record of $811 million, which was recorded in 1971. The monthly net deposit inflow represent amounts deposited less amounts withdrawn, but excluding interest credited to depositors accounts during the month.

title: What a Pleasure Near $8Million Syndication
description: What a Pleasure, an 11yearold stallion who sired last year's Kentucky Derby winner and this year's early favorite, was reported yesterday to be on the brink of being syndicated for a record $8 million. The son of Bold Ruler from Grey Flight by Mahmoud, who stands at Tim Sans's Waldemar Farm in Williston, Fla., will bring $250,000 a share for 32 shares, according to a report in The Daily Racing Form. Waldemar will keep 16 shares, plus four breeding rights.

title: Great Lakes Study Finds Cleaning Up Could Take Decade
description: OTTAWA, March 11A joint Canadian  American governmental hoard reported today that it would take more than a decade to clean up polluted waters of the Great Lakes.

title: ATHERTON NAMED IN MIDEAST LEAK
description: WASHINGTON, March 11A top State Department offidal, Alfred L. Atherton Jr., has been reprimanded for his part in the disclosure of some of Secretary of State Henry A, Kissinger's secret conversations with Middle East leaders, informed sources said tonight.

title: The Owners Agree to Sell Home Where Man Starved
description: The owners of High Tor Manor in Haverstraw, N. Y., where a 65yearold man starved to death, have agreed to sell the home in exchange for an agreement by the State Board of Social Welfare to end efforts to suspend their license.

title: Scarpa, Reputed Colombo Aide, Indicted in Gambling Inquiry
description: Gregory Scarpa Sr., reputedly a member of the Joseph Colombo crime family, and 10 other persons were indicted yesterday in connection with the operation of a regional center for policy gambling in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SCREEN & THEME In which Manhattanmade film did Noel Coward make a ghostly entrance from the ocean, trailing seaweed, and what's the music? It's The Scoundrel (1935), costarring Julie Haydon, with Rachmaninoff's Second Piano Concerto and Isle of the Dead, showing through tomorrow with Design for Living (1934) at Theater 80 St. Marks (2547400).

title: Legislators Avert Default by Agencies
description: ALBANY, Friday, March 12The State Assembly adjourned abruptly just before last mid1, night without taking up Governor Carey's $2.6 billion rescue package of the state construction agencies. Thenin a bizarre legislative spectacle that left the lawmakers and their aides bemused and incredulousit just as abruptly reconvened and passed, two

title: Wilson Survives a Vote of Confidence
description: LONDON, March 11Prime Minister Harold Wilson's new strategy to salvage the floundering British economy, a clear though limited retreat from the welfare state policies that governments here have espoused for decades, survived a grueling test in Parliament tonight with a solid 17vote margin.

title: Brazilian Court Closes Case Of Journalist's Death in Jail
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, March II (UPI)A military court has closed the case of a journalist who died in an army interrogation cell, ruling that he committed suicide.

title: Strikers in Argentina Defiant Despite Concession on Wages
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 11 Opponents of the Government of President Isabel Martinez de Pertm continued strikes and demonstrations today in key industrial centers.

title: When the Buses Stop
description: As the strike against Transport of New Jersey entered its fourth day, without a hint of settlement, the 450,000 daily commuters who ride the company's buses could legitimately

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1976, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Thursday, March 11. 55th day. Weather clear, track sloppy.

title: Arab Aides Quit in 3 West Bank Towns Over Israeli Action in Demonstration
description: RAMALLAH, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, March 11The Arab mayors and city councilmen in three towns of the West. Bank resigned last night, confronting the Israeli authorities, with an embarrassing political crisis in the area just a month before important elections.

title: Ali Agrees to Defend His Title Twice in Less Than a Month
description: Muhammad Ali has agreed to a championship fight in the Capital Centre near Washington for April 30, leaving him just three and a half weeks rest before his next bout.

title: Excerpts From Nixon's Responses to the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Following are excerpts from the text of the sworn answers, in writing, to questions put to former President Richard M. Nixon by the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence. The answers were released by Mr. Nixon's attorneys.

title: Market Place
description: The money market funds, now four years old, are clearly vulnerable to loss of assets when the stock market is strong, but their resiliency in the current spectacular bull market suggests permanence.

title: TV: Specials Abound as Emmy Deadline Nears
description: With the schedule overflowing in specials, this is doubtless the most untypical weekend of the year for television. There are two simple reasons lurking behind this startling largess. Monday is the deadline for entering Emmy Award contenders, and the commercial networks are being forced to show the few quality productions that may win Emmys, but that probably won't snare block buster ratings. At the same time, public television is having its Festival 76 fund drive and, beginning tonight, Channel 13 will present a 10day run of special programming and frequent pitches for money.

title: KISSINGER REPLIES TO FOES OF POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, in a spirited defense of the Ford Administration's rec ord, lashed out today at a con servative and liberal critics alike, warning that together they could end up by wrecking the nation's ability to conduct a strong, creative, moderate and prudent foreign policy.

title: Bridge:
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 11A new event will be played during the Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League, which begin here tomorrow at the Radisson Muehlebach Hotel.

title: Palisades Drive Is Extended 6 Weeks
description: NEWARK, March 11The State Supreme Court gave a sixweek reprieve today to a Tenafly citizens group trying to raise funds for preservation of a 274acre natural woodland tract atop the Palisades.

title: Quake Hits New England
description: NORTH KINGSTOWN, R. March 11, (AP)Strong local earthquake tremors shook homes and rattled dishes in parts of Rhode Island and southeastern Massachusetts early today.

title: Conrail to Speed Freight From Here to Chicago
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The Consolidated Rail Corporation, the new carrier that the Government has organized to operate most of the lines of the Penn Central Railroad and six other bankrupt Northeastern railroads, will offer freight shippers service between New York and Chicago that will cut as much as 12 to 15 hours off existing schedules requiring 48 to 56 hours.

title: The Strong Fell, Too
description: The worst plague ever to afflict mankind was the Black Death of 134751 that killed 75 million people.

title: People and Business
description: Edward N. Cole, retired president of the General Motors Corporation, the world's largest auto maker, was reported yesterday to have said that he was in the final stages of developing a car that could run an a fuel derived from air and water.

title: U.S. Set to Sell $3 Billion In 2Year Notes Thursday
description: As the credit markets waited or the Federal Reserve's weekly report an the money amply, prices of fixedincome securities held steady yesterday but financing activity stayed heavy.

title: Grain Officials Accused of Aiding Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 Ten present and former executives of five grain corporations were accused in a Senate hearing today of having discussed, fraudulent grain handling as part of normal business practices.

title: UOP Cites Payments
description: UOP Inc. disclosed questionable foreign payments of it least $290,000 since 1970 and said it now required that overseas agents be told tneir activities may be reported publicly. Page 47.

title: Plan Unknown in Taipei
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 11America nand Chinese Nationalist military officials here said today that they were not aware of any plan to cut the United States military presence in Tai: wan in half. According to a report published in The Boston Globe, President Ford pledged that the number of American troops in Taiwan would be decreased from the current 2,200 to 1,100.

title: Solar Heat's Future Now Here for Some
description: DENVER, March 10 Clarence and Selma Wolf, a retired couple in East Denver, are solar pioneers. Ignoring talk of solar energy as a thing of the future, they are living comfortably right now in a home heated by the sun.

title: Beirut General Acts to Oust the Leader
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Friday, March 12  The commander of the Beirut military garrison proclaimed himself military governor of Lebanon last night and demanded the resignations of both the President and the Prime Minister within 24 hours.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The city will be able to provide only half the number of summer jobs for the disadvantaged this year because of cutbacks in the federally financed program, Mayor Beame said. The Mayor said he had assurances from the United States Department of Labor that approximately $23 million would come to the city from the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act. This, he said, would allow the city to provide about 50,000 jobs for indigent youths between 14 and 21 years of age. Last year, the city received $39 million and provided jobs for 100,000 young people, Mr. Beame said.

title: Nuggets Defeated By Nets
description: UNIONDALE, LI., March 11The New York Nets played enough basketball to last a week and had enough fights to fill a Garden card tonight in defeating the Denver Nuggets in overtime, 141136, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Stage: Anderson's Joan
description: STAMFORD, Conn., March 11During the 1930's and 1940's few American playwrights had the reputation df Maxwell Anderson, who was considered by some to be even the superior of Eugene O'Neill. But, of late, his fame has faltered, and interestingly, during even this Bicentennial year of American dramatic revivalism comparatively few productions of Anderson have been offered. An exception is 'Alan Arkin's staging of Joan of Lorraine, produced here in Stamford, Conn., by the Hartman Theater Corn

title: Television
description: 8:30 P.M. The Practice (4) 9:00 P.M. Twenty Shades of Pink (2) 9:00 P.M. The Boston Pops in Hollywood (13)

title: Running Everywhere
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Jimmy Carter of Georgia has been saying from the beginning of his campaign for the Presidency that he planned to run in every state for the Democratic nomination. That decision has Mr. Carter spread as thinly over the map as a coat of ink, but if anything carries him through the next four months to victory at the convention, it will be his highrisk strategy of running everywhere.

title: The Decor Is Pleasant and Promising, But the Truth Is Still in the Tasting
description: Judging by most of the new restaurants that have opened within the last six months, it is much easier to find a good decorator than a good chef, for most handsome interiors promise much more than the kitchens can deliver. Two cases in point are the twin restaurants, Hopper's, which opened last September at 452 Avenue of the Americas, and Orson's, operating barely month, at 112 Central Park South.

title: About Real Estate
description: LAKEHURST, N.J.  The new president of the Leisure Technology Corporation, Michael L. Tenzer, was born in New York City and grew up in California. He received a degree in photojournalism, and served as a photographer for Look magazine and as a cameraman in the Signal Corps.

title: U.S., the Biggest Tin Importer, Signs Pact to Stabilize Prices
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP)The United States signed the Fifth International Tin Agreement today, becoming the last major tinconsuming country to enter into membership.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 1.6 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 195.3 from 193.7 last week.

title: Businesses Face Mail Cut Here and in 24 Other Cities
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 The United States Postal Serv. Ice announced today a cutback In business deliveries in 25 Eastern and Southern cities, in eluding midtown and down town Manhattan.

title: Nigeria Sentences 32 To Death for Uprising
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, March II (Agence France Presse)The federal Government today ordered the death sentence for 32 persons implicated in last month's abortive coup, including the former Defense Minister, Maj. Gen. I. D. Bisalla.

title: Redlight for Redlines
description: Governor Carey has made a significant initial attack on redlining in the banking industry. The phrase refers to the discriminatory practices of blanket refusal make mortgage or home improvement loans in neighborhoods with concentrated populations of blacks other minorities. The result of the practice is capital starvation in certain neighborhoods and inevitable deterioration and decay thereafter.

title: Senate Passes Repeal of Hatch Act Curb on Political Activities by Federal Employees
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The Senate passed today legislation that would repeal the Hatch Act's 37yearold prohibition against partisan political activities by Federal civil servants.

title: The Cast
description: WHO KILLED RICHARD CORY? by A. R. Gurney Jr. Directed by Leonard Peters; setting by Joan Ferenchek; wstumes by Gary Jones; lighting be Arden Pingerhut; musical director, Charles L. Greenberg; choreography by Bridget Leicester; production stage manager, Marjorie Horne. Presented by the Circle Reberteory Company. At 99 Seventh Avenue South.

title: Miss Hearst Has a Fever and Is Treated for Infection of Respiratory System
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 11 Patricia Hearst awoke this morning with a fever, the result of a respiratory system infection, and her trial was recessed, until Monday.

title: Books of The Times
description: Would you read a book called Literary Men? Or even Men of Literature or Male Writers (to divest analogically the title of Ellen Moers's new book of its unfortunate stuffiness)? Of course you wouldn't. Aside from referring to a sub

title: Albany Ends Impasse on Agency Funds
description: ALBANY, March 11A weeklong deadlock stalling consideration of Governor Carey's $2.6 billion rescue of the state construction agencies was broken tonight when the Legislature came up with an inventive, lastminute compromise and moved toward expected approval of the Governor's bills.

title: TEXASGULF TELLS WHY IT IS MOVING
description: Texasgulf Inc., whose plans to relocate its headquarters) from New York City to southern Connecticut became known Tuesday, said through a spokes. man yesterday that the move had been prompted in part by the need to save commuting time and improve the efficiency of employees who lived in or near Connecticut.

title: Marchesa Wed to Craig Mitchell
description: Marchesa Nicoleta dl Villamarina of Mania, Italy, widow of Marchese di Villamarina, was married in Palm Beach, Fla., yesterday afternoon to Craig Knowlton Mitchell of Palm Beach and Southampton, L. I.

title: Businesses Face Mail Cut Here and in 24 Other Cities
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 The United States Postal Service announced today a cutback in business deliveries in 25 Eastern anti Southern cities, including midtown and downtown Manhattan.

title: Queens Women Gain in Tourney
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.. March 11 (AP)Queens College defeated Connecticut, 7865, today in the opening round of an Eastern Association of Intercollegiate Athletics for Women basketball tournament.

title: RHODESIAN TALKS SAID TO MAKE GAIN
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 11 Prime Minister Ian, D. Smith and Joshua Nkomo, the black nationalist leader, held one of their longest sessions today in their talks on constitutional changes and scheduled a further meeting for next Wednesday.

title: WHEAT FUTURES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Wheat prices dropped yesterday from 4 3/4 to 7 1/2 cents a bushel. The oldcrop month of May closed at $3.70 a bushel, off 6 1/2 cents on the Chicago Board of Trade, while the new crop month of December closed at $3.81 1/2, down 7 1/2.

title: Merchant Triumphs In Pursuit of Suspect
description: There was something sinister about the man who stepped into Leo Brenner's liquor store on Broadway 110th Street and asked for a halfpint of vodka. His coat collar was turned up, his fatigue cap was pulled low and there was a strange look in his eyes.

title: Yonkers Raceway Results
description: (0TB payoffs subject to 5% Slate tax.)

title: Decorated Court Officer Slain in Queens Ambush
description: The city's most decorated uniformed court officer, who had made several arrests both on and offduty, was shot to death early yesterday morning on a quiet street in Ozone Park, Queens, in what colleagues called an ambush attack for revenge.

title: Officer Is Indicted for Homicide In Slaying of Rockland Minister
description: NEW CITY, N.Y., March 11A 35yearold police officer was indicted on a charge of criminally negligent homicide today in the fatal shooting of the Rev. J. Elmer Hausmann as both men searched for an apparent burglar in the Reformed Church of Spring Valley.

title: Nixon Explains His Taped Cryptic Remark About Helms
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Statements released today by lawyers for Richard M. Nixon provide the former President's first public explanation of a, tape recorded conversation that played a major part in his resignation in 1974.

title: Dow Closes Above 1,000 For First Time in 3 Years
description: The Dow Jones industrial average closed above the psychological barrier of 1,000 yesterday in a dramatic finish that provided an important prop to the nation's brightening business scene.

title: Dow Plunges 15.67 Amid Profit Taking
description: The Dow Jones industrial average dropped sharply amid profit taking yesterday after closing above 1,000 on Thursday for the first time in more than three years.

title: NEW AGENCY SET UP FOR FOREIGN TRADE
description: WASHINGTON, March 12Secretary of Commerce Elliot L. Richardson announced today the formation of a new inter agency Government committee to deal with the interests of the broad services sector of the United States economy in the current international trade necotiations.

title: Bookbinding Method
description: A patent has been issued for apparatus that binds books by welding the paper sheets togetherwithout using thread, adhesives or wire. The method involves resin and heat. Page 37.

title: Vaccine for Syphilis Is Tested; Bacterium Grown in Test Tube.
description: Continued From Page 1, Col. 8 team reported in the current issue of the highly respected British Journal of Venereal Diseases comes 71 years after the discovery of Treponema pallidum, a spirochete, or spiralshaped bacterium, as the cause of syphilis.

title: TV:Dynasty
description: Tonight at 9 NBCTV gives two full hours to a production called James Michener's Dynasty. Presumably, if Mr. Michener can sell books, his name in the billing can't hurt It seems that Mr. Michener's Dynasty is an original story created for television. But the actual script has been written by Sidney Carroll, who has adapted Michener's story for television. The business of creation can be extremely muddled.

title: Anderson, Clayton Offers Cash for Stokely Shares
description: Anderson. Clayton & uompally the big Texas food producer has made a bid of more than $90 million to buy all of the common stock of StokleyVan Camn Inc a leading processor of canned and frozen foods Stokely disclosed yesterday. The move was not regarded by either party as a firm offer, Wall Street sources said. It was described in the announcement as an unsolicited preliminary proposal to acquire Stokely.

title: N.I.T.'s Ticket Sale Hurt by TV Games
description: The National Invitation Tournament, which open's today at Madison Square Garden, is on trial in its present form. Good as the 12team field is, the nation's oldest postscason college basketball tournament will have to prove itself as a gate attraction. There is very little television income to supplement the ticket sale.

title: LEBANON'S CHIEF DEFIES GENERAL, REFUSES TO QUIT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, March 13 The general who has proclaimed himself military governor of Lebanon continued yesterday to demand the resignation of President Suleiman Franjieh, but the President refused to step down.

title: Rehiring Now Key Issue In 16Week Press Strike
description: CHESTER, Pa.For 16 weeks now, members of the striking Newspaper Guild here have marched in front of the entrances to The Delaware County Daily Times carrying signs reading Scab, while inside the old brick building, editors, their wives and newly hired employees have been putting out the paper.

title: SHAPP DROPS OUT AS 76 CONTENDER
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 12Milton J. Shapp, the Pennsylvania Governor whose sixmonth, $700,000 Presidential campaign produced only one convention delegate, withdrew today from the 1976 race.

title: Ford Upholds Kissinger Against Reagan's Attacks
description: CHICAGO, March 12President Ford emphatically endorsed the diplomatic conduct of Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger here today and said he regretted efforts by Ronald Reagan to make foreign policy an issue in their contest for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: City College Advances In Playoff
description: TROY. N. Y., March 12City College, playing in its first postseason tournament since 1957, hit on 70 percent of its secondhalf shots tonight and defeated Rochester Institute of Technology, 9469, in the opening round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III Eastern basketball playoffs.

title: Council Urged to Be a True
description: The City Council, frequently characterized as an ineffective appendage of municipal government, was urged by State Senator Roy M. Goodman yesterday to seize the golden opportunity afforded by the revised City Charter to transform itself into a true legislative body.

title: Rising Austerity
description: The Wilson Government suffered a temporary setback last week on its austerity program when a bloc of 38 leftWingers in the Labor Party joined the Conservative opposition in rejecting Mr. Healey's proposal to cut public spending by billions of pounds. The Healey plan would bring the ratio of public expenditures on goods and services to gross national product down from 35 percent in 197576 to about 28 percent in 1979.80a striking turnabout for a Labor Government.

title: ISRAEL SEES RISE IN FASHION SALES
description: Israel's fashion industry which wound up a week's show ing yesterday at the New York Hilton Hotel, expects to export $130 million in apparel this year, an increase of 11,5 per. icent over the level of 1975, accordine to an Israeli official

title: CITY TO END ITS AM TO 4YEAR SCHOOLS AT CITY U. IN 1977
description: The Beame administration said yesterday that it would cut off all aid to the City University's 10 senior colleges as of July 1977 and that this $140million  a  year responsibility would be left in the hands of the state.

title: Lawyers in Hearst Trial Weigh Jury Instructions
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 12 The courtroom struggle to 0define Patricia Hearst's role in: la 1974 hank robbery continued; today, even though she was absent and recovering in her jail cell from a respiratory infeclion.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LISBON, March 12 (UPI)Sandro Munari of Italy still led the field in the Rally of Portugal today as drivers handled their cars through winding market roads north, then turned south to speed through the snowcapped central mountains in a grueling endurance test. At the end the 18th specially timed section, unofficial results gave Munari and codriver Silvio Maiga a 2minute lead in their 310horsepower Lancia Stratos.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly stated that a temporary restraining order against WABCTV News had been signed by Justice Jacob Markowitz. It was signed by Justice Arthur Markewich.

title: Market Place
description: Wall Street has made money for years on the assumption that the nation's growing fleet of passenger cars would constantly and increasingly need replacement parts.

title: Reforming the Federal FoodStamp Program
description: WASHINGTONLiberals and conservatives agree that the foodstamp program should make it possible for every American to receive a nutritionally adequate diet and that this should be accomplished with maximum efficiency and at minimum cost to the taxpayers, with minimum opportunities for fraud.

title: Paris Proud, Except Those in Path
description: ROISSYENFRANCE, France, March 8Most Frenchmen are proud of the Concorde as a feat of French engineering and are unconcerned by its noise pollution, although those living, in the plane's flight paths here are worried.

title: Notes on People
description: A 15inch dwarf fruit tree brought back from China by Richard M. Nixon last month has been confiscated by Department of Agriculture inspectors, who say he will not get it back. The tree is believed to be a flowering cherry or apricot, which department officials said was banned completely, unlike bonsai, or nonfruit miniatures. On his first trip to China, Mr. Nixon brought back eight miniature trees that, according to the department, were never inspected. You just don't go and shake down the President's plane, said Eugene M. Farkas of the department's inspection service, adding that things are different now that Mr. Nixon is a private

title: N.C.A.A. Action to Start Today at 8 Sites
description: The 38th annual National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament. which starts today at eight sites across the nation may be colored red, white and blue with gold trim by the time the 32team field is reduced to the four semifinal teams that will play at Philadelphia on March 27.

title: City Decision to Shut 4 Hospitals Approved by State Health Chief
description: Dr. Robert P. Whalen, the State Health Commissioner, yesterday approved the decision of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation to close four municipal hospitals, neighborhood family healthcare center and major services I at two other city institutions.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1976, by ??? Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Friday. March 12. 56th day. Weather cloudy, track fast.

title: Antiques: Sword Show
description: Nothing in Western decorative arts can possibly prepare for the experience of viewing the Japanese swords on display through April 25 at Japan House Gallery, 333 Fact 47th Street.

title: Roosevelt Clears Webster
description: Ben Webster's fivemonth banishment from New York harness racing ended yesterday when Roosevelt Raceway reinstated the 36yearold driver. In a brief threepara

title: Protest on Shortened Day Spreads to 4 More Schools
description: A protest by parents that started Monday at Public School 87 against shortened school sessions spread yesterday as demonstrators occupied four more schools on the West Side.

title: Consumer Notes
description: New Jersey's Congressional delegation in Washington has received good marks in a rating of their voting records on consumer issues, according to the Consumer Federation of America, the largest such group in the United States.

title: TWO GUNMEN FREE 16 FROM MEXICAN JAIL
description: EAGLE PASS, Tex., March 12 (AP)I heard someone shout freeze and then they opened the cells and we headed for the river  said Paul Nesinson.

title: Knicks Are Trounced By Lakers
description: LOS ANGELES, March 12 Kareem Abdul Jabbar's 29 points and 26 rebounds led the Los Angeles Lakers to a 11395 National Basketball Association victory over the New York Knicks tonight. The Laker center also had seven assists and five blocked shots,

title: Art. Leger's American Friezes
description: Of all the European artists who came to this country during World War If it was Fernand Leger who adapted most easily. He was also (with Max Ernst) the painter who most relished the particularity of the American scene. American bad taste, he once said, is a treasure for American artists, if only they knew how to use it.

title: Lebanese Coup
description: Throughout the disturbances of the past ten months, Lebanon had at least been spared the trauma of a military power play against the constitutional political leadershipuntil now. The intervention this week by the Beirut garrison commander, General Ahdab, has all the marks a temporary maneuver designed solely to oust a barricaded and inflexible President Suleiman Franjieh.

title: Taxocracy
description: On this particular day I rose and found there was no shaving soap, so I went around the corner and bought some, and the city and the state taxed me 3 percent. This is the beard tax.

title: Blood on the Coal
description: The death of eleven more men in a second explosion in the Kentucky coal mine where fifteen died earlier this week is a harrowing reminder that death is the companion of every miner every minute he is underground. This time three Federal safety inspectors died with the other blast victims.

title: UTEP Increases Lead in N.C.A.A. Track
description: DETROIT, March 12The University of Texas at El Paso built a commanding lead in its drive for a third straight team title as the National Collegiate Athletic Association's indoor track and field championships completed the first day at Cobo Arena.

title: Gas
description: ROME, Saturday, March 13 (UPI)Motorists in Italy whO paying 11 percent more for gasoline today. The cost of premium gasoline rose to $1.65 gallon. It was Italy's seventh gasoline price increase in three years and more than doubled the cost compared with 1973:

title: Missing Goverment Aide Charged in Wife's Murder
description: WHEATON, Md., March 12 (UPI)The Maryland police obtained a warrant late today charging a Foreign Service officer, Bradford Bishop Jr., with murdering his wife. Mr. Bishop has been missing since five members of his family were slain March 1.

title: DR. OTTO SCHAIRER, A TV PIONEER, DIES
description: Dr. Otto S. schairer, a retired vice president of RCA who was instrumental in the development of radio broadcasting and television, died yesterday at his home in Meadow Lakes Village, Hightstown, N.J.

title: Kentucky Mine Toll Is 26 As 11 Die in Second Blast
description: WHITESBURG, Ky. March 12Eleven men were killed last night in the second of two explosions in a mine gear here within three days, bringing the toll to 26.

title: Pel, Month Late, Arrives for Training
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 12Pel worked out with the New York Cosmos today for the first time this season, although his teammates have been at training camp here since Feb. 17.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly stated that a tempo rary restraining order against WABCTV News had been signed by Justice Jacob Markowitz, It was signed by Justice Arthur Markewich.

title: PACT WITH POLES RATIFIED IN BONN
description: BONN, March 12A treaty that, provides for the emigration of up to 125,000 ethnic Germans from Poland was ananimously ratified today by the West German Parliament after a week of tense roundtheclock) negotiations between Warsaw) and Bonn.

title: Grain Shipment Disputed at Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The accusers confronted the accused at a Senate hearing today on the affair of the Rysy II, the giant Polish supertanker that Agriculture Department officials have charged was loaded with improperly graded, low quality corn.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Michelin's Best: Unchanged
description: PARIS, March 12 (AP)  The 1976 Guide Michelin, the companion for traveling and eating out in France, offers no changes from last year in its list of 17 venerated threestar restaurants.

title: High Court and Community Planning
description: LOS ANGELES, March 12Once again the United States Supreme Court has said, in the oblique way it often affects, that it does not want to get into the community planning business. But whehter it can ultimately avoid this onerous role, in the face of a continuing national population increase of more than two million people a year, remains question.

title: Rights Protest Blocks CrimeVictim Survey
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 12 The Westchester County District Attorney canceled a planned survey by college students of witnesses and victims of crimes today after a protest by the county Civil Liberties Union chanter.

title: CHARLES ELLIS, 83, ARTIST AND ACTOR
description: Charles Ellis, a painter and former actor, died Thursday in Pittsfield (Mass.) General Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived with his wife, the former Norma Millay, actress and sister of Edna St. Vincent Millay, the poet, at Steepletop, an art colony in Austerlitz, VY

title: Nets Top Colonels, 124 to 106
description: UNTO/ MALE, L.I., March 12 The bench of the New York Nets in the persons of Tim. Bassett and Chuck Terry provided the needed defensive help tonight in a 124106 victory over the Kentucky Colonels.

title: GULF OIL TO CUT GASOLINE PRICES
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation announced yesterday a reduction of one cent a gallon in the price of all grades of gasoline. The price change was effective immediately. Meanwhile,

title: Questions on Mine Safety Are Raised
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The second deathdealing explosion in less than three days deep in the Scotia Coal Company mine in eastern Kentucky raised new questions here today about both the effectiveness of the Federal mine safety program and the procedures that exposed the latest 11 victims to the threat of death under ground, The cause of both blasts remains a mystery,

title: Yonkers Entries
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing FIRST$6,500. ??? ???

title: U.S.STUDY DECRIES CITY'S NEW TRAINS
description: WASHINGTON,. March 12The General Accounting Office expressed dissatisfaction today with the performance of more than 1,000 New York City subway cars purchased with the help of $63 million in Federal funds.

title: Milton Waldman, Author, Dies; Wrote Elizabeth I Biographies
description: Milton Waldman. a writer, editor and publisher who specialized in Renaissance biographies, died last Saturday in a London hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: Accord With Saudis Reached by Aramco
description: The Arabian American Oil Company announced yesterday that a general accord had been reached on major issues involving the total takeover of the company by the Saudi Arabian Government. Four major American oil companies that make up Aramco now own 40 percent of the company and Saudi Arabia the rest.

title: The Sports Scoreboard
description: Nordiques Get Even WINNIPEG, Manitoba, March 12 (AP)Real Cloutier and Rejean Houle scored three goals each as the Quebec Nordiques outlasted the Winnipeg Jets, 10S, in a World Hockey Association game tonight. On Wednesday night, the Jets routed the Nordiques, 103.

title: Jackson to Forgo North Carolina Race
description: WASHINGTON, March 12Senator Henry M. Jackson today abandoned plans to contest the North Carolina Presidential primary election March 23 to devote his full attention to the New York and Pennsylvania primaries.

title: PARLEY STIRS TALK ON CONNALLY ROLE
description: SAN ANTONIO, March 12Republican state chairmen and executive directors from 19 states arrived here today for what Ray. Hutchison, the Texas Republican chairman, described as a very dull meeting devoted to the Congressional election campaigns and not to further the Presidential or VicePresidential aspirations of former Gov. John B. Connally of Texas.

title: Roundup Time in Albany: Comic Opera
description: ALBANY, March 12From motel rooms, parking lots bars restaurants and as far away as 40 miles down the Thruway enough startled Assemblymen were rounded up early this morning by the state police and frantic staff members to produce the votes to keep a state agency out of default.

title: SHOP TALK
description: There's no name on the door to mark Thomas Bruno Waldow's factory tucked away on out of the way Adams Street, between the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges. Yet the handmade cookware and serving pieces the 73yearold coppersmith produces there are in demand across the country and the stamp Waldow, Bklyn, N. Y. has come to denote a high standard of quality.

title: Dissident Beirut General
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 12  During the Lebanese civil, war that began last April, the Moslem officer who headed the Beirut garrison established special

title: U.S. and Russian Doctors Implant Artificial Hearts
description: MOSCOW, March 12While Soviet scientists watched, an American medical research team implanted an Americanmade made artificial heart today into a 6weekold calf, completing the first work of a joint drive to develop a human artificial heart.

title: Syphilis Vaccine Is Tested After Bacterium Is Grown
description: The bacterium that causes syphilis has been grown in test tube for the first time and then used to develop an experimental vaccine against the potentially fatal venereal disease, a team of researchers in Florida reported yesterday.

title: People and Business
description: Interior Secretary Thomas S. Kleppe warned yesterday that in the face of restrictive legislative moves, the nation's coal producers are left in a state of uncertainty by Administration pleas to increase production.

title: SHAPP DROPS OUT AS 76 CONTENDER
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 12Milton J. Shapp, the Penirsylwmia Governor whose sixmonth, $700,000 Presidential campaign produced only one convention delegate, withdrew today from the 1976 race.

title: Moon Landrieu, OldFashioned Politician
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 12 Mayor Moon Landrieu, who is being honored by New York City for his help during its fiscal trouble, is a shorttempered, hardheaded and frequently effective public official who believes in oldfashioned politics.

title: It Isn't Only Betraying Jimmy Stewart
description: The other night I betrayed Jimmy Stewart. He was playing in a Late Night flick called The Naked Spur (1953) and even though Jimmy is part of my last 40 years as an American, as close to me as family, I ditched him for Doug McClure and Darren the Gavin in a competing film called The Death of Me Yet because it was made in 1971. This wasn't a simple betrayal. Before I made my decision to sink Jimmy I had a doubleshot of Cossack vodka to make it easier.

title: Grateful City Gives Weekend on Town To Southern Ally
description: Moon and Verna Landrieu are finding New York City a nice place to visit this weekend.

title: WalkoutIsAverted At 48 Cemeteries By Tentative Pact
description: A tentative settlement was announced last night in the collectivebargaining dispute between the gravediggers union and negotiators for 48 cemeteries in the metropolitan area.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In his assured manner, Phil Sellers was discussing the burden on unbeaten Rutgers in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament.

title: State Unit Sees Possibility Of Bronx Terminal Fraud
description: The State Select Committee on Crime asserted yesterday that there was prima facie evidence of fraud in the leasing of the Bronx Terminal Market and that the law firm of Patrick J. Cunningham, the Democratic state chairman, had acted as an agent in the transaction.

title: Goodman Urges the City Council To Become a True
description: The City Council, frequently characterized as an ineffective appendage of municipal government, was urged by State Senator Roy M. Goodman yesterday to seize the golden opportunity afforded by the revised City Charter to transform itself into a true legislative body.

title: BERGMAN LICENSE FACES REVOCATION
description: The State Health Department said yesterday that it would move to revoke the nursinghome license of Bernard Bergman, who on Thursday pleaded guilty to Medicaid fraud and the bribery of Albert H. Blumenthal, the Assembly majority leader.

title: Rhodesia Farmers Are Firm but Worried
description: BINDURA, Rhodesia, March 10The white farmers and their wives in this rich region 60 miles north of Salisbury say they are determined to stay onif possible.

title: Who's Sick? Not the Who In the Eyes of Rock Fans
description: The Who, the veteran British rock band that made it into Madistp Square Garden Thursday night, would seem to depend in its performances on the physical and psychological health of two of its four members.

title: Met to Display Dresden Art Treasures in 77
description: More than 200 paintings, pieces of sculpture and other treasures from the State Art Collection in Dresden, East Germany, will be exhibited at the Metropolitan Museum of Art next year in the biggest show of important general art ever brought to the United States from a Communist country.

title: Swedish King Plans to Wed Commoner,
description: King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden, the Western world's youngest reigning monarch and one of European royalty's most eligible bachelors, yesterday announced his engagement to 32yearold Silvia Renate Sommerlath, a West German commoner.

title: PARIS OPERA TO OPEN WITH FIGARO'AT MET
description: Hurok Concerts, which will present the Paris Opera in its engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House next fall, has announced details of the performances, Mozart's Le Nozze di Figaro will open the season Sept. 8, with Sir Georg Solti conducting. It was staged by Giorgio Strehier and designed by Ezio Frigerio, The Countess will be sung by Margaret Price on the first night and by Christiane EdaPierre on Sept. 12 and 16. Edith Mathis, Frederica von Stade, Jose Van Dam and Gabriel 3acquier will be in the cast.

title: Orange Sale Testing Quota Law
description: ORANGE COVE, Calif.Jacques Giddens, a 59yearold farmer, is in trouble with the Federal Government, His crime: selling 3,441 more cartons of navel oranges from his 40acre farm here than the Government said he could.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: IRISH SPECIAL The public is invited at 7:30 P.M. tomorrow to a concert celebrating the feast of St. Patrick in the apt setting of St. Patrick's Cathedral, featuring three visiting musicians from Ireland and a concert orchestra assembled from the Metropolitan Opera Symphony. The Bicentennialyear program, the sixth in a series of cultural events at the church, is being presented by the Irish American Bicentennial Committee and the cathedral.

title: Letters to the Editor.
description: To the Editor:

title: KISSINGER GIVES REPRIMANDS TO 2
description: WASHINGTON, March 12, Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has officially reprimanded two of his closest State Department associates for having disclosed without specific authorization excerpts from Mr. Kissinger's secret conversations with Middle East leaders.

title: State Expects Quick Approval Of New Primary Ballot by U.S.
description: ALBANY, March 12George Zuckerman, head of the State Attorney, General's civil rights division, said today that he had submitted the state's new priMary ballot law to the United Stites Department of Justice and was confident of quick approval by the Federal Government,

title: 2 LISBON PARTIES DENOUNCE PARLEY
description: LISBON, March 12The European Socialist summit meeting, set to open in Oporto tomorrow, came under angry atlack today by both Portugal's Communist and liberal Popular Democratic parties as constituting unwarranted intervention in national legislative elections set for April 25.

title: West Side Highway Foes Find a Target
description: Opponents of a $1 billion plan to reconstruct the West Side Highway are hopeful of crippling the project by deleting a $14 million planning appropriation from the proposed state budget, State Senator Manfred nbrpnstein said yesterday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 13, 1976

title: Kleppe Moves to Block Dam in Carolina
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 Secretary of the interior Thomas S. Kleppe announced today his intention to approve North Carolina's proposal to have a 26.5mile stretch of the New River designated as a part of the Wild and Scenic Rivers System.

title: Farmers to Pay Migrants RecordHigh Rates in 76
description: Puerto Rican farm workers will get record high wages in New Jersey this year, the Migration Division of the Puerto Rican Department of Labor said today.

title: Quality or Politics?
description: Fortunately for the Republicans in control of the State Senate, the confirmation procedures of that body give them a chance to undo the folly perpetrated by the Committee on Crime and Corrections when it refused to approve the nomination of Herman Schwartz to be chairman of the State Commission on Corrections.

title: BELGRADE COURT SENTENCES FOUR
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 12 (Reuters)A court handed out heavy jail terms here today to four Yugoslays charged with being Stalinists, including a former Deputy Prime Minister of Croatia, for allegedly plotting to overthrow the Governmen t.

title: CAREY WOULD CUT SOME CITY TAXES
description: Governor Carey yesterday asked Felix G. Rohatyn chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, to make a thorough study of the city' s tax structure to see what could be done to lower counterproductive taxes that are driving jobs and companies out of New York.

title: Jersey Assembly Defeats Bill to Ease Property Tax
description: TRENTON, March 12In a tumultuous session, a bill to provide propertytax relief to homeowners, possibly the key to the passage of an income tax, was defeated in the Assembly tonight, 31 to 27.

title: Ford Calls for More Progress Toward Transition in Rhodesia
description: Wheaton, Ill., March 12President Ford said here today, that the white minority Government of Rhodesia should make more progress toward yielding control to that nation's black majority.

title: F.D.I.C. OFFERS HELP TO FARMERS BANK
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation agreed today to bail out the financially troubled Farmers Bank of the state of Delaware by taking over $40 million of the bank's problem loans.

title: Kissinger Says He'll Shun Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, March 12Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger told reporters today that he would not take to the political stump in this election year. But he served notice on all opponents of President Ford, in both parties, that he would continue to react strongly to criticism of the Administration's foreign policy.

title: FRANK KLOEB, JUDGE, OHIO CONGRESSMAN
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, March 12Frank Le Blond Kloeb, a former United. States Representative from Ohio's Fourth District who was on the United States District Court bench here for 37 years died yesterday at the age of 85. He retired in 1964 from active status but remained until July 1974 as a judge sitting by assignment in criminal nd civil matters.

title: H. Otis Noyes. 78. Taught At State U. in Plattsburgh
description: YARMOUTH, Me., March 12 Dr. H. Otis Noyes Sr., professor emeritus of language and literature of the State University of New York's College of Arts and Sciences at Platsburgh, died in a nursing home here today. Dr. Noyes was 78 years old.

title: Opera: Moffo as Violetta
description: Anna Moffo, whose voice fell into serious disrepair a few seasons back, reported has been working hard to rebuild what once was a most respectable instrument. Since the American soprano is still in her early 40's, that does not seem at all hopeless, though the odds against entirely successful reconstructing at any age are fairly high.

title: Carey Reported Yielding on Local Aid
description: ALBANY, March 12Governor Carey has acceded to the Legislature's insistence that he restore many of his proposed sharing and other localassistance programs, legislative officutbacks in schoolaid, revenue cials indicated today.

title: Evers Students Upset by Kibbee's Plan
description: It has been causing me many sleepless nights, said Wesley Jackson, a junior at Medgar Evers College, commenting on a proposed reorganization of the colloge.

title: UDALL GETS MORE OF BAH SUPPORT
description: ROCHESTER, March 12 Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona picked up additional support today from former backers of Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana in his effort to marIshal this state's liberal Democrats behind his drive for Presidential delegates in the April primary.

title: Alexander Bellow, Guitarist. Composer and Conductor. 63
description: Alexander Bellow, composer, teacher of the classical guitar and former conductor, died yesterday, apparently of heart attack, at his home in Sherman, Conn. He was 63 years old.

title: Swedish King Plans to Wed Commoner
description: King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden, the Western world's youngest reigning monarch and one of European royalty's most eligible bachelors, yesterday announced his engagement to 32yearold Silvia Renate Sommerlath, a West German commoner.

title: Auguste Perret Honored In Architecture Show Here
description: Auguste Perret died in 1954, at the age of SO, after an odd career in which he was, paradoxically, both a leader of the French architectural Establishment and perennial outsider to it.

title: Daley Views the Primary As Crucial to His Power
description: CHICAGO, March 12 Mayor Richard J. Daley and his powerful Cook County Democratic machine have important goals in Tuesday's Illinois primary that are far more complicated than the state's nonbinding preferential primary among six Presidential candidates.

title: F. & M. SCHAEFER SHOWS A DEFICIT
description: The F. & M. Schaefer Corporation, which had ranked as the nation's seventh largest brewer in 1974, lost $32 million in the fourth quarter of 1975, the largest deficit for any year in its history.

title: Merlino Terms Debate On Taxes a Charade
description: TRENTON, March 12It has all been a charade, the State Senate majority leader, Joseph F. Merlino, said today.

title: LEBANON'S CHIEF DEFIES GENERAL, REFUSES TO QUIT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, March 13  The general who has proclaimed himself military governor of Lebanon continued yesterday to demand the resignation of President Suleiman Franjieh, but the President refused to step down.

title: Way Out in Nowhere,
description: REYKJAVIK, IcelandThis is the land where the Norse sagas were written, including the one about Eric the Red discovering Greenland and his son Leif Ericson alight

title: Bridge:
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 12The Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League began the first of 10 days of play here this afternoon. Some 4,000 players will take part in six major events, including the Vanderbilt Cup, and many minor ones.

title: Gulf's ExLobbyist Is Indicted on Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The former chief lobbyist in Washington for the Gulf Oil Corporation was indicted by Federal grand jury today on two felony counts of making illegal campaign contributions.

title: New Haven's Democrats Elect. Black as the Party's Chairman
description: NEW HAVEN, March 12A 41yearold black man was unanimously elected Democratic Party town chairman here last night, becoming the first black to hold the powerful political post in this or any other major city in Connecticut.

title: 2 COMMODITY MEN GIVEN 10 MONTHS
description: Two former commodity brokers, Douglas Collins of Parlin, N. J., and Dennis Turner of Brooklyn, were sentenced yesterday to 10 months each in jail by State Supreme Court Justice Burton Roberts. They hal pleaded guilty in December to second degree larceny after being indicted by the state attorney general's office for losses of more than $2 million suffered by about 1,000 investors on commodity options handled by their firm.

title: Daley Views the Primary As Crucial to His Power
description: CHICAGO, March 12 Mayor Richard J. Daley and his powerful Cook County Democratic machine have important goals in Tuesday's Illinois primary that are far more complicated than the state's nonbinding preferential primary among six Presidential candidates.

title: 2 Senate Units Oppose Defense Fund Cut
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The Senate Armed Services and Appropriatoins Committees recommended today that Congress make no reductions in the $114 billion defense budget proposed by the Administration for the next fiscal year.

title: EXTAX COLLECTOR CONVICTED OF FRAUD
description: A jury in State Supreme Court last night convicted Frederic S. Rice, the city's for mer tax collector, of filing a fraudulent state incometax return in 1971, but acquitted him of a similar charge involving his 1970 return.

title: State and Civil Service Union Reach Accord on New Contract
description: A tentative agreement on a twoyear contract extension, with no salary raises in the first year, was reached late last night between the State Office of Employee Relations and four units of the Civil Service Employees Association, state officials reported.

title: State Aide Backs a TaxPrivacy Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 12James H. Tully Jr., the New York State Tax Commissioner, testified today that with minor reservations he found acceptable the Privacy Protection Study Commission's draft proposals on the confidentiality of Federal tax returns.

title: Man Slain in Dispute Here
description: A dispute over a bottle of wine worth 50 cents led yesterday to the fatal stabbing of Lorenzo Zoilo, 45 years old, of 565 West 175th Street, the police said. Nicholas Montaldo, 42, who was standing over the dead man in front of 520 West 135th Street, was arrested on charge of homicide.

title: Books of The Times
description: Literary patronage at its most basic is matter of feeding, lodging and entertaining writers in a style that otherwise they couldn't afford. Some writers, like cuckoos, do better in others nests, preferably wellfeathered.

title: In Rio, Jets Are Not Usually Heard
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The Concorde supersonic airliner has gained public and official acceptance in Brazil, and has ceased to be an object of news interest.

title: European Parliament Is Urging First Direct Election by May 78
description: STRASBOURG, France, March l2The ninemember European Parliament called today on Common Market heads of government to make sure that the first European elections take place by May 1978.

title: Patents: Books Bound by a New Method
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 Two brothers who operLate a New York bindery are constructing apparatus to bind books by welding the paper sheets togetherwithout usine thread.

title: Payments by General Tire, I.T.T., Westinghouse Cited
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, the General Tire and Rubber Company and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation are the latest in a growing list of companies that say they have been Involved in questionable or improper payments overseas.

title: Connors Advances Along With. Nastase
description: HAMPTON, Va., March 12 (AP)  Secondseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania posted a 63, 62 victory over Ray Moore of South Africa tonight in the quarterfinals of a $50,000 tennis tournament.

title: Syphilis Vaccine Is Tested After Bacterium Is Grown
description: The bacterium that causes syphilis has been grown in test tube for the first time and then used to develop an experimental vaccine against the potentially fatal venereal disease, a team of researchers in Florida reported yesterday.

title: Reagan and Aide in Illinois Denounce Ford Campaign
description: CHICAGO, March 12Ronald Reagan's campaign chairman in Illinois questioned today the integrity of President Ford and said he was unfairly using the White House to buy votes in the state's primary election next Tuesday.

title: Gulf's. ExLobbyist Is Indicted on Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The former chief lobbyist in Washington for the Gulf Oil Corporation was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on two felony counts of making illegal campaign contributions.

title: HopatcongArea Residents Decry Roar of Speedboats
description: JEFFERSON TOWNSHIPThe lake was serene, crows beat their wings against the cold wind atop the tall bare oaks and summer seemed a distant promise.

title: Baseball Players Stop Informal Drills
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12On the final out of the ninth inning of today's game, Tom Seaver said as he watched the baseball exiles at work, we're putting a sign on the door saying, Gone fishing.'

title: Pentagon Nomination Is Delayed By Dispute on Defense Job Offer
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)The nomination of a former Martin Marietta Corporation executive to a new post in the Pentagon is being held up following disclosure that he accepted a Pentagon post in 1963 after the huge defense contractor promised him a job when he left Government service.

title: Peres Warns Israel Will React If Beirut Changes Raise Threat
description: TEL AVIV, March 12Israeli soldiers and farmers on the northern frontier were on alert today as Defense Minister Shimon Peres warned that Israel would, have to react if its border security was affected by the action yesterday of a general in Lebanon to seize power.

title: WALLACE PRESSES THE HEALTH ISSUE
description: MOLINE, III., March 12Gov. George C. Wallace stuck cosely today to the politics that has worked for him for a decade as he stumped through the Small cities that ring Chicago.

title: NIGERIA EXECUTES 30 FOR COUP ROLE
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, March 12The Nigerian Government announced today that the former defense minister and 29 others had been out to death for their part in last month's attempted coup, in which the chief of state was assassinated.

title: The Ballet: Lisa Bradley
description: Lisa Bradley has had a special relationship with the City Center Jaffrey Ballet, through its changes of name, crises of patronage and other hazards of the arts. She has been the most obvious star of a company officially without stars, and she has exercised that rarity among theatrical virtuesloyalty.

title: Fears of European Devaluations Mount
description: PARIS, March 12  After sharp declines in the British pound and Italian lira, speculaJive pressure against the French franc has increased, stirring fears that Western Europe may be headed for competitive devaluations that could jeopardize its economic recovn.y.

title: Neighbors Talk About Life With Concorde
description: LONDON, March 12  I know when it's a Concorde, said Angela Johnson, 20, who lives and works in Hounslow. The noise is totally different. The windows shake in our porch from vibration. And when I am at my friend's house in Hatton Cross I have to cover my ears with my hands.

title: Islamic Delegates at U.N. Denounce Israeli Policies
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 12Delegates of the 44country Islamic Conference adopted a statement tonight denouncing what it termed Israel's systematic policy to change the status of Jerusalem and gradually obliterate the Moslem and Christian heritage in the Holy City.

title: CITY TO END ITS AID TO 4YEAR SCHOOLS Al CITY U. IN 1977
description: The Beame administration said yesterday that it would cut off all aid to the City University's 10 senior colleges as of July 1977 and that this $140million  a  year responsibility would be left in the hands of the state.

title: The Unexpected Victory
description: LISBONThe only significant plus recorded by United States foreign policy, during the past yeara period marked by disasters in Southeast Asia and southern Africa, by setbacks in India and Canada and by worrisome stalemates in the Middle East and the Aegeanhas come in little Portugal. And one cannot attribute the remarkable change in outlook here to the wisdom, foresight or craft of American planners.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Gov. Ella T. Grasso of Connecticut said she would veto any tax increase this Year unless legislators first tried balance the budget by lengthening the state work week and liquidating a veterans fund. title: Figure Skating Won by Cockerell

Cockerell, who was trailing after the compulsory figures and the short program, won the free skating by 7 points from Takashi Mura of Japan. Brian Pockar of. Canada finished third.

title: A Correction

title: AIRLINES WITH SST WILL SUE OVER BAN

title: Finn Wins Holmenkollen Jump
description: OSLO, March 12 (AP)Erkki Kilpinen of Finland won the Nordic combined ski jumping event today at the Hoimenkollen ski festival. He scored 218.4 points for jumps of 83 and 83.5 meters. Ulrich Wehling of East Germany, the Olympic champion, fell on the first of his three jumps, but followed with leaps of 83.4 and 84 meters and placed second with 214 points.

title: TAX OFFICIAL FAILS TO AVERT RETIRING
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)A career official failed today in a lastminute legal attempt to prevent what he called forced retirement from the Internal Revenue Service because he caused, embarrassment to Donald C. Alexander, the agency's commissioner.

description: TUCSON, Ariz., March 12 (AP)  Iowa's Hawkeyes revined the lead tonight as they try to repeat as the National Collegiate wrestling champions. Iowa passed its strongest challenger. Iowa State.

title: Sinking Pound
description: The fall of the value of the British pound to less than two dollarsit closed at $1.92 on Fridayis shocking those who remember when the pound was worth almost five dollars, as it was until the outbreak of World War II. After three major devaluationsin 1939, 1949 and 1967 the pound oscillated around $2.40 until a year ago when it began its latest plunge, partly because of the recovering strength of the dollar but chiefly because of the inability of Britain to bring its inflation under control.

title: NIGERIA EXECUTES 30 FOR COUP ROLE

Without any Bicentennial fanfares or other factitious embellishments, this exhibition illuminates an important area of our native artistic heritage. It consists of approximately 100 works created by selftaught artists in America from the 18th century to the present day. It has been well selected by Herbert W. Hemphill Jr., the show's guest curator, and given an elegant installation by Daniel Weidmann, the museum's staff designer. It is accompanied by a catalogue that, though it raises more questions than it anewers, is a valuable addition to the literature on American

title: IndianaExecutionPostponed
description: LEBANON, Ind., March 12 (UPI)  The execution of Charles R. Martin, a convicted. murderer who was scheduled to be electrocuted next Monday, was postponed indefinitely today. Judge Paul H. Johnson Jr. of Boone Superior Court granted the indefinite stay on the grounds that the United States Supreme  Court has cases before it testing the constitutionality of state death penalty laws. Mr. Martin. who is 33 years old, was convicted of kidnapping and killing Kathy Wylie, 19, of Gastort, Ind.

title: I'm a Playwright Of Movement

I don't want to sound ungrateful for this noble and lovely gesture, says Jooss, but my birthday was two months ago on Jan. 12, so I really don't know what Bob Joffrey is celebratingbut I'm looking forward to going to New York and finding out.

Even through the mechanical roar that disfigures those primitive cylinders, one can sense the special qualities: the electricity generated by great artists giving their all before an audience as well as the preservation of voices and interpretations that otherwise would have passed into history; these brief excerpts, for example, are posterity will ever hear of the legendary tenor Jean de Reszke who destroyed the few official disks he did make.

The phrase surfaces as I remember lurking around schoolyards and soccer fields covertly observing my own young urban male and his peers. Boys at play they may not vet have it made, but they do seem constantly to be on the make. Their clothestypically grubby, slavishly conformist or eccentric at different stagesare more important to them than popular mythology admits. They learn all too early that clothes are a climber's short cut to lofty social position, a route that is easier on the digestion than eating spiders and more diplomatic than tripping the teacher.

title: Now Hear This: New Wave for Annapolis
description: Lots of students enrolled in Institutions out of town have been around lately on semester breaks. But few like Janice Buxbaum of Baldwin. She is 19 years old, and her proper title is Seaman Janice Buxbaum. She is enrolled in the United States Naval Academy's preparatory school in Newport, R. I. If she excells thereand I am doing well, she saidchances are she will be among the first class of SO women that the United States Naval Academy will accept this July. Since the age of 8. I have always wanted to De naval officer, she said, adding, I hope to go to sea sometime and I would like a shore station command also. I envision myself some day making admiral. Seaman Buxbaum joined the Navy as a recruit last year and attended communication school in Pensacola, Fla. At boot camp in Orlando. Fla. she was an honor recruit and won the American Spirit Medal. For women, she says, acceptance at the prep school has been good. We fit in well, she said. And the men are very helpful.

Kissinger told a Senate committee that working toward agreement among nations that supply nuclear technology was the only way to procfed, and some of the Senators told him that this was not nearly enough.

title: ART VIEW
description: t was Inevitable that the Bicentennial celebration would come to dominate a great many museum exhibitions this year, and it was no less inevitable that this would play havoc with museum standards, resources and energies. How could it be otherwise? The Bicentennial has imposed an obligation on museums the country over to mount showsbig shows, small shows, shows of every size, shape and charactermore or less related to its historical theme, and money from both government and corporate sources has been made available for the purpose of organizing these shows. To meet this obligation and to qualify for the available funds, musetnns have had to come up with all manner of exhibition ideas, some of them pretty remote from normal museological practice. At times, indeed, it has seemed as if the keenest competition was for producing something that did not belong in a museum at all.

title: ART VIEW
description: One of the strangest men who ever made works of art was Joseph Cornell (190372). For much of his life he lived on Utopia Parkviay in Flushing, N.Y. Constantly preoccupied with an invalid brother whom he looked after for most of his life, he did not lead what is called a normal existence. (He loved the romantic, ballets of the 19th century as few people have ever loved them, for instance, but his claustrophobia was so intense that he could not bear to go to a theater to see them. The ballets and the dancers were the inspiration for some of his most important works.) Cornell craved affection, and he gave it in oblique and almost clandestine waysabove all in messages through the mailsbut at the critical moments in his life, he retreated into the whitewashed and lowceilinged studiocumtreasurehouse which wait unlike any other room in the world.

title: Japanese Art in Lawrenceville

For the last few years, the gallery has been a major showcase in New Jersey for some of the most recent developments in painting and sculpture.

title: Northern Luzon Tribesmen Resist Big Dam Project
description: MANILA, March 13Moves by the Philippine martial law government to push development projects into formerly undisturbed interior areas have encountered violent opposition in the mountain provinces of northern Luzon.

title: To Be or Not to Be, That's What Matters
description: At last, Shakespeare has been translated into English. Simon & Schuster has just issued Macbeth, Hamlet, King Lear and Julius Caesar in four separate volumes, with the Shakespearean text on the lefthand page and a modern English paraphrase en face. Maurice Charney begins his general introduction, The purpose of this series is to make Shakespeare fully intelligible to the modern reader. Thus, on the righthand page we read, To be or not to be; that is what really matters. Apparently, the question has become unintelligible.

title: 4 Democrats Seek to Succeed Peyser
description: YONKERS, March 13The contest that is developing for the seat held by Senator James L. Buckley, RepublicanConservative, had resulted in a race in the 23d Congressional District of the northern Bronx and western Westchester.

title: 5 Killed in Michigan Crash
description: BATTLE CREEK, Mich., March 13 (UPI)Five persons were killed and sir others were seriously injured by a speeding car that went out of control, slid into an oncoming lane and crashed Into another auto last night. Those killed were identifled as Thomas Vileo, 19 years old, Shane Marsh, 17, and Richard Loder, 17, all of Battle Creek; Clark Hayden Jr., 23, of Niles, and Ingrid Griffith, 19, of Augusta.

title: Hailstones Pelt the City Amid a Flash of Spring
description: Midtown Manhattan and other parts of the metropolitan area were struck yesterday by a brief fall of hailstones during a thunderstorm that caused a 4degree drop In the temperatures in 10 minutes.

title: If You Thought Benji
