title: Annette Grossman Wed to Melvyn Klein
description: Annette Lorraine Grossman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Saul Grossman of Corpus Christi, Tex., was married there last evening to Melvyn N. Klein of New York, senior vice president and a director of Donaldson, Lufkin, Jenrette & Company, a New York investment firm.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The quarterfinals of the National Invitation Tournament continue at Madison Square Carden tomorrow and Tuesday nights at 7 o'clock. The semifinals arc at 7 P.M. Thursday and the final program on Saturday, with the thirdplace game at 11 A.M. and the championship game at 1 P.M.

title: Nevis: Hey, Mon! Not to Worry!
description: Darkness has fallen gently, as always, over the 35 square miles of tropical greenery that is the island of Nevis. On the flagstone patio of Croney's Old Manor Estate, silverware glows atop linen; the 10room hotel is only halffull, but 50 are expected for dinner. To the sound of subdued conversation and ice tinkling in cocktail glasses, the island's social event of the day is under waythe Old Manor Friday openhouse. Suddenly, the tabletop lamps flicker, dim and go out.

title: Suing in the Public Interest
description: use of sharenoiaer tunas DUI also significant policy questions, said Brent N. Rushforth of the Center for Law in the Public Interest, a nonprofit firm in Los Angeles.

title: Heather Mason Plans May 15 Wedding
description: Heather Mason and Michael Seay Sandifer plan to be married on May 15. Mr, and Mrs. John Harrington Mason of Greenwich, Conn., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Seay Sandifer Jr. of Greenwich and Juillac, France.

title: Argument For Change
description: WASHINGTON March 13The more this capital fusses and agonizes over the election the more it seems to long for fundamental change. It would never admit as much in public but the truth comes out irr private: From the top of the Administration and the Congress to the critical levels of the Civil Service it is almost yearning for new faces and new beginnings.

title: Radio Station for Islam
description: BONN (Religious News Service)A powerful international radio station, to be known as the Voice of Islam, will be built in a West German Protestant news agency. The Mecca fa

title: FILM VIEW
description: Nobody may have told us, but all of us probably have a pretty good idea of what happened to a favorite character after the curtain came down, the story ended, or the legend ran out. Little Orphan Annie, I'm sure, grew up to be the second woman ever admitted to the police force of Wichita, Kansas. She remained unmarried and though her relations with Daddy Warbucks had been cool during her teen years, she stood by him when he was tried and convicted on charges of Mil fraud in the late 1950's, Her patience finally gave out when, two years after Daddy was released from Federal prison, she learned that he had invested her small annuity in a phony retirement village on Key Biscayne, Fla. Daddy died a month after his indictment was handed down. Annie is now a private Investigator.

title: Adventure In a Park
description: NORTHPORT THE Victorian bandstand is still nearby and strollers will find the bobbing boats alongside the pier reaching out into Northport Harbor reassuringly familiar, but a strikingly modern series of freeform structures is being built in a new park at the foot of Main Streeta timber adventure system.

title: A Jaw Found in Pakistan Traced to Ancestor of Man
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 13 (UPI)  A Yale University professor said here that he had discovered a complete humantype lower jaw eight million to ten million years old belonging to an early direct ancestor of man.

title: Green Posts 201, Leads by 4 Shots
description: MIAMI, March 13 My gracious, Jack Nicklaus said with a gentle sigh. I shoot 68 and I'm losing ground.

title: Home Repairs: Caulking and Painting
description: THIS winter has been an exceptionally cold and windy one for residents of New Jersey, and it has subjected most houses to the hardest wear they have been exposed to in many years.

title: Connally Declines to Bar A VicePresidential Race
description: FLORESVILLE, Texas, March 13John B. Connally, assuming the role of a party leader, told Republican state officials invited to his ranch here today that he saw practically no possibility of entering the 1976 Presidential campaign. But con

title: Summer Jobs Few But Around
description: HIGH SCHOOL and college students looking for summer employment on Long Island this year may find themselves competing with their older brothers and sistars and, in some cases, their parents, for jobs that have traditionally been reserved for young people.

title: Nuclear Exporters May Expand Group Against Weapon Spread
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The group of seven nuclear exporting countries that haye agreed on safeguard guidelines to try to prevent a spread of atomic weapons will be expanded to include six more countries later this year, West European and East European diplomats reported today.

title: Crime Program Has Little Effect
description: An experimental Federal program to combat increasing urban crime has had little immediate effect on crime rates in the eight cities where it has been tried, a Governmentcommissioned report has concluded. But the report said that the program might Produce longterm benefits.

title: Florida's Revolution: The Sunshine Patriots
description: Sunshine patriots who retreat each year to Florida could well pack a tricorner hat and Betsy Ross bonnet next to their swim trunks and bikinis. Our War for Independence is usually associated with the snows of Valley Forge, but the war's southernmost actions took place under the balmy skies of the Sunshine State. The inhabitants thereof mean to proclaim the fact throughout 1976, demonstrating to fairweather friends that Florida offers Bicentennial as well as recreational opportunities.

title: Bank Growth: At What Price?
description: THE Security National Bank, which once flirted with fame beyond its humble origins in Huntington only to fall to virtual bankruptcy, was back in the news last week.

title: Criminals At Large
description: New York. Chicago. Indian.. apolis. Hong Kong. All have something in common this month: the police procedural (which is a tautology, really; procedural means police story in the argot). Procedurals vary.

title: France Expels a Russian After Complaint by Emigre
description: PARIS. March 13 (AP) French authorities have expelled a Soviet citizen, Yevgeny F. Ivanov, for trying to put pressure on an emigre Russian author, Andrei D. Sinyavsky, while ostensibly visiting France as a journalist, reliable sources have reported.

title: Negative Vote For the State
description: A SURVEY of 25,000 students now enrolled in New Jersey colleges has disclosed that 70 percent of them don't want to live in the state after they graduate. They showed no marked preference for an other place; they just want to go.

title: Hoosiers Score 9070 Triumph
description: SOUTH BEND Ind., March 13Coach Lou Carnesecca of St. John's said, They mangled usjust mangled us. And we haven't been mangled very often. No one argued with the coach after Scott May scored 33 points and undefeated Indiana University the topranked team in the country, easily won its 28th game this season, 9070 over St. John's today in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament. Western Michigan rallied to beat Virginia Tech, 7767 in overtime in the opening Mideast Regional game before 11,345 persons at Notre Dame's Athletic and Convocation Center.

title: San Francisco, St. Peter's Lose
description: A hungry University of North Carolina Charlotte team scored the National Invitation Tournament's first upset last night with a 7974 overtime victory over the University of San Francisco.

title: Reporter Was Spy For Democrat Foes, Weicker Declares
description: WASHINGTON, March 12Senator Lowell P, Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut, charged today that a Democratic spy acting as a newspaper reporter had attempted to infiltrate his reelection campaign.

title: MARKETS
description: The Dow Jones industrial average, symbol of the market to Wall Street and the investing public, closed above 1,000 last Thursday for the first time in more than three years,

title: $10,000 Digital
description: A $10,000 woman's digital watch with four carats of diamonds and six functions is the latest escalation in the whoseprice is higher war. The model offered by Telestar Time, a subsidiary of Gruen Industries Inc., has diamonds arranged in a circular pattern around the lens, a bracelet made of 14karat gold and a module that goes one function further than most: It also gives the day of the week in addition to the standard hour, minute, second, month and date readings.

title: Jonathan Logan Reaches An Agreement With Union
description: Jonathan Logan Inc. and the International Ladies Garment Workers Union have reached agreement on a new master contract covering 7,500 workers at 32 plants in 10 states, the union announced.

title: On Becoming A Shrinker With Miniature Plants
description: As a child in northern Minnesota, I roamed at will through forests and fields and on the beaches of Lake of the Woods. I learned to appreciate the different colors and textures of leaves, variations in forms, the beauty of bark, ferns, mosses and lichens.

title: Editors
description: Fiction

title: Putting New Life Into Those Old Hardwood Floors
description: For years people have been covering hardwood floors with carpet, tile or other form of floor covering. However, in recent years there has been an increasing trend toward going back to the natural woodin older houses and apartments people are removing their carpet or other flooringcovering, then refinishing the old floors by stripping them to the raw wood and applying stains, sealers and other clear finishes.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE UNITED STATES POSTAL SYSTEM will cut deliveries of business mall by at least one delivery a day beginning March 29 in an effort to reduce Its deficit.. The nation's money supplybroadly defined, as currency, checking accounts and time depositsrose by $1.2 billion

title: 125 to Compete for A.A.U. Diving Titles
description: CLEVELAND March 13 (AP)About 125 divers are expected to compete in the Amateur Athletic Union national indoor championships here March 31 to April 3. This will be the last major event before the Olympic trials.

Counting his tryst with JeanPierre Coopman in Puerto Rico Feb. 20, that makes three title defenses if you'll

description: Right: Traditionally styled suit with vest is brownandwhitechecked Dacron polyester and cotton. Imp Originals. 47. $47. 2d floor, Saks Fifth Ave. Shoes, Indian Walk. Girl's threepiece suit is made of rosecolored cotton denim flecked with white. Youngland. 714. $40. 4th floor, Martin's.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The allforeign coin show is now a fullfledged national numismatic institution. The first international specialty showdevoted to the coins and currencies, ancient to modern, of every country in the world except the U.S.made its debut in the early 1970's in Los Angeles, then spread almost immediately, and with equal success, to New York. The only gap in the crosscountry circuit was the Midwest. Next Friday that gap will be filled when the first annual Chicago International Coin Fair opens for a threeday run in the ChicagoSheraton Hotel.

title: 23 Fishermen Rescued
description: ST, JOHN'S, Newfoundland, March 13 (AP)A Canadian research ship yesterday rescued the 23man crew of the fishing Vessel Cape Freels from the stormtossed Atlantic, 120 miles southeast of St. John's. The

description: Nancy Austin Plans Nuptials on April 17

title: New Tremors in Guatemala
description: GUATEMALA, March 13 (AP)A score of strong earth tremors shook Guatemala again today, frightening the population. The tremors brought the total number of aftershocks In 1,369 since a quake hit the country Feb. 4. killing 23,000 persons and injuring 76,000 others.

title: FBI
description: It is a rare day these days when either the F.B.I. or the C.I.A.our intelligence community's Mr. Inside and Mr. Outsideis not embarrassed by some new revelation of past impropriety. Just weeks net> the C.I.A.

title: The lasting hurrah
description: The farewells were premature. For a generation it had been the fashion to assert that the Irish are fading out as a discernible group in American life, their representative character types disappearing into the bland conformity of suburbia, their characteristic political creationthe Tammanystyle bigcity machinein irreversible decline, and their dominance of that powerful cultural force, the Catholic Church, soon to be a thing of the past.

title: Nixon Perceived A Sovereign's Right to Illegality
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon, replying to questions posed by the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, has asserted his belief in the right of Presidents to commit illegal acts wider some circumstances. Mr. Nixon said that when the President, whom he referred to as the sovereign, determines that national security is at stake, he may lawfully commit acts that would otherwise be crimes.

title: TV VIEW
description: I t is interesting to watch a pietyat work, to see it grow. The closest analogy I can think of in the biological sciences is metastasisthe transference of diseaseproducing organisms or malignant or cancerous cells to other parts of the body by way of the blood vessels, lymphatics or membranous surfaces. In the case of a piety, the disease takes two forms: fugnminaea rnetonc ana DEM legislation. It swells, it inflates, it fills the room and the spaces In our heads, and suddenly we are inside of it, looking out at the ribwork; we become piety's children, in the belly of a blimp.

title: 4 Policemen Hurt in Melee With Hasidim
description: Four police officers were, slightly injured last night in a melee with a crowd of Hasduc Jews in Brooklyn that began when the police attempted lb give a traffic ticket to a Hasidic rabbi.

title: Friedman Sisters Will Be Brides
description: Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Friedman of Massapequa, L. I., have announced the engagements of their daughters, Kathy G. Friedman and Pamela Sue Friedman to, respectively, Dr. Ronald Glatzer and Dr. Louis H. Jacobs.

title: The Morning After the Big Game
description: BY this afternoon, Princeton University's oncourt ogre probably will be pensive about the big basketball game, which was played yesterday afternoon. He'll puff quietly on his omnipresent stogie and talk sadly about the state of basketball at Princeton.

title: Emotional Victory In a Classroom
description: OLD WESTBLTRY. MOST school stories are about money or buildings. This is a school story about two people, who had a victory that changed the lives of both of them, teacher and pupil.

title: Winter's Stay on Fire Island
description: DAVIS PARK, FIRE ISLAND T takes but one golden 36degree day like this, cloudless with gentle westerly breeze, to con me into forgetting the remorseless series of gray, bonechilling days and howling nights. On a day like this, all is forgiven.

title: FRENCH CABINET ALTERS VACATION
description: PARIS, March 13This summer French Cabinet ministers, for the first time, will stagger their vacations instead of following the past practice of leaving Paris all at once, except for one minister.

title: Charles M. Jochem Dies: Educator for the Deaf
description: Charles M. Jochem who had ham superintendent for 35 years of the Marie H. Katvenbad, School for the Deaf in Trenton, died yesterday at Jefferson Hospital, Philadelphia, after heart surgery, He was 70 years old.

title: The Inscrutable Budget; Russia Spends (1) More, or (2) Less Than U.S. for Arms
description: WASHINGTONNot for 20 years has the Russian bear loomed so large over Capitol Hill as in the shadow now being cast over Congress as it attempts to decide on the size of next year's defense budget. In a significant turnabout from the past Congressional approach of cutting away at the budget, the House Armed Services Committee last week recommended that $2 billion be aoded to defense program that the Ford Administration already had increased $14 billion over last year's level. The Senate Appropriations and Armed Services committees proposed that no cuts be made in the Administration' s $114 billion defense program. Whatever happens to the committees recommendationsand in the end they will probably be pruned back somewhat by the House and Senate Budget Committeesthe actions symbolize a changing Congressional attitude toward the defense budget and a growing Congressional concern over Soviet military power.

title: Good Dinner, Better Lunch
description: THE Tulip Tree is a harbinger. When Arthur Grasso reopens his tiny restaurant you know that spring Is at hand. Enter through the small gift shop area to a room with mouthwatering desserts on display, a handful of tables and beyond, the glassedin dining porch. There, a few more tables have a view of gardens,. fountains and, after dark, twinkling lights. The wrought Aron tables are set with elegent Ginori china, very pretty ???

title: BRIDGE
description: Generalizations about bridge are subject to an overriding generalization which confuses semanticists: never say never and never say always. This applies as well to me Latin adage, nil desperandum, never despair. There are times when it is right to cut one's losses, accepting a modest penalty. However, on occasion, almost certain defeat can be avoided thanks to hard thinking and a little help from the opponents.

title: 62% Increase in Lilco Rates Is Highest Among 5 Companies Serving Metropolitan Area
description: The energy crisis of 197374, which sent the price of fuel up, also helped to raise the cost of electricity to the Long Island Lighting Company's res idential customers by 62 percent.

title: Ambro, Klein Digging For U.S. Aid
description: REPRESENTATIVE Jerome A. Ambro, Democrat East Northport, is working with Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein to try to get the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to release sewer construction money to localities, particularly for the Southwest Sewer District in Suffolk, a $640 million project.

title: FOREST PRESERVE IN TEXAS IN PERIL
description: The Big Thicket, a huge wooded area in east Texas that was established as the country's first national biological) preserve in 1974, is in trouble.

title: Map Depicts Jersey Ideas
description: Johh T. Cunningham, a writer and historian from Florham Park, and Bill Canfield, cartoonist for The Newark StarLedger, have collaborated on a map entitled Where Ideas Grow. The map, which lists significant inventions and innovations credited to people from New Jersey, is available from tile state Chamber of Commerce in Newark for $3.50. It stresses New Jersey's role in the growth of the nation, giving information about people responsible for such ??? as the electric light, the phonograph, motion pictures, antibiotics, synthesized vitamins, transistors and even cultivated blueberries. The map measures 22 by 34 inches and Is suitable for framing.

title: Rizzo Seeking to Commit His Delegates to Jackson
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 13 (UPI)Mayor Frank L. Rizzo has thrown his support behind Senator Henry M. Jackson for the Democratic Presidential nomination and will seek court permission to commit his 30 city delegates to him, the Philadelphia Inquirer reported today.

description: LAWRENCE Kan. March 13 (AP)Toby Knight tipped in a lastsecond basket today that gave Notre Dame a 7978 victory over Cincinnati in an National Collegiate Athletic Association Midwest Regional basketball game.

title: Arthur H. Dix, a Pioneer In Market Research, 82
description: Arthur H. Dix, an early developer of market research techniques, died yesterday in Montclair, N. J. He was 82 years old.

title: Alissa Benimoff Fiancee of James Fox
description: Dr. and Mrs. Murray Benimoff of Cherry Hill, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alissa Gay Benimoff, to James Allen Fox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Fox of Grand Island, N.Y.

description: ASPEN, Colo., March 13LiseMarie Morerod of Switzerland, who has challenged for the overall World Cup women's crown for most of the season, won the Roch Cup giant slalom today.

title: Correction
description: In a story in last week's Review, was incorrectly stated that writeins were not permitted in the Massachusetts primary. Writeins were per mated.

description: The John Work Garrett coin collection, composed of approximately 700 pieces, many over a century old and in mint condition, brought $2,308,710, It record, when bidding closed yesterday at the end of a twoday auction. The collection is owned by Johns Hopkins Univercity

title: The Region
description: An unusual lawsuit attacking an apparently widespread realty practice that allegedly helps perpetuate racially segregated suburbia has been filed in Federal court in Newark, N.J.

title: Cover the Ground
description: Not long ago I visited a neighbor who lives on a country road and there is a great deal of shade on her property. Her lawn was made of 100 percent myrtle (Vinca minor), not a blade of grass anywhere to be mowed. It was beautiful and Practical.

title: Senator Cranston Bids U.S. ReExamine Ties to Seoul
description: LOS ANGELES, March 13 (UPI)Senator Alan Cranston. Democrat of California, called on the Ford Administration today to reexamine the United States alliance with South Korea, possibly to the extent of cutting a portion of its military aid, after reports of mass political arrests there.

title: Brown Complicates Democratic Race
description: CHICAGO, March 13A mafor new element of uncertainty has been introduced into the already confused contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination by the decision of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California to enter his state's June 8 primary.

title: American Sovereign
description: The puzzle over who ordered the Central Intelligence Agency to do what in a series of clandestine controversial foreign and domestic operations is not likely to be settled by Richard Nixon's latest sworn statements. However the former President's deposition does place in sharp focus one key issue that was central to his own misuse of powerand that remains central to much of the misunderstanding about unchecked and secret C.I.A. activities.

title: College Within a High School
description: IT cannot be found in any of the guides to higher education and it has no football team to be listed on the Sunday morning sports pages, but there is a kind of college operating in Hauppauge.

title: This ageless hero, Rubinstein; He cannot go on like this forever (though some would not bet on that). In fact, there are now some troubling signs.
description: One day, in what we may only hope is the distant future, an archeologist sifting through the detritus of Western civilization may come upon certain puzzling artifacts. A pair of tennis sneakers, perhaps, with 4inch platform soles. A goosequill pen with a felt tip. A petrified senator holding a Pentagon budget request. Or, if Western civilization is lucky, some piano recordings made by Arthur Rubinstein when he was on the brink of 90 and still playing with astonishing vigor, virtuosity and panache. Like Heinrich Schliemann pondering the myths and legends of Homeric Troy, the excavator will have a mystery on his hands. Did such a hero really live in those benighted times?

title: State Eyes Tax Fund
description: WITH the state looking in all directions for money to meet its ongoing fiscal needs, legislative fiscal experts are hungrily eyeing $81 million that Governor Byrne has set aside in his budget for the coming fiscal year.

title: 49ers Complete Staff
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., March 13 (AP)Monte Clark new head coach of the San Francisco 49ers, completed his staff of seven asistants today by naming Jim Spay tal as offensive backfield coach of the New York Jets last season.

title: Texas at El Paso Keeps Track Title
description: DETROIT March 13The University of Texas at El Paso won its third consecutive track championship today at the National Collegiate Athletic Association indoor meet before a capacity crowd of 9,964 at Detroit's Cobo Arena.

title: U.S. PANEL WEIGHS TESTS ON INMATES
description: BETHESDA, Md., March 13 A national commission concerned with protecting human subjects of research took steps today toward drafting a stringtent set of guidelines to govern medical research in prisons.

title: Crime in London Increases, Notably Teenage Offenses
description: LONDON, March 13 (UPI)Londoners suffered from more crime of all kinds last year and teenage suspects accounted for more than half those arrested, according to Scotland Yard.

title: Leafs, Islanders Battle to 22 Tie
description: TORONTO, March 13 The New, York Islanders were ready to claim a fierce victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs on a powerplay goal by Bryan Trottier with less than 3 1/2 minutes remaining in the game tonight. But 40 seconds later Jack Valiquette, a lanky young Toronto rookie, swooped around from behind the Islander net, stuffed the puck past Glenn Resch, and sent New York home with a 22 tie.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: One of the obvious and necessary results of the dance awakening of Americawhat might be called the choreographing of the United States has been the development of many new companies. Some of these companies have been developed to suit a local need, others have been inspired by the creative desires of their founders. But. here and there, a few companies have evolved that are not like any of their predecessors; they could almost be thought of as conceptual companies. Two of theseeach totally different: from the otherare the Pilobolus Dance Theater, apparently dedicated to the proposition that dance is too good a thing. to be left to just dancers, and Arthur Mitchell's Dance Theater of Harlem, a company, with a supporting school, intended to demonstrate that given the right training blacks can dance just as well as whites.

title: Third World, Congress

description: It all began with an image, an obsession: a mute old rabbi seated before his congregation, somewhere in the Soviet Union, on the eve of Yorn Kippur. The synagogue was crowded, the cantor was singing the customary prayers, a few men were responding. The mood was solemn,

title: Utilities vs the Consumer
description: THE cost of gas and electric service in New Jersey is increasing at such an outrageous rate that some consumers are threatening to withhold payment of their utility bills.

title: Bringing Up the Well Behaved Pigeon
description: Some people seem to have the idea that a pigeon is a sort of a jokebut not to the more than 40.000 pigeon fanciers in this country who belong to national clubs devoted to the breeding, racing and showing of Pigeons. And, their numbers are growing; at the 1975 annual National Young Bird Show in Louisville, Ky, more than 3,500 birds were entered, a 15 percent increase over the previous year.

title: Notes: Boomerang Returns
description: Interest in boomerangs is booming these days. In the months ahead no fewer than three major tournaments will be attracting enthusiasts to Bethlehem, Pa., Portland, Ore., and Washington, D.C. The Smithsonian Institution will sponsor workshop on boomerangs in May; and the new National Aeronautics and Space Museum, scheduled to open in Washington on July 4, will have a permanent exhibit entirely devoted to boomerangs. In addition, world champion practitioners of the art of throwing the Australian flying wing will tour this country.

title: Bronfman Is Named Head Of AntiDefamation Appeal
description: The appointment of Edgar M. Bronfman, chairman and chief executive officer of the Seagram Company, as general chairman of the New York AntiDefamation League Appeal, was announced last night.

title: Long Island/This Week

title: Extraordinary Gifts
description: ONE of the major functions of a museum is making acquisitions, additions that expand and enrich the existing collection. They are necessary to keep the museum alive, to reinvigorate its lifeblood. Museums that are content to survive on their holdings without enlarging often become lifeless mausoleums rather than vital Institutions.

title: Another Week, Another Primary But No Resolution
description: The collective result of this year's preconvention political process so far remains what it was before last week's primary: Irresolution on the question of who the Democratic and Republican nominees will be. President Ford again defeated Ronald Reagan, but not overwhelmingly; Jimmy Carter, the exGovernor of Georgia, led a field of Democrats, but not by much, and Gov. George Wallace of Alabama sustained it clear loss.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Joseph F. Dillon 3d (Letters to the Editor, Feb. 22) failed to state that he actually resides in Happy Rock. This is not to be confused with Glen Rock, which was named for a type of music made famous by a grinder of wheat.

title: Joy on the Delaware
description: A THREEDAY canoe attack on the Upper Delaware River begins long before the actual launch. It begins with talk during the winter.

title: Huge Bust of Brezhnev To Stand in Home Town
description: MOSCOW, March 13 (Reu. ters)A huge bronze bust of the Soviet Communist Party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, is to he set up in his home town of Dneprodzerzhinsk, organizers of a moscow art exhibition said today.

description: What is there left to do? This piercing question which has been beating more and more loudly in the heart of every writer for the past three centuries, was the subject of a piercing book by Walter Jackson Bate six years ago. The Burden of the Past and

title: Exxon's Innovative Little Offshoots
description: Scan Tron, Qume, Vydec, Ramtek, Qwip, Xentex, Daystar and Delphi are not exactly household words, but they have tw'o things in common. They are small companies involved in advanced technologies, and they are all backed by the Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company.

title: SHOP TALK
description: FOR those who melt in a marshmallow world and swoon over truffles and sugary delights, there's much to entice the eye and tempt the appetite in a shop called: Lazar's ChocolateChef, at 38 Middle Neck Road in Great Neck.

title: With An Admiral At the Helm

title: Son of 1924
description: Some Democrats with a sense of history, including a number of seasoned national campaigners, have resisted getting involved in this year's campaign because they feel that, even in its new location, Madison Square Garden is haunted. They remember that in 1924, the last time it met in New York City, the Democratic Party destroyed both its prospects for victory and its reputation in the course Of the longest nominating convention in American history; and they fear there are enough similar factors to cause a repeat of that debacle this summer. Can 1924 happen again?

title: A daughter's memories
description: One of the inventions of 20thcentury literatureand one of the few which is both admirable and lovablehas been the elegy for One's Parents. As far back as we can see, childparent relations have been at least as complex, damaging and rewarding as they are now (Abraham and Isaac, Oedipus and Laius) but early poetry and fiction are generally free of memorials of artistic quality to father and mother. Why? would be an interesting study. Was the available emotion discharged elsewhere (elaborate funerals, rituals of grief)? Was the early death of most parents a factor (many children never knowing their parents)? Is the decline of faith in immortality, with the rising sense of fragility and pathos, increasingly at work?

title: What's Doing Along the RHINE
description: THE RIVERThe broad, swiftflowing Rhine has been attracting tourists for centuries, and despite a dose of industrial pollution, it continues to charm. In the words of the modern German writer Heinrich Boll, the Rhine can be dirty ana majestic at toe sme time. The best part of the river for touring is the middle Rhine, between Mainz and Cologne, which offers the wildest scenery, about 40 castles and plenty of wine. Mainz and Cologne are among Germany's oldest cities and have rich historical and artistic traditions. Bonn, the other city in this area, is a beautiful provincial German university town marred by tacky modern buildings that house the West German Government. Rhinelanders generally are a happygolucky and very friendly lot.

title: If You Go
description: to Switzerland to rent a chalet or an apartment (some chalets have two or three apartments), you can obtain brochures of various towns and resorts from the Swiss National Tourist Office, 608 Fifth Avenue, New York 10020. Write to the local tourist bureau whose address is given on each folder. The bureau will send lists of chalet owners. Enclosing a detailed questionnaire is strongly recommended. Ask about the number of bedrooms, kitchen facilities, telephone, washing machine, proximity to swimming, grocery shopping, public transportation, elevation, the the size of the area around the house. Ask if the house is easily accessible from road (some may be a steep climb away from parking or local bus). Ask for photographs. Choose chalets according to the number of beds you'll need (six beds obviously cost more than three). Since many European vacationers return to the same chalet year after year, expect only a few replies.

title: Bilateral Peril

The 1974 Trade Act, under four different headings, has invited this plethora of complaints by easing the requirements for proving injury or foreign unfair trade practices.

description: A Mozambique's closure of her border with Rhodesia has severed rail connections to the ports of Beira and Maputo which had handled onethird of Rhodesia's trade.

title: Power Is Victorious In C.H.S.A.A. Final
description: Power Memorial has a long basketball tradition of outstanding big men that includes Kareem AbdulJabbar, but it was two little men who were the keys yesterday as Power defeated Tolentine, 6550, for the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship held at St. John's gymnasium in JamaiOueens.

title: Mrs. Young Cards 9Stroke Victory
description: MELBOURNE Australia March 14 (AP)Donna Young of the United States, coasting on her recordsetting 64 of yesterday, carded a twounderpar 70 today and won an Australian women's golf tournament by nine strokes.

title: Neil Sedaka Sings On 37th Birthday Redeeming Genre
description: When Neil Sedaka was having his firse run of hits between 1959 and 1963 it was with a sort of musicbuoyant novelty numbers and bouncy teen tunesthat never really appealed to this listener. Between 1963 and last year Mr. Sedaka was pushed into the background by rock from the Beatles on. Now he's. back, and in general the syndrome he epitomizes, with its Las Vegas arrangements and plastic sentimentality is yet another sort of music this listener abhorsmore a return to schlock than the return to melody its have called it.

title: Gallup Poll Finds Carter Ahead Of Ford by Margin of 47 to 42%
description: Former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia, a contender for the Democratic Presidential nomination, would defeat President Ford if the election were held now, according to a special Gallup poll released today.

title: FRANC CUT LOOSE, ALLOWED TO FLOAT
description: BRUSSELS, Monday, March 15The French Government decided to withdraw the franc from the European joint currency float at a meeting here early today of European finance ministers and central bank governors, Finance Minister Willy de Clercq of Belgium announced.

title: Crime Rose in Richer Neighborhoods, Fell in Poorer Sections of City in 1975
description: Many middleincome neighborhoods in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx registered sharp increases in serious crime last year. At the same time the rate of reported felonies decreased or leveled off in some innercity precincts that have long been menaced by severe crime problems.

title: Duvillard Wins Again
description: STEAMBOAT SPRINGS, Colo. March 14 (AP)Henri Duvillard of France the 1976 champion of the professional skiing circuit, continued his dominance today with a victory in the giant slalom over Josef Odermatt of Switzerland.

title: Ford's Staff Derides His Florida Campaign Chief
description: WASHINGTON, March 14  The President Ford Committee had the last laugh about Representative Louis Frey Jr., occasionally rebellious chairman of the Ford Campaign in Florida, Repeatedly Mr. Frey made public his fear of losing the Florida primary to Ronald Reagan and his low opinion of the Ford committee in Washington. In the end, Mr. Ford won Florida (despite Frey, one Ford man said)

title: GEORGE LEE OF YALE, ASIANART EXPERT
description: George J. Lee, curator of Oriental art at the Yale University Art Gallery since 1959, died in New Haven on Wednesday. He was 56 years old.

title: Albany Plans Bipartisan Effort To Draft Legislative Ethics Bill
description: ALBANY, March 13Legislators here will make a bipartisan effort next week to start drafting a legislative ethics bill that is expected to avoid the problems that impeded separate Assembly and Senate bills last year.

title: SADAT ACTS TO END PACT WITH SOVIET CAIRO SIGNED IN 71
description: CAIRO, March 14President. Anwar elSadat called on the Egyp'ian People's. Assembly tonight to abrogate immediately the SovietEgyptian Treaty of Friendship and Cooperation concluded in 1971.

title: Number in Federal Prisons Reaches Record 26,047
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)The number of Federal prisoners has reached a new high, and the prisons are being stretched beyond their capacity, Attorney General Edward H. Levi said today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, MARCH 15, 1976

title: FRENCH LEFTISTS GAIN IN ELECTIONS
description: PARIS, March 14  The French leftist opposition made sizable political gains today in nationwide local elections, at the expense of the Government majority headed by President Valdr' Giscard d'Estaing.

title: Swedish King's Fiancee
description: STOCKHOLM  Last summer, when speculation was rife that King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden was about to announce his engagement to Silvia Renate Sommerlath a

title: Books of The Times
description: Why is the wife of the English archeologist wearing a dress designed in fertility motifs? For what reason do the archeologist and the Arab sheik talk to each other in code? Who killed the four workmen at the Tell Brak dig? For what sinister purpose is the colonel drowning bats in wash basin at midnight? Why does the Yezidi devil appear in the form of a peacock? What is the cause of the Kurdish women's addiction to bicarbonate of soda?

title: Chile's Debts Worry Washington
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 14  Concern over the ability of Chile to meet its large foreign debt obligations has emerged as the cornerstone of United States policy toward the rightwing military junta here, according to diplomatic and banking sources.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Teachers at eight state colleges said yesterday that they would go on strike March 24 unless a contract impasse between the Byrne administration and union representatives was resolved. A strike vote is scheduled for Thursday and Friday, according to Marcoantonio Lacatena, president of the Council of New. Jersey State College Locals. The state's latest contract offer, made shortly before dawn Saturday, was completely; unacceptable, Mr. Lacatena said. Teacher classroom work loads was the key stumbling block. I will recommend that the membership not vote on this package, but will simply call for a strike vote, Mr. Lacatena said. If the 3,200 faculty members and staff workers strike, some 60,000 students at Keen, Ramapo, Stockton, Paterson, Glassboro, Trenton, Jersey City and Montclair State Colleges would be affected.

title: U.S. HINTS CRIMES BY AIDES OF ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, March 14The Justice Department has concluded that possible criminal violations of Civil Service regulations were committed by employes of ACTION, the Federal volunteerservice agency, in efforts to cover up an influencepeddling scheme four years ago.

title: UNDERGROUND BLAST IS FELT AT LAS VEGAS
description: MERCURY, Nev., March 14 (AP)A nuclear device, 25 to 55 times more powerful than the atomic bomb dropped on

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: PROJECTION The Human Condition Through Song may seem an offbeat title for a program utilizing the voice, guitar and violin, but this is the specialty of Lois Raebeck, who will be performing free tonight at 7:30 o'clock at the Jefferson Market Library, 425 Avenue of the Americas at 10th Street.

title: LAYOFFS OF 2,000 REPORTED A PART OF STATE BUDGET
description: ALBANY, March 14  The budget that leaders in the Legislature are submitting to the membership this week for approval calls for layoffs of as many as 2,000 employees in state operating agencies and sizable retrenchment in the state's support of drugaddiction programs, fiscal officials disclosed today,

title: White House Linked to Callaway Move
description: WASHINGTON, March 14Howard H. Callaway's decision to give up temporarily the chairmanship of President Ford's campaign was encour aged, although not demanded, by the White House, wellplaced officials said here today.

title: SADAT ACTS TO END PACT WITH SOVIET CAIRO SIGNED IN 71
description: CAIRO, March 14President Anwar elSadat called on the Egyp'ian People's Assembly tonight to abrogate immediately the SovietEgyptian Treaty of Friendship and Cooperation concluded in 1971

title: Voting Law At Center Of Dimute
description: The controversy over the validity of designating petitions filed by New York candidates for Democratic National Convention delegates not only gave the Presiden

title: Ludwig R. Engler, ExAide Of RCA Communications, 6E
description: Ludwig R. Engler, former vice president for commercial activities of RCA Global Communications Inc., died Saturday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 68 years old.

title: Gold's Detectives Seek More Bodies in Catskills Lake in Cult Figure Inquiry
description: Three detectives from the office of District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn supervised a search by divers using electrical suction vacuums yesterday for more bodies in the waters of Briscoe Lake in the Catskills, where the remains of two teenage sisters were found last week.

title: FRENCH LEFTISTS GAIN IN ELECTIONS
description: PARIS, March 14  The French leftist opposition made sizable political gains today In nationwide local elections, at the expense of the Government majority headed by President Valer' Giscard d'Estaing.

title: NO TALKS SLATED IN BUS SHUTDOWN
description: With no bargaining talks scheduled, a crippling bus strike involving five bus companies, and forcing a halfmillion riders to seek other means of transportation, went into the sixth day yesterday with no end in sight.

title: Chile's Debts Worry Washington
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 14  Concern over the ability of Chile to meet its large foreign debt obligations has emerged as the cornerstone of United States policy toward the rightwing military junta here, according to diplomatic and banking sources.

title: St. Patrick's Day Parade In the Making for a Year
description: No bedsheets with homemade slogans. Only one permitted slogan: England Get Out of Ireland. No advertising. No cuttingup in front of the television cameras.

title: Attorney in the. Zebra
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 14 The defense attorney for four Black Muslims who were convicted yesterday, after a trial that lasted more than a year, of a series of street slayings in 197374 that were known as the Zebra killings, says he plans to appeal the verdict to a state appellate court.

title: CORRECTION
description: An artice in The New York Times last Monday incorrectly stated that Central Synagogue at Lexington Aveenue and 55th Street was the oldest synagogue in continuous use in New York State. That distinction is held by Temple Berith Sholom in Troy, which was completed in 1870 and conducted its first service that year. Central Synagogue held its first, service In 1872, two year; after the laying of the cornerstone. It is the oldest synagogue in continuous use in New York City.

title: FRANC CUT LOOSE. ALLOWED TO FLOAT
description: BRUSSELS, Monday, March 15  The French Government decided to withdraw the franc from the European joint currency float at a meeting here early today of European finance ministers and central bank governors, Finance Minister Willy de Clercq of Belgium announced.

title: Babylon Tops Malverne
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 14Undefeated Babylon High School, the No. 1ranked team in New York State, defeated Malverne, 7463, tonight at the Nassau Coliseum and won the Long Island basketball championship for the second straight year.

title: U.S.Adds Green Takes Doral Golf by 6 Shots
description: MIAMI, March 14Hubert Green, who calls himself a skinny kid from Alabama, completed today the job of making the DoralEastern open the Huhie Green Benefit Show. He shot a 69 and completed 72 holes at 270, a record and 18 strokes under par for the Blue Course of the Doral Country Club.

title: Connors Wallops Nastase
description: HAMPTON, Va March 14 (AP)  Topseeded Jimmy Connors of Belleville, 111 routed second  ranked Ilie Nastase of Rumania, 6.2 62, 62. today in the final of an Independent Players Association tennis tournament.

title: Mild Winter Averts, U.S. Fuel Shortage
description: The winter now drawing to close appears to be the easiest in terms of fuel and energy that Americans have experienced since the Arab oil embargo imposed in October 1973.

title: Carter's Drive From Obscurity to Front
description: MARION, III.For months now, one of the standard components of Jimmy Carter's campaign speech has been a litany of American heroes ranging from Washington and Lincoln to Franklin D. Roosevelt and Martin Luther King Jr.

title: So. Conn. Gymnast Wins Five Finals
description: NEW HAVEN Conn.peter Korman of Southern Connecticut State College won five of six events today in the individual finals of the Eastern Intercollegiate Gymnastics League championships at the Southern Connecticut fieldhouse.

title: Bobby Unser First at Phoenix
description: PHOENIX Ariz. March 14 (AP)Bobby Unser held off Pancho Carter by less than two car lengths in a lastlap sprint to the finish today for a dramatic victory in the Bryan 150mile Indianapolis car race. Gordon Johncock was three lengths farther back.

title: Protectionist Threat
description: Little noticed by most Americans, exports from the United States in this decade have soared steadily to the staggering total of $107 billion a year, three times the output of the whole automobile industry. Even during the recession the figure continued to rise. Sales abroad have climbed from 4 percent of the gross national product to 7.5 percent; if services are excluded, these sales represented about 20 percent of the goods produced in the United States, with factory and farm products predominating.

title: CASTRO IN GUINEA; TO MEET ANGOLAN
description: DAKAR Senegal March 14 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Fidel Castro arrived in Conakry the capital of Guinea, today for a meeting with three African presidents, including Agostinho Neto of Angola Conakry radio reported.

title: Tennis in the Soviet Style
description: MOSCOW March 13  Tennis ball; may be in short supply in the Soviet Union, but tennis players are not. Tennis, a sport once derided here as bourgeois exercise for the leisure class, has taken on proletarian respectability in such diverse corners of the nation as Vorkuta in the Arctic, Vladivostok in the far east and Samarkand in central Asia.

title: Talent Prizes Announced
description: WASHINGTON, March 15Four high school seniors from the New York City area and one from New Jersey were among the 10 students who won scholarships in the West inghouse Electric Corporation's 35 annual sciencetalent search, it was announced today.

title: Laser Tests Uphold Equivalence Principle on Inertia and Gravity in Einstein's General Theory of Relativity
description: A counterpart of the experiment whereby Galileo showed that objects of different weight fall at essentially the same peed has been conducted, using objects of considerably greater massthe earth and moonto attack the problem from a new angle.

title: WILLIAMS TO BUY 50% OF GOULDING
description: The Williams Companies of Tulsa, Okla., said yesterday that it had concluded an agreement, to have its subsidiary, the Agrico Chemical Company, buy 50 percent of Goulding Chemical, a subsidiary of the Fitzwilton Group of Dublin, Ireland. Goulding, with annual sales Of $60 million, has been engaged in the manufacture and marketing of fertilizersin Ireland for more than 100 years.

title: Baird Team First In Platform Tennis
description: In winning the 10th and final regularseason tournament on the $40,000 Tribuno platform tennis circuit Sunday, the brothers Steve and Chip Baird of Short Hills, N.J., finished first in the season standing. They will lead the circuit's top 16 teams into the $12,000 playoff April 2 at the West Side Tennis Club.

title: Yonkers Entries
description: Yonkers Entries

title: Shearson in Hong Kong
description: The formation of Shearson Hayden Stone Far East Ltd. of Hong Kong and the appointment of Philip M. Waterman Jr. as president was announced Hayden Stone, the brokerage firm. Mr. Waterman was manager of Shearson's Park Avenue office.

title: CALLAWAY RETURN TO POST DOUBTED
description: WASHINGTON, March 15Howard H. Callaway may never return to the helm of President Ford's election campaign, highly placed Administration sources said today.

title: Stocks Down Sharply Again; Bell Issue Up to 8.56% Yield
description: In the key corporate bond sale this week, an issue of 40year Bell System debentures was priced late yesterday to yield 8.56 percentwell above the 8.34 percent rate of return Credit Marketson the preceding American Telephone bond issue that was marketed in February prior to the recent early March runup in interest rates. Even with the higher yield, it was not certain that the new issue would sell quickly after it is offered formally to investors today.

title: Grand Jury Starts Taking Testimony in Case of Dr. X
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., March 15A Bergen County grand jury began taking testimony here today in the case of Dr. X, a New Jersey surgeon who is suspected of having murdered nine or more patients with curare at Riverdell Hospital in Oradell a decade ago.

title: 3 ARE SUSPENDED BY OPTIONS BOARD
description: CHICAGO, March 15 (UPI)The Chicago Board Options Exchange announced today it had suspended three men for up to three years from association with the exchange or its members for alleged violations of exchange trading rules.

title: ARMORED FORCES IN LEBANON MOVE ON FRANJIEHNNIE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, March 16Two armored columns headed toward the heavily guarded mansion of President Suleiman Franjieh yesterday to back demands that he resign, then halted a few miles away.

title: MiamiLos Angeles Route Denied Pan Am by C.A.B.
description: Pan American World Airways suffered a major setback yesterday when the Civil Aeronautics Board picked Western Airlines to compete with National Airlines on the valuable MiamitoLos Angeles route.

title: Action Near on Bills Slashing Election Board's Power
description: WASHINGTON. March 15The campaign legislation due for Congressional action in the net ten days restores the Federal Election Commission to constitutional status, at the cost of reducing the independent agency to the approximate level of a House subcommittee.

title: The Democrats Big 3
description: WASHINGTON, March 15Three quite different men have emerged as the survivors of the early Democratic primaries and caucusesMorris K. Udall, Henry M. Jackson and Jimmy Carter. Each has distinctive strengths and distinctive political problems.

title: Hope Feels Threatened by Tentacles of Development
description: HOPE TOWNSHIP  The natural beauty and preserved historical settings of this rural hamlet in the western foothills of the state are being threatened.

title: Blood in Nigeria
description: Public execution by firing squad of 30 Nigerian Army officers and one civilian for alleged involvement in an abortive coup last month is the act of frightened military rulers, unsure of their support either in the armed forces or the country as a whole. The macabre exhibition on a beach near Lagos furnishes the most striking contrast imaginable to the magnanimous treatment of the military and civilian leaders of secessionist Biafra by Gen. Yakubu Gowon at the end of Nigeria's civil war in 1970.

title: TONY GODWIN, 56, EDITOR, IS DEAD
description: Tony Godwin, one of Britain'S most prolific and innovative literary editors in the 1960's and the copublisher at Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. here since 1973, was found dead yesterday in his apartment at 864 Lexington Avenue, apparently of a heart attack. He was 56 years old.

title: Tom Seaver of Yankees Don't Laugh
description: In talking about trading Tom Seaver, the Mets front office has hit its pique of inefficiency. It also certified the Mets lack of understanding that in the Baseball Revolution, a player's market exists now for a performer.

title: Blighted Areas Use Is Urged by Rohatyn
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, the chief of Governor Carey's new economic recovery program, said yesterday that blighted areas of the city would have to be torn down wholesale and treated as virgin, industrialdevelopment territory, as has been done in the suburbs and in the South.

title: Ingmar Bergman's Taxes: Swedes Brood Over Case
description: STOCKHOLM, March 12A taxfraud case against Ingmar Bergman, the internationally acclaimed film director, has created a wave of selfexamination within Sweden, a debate over police powers and bitter accusations that the bureaucracy is hounding the nation's foremost artist.

title: Betty Jones in City Opera's Figaro
description: It is possible, and even helpful, to introduce touches of humor into the role of the Countess Almaviva in The Marriage of Figaro. That great lady is too often portrayed as an unrelentingly doleful matron of uncertain years when, in fact, she is supposed to be a young wife who has only recently discovered that love is not always eternal.

title: C.I.A. SAYS ISRAEL HAS 1020 ABOMBS
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 The Central Intelligence Agency estimates that Israel has 10 to 20 nuclear weapons available for use, according to an agency official quoted today by a science journalist.

title: Briton Sees Court Ruling As Last Word on SST's
description: TRENTON, March 15A representative of the British Government said today that the question of landing rights for the Concorde supersonic transport at Kennedy International Airport would have to be settled in the courts rather than on the floor of the Legislature here.

title: Jo Mielziner Dies
description: Jo Mielziner, who created the settings for dozens of Broadway hits, died at the age of 74. Details on page 38.

title: Aussie Schoolgirl, 14, Sprints to Spotlight
description: SYDNEY, AustraliaAustralia believes it has a worldclass sprint prospect in a 14yearold schoolgirl from Emmaville, a small country town in northern New South Wales, near the Queensland border.

title: Move is a Setback to Economic Bloc
description: BRUSSELS, March 15European officials indicated today that they considered France's withdrawal from the joint European monetary float a major setback to efforts to increase monetary cooperation within the Common Market. They saw the French action as proof that fixed currency rates within Europe were not possible without full convergence among the economies of the member nations.

title: Bank Seeking Happiness for All
description: People are dying to be treated like human beings, said Robert Previdi, the ad agency dropout who is senior vice president and director of marketing services of the EuropeanAmerican Bank.

title: CLARK CANDIDACY ANNOUNCED HERE
description: Ramsey Clark, who was defeated by Senator Jacob K. Javits, a Republican, two years ago, formally announced yesterday that he would seek the Democratic nomination again, this time o oppose he state's other Senator, James L. Buckley.

title: IrishAmericans in Historic Savannah Debate Plan for Renovating Cathedral
description: SAVANNAH, Ga.  The mystique that develops around many great churches is evident here as deep reverence among IrishAmerican Roman Catholics for the Cathedral of St. John the Baptist.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Two armored columns, apparently from the Lebanese Arab Army, headed today toward the heavily guarded mansion of President Suleiman Franylh of Lebanon to back demands that he resign, but halted a few miles away. One of the columns was blocked by Syrianbacked guerrillas, increasing speculation that a political solution to Lebanon's tangled constitutional crisis might be near. It appeared that Syria, which helped bring about the ceasefire of Jan. 22 in the Lebanese civil war, was trying to work out an agreement under which Mr. Franjieh would quit. [Page 1, Col. 1.]

title: SPANISH CABINET UNDER HEAVY FIRE
description: MADRID, March 15Spain's threemonthold Cabinet, organized to carry out a political reform program and to confront an economic depression, was in difficulty today on both issues after the strongest wave of social unrest here in 40 years.

title: Cautious Spending Plans
description: Despite rising sales and profits, American businesses are showing caution in raising their outlays on new plant and equipment. The latest Government survey of capital spending plans indicates that industry now intends to invest $120 billion in 1976a 6.5 percent increase over last year in current dollars. But, given inflation, that is virtually no increase in real terms.

title: Spurs Halt Colonels By 118105
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 15. (AP)James Silas scored 37 points and George Gervin added 33 tonight and led the San Antonib Spurs to a 118105 American Basketball Association victory over the Kentucky Colonels.

title: City U. Teacher Furlough is Postponed
description: The City University and the uhion representing its faculty members and staff announced yesterday that the weeklong furlough without pay that was planned for this month would be postponed.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Both sides in the weekold strike by Transport of New. Jersey employees that has disrupted service to 450,000 daily riders have agreed to return to the bargaining table for the first time since the strike began on March 9, mediators said yesterday. Representatives of the bus company and the Amalgamated Transit Union agreed to meet at 10 A.M. today at the Ramada Inn in Clark, N.J., according to Federal and state mediators.

title: N.F.L. to Set Draft Dates
description: CORCINADO, Calif., March 15 (UPI)Commissioner Pete Rozelle said today the National Football League would hold its courtdelayed expansion and collegiate drafts within the next three weeks and would also listen to a franchise bid by an owner from the defunct World Football League.

title: Sadat Move on Soviet Called Step to Get U.S. Arms
description: CAIRO, March 15President Anwar elSadat's call yesterday for an end to Egypt's friendship treaty with the Soviet Union was described here today as intended to clear the way for the purchase of arms in the United States and Western Europe.

title: ELMER H. WHITE
description: Elmer H. White, who retired, In 1955, as a vice president and in 1958, as a director of United States Rubber Company, now Uniroyal Inc., died Saturday in Keys Community Hospital in Tavernier, Fla. He was 88 years old and lived at 411 Harbor Road, Southport, Conn.

title: U.S.Puts Off Talks Over Energy, Reportedly to Chide Russians
description: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, March 16An Administration source disclosed early today that the United States, in an expression of displeasure with the Soviet Union, has postponed a threeday energy meeting that was to have begun in Moscow yesterday.

title: Panel Finds Ford's Policy Could Slow the Recovery
description: WASHINGTON, March 15The Congressional Budget Office warned today that, if the budget policies advocated by the Ford Administration were followed, the economic recovery might slow next year to the point where there would be no further decline in unemployment.

title: Express CarPool and Bus Test Disrupts Los Angeles Freeways
description: LOS ANGELES, March 15One lane in each direction on California's busiest freeway was turned over to buses and car pools today, resulting in a small increase in mass transit Patronage, but chaos for motorists who tried to commute as usual on the Santa Monica Freeway.

title: CHARLES M. DOLE OF SKI PATROL, 76
description: Charles Minot Dole, honorary chairman of the National Ski Patrol, which he founded in 1938, died Sunday in Greenwich, Conn., where he lived. He was 76 years old.

title: Disney's Hall of Presidents Not 76 Politics
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. The election year has produced a chorus of lamentations about how cynical and mistrustful of their political leaders the American voters have become. Such attitudes may or may not be justified, and may or may not be healthy, but before jumping to conclusions the larnenters might contemplate the Hall of Presidents here at bisney World.

title: Balanced U.S. Energy Policy is Urged
description: Representative Mike McCormack, Democrat of Washington, told leaders of the paper industry here yesterday that the campaign to undermine nuclear energy is, in effect, a campaign to cause additional unemployment. He added that, if efforts to cut back nuclearenergy programs succeeded, it would mean increased unemployment among disadvantaged Americans, including those right here in New York City.

title: Jackson Optimistic as He Seeks to Build State Coalition
description: BUFFALO, March 15Senator Henry M. Jackson reached Into a shapeless old felt hat held high today by a clerk in the Erie County Board of Elections and pulled out a numbered button that would give his slate of Presidential delegates the first line on the primary ballot in the 37th District.

title: Israelis Impose a Curfew On West Bank Arab Town
description: RAMALLAH, IsraellOccupied West Bank, March 15Israeli military authorities imposed a total curfew on this West Bank town today after another day of violent street demonstrations and protests against the continued Israeli occupation of the area.

title: EQUATORIAL GUINEA AND U.S. IN DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)The State Department announced today the suspension of diplomatic relations with Equatorial Guinea.

title: NIGERIA ANNOUNCES CHANGES IN CABINET
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, March 15 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Nigerian head of state, Lieut. Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, announced today a major shuffle of the Cabinet formed by his predecessor, Gen. Murtala Ramat Muhammed, who was assassinated last month in an attempted coup.

title: Fugitive Captured Upstate After Detective is Wounded
description: GREENBURGH, N. Y., March 15 (UPI)The police in Greenburgh, said they captured a murder suspect today after he had returned to the spot where, they said, he shot a detective five hours earlier.

title: SEMINAR TO OFFER ADVICE ON SELLING
description: NEWARK, March 15A cram course in how to proceed through the bureaucratic maze and sell goods and services to state and Federal government agencies will be offered to economically hardpressed businessmen in northern New Jersey at a oneday regional conference here on May 21.

title: RHODESIAN SEEKS WEST'S SUPPORT
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 15  Prime Minister Ian D. Smith has accused the United States and the rest of the free world of having failed Rhodesia and the other countries of southern Africa and has expressed the hope that the West will rally to Rhodesia's aid in the event of a Soviet or Cuban involvement in the guerrilla war here.

title: Aztecs Trade Calloway
description: LOS ANGELES, March 15 (AP) The Lost Angeles Aztecs of the North American Soccer League traded Laurie Calloway, a center, to San Jose for Geoff Butler today. Butler, also a center, is a former allleague player for Baltimore.

title: People in Sports
description: Leo Durocher's contract to manage a Japanese baseball team has been canceled because he is in poor health. The 70yearold Durocher, who has managed three pennantwinning clubs (the Dodgers in 1941 and the Giants in 1951 and 54) in a career that spanned five decades, signed Jan. 9 for a reported $220,000 to manage the Taiheiyo Club Lions of Japan's Pacific League.

title: United Press International
description: United Press International

title: March 110 Car Sales Up 37.2%; Only A. M. C. Shows a Decrease
description: Continued From Page 47

title: Dr. Roy A. Pizzarello Dies; Color Chemistry Specialist
description: Dr. Roy A. Pizzarello, who retired last September as director of research for the Inmont Corporation, printing inks, colors, pigments and other products, died Sunday in Paterson (N.J.) General Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Franklin Lakes, N.J.

title: Leftward in France
description: The triennial cantonal elections in France for virtually powerless local bodies normally have little significance. The political future of France will be determined by the parliamentary elections of 1978 and the presidential voting of 1981, both a long way off. Yet the left swing in this year's cantonals has a special meaning.

title: East and West Sides Back Bill to Ban Outdoor Drinking
description: Residents of the Gracie Mansion area of the East Side are talking of organizing vigilante committees to combat streetdrinking, teenage terrorists.

title: Dow Drops by 13.14 on Profit Taking
description: Stock prices dropped sharply again yesterday on profit taking to round out the biggest twoday decline since the market began to turn briskly upward early last December.

title: WILLIAM S. M'MENEMY
description: STAMFORD, Conn., March 15  William S. McMenemy, retired president of Countess Mara Inc., men's and women's retail shops in New York, died yesterday. He was 75 years old and lived at 1 Strawberry Hill Court.

title: Carolina Fives Gain in N.I.T.
description: Al Green, a muchtraveled basketball player, and Kenny Carr, a highly regarded young player, led North Carolina State into the semifinal round of the National Invitation Tournament last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: India Plans Big Outlays for Key Projects
description: NEW DELHI, March 15Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government, in an effort to consolidate recent economic gains, announced today a program of major investment in such key development projects as steel, fertilizer, agriculture and energy in the next 12 months.

title: Callaway's Inquiries on Ski Resort Permit Traced in Documenfs
description: DENVER, March 15Howard H. Callaway, both as Secretary of the Army and later as President Ford's campaign manager, made inquiries to the United II States Forest Service and urged it to speed up the issuance of a permit for expanding his Colorado ski resort, according to newspaper reports based on public documents removed two days ago from Government files here.

title: Books of The Times
description: Virginia Hull Babcock Bliss, the heroine on the run from her marriage in Lisa Aither's first, talented comic novel, Kinflicks, seems at first to be a wise guya fairly charming wise guy, admittedly, but not very different from ones we've met in several dozen first novels by disaffected young women in the 1960's and 70s. Ginny's first way of satirizing young motherhood is to tell now her seatmate on the plane on which Ginny is flying home to visit her dying mother hands her a recipe for homemade Play Doh as if it were all that were missing in her life. As the plane approaches her hometown of Hullsport, Tenn., which from the air  looked like a case of terminal acne, Ginny recalls once having asked her mother why she bothered to go on living if she was not all that hog wild about her existence. As Ginny understood the lengthy explanation that ensued, her mother was saying that the human soul was like a green tomato that had to be ripened by the sun of earthly suffering before the gods would deign to pluck it for their cosmic clambake. It's clearly going to be any turn of phrase that gets a laugh with good old Ginny.

title: Screen: 'My Michael,' Gloomy Picture From Israel
description: To call "My Michael" a modest film is to exaggerate. It is downright imperceptible.This Israeli import, which opened yesterday at the Festival Theater, is made with seriousness and some skill. Its depiction of a shut-in, obsessed marriage is a vehicle for exploring a fenced-in, surrounded quality in Israeli society. But we are more aware of the vehicle's own airlessness and monotony than of the landscape it is trying to take us through.Based on the novel by Amos Oz, "Michael" is the story of Hanna, a young teacher who marries an archeology student in Jerusalem. The marriage is impetuous; neither has any money, and they move into a cramped apartment.It is more than the apartment that is cramped, however. They are nice, educated young people; full of tolerance and good will. But life closes in on their marriage. She has a baby, he has to go on with his studies; time and space seem to dry up on them.It is an arid, reasonable marriage. Michael, the husband, escapes into stolidity and a flirtation with a fellow student. Hanna fantasizes about being ravished and carried away. Not by pirates or airline pilots, butthis being Israelby Arabs"What are we living for?" she asks her husband at one desperate moment before she drifts utterly away. "People don't live for anything: they just live," he replies.Now all this could be a wry accusation that Israeli society lives amid Arabs while it avoids all psychological contact with them. The formal message is that such a posture has to be paid for by a loss of reality, by a drying-up of life. As a child, Hanna had two Arab children as her best friends; as an adult she dreams about naked bodies, black mustaches andto pin down the nationality beyond doubtchecked keffiyehs floating out behind.So costumed, the imaginary sequences are ludicrous. But ludicrousness is not the problem with "My Michael." In fact, done as a slapstick comedy about an Israeli housewife with Arab fantasies, it might have been not only funny but pointed as well.The problem is the film's deliberate attenuation; its deadpan development of married banality in a painfully banal style. Every possible soaper clich is brought out: the announcement that she's pregnant; his sulky mopping of the floor while she sits, sulky and distended; his efforts to study while the baby cries; his flirtation; her sexual teasing of a young boy.True, a number of these scenes are done with economy and charm. There is good acting, particularly from some of the older characters with small parts.The performance of the principals is less satisfying. As Michael, Oded Kotler is stolid, as the part requires, but not much else.Efrat Lavie, who plays Hanna, is more effective. But she plays her part from beginning to end with one fixed expression of gloom. Her gloom is a frail and pretty thing to see, but after a while, in its fixity, it makes the whole movie look underexposed.

title: Theater: Clever Revue
description: Shirley Kaplan and the young actors in her Painter's Theater have no fear of flying or of falling. In Mnss Kaplan's new theater piece, In Praise of Falling, expulsion from Eden is not seen as original sin but as something informational and educationalan opening up of life. There is a decidedly upbeat quality about this little musical revue.

title: U. S. STAYS CALM ON DROP IN FRANC

description: SEATTLE, March 15 (UPI)Dr. Dixy Lee Ray, former; Atomic Energy Commission chairman, annouced today she would seek the Democratic nomination for Govunor ofl Washington.

title: Steel Production Shows Rise of 2.8% In the Latest Week

title: On Rainy Days, an Alphabet Soup

The plus is initials, names or easily identifiable patterns somewhere between the spokes. The initials, or names, or what have you, have nothing to do with the men or women carrying the umbrellas. They are an extension of socalled status, happily supplied by designers and business firms, and lapped up by eager consumers.

title: Jersey Horsemen's Boycott Ends

J., March 15An eighthour horsemen's boycott of Garden State Park ended today when the track agreed to make up $266,000 in retroactive pages for the first 24 days of the meeting. The track also promised to eventually reimburse the state division of the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association for $4,300 in administrative expenses from 1975 in compliance with the old parimutuel law.

Goulding, with annual sales of $60 million, has been engaged in the manufacJure and marketing of fertilizers in Ireland for more than 100 years.

It is by the presence of persons and things that we believe we recognize certainty. And though we may not like it, at least we live with this necessity.

description: Concluding that attempts by trail judges to restrain reporters from covering criminal proceedings constitute a growing threat to freedom of the press, a group of lawyers, journalists and judges proposed yesterday legislation that would strictly regulate the manner in which state court judges could issue restrictive orders against the Under the proposal, made by the Twentieth Century Fund's Task Force on Justice, Publicity and the First Amendment, the highest court in each state would be required to establish a committee that would draft standing order, or mandatory guidelines, to be followed by courts in attempting to avoid prejudicial publicity.

title: Red Smith
description: Carol Mann and Jan Stephenson had posed for pictures patting putts across the floor of the First Women's Bank of New York. Miss Mann is a golfer who earns more money swatting a sitting ball than most outfielders do for hitting one in flight. Miss Stephenson hasn't reached that plateau yet, but she is heading that way. They were in New York to talk up the forthcoming ColgateDinah Shore Winners Circle championship, and they were in the bank because that's where the tournament's $200,000 prize money being held for delivery to the low scorers on the Mission Hills course in Palm Springs. Calif., April 1 to 4. That purse, with $32,000 for the winner, is not only the coarsest stack of loot ever offered in women's golf; it makes this the richest single sports event ever presented on the distaff side. Partly because $200,000 is eminently prestigious and partly because the field is limited by strict qualifying standards, this is being called the women's Masters, though members of the Gloria SteinemBetty Friedan persuasion would prefer Mistresses.

The police confirmed only that the robbery took place about 7:30 P.M. as the truck was returning to its headquarters after making collections at a number of stores.

title: Struggle for Currency Stability Growing
description: Harold Wilson's announcement that he will resign as Britain's Prime Minister as soon as the Labor Party picks his successor appears to some observers to have shattered what was left of peace on the European monetary front. But this interpretation looks far too pessimistic. It has been only four months since the cordial meeting at the Chteau de Rambouillet, in France, at which the capitalist worlds principal finance ministers agreed that they would act together for greater stability, not only of underlying economic and financial conditions but even of exchange rates.

A pianist played in the rear corner by a wide, brightly lighted scarlet curtain; next to him a seated colleague cradled a flat cimbalom. The third player was a strolling violinist.

In addition, what are sold as French Burgundy snails most likely come from Savoy these days.

For some these restorative stopovers may be bars, while others favor icecream parlors or pastry and coffee shops. But for many, including me, there are no stops titre soup stops.
