title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I want to draw your attention to a disturbing remark made by Alfred A. Giardino, chairman of the Board of Higher Education. In discussing payless furloughs, Mr. Giardino, in an open letter to the faculty dated March 3, allowed himself a claim which is both preposterous and alarming. I say this without prejudice to the overriding issue of whether, faced with the various choices forced on us, a payless furlough would or would not be the lesser evil. I do not say that it is or that it is necessary or even tolerable. I only say that even if it is, an assumption Giardino makes in connection with it is intolerable and would not be made by anyone who had the least understanding of higher education.

title: ROHATYN SCORED BY CONGRESSMEN
description: Two New York City Representatives attacked yesterday as inhuman the suggestion by Felix G. Rohatyn that blighted areas of the city be bulldozed and developed as industrial areas.

title: TV: Copland in Limelight on Two PBS Programs
description: One of the more prominent figures in public television's fundraising festival this Week is none other than Aaron Copland, the American composer. At the age of 75, Mr. Copland seems to have broken the massmedia celebrity barrier.

title: $1 Million Grant to Aid Unit Of Columbia Medical School
description: A grant of $1 million from the J. M. Foundation and Margaret Milbank Bogert to the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons was announced yesterday. The grant will underwrite the main teaching floor for the college's new healthservices center.

title: Smaller Rise Seen In Prices of Food
description: Further moderation in foodprice inflation is expected during this year by the economic research service of the Department of Agriculture. The reason is that larger food supplies are available, supplies that are large even taking into account indications that there will be some Increase in percapita food consumption.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in The New York Times Saturday incorrectly listed the amounts of trade credits and indemnifications West Germany is providing in exchange for emigration privileges for 120,000 Germans living in Poland. The agreement provides for a $400 million trade credit and a $500 million indemnification.

title: ChildCare Course: No Credits, but a Boon for the Students
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.,  If word gets out; this could be the most popular course at Hofstra Universitydancing, painting, snack and playing outdoors when the weather is good.

title: Governor Will Lead St. Patrick's Parade
description: Governor Carey as grand marshal will lead 120,000 marchers up Fifth Avenue starting at noon today for the 214th annual St. Patrick's Day Parade.

title: Boudreax Ring Victor.
description: Unbeaten Johnny Boudreaux of Houston won virtually every round on the cards pi all three officials in, posting a unanimous decision over Brian O'Meyia of Jersey City in a 10round heavyweight fight. at Sunnyside Garden in Queens last night. The 23yearold Boudreaux, 211 pounds, has won 18 bouts and drawn one in his pro career.

title: Sugar Futures Rise On Announcement Of Buying by Soviet
description: sugar futures attracted some speculators yesterday hoping for higher prices as an aftermath of the announcement of buying by the Soviet Union.

title: BARON ALBERT LILAR
description: BRUSSELS, March 16 (AP) Baron Albert Lilar, Minister of Justice in four Belgian Governments and an authority on maritime law, died today. He was 75 years old.

title: Soovill Manufacturing Sets $40 Million Loss Provision
description: WASHINGTON. March 16The Seovill Manufacturing Company Wined. a provision Of $40 million for the lose it may sustain in disposing of its metals and general products division. The loss, it said, appeared imminent.

title: 3dPlace Atlanta Straining To Betop Convention City
description: ATLANTA, March 12With a huge new convention center and three large and exotic new hotel complexes just opened, the Atlanta business community believes the city can now overtake Chicago and New York to become the nation's leading convention city.

title: HEALTH PROBLEMS TRACED TO JOBS
description: A Ford Foundation study of occupational safety and health concludes that the problem is more widespread than almost everyone had thought and that the Federal Government alone cannot handle it.

title: F.B.I. Guidelines
description: Attorney General Levi has issued a set of written guidelines designed to govern sensitive activities of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. In some areas, the guidelines represent a clear improvement over previous practice; in others, as Congressional critics have rushed to point out, they fail to provide sufficiently clear safeguards against some particularly disturbing F.B.I. abuses of the past. Their basic defect is that they do not have the force of law they are merely administrative regulations, subject to amendment or rescission at will by, the executive branch.

title: A Thick Ukrainian Borscht
description: While almost all of these soup kitchens sell their rich and heady brews on takeout basis, ambitious cooks who would like to make their own might want to try the following recipe from the Front Porch. The result is a soup almost thick enough to keep a spoon standing on end. While sour cream is not served with this at the Front Porch, it is a pleasant and luxurious addition, especially with a little minced fresh dill folded into It.

title: A UPI Employee in Beirut Is Abducted and Murdered
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 16 (Reuters)A 19yearold Lebanese teletype operator working for United Press International here was abducted near the news agency's office in the Hamra area last night and was later killed, the agency said today.

title: Stable or Lower Coal Cost Held Likely
description: WASHINGTON, March 16i The Government's pricemonitoring agency held out conditionally today the prospect of stable or possibly declining coal prices during the next 10 years together with a big increase in domestic production chiefly in the West.

title: Output of Industry Gained in February
description: WASHINGTON, March 16Industrial production rose again last month, housing starts showed a big gain and business has begun to accumulate inventories, Government reports disclosed today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Prime Minister Harold Wilson of Great Britain, the Labor Party's leader for 13 years, announced his resignation to take effect when the Labor members of the House of Commons have elected a successor. He cited his length of service and the. desire to give his successor time to establish his authority as Prime Minister before the next elections, in 1979 or sooner. The leading candidates appeared to be James Callaghan, the Foreign Secretary, and Denis Healey, Chancellor of the Exchequer. (Page 1. Columns 68.1

title: Allied Stores Net and Sales Hit Peak
Taking the Pulse Of Medical Field
description: An organization called Consumers Center for Health Information is being formed by two existing groups, Consumer Action Now and the Scientists Institute for Public Information.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Associated Press

title: N.F.L. Puts Off Further Expansion
description: CORONADO, Calif., March 16  Confronted by a new lawsuit filed today by present and former players in a class action that could cost millions of dollars in damages, owners of the National Football League's 28 clubs put aside any plans for expansion, but did set dates for delayed draft sessions and picked a site for the 1978 Super Bowl game.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: British Football Results
description: By Reuters

title: Harris's Campaign In State Collapses; Phone is Shut Off
description: The New York Democratic Presidential primary was reduced to an essentially threeway contest yesterday as Fred R. Harris's campaign in the state all but collapsed, with his delegates switching to other candidates. The New York Telepnone Company shut off service to his headquarters when deposit it demanded was not paid.

title: Usery Sees Wages in 76 Increasing by 8% to 9%
description: Secretary of Labor William J. Usery Jr. reiterated his belief here yesterday that wage increases negotiated this year under major labor contracts will average on the order of to 9 percent.

title: Castro And the Caribbean
description: WASHINGTON, March 16Fidel Castro's Cuban Government, according to high officials of the Ford Administration, has entered into an agreement to train the police forces of Jamaica, and is also increasing its political contacts with black revolutionary elements elsewhere in the Caribbean basin.

title: Trial Stirs Controversy, Over Expert Testimony
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 The pitched verbal battle between F. Lee Bailey, the defense attorney, and Dr. Joel Fort, the prosecution psychiatrist, at the trial of Patricia Hearst for bank robbery has raised again the controversy over the use of expert testimony in the courtroom.

title: Metreveli Loses at Net To Stone
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI)Allan Stone of Australia bested the Soviet ace, Alex Metreveli,76, 46, 75, in a World Championship Tennis match tonight while fourthseeded Harold Solomon was hard pressed to defeat Cliff Richey, 63, 36, 62.

title: Cyprus Charges a Leader;, Of 74 AntiMakarlos Coup
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 16 (Reuters) Nikos Giorgiades Sampson, a former guerrilla who was president of Cyprus for eight days after the 1974 coup that toppled Archbishop Makarlos, has been arrested and charged for his part in the military takeover.

title: Albany Adopts $10.78 Billion Budget
description: ALBANY, March 17  After a twoday marathon of partisan debate, the Legislature today finally adopted a $10.78 billion state budget for the fiscal year that begins April 1.

title: Patrick Day Rides 0 for 3 on March 17
description: Andre, the gambler, was explaining why he didn't go out to the track much these days.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Knicks Frazier Enters Hospital
description: Walt Frazier, captain of the Knicks, was admitted to Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday after having flown here from New Orleans, where the team played last night. Dr. James Nicholas, team physician, diagnosed Frazier's ailment as a lumbar strain and ordered that he be put in traction. He said the injury was not serious, but had been aggravated by activity.

title: Ethnic Survey of Schools Here For U. S. Will Start This Month
description: A detailed survey of the ethnic and language backgrounds of the city's 1.1 million pupils is scheduled to start here later this month as part of a continuing Federal civil rights investigation into possible discrimination in the city schools.

title: Jackson Fails in Effort to Strengthen Position With New York's Delegates
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson telephoned New York Democratic leaders last weekend in an unsuccessful 11 thhour effort to merge uncommitted delegate slates of the Democratic organization with his own slates, Jackson campaign aides and New York Democrats reported yesterday.

title: Buckley Bill Seeks To End Monopoly In Carrying of Mail
description: WASHINGTON, March 17Senator James L. Buckley, ConervativeRepublican of New Fork, introduced today a bill to allow private carriers to compete with the United States Postal Service in the delivery Of letters.

title: CounterEconomy
description: In terms of basic reform, the fruits of the state's long investigation into profiteering and mistreatment of the elderly in proprietary nursing homes have been pitifully meager in the name of economy, the State Legislature now seems bent on making them more meager still.

title: Administration Urges Cuts In Taxes to Spur Investors
description: WASHINGTON, March 17The Ford Administration proposed to Congress today a plan for encouraging investment in stocks and other property by lowering the taxes that might have to be paid on the proceeds of such investments.

title: Ford Rebuffs Jews OnC130's to Egypt
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 President Ford told a group of American Jewish leaders today that, despite their opposition and that of Israel, he was determined to proceed with plans to lift a military embargo against Egypt by selling the country six C130 military transport planes.

title: Henry Fonda Has Surgery
description: HOLLYWOOD, March 17 (Reuters)Henry Fonda underwent surgery today for removal of a tumor on his right lung. A family spokesman said that the growth was not malignant and that the 70yearold actor, who entered Cedars of Lebanon Hospital on Sunday, would remain there for at least another week.

title: City Club Prods a Silent Carey To Extend the Term of Nadjari
description: Governor Carey has not responded to a request by the City Club, one of the city's leading nonpartisan civic organizations, to discuss extending the term of Maurice H. Nadjari, which is supposed to end June 30.

title: Cosgrave Asks Halting of Aid From U.S. to Irish Extremists
description: WASHINGTON, March 17Prime Minister Liam Cosgrave of the Irish Republic, in a St. Patrick's Day speech to a joint session of Congress, called today in the strongest possible terms for the halting of aid by Americans to extremist groups in the troubled island.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Ford Is Expected to Name Morton as Campaign Chief
description: WASHINGTON, March 17President Ford will soon name Rogers C. B. Morton, now political counsel in the White House, as the new chairman of his campaign committee, sources said tonight.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world told prices Wednesday. London: Morning fixing $133.25, up $0.75; afternoon fixing 5133.3$, up $0.85.

title: N. C. A. A. Regional Semifinals Tonight
description: Lady Luck, who strongly supported Rutgers, Connectiput, Notre Dame and Michigan in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament last Saturday, must forsake two of the teams tonight.

title: Spirit of 76 on Display Now in Morristown
description: MORRISTOWN, March 17 The Spirit of 76, along with other original works from the Wellington Collection, wilt be on display tomorrow through April 10 at the Morris Museum.

title: Hunt for Cancer Causes Urged
description: TRENTON, March 17The State Legislature was asked today to vote $2.3 million for a program designed to find out why New Jersey led the nation in deaths from cancer.

title: Amex and OTC Show Price Rises As Volume Climbs
description: Reports on Tuesday of improving business inventories and housing starts helped prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market post gains yesterday in more active trading.

title: Chamber Reverses Earlier Rejection After Learning of Importance to British
description: WASHINGTON, March 17After a debate marked by laughter and solemn appeals, the House reversed itself today and approved sending a 25member Congressional delegation to London to receive an original copy of Magna Carta for Bicentennial display here.

title: UDALL WILL FIELD, SLATE IN JERSEY
description: Liberal Coalition to Back Him in Delegate Battle

title: Women Writers or Just Writers?
description: The lightning rod at a symposium of women writers, which drew a warm and lively audience out of the pelting rain to Lincoln Center, was undeniably Cynthia Ozick.

title: Poll Finds Carter Strength In Doubt Despite Plurality
description: Although a survey of voters in the Illinois primary Tuesday shows that former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia won a remarkably solid victory among almost all types of voters, the findings left some doubt about how well he would have fared had he faced sterner competition.

title: 'RAG N ROLL REVUE' PLAYS AT TRAMP'S
description: A heritage of Arkansas nillbilly music, operatic training, a role in a road company of Hair and a fascination with jazz musicians have led Cathy Chamberlain to form a group that mixes an assortment of musical sources with wild abandon in her Rag n Roll Revue at Tramp's, 125 East 15th Street.

title: OPTOMETRY BOARD CHALLENGED IN SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, March 17Consumers Union filed suit today, challenging Pennsylvania's exclusion of laymen from the state board that regulates optometrists.

title: European Football
description: European Football

title: Knight Suspect Sentenced
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 17 (AP)Salvatore Soli, one of two men accused of murdering John Knight 3d, a newspaper heir, last Dec. 7, was sentenced yesterday to one and lonehalf to three years in prison on another charge, illegal possession of a firearm. Mr. Soli, 37 years old, was arrested Jan. 18, 1975, when his car hit a tree and an arresting policeman saw a 38caliber revolver on the floor of the car. Trial on the murder charge is pending.

title: 25 Workers Hurt as Gas Ignites In Washington Subway Tunnel
description: WASHINGTON, March 17An ignition of acetylene gas, used in welding, in a subway tunnel under construction 40 feet beneath a busy waterfront intersection injured 25 workmen here tonight, four of them seriously.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Highranking Washington officials said Soviet and American negotiators were close to completing a treaty setting limits on peaceful nuclear explosions. Duration of the treaty, magnitude of allowable explosions and the number of onsite inspections remain open but the United States hopes to complete the treaty by March 31. [Page 1, Column 7.]

title: Wallace Drive in Disarray; Aides Decide to Retrench
description: RALEIGH, N. C., March 17Bitterness and political disarray have replaced the atmosphere of cool confidence that once marked Gov. George'C. Wallace's campaign for the Democratic nomination for President.

title: 3 Arabs Are Wounded as Israeli Soldiers Fire on Crowd of Demonstrators Outside Jerusalem
description: TEL AVIV, March 17Three young Arab demonstrators suffered gunshot wounds today as Israeli soldiers opened fire to scatter rioters besieging an Israeli car outside Jerusalem.

title: Owners Final Offer Viewed As Incomplete but Negotiable
description: TAMPA, Fla. March 17The 17day shutdown of the baseball business ended tonight as the players softened their stand on the critical reserve issue and Commissioner Bowie Kuhn ordered the 24 teams to open the spring training camps.

title: Cup Skiers Find Winter's Back
description: BEAUPRE, Quebec, March 17Hank Tauber, the director of United States Alpine squad, had his skiers out this morning on Mont Ste. Anne, where the delayed World Cup competition starts News tomorrow. The first thing he of noted was the Skiing frigid surroundings., Looks like winter's returned, he said, as his squad rode a pomalift up the mountain in a snowstorm. Because we had mostly sunny skies for our racers last week in Colorado, I kind of forget winter's still with us.

title: Chinese Party Panel Reported investigating F auks of Rightists
description: PEKING, March 17(Agence FrancePresse)  The Chinese Communist Party's Central) Committee has set up a special commission to carry out an inquiry into the faults of the senior Deputy Prime Minister, Teng Hsiaoping and other rightist leaders, a wellinformed diplomatic source said here today.

title: JACK PALMER DEAD; WRITER OF SONGS. 75
description: Jack Palmer, a song writer who specialized in the pop and jazz genres, died yesterday in St. Mary's Hospital in Waterbury, Conn. He was 75 years old and lived in nearby Woodbury.

title: Stage: Cartoon General
description: NEW HAVEN  The title superhero of Michael McClure's new play, General Gorgeous, which has joined the spring repertory at the Yale Repertory Theater, lives in supersecret quarters and uses his superpowers to fight the forces of evil and to earn a niche in the League of Superheroes. He is the superhuman son of superparents. Almost everything is super about General Gorgeousexcept the play. Were it not for the credentials of the author, it could not punch its way out of the pulps.

title: ACCORD PROPOSED IN CARRENT CASE
description: The nation's three biggest carrental companies  the Hertz Corporation, Avis Rent a Car System and National Car System, Inc.said yesterday that they had worked out a proposed consent order with the Federal Trade Commission staff on charges that they had conspired to monopolize the car rental business at airports.

title: And Candidates Got a Chilly Reception
description: Jimmy Carter was chased out of two positions and had to improvise a marching unit of his own.

title: Wilson, in Resigning, Quotes a Conservative
description: LONDON, March 17Prime Minister Harold Wilson quoted a Conservative predecessor, Stanley Baldwin, in his resignation statement yesterday.

title: PLAYWRIGHTS UNIT PLANS TV PROJECT
description: The National Playwrights Conference of the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center will establish a drama for television project during its 1976 conference, which will be held in Waterford, Conn., from July 18 through Aug. 15. The program, developed by Lloyd Richards, conference artistic director, is being supported by grants from the National Endowment for the Arts and the Exxon Corporation. Scripts Will be accepted from former O'Neill playwrights, finalists in this year's National Playwrights Conference, and certain others. From these, four to six playwrights will be chosen to attend the 1976 playwrights conference to work with television plays. Material developed at the conference will be available to any interested television producer.

title: THREE FOUND GUILTY IN CONTRACT BRIBE
description: NEWARK, March 17 (UPI)A Federal District Court Jury tonight convicted three persons of offering a $3.3 million bribe to Neil Piro, Jersey City's director of housing, in exchange for $33 million in municipal construction contracts.

title: Wilson Bowing Out to Mixed Reviews
description: LONDON, March 17Haroldl Wilson was assessed today as a leader who transformed and unified the Labor Party, but failed to stem Britain's economic decline.

title: Administration Urges Cuts In Taxes to Spur Investors
description: WASHINGTON, March 17The Ford Administration proposed to Congress today a plan for encouraging investment in stocks and other property by lowering the taxes that might have to be paid on the proceeds of such investments.

title: Rubin Carter and Artis Get New Trial in Murder Case
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court unanimously ordered a new trial yesterday for Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis, who were convicted nine years ago of a triple murder in Paterson and were sentenced to life prison terms.

title: Life of the Party
description: WASHINGTON, March 17Most Democratic strategists, and most political analysts, wish Ronald Reagan would pull out of the race for the Republican nomination. They attribute this wish to most Republicans, who are supposed to see the Reagan campaignafter five defeatsas pointless.

title: Erving's 34 Pace Nets Over Spirits
description: ST. LOUIS, March 17 (AP)  Julius Erving scored 34 points and Bill Melchionni stabilized New York's floor play in the second half tonight in leading the Nets to a 9690 American Basketball Association triumph over the Spirits of St. Louis.

title: Sports Today
description: National Invitation Tournament, semifinal round, Kentucky vs. Providence and North Carolina State vs. North CarolinaCharlotte, at Madison Equare Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street. First game, 7 P.M.

title: Printer Shot by Gunmen Holding Up Union Offices
description: An unemployed printer looking for a day's work was shot and critically wounded yesterday morning when he walked in on a holdup at the headquarters of New York Typographical Union No. 6 at 817 Broadway.

title: Goldman Sachs Reports $25 Million in Net Income
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment banking house, disclosed here yesterday that its net income, before partners taxes, averaged well over $25 million a year for the last five years.

title: Paint Job and Cleanup Cost the City Nothing
description: The green line down the middle of Fifth Avenue for the St. Patrick's Day parade cost $700but the bill was paid by the parade committee. Parts of the green line that were washed away by rain and snow on Tuesday were repainted early yesterday.

title: FIEROIN USE RISING, U.S. OFFICIAL SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI) The nation's top drugabuse official has estimated that up to 400,000 persons use heroin on a daily basis in the United States.

title: $750 MILLION BUDGET FOR C.I.A. DISPUTEDI
description: WASHINGTON. March 17 (AP)In sworn testimony, William E. Colby, former director of Central Intelligence, disputed today thhe accuracy of the most widely accepted figure for the C.I.A.'s annual budget.

title: Mansfield Terms Carter A Formidable Contender
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI)The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, said today that Jimmy Carter is a very formidable contender for the Pregidential nomination, but he predicted that a brokered national convention would choose the nominee.

title: Mrs. Hearst Tells Jury Her Daughter Was a Loving Girl
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 17 Catherine Hearst, who described herself as an establishment person, testified as the last witness today in the trial of her daughter Patricia and called her a warm and loving girl.

title: Business Records
description: Wednesday, March 17, 1976

title: Music: American Range
description: If nothing else, this Bicentennial season is focusing attention on the prodigal variety of American music. The third of five programs in the Bicentennial Chamber Music Series, presented on Tuesday night, at Cainegie Recital Hall, ranged over a particularly wide spectrum, from a string trio by John Antes, the Moravian Church composer who died in 1811, to Louise Talma's Summer Sounds for Clarinet and String Quartet, a 1973 piece receiving its first New York performance.

title: Ending a Country Phase, Carter Courts Power Here
description: Jimmy Carter, no longer the unassuming country campaigner, toured New York bases of political and communications power yesterday as his drive for the Democratic Presidential nomintttion moved swiftly from the handshaking phase to the serious cultivation of farreaching institutional support.

title: Jackson Picks Up Wide Labo: Backing
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington unveiled yesterday a list of influential labor leaders supporting his effort to win the April 6 New York Presidential primary and predicted that labor would play the critical role, the vital role in his victory.

title: Rival Lebanese Deploy for Showdown; Syrians Seek a Solution Over Fran jieh
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 17 With Syria continuing to search for a formula to ease Lebanon's defiant President out of office, his military defenders and opponents sought today to strengthen their positions for a possible showdown.

title: Easter Recess Canceled
description: EASTCHESTER, N. Y., March 17 (UPI)Public school pupils here will lose their Easter vacation this year to make up work missed in a 21day teachers strike that ended earlier this month, the school superintendent announced today. The superintendent, Morgan Fellows, said the board had voted unanimously last night to eliminate the recess scheduled for April 19 to 23.

title: LISBON AIDE QUITS IN SPLIT ON AFRICA
description: LISBON, March 17Portugal's Secretary of State for Cooperation with the Former Colonies announced his resignation today with a sharp at tack on the Government's decolonization policy.

title: KE.C. DEPLORES FORDSTEEL STAND
description: President Ford's finding that imports were hurting United States producers of stainless and other specialty steels brought an expression of regret from the European Economic Community yesterday but pleased domestic steel Interests.

title: Contaminated Drugs Are Linked To 54 BloodPoisoning Deaths
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)Fiftyfour persons died of blood poisoning over the last 10 years after being administered contaminated intravenous drugs, the Geenral Accounting Office said today.

title: After 5 Years, Legal Fight Still Rages Over an Estate
description: Five years after the death of James Felt, a former City Planning Commissioner, the size of his estate is still in dispute.

title: Joseph C. Peters, Reporter, Wrote on Yugoslav Affairs
description: Joseph C. Peters, a retired foreign correspondent and writer on Yugoslav economic affairs, died yesterday at his home at 4554 41st Street, Long Island City, Queens. He was 76 years old.

title: INDIA CONFIRMS BAN ON PARTS FOR EGYPT
description: NEW DELHI, March 17 (AP) The Government acknowledged today that contractual Commitments with the Soviet Union had prevented India from supplying Egypt with spare parts for MIG21 jet fighters.

title: Head of Columbia Calls on V olunteers To Revivify the City
description: Dr. McGill made his plea in remarks for the 192d annual dinner of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick at the Americana Hotel.

title: ROCKWELL NAMES PENTAGON GUESTS
description: WASHINGTON., March 17Rockwell. International Inc a Majordefense contractor, infckttned Senator Proxmire, DeMocrat, of Wisconsin, today that it had entertained the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the director of the Defense Intelligence Agency at its hunting lodge on the Eastern Shore of Maryland.

title: Speed Skating Mark Set
description: MOSCOW, March 17 (UPI)  Andrei Malikov of the Soviet Union set a new world speed skating record today in the 1,000 meter sprint. Malikov was clocked in 1 minute 15.76 seconds. Another Soviet skater, Valery Muratov, held the old mark, 1:16.92.

title: Ocean City Votes 3 to 1 for Beach Fees
description: OCEAN CITY, March 17Ocean City continued a trend, of recent years yesterday by voting 3 to 1 to impose beach fees this summer.

title: Texas Airlines Shifting To Rives From Tracy
description: Texas International Airlines is moving its advertising business from TracyLocke Advertising, Dallas, to Rives, Dyke/ Y. & R., Houston. Billings are estimated at about $1.5

title: Rutgers Class of East Field
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., March 17They call this area Tobacco Road. But of the four teams that play tomorrow night in the Eastern Regional semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament only unbeaten Rutgers is a filtertipped, kingsized special; the others are strictly roll  your  own brands.

title: COURT PANEL SETS SENTENCING RULES
description: New sentencing procedures have been approved by the Second Circuit Judicial Council in a move to increase the openness, fairness and certainty of criminal sentences in the Federal courts of New York, Connecticut and Vermont.

title: Just in Time, as Fans Say They Are Ted Up
description: New York's baseball fans are disappointed, upset and even disgusted by the delay of spring training.

title: Realignment of Trail, Sparks Opposition
description: VERNON, March 17Over the years, state and Federal agencies have taken over almost 25 percent of Sussex County's 343,216 acres of rolling hills and woodlands for conservation and public recreation.

title: Paper Industry Recovery Raises Capacity Question
description: The chief economist for the American Paper Institute said yesterday that the paper industry had experienced such a very sharp recovery from last year's recession that by next year there may be a question about adequate capacity.

title: 2 NUCLEAR DEVICES SET OFF IN NEVADA
description: MERCURY, Nev., March 17 (AP)Two nuclear devices were detonated underground at the Nevada Test Site early today, causing a pair of earth tremors that were felt in Las Vegas. The first was set off at Pahute Mesa, 120 miles from Las Vegas, at 6:15 A.M. The second was detonated about 6:45 A.M. on Yucca Flat, 90 miles from the city.

title: Geologists Find Snow Rarely Fell in Ice Age
description: Contrary to longstanding assumptions, it apparently snowed very little at the height of the last ice age, 18,000 years ago.

title: The Most Thing Is, I Love to Fight
description: Anybody with five cars naturally needs a sixth. And so Joe Frazier has a Cadillac Seville on order.

title: Military to Shut 4 of Its Offices That Employ 1,300 in City Area
description: WASHINGTON, March 17The Defense Department announced plans today to close one Army and three Navy offides in the New York metropolitan area, with a resulting loss of 1,300 civilian jobs.

title: FORD AND CARTER AMASS DELEGATES IN ILLINOIS RACES
description: CHICAGO, March 17Jimmy Carter demonstrated surprising strength in the Illinois delegateselection primary yesterday, adding to the impact of his triumph in the preferential voting, late tabulations showed today.

title: The Hour Is Very Late, Udall Says, And He's the Only Viable Liberal Left
description: MADISON, Wis., March 17The conventional wisdom, the tall politician told several hundred people blocking a city street here today, is that Mo Udall is in trouble.

title: Notes on People
description: Samuel Bronfman 2d,the kidnapped victim whose father paid a $2.3 million ransom last year, and Melanie Mann, a fellow Williams College graduate with the class of 1975, will be married March 27 at the home of her parents, the Peter R. Manns, in Pacific Palisades, Calif. Mr. Bronfman, a Time Inc. business employee, is a son of Edgar M. Bronbnan,the Seagram liquor executive, and his former wife, Ann Loeb Bronfman.

title: Detente Politics
description: The reach for electioneering advantage has clearly gained the upper hand in foreign policy decisions toward the Soviet Unionor so it would seem from the Administration's decision to suspend three Cabinetlevel meetings with Soviet leaders on energy and economic affairs. This is a petty gesture, intended as a rebuke for any adventurism in southern Africa. If it has any meaning at all, it is only to inhibit one element of the dtente policy that is entirely desirable from the American (as well as the Russian) point of view.

title: Screen:Italian 'Scaramouche' at Showcase Theaters
description: It is the time of the French Revolution, more or less. A mob surges by and the camera shows faces in animated close-up. One face looks strained: the shot lengthens and we see it is being carried on a pike.Only a few minutes into "The Love and Times of Scaramouche" and we become that face. It is our brother in pain. This tedious, jumpy, inept effort to do still another comic take-off on historical swashbucklery is as bad as impalement.Scaramoucheno kin to Sabatini's dashing characteris a ropy womanizer who gets tangled up in a plot to assassinate Napoleon. There are battle scenes, bedroom scenes, pratfalls and uninterrupted clowning, all of it coarse and witless. The acting is abysmal; the photography suggests a bad case of air pollution.Ursula Andress is the best-known figure in this mostly Italian production. She is wooden, but still manages to look good when she takes her shirt off, and to make everything else look cheap."Scaramouche" is being shown at Showcase Theaters.

title: T.W.A., American Report Big Losses; Subsidy Is Denied
description: Trans World Airlines and American Airlines both reported yesterday huge deficits for February and the first two months of this year.

title: CASTRO CAUTIONS SOUTH AFRICANS
description: HAVANA, March 17 (Reuters) Prime Minister Fidel Castro has warned South Africa that continued occupation of Angolan territory around the Cunene dam could cause the war to flare up again and extend to neighboring SouthWest Africa, ilso called Namibia and even to South Africa itself.

title: U.S. SOVIET PACT ON ATOM USE NEAR
description: WASHINGTON, March 17Highranking Administration officials reported today that Soviet and American negotiators were nearing completion of a treaty setting limits on peaceful nuclear explosions.

title: Anaconda Gain Lifts Dow Index by 2.52
description: A sharp rise in the share price of the Anaconda Company accounted for yesterday's entire gain of 2.52 points in the Dow Jones industrial average as the stock market generally saw its sturdy afternoon advance wither by the closing bell.

title: The Sports Scoreboard
description: Basketball

title: ZVI ABBO
description: JERUSALEM, March 17 (AP) Zvi Abbo, former professor of Judaica studies at the State University of New York at Albany was killed in an automobile accident last'week. He was 46 years old and lived in Tel Aviv.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article In The New York Times yesterday dealing with the state's fiscal situation, part of a line was inadvertently dropped. The sentence should have stated that the adoption of a balanced budget brings to an end the last phase of the state's financial emergency that state officials have any way to control.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The March 5 Times editorial opposing the Black Lung Reform Bill based on an unfortunate misunderstanding of its purpose and content.

title: California Seeks to Protect Prime Farmland From Urban Use
description: LOS ANGELES, March 17There is enough land in California to give every person in the United States nearly half an acre. But California is taking steps to see that nothing of the sort happens.

title: Continental Oil Plan
description: Directors of the Continental Oil Company proposed yesterday a twoforone stock split subject to shareholder approval at the annual meeting in Wilimington on May 4 of an in in the authorized comimon shares to 120 million from 60 million.

title: Five Cabinet Members in Britain Enter the Race for Wilson's Post
description: LONDON, March 17Five senior Cabinet ministers today announced their candidacies to succeed Harold Wilson as Labor Party leader and as Britain's Prime Minister.

title: Fund Set for Landscaping President's Swimming Pool
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI)  The National Park Service has put more than $43,000 in a Treasury Department account to be used for beautifying the landscape adjoining President Ford's swimming pool, a Treasury spokesman said today.

title: Concert: Flashy Berlioz
description: Now that Andrt Previn has been engaged as music director of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, his arrival at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night for the first of three concerts there this week with the London Symphony Orchestra was of more than routine interest.

title: The Pop Life
description: Motown has a new record out called Original Versions, and it sets one to thinking. The disk itself consists of 12 songs as recorded by Motown that were subsequently recorded by others. The back of the jacket nicely lists who did the rerecording in each case.

title: Republicans Plan Convention
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo, March 17 (AP)Republican Party planners were back here today for three days of meetings on details for August's Presidential nominating convention at the Kemper Arena. There have been conflicting reports that the city, which contracted last year to host the convention, will not be able to provide the 15,775 rooms pledged.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standin
description: Basketball Standin

title: Taiwan F'Innninn to Buy 10 Million Tons of Grain
description: MEMPHIS, March 17 (AP)Taiwan pldns to buy 10.2 mil. Ilion tons of grain from the (United States in the next five years.

title: Curare Case Points Up Some Problems Doctors Face in Policing the Profession
description: The case of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, who was named yesterday as a New Jersey surgeon suspected of murdering patients at a hospital a decade ago, illustrates in a most unusual way the difficulties of doctors policing the medical profession. It was two doctors at the hospital in Oradell, N.J., whose suspicions originally brought Dr. Jascalevich's case before the Bergen County Prosecutor's office in 1966.

title: British Study Finds Warsaw Pact Adds To Edgeover NATO
description: LONDON, March 17  A Government white paper on defense published today said that in conventional ground and air forces the imbalance in Central Europe has moved further in the Warsaw Pact's favor.

title: Music: Harlem Benefit
description: Two legends met on the stage of Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday, Arthur Rubinstein and Dorothy Maynor bringing a moment of magic to the benefit evening for the Harlem School of the Arts. Miss Maynor the distinguished soprano who founded the school in 1963, and has overseen its growth into one of New York's prime cultural landmarks, was receiving a richly deserved award from Young Audiences in recognition of her incomparable achievement and cultural contributioll to the lives of our childfen.

title: Market Place
description: When to Sell Auto Stocks Some market observers would argue that the best time to sell particular stocks is when Wall Street is enthusiastic about them. If those observers are correct, then this may be the time to sell the auto stocks.

title: Rubin Carter and A rtis Get
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court unanimously ordered a new trial yesterday for Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis, who were convicted nine years ago of a triple murder in Paterson and were sentenced to life prison terms.

title: A New Era At Drydock In Bayonne
description: The big Navy drydock at Bayonne, idle for more than 16 years, took on its first job under civilian management yesterday.

title: U.S. IS IN QUANDARY ON NEW FLU VACCINE
description: ATLANTA, March 17 (UPI)Federal health officials are undecided about ordering the production of 200 million doses of vaccine to protect the nation against a possibly severe epidemic of influenza next fall.

title: Luchino Visconti, Film Director, 69, Dies
description: Luchino Visconti, the internationally known director of sumptuously detailed film melodramas, died yesterday in his Roman villa. He was 69 years old.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article in The New York Times yesterday dealing with the state's fiscal situation, part of a line was inadvertently dropped. The sentence should have stated that the adoption of a balanced budget brings to an end the last phase of the state's financial emergency that state officials have any way to control.

title: Yonkers Results
description: Yonkers Results

title: It Was a Brisk Day for the Irish Parading Up Fifth Ave.
description: The Irish and their friends marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday, parading with varying degrees of style and discomfort. Their flags were green, but their extremities were red, and the wind that whistled across Fifth Avenue sometimes drowned out the sounds of their pipe bands. Still, everyone said it was a very good St. Patrick's Day parade, and the happiest of all the paraders seemed be politicians.

title: Equalizing Education in New Jersey
description: TRENTONIn 1970, Kenneth Robinson, 7 years old, living in Jersey City, petitioned the courts to assure him an equal education.

title: SENATE BARS END TO CAMPAIGN AID
description: WASHINGTON, March 17The Senate defeated today a proposal to abolish Federal subsidies for Presidential candidates and conventions after the 1976 campaign is completed. The new system was first tested in this year's campaign

title: Governor of Utah to Retire
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 17 (AP)Calvin L. Winton, Governor of Utah for the last 12 years, announced today that he would not seek a fourth term. The 62.yearold Democrat said he intended to return to practicing law.

title: ROCKWELL NAMES PENTAGON GUESTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 17Rockwell International Inc., major defense contractor, informed Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, today that it had entertained the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the director of the Defense Intelligence Agency at its hunting lodge on the Eastern Shore of Maryland.

title: New Democratic Hopeful
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI)Reed Larson, a lifelong Republican, said today that he expected to enter the Democratic Presidential race to publicize his National Right to Work Committee. He said that the idea for his potential candidacy was to qualify for Federal matching campaign funds.

title: Lawyers in Case Won Major Victories Before
description: The legal victory yesterday by Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis marked the second time that their chief counsel had won lengthy major courtroom battles involving concealed evidence.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rate toil Wednesday.

title: STUDENTS IN CLASH WITH PARIS POLICE
description: PARIS, March 17After a week of increasing unrest among university students throughout France, violence erupted here today between police and several hundred students protesting changes in the educational system.

title: Late Vote Totals In Illinois Races
description: CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) Following are the latest vote totals in the Presidential and gubernatorial primary elections in Illinois yesterday, the convention delegates awarded as a result of that vote and the total number of delegate preference votes so far.

title: Business Briefs
description: Earnings of J. P. Morgan & Company before gains or losses on securities income in the first two months of this year ran somewhat lower than the monthly average for the first quarter of last year, Elimore C. Patterson, chairman, told the annual meeting yesterday.

title: Professor Says Alger Hiss Lied About His Links With Chambers
description: Allen Weinstein, the Smith College professor whose suit caused the release of 15,376 pages of Federal Bureau of Investigation files in the Alger Hiss case, says that Mr. Hiss has been lying about his relations with Whittaker Chambers for nearly 30 years.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of 2 million common shares of the Dayton Power and Light Company, at 177 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: FORD AND CARTER.AMASS DELEGATES: IN ILLINOIS RACES.
description: CHICAGO, March 17Jimmy Carter demonstrated surprising strength in the Illinois delegateselection primary yesterday, adding to the impact of hi triumph in the preferential voting, late tabulations showed today.

title: Records Reached For Imports of Oil For Second Week.
description: For the second consecutive week, imports of both crude and refined petroleum products set a record, the American Peltroleum Institute reported yesIterday.

title: BOOTHS IS GIVEN IMMUNITY BY DA,
description: The Manhattan District At torney's office has agreed to grant Christopher Boomii, the real estate developer, immunity from prosecution in return for his testimony before a grand jury, sources close to the investigation said yesterday.

title: TV: WNET Sketches Piaf in I Regret Nothing
description: In the early 196U's, at a small gathering in Manhattan, an Englishman, of the sort determined to be charmingly eccentric, announced that Edith Piaf had been seriously injured in still another car accident. He suggested that the group maintain several minutes of silence and think positive thoughts, which would doubtlessly be transmitted to the singer's hospital bed in France. Even this writer, who finds such things ridiculous, was impressed with the seeming fervor of the response. But then, as a college student, had occasionally stored up scarce pennies to see Piaf perform in expensive supper clubs.

title: CHINA AND SOVIET CLASH ON AFRICA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 17China accused the Soviet Union in the Security Council today of hatching new schemes in Southern Africa in the wake of its armed intervention in Angola.

title: Miss Hearst's Fears Insult Four Fugitives
description: BERKELEY, Calif., March 17 (UPI)A letter signed by four fugitives named by Patricia Hearst as potential threats to her safety says that her assertion is a calculated political insult.

title: Edward A. Harris, Winner Of Pulitzer for Reporting
description: FRONT ROYAL, Va., March 17 (AP)Edward A. Harris, former Pulitzer Prizewinning reporter for The St. Louis PostDispatch, died Sunday at a hospital here. He was 65 years old.

title: State Will Study Impact of Bus Strike
description: NEWARK, March 17Transportation Department officials met today with representatives of several state agencies and highway authorities to begin study of the impact of the strike against Transport of New Jersey, the state's largest bus company.

title: Bridge
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 17Two of the eight teams battling in the quarterfinal round of the Vanderbilt knockout team championship here this afternoon survived desperately close struggles in the early hours of this morning.

title: Italian Communists Consulted by Premier First Time Since 47
description: ROME, Thursday, March 18 (AP)With the Italian lira losing value rapidly, Prime Minister Aldo Moro granted a formal consultative role last night to the Communists in his emergency meetings with party, leaders on how to save the currency and the economy from collapse.

title: Westie, Best at Crufts, Rated Below U.S. Dogs
description: The West Highland white terrier; Dianthus Button, who was best of 9,818 dogs at the largest show Crufts ever has held, wouldn't even have placed in the terrier group at Westminster, News Edward Keenan of Green Village, of N. J., told the Dogs Dog Fanciers Club here last week. In my opinion, had he competed at Madison Square Garden, he would have been beaten by Dr. Alvaro Hunt's Ardenrun Andsome of Purston, who took the breed and went on to place second in the group.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Highranking Washington officials said Soviet and American negotiators were close to completing a treaty setting limits on peaceful nuclear explosions. Duration of the treaty, magnitude of allowable explosions and the number of onsite inspections remain open but the United States hopes to complete the treaty by March 31. [Page 1, Column 7.1

title: CPC Dividend Up 40
description: CPC international Inc., the world's largest corn refiner and maker of an extensive, line of branded consumer products, Increased the quarterly dividend yesterday to 57 cents a share from 53 cents. The increase, payable April 23 to holders of record March 31, is the fourth increase in the last 27 months.

title: Head of Columbia Calls on Volunteers To Revivify the City
description: The president of Columbia University, Dr. William J. McGill, appealed to New Yorkers last night to become volunteers to help rebuild the strength of our city.

title: Spain's Opposition Acts To Form United Front
description: MADRID, March 17, (Reuters)Spain's opposition parties announced tonight they had formed a united front to work for free general elections and tradeunion and political liberties.

description: Horses listed In nreer of Post positions Letter deslonetes OTB Iisting

title: U. S.SOVIET PACT ON ATOM USE NEAR
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 Highranking Administration officials reported today that Soviet and American negotiators were nearing completion of a treaty setting limits on peaceful nuclear explosions.

title: Airlines Plan to Start Concorde Service to Washington in May
description: British Airways and Air France announced plans yesterday to start Concorde service to Washington on May 24, and they also filed suit here to overturn the ban on flights to New York.

title: CORN FUTURES UP, ENDING WEAKNESS
description: After five sessions of weak prices, corn futures rallied yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The March delivery closed at $2.65, up from $2.61 a bushel.

title: Music
description: THE BERGERFOLK FOLK MUSIC, children's concert, 2:30 P.M. Saturday, at the Heckscher Oval, Lincoln Center, Library & Museum of the Performing Arts, Ill Amsterdam Avenue. Free; for reservations call 799.2200. TOM GLAZER'S PROGRAM OF SONGS, 2:30 P.M, Saturday, at the McMillin Theater, Columbia University, 116th Street and Broadway. Tickets, 51.50. 6639263.

title: SUSLOV DENOUNCES INDEPENDENT REDS
description: MOSCOW, March 17 (AP)The Soviet Communist Party's chief theoretician, clearly aiming his words at independentminded Communists in the West, denounced dissidents to day in Moscow's sharpest attack yet on those who threaten the purity of MarxismLeninism. Mikhail A. Suslov, in a major ideological address to the Soviet Academy of Sciences, branded as enemies of Marxism those who interpret Communist dogma in their own fashion, slander real socialism, try to wash out the revolutionary essence of MarxistLeninist teaching and to substitute bourgeois liberalism for Marxism.

title: A Sign of Spring
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn ordered yesterday that the 24 major league baseball clubs open their spring training camps as soon as possible. Details on Page 53.

title: MEDICAID CURBS VOTED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, March 17In a major attempt to hold down the rising costs of its socialservices budget, the Legislature approved a complex bill today introducing radical changes in the way the state ran its Medicaid program.

title: The Day Weeds Grew on U.S.
description: What if someone put one out of every six people on the street out of work? What if 14.7 million people were thrown into the ranks of the unemployed?

title: Books of The Times
description: Should the United States do anything about inequities between its rich and its poor? Should we attempt to solve this problem by means of more economic planning? Sometimes you have to wonder if Mel people who ought to know the answers to such questions1 mean, of course, the economistsaren't simply creating confusion. Take Robert L. Heilbroner, the author of Business Civilization in Decline, and Robert Lekachman, whose latest book is Economists at Bay. Both are reputable.

title: People and Business
description: Earl L. Butz waned yesterday that the farmer's alnlity to produce incresing load supplies would he crippled if current trends toward Government reguation of farm chemicals, drugs, environmental controls and safety devices cominued.

title: John Reeves, Industrialist, Dead; Began Textile Employee Benefits
description: John M. Reeves, cofounder of Reeves Brothers Inc., a textile industry concern, died Tuesday at his home in Pinehurst, N. C. He was 88 years old.

title: A Sign of Spring
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn ordered yesterday that the 24 major league baseball clubs open their spring training camps as soon as possible. Details on Page 53.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HEDY STUFFCasbali, the newest Middle Eastern entry on the Manhattan night scene (which has about 12 of note), is a modest but exotic showcase that hears watching. Opened three weeks ago, the club needs a little better organization in its entertainment, featuring NA exuberant woman singer and a lively quartet of instrumentalists every Friday and Saturday from, loosely, 9 P.M. to 4 A.M.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The state police announced that they were planning roundtheclock coverage for all of its rural facilities. Col. Clinton L. Pagano, Superintendent of the Division of State Police, said that by April 24 his organization would complete a transition from the traditional assignment system barracks to one involving rotating shifts and hourly work periods. He noted that an assignment system based on patrol shifts had been the rule on the New Jersey Turnpike since 1951 and on the Garden State Parkway since 1954.

title: Envoy to Ecuador Quits
description: WASHINGTON. March 17 (Reuters)President Ford accepted the resignation today of Robert Brewster as Ambassador to Ecuador, He was appointed to his post in July 1973.

title: Pillsbury's Quarter Profit Up by 22.8%
description: The Pillsbury Company, which derives the bulk of its earnings from the Burger King fastfood restaurants, reported yesterday profit increases of 22.8 percent for the third, fiscal quarter and 23 percent for the nine months ended Feb. 29.

title: INCOME TAX GAINS SUPPORT IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, March 17Two State Senators who voted against a state income tax last summer and one who was absent for the vote indicated today that they would support the income tax measure passed by the Assembly early yesterday. Several other former opponents also seemed to be easing their stand.

title: Mrs. Hearst Tells Court of Daughter
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 17 Catherine Hearst, who described herself as an establishment person, testified as the last witness today in the trial of her daughter Patricia and called her a warm and loving girl.

title: Chrysler Recalls Trucks
description: DETROIT, March 17 (AP)The Chrysler Corporation is recalling 2,450 lightduty trucks, equipped to work as snowplows, to correct a potential defect that could allow plow blades to fall from a raised position, the concern announced today. Chrysler said the recall campaign affected 1975 and 1976 Plymouth and Dodge trucks. The auto maker said its dealers would reinforce plow lift frames at no cost to customers.

title: Trial of Security National Bank Told It Knew Gifts Were Illegal
description: A Democratic Town councilman from Huntington, L.I., testified yesterday that he had participated in a political contribution system at the Security National Bank while he was both an elected official and a bank officer.

title: Origami and Other Fun for Children
description: The Japanese art of paperfolding, origami, isn't as foreign as it sounds. Most children are already familiar with its techniques they make paper airplanes. But it's Lillian Oppenheimer's goal to take them beyond paper airplanes to paper baskets and to fish that have moving mouths and to lovely swans.

title: Poll Finds Carter Strength In Doubt Despite Plurality
description: Although a survey of voters in the Illinois primary Tuesday shows that former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia won a remarkably solid victory among almost all types of voters, the findings left some doubt about how well he would have fared had he faced sterner competition.

title: House Unit Votes a Bill To Stiff en Grain Checks
description: WASHINGTON, March 17The House Agriculture Committee voted final approval today of a bill designed to guard against further corruption in the nation's graininspection system. The vote was 32 to 5.

title: Chess
description: Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, led the Louis D. Statham mastersplus tournament in Lone Pine, Calif., after six rounds of play. Re had scored five points and held a halfpoint edge over another former world champion, Vasily Smyslov, also of the Soviet Union, John Grefe, an international master of Berkeley, Calif., Grandmaster Oscar Panno of Argentina and Larry Christiansen, master of Riverside, Calif., all tied for second place.

title: MEDICAID CURBS VOTED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, March 17In a major attempt to hold down the rising costs of its socialservices budget, the Legislature approved a complex bill today introducing radical changes in operating the state Medicaid program.

title: Charter Committee Weighs End of 2 Planning Boards
description: Two community planning boards, both in Manhattan business districts, would be eliminated under a plan being weighed by the city's Charter Implementation Committee, ofIficials said yesterday.

title: Contract Awards
description: The General Dynamics Corporation's Convair division has been chosen by the Navy as prime contractor for development of the sealaunched Tomahawk cruise missile. The $34.8 million contract is for complete Integration of subsystems into prototype missile.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Council for Namibia3 P.M.

title: Ford Rebuffs Jews On C 130's to Egypt
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 President Ford told a group of American Jewish leaders today that, despite their opposition and that of Israel, he was determined to proceed with plans to lift a military embargo against Egypt by selling the country six C130 military transport planes.

title: JUDGE CURBS ARMY ON OVERSEAS TAPS
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)A Federal judged ruled today that the Army must obtain court warrants before it can place wiretaps on United States civilians abroad.

title: Island Gets Temporary Light
description: FAULKNER ISLAND, Conn., FAULKNER ISLAND, Conn., March 17 (UPI)A temporary light was in operation last night on Faulkner Island as officials Investigated the cause of a fire that destroyed the Coast Guard's 94foottall lighthouse. A spokesman said engineers rigged a light 17 feet atop a shack that will beam about half of the 15 nautical miles of light generated from atop the tower that overlooks Long Island Sound.

title: Regan Scores Stock Rules He Sees Favoring Banks
description: Rules described as favoring banks over brokerage houses in the handling of stockmarket orders were assailed here yesterday by Donald T. Regan, chairman of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., the world's largest brokerage firm.

title: Briton Looks to U.S.
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 17The chairman of a British group opposed to operations of the Concorde at Heathrow Airport outside London said here today that we look to you to fight our battle against the supersonic jet.

title: BURNS IS HOPEFUL ON STATE'S CREDIT
description: WASHINGTON, March 17Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and other Federal financial officials said today that New York Stgte obligations would be regarded as acceptable investments if the state put its financial house in order.

title: School Aid Travesty
description: In the process of restoring to the schools the state aid that Governor Carey had previously cut out of his budget, the Legislature managed to adopt a pattern allocations which guarantees a minimum return for the investment of scarce tax dollars.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: NEW YORK  Johnny Boudreaux, 211 pounds, Houston, outpointed Brian O'Melia, 203, Jersey City, 10 rounds.

title: Kenya's Flying Doctors Make Rural Calls
description: LODWAR, Kenya, March 11The doctors small plane flew over the dusty expanse where families of Turkana tribesmen could be seen squatting in patches of rare shade guarding their herds of scraggly goats. Here and there camels munched on the leaves of strangely green trees sprouting on the banks of dry rivers.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Beginning Monday, the Transit Authority will provide two new bus services that will take commuters from Grand Central Terminal and the Port Authority Bus Terminal to the Avenue of the Americas as far north as Central Park South.

title: Gov. Grasso Rebuffed on Budget; Legislature Balks at Fund Shift
description: HARTFORD, March 17The Democratic majorities in both houses of Connecticut's General Assembly today rejected Gov. Ella T. Grasso's proposal to balance the budget by absorbing a veterans fund into lit.

title: ExP.O.W. to Take Charge of Navy Recruiting Here
description: A Navy pilot whose photograph bowing in a North Vietnamese prison camp was widely circulated is to take command Saturday of naval recruiting in New York City and its suburbs.

title: MADRID AVOIDING APOLITICAL CRISIS
description: MADRID, March 17A seriesi of informal meetings among ministers appeared today to have resolved for the moment an incipient political crisis stemming from economic and labor troubles.

title: Rangers Top North Stars,31
description: What seemed like the continuation of the Fifth Avenue St. Patrick's Day parade turned out to be a game between two of the National Hockey League's most disappointing teams last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: In Memoriam
description: JOSEPHJudoe Samuel J. In cherished mem or of me beloved wonderful huineed.

title: Detente and Angola: Soviet Sees Western Hands Tied in Africa
description: MOSCOW, March 17Despite Washington's dispasure anounced this week in postponing several bilateral meetings, the Soviet Union seems determined to keep treating dtente with the United States as only one element of a more complex foreign policy. The relaxation of EastWest tensions was endorsed anew at the recent 25th Soviet Communist Party Congress as a commendable means to an end, but not the end in itself, as some in the West presumed. The distinction has been made clearer as other Soviet strategies have unfolded.

title: Civil Service Association Bars Merger With Unionl
description: Delegates attending the Civil Service Employees Association's annual convention in Kiamesha Lake, N.Y., voted overwhelmingly Tuesday to reject discussions of a merger wit hthe American Federation of State, County and Municipal Fmninvees. A.F.L.C.I.O.

title: 4LEXANDER LILLEY, EXHEAD OF CALTEX
description: Alexander N. Lilley, who retired six years ago as chairman of the Caltex Petroleum Corporation, died yesterday in Gulfstream, Fla. He was 70 years old.

title: A.T. & T. Profit Up 20.6% As Revenues Rise by 14.8%
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported here yesterday that its profits for the three months ended Feb. 29 rose to $831.2 million,1 or $1.31 a share, a 20.6 percent increase over the $689.2 million, or $1.13 a share, reported for the corresponding period a year ago.

title: Not Above The Law
description: WASHINGTON, March 17Fifty years Igo Attorney General Harlan F. Stone said the Bureau of Investigation, as the F.B.I. was then called, is not concerned with political or other opinions of individuals. It is concerned only with their conduct, and then only with such conduct as is forbidden by the laws of the United States.

title: Films
description: THE MYSTERY OF THE WAX MUSEUM, (1933; 75 minutes), noon Saturday and Sunday, at Films for Young People, Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street. Museum admission, 75 cents for children, 82 for adults, includes movies. 9567078.

title: PERSONAL INCOME UP FOR 7TH MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)Payment of special tax credits to lowincome families and a speedup in certain veterans benefits contributed to the seventh consecutive monthly increase in Americans personal income in February, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Events Today
description: LADY FROM THE SEA, by Henrik Ibsen, translated by Michael Meyer. Directed by Tony Richardson; slarring Vanessa Redgrave, Pat tlingle, and John Heffernan. At the Circle in the Square Theater, 50th Street, west of Broanwav, at 6:30.

title: Ski Project Dispute Began Six Years Ago
description: CRESTED BUTTE, Colo., March 17Howard H. Callaway's sudden suspension last Saturday as head of President Ford's campaign came over a controversy that began here six years ago, when he bought a mountain in Colorado.

title: Wallace Drive in Disarray; Aides Decide to Retrench
description: RALEIGH, N. C., March 17Bitterness and political disarray have replaced the atmosphere of cool confidence that once marked Gov. George C. Wallace's campaign for the Democratic nomination for President.

title: ARCO IMPLEMENTS ANACONDA OFFER
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, a widely diversified petroleum concern, announced its plan to purchase 6 million shares of 27 percent of the Anaconda Company, the giant Merger copper producer, News at $27 a share for a total outlay ofl $162 millidn, will, go into effect today. Anaconda closed yesterday at 26, up 4 for the day on a volume of 369,700 shares.

title: Daley and the Irish Agree: It's Great to Be a Winner
description: CHICAGO. March 17Michael J. Howlett, the new Democratic nominee for the governorship of Illinois, and Mayor Richard J. Daley, his mentor and patron, joined thousands of their closest friends in the Chicago Loop today to prove that winning was everything it was cracked up to be.

title: 4 years Hope To Topple Wolf pack
description: No matter what happens to the University of North Carolina at Charlotte in the semifinals of the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden tonight it has overcome its national identity crisis. So has Cedric Maxwell, the 4 years 6foot8inch center.

title: Liberals Vote to Keep Thorpe as Party Chief
description: LONDON, March 17 (Reuters)  The leader of Britain's Liberal Party Jeremy Thorpe, who has been under strong pressure to resign, will keep his post  at least for the moment.

title: School Sports Backers Near Giving Up
description: A memorandum yesterday from School Chancellor Irving Anker to the Board of Education forbidding commercialism In outside fundraising procedures has all but closed operations of the Save Our Sports Committee.

title: Restoration Comedy
description: Although some observers have dubbed it a restoration comedy, there's nothing funny about the legislative reshuffle of Governor Carey's $10 billionplus austerity budget.

title: Rosensaft Art Sale Brings Record Price for a Gauguin
description: A record price of $1.4 million for a painting by Paul Gauguin, Still Life With Japanese Woodcut, was set last night at a Sotheby Parke Bernet auction of works from the collection of the late Josef Rosensaft. The price, $200,000 higher than the highest estimate expected for the work, is the second highest on auction record for work of the Impressionist or postImpressionist period.

title: Lira Drops Again; Bank Rate Raised
description: BRUSSELS, March 17 (UPI)Reflecting the third consecutive day of upheaval for almost all major European currencies, the French franc, the Belgian franc and the Italian lira came under pressure, with speculators predicting that the strong German mark would soon be revalued upward.

title: N.F.L. Revises Format For Pregame Coin Toss
description: CORONADO, Calif., March 17 (UPI)National Football League owners today made only two minor modifications in the rulesmoving up the pregame coin toss to three minutes before kickoff and banning the striped football. They tabled a proposal to widen the field.

title: There They Are in Aaron Burr's House in SoHo Dreaming
description: The small cardboard house sits on a table in Anna Thornhill's living room, looking rather like the model in the set of Edward Albee's Tiny Alice. There's even a cutout Tiny Anna living inside. My husband put it there, Miss Thornhill said, lifting off the roof to show an interior of levels, rather than walled rooms. At the top, she points out, there will be a glass roof someday and a garden with a fountain and trees, between the bedroom and a Japanese bathroom.

title: Careless Reporting By Banks Charged

description: NEW ORLEANS, March 17 (AP)The New York Knicks capitalized on a coldshooting third quarter by New Orleans tonight and defeated the Jazz, 112107, in a National Basketball Association game.

title: CONGRESS IN ACCORD ON A FISHING LIMIT
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)Senate and House conferees agreed today on legislation to establish a 200mile limit for United States fishery jurisdiction, effective March 1, 1977.

title: Recital: Hiroko Yajima
description: Hiroko Yajima, a violinist who gave a recital under Young Concert Artists auspices at the Hunter College Playhouse on Tuesday night, must feel the place is cursed. In the slow movement of the SaintSavns Sonata No. 1 (Op. 75), some students wandered into a nearby shop and began clumping and banging about. Then, during Allesandro Rolla's Duo in D minor for violin and viola, the peeling ceiling took it upon itself to shed big chips of paint on Miss Yajima as she played away, unpertubed.

title: 'Scar of Shame,' a Pioneer Black Film, at Whitney
description: "Scar of Shame," which opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is the first program in the museum's two-part series devoted to the early black American cinemafilms made in the silent and early sound eras, by black film makers as well as white, for black audiences, that otherwise saw themselves portrayed in movies only as servants or buffoons.Produced in 1927 by the Colored Players Film Corporation of Philadelphia, "Scar of Shame" is a fascinating footnote to the story of black aspirations in this country. Though produced on a limited budget, it is technically no better or worse than hundreds of conventional "white" silents of the period. As history, however, it is a devastating reminder of the obstacles that black Americans had to overcome before they could begin to identify the goals of social progress.A little card at the beginning of "Scar of Shame" promises that the theme of the film will be the effects of environment, how "the childhood training" and "the companions" of one's youth determine whether or not one spends his "useful time on this earth" in pursuit of "the higher things in life." All this sounds harmless enough, but the film that follows demonstrates a system of contradictions that have only recentlyin the last 30 yearsbeen hooted and jeered into oblivion."Scar of Shame" is the story of a poor, beautiful slavey named Louise who is saved from her wicked step-father when a rich young concert pianist, Alvin Hillyard, marries her. A few months later Louise learns that Alvin has never told his socialite mother of his marriage, and Alvin, who is meant to be a sympathetic character most of the time, explains, "caste is one of the things mother is very determined about, and you don't belong in our set."In a fight with a gangster, Alvin accidentally shoots Louise in such fashion that, according to a newspaper account, it "left a hideous scar on her neck which completely marred her beauty." Alvin is sent to jail. Louise takes up the life of a night-club hostess, wearing a scarf to hide her hideous scar, which could easily be covered by a small Band-Aid. Alvin escapes, falls in love with a girl of his set, and Louise, distraught because she still loves him, commits suicide, paving the way for Alvin's future happiness.It's necessary to go into the plot in this detail to appreciate the odd things the film is doing as it attempts to meet the fantasy needs of its black audiences while providing them with uplift.The black caste system we see is simply an extention of the white bourgeoisie's: white is perfect, light-skinned is acceptable, black is ugly. The values and the manners, "the higher things in life," have been borrowed from white society with no questions asked. Louise's sin is not that she does anything wrong, or that she had evil companions in her childhood, but that she wasn't a member of Alvin's set.Poor Louise simply didn't measure up. Which is something that ghetto audiences of the time apparently understood and accepted. Militant blacks have subsequently expressed outrage at this sort of nonsense, but that may be to overlook some of the positive effects of such films. Among other things, they portrayed a black society that was educated, had its own lawyers, doctors, intellectuals and artists. At a time when Hollywood was still getting laughs out of the amount of fried chicken eaten by little Farina in the Our Gang comedies, these fantasies and distortions were comparatively healthy ones.

title: Crime Figure's Plea Fails
description: BOSTON, March 17 (AP)1 An appeal by Raymond L. S. Patriarca, reputed new England crime head, to have a murder conspiracy conviction cleared from his record has been denied by the United States Court of Appeals here. The court, in a ruling handed down yesterday, upheld the decision of Judge Raymond J. Pettine of Federal. District Court in Providence to let stand Mr. Patriarca's conviction in a state court in 1968.

description: Here are the significant dates and actions in the baseball dispute that has delayed spring training.

description: CLINTON, N.J., March 17I only know that I am still in the penitentiary, Rubin (Hurricane) Carter was saying. I only know that the moment you walk out of here and return to your home I will remain here.

description: WASHINGTON, March 17Howard H. Callaway, who stepped down last week as President Ford's campaign manager, has obtained special exemptions from the Civil Aeronautics Board over the last seven years to bring skiers to his Crested Butte, Colo resort on special cutrate charter flights, according to the newsletter Airline Reports.

title: State Takes Crow Under Wing, Adding It to Protected Species
description: ALBANY, March 17Crows became a protected species in New York State yesterday. A food seller or restaurateur cannot call nonkosher food Jewish style unless it is also marked nonkosher. And City Court Judge Harold Lieberman of Hudson can live outside the city and still keep his job.

title: Army Tests Two Tanks as Rivals to a German Entry
description: Since last month, the two heaviest, fastest, bestarmed tanks ever built in the United States have been pounding across the 69,000 acres of the Aberdeen Proving Ground in Maryland competing for selection as the Army's new main battle tank.

title: Training Slated to Start Today
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn, intent on salvaging the start of the baseball season, ordered major league club owners last night to open spring training camps at the earliest possible time.

description: Stephen P. J. Benoric, a saxophonist and clarinetist with leading dance hands beginning in the Dig Band era of the late 1930's and 40's, died yesterday in a hospital in North Tarrytown, N. Y. He was 03 years old and lived in Ossining, N. Y.

title: G.O.P. Halts Democratic Trend In Westchester Village Elections
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 17Voters halted a Democratic trend in Westchester County village elections yesterday prompting hope among local Republican leaders in wider contests this fall.

title: It Was a Brisk bay for the Irish Parading Up Fifth Ave.
description: The Irish and their friends marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday, parading with varying degrees of style and discomfort. Their flags were green, but their extremities were red, and the wind that whistled across Fifth Avenue sometimes drowned out the sounds of their pipe bands. Still, everyone said it was a very good St. Patrick's Day parade, and the happiest of all the paraders seemed.to be politicians.

title: Zalmen, Wieser s Parable of Silence
description: In 1965 on the eve of Yom Kippur, the writer Elie Wiesel found himself in a synagogue in the Soviet Union. The temple was crowded, and it was stifling hot. Suddenly, Mr. Wiesel found himself convinced that the old Russian rabbi would shout out from the pulpit, that the pain of centuries would burst and that he would denounce the Soviet oppression of his people. Of course, the rabbi did no such thing. Rabbis do not do such things in Russia they are what Mr. Wiesel once so poignantly called the Jews of silence.

title: Advertising
description: The Bayer line of products, with annual billings in the neighborhood of $20 million, is being switched to Doyle Dane Bernbach from DancerFitzgeraldSample.

description: The rise of ABCTV in the primetime ratings this season, along with the network's preeminence in sports, have put the corporate focus on ABC News for its nogrowth record in the competition with CBS and NBC.

title: Late Modest Credit Market Rally Spurs Optimism on New Issues
description: The credit markets perked up late yesterday afternoon, perhaps buoyed by Treasury Secretary Simon's statement that he expected the nation's annual inflation rate to subside to about 2 percent within two to three years. Many leading bond dealers, however, were unwilling to ascribe any neat causeandeffect relationship between Mr. Simon's prediction and the late afternoon recovery, and they said instead that the rise in prices was caused more by Wall Street traders reducing their short positions.
