title: AntiPeron Bomb Disarmed
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 18 (AP)An attempt on the life of President Isabel Martinez de Peron was foiled today by the police when they saw two peisons placing a bomb near her office, Government sources said. The police noticed the two persons with a parcel just as Mrs. Perlin was arriving by helicopter from her suburban residence, the sources said. The two suspects fled.

March 18 (Reuters)Typesetters at The Financial Times stopped production of the newspaper today because they objected to a report about a Government investigation into the press, The action was believed to have been taken because the report mentioned the high earnings figures of some typesettlers, but not those of journalists.

description: The Arol Development Corporation, operator of the Bronx Terminal Market, denied yesterday it had obtained its lease by fraud and charged that the city's Investigation Department was pressing such an allegation reluctantly, because of the clamor of publicity.

description: Move Follows Rejection of Oil Company's Offer to Buy Balance of Shares.

description: WASHINGTON, March 18The American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics has asked one of its members, Arthur Kranish, to resign because he published information given confidentially to its Washington chapter in a background briefing by senior officials of the Central Intelligence Agency.

description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 18 (AP) Democratic Party officials in Ohio say that campaign aides to Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California are exploring the possibility of his making a late entry as a candidate in this state's Presidential orimary election.

title: CITY LOAN ASSISTS PLANT EXPANSION
description: The city's twoyearold Industrial Development Agency has arranged its first taxexempt financing of a factory expansion, and the agreement is permitting a Bronx manufacturer of metal cabinets to move into a new plant and double its staff of 67 workers.

title: Credibility of Miss Hearst Is Key Issue at Summation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 18  The prosecutor in Patricia Hearst's bank robbery trial told the jury in his summation today that her story was just too incredible to believe, but her chief defense lawyer said, This is not a case about bank robberyit is a case about dying or surviving.

title: Hiss Says F.B.I. Files Support Some of His Claims of Innocence
description: Alger Hiss said last night that newly available files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation show that agents knew that a former maid's son had Mrs. Hiss's typewriter before the time she was alleged to have typed documents on it for a Soviet spy network.

title: Sequestered Hearst Jurors: Wonderful Time Tempered by Homesickness
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 18Oscar McGregor has eaten in an expensive restaurant in San Francisco almcst every night for the last eight weeks and gained 20 pounds. Back home, 50 miles to the north, his wife, Gail, has painted their house and done her spring cleaning.

title: Red Smith
description: Bowie Kuhn's order to his employers to open the baseball training camps is the most helpful single step he could have taken to hasten agreement between the players and the club owners. If the commissioner had done it three weeks ago, much bitterness caused by the lockout could have been avoided, and by now a new basic agreement might have been reached. The next move is up to the owners, who will meet with Kuhn in New York tomorrow. Chances are some like Gussie Busch of St. Louis will denounce him for giving in, but Gussie and the others had maneuvered themselves into a hopeless fix, and Kuhn gave them a chance to back down without too great a loss of face. After the meeting, negotiators can discuss changes in the unchangeable proposal the owners left on the table last Monday.

title: Document Says Callaway, In U.S. Job, Pushed Resort
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 Soon after he became Secretary of the Army in 1973, Howard H. Callaway attended a United States Forest Service meeting in Colorado and promoted the beneficial effects to the local area of a ski resort in which he held twothirds interest.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AFRICAN METEOR (Farrell), Monrovia March 28, Abidlan April 4, Tema 6 and Matadi 10; sails from Joralemon St., Brooklyn.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI)Record savings flowing into thrift institutions and improved capitalmarket conditions last month helped conventional home mortgage interest rates to decline by the largest onemonth amount since last spring, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

description: Now that spring training camps are alive and well in Florida, Arizona and California, the baseball picture is brightright?

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTQN, March 18The Association of American, railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15 billion tonmiles, 4.6 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 450,922 cars, 4.2 percent above last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc. reported intercity truck tonnage was 15.5 percent above last year.

title: U.S. Offers 3 Alternatives To Develop Gateway Park
description: SANDY HOOK, N. J., March 18The National Park Service, vdnturing cautiously into a metropolitan setting unfamiliar to its guardians of forest and wilderness, offered the public three choices today for developing the 26,000acre Gateway National Recreation Area, which extends from this wild strip of the oceanfront to the crowded beaches of Queens.

title: Primary Focus Shifts To 3 Midtown Offices
description: The grand drama with which America picks its President turns now to three disheveled offices in midtown Manhattan. There, bands of Democrats, familiar political faces for the most part but projecting group personalities as varied as the men they support, toil to win delegates in the New York primary election on April 6.

title: Aqueduct Is Closed By Strike
description: Today's thoroughbred racing program at Aqueduct was canceled last night after maintenance workers called a midnight strike.

description: LEHAVRE, France, March 18 (AP)Striking printers, out of work for a year, occupied the laidup liner France today in a demonstration against abandonment for the sake of wastage and profit and to publicize their cause.

description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP)The Taser, an electric dart gun intended as a selfdefense weapon that only stuns the attacker, was ruled by the Government today to be firearm that must be registered when manufactured after May 1.

Nyquist has replied to the Beame administration's threat to end all fiscal support for the City University's senior colleges as of July 1977 with the counterthreat that this would free the state to shut the colleges down two months later. Mr. Nyquist insists, moreover, that Albany will not consider enlarging its present support of CUNY unless the city rescinds its freetuition policy.

description: TORONTO, March 18, (Reuters)Alain Goulet, 49 years old, a truck driver from Calgary, Alberta, who received a new heart in a transplant operation last month, died early today. On Feb. 10 Mr. Goulet received the heart of a teenage girl who had shot herself to death. A spokesman at St. Michael's hospital listed the infection and rejection.

title: U.S. Aides Disclose Threats of Violence To Nuclear Plants
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP)Federal officials have disclosed that there have been at least 175 instances of violence or threats of it against nuclear facilities across the nation since 1969.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Council of Churches of the City of New York paid it's yearly homage to the aviation industry at its fifth tnnual Bishop Wright Awards Luncheon, at Kennedy International Airport. Those honored, before more than 300 representatives of the aviation industry, religious groups and the city government were Princess Fatemeh Pahlavi, a pilot and sister of the Shah of Iran; Gen. Daniel James Jr., commander in chief of the North American Air Defense Command; James Pyle of the Aviation Development Council; Col. Bennett Griffin, an aviation pioneer, and Drs. Leon Star and Louis Abelson, founders of the medical facility at Kennedy Airport. The luncheon is named in honor of the late Bishop Milton Wright, prelate in the late 1800's of the Brethren Christ Church, Huntington, Ind., and the father of Orville and Wilbur Wright, inventors of the airplane.

title: Handcuffed to a Piano, Woman Foils a Robbery

title: Senator Church Joins Presidential Race

title: Hemmi Victor in Sky Race
description: BEAUPRE, Quebec, March 18Since Heini Hemmi, the bearded housebuilder from the Swiss village of Churwalden, became the surprise winner of the giant slalom gold medal at the Winter Olympics in Innsbruck, Austria, last month, international racers have been wondering whether Hemmi just had lucky day.

title: Books of The Times
description: We have fallen out of love with ourselves and our civilization, says Meepers. If we are destroyed, it will not be by war or pollution, but by selfdisgust. These notions are not newthey are in all the fashionable sociology booksbut what Maureen Duffy does with them in Capital makes for a moving and original novel. Meepers, a shabby homeless eccentric, is a selftaught historian of the socalled Dark Ages, and he believes that we have misinterpreted that historical gap. He is convinced that, contrary to established opinion, London and its inhabitants did not disintegrate at the hands of the barbarians after the Romans left. They survived, he in.

description: ROME, March 18The Italian Government announced today a series of austerity measures, designed to ease the economic crisis and prevent its own political collapse.

description: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, March 17Vast additional oil fields, equivalent in size to more than 20 percent of the United States total proven reserves, were discovered in Saudi Arabia during 1975, executives of the Arabian American Oil Company reported here today.

description: People are calling the Department of the Public Advocate in increasing numbers these days since the office recently expanded its costfree phone line for citizen complaints to a roundtheclock service.

title: Credibility of Miss Hearst Is Key Issue at Summation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 18  The prosecutor in Patricia Hearst's bank robbery trial told the jury in his summation today that her story was just too incredible to believe, but her chief defense lawyer said, This is not a case about bank robberyit is a case about dying or surviving.

title: Car In Tennessee Identified As Suspect's in Slaying of 5
description: GATLINBURG, Tenn., March 18 (UPI)A station wagon belonging to Bradford Bishop Jr., a State Department official wanted in the slaying of his wife, mother and three sons, was found today in a hikers parking lot in the Great Smoky Mountains.

description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP)  The Pentagon notified Congress today that it planned to sell $82 million worth of special kits to Greece to modernize that country's United Statessupplied M48 tanks.

title: Farmers Protest in Portugal On Reforms and Ask Land Back
description: LISBON, March 18Manuel da Silva Aguardenteiro is a 54yearold sharecropper with sunburned face and calloused hands who was driven from his land by the Portuguese revo Salazar exploited us for 48 years, but the revolution has destroyed what little we had in two)fears, the sharecropper said bitterly. He stressed that he had not been able to find work and the family lived on what his 14yearold daughter earned as a field hand.

title: Hiss Says F.B.I. Files Support Some of His Claims of Innocence
description: Alger Hiss said last night that newly available files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation show that agents knew that a former maid's son had Mrs. Hiss's typewriter bekre the time she was alleged to have typed documents on it for a Soviet spy network.

title: The Sheep Squadron
description: WASHINGTON  This winter more than 8,500 Jamaicans were cutting sugar cane less than 35 miles from Palm Beach, Fla. They were flown Into the area on chartered planes, and when the season is over they will be flown back home.

title: Anarchy in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT. Lebanon, March 18 With guns, threats and good deal of bluffing and mutual suspicion, the Lebanese are in the process of picking a new President. But a disintegration of the Leinnese state has made the choice an interArab affair.

title: STUDY FINDS LAG IN YOUTH FITNESS
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI)The physical fitness of American boys and girls, which showed significant gains from 1958 to 1965, has not improved in the last 10 years, the Office of Education said today.

title: 3 Share Lead by Shot at Jacksonville
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Maroh 18 (AP)Ray Floyd, who reached the turning point in his career in this event three years ago, posted a solid, fourunderpar 68, and tied for the firstround lead today in the $175,000 Greater Jacksonville open golf tournament.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Italian Government announced yesterday a series of austerity measures that It hoped would ease the economic crisis and prevent its own political collapse. Gasoline prices were raised, and sales taxes on automobiles, movie tickets, alcohol and other consumer items were increased, as were interest rates on loans. The announcement was made as the Christian Democrats, who govern the country, began a general meeting, their first in three years and one of their most crucial. [Page 1, Column 8.]

description: In Billions

title: Oval Office Used as Base for Influencing Presidential Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, March 18President Ford's advisers have urged him to use his office in his contest with Ronald Reagan for the Republican Presidential nomination. He has taken the advice literally, using not just the Presidency but the Oval Office itself to reach voters in the primary states.

title: Top Women Advance
description: DALLAS, March 18 (UPI)  Evonne Goolagong and Martina Navratilova, the top two seeded players in the Maureen Connolly Brinker tennis tournament, advanced to the quarterfinals today with easy secondround victories.

title: Black Weakness Abets White Rhodesian Rule
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 16  Rhodesia's blacks are in their vast majority so inactive politically and their few political activists are so disunited that they present a force that Is disproportionately weak as it confronts the commanding white minority.

description: DAVISGertrude. In cherished and everlasting memory of my darling mother. Remembered, missed and beloved forever.

description: WASHINGTON, March 18Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona said today he wished Senator Frank Church of Idaho had not declared his Presidential candidacy, but it really isn't going to affect our strategy or tactics.

title: CHILEAN SEX TET PLAYS FOLK MUSIC
description: The performance by the Chilean folklore group Intllllimani at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday evening was as much a political statement as it was a concert. Each aspect complemented the other as the six musicians and singers played and sang what is identified as. New Chilean Song. This included traditional songs, settings to poems of Pablo Neruda the Chilean Nobel laureate, by Victor Jara, a poet who was leader in the New Chilean Song movement, and works by the Chilean folklorist Violeta Parra.

Feinstein, a Teamsters Union leader whose local closed 23 city drawbridges in a strike that paralyzed traffic here nearly five years ago.

description: ALBANY, March 18Representatives of business and civic organizations gave qualified support today to the socalled Kinzel Plan for a unified state and local government employees pensions system.

title: Deal to Acquire Consyne Set By American Hospital Supply
description: The American Hospital Supply Corporation of Evanston, Ill., said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to acquire the Consyne Corporation of San Marcos, Calif., for stock valued at $27 million. The terms of the agreement provide that each Consyne shareholder would receive about threetenths of a share of American Hospital stock for each Consyne share. On the basis of yesterday's closing price of American Hospital Supply on the New York Stock Exchange, each Consynel share would be exchanged fort stock worth about $10.50.

description: Beanie administration officials are planning to seek the services of dozens of additional executives from the business world as dollarayear volunteers to help deal with what is termed a growing management crisis'the loss of a third of the city's cadre of career management specialists since the fiscal crisis began.

Betsy Ross and Molly Pitcher were good helpers, but they just don't inspire patriotic ecstasy. Indeed, the whole masculine, militaristic flavor of the celebration turns me off.

description: HARRISBURG, Pa., March 18 (AP)Fred R. Harris said today that he planned a major effort in Pennsylvania's April 27 Presidential primary.

Last night, at the uptown Circle in the Square Theater, she made her sadly belated Broadway debut in Tony Richardson's exquisitely styled staging of Ibsen's The Lady From the Sea.

title: BILL FORD
description: BALTIMORE, March 18 (AP) Bill Ford, trainer for the Washington Bullets of the National Basketball Association, was killed early today when his car collided headon with a tractortrailer inside the Beltimore Harbor Tunnel. He was 46 years old.

description: NEW DELHI, March 16India, which has one of the world's major population problems, has begun a national debate about a drastic solution to itcomoulsory sterilization.

title: Karpov Wins Skopje Event
description: SKOPJE, Yugoslavia, Marcn 18 (AP)The world chess chainpion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, won the Skopje international tournament today. He did not lose a game and had 121/2 points at the end of the tournament's 15 rounds. An American, James Tarjan, tied for fourth place. The other American who took part in the tournament, Samuel Reshevsky, finished low.

title: HEALEY JOINS RACE FOR WILSON'S POST
description: LONDON, March 18The scramble to succeed Harold Wilson'as Britain's Prime Minister was widened tonight when Denis Healey, the controversial Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced that he would seek the Bost.

Here was a slimmer Jimmy Connors, fresh from overwhelming victories against Manuel Orantes and Ille Nastase, being pummelled by Ray Ruffels, an Australian who reaches his 30th birthday next week and has virtually disappeared from the big tournament scene.

title: MERRILL LYNCH SUIT ALLOWED 3 CLIENTS

description: WASHINGTON, March 18 A retired vice admiral who was in charge of nuclear targeting said today that the Defense Department was proposing to revoke the authority given to the North American Air Defense commander to use nuclear weapons in certain circumstances.

title: U.N. AFRICA STUDY IS SET FOR HAVANA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 18A United Nations committee announced today that it would sponsor an intertiational seminar in Havana in May in support of the struggle for liberation in South Africa.

description: A waning of the entrepreneurial spirit is a principal cause of New York State's economic decline, according to two scholars who have made a new assessment of the state's problems and published their findings in Search, the quarterly of the State University of New York.

description: WASHINGTON, March 18Matthew DeMore, retired general secretarytreasurer of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, died of leukemia yesterday at the George Washington University Hospital. He was 72 years old.

description: KASSEL, West GermanyEdgar Keenon, the giant American bassbaritone, who is the Flying Dutchman in the new Kassel production of Wagner's opera, sits as the makeup artist paints his face ghostly pale and cautions a visitor about the performance. Now, don't be shocked, he says.

description: The American Jewish Congress has received assurances from 22 leading United States concerns that they would not become involved in the Arab boycott of Israel.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: An 82yearold Bayonne widow suffering from a chest inflammation won $250,000 in the Jersey Jackpot, lottery drawing and said she would use the winnings to convalesce in Florida. The woman, Victoria Kondrukewich, who has been a widow since 1939, could not attend the drawing at the Oradell firehouse because she bad recently been ill with pleurisy, a chest inflanunation that makes breathing difficult. She was represented at the drawing by her son and daughterinlaw, Mr. and Mrs. John Konn.

description: It was a day that politicians dream about it.

description: As an exercise in electing somebody, the Presidential campaign is slowly beginning to do its work. As an exercise in political education, it is not only a bust, as are most campaigns; but this one may be a disaster.

description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI)President Ford has not asked or authorized anyone to get in touch with Ronald Reagan and urge him to drop out of the Republican Presidential nomination race, the White House press secretary, Ron Nessen, said today.

title: SCHOOLAIDE SESSION DELAYED BY PROTEST
description: A Board of Education meeting with district superintendents that was scheduled to be held yesterday was suddenly postponed after representatives of the city's community school boards called for a boycott of the session.

Reid, the Commissioner ot Environmental Conservation, must sell substantial holdings of stock in companies that are regulated by his department.

title: Atlanta Is Scheduled to Get New Tabloid Paper in July
description: ATLANTA, March 18 (UPI)T. D. Jones, a realestate man, announced today that he would begin publishing a tabloid newspaper in Atlanta five days a week, beginning in July. He said a special first issue of The Press was to appear July 4, with regular MondaythroughFriday production set to begin July 12.

title: Students Hold Protestsitins
description: Demonstrations were held yesterday on at least five campuses in various parts of the state, with students staging sitins in administrative offices and warning of more to come.

title: Gateway Park Alternatives Offered
description: SANDY HOOK, N. J., March 18The National Park Service venturing cautiously into a metropolitan setting unfamiliar to Its guardians of forest and wilderness, offered the publici three choices today for developing the 26,000acre Gatewayl which Recreation Area,1 which extends from this wild strip of the oceanfront to the crowded beaches of Queens.

title: ROCKEFELLER HITS CURBS ON BUSINESS
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP)Vice President Rockefeller said today that Congress should not attempt to solve the problems of unemployment by legislating new constraints on the free enterprise system.

title: Russians Given a Look At Candidates of U.S.
description: MOSCOW, March 18 (AP) Photographs of contenders for this year's Democratic and Republican Presidential nomination have been placed on display here in a United States Information Service exhibit called The Struggle for the White House Lead.

title: Carey Vetoes a SchoolSpending Mandate for the City
description: ALBANY, March 18Governor Carey today vetoed a bill that would have required New York City to spend a fixed proportion of its budget on its schools, thus setting up potentially embarrassing confrontation with the Democraticcontrolled Assembly, where the bill has overwhelming support.

title: 1,000 Policemen Assigned to London's Subway After Bombings

title: FORD TOED TO PAY DEALER $1 MILLION
description: The Ford Motor Company was ordered yesterday by a Federal judge here to pay a small Yonkers distributor of autorepair parts more than $1 million in damages and lawyer's fees as a result of unlawful price discrimination.

title: Blacks Name 21 To Hall of Fame
description: Ernie Banks, Leo Durocher, Marion Motley, Jersey Joe Walcott and the late Paul Rohesan were amonl 21 athletes from nine sports named to the Black Athletes Hall of Fame yesterday. Their formal induction at the Hall's third annual dinner at the New York Hilton on March 31 will bring the total membership in the shrine to 65 members.

title: A Nonpolitical White House Is Up for Sale
description: LA PORTE, Tex., March 12 For sale one White House. Needs work, but no primaries, baby kissing, or global burdens required. A real steal at $415,000, with immediate occupancy guaranteed. Why wait until November?

title: NATO Workers Strike
description: BRUSSELS, March 18 (AP)International employees at the headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization went on a oneday strike today to protest plans to reduce costofliving allowances for betterpaid employees: Members of the delegations from the 15 NATO member nations were not affected.

title: Amins Lose Positions In Cairo Press Shifts
description: CAIRO, Friday, March 19 (AP)Ali and Mustafa Amin, twin brothers, have lost their positions on the newspapers they founded 30 years ago, the Cairo daily Al Gumhouria reported today.

title: When Jimmy Pretends
description: WASHINGTON, March 18Jimmy Carter is discovering what Ed Muskie and George McGovern learned to their sorrow in the last Democratic Presidential campaign that the role of the frontrunner is much tougher than the role of the challenger.

title: Financial Legislation Is Criticized by Barn
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today made the most vigorous attack so far by a Federal Reserve official on a key element of financial legislation that would among other things, divest the Fed of its bank regulatory functions.

title: First 7 Women Named To the Naval Academy
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 18 (AP)Seven women, the first appointed to the Naval Academy, are among the initial group of 247 persons accepted for the class that will enter the Academy on July 6.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: DAZED AND SHAKEN

title: Need for Realism
description: The new measure, with Senator Humphrey of Minnesota and Representative Hawkins of California as chief sponsors, represents an impressive challenge to the changenothing approach so characteristic of the White House and most of Congress through the past eighteen months of intolerably high unemployment.

title: Market Place
description: The stock market is still trading in the vicinity of the magical 1,000 level as measured by the Dow Jones industrial average and the question is, What next?

title: Reports on Ski Conditions
description: Boileayre  50.to.70.inch base; parked powder; sk ling good to excellent.

title: An Interim Rate Increase Denied to Lilco by P.S.C.
description: The Public Service Commis sion yesterday denied an application of the Long Island Lighting Company for an interim electric rate increase of $26.4 million, pending decision on its application for a permanent increase of $90 million a year.

title: S.E.C. IN CENSURE OF PAINE, WEBBER
description: WASHINGTON, March 18The Securities and Exchange Commission today censured Paine, Webber, Jackson and Curtis Inc., the New York brokerage house, and suspended one of its salesmen from the securities business for 60 days as a result of an episode in 1972 involving large purchases of shares in the Giant Stores Corporation.

title: BANK OF AMERICA DEMANDS ALBANY PROTECT REVENUE
description: ALBANY, March 18  The Bank of America, the country's largest bank, has demanded further action by Governor Carey and the Legislature to strengthen the security of state notes and revenues as a condition for its assistance in meeting the state's critical borrowing needs this spring.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts; 1976, by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)
description: FIRST$7,000, cl. Prices, $8,50057,500, 3 and 4Y0, 6F. Winner, Flying Zee Stable's ch. 9, 3, by Boston BakerLate April. Trainer, R. Debonis. Net, $4,200. Times I 22 4/5; 47 2/5; 1:13 3/5.

title: SEARS NET UP 102% ON RECORD SALES
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the world's largest retailer, reported yesterday that it rang up record sales in the quarter and fiscal year ended Jan. 31, with earnings 102 percent highft for the quarter and 5.4 percent higher for the year.

title: Mexico Defends Its Narcotics Drive Criticized in U.S.
description: MEXICO CITY, March 18Renewed charges from the United States that Mexico is not doing enough to curb the northward flow of narcotics have brought err angry defense of the Mexican Government's latest drive against the illegal drug traffic.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: Deily Averages for be weeks ended: (Mar. 17, 1976) (Mar. 10, 1976) (Mar. 19, 1975)

title: Market Drifts Downward As Trading Pace Slows
description: Weakness in some chemical issues and strength in the oil group appeared in the market yesterday as most stocks drifted downward on relatively low volume.

title: Prison Protesters Subdued
description: CANON CITY, Colo., March 18 (UPI)More than 120 protesting inmates armed with homemade clubs were subdued by tear gas grenades last night and peacefully returned to their cells in the state prison here.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: A visiting Korean friend recently observed that one could take a trip around the world simply by going to restaurants in New York. Anyone interested in a brief stopover in Bucharest would do well to dine at Dracula's Feast, an ebullient and completely enchanting Balkan boite tucked away in an otherwise dark and drab strip of 32d Street between Madison and Park Avenues.

title: S.I.A. ASKS THE S.E.C. FOR OPTIONS POLICY
description: The Securities Industry Association disclosed here yesterday that it had requested the Securities and Exchange Commission to avoid what it called dangers in the option market by deciding as a policy matter how trading in put Options would begin.

title: Yugoslav Sees Victory for U.S. Five
description: HUTCHINSON, Kan. March 18 (UPI)The assistant coach of the Yugoslavia national basketball team said today he expected the United States to beat the Soviet Union for the basketball gold medal at the Summer Olympics Montreal. The United States has the greatest basketball players in the world, said Vezovic Vojislav of Belgrade. In America, the big players are very agile and have great mobility. In Yugoslavia, most of them can't even dribble and are very slow. Vojislav predicted his country would finish third in the Olympics.

title: Army Division Adds 2 Units
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP)  Two Army National Guard and Reserve units have been assigned to round out the Army's Seventh Infantry Division at Fort Ord, Calif., as part of a policy to mesh the Guard and Reserve more closely with the Regular Army. The Army said today that the units are the 41st Infantry Brigade of the Oregon National Reserve Guard and the 840th Armored Battalion of Arizona, a reserve unit.

title: LEBANESE CONSULT ON FRANBEH OUSTER
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 18 Behindthescenes negotiations continued today for a formula to ease President Suleiman Franueh out of office.

title: POLL FINDS INCREASE IN CARBUYING PLANS
description: The Conference Board said yesterday that its latest survey of consumer intentions indicated that 10.7 percent of the 10,000 families studied intended to buy a new or used car in the next six months. This compared with 7.5 percent voicing such intentions in December.

title: Black Group Asks Draft of Rep. Dellums
description: CINCINNATI, March 18The executive council of the National Black Political Convention announced today that it would recommend the drafting of a black member of Congress. Representative Ronald V. Dellums, Democrat of California, to run for President as the candidate of the new Independent Freedom Party.

title: Arco Is Unopposed By Anaconda Co.
description: The Anaconda Company, the ailing copper concern that has been sought by a succession of corporations as a merger partner, announced yesterday that it would not oppose the acquisition of 27 percent of its stock for $162 million by the Atlantic Richfield Company.

title: HATFIELD WIRE LIFTS CONVERSION CHARGE
description: The Hatfield Wire & Cable group of Continental Copper and Steel Industries Inc., announced yesterday a price increase in conversion costs for copper, effective next Monday, to 4.8 cents a pound f.o.b delivered in the East Coast region. The company said increased costs of natural gas, electricity, a.id freight were responsible for the move.

title: CORN FUTURES UP ON HEAVY BUYING
description: Heavy commercial buying sent corn prices higher once again yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. May corn gained 2 cents a bushel to close at $2.73,.

title: City Seeking Better Designs for Housing
description: A city zoning plan intended to improve the quality of housing design was enacted yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

title: Opera: Lucrezia Borgia
description: It has been a long time between drinks. The last time New York saw a staged prodtiction of Donizetti's Lucrezia Borgia was at the Metropolitan Opera in 1904, and it had only one performance there. Last night, the New York City Opera gave a Borgia. staged for Beverly Sills at the New York State Theater.

title: DONALD SINCLAIR, 71, INVESTMENT BANKER
description: Donald G. C. Sinclair, a longtime Brooklyn civic leader who retired two months ago as senior accounts executive with White, Weld & Company, investment bankers, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, at New York Polyclinic Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Locust Valley, L. I.

title: Couple Rescued Off Florida
description: FERNANDINA BEACH, Fla., March 18 (AP)Albert Berry Tucker, 59 years old, and his wife Phoebe, 62, of Brevard, N. C., were rescued from their disabled 14foot outboard motor boat last night about five miles offshore near the GeorgiaFlorida border, officials said. They had been adrift for four days. Mr. Tucker was in fair condition at a hospital in Brunswick, Ga. Mrs. Tucker was released after an examination.

title: Giuseppe Genco Russo, 80, Dies; One of Last Sicily Mafia Chiefs
description: MUSSOMELI, Sicily, March 18 (AP)Giuseppe Genco Russo, reported to be one of the last big godfathers of the Mafia in Sicily, died here today in his native town. He was 80 years old.

title: U.S. Halts Two Booklets Used to Spot C.I.A. Men
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (Reuters)The State Department has halted publication of two official booklets that made it easy for outsiders to identify Central Intelligence Agency personnel posing as dinlomats.

title: Panama Canal Job Action Cuts Traffic to 6 Ships
description: CRISTOBAL, Panama Canal Zone, March 18 (AP)Only six ships passed through the Panama Canal yesterday and more than 100 were backed up today in a job action by. United States employees that has created the most expensive traffic jam in the canal's 62year history.

title: Document Says Callaway, In U.S. Job, Pushed Resort
description: WASHINGTON, March 18Soon after he became Secretary of the Army in 1973, Howard H. Callaway attended a United States Forest Service meeting in Colorado and promoted the beneficial effects to the local area of a ski resort in which he held twothirds interest.

title: Football Union Clears Air, Prods Owners to Negotiate
description: CORONADO, Calif., March 18In what was intended by the players as a constructive step toward the resumption of bargaining with the club owners, Dick Anderson, newly elected president of the National Football League Players Association, addressed the owners for about 20 minutes at their annual meeting today and won acceptance for his suggestion that talks be scheduled next week.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: United Press International

title: Amex and OTC Stocks Decline; Profit Taking Is Called a Factor
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market closed lower yesterday in slower trading.

title: Notes on People
description: Celebrating his demicentennial in show business, as well as St. Patrick's Day, Bing Crosby gave his first concert at the Los Angeles Music Center Wednesday night. He said that he would give othersalso for charity in this country and in London. The 71yearold singer, Who has been semiretired, said, I decided to get back in the swim and was reportEnjoying to be in solid voice and enjoying himself. He received an Ovation that brought him close to tears when he crooned a medley of oldies including I Surrender, Dear, Pennies from Heaven, Blue Hawaii and Sweet Leilani. Singing with his wife, Kathryn, and their son and daughter, Harry and Mary Francis, Mr. Crosby told the audience Nathaniel would be here except that he got three F's on his last report, card.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: BRIGHT AND BREEZY The music you hear  piano and bass  upon entering Le Chevalier (2889031), a French restaurant at 1464 Second Avenue (between 76th and 77th Streets), is as lively and relaxing as the atmosphere of the entrance bar. Michel (who turns out to be the owner) extends a greeting and invites a stranger to join the cocktail crowd and eniov himself.

title: Ban on 3DayOld Strike In Orange County Upheld
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday upheld an Orange County court ruling that bans a strike by county employees. But leaders of the walkout by same 600 members of the Civil Service Employees Association said the strike, which enters its third day today, would conItinue.

title: Lilco Denied Increase
description: The Public Service Commission yesterday denied an application of the Long Island Lighting Company for an interim electric rate increase of $26.4 million. Page 45.

title: BANK OF AMERICA DEMANDS ALBANY PROTECT REVENUE
description: ALBANY, March 18  The Bank of America, the country's largest bank, has demanded further action by Governor Carey and the Legislature, to strengthen the security of state notes and revenues as a condition for its assistance in meeting the state's critical borrowing needs this spring.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Linco???t, Center, Bizet s Carmen, 8.

title: Music: The Londoners
description: The London Symphony Orchestra's second concert of its current New York run Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall confirmed some of the problems that had been reported after itsopening concert on Tuesday. In particular, there was a curiously unblended quality to the various instrumental choirs in the two big orchestral works of the program, Roy Harris's Symphony No. 3 and Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 4.

title: Gas and Electric Bills To Be Lower in April
description: NEWARK, March 18 (UPI) Public Service Gas and Electric customers will get a $6.1 million reduction in their gas bills next month because the utility received a rebate from its gas pipeline suppliers, it was announced to day.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Internal political conditions in South Korea have steadily deteriorated during the past five years. In the 1960's the Government of President Park Chung Hee, which came to power in 1961 via a military coup, made great economic progress and seemed to be gradually developing an open political process that would eventually vindicate the massive American economic and military aid to the Republic of Korea. In a series of moves since 1971, however, Park changed the constitutional system to guarantee his lifetime rule and has now suppressed even token public dissent.

title: MEXICO INCREASING OIL OUTPUT FOR 1976
description: MEXICO CITY, March 18Mexico's state oil monopoly, Pemex, announced today that crude oil production here would exceed one million barrels a day by the end of 1976. but it continued to withhold any estimate of the country's newly discovered reserves.

title: Anarchy in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 18 With guns, threats and good deal of bluffing and mutual suspicion, the Lebanese are in the process of picking a new President. But a disintegration of the Lebanese state has made the choice an interArab affair. A year ago, Lebanon's rightwing Christian parties began a campaign to reassert national sovereignty, which they feared was being usurped by the s'IJrawling, wellarmed Palestinian guerrilla movement.

title: Antitrust Bill Approved; House Defies Veto Threat
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI)  Defying a threatened veto by President Ford, the House approved today a bill to allow state attorneys general to file class action suits in Federal court on behalf of calzens injured by antitrust violations.

title: Senate Moves to End Subsidies To Candidates With Few Votes
description: WASHINGTON, March 18The Senate voted unanimously today to cut off Federal subsidy payments to Presidential candidates who receive less than 10 percent of the vote in two consecutive competitive primaries.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In two political articles that appeared in The New York Times yesterday, the results of the most recent poll in Wisconsin were incorrectly reported. The poll, conducted by The Milwaukee Sentinel throughout the state, showed Jimmy Carter first and Gov. George C. Wallace second.

title: Arabs Close Shops to Protest West Bank Shootings
description: JERUSALEM, March 18 (Reuters)Arab merchants in the Old City of Jerusalem conducted a strike today to protest the wounding of three young Arabs by an Israeli soldier yesterday during a demonstration.

title: PRUDENCIO UNANUE, HEADED GOYA FOODS
description: Prudencio Unanue, founder and board chairman of Goya Foods Inc., processors and packagers of beans, rice, hot sauces and other foods popular in the Hispanic community, died Wednesday at his home in Rio Piedras, P.R. He was 89 years old and also lived in Bogota, N.J.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 1.6 From. WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 196.9 from 195.3 last week.

title: The Spocks: Bittersweet. Recognition in a Revised Classic
description: Jane Cheney Spock stretched out on the couch in her sunny melon and avocado East Side apartment, a heating pad on her right knee to ease the pain of arthritis. Then she began to talk about another kind of painthe pain she said she had suffered for 30 years until her estranged husband, Benjamin, finally gave her the credit she felt she deserved for helping him write his bestselling book, Baby and Child Care.

title: Pratt Show Relates Energy to Architectural Design
description: There is a large drawing of a windmill at the entrance of The Energy Show, an exhibition of energyconscious architectural design that opened last week at Pratt Institute's Pratt/Phoenix Gallery at 160 Lexington Avenue. If this were one of the flashy multimedia exhibitions of the sort that has been cropping up at museums lately, it would probably have been a real windmill, but the drawing fits this show much better. For the Pratt exhibition is sensible and straightforward, free of fancy gimmicks, but brimming over with intelligent material.

title: People in Sports
description: The first Woman Athlete of the World award was presented to Chris Evert yesterday at a luncheon held in her honor at Gallagher's Steak House. Miss Evert, who won $362,227 last year in capturing the United States, French and Italian tennis opens, the Virginia Slims and other tournaments, was presented with the Haig and Haig trophy and a check for $10,000.

title: Gucci: Adding To His Fan Club
description: The luncheon tablecloths and napkins at the St. Regis roof were Gucci. So was the host. Resplendent in the new color he calls Venetian blue, Dr. Aldo Gucci sat next to Mary Beame, who complemented him nicely in raspberry and pink. The chain around her neck dangling a silver No. looked like a Gucci design, but it wasn't. It was a gift from a friend who said the Mayor's wife was New York's No. 1.

title: Bucks Fox Hospitalized
description: MILWAUKEE, March 19 (AP)  Jim Fox, a reserve center for the Milwaukee Bucks, was hospitalized today after complaining of back pain, the National Basketball Association team said. Xrays diNclosed no serious problems. Fox will he in fraction Int three or four days.

title: I.C.C. BEGINS STUDY OF 15 RAILROADS
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission announced yesterday the start of what it termed a farranging investigation into the managementbusiness interrelationships and transactions of 15 of the nation's major railroads and their controlling holding companies.

title: The Oakland 9 Challenge Charles O.
description: MESA, Ariz., March 19 In the Oakland A's locker room at Rendezvous Park today, their young second baseman, Phil Garner, was putting on a goldsleeved sweatshirt for the opening workout.

title: PORTIA NELSON SINGS ALL THE OLD THINGS
description: Portia Nelson, who was one of the regular performers at the Blue Angel a quarter of a century ago and who was heard in several of Goddard LieberIson's recorded productions in the 1950's of Broadway musicals that appeared before the days of original cast albums, is singing in New York for the first time in 17 years at Brothers and Sisters, 355 West 46th Street.

title: COURT RACKS CURB ON GASOLINE LEAD
description: WASHINGTON, March 19In a major environmental decision, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled today that the Environmental Protection Agency, may order reductions of lead in gasoline to head off potential but not fully proved public health hazards.

title: Artis Says He Had Doubted a Victory
description: GLASSBORO, N. 3., March 19 John Artist Whose conviction in a triplemurder case was reversed Wednesday said today that he was ecstatic about prospects for his imminent release from prison.

title: Strike Talks in Las Vegas Suspended After 9 Hours
description: LAS VEGAS. Nev., March 19 (AP)A round of talks ordered by Gov. Mike O'Callaghan in hopes of ending an eightday strike by service emploeos against 15 Las Vegas hotels broke off early today.

title: ADAPT OR FACE CUTS, CITY U. IS ORDERED
description: The Board of Higher Education was told last night by the newly designated head of the Emergency Financial Control Board that the city's plan to end aid to the senior colleges next year might be averted if the school board approved a restructuring plan for the City University by next Wednesday, sources close to the board reported.

title: Philadelphia Inquirer Blocked by Pickets
description: PHILADELPHIA, Saturday, March 20About 250 pickets, some of whom were disorderly at times, blocked entry into the building of the Philadelphia Inquirer yesterday afternoon and last night by crowding into doorways.

title: Listing of Prices of Commodity. Futures
description: Friday, March 19, 1976 CHICAGO GRAINS WHEAT

title: Parity in U.S.Canada Pay Demanded by Auto Workers
description: DETROIT, March 19 (AP)United Automobile Workers will fight to keep pay parity among United States and Canadian workers during contract talks this summer despite wage controls in Canada, the union says.

title: Coleman Demands Rail Accord
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI)Transportation Secretary William T. Colemanr Jr. demanded today that two profitable railroads and rail unions immediately reach agreement to allow the purchase of almost 2,500 miles of bankrupt Northeastern railroads.

title: Tycoonery In the First Degree
description: We are in the office, ladies and gentlemen, of B. J. Marvellus, president of Dynamic Consolidated. Mr. Marvellus has graciously consented to talk to us about the magnificence of the freeenterprise system.

title: N.I. Racing Extended
description: EAST WINDSOR TOWNSHIP, N. J., March 19The New Jersey Racing Commission today approved a.joint application adding 25 dates to Atlantic City Race Course's summer night meet, starting June 12. The additional nights will be Sept. 1 through Oct. 2.

title: Connors, Nastase Reach Final
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., March 19Helped by one streak in which he took five games running, chiefly by charging the net and burying every overhead in reach, Jimmy Connors defeated Roscoe Tanner, 64, 64, in 80. minutes today. It put Connors in the final of this $100,000 Independent Players Association tournament.

title: Market Mixed as Trading Falls to 2d Slowest of 76
description: Stock prices were mixed in lackluster trading yester day. Investors appeared to shrug off, or had already, discounted, several positive economic reports. On the heels of a 6.14point drop in the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial issues on Thursday, the market opened still lower yesterday. The 1 ist recovered, somewhat from its wear opening tiy noon, slippea again in the early afternoon and wound up, as measured by the Dow index, unchanged on the day at 979.85.

title: Unruly Fans a Growing Islander Problem
description: Nassau Coliseum hockey fans have never been hostile to the dull Black, Hawks, but the Coliseum's director cof security is prudently increasing his force of guards for tonight's game between Chicago and the New York Islanders.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: More than 500 people picketed City Hall to protest the proposed elimination  of the city's Addiction Services Agency and cuts in funds for narcotics treatment programs, warning that the shutdown would increase crime by addicts. When the Addiction Services Agency pickets rallied in nearby Murray Street, City Hall was ringed by another groupmore than 1,000 students protesting a proposal to change Medgar Evers College in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn from a fouryear to a twoyear college.

title: Laser System Produces Fibers
description: WASHINGTON, March 19A Massachusetts research and consulting company has developed a laser system for producing flawless, smalldiameter fibers with strengths Patents of the Weekdescribed as nearly theoretical. For example, a singlecrystal sapphire fiber has tensile strength in xcess of 1.4 million pounds 3e r square inch. Arthur D. Little Inc., of Cambridge, remived Patent 3,944,640 this week for the method and apparatus. The inventors are John S. Haggerty, senior staff member of Arthur D. Little, and Wilson P. Menashi and Joseph F. Wenckus, officers of the Intermat Corporation, a subsidiary.

title: Letter's to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary and Index
description: Princess Margaret of  Britain and her husband, Lord Snowdon, whose courtship before their marriage nearly 16 years ago attracted worldwide attention, are separating, according to a statement yesterday from Kensington Palace in London, the home of the Princess. The statement said that the Princess would carry out her public duties and functions unaccompanied by Lord Snowdon, and there were Apo plans for divorce proceedings. [Page 1, Columns 14.]

title: Betty. Grimes Lindley, 76, ExAide to Mrs. Roosevelt
description: WASHINGTON, March 19Betty Grimes Lindley, long active in political and civic affairs in New York City and Washington and the wife of Ernest K. Lindley, writer and columnist, died yesterday in a nursing home here after a long illness. She was 76 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: Recently a reporter on the television news announced that President Ford was giving a series of exclusive interviews to Florida radio reporters. The point of an otherwise rather parochial story was that it was the week before the Florida primary: the President was thus Unlimbering what the loser, Ronald Reagan, later referred to as the powers of the incumbent. As for the radio reporters, one of them explained, We're being used but he is the President and what the President says is news.

title: MAKEUP OF CABINET APPROVED BY SADAT
description: CAIRO, March 19 (Reuters)President Anwar elSadat of Egypt issued a decree tonight approving the new Cabinet of Prime Minister Mamdouh Salem, designed to tackle the country's ailing economy.

title: Capistrano Swallows Back on Time Again
description: SAN JUAN CAPISTRANO, Calif., March 19 (UPI)True to the celebrated legend, the swallows returned today, the Feast Day of St. Joseph, to the 200yearold Roman Catholic mission that first gave them a home.

title: Wick, Former Nazi, Withdraws His Bid To Be Rotary Head
description: EVANSTON, Ill., March 19 (UPI)Faced with mounting opposition to his background as a wartime Nazi SS trooper, Wolfgang Wick, an Austrian industralist, withdrew today as a nominee for president of Rotary International, the global service club.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Friday.

title: Signatures Argued on Complex Petitions
description: For 30 minutes the other day, the forces of Jimmy Carter and Representative Morris K. Udall picked over the attributes of an innocent and unwitting voter named Selma Stern.

title: Swiss, Italians Advance
description: BIEL, Switzerland, March 19 (AP) Switzerland and Italy won the first two secondround games of the Group B world ice hockey tournament here and in Aarau today. At Biel, Switzerland edged Yugoslavia, 54. In Aarau, Italy beat Bulgaria, 83.

title: Cahn Is Indicted Again in Billing Case
description: William Cahn, former Nassau County District Attorney, was reindicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on charges that he doublebilled Nassau County and various law enforcement organizations for trips he took to attend meetings.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Teachers and other employees or eignt New Jersey state colleges yesterday authorized their union negotiators to call a strike next Wednesday if a new contract with the state is not reached. Meeting at Rutgers University, they voted 1,226 to 1,112 to authorize a strike.

title: College Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: Residents of City AdultCare Homes Tell of Abuses
description: Residents of city adultcare facilities testified at a United States Senate subcommittee hearing here yesterday that they frequently lived in terror of beatings, often in squalid conditions, and sometimes were forced to pay bribes for meals.

title: Braniff and the Teamsters Agree on a Labor Contract
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)Braniff Airways and the international Brotherhood of Teamsters reached a tentative agreement today on a new contract for 3,600 ground employees who had threatened to strike the airline.

title: Morris C. Leikind Is Dead at 70; Medical Historian and Archivist
description: Morris C. Leikind, a medical historian, archivist and teacher with the Federal Government Ifor nearly 40 years, died Monday in a hospital in London. He was 70 years old and had lived in Tel Aviv for the last three years.

title: Sports Today
description: N.C.A.A. regional finals, East, Rutgers vs. V.M.L. at Greensboro, N.C.; Mideast, Marquette vs. Indiana at Baton Rouge, La. West, 1T.C.L.A. vs. Arizona, at Los Angeles.

title: 63 BOMBING DATA WITHHELD BY F.B.I.
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 18 The Federal Bureau of Investigation withheld the results of its inquiry into the 1963 bombing of a Birmingham church from the Alabama Attorney General for more than Tour years despite repeated requests for the data.

title: Computers, Consumers.
description: When is a consumer victory not a victory? Answer: When the supposed triumph tends to raise the price the consumer must pay.

title: Concert: A Clever Idea
description: Gordon Crosse, the English composer, is an ingenious fellow. His Epiphany Variations: Double Variations for Orchestra, which had its world premiere at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night, is so cleverly conceived that it succeeds as an intellectual tour de force even though it falls sadly short of sustaining aural interest over its halfhour length.

title: February Level of Prices Almost Stable in City Area
description: Consumer prices in the New YorkNortheast New Jersey area displayed in February a stability not seen in years, with food prices recording the smallest overtheyear rise in four years, the United States Bureau of Labcir Statistics reported yesterday.

title: TV Review
description: Two of the more prominent productions being used to end public television's Festival 76 fundraising campaign are acquisitions from the British Broadcasting Corporation. Each is the recipient of an International Emmy Award. The Evacuees, shown on Channel 13 last night, is a drama about two young Jewish brothers in Manchester, England, at the beginning of World War II. Marek, which will be presented tomorrow at 10:05 P.M., is a documentary about a 7yearold boy who undergoes heart surgery.

title: Puerto Rico Takes a Dual View of the Bicentennial
description: GUANICA, P.R.  Puerto Rico's 3.1 million United States citizens of Hispanic origin are celebrating the nation's Bicentennial with a mixture of official enthusiasm and public, indifference.

title: BAIL FOR CARTER AND ARTIS POSTED
description: PATERSON, N.J., March 19Combined bail of $35,000 for Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis was posted here tonight, and both men are scheduled to be released tomorrow after having spent nearly 10 years in prison on triplemurder convictions.

title: MORRIS HUBERMAN, U.N. FORESTRY AIDE
description: Dr. Morris A. Huberman, specialist in forestry who retired from the United Nations staff in 1972, died Thursday of a heart ailment in Waterbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 65 years old, and lived at Heritage IVillaee in Southbury. Conn.

title: Who's That Knocking at My. Door?
description: ROMEAs the Italian Communist Party (P.C.I.) creeps perhaps immutably toward a share in governing power, Enrico Berlinguer, its logical and persuasive leader, insists he has no remote intention of doing away with democracy in this tormented republic and that his massive organization is pledged to honor democratic freedoms.

title: Ford Acclaims Sadat's Decision To Annul Treaty With Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI)President Ford today hailed Egypt's move to abrogate a friendship treaty with the Soviet Union as a victory for United States foreign policy and he pledged that Washington would respond with economic aid and other assistance for Cairo.

title: 2 RHODESIAN SIDES BREAK OFF TALKS, APPEAL TO BRITO
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 19  Negotiations between the Rhodesian Government and black nationalists were broken off today and both sides called on Britain to resolve their dispute.

title: Israel Will Attend U.N. Debate Despite Participation by P.L.O.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.,I March 19Israel, in a change of strategy at the United Na1tions, announced tonight that, it would participate in a Security Council debate Monday on West Bank unrest at which the Palestine Liberation Organization was also due to be represented.

title: Margaret and Snowdon Agree to Separate
description: LONDON, March 19Princess Margaret and the Earl of Snowdon are separating after 16 years of marriage, it was announced today.

title: Mrs. Mellon Recounts Her Custody Fight
description: Sitting in the cramped office of a Brooklyn private detective agency, Karen Boyd Mellon told yesterday of a nearly fourmonth ordeal in which she sought to retain custody of her two daughters, who, she said, her former husband was desperately trying to take back to Pennsvlvania.

title: Swiss Set Participation

title: Bush Backs Colby on Funds

Colby, today in refusing to divulge the agency's budget because I don't want to help Soviet intelligence. Mr. Bush told the National Newspaper Association, Our budget figures are not made public.

title: Argentina Is at the Crisis Point
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 19President Isabel Martinez de Peron has managed to cling to office in Argentina's mounting political crisis by a combination of sheer determination, lastminute concessions and fear on the News part of others as Analysis to what might happen to the country if she is removed from office. Mrs. Peron has proved far tougher than her many political adversaries and critics imagined possible during her 21 months in office.

title: Union Carbide, 3,500 on Staff, to Quit City
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, the nation's second largest chemical manufacturer, yesterday ended two years of agony over whether to move its headquarters out of New York City and told its 3,500 employees it was relocating to Connecticut. The planned move, which will take three or four years to accomplish, further reduces, New York's shrinking roster of industrial giants, weakens the city's ailing economy and disappoints the hopes of Mayor Beame, Governor Carey and other public officials who had made personal appeals to the company's leaders to remain here.

title: Miss. KasererWins Slalom AsWorld Cup Season Ends

The programs, including a slide lecturedemonstration tracing the development of the 2,000yearold entertainment art form in other Asian cultures, are at 1:30, 2:30 and 3:30 P.M.

title: Notes on People

Low, deputy administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for the last six years, will leave in June to become president of his alma mater, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y. Mr. Low, who has more than 25 years of government service in aeronautics, was acting NASA administrator in 197071. Earlier, as manager of the Apollo spacecraft program in Houston after the 1967 fire that killed three astronauts, he received major credit for getting that program back on a successful course.

description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI)The Postal Service announced today it had placed an embargo on surface mail to Lebanon because of severe problems in the port of Beirut. Oily air mail letters and parcels are being accepted for delivery to Lebanon.

The program, first given Thursday night and being repeated tonight and next Tuesday, also included Schoenberg's Five Pieces for Orchestra (Op. 16) and Prokofiev's Fifth Piano Concerto, with Vladimir Ashkenazy as soloist.

description: WASHINGTON. March 19 (UPI)The. House Commerce Committee approved yesterday a bill that puts off many of the deadlines of the Clean Air Act of 1970chiefly the automobile exhaust requirements.

Metcalf was reelected president and Harry B. Freeman chairman of the executive committee. The company publisbes The Providence Journal, The Providence Sunday and., The Evening Bulletin. title: Morgan Russell, the Synchrornist Pioneer
description: It is not always the major talents who respond most quickly and decisively to important flew developments in art. Minor artists, confronted with a radically new possibility and having less at stake in abandoning a safe position: are sometimes able to move more swiftly into new and untried realm of expression. And if they succeed in the attempt, even briefly, they are likely to be rewardedin the short run, anywaywith the kind of recognition that normally belongs only to genius.

description: Broken glass crunched under his feet and photographers lights flashed in his face as Representative Morris K. Udall marched through the debris of a vacant lot in the South Bronx yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: Recently a reporter on the television news announced that President Ford was giving a series of exclusive interviews to Florida radio reporters. The point of an otherwise rather parochial story was that it was the week before the Florida primary; the President was thus unlimbering what the loser, Ronald Reagan, later referred to as the powers of the incumbent. As for the radio reporters, one of them explained, We're being used but he is the President and what the President says is news.

title: Msgr. Nicholas H. Wegner Dies; Former Director of Boys Town
description: Msgr. Nicholas H. Wegner, former director of Boys Town, Neb., near Omaha, who built the home for boys into a $200 million institution, died Thursday; at St. Catherine's Hospital Center for Continuing Care in Omaha, where he spent the last year after having suffered several strokes. His age was 77.

Bassbtt, the Canadian millionaire, maintains.

title: Art: Freewheeling Portraits by Enrico Baj
description: Enrico Baj is a very funny fellow. He also is very fertile. (The Bolaffi catalogue of his complete worksto 1969 onlyincludes 1,567 items.) Primarily a portraitist, he has ruminated with great profit on facts of which we become daily more aware: That every human being is a battleground of opposites, for instance, and that the battle sways this way and that, rarely ending in a decisive victory for one side or the other.

title: Five Die in Havana Crash After Two Planes Collide
description: HAVANA, March 19 (Reuters) Five people aboard a Cuban transport plane died today when the aircraft and a dejet leased by Cuba's national airline from Air Canada collided in midair over Havana last night.

description: Dr. Carmyn J. Lombardo, a cardiologist and specialist in internal medicine, who formerly served on the Board of Higher Education, died of cancer Thursday at his home, 2501 Palisade Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. He was 70 years old.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Princess Margaret of Britain and her husband, Lord Snowdon, whose courtship before their marriage nearly 16 years ago attracted worldwide attention, are separating, according to a statement yesterday from Kensington Palace in London, the home of the Princess. The statement said that the Princess would carry out her public duties and functions unaccompanied by Lord Snowdon, and there were no plans for divorce proceedings. [Page 1, Columns 14.]

title: Union Carbide, 3,500 on Staff, to Quit City
description: The Union Carbide Corpora. tlon, the nation's second largest chemical manufacturer, yesterday ended two years of deliberations over whether to move its headquarters out of New York City and told its 3,500 employees it was relocating in Connecticut.

title: 12 Americans Are Freed In Lebanese Jail Aitacks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 19, (Reuters) Twelve Americans who were among hundreds of priscne.rs freed by gunmen from Lebanese jails this week are returning home, United States consular officials here said today.

title: Shearson Fined $10,000
description: Shearson Hayden Stone Inc., the brokerage firm, reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that it had been fined $10,000 by the Chicago Board Options Exchange. The company said the fine was paid with its consent, although it did not admit or deny the exchange's charge that it violated rules dealing with the opening of new accounts to trade in options.

title: Scranton, at U.N., Doubts Need For U.S.Third WOrld FaceOff
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 19The new American representative at the United Nations, William W. Scranton, presented his credentials to Secretary General Kti1 Wald??? today, and late told a news conference that he saw no basic reason for confrontation between the United States and the third world.

title: Labor in Germany To Get Bigger Role InCompany Affairs
description: BONN, March 19West German labor leaders, after 25 years of fighting for full voting equality with shareholders on company boards, have settled for less with both anger and satisfaction.

title: SEC. SUBPOENAS BEAME'S PAPERS
description: Mayor Beame has been subpoenaed by the Securities and Exchange Commission to produce his official papers by March 31 to help the Government agency in its continuing investigation of possible fraud in the sale of New York City securities.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Friday.

title: Coping With Loneliness Of East German Elderly
description: EAST BERLIN  An angry social worker rang the.doorbell at the suburban home of a family here not long ago.

title: House Coal Inquiry Slated
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)Representative John W. Jenrette Jr., Democrat of South CaroLida, said today that a House Commerce subcommittee had been directed to begin an investigation into the coal industry. The study to begin by April 1, will include a look into coal prices and their effect on utility rates as well as the possibility of price fixing and other unfair anticompetitive actions within the coal industry.

title: F.C.C. Plans to Resolve Issue Of Jersey TV Service by July
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday announced its intention to resolve the problem of television service for New Jersey by July, but it dismissed as unfeasible earlier proposals to transfer New York's Channel 7 to that state or to create new stations by easing its rules for minimum mileage separation between channels.

title: Executive of Kodak Leaves $25 Million To U. of Rochester
description: ROCHESTER, March 19The University of Rochester announced today that it would receive more than $25 million from the estate of Charles F. Hutchison, an alumnus and former trustee who was an associate of George Eastman, founder of the Eastman Kodak Company.

title: The Right to Know
description: The confusion over the question of secrecy is illustrated by the fact that the substance of the report on the Central Intelligence Agency by the House Select Committee on Intelligence has become obscured by the row over its unauthorized publication. Instead of giving consideration to the committee's findings, the House has let its attention be diverted to an inquiry into the way the document was leaked to television reporter Daniel Schnrr.

description: Stockton, Calif.Rudy Barro. 142. pounds, Stockton, Calif., outpointed Miguel Mayon, 136, Mexico. 10 rounds.

description: A memorial service for Oscar Baron, an author, publisher and, in more recent years, book dealer in Yonkers, will be held at 4 P.M. tomorrow at the Park Hill Church of the Redeemer. 21 Ludlow Street, Yonkers. He died Feb. 21 at the arze of 67.

title: Antiques: At Fraunces
description: For the first time since Fraunces Tavern was reconstructed in 1907, its museum has been furnished as the galleries above the restaurant might have looked 100 years ago when George Washington visited the site at 54 Pearl Street.

description: FRANKFORT, Ky., March 19 (AP) Kentucky's Senate passed yesterday a stringent mine safety bill designed to protect workmen from disasters similar to the mine explosions last week in Oven Fork that killed 26 men.

description: Sherrell Bingham Bland of Chevy Chase, Md., was married last evening to the Rev. Richard Hill Downes, chaplain of St. Albans School in Washington. The Rev. Joseph Zorawick of New York performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Little Sanctuary of St. Albans.

title: Laotians Quit Peking With Pact Assuring China Vientiane Role

title: Our New Man in Peking
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 In 1965, when most Americana feared that China might intervene in the Vietnam war, Thomas S. Gates Jr., a former Defense Secretary and then a Man banking executive, shocked In the some friends by News advocating that the United States begin negotiations with Peking'. His advice went nowhere at the time. Today, President Ford named Mr. Gates head of the United States liaison mission to China. With the special rank of ambassador, Mr. Gates will get a chance to see what he can do about involving the Chinese more in the mainstream of world affairs.

title: Rights Action Stands
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., March 19 (AP)The Kentucky House adjourned yesterday without acting on an amendment that would have rescinded the. State's ratification of the equalrights amendment.

They have also learned that three of the nine directors of the organization were dead when the contract was signed.

description: WASHINGTON, March 19Frank G. Zarb, the Federal energy administrator, was reported tonight to be on the verge of making a change in Federal energy regulations that Would raise prices of heavy fuel oil on the Eastern Seaboard from Maine to Florida.

Miss Brasch, a singer with a model's smoothly planed face and a smooth, confident voice, ties her performance of 26 Weill songs together with brief introductory remarks, but they do not add depth.

title: Along Came the Witch
description: Helen Bevington is back with her gentle civilized humor and wit to remind us that all is not lost so long as someone remembers that Ben Jonson liked the taste of godwit (a bird) and that Augustine Birrell, having bought in his youth the works of Hannah (Holy Hannah) More, wearied of their piety and buried all 19 calfbound volumes in a hole in the garden. (Byron had 92 volumes of Voltaire, she tells us; Leonard Woolf had 90 and carried them to Ceylon when he went to work for the Ceylon Civil Service.)

description: Virtually all Federal money directed at the nation's energy problems is intended to expand, ensure, or regulate energy supply. Only about 1 percent is earmarked for energy conservation. Yet conservation holds far more promise over the next few decades than do any of the proposed new sources of supply.

title: BRITISH PANEL ASKS LOANS FOR PAPERS
description: LONDON, March 20 (UPI)Britain's national newspapers should receive $110 million in loans to help finance technological change in the industry, the Royal Commission on the Press has reported.

That's the thing that troubles those who remember the fruit orchards of Bergen County, the vegetable farms of Passaic County, the pig farms of Hudson County and the dairy farms of Morris and Sussex Counties. Today, less than 22 percent of New Jersey's 4.8 million acres of land is being used for agricultural purposes.

title: Knights Beat V.M.I., To Face Michigan
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 20The record book will always show that the Rutgers basketball team was 16 points better than the Virginia Military Institute team today. The final score will always read: Rutgers 91, V.M.I. 75.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: After the New York City school system began a new policy of encouraging pregnant girls to continue their education in school as long as possible, in January 1970, the City Department of Health sent instructions to all the schools on how to deliver babies in an emergency.

title: They love him in Seattle
description: Ask any composer. Writing an opera is the most thankless, unprofitable, even heartbreaking task imaginable. It may take from one to 10 years or even longer to complete a work of major proportions. Perhaps a sympathetic impresario can be found to stage the piece, a friendly foundation to help pay the production costs, group of singers willing to learn music they may never sing again, even an audience to fill half the theater. Afterward, there may be a few reviews ranging from Mild condescension to utter scorn, and another score goes back on the publisher's shelf to gather dust. No wonder so many peoplecomposers, critics and opera fans toosay that opera as a creative art form has had its day and that the repertory dried up after the deaths of Puccini and Strauss.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his review of Jonathan Schell's The Time of Illusion (Jan. 18), Robert Sherrill agreed that madness has in some measure overtaken all American Presidents since Eisenhower but doubted that nuclear terror had caused this madness to the extent that Schell suggested. By refraining from offering an alternative interpretation of his own, Sherrill no doubt set many readers to pondering this problem. I would like to suggest an explanation for this phenomenon, which seems to me to be worth thinking about right now, in connection with the current primary campaigns and the upcoming Presidential election.

title: Cuban Influence in Caribbean Rises, Worrying U.S. Officials
description: WASHINGTON, March 20In the last two years Cuba has gained considerable Influence among the small republics of the Caribbean and is now enjoying some regional support for its military ventures in Africa, in the assessment of topranking United States policymakers.

title: Ford's Headquarters Is Open To Everyone But Nixon's Ghost
description: WASHINGTONA young volunteer at President Ford's campaign headquarters had a brilliant idea not long ago for disposing of waste paper. What the President Ford Committee could use, he suggested, was a paper shredder.

title: Nonsense, Dear Lois

Miss Maples took issue with Dr. Hidalgo's contention that there ought to be a period of selfidentification between high school and college, a period in which a person could decide on his life work. find out who he is and what he is all about.
