title: Moser Takes U.S. Open Bowling
description: GRAND PRAIRIE, Tex., March 20 (AP)Paul Moser captured his first major title today In winning the $100,000 Bowling Proprietors Association of America United States open at Forum Bowl. The bowler from Medford, Mass., defeated Jim Frazier of Spokane, Wash., 226195, after Frazier had beaten three opponents to gain the final. Moser won $10,000 and Frazier $6,000.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Richie Zisk of the Pittsburgh Pirates makes a prediction on the National League East pennant race: We'll win it by more games and earlier.

title: Will This Fair Lady Be as Loverly?
description: There will be ghosts hovering over the St. James Theater on Thursday nightthe spirits of performances past. As the familiar overture begins, for many in the audience it will be March 15, 1956, the night that saw the premiere of My Fair Lady. Then reality will assert itself, the illusion will evaporate, the comparisons will begin.

title: Now Is the Time to Put Some New Life Into That Patio Furniture
description: Good quality outdoor lawn and patio furniture is surprisingly durable and normally requires very little maintenance. However, even the best quality pieces eventually show signs of wearcolors Start to fade, vinyl fabrics tear or get discolored, painted or varnished finishes start to crack or peel, metals show signs of oxidation or corrosion, and joints become loose and wobbly.

title: Headliners
description: Dr. X, the suspected villain in a series of New York Times stories about the mysterious deaths in 1966 of 13 patients in a New Jersey hospital, has finally been identified. He is Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, a surgeon with an active practice in New Jersey. Dr. Jascalevich's name was revealed when it was learned that the Bergen County Prosecutor would seek an indictment against him for the murder of one or more persons at Riverdell Hospital. The case was reopened after an extensive inquiry by The New York Times, and after a leading forensic expert had said that at least nine of the deaths were not attributable to natural causes or the causes listed, but were consistent with death caused by a fast acting poison such as curare. Exhumations of four of the bodies have revealed some traces of curare. Eighteen empty or near empty vials of curare had been found in Dr. Jascalevich's locker at the time of the deaths.

title: Olivia E. Kuser, Lyon A. Loomis To Be Married
description: Olivia Erdmann Kuser and Lyon Anderson Loomis, who both will graduate May 16 from Vassar College, plan to be married in June.

title: Ideas&Trends/Continued
description: Sheriff Harold Bray of Golden, Colo, likes aides who can analyze not: only a set of fingerprints but a Socratic dialogue as well. In his search for a new deputy sheriff, he ran an ad in jobs in Philosophy, a periodical of the American Philosophical Association. The ad described the job and said that preference would be given to Ph.D.'s with specialization in classical and/ or early modern philosophy.

title: Islanders Win, 42, Rangers Trotunced
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 20On the strength of three goals in the middle period, all initiated by Jean Potvin, the New York Islanders overcame another penaltykilling challenge and the Chicago Black Hawks, .42, tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

description: Announcement has been. made by Mr. and Mrs. Serge Jerome Hill of Bridgehampton, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Sally Baker Hill, to Charles Ewing Green Lloyd Jr.; son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd of New Canaan, Conn. The wedding is planned for May 8.

title: Letters:
description: To the Editor: It could be said that I read The Ultimate Togetherness: 4 Adults, Children, 1 Car, by Julie Stern (Travel Section, Feb. 29) without a sense of humor.

title: Educator's Son Stain

title: DANCE VIEW
description: People often ask why good choreographers are so rare. On its face, that may seem a difficult question to answer. After all, does it take any more creativity to be a choreographer than, say, a composer or novelist? No. However, the basic raw materials of dancespace, time and bodiesare both expensive and hard to come by. One might write a novel in an attic or on a desert island; one could never create a ballet in those circumstances.

title: Chile, Lab Test for a Theorist
description: SANTIAGO, ChileIt is not often that a leading economist with strong views is given a chance to test specific prescriptions for a very sick economy. It is even more unusual when the economist's client happens to be a country other than his own.

title: Callaway Denies Using Post in Cabinet to Benefit His Ski Resort
description: WASHINGTON, March 20Howard H. Callaway, a former Secretary of the Army who last week stepped aside as President Ford's campaign manager, said today that he had never used his Government position to benefit a Colorado ski resort in which he is a principal stockholder.

title: BRIDGE
description: We are told that Queen Victoria, after enjoying the bestknown writings of Lewis Carroll, demanded the other works of the same author and was baffled by the serious tomes of an Oxford mathematical professor, The Rev. Charles Lutwidge Dodgson. She might have had another Alice book to delight her if the imaginative professor had had not only chess but also contract bridge to serve as a theme. He would have been quick to recognize that the modern cardgame offers numerous examples of backtofrontery, upsidedownishness and topsyturvery.

description: THE Nassau Visitors and Convention Bureau, a private group formed almost a year ago to help the economy of the county by bringirrg outoftowners into Nassau, says that it has booked a number of conventions with more than 30,000 people for this year and next.

This shatters the 1964 proof set record that no one thought would ever fall; sales of that year's proof set totaled 3,950,762, which was largely attributed to the debut of the Kennedy memorial half dollar.

title: Baeza Up On Victor In Photo

He is the regular rider for Honest Pleasure, the Kentucky Derby favorite, Optimistic Gal probably the best 3yearold filly in the country, and Foolish Pleasure, rated the nation's best handicap horse.

title: Dahlia Heads Field on Coast Today
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 20 (AP)Dahlia, thoroughbred horse racing's millionaire mare, will test Santa Anita Park's grass course tomorrow in the $100,000 San Luis Rey Stakes. Dahlia has been within striking distance of becoming the richest mare in history for months. Despite having lost her last two races, she has been moving closer to the mark for money won set by Allez France.

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: ON March 5, five New Jersey state troopers were suspended from their jobs, allegedly for misusing their state gasolinecredit cards. The case has curious aspect. According to Col. Clinton L. Pagano, superintendent of the state police, the suspended troopers may have had a little racket going with some attendants the Exxon service stations along the New Jersey Turnpike. The troopers are suspected of signing tickets for gasoline and getting cash instead of fuel.

title: The Golf Clinic
description: What is the most Important putt in golf for the weekend player?

title: A Lion's Share
description: Somewhere amidst the raw material of this retrospective novel there should be a story that could move the reader to either pity or laughter. But as Mark Steadman assembles the history of the St. Boniface High School football team of 1947, it is neither as funny as, say, John R. Powers's The Last Catholic in America. nor as tragic as the untimely death of its hero demands. This is worth mentioning only because there is a vein of talent here that gleams through the anticlimaxes.

title: Riverhead vs. Progress
description: ALPHONSE Danoweld was taking a nap the other Sunday, a luxury for a hardworking farmer like himself. Suddenly he was awakened by a persistent buzzing in the back of his 17acre farm.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Like James Jones and a few others one could mention, Gerald Green is a highly regarded novelist (The Last Angry Man was his biggest success) who is now turning to suspense fiction. He already has written a privateeye novel under a pseudonym. Under his real name he has just come out with THE HOSTAGE HEART (Playboy, $8.95), and it is a fast  moving, if unoriginal, spinetingles that testifies to his powers of construction, his ability to do research and his novelistic experience.

title: OKLAHOMA PARTY SPLITS ON CARTER
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, March 20 Oklahoma Democrats today disregarded Gov. David Boren's endorsement Thursday of Jimmy Carter, picking a slate of 15 uncommitted delegates to lead the state into the Democratic national convention.

description: Tucked into a lushly overgrown hillside on the northeasternmost peninsula of Queens, the old battery at Fort Totten is a landmark in limbo.

title: Inflation and Recovery: What the Indexes Say
description: As the economic recovery approaches its first birthday, all eyes are turned to the inflation rate. There is a morbid fear among economists, businessmen, as well as consumers that, as the recovery matures, the inflation rate will once again accelerate. And, as we have seen demonstrated all too vividly in the recent past, a high enough rate of inflation can produce a severe business contraction.

title: The World/Contnued
description: SALISBURY. Rhodesia Ian Douglas Smith moved from  the second rank of Rhodesian politicians to the forefront when a Constitution adopted in 1961 set Rhodesia on a course that would have led to gradual participation of its black majority in the British colony's political life. Rather than accept such a loss of power and privilege, he broke with his party and helped to form the Rhodesian Front, whose overriding reason for being was to reverse the trend toward majority rule.

title: The Artmakers of Garwood
description: WHEN the champagne corks fly on North Avenue in Garwood this afternoon, they will he sailing past prints, watercolors, oil paintings and metal sculptures that are a cause for celebration.

title: Miss Wendel To Wed in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. William H. Wendel of Lewiston, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christine Wendel, to Michael Longyear. He is a son of Mrs. Mary E. Longyear of Port Byron, N.Y., and the late Leslie W. Longyear.

title: GARDENING
description: AS spring draws near, it is time to think about plants for our outdoor gardens. Most flower and vegetable plants may be purchased from, garden center and nursery outlets in sizes ready to plant outside. The average gardener Will find all his needs there.

title: Picture credits
description: Picture credits

title: DINING OUT
description: SOME may call it class; some may call it style. Whatever it is, The Harbor has a lot more of it than most New Jersey restaurants. The waitress introduces herself. A young girl strolls by, offering hot hors d'ouvres. There is a sommelier to open the wine. The management is visible on the floor all eveningwatching, helping, making sure things are running well.

title: Notes: Operatic Premieres by Sessions, Tal and Pasatieri
description: April this year is by no means the cruelest month, at least for opera lovers. April 1, in fact, sees a pair of premieresthe first production in America of Josef Tal's Ashmedai at the New York City Opera and the world premiere of Thomas Pasatieri's Ines de Castro at the Baltimore Opera. And preceding these by a day, on March 31, is the first U.S. performance of Roger Sessions Montezuma, by Sarah Caldwell's Opera Company of Boston. All three composers have spent most of March hovering around rehearsal halls, and all have the look of happy men.

title: Artistry in Wood: The Beaton Path
description: WEST MANTOLOKING, N.J.  The boatyard looks like the aftermath of a hurricane. Boats are strewn everywhere. Some have obviously been abandoned, pushed out In the marsh to weather away. Others are tucked into low, weatherbeaten sheds. Still more bob at moorings out in the cove that carves a shelter here out of the narrow head of Barnegat Bay. Other boats lay alongside ramshackle docks.

title: Radio
description: 77:30 A.M., WNEWAM: Yale Reports. Debating the Equal Rights Amendment.

title: Sally Fields To Be Wed in May
description: Sally ArM Fields and ??? Abram, 1973 graduates ??? Princeton University, will be married in May.

description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: IDA ELKAN
description: Ida Elkan, a pianist and teacher, died Wednesday at her home at 408 West 57th Street. She was 81 years old.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: At its present, rather rarefied level just below the 1,000 point for the Dow Jones industrial average, the stock market has been encountering a slower trading pace and comparatively dispirited price movements of late. Last week was, by and large, more of the same.

title: U.S. STUDY BACKS NEW PENSION LAW
description: A Federal study of pension plans that ceased operation in 1975 concludes that more than threefourths of them did so for reasons unrelated to the new pension reform law.

title: Mansfield Comments
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI)Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, suggested today that failure to meet Monday's deadline for reviving the Federal Election Commission could he the prod that Congress needed to act on the issue.

title: David Osler Fiance of Holly Mower
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Mower of Old Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mildred Halliwell Mower, to David D. Osier, son of Mr. and Mrs. David K. Osler of Riverside, Conn. His mother is Republican State Representative Dorothy K. Osier.

title: Education: The Pros And Cons
description: Francis M. Conlon's article [Opinion Pane, Feb. 22] performs an unfair disservice to the cause of suburban public education. His negative criticisms and proposed solutions are reflective of a simplistic, Archie Bunkeresque thinking about educational matters among those looking for a whipping boy to blame for the general problems of society.

title: Inside View of Contemporary Events
description: THE history, customs, culture and politics of a number of foreign countries are being brought alive for Glen Cove High School students this mouth through daily personal visits of emissaries from abroad. The monthlong program with a different country the focus each day, has drawn participation by diplomats from the consulates of the nations discussed or their missions to the United Nations.

title: Post Lacrosse Victor
description: GREENVALE, L. I., March 200. O.J. Alexander scored a goal with 16 seconds remaining today to lead C. W. Post to an 1110 upset victory over Army in lacrosse. Post evened its wonlost record at 11, while Army is now 01.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor: An article devoted to Speculum Musicae in the music pages of the Sunday Times, February 22, was accompanied by a photograph of the group and with a large caption in the form of a quote from the article stating that At Juilliard, contemporary music was considered nonmusic.

title: Food for Thought: Exotic Meals
description: NEXT to langpages, I like to collect foods unusual foods, exotic foods, native American dishes superlatively prepared. The range of my interests can be gauged from the fact that I once attended, as a member's invited guest, tte annual banquet of the Explorers Club, a function at which I feasted, among other things, on Alaskan bear steak, South American jabali (wild pig), canned rattlesnake and locusts in honey.

title: Europe Again Approaches a Decision on Political Unity
description: BONNThe European Common Market is undergoing such economic and political strains, in the words of its elder statesman, Leo Tindemans, of Belgium, that we have first salvage what has been achieved up to now and then try to make a significant leap forward. There is danger that the halffinished edifice of European unity will collapse without a great leap forward, a fear shared by Mr. Tindeman's and many other European leaders.

title: DETROIT PLANS CUTS TO REDUCE DEFICIT
description: DETROIT, March 20 (AP)Four city departments will he eliminated, the Historical Museum shut and 467 workers laid off permanently under austerity cuts announced by Mayor Coleman A. Young.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: AMAJORITY of New Jerseyans interviewed in a poll by The New York Times support a state income tax and casino gambling in Atlantic City. Most believe that living in New Jersey is better than outsiders may think. They are pleased with their life style, proud of their beach resorts and satisfied with the environment, but they are wary of government officials, unhappy with the tax structure and worried about the economy.

title: Job Package Offered
description: ALBANY, March 19  The Chairman of the Senate Labor Committee announced today the introduction of a package of bills designed to aid business development and generate jobs in the state.

title: SCHOOL BASKETBALL
description: Holy Trinity 58, Molloy 55 (overtime), Power 69, Loughlin 62.

title: The Sunday Drive: Dad Against Fate
description: I will not claim that my father made a wrong turn on every trip I took with him as a boy in the 1950's. Like everyone else, he had his ups and downs. But even on his best days he could suddenly fall prey to his fatally independent nature. He despised getting directions, be they oral, written or diagramed. If he followed them at all he followed them selectively, rejecting whatever turns seemed to him unreasonable. Turn right at Shilk's Liquor Store, the directions would command, and my father would pause at the intersection, regard the flow of traffic, declare, They can't mean this Shilk's Liquor Store, and shoot past to new and uncharted destinations.

title: My Lai, South Vietnam, Recalls A Day of Killings in March, 1968
description: MY LAI. South Vietnam, March 20 (UPI)A few of the graves are still marked with wooden sticks but the names of the dead are freshly painted in black.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: A recent ruling of the state's highest court is believed to be the most severe rebuff to date of sponsors of a cooperative apartment house conversion do the state.

title: At No Point Is the System Really Helping
description: Across the nation, the violent youngster is responsible for a frightening, and increasing, trend in crime. In New York City alone, crimes of violence by persons under 16 have risen 70 per cent in the last five years, with murders nearly tripling, rapes more than doubling.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: THE garden chores come so fast and furiously along with the crocus and robins, that the only way to approach them is with a plan of action. First things first.

title: Barker, Rivkind Senior Net Victors
description: Bob Barker, the defending champion, and Dan Rivkind each won two matches last night and led the field into the quarterfinals of the Eastern senior indoor tennis championship at the Parade Grounds Tennis Center in Brooklyn. Play continues tonight at 6 P.M.

title: Schoolbook Aid for Manila
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (Reuters)A $25 million loan to the Philippines for the writing and production of textbooks has been announced by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. The money will be used in a plan to introduce 98 million new textbooks into public primary and secondary schools by 1984.

title: KING AND BLAND GIVE CONCERT AT BEACON
description: B. B. King had been making blues recordings for three years In 1952, when he played the guitar on some of the earliest records by Bobby Bland. Mr. Bland went on to become the undisputed master of the Southern blues circuit, while Mr. King eventually expanded his following and became the first bluesman to headline in Las Vegas.

title: Births
description: Steve and Carol (nee Hassan) Joyfully announce the birth of their daughter, Stacy Beth, born March 5th. The proud grandparents are Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Hassan and Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Bromberger.

title: University of Pennsylvania Sets $335 TuitionFee Ri
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 20 (UPI)Undergraduate tuition and fees at the University of Pennsylvania will be increased from $3,790 to $4,125 for the 19761977 academic year.

title: Divine Comedies
description: Auden would have liked this bookin fact, he is mentioned in it as one of the spirits who, from the next world, act as patrons of the living. A spirit named Ephraim tells the narrator, J. M., and his friend, D. J., that spirits must return to earth repeatedly, as to a school, until they have worked through their ignorance. Then they obtain peace from representation, graduate to the lowest of NINE STAGES/Among the curates and the minor mages and become patrons themselves. Ephraim was once a Greek Jew living in Asia Minor; in another incarnation he was a favorite of the Emperor Tiberius.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Outsized plans. When Parker Ladd, whose job it is to arrange such affairs for the Association of American Publishers, announced plans for the seminar, he thought he'd do well to get 125 registrants at $25 and more a head. When it was held in the Hotel Plaza's ballroom the other Thursday morning, 375 people showed up. If anyone still doubts that the liveliest corner of book publishing today is occupied by the trade paperbackthose outsized, often profusely illustrated volumes priced $3.95 and uphe should have watched the audience intently taking notes on what the panel of publishers and booksellers had to say, then furiously discuss it during coffee breaks.

title: CUBA IS DISCUSSING AID FOR JAMAICA
description: New contacts between Jamaica and Cuba, among other nations, on the question of aid for the Jamaican security forces reflect growing concern in Jamaica and elsewhere over the island's ability to cope with any serious internal disturbances.

title: FOOD
description: THE enthusiasm with which Americans have taken to Chinese food is frequently matched by the desire to cook it, too, a fact well documented by the growing number of classes in Chinese cooking.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Republican Peter A. Peyser called here for a meeting of the state's Congressional delegation and the heads major local corporations to discuss possible Federal measures to stem the flight of business from New York City. Mr. Peyser, a Republican from Westchester and the Bronx who is challenging Senator James L. Buckley, RepublicanConservative of New York, for his Senate seat, said he would like to convene the emergency conference in Washington the first week in April. Mr. Peyser said the conference could explore avenues that might be open to the Federal Government in order to prevent the continued exodus (of business from New York.

title: It's the Little Things That Count in Boating, Too
description: When Dr. Alan J. Wasserman of Manhattan has time on his hands, he tinkers with his yacht. It is a graceful craft, with a wellpolished mahogany deck, a light blue hull, and blue and yellow sails, and Dr. Wasserman built it himself. When the weather is pleasant, he eaves his Central Park West apartment and takes her for a lazy cruise, or perhaps to race with his other yachting friends.

title: In Memoriam
description: FELDMANBlanche Kaplan, March 21, 1955; Morris Kaplan, April 21, 1960; Dora KapIan, Aug. 21, 1968. In loving memory.

title: More Use Connecticut Buses
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., March 20 (AP)Ridership on statesubsidized buses in the Hartford, New Haven and Stamford areas rose for the sixth consecutive month in February, the State Department of Transportation said. According to the State Transportation Commissioner, James Shugrue, 1.9 million passengers rode the buses in February.

title: Japanese Freighter Sinks
description: TOKYO, March 20 (AP) I The 2,958ton Japanese freighter Senyo Maru sank in rough seas in Bashi Channel south of Taiwan yesterday and 6 of its 24 crewmen were reported still missing, the owners of the ship, the Senko Unyu Company of Osaka, said today.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: For the 7.5 million residential customers of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, the lengthy process of installing a phone is being shortcircuited. The old way, of course, was calling the phone company and making an appointment for installation, which meant waiting around for the installers. That's beine abolished.

title: POLITICS
description: SEVERAL months ago Representative Otis G. Pike was a hot political property. As the newly appointed chairman of the House Select Committee on Intelligence, which was investigating the. Central Intelligence Agency, the Riverhead Democrat became a national figure overnight as he engaged in a highly publicized confrontation with President. Ford and Secretary of State Henry Kissinger over the release of C.I.A. files to the committee.

title: No Thank You, Mr. President
description: It costs, I would guess, between $50,000 and $100,000 a year for a good newspaper to maintain a White House correspondent. If I were a publisher I would use the money to improve the food in the employees cafeteria or, at least, give it to the A.S.P.C.A.

title: Premature Victory Gestures Often End in Defeat
description: One Monday evening a few years ago, Dave Smith of the Pittsburgh Steelers spiked the football in the familiar fashion to mark the end of a touchdown run, Unfortunately, he was on the 3yard line at the time. The ball wound up rolling out of the end zone or a touchback, and Smith wound up looking for a place to hide from his coach and teammates.

title: The Soil Is Almost ReadyAre You?
description: Experienced gardeners anxious to get an early start on the vegetable garden eagerly await that time when frost is out of the ground. They know that they can plant seeds of a number of hardy or cold resistant vegetables long before the date of the last killing frost where they live. In the vicinity of New York City, ail.: could be late March. For peas, early cabbage, broccoli, lettuce, radishes, turnips, beets and spinach early planting often means the difference between success or failure.

title: Pension Funds Here Win Clearance on Aiding City
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., March 20 (AP)President Ford announced here today that he had signed legislation allowing five New York City employee pension funds to preserve their taxexempt status even if they purchased New York obligations, which had been prohibited by Federal law.

title: If You Go
description: to Cornwall and explore by car, remember that smallness is the key. A small car makes it easier to negotiate the narrow lanes that lead to tiny villagesunless you go in fall or winter when all the county's good things can be experienced free of fellow emmets. Take a train to Exeter in Devon from Paddington Station in London: about a fourhour trip. There are several car hire firms in Exeter (but neither Hertz nor Avis). Acquire a Texaco map of southern England; drive west to Launceston and then on to Boscastle. Boscastle has two good hotels: the de Bottreaux and the Wellington. At the Bottreaux one can spend a week for less than 370, including bed, breakfast and dinner (from October through June it is less expensive).

title: Economists At Bay
description: Poverty was last high on the national agenda in the mid1960's, as reflected in the programs and goals of the Great Society. Though the magnitude of the problem was apparent, there seemed to be likely solutions then. A decade laterafter a wrenching war, political protest, racial upheaval, governmental crisispoverty and the poor are again high in the national consciousness. This time, however, there is a difference, for confidence in workable solutions is in short supply. Indeed, there is increasing doubt that anything at all can be done about anything, for, according to the new conventional wisdom, we are at the end of that period of phenomenal postwar growth.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: BUENOS AIRES. Argentina has everything a nation needs to succeed, and for most of this century it strode ahead of the rest of Latin America as a developing, Western society. Now, it is reeling backward.

description: To the Editor: My congratulations on your article about Lefrak City [Lefrak City Crucible of Racial Change, Feb. 1]. I think Lefrak City sums up one of the most important issues that American society must facenamely, that it is most difficult for decent peopleblack, white, green, yellow, blueto live next door to people who have all sorts of pathologies.

description: ROMEEnrico Berlinguer, head of the Italian Communist Party which aspires to sharing control of this country's Government, insists that whenand ifhis massive Marxist apparatus assumes ministerial responsibility it will remain a faithful supporter of NATO for so long as it endures.

description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, March 20 (AP) JoAnne Carner of the United States carded a twounderpar 71 today for a twoday total of 143 to take the lead in a women's golf tournament at the Grange Links. Four strokes behind was Jane Lock of Australia, last year's winner.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Seaver and His Loyalties
description: To the Sports Editor: I am deeply indebted to Tom Seaver for his admirable position that My first loyalty is to my family, not the Mets. It releases me from what has become an onerous responsibilityloyalty to Tom Terrific, the Mets and the entire baseball scene.

Philip William Noel of Rhode Island has stayed put.

title: Green, on 67 for 206, Gains Stroke Lead
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 20 (AP)Hubert Green the winner of last week's Doral open, kept hig eye on a second consecutive tournament victory when tie shot a 67 today for the thirdround lead in the $175,000 Gerater Jacksonville open golf event.

title: Museum at home
description: Marilynn and Ivan Karp found the ideal space for them and their e x traordina r y collections in a Soho loft. In many ways, they are the ultimate collectors. Tally their inventory: American saltglaze crocks, 19thcentury landscape and portrait paintings, 20thcentury paintings and sculpture, Art Nouveau and Art Deco sculpture, antique kitchen and carpentry tools, turnofthecentury tableware, commemorative spoons of the Dionne quintuplets, CocaCola trays, embossed cigarbox papers and 1940's decals.

title: Agents, to Open Briefcase, Set Off Blast Near Court
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 20 (AP)An explosion set off by bomb squad investigators to blast open a suspicious briefcase Saturday rocked a hallway near the courtroom where Patricia Hearst was found guilty of bank robbery only 90 minutes earlier.

title: DYSON PROPOSES FASTER LICENSING
description: ALBANY, March 20  The State Commerce Commissioner, in another of the Carey administration's moves to aid business in the state, proposed setting a threemonth time limit in which to act on most requests, or state licenses or permits.

title: Lure of a New Life
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I. THE island of St. Thomas, a sliver of lush vegetation and Caribbean beaches of silken sand is home now to at least 50 former New Jerseyans who fled the Aressures of living in the country's most urban state.

title: Hotel Fire in Israel Kills 4; 20 American Tourists Escape
description: TEL AVIV, March 20 (AP)A predawn fire burned out an eightstory Israeli resort hotel today, killing four tourists and injuring 46. Some guests leaped from windows to escape the flimes, authorities said.

title: A Bridge to Solitude
description: ONE of Melva MurrayWhite's earliest memories is of dance. I had started to take a at a neighborhood recreation center in Philadelphia when I was 2 years old, the young soloist with the Dance Theater of Harlem remarked between performances on a recent Saturday afternoon. I studied there until I was 4.

title: Governor Is Seeking to Ease State Marijuana Law
description: ALBANY, March 20Governor Carey has been privately circulating among legislators a rough draft of a bill to decriminalize the possession of up to two ounces of marijuana and the transfer, as a gift, of up to one ounce.

title: David de Sieyes And Miss Scott Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Gordon Scott Jr. of Boston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Porter Scott, to David Conroy de Sieyes, son of Mrs. William Risley of Litchfield, Conn., and the late J. Malcolm de Sieyes of Washington, Conn.

title: Dr. Prinz Named Chairman Of World Jewish Group
description: Dr. Joachim Prinz of Orange, N.J., has been elected chairman of the World Conference of Jewish Organizations, it was announced yesterday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Thailand last night ordered the United States to close its remaining military installations and withdraw all its military personnel, except 270 military aid advisers, in the next four months. The decision was announced after a meeting of the Thai Cabinet that followed a deadlock in negotiations begun nearly a year ago between the two countries on the future of American military personnel in Thailand. Prime Minister Kukrit Pramoj said that the Government had issued the order because agreement could not be reached on the question of Thai jurisdiction over American personnel. There are about 4,000 American military personnel, mostly noncombat troops, in Thailand. The United States had been negotiating in the hope of keeping about 3,000 troops to operate certain installations. Most of the combat forces had been withdrawn by last Dec. 20. [1:5.]

title: What's Doing in NASSAU COUNTY
description: GEOGRAPHYNassau County begins on Long Island where New York City ends. It is about 15 miles long and 20 miles wide, Like Suffolk County, its larger, more rural neighbor, Nassau, with its excellent beaches and sandy coves, was shaped by huge glaciers about 40,000 years ago. The county was settled in 1643 by colonists from Stamford, Conn., led by John Carman, and was incorporated 77 years ago. As recently as 20 years ago there were large dairy farms in Nassau. But the postWorld War II exodus from the city has made the county into what Lee E. Koppelman, Long Island's chief planner, calls a thoroughly suburban set of communities. However, a sufficient number of bucolic areas remaid and there are more than enough beaches and parks to insure a sense of openness. Although Nassau is habitually called New York's bedroom county, those who live thereand there are 1.5 million of themlike to think of their area as having a distinctly separate identity from that of the urban landscape to which about 175,000 of them commute for a livelihood.

title: Fresh Start For Villager With a Past: The Albert
description: When William Ryder, a restaurateur, opened his squat, stately hotel in Greenwich Village in 1883, he named it after his brother, Albert Pinkham Ryder, who was then an eccentric but promising painter.

title: Music: EastWest Group
description: One of the most pleasant aspects of American culture is its ability to breed eccentrics. Even if the general history of a particular art form at any given time isn't all that impressive, one can usually find some lonely, idiosyncratic creator, unappreciated by the world at large or even fellow artists, steadily turning out work that pleases him. Often the result is naive or downright worthless. But sometimes it's at least piquantly interesting, and very occasionally (cf. Charles Ives) it's extraordinary.

title: Mr. Ford and the Scarlet S
description: DURHAM, N. C., March 19A slowpaced but real improvement in economic conditions undoubtedly has helped Gerald Ford defeat Ronald Reagan in five consecutive primaries, and should help Mr. Ford win a sixth in this state on Tuesday. Mr. Ford has not been reluctant to point with pride to the rising economic indicators that show, he says, his skill in leading the nation out of recession without reviving inflation.

description: In his article, Notes on Seeing Barry Lyndon (Feb. 29), Harold Rosenberg equates information with cultivation.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Leslie W. Engler of Quechee, Vt., formerly of Tenafly, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Marie Engler, to Edmund M. See, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar T. See of Westport, Conn. A wedding in June is planned.

title: Laurence Wilson Fiance Of Morli T. Nicodemus
description: The engagement of Maureen Townsend Nicodemus to Laurence Phelps Wilson has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Richard Townsend Nicodemus of Smithtown, L.I., parentm of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John O. Wilson of Hamden, Conn.

description: I am opposed to the plan to build the Steuber chemical tank farm in Jersey City. Such a construction would be an environmental hazard.

title: Battle Over Morgan Land Nearing a Key Phase
description: IN 1984, the 448acre estate of Henry Morgan, grandson of J. P. Morgan, was added to the village of Asharoken. Joining a parcel of that relatively small size wouldn't have much impact in most communities. But it doubled the size of Asharoken.

description: ON this first day of spring, some budding vegetable gardeners in New Jersey may still be uncertain about the best site for their new garden.

description: PATERSON, N. J., March 20 Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, 45472, and John Artis, 45473, exchanged their prison numbers for freedom here today.

description: LOS ANGELES, March 20 With a burst of 12 consecutive points with less than three minutes remaining, the University of California, Los Angeles, defeated Arizona, 8266, today in the Western Regional final and qualified for the semifinals of the National Collegiate basketball tournament.

title: STAMPS
description: Both the United Nations and the United States are putting out new issues on the same date, April 23, with the U. N. heralding international efforts to spur trade and development and the U. S. issuing a special single for bulk mailings.

title: Coin Caper
description: Look again at the next bright new quarter you put into a vending machine. You may do better with an old dull one. The Bicentennial commemorative quarters sometimes get jammed before making it through the machine's acceptor device. The result: no product and no quarter returned.

title: Dreamboat: The Long Search Ends
description: One bright morning in August of 1972, our boatofthemoment with family of five aboard was tied up in Falmouth Harbor in Massachusetts waiting for the slack tide at Woods Hole. As we occupied ourselves with deck  swabbing, people stopped alongside with the usual friendly questions. We told them the boat was a Columbia 36, and that we had chartered it out of Wickford, R.I.

title: DEFENDERS KEEP BRIDGE LAURELS
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 20The Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship, the prestige event of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here, was won in the early hours of this morning by the defending champions headed by Dr. George Rosenkranz of Mexico City.

title: Without Watergate, the Campaign Is Part Illusion
description: For the better part of two years, ending in 1974, the United States was preoccupied by a trauma, the Watergate scandals that brought down a President and most of his cabinet. Yet in 1976, except for an occasional, jarring reminder by Ronald Reagan, the Presidential campaign so far has played before the American people almost as if Watergate never happened.

title: Engagements
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leon I. Bedrlrk, Woodsbureh, N.Y. and Rabbi and Mrs. Seymour Hirschman take pleasure to announcing the engagement of their children Sue and Samuel. A November weddlna Is planned.

title: ZINA SCHIFF SHOWS A RICH VIOLIN TONE
description: Looking younger than her 23 years, but playing with the assured ease of a veteran, Zina Schiff reenforced the excellent impression of her 1972 debut at her concert Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The violinist has a full, rich tone, and the sensitivity to mold gracefully proportioned, stylistically sound performances.

description: TOY (Mrs. Justin Herold, judge)1, Mrs. Walter M. Jetfords Jr.'s and Michael Wolf's Pekingese, Ch. Yang Kee Bernard; 2, Terence Child's and Joseph Champanne's Yorkshire terrier, Ch. Carnaby Rock N Roll; 3, Helen Daberkow's PU9, Ch. Huck Hill Wilbur; 4, Lmily Gunning's Shit lzu Cherielong's Bronze Bandit.

title: INVESTING
description: When the Dow Jones industrial average first closed above 1,000 in late 1972, some stockbrokers hailed the event as magical and romantic.

title: Osborne's Latest  Slang, Bash, Fizzle
description: John Osborne's Watch It Come Down is the first of his plays in 10 years to be staged by the National Theater. Its recent presentation at the Old Vic did not confirm the management's appraisal. The audience found it ludicrous and, by the end, exasperating. Nonetheless, the play is one of six productions that have been transferred from the Old Vic to the National's new home, which opened last week.

title: A Lone New Face in Oil Refining
description: GARYVILLE, La.Despite considerable rhetoric about freeing the United States of reliance on foreign energy sources, only one new oil refinery is under construction in this country now.

title: THAILAND ORDERS LAST U.S. FORCES TO LEAVE BY JULY
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 20The Government tonight ordered the United States to close its remaining military installations in Thailand and withdraw all its military personnel, except 270 military aid advisers, in the next four months.

title: Turtle Diary
description: We must take good writing wherever we can find it, and one of the places where it can be found today is in genresdetective stories, children's books, reportage, science fictionnot traditionally identified as the precincts of high art. Yet the prestige of the novel and the short story remains so potent that even those writers who have mastered newer and more popular forms sooner or later try their hand at serious fiction. Thomas M. Disch is the young author of marry volumes of science fiction; Getting Into Death is his first collection of short stories, and only one of the stories could be classified as science fiction. Turtle Diary is an adult novel by Russell Hoban, who has published 37 children's books.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: and AleNaoder Slobodvanik, pianist; Henry Lewis, conductor. Works of Elgar, ProWiley and Weber. Wednesday, 8:30 P.M. $857.50. (201) 8429000.

title: Baseball Leagues Both Eye Toronto
description: Baseball's club owners waged war on two fronts yesterdayfirst with their players, then with one another.

title: Evonne Goolagong Gains Dallas Final
description: DALLAS, March 20 (AP)Evonne Goolagong of Australia and Martina Navratilova, who fought off a painful wrist injury, advanced to the final of the $75,000 Maureen Connolly Brinker tennis tournament tonight.

title: Plants Need Some Nutritional Push to Make Them Thrive
description: Of the three elements in commercial fertilizers, nitrogen has the quickest and most pronounced effect. It tends to encourage aboveground vegetative growth and to give the leaves a deep green color. It also acts as a regulator of the utilization of potassium, phosphorus and other constituents. Plants receiving insufficient nitrogen are stunted in growth and have restricted root systems. The leaves turn yellow green and tend to drop off. The addition of available nitrogen will cause a remarkable change, indicative of the unusual activity of this element within the plant.

title: Philadelphia Refurbishes For the Bicentennial
description: The popular complaint that the Bicentennial is a bore doesn't hold in Philadelphia, at least not in its two great art museums, where the year is being celebrated with minimum emphasis on knee breeches and powdered wigs. Philadelphians, after all, have grown up with the Liberty Bell, and Independence Hall is so familiar that it is only a degree more venerable than Wanamaker's. Sidestepping clichs, the Pennsylvania. Academy of the Fine Arts and the Philadelphia Museum of Art are observing the Bicentennial with one Tricentennial and two Centennial exhibitions and are giving all three a vigorous here andnow emphasis.

title: Letters
description: in machinereadable form is not as hard, but still many times harder than, say, to transcribe a musical composition on a roll of playerpiano tape. It is simply and plainly not true in any sense that real computing machines are now almost selfreplicating. Nor is it at all clear that, even if we wanted to achieve it, we could ever build practical selfreplicating computers.

title: The Region In Summary
description: It appears that a New Jersey income tax, sought by the state's Governors in vain for years, may be close to enactment. Knowledgeable observers believe the State Senate, which has been the naysayer five times in the last two years, will go along when it takes up the matter this week.

title: THE WIZARD OF LAZARD
description: On a Monday morning last November, a dark month in a string of dark months for the city, you could have found the nine members of the Municipal Assistance Corporation at a long table in a conference room at the Park Avenue offices of their general counsel, Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, amp; Garrison. All but one were deep in debate over whether to bring in a new staff director, who, for unfathomable reasons, had been found in Hawaii. The ninth memberand chairmanof M.A.C.. Felix Rohatyn, slumped at the head of the table and stared out the window.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONWhatever happened to the economic issue in the Presidential election campaign?

title: The Good Old Days: A Matter of Opinion
description: It was an Inspirational spring day. The boatyard was bathed in sunshine. A soft breeze wafted the scent of flowers past the cockpita perfect time for prelaunch chores, but there Weren't any to perform.

title: Teachers and Students Unrest Upsets a Quaker School Here
description: Emotional turmoil in the outwarely peaceful environs of the Friends Seminary on East 16th Street in Manhattan culminated last week in events that left the Quakers who attend and operate the school uneasy.

title: Opera Strike Cancels Giscard's Merit Gala
description: PARIS, March 20 (AP)President Valery Giscard d'Estaing was forced today to cancel a gala opera performance to which he had invited 1,500 people because stagehands at the Paris Opera have gone on strike.

title: Who Gets How Much
description: In March, 1975, apparently as an aid in salary negotiations, the National Basketball Association office issued a confidential memorandum giving the salaries of the forwards It judged to be the best the league. Following are the contract terms of each of the players listed after Bill Bradley:

title: Music in Review
description: In a hymn collection published in Boston in 1849 there is a short account of the death of Mozart that turns the composer into a Little Eva. He is pictured as having just finished his Requiem (which he did not finish), saying farewell sweetly to his daughter, Emelie (who never existed), and looking forward to meeting his wife, Constanze, in heaven (she survived him by several years).

title: They're Rediscovering the Songs of the Gay 90 s
description: At a time when popular singers like Cleo Laine and Barbra Streisand are venturing into the classical music field, two classically trained musicians  Joan Morris; mezzosoprano, and William Bolcom, pianist and composer are travelling in the opposite direction, making a considerable name for themselves rediscovering the popular song.

title: Was Tetley Too Modern For the Stuttgart Ballet?
description: A mighty fortress is the Stuttgart BalletWhich is exactly what it has had to be to withstand the forces battering it from within and without since the death of its founder, John Cranko, in June 1973. The latest blow was the unexpected resignation this winter of Cranko's successor, Glen Tetley, the 50yearold American choreographer, after a tenure of less than two years. Although Tetley's contract runs through July and he will direct a new version of Stravinsky's Le Sacre du Printemps this spring, his duties as director have been assumed by Marcia flaycltse, 37, the company's Brazilian prima ballerina who will continue as director at least through next season and pos. sibly even longer.

title: RUMORS OF A COUP RISE IN ARGENTINA
description: BUENOS AIRES. March 20Lieut. Gen. Jorge Rafael Videla, the likely head of a government junta if the Argentine armed forces seize power, chatted amiably today over champagne with Peronist ministers at a regimental anniversary party.

title: Lawyer Marries Suzanne Glasser
description: Suzanne Glasser, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin F. Glasser of Highland Park, N.J., was married last night to Gilbert Lang Mathews, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving A. Mathews of San Antonio and New York.

title: Jackson Urges Guarantee To Egypt Against Invasion
description: SYRACUSE March 20Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington said today that the United States should issue guarantees to Egypt that it would not be invaded by any foreign power.

title: Black Political Convention Begins Petition Campaign
description: CINCINNATI, March 20 Hundreds of participants at the National Black Political Convention converged today on Lincoln Heights, a predominantly black suburban cornmunity, to collect 5,000 signatures to put the convention's choice for President on the ballot as the Independent Freedom Party candidate.

title: Battling Against Blights and Bugs
description: Millions of people of all ages have learned the pleasures and values of growing their own vegetables. With the vast public press and Extension promotions since 1974, nearly 80 million Americans have become involved in this venture, most with great success and others with some disappointments.

title: Lane Change For Lovers
description: OVERS Lane, AmeriLca's contribution to the courting ritual, has lost so much ground to suburban development, especially in Nassau, that couples have been forced to become bolder, parking off major thoroughfares and at shopping centers.

title: O'Neill Says Ford Blocks Election Law Reforms
description: WASHINGTON, March 20The House majority leader accused President Ford today of blocking campaign reform legislation now that he seems assured of the Republican nomination for President and his need for Federal primary subsidies no longer exists.

title: AIM OF SAHARANS IS INDEPENDENCE
description: AIUN, Western Sahara, March 20 (UPI)They squatted around a coal fire that glowed bright orange. In the coals lay a bent, blackened tin pot used to brew sweet mint tea.

title: Soviet Pig Killer Jailed
description: MOSCOW, March 20 (AP)A Soviet tractor driver who fortified himself with liquor and then drunkenly shot two pigs at a collective farm has been sentenced to two years in jail, Pravda reported today. The hunter hoped to shoot wild boar, the Communist Party daily reported, heard snorting from the edge of the village. Flush with alcohol, he leapt forward, killed two collective farm pigs, loaded the corpses on his vehicle and brought the

title: A Squirt in Orange Juice Prices
description: Will frozen orange juice be cheaper now that Florida's annual frost scare is over and the bulk of the citrus crop is nearly harvested? No, it won't.

title: A Prince of Our Disorder
description: It is bewildering to read the mass of testimony that has accumulated since Lawrence of Arabia exploded legendsize into public awareness in 1919. According to the source, Lawrence has been described as a sadistic homosexual for whom the Arab uprising against the Turks in 1916 was an adventure in procurement, or as the most generous man who ever lived; as a fraud who took credit for what others accomplished in Arabia, or as the only important military mind to emerge from World War I. Virtually everyone who knew him during and after the war seems to have been convinced that he was a genius, though they rarely agreed as to what sort. For Robert Graves and George Bernard Shaw, he was one of the important writers of the century, while his service mates in the R.A.F. during the 1920's and 1930's remember him as the best mechanic, or quartermaster's assistant or boat designer they ever knew. Shaw's wife described him as a d6perately kind man, a sort of saint. While, for a decade, the British Foreign Office had troubled dreams about his real ambitions, and breathed a sigh of relief when he was finally killed in a motorcycle accident, after flirting with the possibility for 15 years high speed driving over bad roads.

title: Delights of Netsuke in Newark
description: NEWARK THE netsuke, or decorarative toggles, that Japanese artists crafted in the 17th, 18th and 19th centuries were made by painters and sculptors. They were crafted as a means of distraction from usual pursuits, and served as a catharsis or relief for the artists, as well as for the viewer. They were intended to put us in a good mood.

title: Crack of Bat Happy Sound For Sun Belt
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20When the great shutdown of the baseball business ended the other night after 17 days, a bartender named Hoot Gibson stopped the music and announced the news to the crowd. The noise of the St. Patrick's Day revelers subsided, they listened, then the lounge erupted into the loudest cheers and whistles of the night.

title: In London, Hopes of Mediation Role Ebb
description: LONDON, March 20  The British Goverment has virtually abandoned all hope of intervening to help achieve a settlement in Rhodesia following yesterday's collapse of the talks between Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia and the black nationalist leader, Joshua Nkomo.

title: Cup Scoring Called Unfair
description: BEAUPRE, Quebec, March 20Nancy Greene Raine, once the skiing darling of Canada, looked at the dual slalom course on this fogshrouded afternoon as top women internationalists competed for Nations Cup team points and said she thought the present scoring system unfair.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SETS ANGOLA PULLOUT
description: UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., March 20South Africa informed Secretary General Kurt Waldheim today that it intended to withdraw its troops from southern Angola not later than March 27 if certain Assurances it had received proved to be correct.

title: Edgar Joyce Weds Sarah McFarland
description: In St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning, Sarah Ann McFarland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. McFarland of Fort Lee, N. J., became the bride of Edgar Michael Joyce, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Joyce of Eastchester, N. Y. The Rev. Thomas Nielson performed the ceremony.

title: Five Mafia Families Open Rosters to New Members
description: For the first time since 1957, New York's five Mafia families have been authorized by the national Mafia commission to initiate new members, according to law enforcement officials.

title: Why Ford and Carter Are in the Lead
description: WASHINGTON, March 20ms success of Gerald Ford and former Governor Carter in the Presidential race so far cannot be explained adequately by computerized analysis of voting districts ar by the prestige of the Presidency or the tireless energy and administrative skill of Mr. Carter.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: SAN FRANCISCOWhen David B. Gold, a 49yearold San Francisco lawyer, scans a corporation's profit and loss statement, he looks for what isn't there. And often he finds what he is looking for.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.There has been a virtual halt the oncefrenzied pace of condominiumbuilding along the Gold Coast and elsewhere in Florida, but the depression of the state's construction industry no longer dampens spirits to the degree it did last year. Thanks to the general economic recovery in the nation, the bust in building is being largely offset by some concrete gains in other business areas.

title: PEOPLE
description: NOT bad for a tyro. With these words Richard DyerBennet summed up his return to the Long Island concert stage as the narrator of Aaron Copland's A Lincoln Portrait and Prokofiev's Peter and the Wolf. Mr. DyerBennet is scarcely a novice on the stage. The man known for at least two generations as The 20th Century Minstrel has a repertoryranging from the 13th century to the presentof 600 songs, including more than 100 of his own compositions. But he is not only a performer. Mr. DyerBennet is at present an associate professor in the theater arts at the State University Center at Stony Brook, where he applies classic belcanto training to the speaking voice. Language, he says, is secondary function. The words can only give you a gross sense of what is meant. While he does not see himself going back to being primarily a performer ever again, neither does he foresee ever stopping entirely.

title: For young readers
description: As an only child Dorrie O'Brien lives a silky life in upperstrata San Francisco. Her doting parents include Dorrie in all their plans. Before Dorrie was 10 she had been to Mexico and the opera. This tightlyknit trio has resulted in a smug, selfcentered knowitall.

title: Recital: By Elly Ameling
description: Elly Ameling is one of the loveliest artists now before the public, and nowhere was the soprano more appealing than in Schumann's Frauenliebe Leben cycle in her recital in Hunter College Assembly Hall on Friday night. This set of saccharine lyrics about a woman's falling in love, getting married, having a baby and becoming a widow is redeemed by the music. Too often, however, it is sung with so much emotional force that the listener feels drowned in sentiment that robs the music of its touching lyricism.

title: TV VIEW
description: Norman Lear was in New York recently, demonstrating once again that he is one of the more fascinating figures on the current entertainment scene. The producer is connected, in varying degrees, with an extraordinary array of TV series: All in the Family, Maude, Sanford and Son, The Jeffersons, Good Times, One Day at Time, The Dumplings and, on the syndicated lrcuit, Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman. Has such unprecedented success spoiled Norman Lear? The answer would depend, evidently, on which part of the man you choose, or are 14314, to see.

title: Minibus Sales Lag in an EnergyConscious Age
description: Minl transit moves along at a mini pace.

title: The Region/Continued
description: The earliest clear warning to New Yorkers that their city might one day be playing hideandseek with bankruptcy came five years ago. took the form of a New York City pension agreement so generous that the state, worried over the me too effect on pensions for its own civil servants, put the accord in a legislative deep freeze. This upset of a signed contract touched off a twoday strike in the city.

title: An IceAge Snapshot Has Unexpected Clarity
description: New studies of what the earth's surface and climate were like 18,000 years ago have produced results that contradict some longstanding assumptions about climatic conditions at the height of the last ice age.

description: Economic Indicators

title: CITY MAY CHANGE FISCAL PRIORITIES
description: Beame administration officials say a fullscale economic recovery program will force the city to make choices among basic priorities, such as dropping old ideals for mixed zoning, earmarking limited road and sewer funds for industrial parks and even choosing whether parts of a precinct's shrunken police force would best be deployed at a factory gate or on residential street.

title: Bergen: Comics Haven
description: THE idea that a comedian on television or in the nightclubs of New York and Las Vegas can get a laugh with a comment like, If I do well here, they've promised to open me in Hackensack, is readily conceded by the comedians who live in Bergen County.

title: Dave Anderson
description: After nearly 10 years in prison, Rubin (Hurricane) Carter has emerged as a folk hero surrounded by celebrities. Muhammad Ali is with him. Bob Dylan wrote a song about him. The Rev. Ralph Abernathy talks of building a tent city in Trenton until the retrial exonerates him. George Lois, the New York advertising man, organized a committee of influential people for him. It's of very fashionable now to be involved with The Times Rubin Carter, much more so than when he was a middleweight contender. All these people have truly helped Rubin Carter, but he remembers when he was forgotten. He remembers the one man primarily responsible for his freedom on $20,000 bail, pending the retrial ordered unanimously last week by the New Jersey Supreme Court for the 1966 murder of three patrons in a Paterson, N.J., tavern.

title: The Lollipop of Telly's Private Eye
description: WHEN Telly Savalas, television's Irrespressible Kojak, asks Christina Sarantakos, Who loves ya baby? she doesn't have to wonder. Telly loves her.

title: The Joys and Perils of Coaching Softball. in Tanzanial
description: I was once manager of the best softball team in tropical Africa. (Actually, my title was softball master, but I signed my correspondence as manager.) Our season at Magamba Secondary School, near Lushoto in the Usambara Mountains of northern Tanzania, reached its climax in October, appropriately enough, with the annual interhouse knockout tournament among our four dormitory teams.

title: Rhodesia Facing War
description: There was never much chance that the talks between the white minority Government and one faction from the black African majority would produce a workable agreement for Rhodesia's political future. Even if these negotiators had been able to agree on a constitutional blueprint, it might well have been repudiated by more radical African leaders, Including those preparing in Mozambique for guerrilla warfare against Rhodesia.

title: 2 JEWS BID FORD HALT EGYPT SALES
description: The heads of two major Orthodbx Jewish groups called on President Ford last night to cari..1 his plans to lift a milltaiy, embargo against Egypt by selltng it six C130 military transport planes.

title: Jane Tishman Wed To John Eric Sellar
description: Jane Tishman, a theatrical production assistant, and John Eric Seller, a vice president and branch manager of the Greenwich Savings Bank, were married her yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations by the Rev. Melvin Hawthorne.

title: MISS HEARST IS CONVICTED ON BANK ROBBERY CHARGES; FACES SENTENCE APRIL 19
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 20 Patricia Campbell Hearst was convicted of armed robbery today by a jury that refused to believe her story that she was an innocent victim forced into crime by the group of revolutionaries that had kidnapped her 10 weeks before.

title: Cecile Strauss Will Be Bride Of Noah Hanft
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sigi Strauss of Baltimore have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cecile Basia Strauss, to Noah Jonathan Hanft, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Hanft of Great Neck. L.I. A summer wedding, in the old Lloyd Street Synagogue in Baltimore is planned. the School of International Affairs of Columbia University and is a financial and political analyst with American International Group Inc.

title: The Steel Steal
description: The economic ideologues of the Ford Administration lose no opportunity to sing the praises of the market system and to limit Government intervention for social reasons. But somehow all these strictures are easily forgotten when competition proves painful for some part of the constituency.

title: GIFTS TO COLLEGES DOWN $80 MILLION
description: Gifts to 986 public and private colleges and universities across the nation fell by $80 million, to an estimated $2.16 billion, in the academic year that ended June 30, 1975, a 3.6 percent decline from 1974, according to a survey by the Council for Financial Aid to Education.

title: Hustlers and Con Men
description: $14.95? Well, it's not a con because the book isn't blank paper, it's full of good reading. This book has details on every con except Kublai Khan and the exploits of the great swindlers offer delicious thrills to us taxpayers. The elegant Victor The Count Lustig conned Al Capone in the early twenties. He told the gangster he could double $50,000 for him in 60 days, and Capone shelled out. The Count deposited the 50 Gnotes in a safe deposit box and spent the next two months in New York fleecing chumps as usual. Then he reported back to Chicago. Surrounded by Capone's goons he told Scarface with deep embarrassment that he had failed in his mission. Before anything got nasty, The Count placed the neat stack of bills back on Capone's desk.

title: DAVID WAINHOUSE, A LAWYER, DIPLOMAT
description: WASHINGTON, March 20David W. Wainhouse, international lawyer, author and Deputy Assistant Secretary of State during the Eisenhower Administration, died here yesterday of a heart attack. He was 75 years old.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The most passionately political films being made in this country today have nothing to do with government scandals or coverups by highly placed public officials who goofed. They contain no references to Watergate, Mao, dtente, the CIA, Fanne Fox or even the Bicentennial. They make no pleas on behalf of the underprivileged. They certainly aren't revolutionary threats from some underfed underground cooperative. Instead they are what the writers of irate letters to movie critics call pure entertainment, which is usually a euphemism for mindless. They haven't the slightest interest in current affairs or social problems, or, at least, none that shows. They are totally devoid of sex and the only violence shown is nature's way. Apparently because of these things, they are films that parents by the carloads are dragging their children off to see in the fond belief that innocence is being simultaneously protected and served.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: At a time when Henry Kissinger is the target of a good deal of criticism, it is only fair to recognize his major achievements, one of which was symbolized by Egyptian President Sadat's abrogation of his treaty with the Soviets.

title: The Sports Scoreboard
description: By Reuters

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Knicks are home in Madison Square Garden at 7:30 P.M. Tuesday against the Detroit Pistons and at 8 P.M. Saturday aganst the Boston Celtics. The Nets have 8 P.M. games at the Nassau Coliseum against the Spirits of St. Louis on Wednesday and the Kentucky Colonels on Friday.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE LABOR DEPARTMENT reported that the Consumer Price Index rose only 0.1 percent in February, the smallest Increase since February 1971. The index, with 1987 equaling 100, rose to 167.1 last month. Food declined 1 percent, but commodities other than food rose 0.3 percent. Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said the annual rate of inflation would drop to 2 percent annually in the next tae or three years.

title: Rentals by the Season
description: >JUST when the waves start getting warm enough for an afternoon dip, it is time for some families living in Atlantic Beach and other spots in Nassau County to pack their bags and go elsewhere for the summer.

title: Paperbacks
description: BEHIND THE DOOR, by Giorgio Bassani. (Harcourt/ Harbrace, $2.25.) Intrigue and disillusionment in Jewish high school in an Italian provincial city when a boy learns that his best friend wears two faces: a subtle, complex, highly dramatic novel by the author of The Garden of FinziContinis.

title: Knicks Beaten by Bullets; Nets Top Squires, 109101
description: LANDOVER, Md.. March 20 (UPI)Each Washington starter scored 16 or more points tonight as the Bullets posted a 109.104 victory over the New York Knicks in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Dodging Emmetsin Cornwall: An Exploration in High Season
description: When I told a Cornish friend in London that my wife and I were leaving within a few days for his home county, he was appalled. July! Cornwall in Julyl It's the height of the emmet season. It sounded ominous  emmet being an archaic term for antbut it turned out that our friend was talking about twolegged emmets: tourists. That, too, had its ominous side, but we decided to persevere.

title: How Life Subsists In a Chilean Slum
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 14Enrique Otero makes his Jiving by looking after the cars that are parked in front of a Government ministry and hotel in downtown Santiago.

title: SHOP TALK
description: THE back room in The Great FrameUp in South Orange is lined with long workbenches at which several customers are usually busy With hammers, drills and staples.

title: Porsches Finish 1 to 6 At Sebring
description: SEBRING, Fla., March 20 (UPI)Al Holbert and Mike Keyser recovered from as early collision that sent their car to the pits for 10 minutes and came back to win the 12 hours of Sebring endurance race tonight in a sweep by Porsche Carreras.

title: Changes in Communist Parties in Developed Capitalist Nations
description: A look at the scope and background of the doctrinal changes occurring in the major Communist Parties in developed capitalist nations suggests they are not tactical or cosmetic, as some speculate, or opportunist, as Leonid. I. Brezhnev has implied. A halfcentury of experience has led to the realization that hitherto sacrosanct Communist theories are not applicable to all societies. Major points of challenge involve means of transition from capitalism to socialism, relations with the Soviet and Chinete parties, attitudes toward Soviet society, the nature of socialism envisioned.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: The article In Defense of the Pension Reform Act (Feb. 29), fails to come to grips with one of the major flaws of the Employee Retirefnent Security Act. In drafting the Act, Congress made no distinctions between the rules applicable to companies with thousands of workers and those with but a few employees.

title: Hollywood Takes On The Last Tycoon
description: Los ANGELES In The Last Tycoon F. Scott Fitzgerald described the studio back lot as thirty acres of fairyland. The acreage has shrunk since ttlen, but the moviemakers who are filming The Last Tycoon have created their ctwn magic kingdom on the Haramount back lot, complete with a simulated Western town, an artificial lake and a miniature South Seas ??? The lakeactually a huge tankis the same one di Mille used in his parting of the Red Sea. Tonight, as I watch, the waters are rag??? and a giant head of the Indian goddess Siva comes riding down the current, with two girls crouched op top of her golden curls.

description: Atlanta 500 stock car race, at Atlanta International Raceway. (TelevisionChannel 7. 7:30 P.M.)

title: C.I.A. Memo Says Warren Unit Slighted Leads on Foreign Plot;
description: WASHINGTON. March 20 (AP)A Central Intelligence Agency memorandum says the Warren Commission should have given more credence to the possibility that President Kennedy's assassination was a result of a foreign conspiracy. particularly in light of two promising leads that were not pursued.

title: REAGAN, WALLACE FACING KEY TESTS
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., March 20North Carolina, one of the nation's dozen largest states, has seldom exercised national political clout, but it may determine on Tuesday the fate of two conservative Presidential hopefuls.

title: Isabel Wadsworth Bride of J. A. Collins
description: The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Collins of La Jolla, Calif.

title: Fashion
description: This summer its possible to choose pants and Jumpsuits (all in pure cotton here) from a variety of lengthstop of the thigh, Just above the knee, midcalf and conventional ankle. The newest length is midcalf. Midcalf pants are not so distant from the 40's clam diggers, except this time around the silhouette Is a lot softer. Design detailing like side slits, drawstring waists, sailor buttons and tabs at the ankle make all the pants more interesting than the classic tailored ones so Snug lowslung shorts in sturdy white cotton are cut to the minimum. Tan cotton Tshirt has brown RollsRoyce insignia. Levi shorts, $9; Tshirt, $12, At all the Gap stores. Available in April. Seated figure wears white cotton bike pants with tabs that pull them in at the ankle. White cotton Tshirt is banded in navy. Ralph Lauren. Pants, $48; top, $12. Third floor, Bloomingdale's popular last year.

title: Where to Get Help
description: Soil, on which most of mankind depends for its food, is simply air, water, organic matter and mineral matter. Yet a most complex series of chemical, physical and bacterial reactions take place as plants grow in it.

title: Editors Choice

title: Target Plutex
description: A cell of six freelance terrorists decides to destabilize an oil cartel doing business in Angola. The lengths to which they go prove that fiction can sometimes be stranger than truth. In short order, the gang: (1) blows up the London library of the Plutex Oil Company; (2) bombs its British refinery; (3) tampers with a computer to pinkslip 60 shop stewards; (4) shoots three topechelon executives and a United States Senator in Pittsburgh.

description: Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords Jr. of New York and Michael Wolf of Christiana, Pa., have owned some very good Pekingese over the last few years. Now they have another one. He is a 4yearold Scottish import, Ch. Yang Kee Bernard.

title: McGovern Says Hanoi Offers A Report on U.S. Missing
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI)  Senator George McGovern said today that Prime Minister Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam had offered to give a status report on the available information on Americans missing M action in Southeast Asia.

title: Aerial Lifeline to the Hinterlands
description: Ten years ago, a businessman arrived at the airport outside a Texas town and checked in his rental car with a woman at the airline counter. She sold him his plane ticket, too, then took his baggage and stepped outside. A moment later, she appeared again at the wheel of a tank truck; he watched as she fueled the small plane on the runway and loaded his baggage aboard. When she stepped back inside the terminal, the shaken businessman said, If you're the pilot, too, I'm not going.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEL AVIV, March 20 (AP)Israeli troops moved against rioting youths in three towns in the occupied West bank today and the Arab mayor of Hebron resigned in protest.

title: Berlinguer And the Professor
description: As to the anonymity of this squib, my bank manager in Bracciano tells me that the author is one of his clients. I had already learned that. having sold over 300,000 copies in Italy, the lucky man had bought himself a Swiss villa. Such are the rewards of political satire in a country where politics is selfsatirizing. The writer's name would mean little to an American reader, so I refrain from divulging it. Does the title mean much more?

title: Those Sad Dogs May Have Eye Troubles
description: When people look at a basset hound or a bloodhound, invariably they talk about the sad expression, the pathetic look in the eyes, said Dr. K. C. Barnett. You would look sad, too, if you were affllicted with the same type eye, As a result of breeding for this sad expression, and in the case of he bloodhound with all that loose skin, frequently we have to operate for a drooping eyelid.

title: Spring
description: Yesterday's vernal equinox was a signpost, nothing more. It said that spring lies ahead, that our part of the earth now comes to the place in the annual sequence where sap rises, buds open, life is renewed. Not necessarily today, but soon; for spring is now an inevitability. Spring and change. Winter's debris may clutter the roadside find murk the brooks, but the cleanliness of new green is already in sight in protected corners, new grass, crocuses, daffodil tips.

title: Udall Sues on Indiana Law
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 20 (UPI)  Representative Morris K. Udall filed suit in United States district court yesterday. challenging Indiana's law on filing for the May 4 Presidential primary. The Arizona Democrat was ruled ineligible for the primary earlier this week after Secretary, of State Larry Conrad discovered that petitions filed by Udall campaign workera did not contain a sufficient number of signatures from one Congressional district.

Later in the week, he branches outto his wife's dance studio in SoHo, in Lower Manhattanwhere he works with a new et of fundamentals using omputers, electronic music and intricate rhythms.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Last week, Washington was the City Beautiful, as L'Enfant and McMillan intended, with the blush of magnolias and cherry blossoms laced lightly with snow. It was false spring, and false winter, and even the city didn't seem quite real. Washington can be heartbreakingly lovely in the oldfashioned way of cities as places of dignity, elegance and grace, in spite of the mayhem being visited on it by commercial developers and government builders alike.

title: The City's Beat Is Allegro Furioso
description: John Cage once wrote a piece of music in which the pianist does nothing more than stare at the keyboard for about four and a half Minutes. It was a dadaist idea and, like so much dada, had a crazy kind of logic. Cage always has been interested in sound qua sound, and in this piece he wanted the audience to concentrate on sounds in the concert hall: sounds of breathing, of creaking seats, of whispering, of the blood going through the body, of the beating of the heart. That was the music of this particular piece.

title: The Future: Laissezfaire Or C. A. B.?

Trunk and regional lines must get C.A.B. approval before entering or leaving a market or raising a fare. The commuters can go into or leave a city at will, and they can set whatever fares the traffic will bear.

title: Ideas & Trends Education, Geology, Behavior
description: Cultural attitudes toward various types of socalled mental illness in two nonWestern societies appear largely similar to Western attitudes, according to a recent study published in Science magazine. The study appears to imply that some types of mental disturbance, and social attitudes toward them, are more nearly universal than some theorists have proposed.

This is because Stephen Dobyns has given his hero, a 41yearold cop from Saratoga, N.Y., an ingenuous nature and a kid's zest for new sights and sounds. So when Sgt. Charlie Bradshaw comes to New York City to look for the missing son of an old girlfriend, the reader is privileged to see some familiar and tawdry sights with a fresh eye.

Like an architect who must often submit to the wills of the builder, engineer and municipal codes, the portraitist has to yield to the dictates of the sitter, who might view himself in a particular way. He expects the aritst to depict the particularity, and in so doing the artist may abandon his own stylistic and inter??? tenets.
