title: The High Price Of Stability In Korea
description: SEOUL, South KoreaEver since South Vietnam changed hands almost a year ago, it has been fashionable in this part of the world to say that Korea is not Vietnam, that there is little danger of the internal collapse in South Korea that permitted the Vietcong to march into Saigon.

title: How an Israeli Show Kids Israel and Gets Away With
description: Nikui Rosh, a 45minute, biweekly barrage of fastpaced political satire and buffoonery that is aired here over the state  subsidized broadcasting network, is not just a television show. It is something between a scandal and a national resource. Members of the Knesset, Israel's narliamenta frequent target of the show's cutting humorperiodically deliver indignant speeches charging it with undermining the nation's morale and demanding that it be taken off the air. Nevertheless, every other Thursday at 10 P.M. no less than two out of three Israelis, including Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin when he is not otherwise preoccupied, tune in for their Nikui Rosh (free translation: brain wash), and were they to be deprived of it, there is reason to believe that many would be extremely displeased.

title: Politics, Here & There

title: The Last European War
description: There have been several moments in the 20th century when historians have proclaimed that we had reached the end of European history, but December 1941 and the entry of Japan and the United States into the war, the date chosen by John Lukacs as the end of The Last European War, is as good as any. Indeed, dater himself saw his declaration of war on America as a turning point and stated that a historical revision on a unique scale has been imposed on by the creator.

title: Answers/Questions
description: AAZALEA/RHODODENDRON SEED (March 7) G. K., Greenwich, Conn., has a quantity of Exbury azalea and rhododendron seeds and he asked when and how to plant them. Seeds of both evergreens can be sown in a similar manner. Planting can begin any time now. The seed does not require a cold period (stratification). The seed is very fine and is best shown in shallow flat or plastic shoe boxes with drainage holes punched in the bottom with a hot ice pith. Place a mixture of sterilized soil and peat moss (equal parts) and some sand in the bottom of the container and fill to one inch from the top. Sieve sphagnum moss over the top of a depth of onehalf inch and moisten well by placing the seed pan in a tub of warm water which will seep up through the drainage holes. Dust the fine seed over the top when fully moist and insert the seed pan in a plastic bag. The seeds need warmth to germinate in about three to four weeks. They can he grown under fluorescent light or in a sunny window until mid spring when they can he transplanted outdoors to a coldframe or protected nursery bed. The seedlings should remain through their first winter undisturbed in this site with adequate winter protection. Transplant to the permanent site in the second year. Ed.

When he considers a national election as a sporting proposition, Phil's memory goes back 60 years to the campaign of 1916. President Woodrow Wilson, a reformed of football coach and college president, was running for reelection on the slogan, He kept us out of war, opposed by Charles Evans Hughes, who as Governor of New York had outlawed bookmaking and chased horse racing out of the state for a couple of years.

title: Dark Inheritance
description: Little does impusive, highspirited Susannah Button know. as Button Ore lies dying in her arms at the foot of a Cornish cliff, that this humble smuggler is not really her father. Nor was her mother of record her mother. But wait. Susannah will have to become a governess (what else?) to the snooty Dewaine family in the big manse on the hill before her dark inheritance begins to reveal itself. She will have to marry handsome Durward de Lacey, the youngest painter in the Royal Academy, and see him pass on from an overdose of laudanum. Then, in the Venetian palazzo, where mama went mad, she will learn who mama really was, and papa tooa genealogy you won't believe, my dears. All of this is set in the Victorian era, of course, when a secret identity was as obligatory as a Social Security number, only much more fun.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: TWYLA THARPThe choreographer will be joined by six dancers from her company in a brief engagement, starting Thursday, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Miss Tharp, whose Push Comes to Shove was given its premiere performance by American Ballet Theater this winter, will offer another new work set to a pastiche of music from Sousa marches to classical compositions. Also on the program is her work entitled Eight Jelly Rolls which was performed in London in 1974 but has never been seen with live music in the United States. The piece waS choreographed to eight compositions by Jelly Roll Morton. Tommy Benford, one of the original members of Morton's Red Hot Peppers will be on hand for the Brooklyn engagement along with a number of specialists in his music, including Dick Hyman and Major Holly.

title: Food
description: 2to3pound chickens, cut into serving pieces Salt and freshly ground pepper 4 tablespoons butter  cup finely chopped onion  cup finely chopped celery I bay leaf  teaspoon dried thyme or 2 sprigs fresh thyme  teaspoon grated nutmeg 2 whole cloves 1 bottle (3 cups) dry red wine  cup heavy cream  cup chopped pecans. I. Sprinkle the chicken pieces with salt and pepper to taste. 2. Heat the butter in a heavy skillet and brown the chicken pieces all over. Scatter the onion, celery, bay leaf and thyme around the pieces. Sprinkle with nutmeg. Add the cloves, wine and salt and pepper to taste. 3. Cover and simmer 30 minutes or until the chicken is tender. 4. Remove the chicken pieces and keep warm. Skim off the fat from the surface of the sauce. Reduce the sauce to about two cups. Add the cream. Return the chicken pieces and return to the boil. Add the pecans and serve hot. Yield: Six to eight servings.

title: Uncle Of Europe
description: How important are monarchs? Only a handful of the genuine article still survive; and if at present we have quite a few more tyrantsin the guise of generals, sheiks and commissarsthan kings, it is not clear that the latter weren't preferable. One of the last of the authentic royals, Edward VII's greatgranddaughter Elizabeth II, presides over the dwindling fortunes of her country, and though she can still summon up something of the pageantry Edward enjoyed, she is wholly without his power to influence, shape or alter the course of public events at home or abroad. To be sure, Edward's power was itself much diminished from that wielded by his redoubtable mother, Victoria, as she reigned over Great Britain and its Empire from 1837 to 1901 and, being prolific as a broodmare, gradually populated most of the thrones of Europe with her offspring or their children. Yet enough power still remained to make her eldest son an important figure rather than a merely symbolic figurehead, and Gordon BrookShepherd can legitimately raise the question of Edward VII's importance in the history of prewar Europe: did he make a difference?

description: The Ford Administration both spoke and acted on its currently slightly strained relationship with the Soviet Union last week, clearly reflecting the degree to which the Presidential campaign has expanded the context in which some aspects of foreign policy are being considered.

title: Oxford Sets Records in Victory
description: LONDON, March 20Oxford University's crew broke every course record in the 145year history of The Boat Race and defeated Cambridge University today by six lengths.

title: A CRIME AND ITS AFTERSHOCK
description: At 8:00 on the night of Oct. 18, 1975, KNOP, the only television station in North Platte, Neb., began transmitting the NBC Saturday night movie, The Deadly Tower, a dramatization of the 1966 massacre of 16 persons and the wounding of three others by Charles J. Whitman, a sniper atop the University Tower in Austin, Tex. By uncanny coincidence, the movie was about to provide the electronic backdrop for another grotesque mass murder.

title: South Vietnam, After 30 Years of War, Is Land of Widespread Disease, U.N. Group Says
description: MANILA, March 20 (AP)After 30 years of war, South Vietnam is a land of widespread malaria, bubonic plague, leprosy, tuberculosis, venereal disease and 300,000 prostitutes, according to the World Health Organization.

title: Hanging the Ghetto Dog
description: Not long ago, Saul Bellow was interviewed in The Times and argued on behalf of some distinctions and against some others.

title: Israeli Book Gives a Critical View of Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, March 20An Israeli journalist, in a revised manuscript after the first draft was banned by Israeli censors, has published an attack on Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's Middle East diplomacy that he says is based largely on secret Israeli Government records of the negotiations.

title: PEOPLE
description: Since Soshitsu Sen, as Japanese Grand Tea Master, is regarded as a sort of king without a crown in his country, where ceremonial teamaking is an ancient art, it seemed only fitting to Msgr. Thomas Fahy, president of Seton Hall University in South Orange, which has developed a strong program in Asian studies and close ties to Japan, that Mr. Sen should be honored by the university. And so the master of the Chado tea ceremony, developed more than 400 years ago, has been awarded an honorary degree of Doctor of Fine Arts at Seton Hall.

title: A Guide for Grape Growers
description: Grapes are the most important fruit crop in the world. There is no reason why home gardeners cannot successfully grow dessert grapes.

title: Portugal's Political Leaders Do Their DecisionMaking on the Night Shift After Long Hours of Debate
description: LISBON, March 20In Portugal politics are made at night. Sessions of the ruling Council of the Revolution rarely break up before dawn, and allnight Cabinet meetings have become the rule.

title: Notes: Rich Man, Poor Man Starts a Trend
description: Rich Man, Poor Man, the ABC Monday  night series that came in for a 10week run in January and closed last Monday, has left television permanently changed. Its smash ratings not only altered the thinking at the networks about their breadand  butter programming component, the weekly series, but has also opened the gates to dramatization of contemporary American fiction in the commercial medium.

title: F.B.I. Is Studying the Mellon Abductions
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that it had begun an inquiry to learn whether Federal law was violated In the abduction of the two young daughters or Katherine Leigh Boyd Mellon and her divorced husband, Seward Prosser Mellon, the Pittsburgh banker.

title: A Dirge to Spring
description: SPRING, which dropped in on us last night, is receiving the usual hosannas. But a wetblanket minority of Islanders are snarling: What's so great about spring? We've just gotten comfortable in the house over winter and now spring comes along to put us to work.

title: DINING OUT
description: FRANK and Dorothy Amato have always prided themselves on their food and service. About two years ago, when they moved their restaurant to a new building a few hundred feet down the road, they took pains to maintain the things that made their reputation.

title: ART VIEW
description: It is often averred rowadays that the socalled subject in painting, especially modernist painting, is a matter of little or no importance. All that counts, according to this view, is the form, and it is assumed that this form, if fully realized, is to be perceived as something wholly independent of anything resembling a subject. We are expected to launder our vision, so to speak, if we have any hope of being truly in touch with the esthetic core of painting. The subject is to be regarded as a kind of epiphenomenon, or historical accident, of interest to specialists in the social history of art, perhaps, and beguiling to amateurs not yet initiated into the mysteries of pictorial science, but strictly irrelevant to an eye in the know.

title: Top N. B. A. Stars Were Subsidized
description: For at least five seasons beginning in 1968, each team in the National Basketball Association was paying part of the salary of such superstars as Rick Barry, Kareem AbdulJabbar and Elvin Hayes, according to documents on file in Federal District Court here.

title: In a word, the Capitals are atrocious
description: Right from the beginning the new hockey team in the nation's capital developed unfortunate identity problems. At one of their first exhibition games, the program mistakenly billed them as the Washington Generals. Bad as that was it was preferable to some of the names that fans had suggestedthe Chimney Sweeps, the Pink Violins or the Cold Cuts, for example. None of these was a winner, but, as it turns out, neither was the team; indeed, in some Washington circles, fans now favor the Capital Losses.

title: Golfing For Cats
description: The steady practitioners of written humor can be counted on half the fingers of a single Wcody Allen. After Allen himself, and the stalwart BuchwaldBaker duo, who else is there? Alan Ccren, that's who. About Mr. Coren, I can only pass on what the book jacket says: he's Deputy Editor of Punch, has been to Oxford, Yale and Berkeley, is TV critic for The Times (the other one) and is the funniest writer in Britain today. After reading Golfing for Cats, I wouldn't be surprised.

title: Richard W Darrow Dies at 60; Top Officer of Hill & Knowlton
description: Richard W. Darrow, chairman and chief executive of Hill & Knowlton Inc., public relations counselors here, died yesterday of cancer in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived here.

title: POT LUCK
description: I'm like a bottle maker during Prohibition, Burt Rubin says with a grin. I make something legal to hold something that's illegal. When it's legalized, I'll make even more money than I do now.

title: Rhodesia Hints at Restoring British Tie
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 20Prime Minister Ian D. Smith held out the possibility today that he might be prepared to abandon Rhodesia's 11yearold declaration of independence from Britain in the search for a solution of the country's constitutional crisis.

title: Bowie's Back But the Glitter's Gone
description: Bowie has a record of dropping an image once it has proved successful

title: Carll Tucker 3d Weds Diane Straus, an Editor
description: Diane Ellen Straus and Carll Tucker 3d, who graduated with the class of 73 from Yale; were married last evening in the Cotillion Room at the Pierre. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony, and Bishop Paul Moore of New York gave the blessing.

title: Beverly Fuller To Be a Bride
description: Dr. and Mrs. W. Allen Fuller of Halifax, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beverly Harrison Fuller, to Stephen Douglas Hope, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. C. Hope Jr. of Charlotte, N. C. The couple plan to marry May 29 in St. John's Episcopal Church in Halifax.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: The next time someone comes up to me, at a party or even in a lockerroom, and, speaking some recent entertainment I've reviewed, says, Hey, did you see the same show I did?. I am not going to wince, I am not going to look weary, I am not going to lie down and cry. The implication of the question Is clear: we've disagreed about the show, one of us is out of his skull, there is little need to ask which one. I am just going to look the fellow straight in the eye and tell him the truth. No, I didn't see the same show he did.

title: Virginia L. White Bride of R. S. Jones Jr.
description: Virginia Lawrence White, a physical education teacher at the Lawrence (L.I.) Country Day School, was married yesterday afternoon to Richard Steiner Jones Jr., the school's assistant headmaster. The Rev. Joseph Murray performed the ceremony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Hewlett, L. I.

title: SOUTH ASIA SHIFTS FAIL TO HELP POOR
description: TORONTO, March 20Findings presented at a conference of experts on Asia here yesterday indicate that the changes introduced in political institutions in India, Pakistan, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka to fight poverty have failed to keep the extremely poor from becoming even poorer in those countries.

title: Boatmen, Yards Labor Together For Spring Rite
description: Spring. No longer a time for mixed feelings. The Joys of the approaching boating season used to be tempered by the drudgery of fitting out. Armed with sheets of sandpaper, caulking compound and paint, the boat owner gently probed that wooden hull with a screw driver, making sure dry rot hadn't invaded.

title: Athens Ruin May Be Jail Of Socrates
description: ATHENS, March 20  An American archeologist believes that he has identified the prison where. Socrates spent the last month of his life and was executed on charges of corrupting the youth of Athens in 399 B.C.

title: Sarah Chasis Engaged to Lawyer
description: Sarah Chasis and Henry Clabaugh Hiles plan to marry here this spring.

title: POLITICS
description: LONG with former Gov. Rorrald Reagan of California, the biggest loser to President Ford in the Republican Presidential primaries in Florida and Illinois was Vice President Rockefeller. To propel himself forward as the moderate alternate in states like New Jersey, in the event Mr. Ford had faltered, the former New York Governor needed decisive Reagan victories in both primaries.

title: Marguerite G. Corcoran Is Married
description: Marguerite Grace Corcoran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick James Corcoran of Scarsdale, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Leslie Mead Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mead of Larchmont, N. Y.

title: Great Expectations for City Gardeners
description: Imagine the amazement of my country cousins when I offer them a bowl of blueberries, freshly plucked from shrubs growing on my terrace or hand them a bouquet of my roses with dew drops still clinging. Far too many people are skeptical about city gardening and overlook he vast number of plants wljrch live happily, unperturbed by pollutants or soot faloout.

title: Representations
description: Steven Marcus teaches English at Columbia University and is well known and justly admired as the author of three important studies, Dickens: From Pickwick to Dombey (1965), The Other Victorians (1966), an analysis of Victorian sexual attitudes, and Engels, Manchester and the Working Class (1974), an attempt to understand a particular society by studying a crucial example of an unusually acute imagination's response to it: the example chosen was Engels's The Condition of the Working Class in England in 1844. In all his work, Marcus insists upon the cognitive value of literature and therefore upon a significant relation between literature and the society which it discloses. Writers, he maintains, act as the imaginations of the actual societies in which they live. We read them in the hope of understanding how societies imagine themselves, how they represent their own existences to themselves.

title: Income Tax: Is the Battle Won?
description: IF the proposed state income tax comes to pass, New Jersey may once again be in the top 10 in per capita state levies. For years, the officials who run the state government have wheedled new taxes from the Legislature by pointing opt that New Jersey has ??? toward the bottom in that cateaorv.

title: Nastase Runs 10 Games, Downs Connors in Final
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., March 20 Jimmy Connors lost 10 games in a row today during a 1hour35minute match that saw him humbled if not humiliated by Vie Nastase. 4.6, 6.0, 6.1, in the final of an Independent Players Association tourney at the La Costa Racquet Club.

title: Fresh Approaches By Ella Fitzgerald Improve Program
description: Ella Fitzgerald has become so firmly established in her specialniche of popular song that the surprises or deviations that occur at her concerts are minimal. At Avery Fisher Hall on Friday evening, she seemed to be acknowledging this when she apologized because her performance of Mountain Greenery was slightly different from her recording of the tune.

title: Planting a Specimen Tree
description: There are gardens whose entire claim to fame rests in one plant. In our town, for instance, there is a house known as the one with that gorgeous clematis on the garage wall. That famous clematis is what in garden jargon is called a specimen plant.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Weddings, graduations, family celebrations; parties and outings are all exciiting family events that amatur photographers are always eager to record on film. Too often,. however, only a few skimpy pictures are made before the event is overusually a result of little or no advance planning with not enough thought given to the many photographic possibilities the occasion may hold.

title: Pike Pace Is Slowing
description: ANEW speed record52.93 miles an hour. That's not Barney Oldfield's racingcar speed back in 1903. He did far better than that. No, it was the average speed of vehicles at a given moment when clocked this month in the northbound center lanes of a 36milelong computerized section of the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: Indiana, Rutgers Reach Semifinals
description: BATON ROUGE, La., March 20Al McGuire, Marquette's outspoken basketball coach, spoke once too often today and cost his team its final opportunity to upset Indiana when he drew a technical foul with 25 seconds remaining and his team trailing by only 3 points.

title: The Brothers Lionheart
description: Alas, let no one encountering this new book by the creator of Pippi Longstocking expect more of the same. Not that I am against new departures, but the content of The Brothers Lionheart, a fantasy about life after death, seems to me dubious.

title: Business Civilization In Decline
description: Is capitalism dying? Robert L. Heilbroner is sure it is. He expects it to be gone within a century. Yet, although Heilbroner is himself a socialist, the impending demise of capitalism leaves him joyless; for he is full of apprehension about the conditions that are causing capitalism to rot and bringing statist regimes into being. And he fears that personal freedoms and parliamentary political institutions, which he reveres, may die with capitalism.

title: F.C.C. TO DISCIPLINE CITIZENS BAND RADIO
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)The Federal Communications Commission has told Congress that it will ask for $3.8 million extra to cope with the boom in citizens band radios.

title: The Only Job Is Keeping Busy
description: WHEN Orville Lee Callahan would come home to Ronkonkoma after a twoday shift as a New York City fireman, his children would cry, Daddy's home, Daddy's home! jump into his arms and kiss him. Now when the children come, home from school they find Daddy at home, give him a perfunctory kiss and go about their business.

title: College Basketball
description: Scranton 60, Wittenberg 57 (overtime).

title: Concert by Arlo Guthrie Aids Harris's Campaign
description: SUFFERN, N. Y., March 20 It might have been any Arlo Guthrie concert last night at Rockland Community College as the multicolored lights washed across the stage and sound filled the field house.

title: Rutgers Five Gains
description: Undefeated Rutgers gained the semifinals of the National Collegiate basketball championships yesterday by beating Virginia Military Institute, 9175. Rutgers, which has won 31 games this season, next plays Michigan, a 95.88 victor over Missouri. India ana's undefeated and top. ranked team beat Marquette, 65.56, and will play U.C.L.A., which beat Arizona, 8266. Details in Section 5.

title: OHLSSON, MISS FRIED EXCEPTIONAL AS DUO
description: Miriam Fried and Garrick Ohlsson worked as a duo at the Metropolitan Museum on Friday night to perform three demanding works for violin and piano: Beethoven's Sonata in E flat (Op. 1, No. 3), Bartok's Sonata No. 22 and Schubert's Fantasy in C.

title: 2YEAR COLLEGES UNDER PRESSURES
description: WASHINGTON, March 20Officials of the nation's 1,000 twoyear community colleges, long the portal to higher education for the academically underprepared and the economically disadvantaged, are concerned that the doors are slowly closing.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Serious gardeners are just that, deeply involved in their art and interested in ways to better and improve results. This bettering and improving usually involves the whet+ plants get their start. And since vegetable gardening has become the big thing, there is renewed interest in soil eare. Experience is teaching gardeners that the better the condition of the soil, the better the growth and yields of their crops.

title: M'GEE SCORES CUTS POSTAL SERVICE
description: WASHINGTON, March 20Senator Gale W. McGee, chairman of the Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee, has attacked the agency's recent costcutting programs and criticized the Postmaster General for recent speeches around the nation suggesting radical changes in the postal system.

title: CHESS
description: Nona Gaprindashvili of the Soviet Union had an easy time defending her women's World championship, defeating, her compatriot and challenger Nana Alexandria by 83, in their match in Tbilisi, the Soviet Union.

title: The Corporate Image and NBC's
description: We must break through with new directions in expressing corporate image.

title: Havlicek Breaks Point Record
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 20 (UPI)John Havlicek set a National Basketball Association record by scoring over 1,000 points for the 14th consecutive season but it was a jump shot by Jo Jo White with 49 seconds left in overtime tonight that sparked the Boston Celtics to a 10396 triumph over the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: N.I.T. Is Threatened by Financial Pinch
description: The National Invitation Tournament final between Kentucky and North Carolina at Charlotte today at 1 P.M. at Madison Square Garden will he played, more for honor than money. When the accounting is done and the N.I.T. divides approximately $300,000, there will he thank yous for all, but little money, if any, for the 12 teams that competed in the basketball tournament.

title: Will Love of Utility Survive a Rate Rise?
description: For more than two decades, the Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company, has been known as the loveable utility in Oklahoma and throughout the electric power industry. Perhaps that's because O.G.&E., which has some of the lowest power rates in the nation, hasn't raised its rates since 1954.

title: Stracey Is Victor, Keeps Welter Title
description: WEMBLEY, England, March 20 (AP)  John Stracey of Britain stopped Hedgemon Lewis of Los Angeles in the 10th round tonight and retained the World Boxing Council welterweight title.

title: CAR ACCIDENT KILLS 4 IN A JERSEY FAMILY
description: Four members of a West Caldwell, N. J., family were killed and one was critically injured yesterday afternoon when their car struck the rear of a dairy truck parked on a shoulder of the Garden State Parkway In Brick Township, N. J.

title: 111 Shot Wins Derby By a Neck
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 20 (AP)  Greentree Stable's Johnny Appleseed came from off the pace and won the $100,000 Louisiana Derby today by a neck at the Fair Grounds race track. Glassy Dip was second in the stretch drive and Gay Jitterbug third, seven lengths back.

title: The Mother Knot
description: Motherhood is to women as making money is to men in our culture. Demur, you're straightway dangerous/ And handled with a chain, as Emily Dickinson said. About motherhood, there is still both a conspiracy of silence and the incessant babble of mythmaking. Where is motherhood in great literature? Emma Bovary, Anna

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Hockey, Basketball Standings

title: Air Canada Sets Cuba Route
description: TORONTO, March 20 (UPI)Air Canada has announced that it will begin weekly scheduled fights between Toronto and ??? in April, The airline has been operating charter service to Cuba for four years.

title: Notes: Domesticating The U.S.A. Rail Pass
description: On the first of this month, Amtrak, the National Passenger Railroad Corporation, began offering its U.S.A. Rail pass to Americans. Previously the pass, which entitles the holder to unlimited train travel for 14, 21 or 30 days, had been available to foreigners only. Since Americans became eligible, about 450 of the passes have been sold every day, and Amtrak is now in the process of deciding whether United States citizens should be allowed to buv them beyond the present cutoff date of May 15. The passes will continue to be offered to foreigners through Dec. 3.

title: Picketing Halts at Paper Critical of Rizzo
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 20The Philadelphia Inquirer published only one of its three editions today because construction union demonstrators, some of whom were disorderly, blocked entrances to the building for 11 hours.

title: Endpaper
description: Vogue words are bits of language that slip into American speech, are disseminated far and wide by television talk shows, and make a person appear withit. Many of the words run a flulike course and disappear, leaving memories of semantic headaches and fevered articulation. Others, like dtente, are formally banished by Presidential fiat. Here is my first annual vogueword watch, compiled with the help of a few lexicographical colleagues around the country.

title: The New Golden Land
description: What is called the New World came into existence for Europeans late in the 15th century, an event as bewildering as it was unexpected. The initial preoccupation was how to account for this land, for its unsuspected location blccking the western route between Europe and Asia, its splendidly exotic vegetation, its curious naked peoples of unusual hue and baffling character. America it self, as a word, did not appear until 1507. Columbus, who died in 1506, insisted to the end that the lands he found were part of Asia, that is, within the horizon of the known wcrld. When he touched land in 1492 he immediately bestowed European namesSan Salvador, after the Saviour, the Indies. The name, writes Nietzsche, is what first makes a thing visible. What remained invisible to Columbus was that the lands he charted on his four voyages were not pieces of Asia, or as he suspected during his third voyage, the Earthly Paradise, but something wholly unaccountable by Scripture or classical text or familiar geography: an independent land mass.

title: New Corporate Bonds
description: Week ended March 19, 1976)

title: Union Votes Today on Transport of Jersey Offer
description: Members of the Amalgamated Transit Union are scheduled to vote today on the latest offer in their contract dispute with Transport of New Jersey.

title: AntiBoycott Law Trims. Port's Mideast Traffic
description: Exporters, apparently worried about breaching a new state law that makes aiding the Arab boycott of Israel a misdemeanor, are diverting cargo destined for the Middle East from New York City to other ports.

title: Full Automation of the Stock Market Called Unlikely Before the Late 1980's
description: WASHINGTON, March 20Development of a fully automated stock market in which a black box would execute each order from the time it is placed until the final moment of transfer and settlement is unlikely to occur before the late 1980's.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: POLICE TO DISCUSS MELLON ABDUCTIONS
description: Members of the Police Department will meet today with District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn to discuss possible criminal charges in connection with the abduction last Friday of the two daughters of Karen Boyd Mellon from her home in that borough.

title: Election Unit to Certify Its Last Million Today
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)  The Federal Election Commission meets tomorrow to certify a final $1 million to Presidential candidates before its authority to give out the matching funds expires under a Supreme Court ???.

title: British Find Bomb Factory
description: LONDON, March 21 (AP)Scotland Yard's antiterrorism squad announced today that it had found a second Irish guerrilla bomb factory and detained five men and a woman. The seizure of explosives, detonators and other bombmaking materials in a house at Lavender Hill in south London came Friday night, two clays after the discovery of a bomb factory in a nearby neighborhood, Scotland Yard said.

title: CAROL ANNE DUOME
description: Carol Anne Duome, assistant art director of Fawcett Publications, died of leukemia yesterday in Memorial Hospital. She was 25 years old and lived here.

title: Big Concerns Alter Capital Search
description: Big corporations, increasingly encouraged by the strength of the stock market, are expected to turn to Wall Street this year to raise an estimated $12 billion of new capital by selling stock.

title: New Fusion Reactor Likely to Break Even in Fuel Use
description: Unexpectedly rapid progress in recent months in a critical area of fusion research, known as neutral beam injection, has virtually guaranteed breakeven power production for a new fusion reactor to be built at Princeton.

title: Nixon's Report on China Is Reported Given to Ford
description: President Ford and Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger have received a written report from former President Richard M, Nixon about his recent trip to China, Time magazine reports in its current issue, out today.

title: Concert: Amici Quartet
description: The Amici Quartet, one of a family of recently organized string ensembles nurtured by the Young Artist Program at the State University of New York at Binghamton, made its New York City debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday night under the sponsorship of Artist Development Inc., a Binghamtonbased nonprofit organization.

title: TV: The Mystery of the Andrea Doria Is on CBS
description: The Mystery of the Andrea Doria, a documentary that will be shown on CBSTV this Wednesday at 8 P.M., claims to have discovered why the $30 million Italian luxury liner sank off Nantucket Island in 1956 after colliding with the Swedish liner Stockholm. The film was made by Peter Gimbel, a sea diverphotographer, and Elga Andersen a European actress.

title: DR. ARTHUR E. BROOKS
description: Dr. Arthur E. Brooks, who retired in 1959, as manager of the general laboratories of the United States Rubber Company, now Uniroyal Inc., died Saturday in a nursing home in Nutley, N.J. He was 81 years old and lived at 426 Prospect Avenue in Nutley.

title: U.S. AFUEL CURBS MAY BE OVER SOON
description: Action is expected within a few days by Congressional sources on sending a bill ending the Government's 30year monopoly of nuclear fuel enrichment to the floor of the Senate and House.

title: Sharon, a Miltary Hero, Quits as Adviser to Rabin
description: JERUSALEM, March 21 (AP) Maj. Gen. Ariel Sharon, Israeli hero of the 1973 Mideast war, said today that he was resigning as military adviser to Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and warned of grave deterioration in Israel's political and military posture.

title: HamRadio Flea Market Draws 600
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, March 20More than 600 ham operators gathered today for a flea market and auction cn ham radio equipment in the auditorium of St Joseph's Roman Catholic church here.

title: SOLZHENITSYN BIDS SPAIN USE CAUTION
description: MADRID, March 21Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the exiled Soviet writer and political dissident, warned Spaniards last night of the dangers of Communism and told liberals not to push too hard for changes because Spain had more freedoms now than the Soviet Union had ever known.

title: Student Volunteers Scarce In Presidential Campaign
description: Four years after the student movement formed the vanguard of George McGovern's successful sweep to the Democratic Presidential nomination, campaign coordinators in this state are, finding that the movement is over.

title: Mantle in Camp of OldTimers
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 21A rookie righthander, Doug Heinhold, arrived at the Yankees training camp today to complete the squad, and Mickey Mantle checked in to complete Manager Billy Martin's alumni coaching and instructional staffs.

title: Survey Shows 53% in the State Support an Income Tax
description: Continued From Page 1, Col. 7 the survey are rougher indicators of sentiments among corresponding groups in the general population.

title: Miss Hearst Is Facing New Test in State Cases
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 21 Patricia Hearst, convicted yesterday of armed bank robbery, will be turned over to the California state authorities this week to face charges ranging from kidnapping to armed robbery, her Federal prosecutor said today.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Hearst Jurors Hoped to Believe
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 21The jurors in the trial of Patricia Hearst wanted all in our hearts, as one said, to believe that she was innocent, but they felt obliged to vote for conviction because the steady accumulation of evidence against her and the quality of her defense left them no choice.

title: TskTsk
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.I was wincing the other day at yet another offhand putdown of Mississippi by yet another glib New Yorker, when it occurred to me that the author had based his slur on a moribund set of assumptions.

title: Yonkers Entries
description: Yonkers Entries

title: CALLMAYRESORT RECEIVED U.S. AID
description: MOUNT CRESTED BUTTE, Colo., March 20The ski resort town being developed here by Howard H. Callaway has received $46.305 in Federal grants in the last two years to pay for its twoman police force and to hire a town planner.

title: WASTE IS CHARGED IN DEBATE PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI)Senator William Proxmire said today that the National Endowment for the Humanities squandered $2 million on a Bicentennial debate program while shortchanging the young people who took part in it.

title: Events Today
description: Events Today

title: Neglected Tenants in a Forlorn Battle
description: There is only one family living in the fourstory building at 1506 Lexington Avenue. near 97th Street.

title: Hearst Jurors Hoped to Believe
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 21The jurors in the trial of Patricia Hearst wanted all in our hearts, as one said, to believe that she was innocent, but they felt obliged to vote for conviction because the steady accumulation of evidence against her and the quality of her defense left them no choice.

title: Diverse Views Given on U.S. Jewish Experience
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 21Man has risen above the inclination to atribute excesses of nature to God's anger. And yet today, when the wind roared and a torrent descended and electricity flickered and died, haw could one he sure that a speaker at the conference here on the American Jewish experience had not incurred the wrath of Jehovah?

title: U.N. TRADE PANEL RUNS INTO A SNAG
description: GENEVA, March 21  The, board of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development was unable to agree during a special twoweek session here on a program of negotiations for promoting the economic growth of the world's poorer countries.

title: Flyers Win And Take Conference
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 21 (UPI)Terry Crisp, a 32yearold veteran who had scored only four times this season, got two goals tonight and helped the Philadelphia Flyers gain an uphill 42 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Pittston Unit in Bid For Belcher Oil Co.
description: The Pittston Company announced yesterday that its Metropolitan Petroleum division proposed to merge with the Belcher Oil Company, a privately owned company baswed in Miami, Ha. Under terms of the merger, Pittston, a diversified concern, would receive all the common stock of the combined company, roughly 370,000 shares. Belcher's 303,000 shares would be exchanged for la like number of preterence stock in the new company.

title: Music: Three Pieces
description: Yesterday afternoon's unusually enjoyable American Symphony Orchestra concert in Carnegie Hall had three main items of interesta New York premiere, the appearance of an excellent young Gentian pianist and Tchaikovsky's Manfred, which is always a pleasure to encounter.

title: Ban on Jewish Prayer at Temple Mount. Upheld
description: TEL AVIV, March 21  The Supreme Court in Jerusalem today upheld the authority of the police to ban Jewish prayer on a sacred hilltop where Moslem shrines stand over the ruins of King Solomon's Temple.

title: DEATH
description: DEATH

title: New President of Tufts.
description: That Dr. Jean Mayer, the scholarly looking Harvard nutritionist and newspaper health columnist, has been chosen, from almost 400 candidates, to be the 10th president of Tutts University should surprise no one familiar with his history.

title: Rhodesian Drama Engrosses South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 21The collapse of the Rhodesian constitutional negotiations between Prime Minister Ian D. Smith and the black nationalist leader Joshua Nkomo has heightened the South African Government's sense of urgency in prevailing on Mr. Smith to soften his position against majority rule, according to informed sources here and in Cape Town and Pretoria.

title: Rockefeller Is in Paris On a Bicentennial Visit
description: PARIS, March 21 (AP)Vice President Rockefeller arrived in Paris today on a threeday visit timed to American Bicentennial observances in France.

title: This Article Is Late, But There's a Reason
description: Some people are celebrating the nation's Centennial this year. They are the same people who went to Spain in 1972 to raise money for three ships to discover America and who publish something called Last Month's Newsletter. They are the Procrastinator's Club of America Inc., and yesterday they proclaimed National Procrastination Weeka week after it was over.

title: The End of NATO?
description: WASHINGTONThe Communist invasion of Europe is well under way and the United States is doing nothing to stop it.

title: On the West Bank
description: Israel's nineyear administration of the Jordan West Banksurely among the most benign military occupations of modern timesis undergoing a severe challenge. The immediate cause of the past month's unrest among Arab Palestinians is relatively trivial; the questions raised for Israel's future policy toward its Arab neighbors are fundamental.

title: Harold Wagenheim Dead; Retired School Principal
description: Harold H. Wagenheim, who retired recently as principal of the Dodge Vocational High School, the Bronx, died Friday in Montefiore Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 3050 Fairfield Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Figure Skating Champion Gets a Heroine's Welcome
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 21The hometown girl who left here five years ago in pursuit of an Olympic gold medal returned the hometown heroine today as she was welcomed back as only, a small town can welcome back its own.

title: Avatar Captures Rich Coast Ra ce
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 21 (AP)  Avatar, the 1975 Belmont Stakes winner, but a loser at Santa Anita this winter, switched from the dirt course to the turf for the first time today and scored a close victory in the $109,300 San Luis Rey Stakes.

title: 12 Die in South Africa Flood
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 21 (AP)  Heavy floods caused by torrential rains left at least 12 persons dead in a suburb of the South African port city of Durban, sod the eventual death toll may be much higher, officials said today.

title: RUSSIANS DEPLORE RUPTURE BY EGYPT
description: MOSCOW, March 21 (Reuters)The Soviet press charged today that President Anwar elSadat of Egypt had decided to abrogate a friendship treaty with the Soviet Union in return for financial aid from the United States and Saudi Arabia.

title: Street Theater Protests John Jay College Closing
description: The spirit of John Jaythe first Chief Justice of the United States and onetime Governor of New York stalked Manhattan yesterday in an effort to keep open the college of criminal justice that is named for him.

title: Bonnie Rudensky Bride of Dr. Lubin
description: Dr. Bonnie Rudensky, an assistant professor of English at Ohio State University, was married yesterday afternoon in Columbus, Ohio, to Dr. A. Harold Lubin, chairman of the nutrition division of the department of pediatrics at the university's school of medicine.

title: Recital: Perahia's Romantic Appeal
description: The dream of young musicians is to balance their careers on the dangerous high wire that runs between popular acclaim and elite esteem, and only a few artists have the talent and poise to pull off that feat. Among pianists who have come to prominence in the 1970's, perhaps none is a better bet to walk the line successfully than Murray Perahia, who gave a recital at Alice Tully Hall yesterday lit the Great Performers at Lincoln Center series.

title: Miss Hearst Is Facing New Test in State Cases
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 21 Patricia Hearst, convicted yesterday of armed bank robbery, will be turned over to the California state authorities this week to face charges ranging from kidnapping to armed robbery, her Federal prosecutor said today.

title: The Entertainer
description: When Harold Wilson became Prime Minister in 1964, his Government's first major decision was to hold the pound at a value of $2.80. It proved a disastrous policy. For three years Britain borrowed and bluffed in an attempt to defy reality.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Brown Bets on California In Thrust for Nomination
description: LOS ANGELES, March 21Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, sensing that the nation is ready to turn to a new generation of leadership, is taking a longshot gamble that his ability to control the California delegation to the Democratic National Convention this summer can be converted into his party's nomination for the Presidency.

title: Farmland and River
description: Secretary of the Interior Kleppe's intervention with W. R. Grace and Company promises to save a thousand acres of historic farmland in central Virginia from being stripMined for vermiculite, a substance used for insulation and cat litter. If Mr. Kleppe's appeal is heeded by the companywhich owns the land even though it is part of the Green Springs National Historic LandmarkW. R. Grace will donate to the Government its mining rights by way of a scenic easement, getting an appropriate tax deduction in return.

title: Miss Barbanel Wed to Doctor
description: Cheryl Sue Barbanel, who expects to graduate in June from the New York University School of Medicine, was married yesterday to Dr. Kenneth B. Miller, chief medical resident at the Veterans Administration Hospital here. Rabbi Martin Gordon performed the ceremony at Temple Torah in Little Neck, Queens.

title: Soviet Kitchen Debates Yield Odd Views of U.S.
description: MINSK, U.S.S.R.  Once again, American kitchens on display in the Soviet Union have become the scenes of debate, and the confrontationsthis time between young Americans and ordinary Soviet citizenshave revealed the extent to which Soviet perceptions of the United States are permeated by bizarre images and caricatures, despite dtente.

title: Libya Expels Tunisians
description: TUNIS, March 21 (Reuters) More than 5,000 Tunisians have been expelled from Libya In the last three weeks, officials raid here today.

title: VIOLENT STORMS STRIKE NORTHEAST
description: Violent thunderstorms with galefarce winds hit parts of the northeastern states yesterday afternoon, striking erratically and causing widespread injuries and damageeven cutting short a late St. Patrick's Day parade in western Massachusetts.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: M.T.A.  Union Battle: A Classic Tragedy?
description: Like Odysseus, David L. Yunich, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, sees himself caught in tricky financial straits between modernday versions of Scylla and Charybdis.

title: Redford Film Premieres to Aid GrassRoots Lobbyists
description: DENVERIn an unusual effort to encourage grassroots lobbying for environmental and consumer issues, Robert Redford has arranged special benefit premieres of his new film, All the President's Men, in 12 cities April 8.

title: 16thCentary Ming Jar Brings $200,000 Here
description: An ancient Chinese jar that a Philadelphia couple bought in an antiques shop in the late 1940's for $150 was sold at auction Saturday at Sotheby Parke Bernet for $260,000, a price that was said to have set a United States record for a Chinese work of art.

title: Today's Entries at Aqueduct
description: Today's Entries at Aqueduct

title: MARY FRANCES HUGHES
description: Mary Frances Hughes, who retired in 1959 after five years as research director of the Refined Syrups and Sugar Company of Yonkers, died Friday at the St. Elizabeth Center, 7 Gramercy Park West. She was 81 years old.

title: Love's Labor Done in Park
description: I know a hank where the wild thyme blows.

title: Panama Canal Operations Are Resumed After Strike
description: BALBOA HEIGHTS, Canal Zone, March 21 (Reuters)The Panama Canal resumed normal operations today after a fiveday strike by 700 American, pilots and tugmen.

title: Jill Jacobson, U. S. Lawyer, Marries
description: Jill A. Jacobson of Lebanon, N. H., an assistant United States attorney for the District of Vermont in Rutland, was married yesterday to Thomas Joseph Cullen, a lawyer and candidate for a master's degree at the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College.

title: La Scala U.S. Visit Off
description: Italy announced It had canceled the scheduled first United States tour of Milan's La Scala Opera Company because of Italy's fiscal problems. The visit this fall was to have included Washington, Philadelphia and New York. Page 21.

title: ELIZABETH JEAN REED
description: Elizabeth Jean Reed, former editor of PepsiCola World, a company publication, died of cancer Saturday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 55 years old and lived here.

title: DATA CURB ROILS STRIPMINE ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 Raymond A. Peck Jr., a Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Interior, who earlier this month. ordered the department's geol ogists not to give technica information to members of Congress on the estimated impact of Federal stripmine legislation without first clearing the data with him, says he was trying to protect the scientific objectivity of the geologists.

title: Reagan Virtually Concedes Defeat in North Carolina
description: ASHEVILLE, N. C., March 21 Ronald Reagan virtually conceded here today that he would lose the North Carolina Republican primary on Tuesday, but he said that another loss would not doom his candidacy.

title: Personal Finance: Capital Gains Tax
description: Special rules govern the taxation of capital gains, often enabling individuals to pay lower taxes than on ordinary income. It is important, therefore, to understand the definition, timing, methods of determination and limitations of this tax.

title: New Casting Adds Luster to Dances By Harlem Troupe
description: New casting at the Dance Theater of Harlem brought touches of luster to some familiar works Saturday afternoon at the Uris Theater.

title: Reduced Budget Shows Favors for Legislators
description: ALBANY, March 21While most of the attention was focused on the cuts the Legislature made in the new state budget it adopted last week, the real measure of political power is not who loses nut  especially in an era of shrinking budgets  who comes out ahead. Scattered throughout the $10.78 billion budget document are intriguing examples of obscure local programs suddenly enriched, moribund legislative commissions restored to life, and other favors that legislators bestow upon one another under the general heading of political contracts.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OLD GOLD Well, here wt go  way back  and if you don't know the words, I'll feed em, called Bill Selden from his small, singalong piano at Charlie Bates, a barrestaurant at Third Avenue and 75th Street. Thisis a popular, informal spot that draws young and old, with an oldfashioned decor of mahogany, French beveled glass and marble and a dining veranda. At the bar (a rye highball was $2), patrons cluster at Mr. Selden's keyboard and sing back the years with him.

title: Black in Rhodesia Says Smith Remark On Talks Was a Lie
description: GWELO, Rhodesia, March 21 (AP)  The black nationalist leader Joshua Nkomo accused Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia today of lying when he said that Britain had advised Mr. Nkomo what terms to demand in the constitutional talks that collapsed last week.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 22. 1976

title: Senate Is Pressured As It Takes Up Tax
description: TRENTON, March 21The State Senate convenes tomorrow to take its first formal look at the personal income taxproperty tax relief measures passed by the Assembly last Tuesday morning.

title: Fulks Shot to Death; N.B.A. Ace in 1940's
description: EDDYVILLE, Ky., March 21 (AP)Joe Fulks, a star in the early days of the National Basketball Association, was shot to death early today. The police said that Fulks, 54 years old, and Gregg Bannister, 24, were arguing over a handgun when the shooting occurred. Bannister has been charged in connection with the shooting.

title: Scholars, Meeting in Toronto, Troubled on India
description: TORONTO, March 21Concern over the political trends in India has been expressed here by prominent specialists in Indian affairs at the 28th annual meeting of the Association for Asian Studies.

title: $75 Reflects a Democratic Split
description: LONG BEACH, L.I., March 21What's the difference between $100 and $25? For Senator Henry M. Jackson, the difference was not merely mathematical at Democratic functions in two adjoining rooms last night.

title: MRS. HERVEY ALLEN
description: Ann Andrews Allen, widow of Hervey Allen, author of the 1933 bestselling novel Anthony Adverse, died last Thursday in Phoenix, Ariz., at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Melvin G. Marcus. She was 69 years old.

title: Margaret Accused of Neglecting Duty; Sympathy Over Marriage Rift Wanes
description: LONDON, March 21After an initial wave of sympathy for Princess Margaret, the breakup of her marriage to Lord Snowdon stirred sharp criticism today for the first time.

title: Consumer Leads Recovery, Retailers Find
description: The consumer is leading the way in the nation's economic recovery.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD ??? UNTIL ??? ??? ??? CO, AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES ??? WHITE PLAINS ??? NASSAU CO. (516) 74/.0500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 669800 CONNECTICUR (203) 3487767.

title: Holy Trinity Snaps Power Streak, 5755
description: Holy Trinity scored the last 10 points, including the winning basket with four seconds left, to upset Power Memorial, 5755, yesterday in the final of the Cardinal Cooke Interdiocesan tournament at St. John's Alumni Hall. The victory snapped Power's 20game winning streak.

title: Radio
description: 57:25 A.M. WNYCFM. Gymnopedie No. 3, Satie; Piano Concerto No. 1, Albeniz; Suite No. 3, Tchaikovsky.

title: Sales of New Shares Grow; Bond Traders See Rate Drop
description: The credit markets, encouraged by their success in handling an even larger volume of fixedincome securities in the first quarter this year than they did a year ago, are becoming inure and more convinced that interest rates will decline. After the corporate market dispatched last week's three big new bond issues$725 million of highgrade long term securities traders and underwriters cheered.

title: Stateized Railroad?
description: The one thing on which the White House and Congress fully agreed in the long wrangle over how to reorganize the sickly Northeast railroads was that the Federal Government wanted no part of nationalization. That was why Conrail was chartered as a forprofit corporation, though whenif everit will show a profit is conjectural.

title: Hope Budner Wed To Gorden Brown
description: Hope Ann Budner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley P. Budner of Wilmington, Del., was married there yesterday afternoon to Gorden Sander Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Brown of Wallingford, Pa. Rabbi David Geffen performed the ceremony at the Du Pont Hotel.

title: Coin Collecting: Investors Hobby With High Stakes
description: Numismatics: a hobby to some, a gamble to others and a serious investment to many collectors. The aim is the purchase of proof coins for pleasure and also a profit. The players range from small children hopeful of finding a 1913 Liberty head nickel in a handful of change to bankers parlaying coin purchases into a net return of as much as 119 percent a year.

title: Antilioycott Law Trims Port's Mideast Traffic
description: Exporters, apparently worried about breaching a new state law that makes aiding the Arab boycott of Israel a misdemeanor, are diyerting cargo destined for the Middle East from New York City to other ports.

title: Knee Injury Sidelines McGinnis
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 21 (UPI) George McGinnis, the Philadelphia 76ers leading scorer and rebounder, suffered a torn cartilage in his left knee in last night's 10396 overtime loss to Boston here, and will be out indefinitely.

title: Paper Industry Expecting Price Increases This Year
description: Paper and paperboard prices are expected within the industry to rise this year. The only question seems to be the size of the increases.

title: Stage: Line, a Surprising Look at Fight to Be First
description: There is a pleasant surprise lying in wait for people who go to Israel Horovitz's short play Line at the 13th Street Theaternot least for those who have seen the play in earlier manifestations, notably the major production at the Theater de Lys four or five years ago. Of course itmay merely be a change of heart on the part of this critic. But I think not. The play really does look a lot better in this new and very responsive Off Off Broadway production. In fact it looks very good indeed.

title: A JAILED YUGOSLAV SAID TO END HIS FAST
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 21 (Reuters) Mihajlo Mihajlov, the dissident Yugoslav writer, has ended a hunger strike of three and half months in jail and has won several concessions from the authorities, sources here said today.

title: RaceFix Driver Gets Six Months
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., March 21A harnessracing driver, Adrian Bowling of Morrisville, Pa., has been sentenced to six months in prison for fixing a race at Pocono Downs last Aug. 5. The 36yearold Bowling, who pleaded guilty to two counts of rigging a Big Triple race, was liable, on each charge, to a $10,000 fine and/or five years imprisonment.

title: Live a Little
description: PITTSBURGH  The recession has spread the pain of unemployment, but neither generously nor evenhandedly. For an astonishing proportion of our society, unemployment is nothing new.

title: CBS to Drop Affiliate for Schedule Shifts
description: CBSTV, in an unusual action, has notified its Spokane, Wash., affiliate, KXLYTV, that in August it will end their 23year affiliation agreementa move that industry observers say is a warning to other affiliates not to juggle the network schedule.

title: 2 Children Die in Explosion
description: TAYLORVILLE, W. Va., March 21. (AP) Two children sleeping in the rear of a Mingo County tavern died this morning when an oil furnace exploded, the state police said. The victims parents, Luther and Rosie Chafin, who operate the tavern, were listed in fair condition at a hospital.

title: Jeffrey Seitelman Weds Susan Gimovsky
description: Susan Debra Gimovsky, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius H. Gimovsky of Woodside, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Jeffrey Kevin Seitelman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Seitelman of Brooklyn.

title: Unsuccessful Cooperative Will Now Offer Rentals
description: The 420 walkup apartments in West Village Houses, an innovative MitchellLama project that failed as a cooperative and has stood empty for nearly two years, will be offered for rental by the city at marked down rates.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A major contractors association charged in Albany that Governor Carey's freeze on hiring state, employees could result in the loss of $328 million in Federal fundsa major portion of a $3 billion publicworks program intended to create 150,000 jobs. Frederick Compagni, president of the State Federation of Utility Contractors Associations, said in a statement that delays in processing project applications could mean the failure to meet deadlines for receiving Federal water and sewer funds. Mr. Compagni attributed the delays to the failure to fill 20 sanitary engineer positions approved by the Legislature last year for the Environmental Conservation Department's bureau of construction grants.

title: Student Volunteers Scarce In Presidential Campaign
description: Four years after the student movement formed the vanguard of George McGovern's successful sweep to the Democratic Presidential nomination, campaign coordinators in this state are finding that the movement is over.

title: Coast Democrats Play Down Controversy in Platform Proposals
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 21 Ghosts of the 1972 Presidential campaign seemed to haunt the final meeting here yesterday of the California Democratic Party Commission on Platform and Policy.

title: Books of The Times
description: First, the good news. There are two firstrate pieces in Louis Auchincloss's latest collection of thematically linked short stories, The Winthrop Covenant. One of them, In the Beauty of the Lilies Christ Was Born Across the Sea, concerns a pillar of mid19thcentury New York City society who takes it upon himself to scotch a love affair his law partner's wife is about to consummate.

title: THOMAS CASILEAR COLE
description: Thomas Casilear Cole, portrait painter, died Saturday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 87 years old, and lived at 939 Eighth Avenue.

title: Diverse Views Given on U.S. Jewish Experience
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 21Man has risen above the inclination to atribute excesses of nature to God's anger. And yet today, when the wind roared and a torrent descended and electricity flickered and, died, how could one be sure that a speaker at the conference here on the American Jewish experience had not incurred the wrath of Jehovah?

title: 2,000 Elderly Give Vent to Anxieties
description: UNION TOWNSHIP, March 20Hooting the spokesman for the gas and electric company and cheering the speaker who told them they must demand to be treated with dignity, the elderly of Union County made their views known today to officials of industry and government.

title: Spain, Under Pressure, Acts Slowly on Changes
description: MADRID, March 21Of seven proposed measures to change the political and social face of Spain, the threemonthold Government has acted on four, and only one of those is in effect.

title: Bieler Defeats Stenmark in Final of Nations Cup Slalom in Quebec Rain
description: BEAUPRE, Quebec, March 21The lanky young accountant and his seat companion on the weekend bus tour from Ottawa, the nation's capital, ended their skiing day well before noon. He said the rain was making him too wet. She said the thick fog was making it impossible to see.

title: McShane, Williams, Veteran Jazzmen, Play Michael's Pub
description: The rollicking, pungent sound of Kansas City jazz is flooding through Michael's Pub these nights, conjured up by two lively visitors from Kansas City, Jay McShann, the pianist, and Claude Williams, the violinist.

title: Mets' Frazier Plans Ahead As Yanks Conjure the Past
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21  Joe Frazier waited 10 years to manage a big league baseball team and, when he finally did, a historic labor dispute turned his first spring training into a threeweek panic.

title: Hunger Strike in Jail Ends
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 21 (AP)Dr. David Hornick, who was jailed March 6 after refusing to pay $815 in fines for 50 parking tickets, ended his protest hunger strike yesterday at the. Philadelphia House of Detention where he is serving a fivemonth sentence.

title: SOLO CELLO ADDS ZIP TO A ROCK CONCERT
description: Unaccompanied cello solos do not ordinarily bring down the house at rock concerts, but the Electric Light Orchestra is not an ordinary rock group. Formed several years ago from the debris of the Move, a British group that was a critics favorite in the United States, Electric Light combines attractive original material with classical music. The group plays relatively straight but very loud.

title: Rep. Dellums Rejects ThirdParty Draft
description: CINCINNATI, March 21 Representative Ronald V. Dellums, Democrat of California, refused last night to be drafted as the Independent Freedom, Party's candidate for President, but leaders of the National Black Political Convention said today that the party would stilt be formed and that they would definitely run a black candidate for President this year.

title: Ford Plant Closing a Week To Balance Its Inventories
description: EDISON, March 21 (UFOThe Ford Motor Company will close its assembly plant here for a week, beginning tomorrow, to balance its inventories of compact cars, according to company officials.

title: Override Sought on School Bill Veto
description: Proponents of legislation that would require New York City to set aside a specific proportion of its budget for education outlined strategies yesterday that they said would be used to try to override last week's veto of the bill by Governor, Carey.

title: BEIRUT LEFTISTS SEIZE HOLIDAY INN IN HEAVY ASSAULT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Monday, March 22  Hundreds of Moslem and leftist gunmen, backed by armored vehicles yesterday drove rightwing Phalangists from the towering, battered Holiday Inn, gaining an important military and psychological victory.

title: Applicants Dropping at City University
description: Data gathered by the City University indicate that if the chancellor's proposed higher admissions standards were put into effect, York, Medgar Evers and John Jay Colleges would not enroll enough new students next fall to assure their survival as senior colleges.

title: Tire Change Helps Pearson Win Race
description: HAMPTON, Ga., March 21 (AP)David Pearson took on a full set of tires with 50 miles to go and sped away from Benny Parsons for the victory today in the Atlanta 500 stock car race.

title: Rangers Lose to Penguins
description: The Rangers lost their 39th game of the season last night as the Pittsburgh Penguins won, 42, at Madison Square Garden. With only seven games left on their National Hockey League schedule, the lastplace Rangers would have to win every one, while the third  place Atlanta Flames lost all of their remaining six, to qualify for the playoffs.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Dividend Meetings

title: SOVIET DELAY SEEN ON ARMS PROPOSAL
description: MOSCOW, March 21The lack of a Soviet response so far to the latest American proposals for resolving remaining differences over a new agreement on limiting strategic arms has puzzled a few Soviet insiders as well as some Western diplomats here.

title: Paper Attacks Rizzo For Inaction by Police
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 21 (UPI)  The Philadelphia Inquirer assailed Mayor Frank L. Rizzo today for not ordering the police to break up a 10hour demonstration by about 200 construction union employees that disrupted the publication of the newspaper's Saturday editions.

title: 3 Women Heading Toward Success
description: Last spring Liberty Lassiter, Beth Karten and Lucy Scirocco were doing the rounds of the smart boutiques with samples of their products in brown paper bags. Then, orders in hand they were farming out the work to seamstresses as a kind of cottage industry. Now the trio are on their way to the big time, with a company of their own called Cloak of Many Colors, as well as an agent, a cutter and a contractor and are distributing their classic sports separates nationally.

title: Senator Church, on Coast, Tests a LongShot Gamble
description: LOS ANGELES, March 21Senator Frank Church of Idaho has been trying out his Presidential candidacy up and down California the last few days, and it is apparent that this is almost an experimental campaign, resting on more than the usual quota of propositions becinning with the word if.

title: With Awareness of PCB's in Fish, Consumer Concern Grows
description: Spring, more than any other season, is usually celebrated by fishloving gastronomes for its early runs of shad and their highly prized roe, and for the abundance of striped bass, a delicacy to be enjoyed cold now and throughout summer. In addition, the seasonal demand for freshwater species such as carp, pike and whitefish is greatly increased, since those fish are prime ingredients of gefilte fish, traditionally served during Passover.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor.

title: Javits Says Ford Should Pick Rockefeller as Running Mate
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he believed President Ford had the Republican nomination locked up and that Vice President Rockefeller should be considered as Mr. Ford's running mate.

title: Stensen Sets Speed Skating Mark
description: OSLO, March 21 (AP)Sten Stensen of Norway set a world speed skating record of 14 minutes 38.08 seconds for 10,000 meters today at Alma Ata in the Soviet Union, the Norwegian radio reported. Stensen, who held the previous record of 14:50.31 set in Oslo earlier this year, raced against Piet Kleine of the Netherlands who was timed 14:41.90, the radio said.

title: ln Memoriam
description: BERNSTEINEthel K. For you ere the ??? soul I even knew. M., thoughts seek You As the waves seek the shore, and when I think of you, I am at rest, MORRIS J. BERNSTEIN.

title: A Correction
description: In the recipe for Ukrainian borscht that appeared in some editions of The New York Times last Wednesday, instructions for including the beets in the soup were Mistakenly omitted. The sliced bents should be added to the simmering beef and stock, along with the onions, carrots and potatoes. If the beets were canned, add their canning liquid as well. Do not add the liquid in which the unpeeled raw beets were blanched.

title: POLITICAL KILLINGS IN ARGENTINA RISE
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 21Rightist and leftist groups stepped up political violence in Argentina in the last week, leaving at least 40 people dead.

title: Blast Kills 4 in Bangkok As U.S. Shuts Thai Bases
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 21The United States today ended all operations at bases in Thailand in preparation for its final military withdrawal, as several thousand students demonstrated in front of the American Embassy in downtown Bangkok.

title: State Endeavoring To Avoid Difficulty With Food Program
description: Extensive changes will be made in the administration of a free food program for needy New York City children enrolled in public schools, an official of the State Department of Education said yesterday.

title: JOHN LAFFEY M'HUGH
description: John Laffey McHugh, a member of the board of Prescott Neighborhood House, died Friday of cancer at his home here. He was 54 years old.

title: Science of Sitting: Designer Applies Himself to Comfort
description: Bill Stumpf spent a large part of the last few years watching people sit. Why would anyone want to watch people sit? Why, the better to design chairs for them.

title: GEN. GRIGORY F. POPOV
description: MOSCOW, March 21 (UPI)Lieut. Gen. Grigory F. Popov has died at the age of 58, the Army newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda said today.

title: BEIRUT LEFTISTS SEIZE HOLIDAY INN IN HEAVY ASSAULT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Monday, March 22 Hundreds of Moslem and leftist gunmen, backed by armored vehicles, yesterday drove rightwing Phalangists from the towering, battered Holiday Inn, gaining an important military and psychological victory.

title: Carter to Appear Upstate for One Day
description: Taking the calculated risk that momentum from victories elsewhere will spur his New York campaign, Jimmy Carter plans only one quick visit to this state before April 1, five days before the Presidential primary that will allocate 274 delegates to the Democratic convention. On Friday, he will dart in for a oneday upstate swing, then leave, not to return until late the next week.

title: 53% OF JERSEYANS BACK INCOME TAX
description: Young people, college graduates, blacks and those who moved into New Jersey as adults appear to be in the forefront among supporters of a state income tax, according to a poll by The New York Times.

title: COALITION BACKS UDALL AFTER PLEA TO UNP LIBERALS
description: The New Democratic Coalition, which seeks to speak for the liberal wing of the New York State Democratic Party, yesterday endorsed Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona for the party's Presidential nomination.

title: Parallel Slalom Race Summaries
description: Round of 16Stenmark defeated Steiner; ??? defeated Read; Tresch defeated Himier defeated KIammer; Thoeni ??? ??? Bieler defeated Steve ??? Neureuther defeated Parnaetzi; Radici defeated Gros.

title: Green Wins 2d In Row
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 21 (AP)  Hubert Green rallied from the potential disaster of a double bogey with a twounderpar 70 today and scored his second consecutive tour victory in the Greater Jacksonville open.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: Figure Skating Champion Gets a Heroine's Welcome
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 21The hometown girl who left here five years ago in pursuit of an Olympic gold medal returned the hometown heroine today as she was welcomed back as only a small town can welcome back its own.

title: Red Smith
description: As this is written a rodeo is winding up in Calgary, Alberta, not the famous Calgary Stampede, which is a fulldress affair that comes off in July, but an indoor show. When competition started last week, the bulldogger who won top money in the opening goround, the cowboy who was second and the one who finished third all worked off the same horse, a swift but temperamental animal named Little Eight. In steer wrestling, the horse is all important, and several cowboys may use the same mount, each paying the owner 25 percent of his prize money. Sports For three comparative strangers, Little Eight of performed flawlessly. When Bob Marshall, his owner, got aboard, Little Eight left the The Thum chute too soon and Marshall didn't score. Considering that Marshall thinks so highly of Little Eight that he paid a bigger price for him than any dogging horse had ever brought, this was downright bad manners, but Little Eight always did have a will of his own.

title: Levin Back on Street Where She Lived
description: Given the odds against success for any particular Broadway play, a theatrical producer has to be a man Who can believe three or four impossible things at the same time.

title: Brown Bets on California In Thrust for Nomination
description: LOS ANGELES, March 21Gov. Edmund G. Brdwn Jr. of California, sensing that the nation is ready to turn to a new generation of leadership, is taking a longshot gamble that his ability to control the California delegation to the Democratic National Convention this summer can be converted into his party's nomination for the Presidency. ine 37yearold Governor, whose blend of liberal and conservative politics in the nation's most populous state has earned him one of the highest approval ratings in California history, said in an interview that he had not yet decided whether to expand his favoriteson candidacy into a broader campaign in other primary states.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Adelaide Portash, 44 years old, wife of Joseph Portash, the former Manchester Township Mayor who was convicted of bribery, will take her husband's seat on the Township Committee and head the Police Department. She was named Police Commissioner and finance committee chairman and was also appointed to the seat on the Municipal Utilities Authority that had been held by her husband. He stepped down last week after receiving a sixmonth suspended sentence on charges of using his influence to help a land developer win a contract to build a $20 million complex in the town for elderly citizens.

title: Plan to Remodel Union Square Is Urged by Community Groups
description: An ambitious Bicentennial plan to revitalize Union Square has been advanced by the city, but It appeared unlikely that money could be found soon to accomplish most of the improvements, public and private.

title: Bridge:
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 21  A strong East Coast foursome battled the 1976 United States women's world championship team here this afternoon in the final of the first National Women's Knockout Team Championship, concluding 19 days of play in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: Advertising
description: At the end of this week the Mobil Oil Corporation will break its first product advertising since June 1973, when Mr. Dirt bit the dust.

title: Ashe Tops Borg for $10,000
description: KEAUHOUKONA, Hawaii, March 21 (UPI)  Arthur Ashe caused Bjorn Borg's first defeat in the World Championship TennisAvis Challenge Cup series, 64, 76, 63, today in a $10,000 winner  take  all match marred by controversial line calls.

title: VIOLENT STORMS STRIKE NORTHEAST
description: Violent thunderstorms with gale force winds hit parts of the northeastern states yesterday afternoon, striking erratically and causing widespread injuries and damageeven cutting short a late St. Patrick's Day parade in western Massachusetts.

title: COALITION BACKS UDALL AFTER PLEA TO UNIFY LIBERALS
description: The New Democratic Coalition, which seeks to speak for the liberal wing of the New York State Democratic Party, yesterday endorsed Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona for the party's Presidential nomination.

title: Lauren Smith Wed To M. L. Kesselman
description: Lauren Marie Smith and Mark L. Kesselman, an account officer with Citibank, were married yesterday afternoon in the Interfaith Chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Hockey, Basketball Standings

title: No Contract, No Work, vs. No Money
description: Intensified negotiations between the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union get under way today at the Americana Hotel, but with critical differences, compared with the past, that have added complications to the alwayscomplex bargaining. The fiscally troubled city has no funds available to help pay for the wage increases and other contract improvements sought by the Transport Workers Union.

title: WILLIAM C. O'KEEFFE
