description: William C. O'Keeffe, who retired nine years ago as associate treasurer of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 116 East 66th Street. He was 74 years old.

title: Horse Show Results
description: AT WEST ORANGE, N.J.

title: Gimbels to Stop Dressing ROom Surveillance
description: The New York division of Gimbel Brothers has agreed to stop trying to catch shoplifters by having security guards watch customers as they try on clothes in dressing rooms, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: Red Scare Is Over and the Sun Draws Vacationers Again to Portu gal's South
description: FARO, Portugal, March 21  The tourists who fled in panic last year when they thought Portugal was going to be taken over by the Communists are beginning to come back to the Algarve.

title: 7 G.I.'S DIE IN GEORGIA IN CRASH OF COPTER
description: BLAIRSVILLE, Ga., March 21 (UPI)Seven soldiers were found dead today in the wreckage of an Army helicopter atop a North Georgia mountain. An injured soldier managed to walk off the mountain and search crews found a ninth soldier wandering in the undergrowth.

title: Italy Cancels La Scala U.S. Visit
description: The Italian Government announced yesterday that it had canceled a scheduled tour in the United States this fall by Milan's La Scala Opera Company because of Italy's financial straits.

title: CHINESE SUGGESTING TENG MIGHT REPENT
description: PEKING, March 21 (Reuters) The newspaper Jenmin Jih Pao appeared to hint today that Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping, who has been the target of a wallposter campaign, could still survive politically if he would sincerely repent.

title: Fencing Results
description: Fencing Results

title: Westbrook Victor In Final of Saber
description: After a chorus of coaches prompted the baby of this competition with instructions, 23yearold Peter Westbrook grinned and saluted the crowd of 600 persons with his shining saber yesterday on finishing first in the Martini & Rossi international Fencing challenge. Twelve nations participated in the 16th annual competition at the New York Athletic club.

title: Cuban Defector, Cited by C.I.A., Hinted Oswald Link to Havana
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)A Cuban defector told the Central Intelligence Agency in 1964 that Lee Harvey Oswald may have been in contact with Cuban intelligence agents seven weeks before he killed President Kennedy, newly released documents show.

title: About New York
description: Avon Long took a fan from downtown last Friday on a walking tour of the Harlem he remembereda kind of reenactment by daylight of Bubbling Brown Sugar, the revue in which he is starring.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Relentless Wind Tries Mettle of Earth Day Marathon Runners
description: WESTBURY, L.I., March 21Twentyfivemileanhour gusts of wind and a 26mile, 385yard course tested the mettle of longdistance running enthusiasts today in Nas'sau Countys 18th annual Earth Day marathon.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, MARCH 22, 1976

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: U.S. CLOSES BASES AS THAIS ORDERED
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 21The United States today ended all operations at bases in Thailand in preparation for its final military withdrawal, as several thousand students demonstrated in front of the American Embassy in downtown Bangkok.

title: Bulls Brawl With Fans, Lose Game.
description: KANSAS CITY, March 21 (AP)Ollie Johnson, a reserve, scored 10 fourthquarter points to spark a rally as the Kansas City Kings defeated the Chicago Bulls, 112101, in a brawlfilled National Basketball Association game today.

title: Fair Revenue Sharing
description: The Joint meeting of the National League of Cities and the United States Conference of Mayors in Washington last week, complete with a Presidential speech lambasting Congress, for inaction on general revenue sharing, indicates that the great push for extending that legislation has now begun.

title: Opthof and Flagello In Debuts at Met In a Fine Puritan
description: The Metropolitan Opera mustered a fullthroated quartet of principals for its handsome new production of I Puritani earlier this month. Saturday evening the two leading members of the cast were on hand, with Joan Sutherland sounding superb and looking wonderful in Peter J. Hall's costumes and Luciano Pavarotti singing better than this observer had ever heard him before.

title: JEROME SWINFORD
description: Jerome Swinford, a voice teacher and former bassbaritone singer, died yesterday of a heart attack at University Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 40 East 10th Street.

title: William J. Simmons Dies; Alcoholism Council Aide, 57
description: William J. Simmons, business administrator of the North Jersey Area of the National Council on Alcoholism, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 310 Vesta Court, Ridgewood, N.J. He was 57 years old.

title: President's Campaign Promises
description: ASHEVILLE, N.C., March 21 President Ford has said it often, and he repeated it yesterday to the thousands who jammed the Asheville Mall on a stormy afternoon: We need people in public office who won't promise more than they can produce and who produce what they promise. The comment comes close to the heart of the Ford Presidency in its earnestness and its selfconscious avoidance of excess.

title: Man Beaten by Final Four Picks Indiana to Stay No. 1
description: The teams have dwindled down to a precious fewIndiana, Rutgers, Michigan and (of course) the University of California, Los Angeles, the defending National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball champion  the Final Four in your N.C.A.A. program. Fred Schaus is picking Indiana.

title: New Federal Rules Will Reduce Eligibility for DayCare in City
description: Parents of many of the 5,0001 to 16,000 children expected to become ineligible for city daycare programs under guidelines that become effective April 1 will be forced to return to old alternatives, such as care by relatives or neighbors or return to welfare rolls, according to city and state officials.

title: Kentucky Five Takes N.I.T. Title by 7167
description: You can find a Reggie Warford on most any college basketball team in the country. He is the high school hotshot who gets lost in a wealth of other high school hotshots, all recruited for the same position.

title: The Sports Scoreboard
description: The Sports Scoreboard

title: Tennis Students Yell Out Loudly
description: BALDWIN, L.I., March 21 Tile Nastase might have had a heart attack if he had been here to see ita school for tennis officials. There they were at Baldwin Tennis Club this weekend, about 60 men and women learning to shout out! with all the gusto of an angry World Serves umpire. Argue with that kind of authority and you'd wish you were out playing in the traffic on Sunrise Highway.

title: 9 County Leaderships at Stake In Unheralded Primary Voting
description: The hoopla surrounding the battle for Democratic Presidential delegates in the April 6 primary has obscured for many voters the fact that the leadership of nine county political organizations here will be at stake that day.

title: Robert Braley, 80, Credited With First U.S. Shot in 1917
description: CINCINNATI, March 21 (UPI) Robert E. Braley, who is credited with having been the first soldier in the American Expeditionary Force to fire shot in World War 1, died Friday at his holm here. He was 80 years old.

title: Woman Enters the Race for Sheriff
description: Marie Distefano Miller, a 34yearold sociologist from Hillsborough who has taught criminology on the college level, announced yesterday that she had received the Democratic Party's endorsement for sheriff of Somerset County.

title: FUND FOR INQUIRY INTO LEAKS IS CUT
description: WASHINGTON, March 22In a surprise move, a House subcommittee today cut funds sought to investigate the leaking of the Pike Intelligence Committee report from $350,000 to $150,000.

title: Cancer Patients Relieved by Placebos
description: CHICAGO, March 22 (AP)Pills containing no active ingrediens brought pain relief for a large percentage of cancer patients, particularly among very selfsufficient persons, a Mayo Clinic study shows.

title: College Results
description: College Results

title: N.H.L. Plans Cup TV; Seeks New York Outlet
description: The National Hockey League, which had been without a network television base in the United States, has formed its own TV company in an attempt to get the Stanley Cup playoffs on the air. No New York outlet, however, has been set.

title: Israel and P.L.O. Clash in U.N. Debate
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 22Representatives of Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization clashed in debate before the Security Council today as the Council began, discussing antiIsraeli unrest in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River.

title: City to Pay Broker's Fee In Auction Sale of School
description: For services that are not altogether clear, the city has decided to pay a brokerage fee of $35,500 to Abraham M. Lindenbaum, the real estate lawyer and Democratic fundraiser in connection with the sale of a school.

title: Shriver Is 5th Democrat To Quit Presidential Race
description: WASHINGTON, March 22Sargent Shriner became today the fifth Democrat to abandon pursuit of the party's Presidential nomination, contending that his sixmonth campaign had been a remarkable success in the light of the handicaps he faced.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Supreme Court refused to intervene in the closing of a Hackensack adult bookstore whose owners have been charged with violating local and state obscenity statutes. The store, Le Sex Shoppe, was ordered closed by Judge Gerald Monahan in District Court on March S. He ruled that the store violated the state's obscenity law beyond a reasonable doubt.

title: More Drift for Britain?
description: Harold Wilson's surprising decision to step down at 60 as Prime Minister and leader of the Labor Party has inevitably kindled hopes for a major recasting of British politics. Those hopes will almost certainly be disappointed.

title: Rangers: Proud Team Stumbles to Mediocrity
description: In this Bicentennial year, on their Golden Anniversary, after nine consecutive years in the Stanley Cup playoffs and despite two coaches and a new general manager, the New York Rangers have turned out to be the flop of the town.

title: Prosecutor Seeking An Underworld Role In Mellon Abduction
description: District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn is reported to be investigating whether $250,000 to $275,000 was paid to organizedcrime figures to abduct the two young daughters of Karen Boyd Mellon from her home here last Friday.

title: Economist Joan Robinson, 72, Is Full of Fight
description: AMHERST, Mass. Few economists of any generation manage to achieve a reputation for greatness in the rarefied world of economic theory, where deep and difficult questions are pondered about how economic systems actually work.

title: Face to Face With the Spirit of the Clay
description: Some of the women were lying on the floor, others were sitting on tables. A few stood, or knelt.

title: Tonight's Yonkers Entries
description: Horses listed In order of post positions. Lefler deslonairs OTB iislion

title: City Underground
description: The decision of Union Carbide to move its corporate headquarters to Connecticut is a grave reflection of the illness afflicting New York. Unless this city can provide firm evidence that it is putting its fiscal house in order and at the same time restoring the decencies of urban life, the productive base on which it depends for jobs and tax revenue will be irreparably injured.

title: Sampson in Nicosia Court
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 22 (Reuters)Nikos G. Sampson, who was briefly president of Cyprus after the 1974 coup that toppled Archbishop Makarios, was taken handcuffed and with a strong police escort today to the Nicosia district court, where he was granted an extension of time to appoint a lawyer and prepare his defense.

title: Social Security Out?
description: Mayor Beame may be playing political poker with the tightfisted dispensers of urban aid in Washington as he files twoyear notice of the city's intention to quit the Social Security System. But bluff could well turn Into reality if constructive action is not taken this year reduce the staggering burden of civil service retirement costs on the taxpayers of New York City and State.

title: Television
description: Evening

title: HIGH COURT PLANS STOCKTAX RULING
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI)  The Supreme Court agreed today to rule next term on whether New York State's stock transfer tax unconstitutionally discriminates against purchases made in outofstate regional exchanges.

title: Two Uncommitted Slates Switching to Humphrey
description: Two uncommitted national convention delegate slates sponsored by the powerful Erie County Democratic organization announced yesterday that they would support Senator Hubert H. Humphrey for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Off at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, March 22Yields declined on Treasury hills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Added Options Approved
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had approved a proposal by the Chicago Board Options Exchange to add up to 20 classes of options.

title: WEST BANK VICTIM DIES IN A HOSPITAL
description: TEL AVIV, March 22An 11yearold Arab boy who was shot last Wednesday as Israeli soldiers sought to disperse demonstrators in the occupied West Bank died today in a Jerusalem hospital.

title: Ralph Blane Plays Dual Role in Series, Singing Own Songs
description: Ralph Blane, who ended the sixth season of the Lyrics and Lyricists series at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. on Sunday evening, proved to be the first lyricist to appear there who is basically a singer.

title: JERSEY WORKERS VOTE TO ACCEPT BUSLINE OFFER
description: Drivers, clerks and mechanics of New Jersey's largest bus company, Transport of New Jersey, overrode their union leadership last night and voted, by a slim margin, to accept management's latest contract offer and end their twoweek strike.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times on Feb. 27 said that the public relations firm of Sydney S. Baron & Company had hired Jules Backman, an economist, to serve as spokesman for its client, the Electronic Industries Association of Japan, before Congressional committees. Mr. Backman wrote a report for the Baron company on electronic imports but was not retained to appear before Congressional committees and did not appear before any committee.

title: Senior Tennis Is Flourishing Locally
description: Senior tournament tennis (ages 45 to 70) is alive and vigorous in the metropolitan area, despite perennial complaints of aches and ailments among its partisans.

title: Energy Crisis Rescues Ferries
description: A few years ago, the plodding, oldfashioned ferryboat looked as if it would go the way of the stagecoach. Each new bridge inevitably put yet another ferry line out of business, and new highways, allowing faster automobile travel, made circuitous land routes quicker than short water crossings.

title: PRINCESS WHITE, 95, JAZZ DANCER, SINGER
description: Princess White, whose stage career as a dancer and singer began in 1886, collapsed and died backstage at the Emelin Theater for the Performing Arts in Mamaroneck, N. Y., Saturday night after singing two numbers with Clyde Bernhardt's Harlem Biues and Jazz Band. She was 95 years old and lived at 387 South 18th Street in Newark.

title: State Senate Unit Urges New Way to Select Judges
description: ALBANY, March 22Judges on the state's highest court would be appointed by the Governor and voters would be able to decide in local referendums whether they wanted their Supreme Court judges to be elected or appointed, underi a package of proposed state constitutional amendments in troduced today by a bipartisan Senate task force.

title: Advertising
description: Ethan Allen Inc., the furniture manufacturer, is betting that the public is ready to buy again and is putting up more than $1 million to implant its name in the consumer consciousness.

title: Prosecutor Seeking An Underworld Role In Mellon Abduction
description: District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn is reported to be investigating whether $250,000 to $275,000 was paid to organizedcrime figures to abduct the two young daughters of Karen Boyd Mellon from her home here last Friday.

title: MARSHALL BALFOUR, POPULATION EXPERT
description: Dr. Marshall C. Balfour, a retired staff member of the Rockefeller Foundation, who had been active in population control efforts, died Saturday in. Chapel Hill, N.C., where he lived. He was 79 years old.

title: Supreme Court Upholds Right of Cities To Set Residency Rules for Employees
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Supreme Court upheld today ordinances that require municipal employees to live within a city's boundaries.

title: Hearings to Open Today on Application to Manufacture Floating Nuclear Power Plants
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 22Public hearings on whether ???license the manufacture of the world's first floating nuclear power plants will open here tomorrow.

title: Kissinger Says U.S. Will Not Tolerate Any Further Cuban Intervention Abroad
description: DALLAS, March 22Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger warned Cuba again today that the United States would refuse to countenance the use of Cuban troops to bring about another Angolaeven against white minority regimes opposed by this country in Africa.

title: Television Agreement Is Reached by Cosmos
description: Television is no longer forbidden zone for the New York Cosmos.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Federal judge in New Haven yesterday handed down prison sentences ranging from 10 to 20 years to six men convicted in the March 1, 1975 firebombing of the Sponge Rubber Products factory in Shelton. David N. Bubar, 46 years old, received a 20year term, the stiffest sentence handed out by Judge Jon 0. Newman in District Court.

title: Tito Back From Tour
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 22 (UPI)  President Tito returned today from a 13day tour that included visits to Mexico, Panama, Venezeula and Portugal.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Strauss's Ariadne auf Naxos, 8. NEW YORK CITY OPERA, New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, Blzet's Carmen, 8.

title: 722 Adult Residents Took Part in Survey
description: The New York Times poll of 722 New Jersey adults was conducted by telephone from March 4 through March 8.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: News Summary and Index
description: Britain yesterday proposed a twostage plan to end the Rhodesian crisis and offered to join other countries in providing Rhodesia with financial aid to insure an orderly transition to a multiracial society. But Foreign Secretary James Callaghan said that no assistancediplomatic or financialwould be offered unless Prime Minister Ian D. Smith agreed to accept the principle of majority rule and to hold democratic elections in 18 months to two years. [Page 1. Column 8.]

title: Racing Board Cuts May Imperil Role
description: The diminishing number of people who work for the State Racing and Wagering Board are wondering who will be the next to go.

title: Panel AsksWage Freeze For City Transit Workers
description: The Temporary Commission on City Finances urged yesterday that wages be frozen for Transit Authority workers and that the transit fare be held at its present rate until July 1. 1978.

title: NATIONAL ENDING NO FRILLS FARE
description: National Airlines has decided to drop its no frills bargain fare to Florida May 1, and competing airlines that never liked the idea In the first place are following suit.

title: Beame Gives U.S. Notice Of Social Security Pullout
description: Mayor Beame yesterday filed notice that the city would withdraw from the Social Security system two years from r.ow if studies confirmed tentative estimates that withdrawing might save the city up to $200 million annually.

title: ITALIANS ARREST AN EXAIR CHIEF
description: ROME. March 22 (AP)The former chief of the Italian Air Force and a prominent Rome lawyer were arrested tonight in connection with a reported $1.6 million bribe by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for the sale of 14 C130 Hercules planes in 1970.

title: Seaver Will Be Surprised if Mets Trade Him
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22Tom Seaver replied to some public sniping today, insisted he was neither militant nor reaching for the moon and said he would be really surprised if the New York Mets traded him.

title: CareyCunningham Slate Lacks Versatility That Had Been Goal
description: Two weeks before the New York Democratic Presidential primary, the Empire Slate for the Empire Statethe grand plan of Governor Carey and the Democratic state chairman Patrick J. Cunningham, to elect an uncommitted Democratic National Convention delegation under their controlis more of a hollow slogan than a political reality.

title: Drouin of Islanders Cleared of Charges
description: Drouin received a :gross misconduct from Dave Newell, the referee, after he allegedly fired the puck at him at the buzzer of the penaltyfilled game.

title: ITALY'S TOP PARTY DIVIDED ON REDS
description: ROME, March 22For five days now, the Christian Democrats have been applauding, booing and sometimes scuffling, finding time for threehour lunches and struggling all the while at their congress to find a way to maintain their political dominance.

title: Don't Bury It
description: The basic average earnings of transit workers now stand at $13,700; but extra pay, cityfinanced pensions, free optical and dental care and other benefits increase that figure by more than half, bringing the annual cost of maintaining the average employee to $20,787, exclusive of costofliving adjustments.

title: Helping New York
description: A group of volunteer tutors sitting in the office of the principal of Public School 169 in Bayside, Queens, were talking intensively about their firstgrade pupils before they begin instruction: I knew I wanted to help a child try to read well, one tutor said, because if they can't read now, they may drop out of school later.

title: HYNES TO DEFEND BID FOR AUDITORS
description: ALBANY, March 22Charles J. Hynes, the special state prosecutor in the nursinghome situation, was asked by Assembly Democrats today to appear with his staff before legislative (fiscal aides tomorrow to defend Ihis request for a $2.3 million budget appropriation providing his office with 90 more audirtors.

title: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title
description: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title

title: Hilda Butsova, 78, Ballerina in Pavlova's Company, Dead
description: Hilda Boots Mills, an Englishhorn ballet dancer who joined Anna Pavlova's company in 1912 and took the professional name Hilda Butsova at her suggestion, died Sunday in White Plains Hospital. She had suffered a heart attack while staying with relatives in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: INTERNS STRIKES CURBED BY N.L.R.B.
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)The National Labor Relations Board delivered a crippling blow to the budding union movement among young doctors today by ruling that interns and residents were not entitled to organize or strike under the umbrella of Federal law.

title: Woman Dies Landing Plane
description: HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 22 (AP)Joyce Arrington, 51 years old, who did not know how to fly, was killed yesterday, when the singleengine airplane in which she was to be a passenger took off accidentally, then crashed when she tried to land it. Officers said the pilot of the Cessna 210, Dr. Jack Delhotal, 52, also of Wichita, Kan., had trouble starting the plane's engine and was outside the aircraft handcranking the propeller when the engine caught and the plane climbed into the air.

title: Syria Reported Confident Of Truce in Lebanon Soon
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, March 22Syrian mediators are confident that a new ceasefire in Lebanon may be achieved within two or three days, informed sources said here tonight.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: Unlike humans, who can manipulate their environment or don clothing, or certain birds and animals who can grow down or fur to offset the cold, most fish are coldblood d. They have to be in water that nearly matches their body temperatures.

title: 2 HARNESS TRACKS ASSAILED BY STATE
description: While Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways were lobbying in the Legislature for larger shares of betting revenues, the tracks were being financially drained by their parent corporations, the State Commission of Investigation charged yesterday.

title: Today's Primary
description: North Carolina votes today in the nation's sixth Presidential primary election of 1976.

title: INQUIRER SUES RIZZO OVER UNION PROTEST
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 22 (AP)The Philadelphia Inquirer filed in Federal court today a $70,000 damage suit against Mayor Frank L. Rizzo and Police Commissioner Joseph O'Neill for permitting picketers to force a curtailment of the newspaper's operations on Saturday.

title: Roosevelt and Yonkers Tracks Assailed in State Inquiry Report
description: While Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways were lobbying in the Legislature for larger shares of betting revenues, the tracks were being financially drained by their parent corporations, the State Commission of Investigation charged yesterday.

title: City Fighting Navy's Plan to Move Office
description: City officials and members of Congress began a campaign yesterday to head off a Navy Department plan that would move 734 civilian jobs and a $12millionayear payroll from Brooklyn to the Great Lakes Naval Station 40 miles north of Chicago.

title: State Receives $183,209 To Restore Historic Sites.
description: TRENTON, March 22 (AP)The Department of Environmental Protection said today it had received $183,209 for the purchase and restoration of historic sites.

title: PARTS MONOPOLY BY G.M. CHARGED
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Government charged the General Motors Corporation today with monopoly control of crash replacement parts for its autos, a practice that is allegedly costly to the public and to independent repair shops.

title: A Date Is Chosen For Payless Week At City University
description: The Board of Higher Education passed a resolution last night designating the week of April 12 as the week its employees may be furloughed without pay, but it left open the possibility that continuing negotiations may avert such a furlough.

title: Senate Will Hold Hearing On Tax Package March 31
description: TRENTON, March 22The State Senate took up today a $900 million tax program, including a state income tax, with the Senate President, Matthew Feldman, cautiously optimistic about passage.

title: 2 Bank Mergers Approved By U.S. to Avoid Failures
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)Federal officials have approved bank consolidations in Florida and Washington in moves to prevent bank failures.

title: JERSEY WORKERS VOTE TO ACCEPT BUSLINE OFFER
description: Drivers, clerks and mechanics of New Jersey's largest bus company, Transport of New Jersey, overrode their union leadership last night and voted, by a slim margin, to accept management's latest contract offer and end their twoweek strike.

title: The Campaign Doctor
description: The telephone rings constantly these days. Everybody wants advice. One moment it's Morris Udall. This is Morris Udall, he says. Udall, I tell him, I'm a busy man. I've got Ronald Reagan on hold and Fred Harris trying to get me to accept a longdistance call collect, so I'm going to give it to you short and sweet and I'm just going to say it once.

title: 32 Seized, Policeman Is Shot In Major California Drug Raids
description: LOS ANGELES, March 22 (AP)Thirtytwo persons were arrested and a policeman was shot today in raids that the police described as the dismantling of a drug ring that had supplied up to a quarter of the heroin on Los Angeles streets.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Britain yesterday proposed a twostage plan to end the Rhodesian crisis and offered to join other countries in providing Rhodesia with financial aid to insure an orderly transition to a multiracial society. But Foreign Secretary James Callaghan said that no assistancediplomatic or financialwould be offered unless Prime Minister Ian D. Smith agreed to accept the principle of majority rule and to hold democratic elections in 18 months to two years. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Jackson Passes Up a Race, Waits for April Primaries
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 22  The phone rings and rings at the JacksonforPresiclent office in Raleigh. On the clay before the North Carolina primary, there is no one there to answer at noon or at 4 P.M.

title: Legislator Decries Synagogue Arson
description: Assemblyman Charles E. Schumer led a tour of a burnedout synagogue on the Lower East Side yesterday to dramatize legislation he is introducing to try to curb arson in houses of worship.

title: Pound Unchanged As Lira Rebounds; Dollar Ends Mixed
description: BRUSSELS, March 22 (UPI)The Italian lira and the British pound held their own on European money markets today with an easing of speculative pressures that had buffeted foreign exchanges last week. The dollar was mixed.

title: Italian General Seized
description: Gen. Duilio Fanali; former chief of the Italian Air Force, and a Rome lawyer were arrested in a reported $1.6 million Lockheed bribe. Page 7.

title: Bleak Report Has Fleet Street at Odds
description: LONDON. March 22A bleak report on British newspapers, which urges sharp manpower cuts and at least $100 million in loans to the ailing industry, has triggered a controversy an Fleet Street and raised questions about the future of a number of publications.

title: ARGENTINE ARMY MAPS TAKEOVER
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 22The Argentine armed forces, now visibly preparing to overthrow the Government of President Isabel Martinez de Pern, plan to close congress, arrest many Peronist political and union leaders and impose martlal law, according to military sources.

title: DOLLIE BOOTH HEPBURI
description: Dollie Booth Hepburn, former acquisition and personnel director of the Columbia University Libraries, died Friday in New Paltz, N.Y. She was 85 years old.

title: RICHARD KUTZLEB, NEWSMAN, 59, DIES
description: Richard H. Kutzleb, a former newspaper and broadcasting executive, died yesterday in Red Bank, N.J. He was 59 years old and lived in Freehold, N.J.

title: Summary of Actions Taken by the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON. March 22 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Election Board Loses Most of Power
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Federal Election Commission lost most of its authority today when Congress failed to meet a supreme Court deadline for reconstituting the agency to make it Constitutional. Hours before the commission went into almost total eclipse, it approved payment of $980,000 in Federal primary subsidies for Presidential candidates, the last money it can authorize until Congress restores its power.

title: Wards Island Offered To U.S. Fire Academy
description: Mayor Beame proposed yesterday that the city's newly completed Fire Department Training Center on Wards Island serve as the home of the new National Fire Academy. City officials will present the proposal today at a hearing in Washington of the Site Selection Board for the federally sponsored fire training center mandated under the National Fire Protection and Control Act of 1974.

title: Books of The Times
description: Andrew Marvell's Green Thought in a Green Shade would not do for us today when we think in tanks. Besides, nature makes many of us nervous, unless we have a swimming pool or a tennis court to lend it a less profound purpose than simply being there. The Bible says we began life in a garden, and some of us hope to end it in another one, the Elysian Fields of heaven. In the interval, we have our pachysandra, our treelined streets, our window boxes, our flower pots, our plastic heresies.

title: TV: CBS 60 Minutes Returns to the Syrian Jews
description: Declaring that in the eight years of 60 Minutes, to single piece has caused more controversy than Syr??? Toughest Enemy, which was broadcast in February, 1975, Mike Wallace and the CBS News series returned to the subject of Syrian Jewry this last Sunday.

title: Shula Rating On Kapp Not Impressive
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 22Don Shula, head coach aridpart owner of the Miami Dolphins, gave Joe Kapp relatively low marks today as he rated quarterbacks from the witness stand in Kapp's antitrust suit against the NationalFootball League.

title: Wallace, Reagan At Bay
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., March 21On this last weekend before the North Carolina primary, residents of this city were almost unanimously gathered by their radio and television sets but not to listen to Presidential candidates. The basketball team of the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, unknown by most of the nation, was playingand barely losing in the finals of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: Most Jerseyans in Poll Back Income Tax
description: A majority of New Jerseyans interviewed in a poll by The New York Times support a state income tax and casino gambling in Atlantic City. Mcst believe that living in New Jersey is better than outsiders may think, They are pleased with their life style, proud of their beach resorts and satisfied with the environment, but they are wary of government officials, unhappy with the tax structure and worried about the economy.

title: EARL BENHAM DIES; ACTOR, SONG WRITER
description: Earl Benham, a former actor, song writer and outfitter to entertainers, died Sunday at his home in Northport, L.I. He was 89 years old.

title: Music: Composer Boulez
description: At some point late in the last century it occurred to Ives and probably other composers that fresh sounds and undreamedof musical complexities might be achieved by setting musicians free to wander about the orchestra uhile playing. In recent years the idea has been exploited with great ingenuity. Within the last few weeks alone, we have heard pre mieres of works by Lukas Foss and Thea Musgrave that made much of the transientsoloist device. And on Sunday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Pierre Boulez led members of the Brooklyn Philharmnia in the New York premiere of his Domaines, in which the clarinet soloist, Stanley Drucker, may have established a mileage record.

title: Bulge Along San Andreas Fault Sends Tremors Through. Quake Specialists
description: LOS ANGELES, March 22They call it The Bulge and The Blister and The Palmdale Bubble. And the scientists who study such things wonder: Has the earth heaved itself upward because it is sending an advance warning of the great earthquake that has long been expected here?

title: $1,000aSeat Gala to Aid Carnegie Hall
description: Carnegie Hall will open today a drive for $6.5 million that will be highlighted by a concert on May 18 that will include such artists as Vladimir Horowitz, Leonard Bernstein, Dietrich FischerDieskau, Mstislav Rostropovich, Isaac Stern, Martina Arroyo and members of the New York Philharmonic.

title: ESTHER WHERRY
description: Esther Ann Redway Smith Wherry, a former fashion copywriter for John Wanamaker and Franklin Simon stores here, died Sunday in Middlebury, Vt., at the age of 87.

title: Britain's Initiative
description: Britain has unexpectedly launched a fresh initiative aimed at producing a constitutional settlement in Rhodesia and heading off racial war in southern Africabut with no great hope that its proposals will be accepted by Rhodesia's white minority Government. As Foreign Minister dames Lailagnan Iola Parliament, the contradictory utterances by Prime Minister Ian Smith give very little room for believing that one can negotiate with him.

title: Ford Gets Nixon Report, Calls It Useful
description: WASHINGTON, March 22President Ford received last week former President Nixon's report on his recent trip to China and found It very interesting and useful, the White House press secretary, Ron Nessen, said today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 23, 1976

title: Article 1  No Title
description: THE ART OF BASE RUNNING being demonstrated to St. Louis Cardinals pitchers at training camp in Florida

title: Swiss Reject Participation By Workers in Management
description: GENEVA, March 22  The Swiss have rejected overwhelmingly in national referendums two proposals to permit the federal Parliament to enact legislation granting workers a voice in the management of the companies that employ them.

title: Kissinger Applauds Plan
description: DALLAS, March 22  Secretary of State Hery A. Kissinger, at a question period tonight following a speech here to the Dallas World Affairs Council, said the United States welcomed the proposals for a Rhodesian settlement by the British Foreign Secretary, James Callaghan. Mr. Kissinger call Mr. Callaghan's speech in the House of Commons today a most constructive approach.

title: BRITAIN PROPOSES A TWOSTAGE PLAN IN RHODESIA CRISIS
description: LONDON, March 22Britain proposed a twostage plan today to end the Rhodesian crisis, and offered to join other countries in making available financial aid to Rhodesia to insure an orderly transition to a multiracial society.

title: Panel Asks Wage Freeze For City Transit W orkers
description: The Temporary Commission on City Finances urged yesterd day that wages be frozen for Transit Authority workers and that the transit fare be held at its present rate until July 1. 1978.

title: DelBello Asks County to Modify 2YearOld Disposal System
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 22The Westchester County Executive, Alfred B. DelBello, asked the Board of Legislators today to approve major modifications in a countywide solidwastedisposal system described two years ago as among the most advanced in the nation.

title: Principal Is Suspended For Disobeying an Order
description: A Queens high school principal with a reputation for being a strict disciplinarian was suspended yesterday by School Chancellor Irving Anker after the principal had refused to comply with the board's orders to readmit a student he had suspended for misbehavior.

title: Smith Leads Advance in Coast Tennis
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 22 (AP)Stan Smith had to struggle to defeat Mike Cahill of Wilmington, Del., 64, 75; Steve Krulevitz of Baltimore upset Vijay Amritraj of India, 36, 63, 62, and Bill Brown of San Luis Obispo, Calif., pulled the second upset of the day by downing Jeff Borowiak, 46, 76, 61, at the start of the $200,000 American Airlines tennis tournament today at the Mission Hills Country Club.

title: Bridge:
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 22The United States women's team seeking the world championship successfully defended its national wornen's team title here last night, in the concluding event of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, after a fierce struggle with an East Coast foursome.

title: 1600 Takes Rough Road to Broadway
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 Broadway musicals are not born, they are remade on the road, but if there ever wasat least on papera milliondollar sure thing it was 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: H. TERRELL VAN INGEN
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 22H. Terrell Van Ingen, a retired realestate man, died today at Griffin Hospital in Derby, Conn. He had been a resident of Greenwich for 50 years.

title: Steinbrenner Rule on Hair Splits Yanks
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 22Hair today, gone tomorrow.

title: STOCKS EDGE UP IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market edged up yesterday for the second consecutive session.

title: DOW RISES BY 2.44 TO END AT 98229
description: The stock market, generally unmoved by last week's rather glowing economic reports, remained little changed in neutral ground yesterday. Volume again was moderate and well below the pellmell pace set in January and February.

title: STATE COURT ORDERS CUNNINGH AMINQUIRY
description: The Court of Appeals, in an unusually quick action, yesterday ordered oral arguments next week on an appeal brought by Patrick J. Cunningham, the Democratic state chairman, to reverse a lower court order requiring him to appear before a special grand jury investigating the sale of judgeships in the Bronx.

title: GEORGE J. DELANEY
description: George J. Delaney, who retired in 11)64 as circulation sales director of The Wall Street Journal of Dow Jones & Company Inc., died Saturday In West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 70 years old and lived in Lakehurst, N. J.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Wisconsin Public Service Corporation said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission 1.1 million common shares in connection with a proposed public offering through underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc.

title: A Japanese Dives Plane Into House Of Lockheed Agent
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, March 23 A young Japanese actor apparently tried to kill Yoshio Kodama, the rightist power broker involved in the Lockheed scandal here, by crashing a light plane into Mr. Kodarna's home this morning.

title: Lever Brothers Lists 9.7% Rise in Net on 11.7% Sales Gain for Year
description: The Lever Brothers Company, the United States subsidiary of Unilever, Ltd. of Britain and its partner, Unilever N.V. of the Netherlands, had a net profit last year of $11.3 million, an increase of 9.7 percent from the $10.3 million earned in 1974.

title: $1,000aSeat Gala to Aid Carnegie Hall
description: Carnegie Hall will open today a drive for $6.5 million that will be highlighted by concert on May 18 that will include such artists as Vladimir Horowitz, Leonard Bernstein, Dietrich FischerDieskau, Mstislay Rostropovich, Isaac Stern, Martina Arroyo and members of the New York Philharmonic.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standinas
description: Hockey, Basketball Standinas

title: SHAPINSKY, ATPIANO, HAS LIKABLE WAYS
description: Ian Shapinsky, the young California pianist, left a mixed though generally favorable impression at his Town Hall recital Sunday. On the positive side of the ledger were his iightfingered, highpowered Mephisto Waltz and a pulsirig account of the Scriabin Fifths Sonata that made a cohesive unit out of the score's darting colors, shifting moods and sharp dynamic contrasts.

title: WEEKEND BOXING
description: WEMBLEY, England  John Stracey, 146 pounds, England, knocked out Hedgemon Lewis, 146, Los Angeles, 10 rounds.

title: Chess:
description: Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, captured the $8,000 first prize in the Louis D. Statham mastersplus tournament in Lone Pine, Calif., with a score of 51.

title: Dividends
description: Dividends

title: Two Southerners Even in a Carolina Town
description: SANFORD, N.C.Twentyfive years ago, this Small town lying almost in the exact geographic center of North Carolina was fundamentally a tobacco town.

title: Wallace Hopes for Victory In North Carolina Today
description: FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., March 22In a lastminute effort to stave off defeat by Jimmy Carter in tomorrow's Democratic Presidential primary, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama traveled to six North Carolina cities and towns today, proclaiming his fine health and charging the former Georgia Governor with misleading voters.

title: MOST IN POLL CALL NIGHT WALKS SAFE
description: A majority of New Jersey residents polled by The New York Times believes it is safe to walk in their neighborhoods after dark, but they also fear that crime is increasing and would like to see stiffer punishment for lawbreakers.

title: Business Records
description: Chapter XI petition for an arrangement by: CHRONETICS INC., 1 Levevre Lane, New Rochelle, N.Y. Liabilities, $1,484,813; assets, $605,000. Signed by Sid Gordon. Business is selling electronic equipment.

title: Botswana Nervous About the News From Neighboring Rhodesia
description: GABORONE, Bdtswana, March 18Gaborone is a pleasant little town that affords transit passengers on flights between South Africa and Zambia the rare sensation of being somewhere without knowing what country they are in. Few passengers get off and stay.

title: Helping New York
description: A group of volunteer tutors sitting in the office of the principal of Public School 169 in Bayside, Queens, were talking intensively about their firstgrade pupils before they begin instruction: I knew I wanted to help a child try to read well, one tutor said, because if they can't read now, they may drop out of school later.

title: Taiwan Strengthens Ties With Saudis
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 22One of Taiwan's few foreignpolicy successes in the last few years, a period in which more than 30 countries broke relations with Taipei to recognize Peking, has been in strengthening ties with Saudi Arabia. Several developments recently have pointed up the close relations between the two countries.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: Yorkers who have not recently visited the Frick Collection, one of the city's most splendidly housed art troves, as well as flower lovers who are mindful that the Conservatory of the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx Is temporarily closed for reconstruction, can enjoy a double treat tomorrow through Sunday, when a largescale assembly of orchids will adorn the museum at I East 70th Street.

title: Readan Declares Ford Is Evading Key Issues
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., March 22Ronald Reagan ended his North Carolina campaign today by charging that President Ford and his supporters were evading crucial issues and might be engaging in dirty tricks.

title: Carnegie Hall Board Chairman
description: As might be expected, the board chairman of the Carnegie Hall Society Inc., which today begins a twomonth task of raising $6.5 million for the new Carnegie Hall National EndowMan ment Fund, is a devoted lover of In the music. Less likely News to assume, however, is that Richard Abraham Debs, who took over his post as the society's chief administrative officer last November, is a man with a decidely varied past, who just happens to make his living as the secondranking officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: Beame Gives U.S. Notice Of Social Security Pullout
description: Mayor Beame yesterday filed notice that the city would withdraw from the Social Security system two years from row if studies confirmed tentative estimates that withdrawing might save the city up to $200 million annually.

title: Ski Team Has Bumpy Landing
description: HUNTER. N.Y., March 22The international World Cup skiing troupe, numbering 160 racers, coaches and trainers, suffered the indignity of having their luggage and equipment dumped in front of their hotel following their arrival here tonight after an eighthour bus ride from Quebec.

title: Economist Joan Robinson, 72, Is Full of Fight
description: AMHERST, Mass.  Few economists of any generation manage to achieve a reputation for greatness in the rarefied world of economic theory, where deep and difficult questions are pondered about how economic systems actually work.

title: Rockefeller Warns Europeans Against Reds in Governments
description: PARIS, March 22Vice President Rockefeller asserted today that the United States would have to review its relationships with any Western European government that included Communists.

title: HELEN E. CURTIN
description: MIDDLETOWN, R. I., March 22Helen Elizabeth Curtin, former chief dietitian at Veterans Administration Hospitals in New York and Boston, died at a nursing home here Saturday.

title: Dogging Fat Cats No More.
description: LOS ANGELES  This Presidential primary season marks the first time since 1968 that I won't be on the prowl for fellow fat cats.

title: HYNES TO DEFEND BID FOR AUDITORS
description: ALBANY, March 22Charles J. Hynes, the special state prosecutor in the nursinghome situation, was asked by Assembly Democrats today to appear with his staff before legislative fiscal aides tomorrow to defend his request for a $2.3 million budget appropriation providing his office with 90 more auditors.

title: Market Place
description: From time to time of late there may have been a howl or two in the executive suites of companies, whose stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange as letters arrived from the exchange concerning listing fees.

title: Yonkers Results
description: Yonkers Results

title: Walter J. Kohler Jr. Dead; ExGovernor of W Wisconsint
description: Walter Jodock Kohler Jr., threeterm Governor of Wisconsin, whose loss to William Proxmire in 1957 in the race to fill Joseph. R. McCarthy's Senate seat shocked Republicans across the country, died on Sunday of a heart ailment at Sheboygan (Wis.) Hospital. He was 71. years old.

title: Poll Finds Humphrey Democrats Top Choice
description: The Gallup Poll reported yesterday that Senator. Hubert H. Humphrey remains the top choice of rankandfile Democrats for the 1976 Presidential nomination although he has not indicated his intention to enter the Democratic primaries.

title: Inquiry on F.B.I.'s Buying Expanded to All Purchases
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Justice Department's investigation of possible kickbacks to senior F.B.I. officials has been expanded to include scrutiny of all F.B.I. procurements in the last five years, a wellplaced Justice Department official acknowledged today.

title: Notes on People
description: An electronic professor at the University of Tokyo, Hiroshi Inose, will be awarded the second annual $25,000 Marconi International Fellowship. The scholarship, supported by 22 corporations in the field, was established by Gioia Marconi Braga, daughter of the radoi pioneer, the late Guglielmo Marconi, and the Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies. Dr. Inose was cited not only for pioneering in switching systems applicable to control of the information explosion and Tokyo's trafficcontrol system  but for applying computer technology to the study of Greek and Roman influences on Japanese roof tiles of the 7th and 8th centuries.

title: FORD MAKES PLEA FOR SCIENCE BILLS
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 In a message on science and technology, President Ford today asked Congress to approve his $24.7 billion budget request for research and development and to pass legislation promptly to create a White House science, technology and engineering advisory office.

title: Lead Shot Will Be Banned For Hunting Use on Flyway
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI)Secretary of the Interior Thomas S. Kleppe has decided to bar waterfowl hunters from using lead shot, which may poison nearly 2 million ducks a year, this fall in designated areas of the Atlantic Flyway, it was announced today.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1978, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Monday, March 22. 63d day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAN JUAN (PRIMSA), San Juan March 29; sails from Elizabeth, N.J.

title: Court Extends SavingsBank Checkin
description: ALBANY, March 22  The State Court of Appeals today extended until May 31 the right of savings banks to offer socalled NOW checking acCounts. Opponents of a measure that would give such banks full checking powers used the court's decision to force a delay of the measure in the Assembly and Senate.

title: City Shelter for Men Assailed as Subhuman
description: State Senator Roy M. Goodman toured the city's Shelter Care Center for Men in downtown Manhattan yesterday and deplored conditions there as subhuman, filthy and degrading.

title: Benson, Indiana's Big Man Carrying an Extra Burden
description: Kent Benson's left wrist is wrapped in a plaster cast minutes after each Indiana basketball game, and the big Hoosier lives with the heavy thing until it is cut off minutes berore College the next game. This has been Sports routine since the Notes middle of the season, when the 610, 245pound center fell and tore ligaments in the wrist during the 14th of Indiana's 30 victories.

title: Bradley Buell, Health Planner And Welfare Expert, Dies at 83
description: Bradley Buell, a leader in the planning of health and welfare services, died yesterday in Lee Memorial Hospital, Fort Myers, Fla. He was 83 years old and a resident of nearby Sanibel Island.

title: ACCORD REACHED IN PIPER DISPUTE
description: A settlement has been reached in the sevenyear case growing out of the Bangor Punta Corporation's acquisition of control of the Piper Aircraft Corporation in 1969, Bangor punta announced yesterday. A lawsuit between Bangor Punta and certain members of the family of the late William T. Piper will be dropped, it was said.

title: In Memoriam
description: GILMORESarnueL To the most gentle man's man I have ever known. I salute you.

title: Magazine at OTB Off and Running
description: Two men have gone into the publishing business to make sure that no one has to leave an Off Track Betting office emptyhanded. They are not going to supply sure winners but they will distribute a free magazine.

title: French Champagne Use Up
description: PARIS, March 22 (AP)World consumption of French champagne jumped by 15.8 percent last year to 122.2 million bottles from 105.5 million a year before, the industry association reported today.

title: Soviet and the U.S. Are Shifting Hot Line to Satellite Systems
description: MOSCOW, March 22Soviet and American communications experts have successfully tested a new network of space satellites that will eventually replace the existing WashingItonMoscow hot line.

title: Zaire Spurs Reconciliation With the Victors in Angola
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, March 22 The command post here of the Angolan nationalist faction that was backed by Zaire in the Angolan civil war is empty.

title: ES. LINK STRESSED BY THAI MINISTER
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 22Thailand's Prime Minister said today that his country would not attempt to supervise, or interfere in any way in, the United States withdrawal from Thailand for the sake of friendship between the two countries in the future.

title: Southern and 12 Unions Accept a Rail Settlement
description: The Southern Railway and 12 of 20 labor unions announced acceptance yesterday of labor conditions laid down by Transportation Secretary William T. Coleman last week for Southern's acquisition of a 460mile line of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad through the Delmarva Peninsula.

title: State's Housing for Patients Decried
description: TRENTON, March 22 A subcommittee of the Legislature said today that the housing for patients at state institutions had been allowed to deteriorate to a deplorable Condition because maintenance workers were kept busy renobating employee housing.

title: Quebec Teachers Walk Out
description: MONTREAL, March 22 (AP) Thousands of Quebec teachers and publicservice workers staged a oneday walkout today, closing schools across the province and leaving many hospitals to operate with a minimum of support staff.

title: People and Business
description: Arthur F. Burns, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, warned the Senate Budget Committee yesterday that an effort to spur economic recovery by further budgetary stimulus could well backfire. He called for vigilance and flexibility in the months ahead.

title: Loyal Readers and Advertisers Put Frosting on McCall's Cake at 100
description: It is 13 years since the accompanying analysis of women's magazines appeared in the book that is generally credited with having started the women's liberation movement. Since then, American women by the millions have questioned their own dearly held assumption and reassessed their lives. They have changed their attitudes, their priorities, their life styles, and even in some cases, their partners.

title: David Rockefeller Said to Agree To Advise Egypt on Its Economy
description: BOSTON, March 22 (UPI)David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, has agreed to become an informal financial adviser to President! Anwar elSadat of Egypt, The Boston Globe reported tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: For more than two months the Board of Estimate has failed to act on New York City's secondyear proposed Community Development Program. As a result, $102 million in desperately needed money is sitting idly in the U.S. Treasury. This dreary development comes on top of the fact that only $20 million of last year's $100 million in Colimunity Development grants has actually been spent. This sluggish financial behavior hardly seems appropriate for a city flirting with bankruptcy.

title: Actress Is Freed On Bond in Death Of Colorado Skier
description: ASPEN, Colo., March 22 (AP) Claudine Longet, accompanied by her former husband, Andy Williams, the singer, appeared in court today in connection with the shooting death yesterday of Vladimir (Spider) Sabich, a professional skier.

title: On Hectoring Allies
description: The prospect of Communist participation in coalition governments of Italy and France is a legitimate concern for other members of NATO, particularly the United States. Despite a degree of independence of the Kremlin, demonstrated for years by the Italian party and in recent months by its French counterpart, Communist sharing in national power carries risks for the democratic systems of the two countries as well as for the alliance.

title: Many Clinical Labs Fail In Drug Identifying Tests
description: WASHINGTON, March 22It was a test of proficiency and everybody knew it. So when the Federal Center of Disease Control sent urine samples from drug abusers to 22 clinical laboratories, 17 of them made a perfect score in drug identification.

title: BEIRUT RIGHTISTS IN COUNTERATTACK
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, March 23Supported by heavy artillery fire, rightwing Christian militiamen counterattacked yesterday in a daylong bid to recapture their hotel stronghold in downtown Beirut, and closequarter fighting was still under way last night.

title: Frank French, 69, Headed Allied Chemical Fibers Unit
description: Frank J. French, former president of the Allied Chemical Corporation's fibers division, died Sunday of leukemia in Farmington, Conn. He was 69 years old and lived in Pine Plains, N. Y.

title: ANACONDA KEEPS PRICE RISE TO 3C
description: The Anaconda Sales Company, which raised its price for full sheet copper cathodes by 5 cents a pound on Saturday, yesterday rescinded 2 cents of that increase and joined other major copper producers at a price of 66 cents a pound. No reason was given, but the cutback was similar to the action taken on March 1 by the Cities Service Company, which tried to raise its price by cents a pound on Feb. 25. When other companies declined to go along, Cities Service rescinded its action.

title: A Japanese Dives Plane Into House Of Lockheed Agent
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, March 23 A young Japanese actor apparently tried to kill Yoshio Kodama, the rightist power broker involved in the Lockheed scandal here, by crashing a light plane into Mr. Kodama's home this morning.

title: Radio
description: 67:25 A.M., WNYCFM. Polka and Fugue from Schwanda, Weinberger; Ballet Suite No. 3, Shostakovich; Cello Concerto No. I, Viasov; Scherzo Fantastique, Stravinsky.

title: BEIRUT RIGHTISTS IN COUNTERATTACK
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, March 23Supported by heavy artillery fire, rightwing Christian militiamen counterattacked yesterday in a daylong bid to recapture their hotel stronghold in downtown Beirut, and closequarter fighting was still under way last night.

title: MachineWashable Suede
description: It seems that every other womar with a washing machine is dashing off to buy an Ultrasude dress to toss into it.

title: PARTS MONOPOLY BY G.M. CHARGED
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Government charged the General Motors Corporation today with monopoly control of crash replacement parts for its autos, a practice that is allegedly costly to the public and to independent repair shops.

title: The Theater
description: Three little girls growing tip.or at least getting a little less little. Jack Heifner's Vanities, which opened last night at the Chelsea Theater Center's Westside Theater (in West 43d Street, is a diverting account, perhaps even a mildly honest account, of three girls on their long, sad journey from cheerleaders at high school to sorority queens and finally to ladies wanly approaching the 30's with little more than their courage and their props to call their own.

title: Recital: By David Burge
description: David Burge remains one of the very finest exponents of contemporary piano literature before the public today, as his appearance Sunday evening at Alice Tully Hall, part of the ongoing Eastman School of Music series, reaffirmed.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times on Feb. 27 said that the public relations firm of Sydney S. Baron & Company had hired Jules Backman, an economist, to serve as spokesman for its client, the Electronic Industries Association of Japan, before Congressional committees. Mr. Backman wrote a report for the Baron company on electronic imports but was not retained to appear before Congressional committees and did not appear before any committee.

title: Production of Steel Shows Drop For the First Time in 6 Weeks
description: For the first time in six weeks, domestic steel production slipped from the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The weekly statistics placed output for the week ended March 20 at 2.51 million tons, down 1.2 percent from the preceding week when output reached its 1976 high of 2.54 million tons.

title: Carter Is Confident
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., March 22Mr. Carter, looking ahead, said today that he thought he had a chance to fool folks in Wisconsin, where Representafive Morris K. Udall has been: favored in the April 6 Democratic primary. He also predicted that he would win tomorrow's North Carolina primary by a small margin.

title: Miss Hearst Being Urged To Testify Against Others
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 22 Pressure has begun to build on Patricia Hearst to testify against her former associates and thus possibly obtain leniency from the Federal Government.

title: WNET Gets Record $685,512 in Pledges by Viewers
description: WNET 13 raised a record $685,512 in pledges from viewers during the 10day national subscription campaign, Festival 76, which ended Sunday night. The fundraising event was built around 15 special programs acquired by the Public Broadcasting Service, most of them produced abroad, and classic movies from the Janus Films library recently licensed to public television.

title: Phils Beat Tigers, 10, as They Play Ball!
description: LAKELAND, Fla., March 22 (AP)Jerry Martin's sacrifice fly in the ninth inning gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 10 victory today over the Detroit Tigers in the first exhibition baseball game of the delayed spring training season.

title: Today's Entries at Aqueduct
description: Horses listed In order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Yields on New YorkRelated Bonds Off; Credit Market Prices Continue to Surge
description: Interest rates on New Yorkrelated bonds and notes declined sharply yesterday in response to the spreading conviction that the state will solve its financial problems this spring Municipal Assistance Corporation and Urban Development Corporation bonds climbed dramatically in price, and Westchester County sold bondanticipation notes at a rate well below the rates incurred by Monroe County in recent months.

title: Charles Chapman, Boat Editor And Author of Piloting, Dead
description: Charles Frederic Chapman, editor and publisher of Motor Boating and Sailing and the author of the boatmen's bible Piloting, Seamanship and Small Boat Handling, died in Essex, Conn., on Sunday of a cardiac arrest. He was 95 years old.

title: Referees Under Attack
description: Kareem Abdul  Jabbar called Bob Rakel a racist. Earl Monroe threw a ball at Jake O'Donnell and Norm Van Lier hit Ken Sussman with a wad of chewing gum. Kevin Loughery collected six technical fouls in one game, Hubie Brown accosted Norm Drucker after a game and was fined $1,000, and Sunday night in Kansas City Ed Badger, the Chicago Bulls assstant coach, heaved a chair toward a fan after having been ejected from the game.

title: U.S. Offers to Exchange Soviet Agent for American
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The State Department has proposed to the Soviet Government that it exchange Sarkis O. Paskalian, who pleaded guilty last September to a charge of spying for Moscow, for an American intelligence agent now in Soviet custody, an American official confirmed today.

title: BRITAIN PROPOSES A TWOSTAGE PLAN IN RHODESIA CRISIS
description: LONDON, March 22 Britain proposed a twostage plan today to end the Rhodesian ??? and offered to join other countries in making available financial aid to Rhodesia to insture an orderly transition to a niultiracial society.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 22An official of Smith International Inc. disclosed today that Indonesia was the country involved in questionable payments the company has reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: A Mission of Mercy for a Blind Boy
description: Liviu Negut, a shy, 6yearold darkhaired boy from a small mountain village in eastern Rumania, will arrive at Kennedy International Airport this afternoon with the slender hope of regaining the eyesight he lost as an infant.

title: Miss Hearst Being Urged To Testify Against Others
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 22 Pressure has begun to build on Patricia Hearst to testify against her former associates and thus possibly obtain len1 iency from the Federal Government.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1978, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Monday, March 22. 63d day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Ballroom on a Ballroom Wall Is Unveiled in SoHo
description: A SoHo dream scene with an ideal SoHo cast takes place in The Ballroom Restaurant.

title: Maine Potatoes Advance by Limit Again,
description: The price of Maine potatoes for delivery in May again rose the daily permissible limit of 50 cents a hundred pounds yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: Offshore Challenge
description: When California voters passed the highly publicized Proposition 20 nearly four years ago, they had every right to think they were creating the first really effective coastal planning body in the nation. What they could not foresee was that at the first major opportunity, the oil industry would scorn that bodyand doing so enjoy Department of the Interior backing.

title: Smith in Stock Offering
description: A public offering or 1,083,850 common shares of Smith International Inc., at 3 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Canadian Paper Pact
description: CORNWALL, Canada March 22 (AP)Negotiators for Domtar Fine Papers Ltd. and the Canadian Paperworkers Union reached a tentative contract agreement yesterday for 1,400 striking workers in company plants in Toronto, Cornwall and St. Catharines, Ont.

title: The Angels Ask for an Arm and a Leg
description: HOLTVILLE, Calif., March 22Across the Imperial Valley, the flat green fields of carrots stretch toward the purple mountains beyond the nearby Mexican border. This farming town is the carrot capital of the world. Bugs Bunny should train here instead of baseball players. But the California Angels always spend a week on the four diamonds of their minor league Angeltown Complex before putting on fancy clothes in Palm Springs for their exhibition games. This is a good place to get into condition be cause there isn't much else to do, not even in El Centro where the Angels are lodged. Condition is particularly important to two Angelsto Nolan Ryan, the pitcher whose right arm underwent surgery for the removal of bone chips last year, and to Bobby Bonds, the outfielder whose right leg incurred knee damage last year. If the arm and the leg stay healthy, the Angels surely will terminate their twoyear lease on the American League West basement apartment. With a big year, Bobby Bonds would embarrass the Yankees as much as Nolan Ryan has embarrassed the Mets.

title: UDALL VOWS FIGHT ON MAJOR CRIME
description: Representative Morris K. Udall promised yesterday that if elected President he would fight crime with an array of Federal programs costing as much as three or four billion dollars, saying liberals should not again let conservative politicians monopolize discussion of the problem.

title: T.W.U.E. Economist Asserts City Underpays Its Transit Workers
description: Negotiations for a new transit workers contract moved into high gear yesterday with the Transport Workers Union offering a detailed chartandslide presentation to show that its 34,000 members were underpaid.

title: Italian General Seized
description: Gen. Duilio Fanali, former chief of the Italian Air Force, and a Rome lawyer were arrested in a reported $1.6 million Lockheed bribe. Page 7.

title: British Soccer Standing
description: British Soccer Standing

title: Pitcher Still Nettled by TradeHarrelson Looks Fit in Game
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23The New York Mets were still rattling the saber at Torn Seaver today, but, took time out from their war of nerves to play a fiverming camp game that marked the debut of Mickey Lolich as a Met pitcher at the age of 35.

title: Miami Beach May Raze Blighted Area of Elderly
description: MIAMI BEACH  South Beach, which is what the neighborhood at the southern tip of this resort city is called, could be a hundred miles from the Miami Beach of song and story. It is quiet and tranquil; it has a real beach instead of a series of swimming pools jutting out into the ocean; its buildings are almost plain, whitewashed apartment houses two or three floors high.

title: STOCKHOLDERS SUIT HITS WESTINGHOUSE
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 23 (UPI)The Westinghouse Electric Corporation of Pittsburgh was accused today in a stockholder's class action suit of concealing the extent of the pretax losses in the years from 1954 through 1974 in its consumer appliance division.

title: BANKER CHARGED IN SALE OF TEAM
description: SAN. DIEGO, March 23 (UPI) The San Diego County grand jury today amended a 58count indictment against C. Arnhoit Smith, charging him with tax evasion and grand theft in connection with the sale of the San Diego Padres.

title: GOVERNOR ASSAILS SOME BUDGET CUTS AS NOT FEASIBLE
description: ALBANY, March 23Governor Carey warned today that the cuts the Legislature made last week in his budget requests for state agencies and departments were unworkable and counterproductive and could make it impossible for us to do the job of running the state.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Isabel Martinez de Pern was reportedly arrested by airforce officers last night as the armed forces overthrew Argentina's Peronist Government. Mrs. Pern is expected to be held in Argentina during an investigation of charges of corruption under her presidency. Gen. Jorge Rafael Videla, the army commander, is expected to head a junta with other military leaders. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Candy Spots Dead; Won 63 Preakness
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 23 (UPI)The stallion Candy Spots, winner of $824,718 in his racing career, died over the weekend at W. B. Perry's Domino Stud. Candy Spots won the Preakness in 1963 and was third in the Kentucky Derby that year and second in the Belmont Stakes.

title: French TV Tattletale a Topical Circus
description: PARIS, March 23Puckish social and political satire, conspicuously absent from French television during the dour de GaullePompidou era, now has millions of Frenchmen laughing in their living rooms every Sunday afternoon at the foibles of their betters, their inferiors and themselves.

title: Mammoth in the Swamp
description: ROMEThere are hints that homo boobus, H. L. Mencken's affectionate term for the political American, is at last starting to realize his country is plummeting down the power slide. The coming splash could be a dismal experience for the freedom whose second century he celebrates this year. Overseas one encounters more than hints.

title: WINE TALK
description: About 200 wine enthusiasts, wine makers acrd wine sellers gathered at the Four Seasons Restaurant here the other night for what most of then considered an extraordinary wine tasting and dinner.

title: Insurers Accept Antibiotic Settlement
description: ST. PAUL, Minn., March 23 (AP)The office of Judge Miles Lord of United States District Court said today that a group of private health and accident insurance companies had agreed to accept a $12.5 million settlement from five drug companies accused of overcharging for some antibiotics.

title: General Tire Payoffs Cause Meeting Delay
description: General Tire Payoffs Cause Meeting Delay

title: 72 Nations Joining in 200th Birthday
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 Those who have had their fill of red, white and blue pickup trucks and historically embossed liquor bottles might find relief in the ways some other countries are commemorating the Bicentennial.

title: U.S. Offers a Plan For Big Tariff Cuts
description: GENEVA, March 23The United States today presented a formula at the world trade negotiations here under which industrialized countries would cut their tariffs as much as 60 percent.

title: FEDERATED LIFTS RETAIL EARNINGS
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. which includes Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus in the metropolitan New Ycrk area, reported yesterday earnings increases cf 33.8 percent for the fiscal fourth quarter and 32.3 percent for the year ended Jan, 31. The yeartoyear fain was the company's largest in 20 years.

title: HONG KONG FOCUSING ON QUALITY FASHIONS
description: Hong Kong, the world's largest exporter of men's, women's and children's apparel, will have a showing of quality fashions tonight at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: ITALY CHARGES TWO IN LOCKHEED AFFAIR
description: ROME, March 23A magistrate investigating the widening Lockheed scandal today issued two more warrants for the arrest of highlevel employees of a company that allegedly accepted and rechanneled funds from the aircraft company to favor the sale of planes in Italy.

title: Dow Rises 13.14 to 995.43 As Oils Display Strength
description: Stock prices moved ahead yesterday, led by some strength in oil issues as well as several bluechip and glamour stocks. Volume perked up somewhat but remained well below the heavy pace of trading in January and February.

title: Going out Guide
description: REFLECTIONS Stephen Spender, one of the remaining major figures of the Oxford literary group that was so productive and significant between the wars, will make a rare local appearance before an audience tonight at 8 o'clock at the Poetry Center of the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. off Lexington Avenue. The poet and critic, who teaches at University College in London and is now working on a biography of W. H. Auden, an Oxford classmate. witi read from his works and discuss his poetry. Admission at the door is $2.

title: First Graders Are Exempted In Louisville's Busing Plan
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 23 (UPI)A Federal distritc judge today ordered about 10,000 first grade pupils entering school next September exempted from courtordered busing for desegregation in the LouisyilleJefferson County school system.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Military action to overthrow President Isabel Martinez de Pern was under way early today in Argentina. She refused to resign and awaited developments in the Casa Rosada, the Government House. The General Confederation of Labor, the only possible source of organized resistance, said the military were making a tragic mistake but gave no order for a general strike. General Jorge Rafael Videla, the army commander, is expected to head a junta with other military leaders. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Legislature's Office of Fiscal Affairs predicted yesterday that revenues from the proposed state income tax would fall short of paying for the programs the tax was designed to finance. The office's point estimate, representing its best guess, was that the total shortfall would be $14 million in the coming fiscal year and $264 million in the fiscal year ending June 30, 1978.

title: KISSINGER REPEATS
description: DALLAS, March 23Secretary of State Henry A. Kissitiger refused today to rule out any move by the United States including a military invasion of Cubain the event Cuba disregarded the Ford Administration's warnings and took part in a new armed action in southern Africa.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust said here yesterday that it had reduced its debt $85 million by selling $80.8 million of loans to four creditor banks. Although nine of the 10 loans sold are currently not earning interest, the creditor banks bid $2.533 million cash for them in addition to reducing Chase Manhattan's debt by $85, million.

title: Thinking About Social Costs
description: OXFORD, EnglandA characteristic sight in the streets of English cities is the meter maid, in neat uniform, with yellow trim, calm, quiet, walking slowly, pencil and notebook in hand, on the lookout for cars illegally parked: a notoriously incorruptible figure, unpersuadable, authoritative and of uncertain age; a British institution; a bourgeois social service.

title: Excerpts From Statement by House Budget Panel Chairman
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 Following are excerpts from the statement made by Representative Brock Adams of Washington, chairman of the House Budget Committee, in presenting his own proposed budget figures for the next fiscal year:

title: Study Finds City Pensions Have Sufficient Funding
description: The city's multibilliondollar, pension funds, covering morel than 400,000 municipal employces and retirees, are not underfunded, according to a sixmonth study by a task force composed primarily of businessmen.

title: E. L. SPETNAGEL JR., INVESTMENT ADVISER
description: Edward L. Spetnagel Jr., an investment counselor, died Sunday of a cerebral hemorrhage in the Boca Raton (Fla.) Community Hospital. He was 67 Years old and lived in Boca Raton.

title: Justus Frantz, Pianist, Excels in a Return Recital
description: Justus Frantz, the young German pianist who played with the New York Philharmonic last season, returned to give his first solo recital at Tully Hall last night. He played a rather standard program that progressed from Mozart to Beethoven and Debussy and then swung back to Schumann, and he played it very well, even if some Questions were raised.

title: Teng's Pragmatism Tied to His Undoing
