description: HONG KONG, March 23The lengthy list of charges being made against Teng Hsiaoping, China's senior Deputy Prime Minister, indicates that he apparently provoked the current conflict among Peking's leaders sometime last summer when he moved too forcefully and bluntly in promoting his own pragmatic policies.

title: MRS. PERON OVERTHROWN BY MILITARY IN ARGENTINA AND REPORTED ARRESTED
description: BUENOS AIRES, Wednesday, March 24Air force officers reportedly arrested President Isabel Martnez de Pern at an air base here early today as the armed forces overthrew Argentina's Peronist Government.

title: H.E.W. Chief Tours. Facilities in the City
description: Do you speak Spanish? the tall, smiling Southerner whose frame was folded into a tiny children's chair asked Joseph Ayala, whose small frame fit neatly into his chair, as the two set chatting at the La PRACA daycare center in the Bronx yesterday.

title: Knicks Box Score
description: Knicks Box Score

title: MARINE MIDLAND PLANNING LAYOFF
description: The Marine Midland Bank, which experienced difficulties with a substantial volume of loan losses in the closing months of 1975, disclosed plans yesterday to lay off 500 employees, including more than 200 officers, in an effort to curtail costs.

title: PM AM MONTH LOSS PUT AT $24.6 MILLION
description: Pan American World Airways reported yesterday a net loss of $24.6 million in February and a net loss of $40.5 million: for the first two months this year in February of 1975, Pan American reported a net loss of $26.3 million after a tax credit of $2.5 million, and for the first two months of 1975 it reported a let loss of $49.7 million after a tax credit of $5.4 million.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is hard to think of a better example of Burke's observation that to innovate is not to reform than the socalled Campaign Reform Bill enacted in reaction to the Watergate scandals. The irrelevance of its major provisions to those scandals is best illustrated by the fact that the majority of members of the Senate Watergate Committee voted against it.

title: Mittermaier, Hemmi Win Ski Races
description: HUNTER, N.Y., March 23 Rosi Mittermaier of West Germany and Heini Hemmi of Switzerland, gold medal winners at the recent Winter Olympics at Innsbruck, Austria, triumphed today at Hunter Mountain on manmade snow that surprised the visiting European stars.

title: Productivity a Big Issue In Transit Negotiations
description: Improved productivity is emerging as an important issue in the current transit contract negotiations, in which the union is talking about higher pay and protection against inflation while the Transit Authority is stressing its economic limitation.

title: DEPOSITS GROWING FOR WOMEN'S BANK
description: Checking accounts and saylings deposits at the First Women's Bank of New York, organized last year to promote financial parity for women, have grown substantially in recent months, the bank's shareholders were told yesterday at its first annual meeting.

title: FOOD PRICES IN CITY STABLE FOR A WEEK
description: Retail food prices in the New York area remained stable last week and the cost of feeding a family of four in the city stayed at last week's level, the Department of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday.

title: New York's Loss
description: The decision of Union Carbide, one of the city's largest employers, to move its corporate headquarters from Manhattan to Connecticut raises some challenging questions for officials who have been striving to reverse the flight of business and industry from New Yorkand for their counterparts in Connecticut and other suburban areas of the tristate region.

title: World Bank's Loan To Chile Is Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, March 23In an eightpage letter to the World Bank protesting the bank's recent decision to grant a $33 million credit to the Government of Chile, Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin, has charged that the bank succumbed to political pressure to shore up an inhuman rightwing dictatorship tottering on the edge of bankruptcy.

title: The Most Unkindest Cut of All
description: The House of David baseball team was a bearded band of barnstormers sponsored by a religious sect whose mother house was in Benton Harbor, Mich. This was in the era of between Alexander Cartwright and Rollie Fingers, when whiskerbearing ballplayers were a novelty, and the House did a lively business playing mostly at night under portable floodlights when baseball was still an afternoon game in the major leagues and most minors. The only member of the troupe who didn't wear brush was incomparable old Grover Cleveland Alexander, who had at long last drunk himself out the majors. He was still one of the most famous pitchers on earth, and the House advertised at every stop that he would work an inning or three. According to one press handout, his contract provided for a daily allowance of cents for a shave, in addition to his salary.

title: A Fiery Stage Troupe Moving to Paris
description: Andrei Serban is off to Paris at the end of the week with his flock of jeweled sparrows. They can't survive in New York, and that is a good deal more than a pity. Mr. Serban and his Great Jones Repertory Projct have put on two of the most remarkable things seen on the New York stage this seasonFragments of a Trilogy and The Good Woman of Setzuan. Their departure is partly a matter of our restricted cultural pilanthropy; perhaps it is also a case in which those who run this philanthropy have become silted up in their commitments.

title: People and Business
description: Wallace E. Olson, president of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, said yesterday that corporate financial statements should include more explanations of the data they contain.

title: Radio
description: 11:15Noon, WORAM: Patricia McCann. Lloyd Motz. Professor of Astronomy at Columbia University.

title: Canucks Defeat Islanders, 5 to 2
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, March 23 (UPI)Mike Walton scored two goals tonight as the Vancouver Canucks moved to within a point of idle Chicago in the Smythe Division of the National Hockey League with a 52 victory over the New York Islanders.

title: 4.00 Attend a Benefit to Raise Defense Funds for Monserrat
description: More than 400 people turned out at a benefit party for Joseph Monserrat, the Board of Education member who placed himself on leave until conflictofinterest charges against him are settled.

title: L.I. Parents Draft Protest to Nyquist On School Book Ban
description: LEVITTOWN, L.I., March 23 A group of residents in the Island Trees School District said today that they intended to protest to the State Education Commissioner the removal of 11 book titles from the junior and senior high schoollibraries.

title: The Sports Scoreboard
description: The Sports Scoreboard

title: SIX MORE OFFICERS NORTHROP'S GUESTS
description: >WASHINGTON, March 23 (Reuters)  Senator William Proxmire today released the names of six more highranking military officers entertained by the Northrop Corporation contrary to Defense Department regulations.

title: TIMES MEETING SET FOR NORTH CAROLINA
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it would hold its 1976 stockholders meeting April 20 in Wilmington, N. C., where the company last year purchased The Wilmington StarNews, a daily newspaper. It will he the first time the annual meeting has been held outside New York City.

title: Stolen Italian Paintings Found in Switzerland
description: LOCARNO, Switzerland, March 23 (AP)Swiss and Italian police recovered today three Renaissance paintings that were stolen from the Ducal Palace Museum in Urbino, Italy, early last year in one of the largest art thefts in Italian history.

title: 3 MUSICALS LEAD IN TONY NOMINEES
description: Three Broadway musicals, A Chorus Line, Chicago and Pacific Overtures, captured the bulk of this year's Antoinette Perry (Tony) award nominations. A Chorus Line received 12, Chicago 11 and Pacific Overtures 10.

title: Control Board Held Lagging on Budget
description: Mayor Beame's chief fiscal deputy contended yesterday that the Emergency Financial Control Board had been procrastinating on deciding whether to approve or reject the city's latest estimate of its deficit problem.

title: Fear of Job Loss Cited In Bus Strike Settlement
description: TRENTON, March 23An 84centanhour wage offer over two years and fears of the possible loss of jobs and pensions were given today as reasons that members of the Amalgamated Transit Union rejected their leaders recommendations last night and voted to accept Transport of New Jersey's latest contract proposals.

title: Metropolitan Museurn, Counting Its Visitors, Says It Has Been a Great Boon to the City
description: The origins of the possessions of the Metropolitan Museum of Art have been fully catalogued, but until now the provenance of the visitors to the institution has gone unstudied.

title: Budget and Critics Slow Caso's Pace
description: Ralph G. Caso was 60,000 feet above the ground as the aircraft shifted into supersonic speed. Far below him, the coasts of England and France resembled a page in a miniature Atlas.

title: Yonkers Entries
description: Yonkers Entries

title: Negotiations Are Key to Future Of Jerusalem, U.S. Says at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 23  The United States restated today its view that the future of Jerusalem would be determined by negotiations rather than by onesided action, and declared that Jewish settlements in Israelioccupied Arab territories were an obstacle in the search for peace between Israel and its neighbors.

title: Sick Baby Whale Captured
description: ROCKPORT, Me., March 23 (AP)An apparently sick baby sperm whale sighted swimming in circles offshore here was captured today.

title: Recital: By Ann Schein
description: Any piano recital that embraces both Carter's Piano Sonata and Gottschalk's Uttion, Paraphrase de Concert demonstrates at very least that the performer's musical interests are manifold. Ann Schein, who made her Carnegie Hall debut in 1962 but who has been absent from the concert scene for several seasons, showed on Monday evening a particular affirrity for the early (194546) Carter piece and had the technical aplomb to handle its perpetualmotion runs, bravura octaves and other bedazzlements, es well as the sensitivity to discover elegiac overtones in the andante sections.

title: Talking Heads: Cool in Glare of Hot Rock
description: New York Is caught up in an eruption of underground rockandroll bands at the moment, arid the center of the scene is CBGB's, an almost deliberately tacky bar at 315 Bowery. Most of the bands that play there fit into the postVelvet Underground stylized punk schoolblack leather jackets or lyrics about drugs and sadomasochism or screamingly loud, twanging, threechord guitar rock.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Sweetly fragrant banana breads and golden carrot cakes are among the specialties baked by Naomi Schechter of recently moved Montana Palace.

title: BankRestructuring Plan Is Bogged Downin House
description: WASHINGTON, March 23A farreaching proposal to restructure the nation's banking system has bogged down in a House subcommittee and faces removal of key provisions if it is to survive.

title: CLAIRE WI LEY
description: Clnire Wiley, sister of the late Louis Wiley, business manager of The New York Times, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 92 years old and lived at the Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street. Miss Wiley, who attended Wellesley College, taught physical education in Rochester for a number of years.

title: Negotiators W ork to Avert Strike Today at 8 Colleges
description: TRENTON, March 23 Negotiations continued today in an effort to avert a strike tomorrow of teachers at the eight state colleges, which enroll 82,000 students.

title: KIBBEE PLAN GETS BACKING OF MAW
description: The Board of Higher Education will advise the Emergency Financial Control Board today that it is prepared to accept the bulk of the controversial Kibbee plan for consolidating and restructuring the City University, sources in the board reported yesterday.

title: About Education
description: Williams College in Massachusetts has concluded that an experiment in accepting certain kinds of risk students as a fixed 10 percent of each entering class has been a success that is worth continuing.

title: CITY COUNCIL UNIT KEEPS RENT CURB
description: A threeyear extension of rent control in the city was virtually guaranteed last night when a City Council committee approved the extension after a public hearing that lasted more than eight hours.

title: Price Stability
description: A dramatic and welcome change for the better has taken place in the price inflation that has wreaked so much damage on the nation's economic life this decade. As recently as last July, the monthly increase in the Consumer Price Index was at a rate equivalent to doubledigit inflation for the year. The latest figures, for February 1976, show a gain of only onetenth of 1 percent, equivalentif unavoidable sampling error is taken into accountto virtually no change.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: A boy waving to Argentine soldiers on a tank carrier as troops moved through the streets of Buenos Aires recently ly.

title: Ban on Interstate OTB Urged
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) Thoroughbred and harness horse owners, breeders and track operators urged, Congress today to prohibit interstate offtrack betting, contending the industry oth erwise Would be killed off.

title: New York Bonds Rise
description: Prices of New Yorkrelated bonds and notes rose again yesterday on the growing conviction that the state was well on its way to overcoming its financing problems. Page 62.

title: Sterilization: For Women, An Easier Way
description: If I were writing a story in a true confession magazine, it might be called How I Found Freedom From Pills, Diaphragms, IUD's and Other Contraceptive Gadgetryand Unwanted Childrenby Having a Simple Operation That Left Me Permanently Sterile.

title: Argentine Armed Forces Act To Overthrow President Perot
description: BUENOS AIRES, Wednesday, March 24 Military action to overthrow President Isabel Martinez de Perlin of Argentina was under way early today.

title: A Kind of Carter Coalition Seen by the Happy Winner
description: ST. LOUIS, March 23Jimmy Carter, basking in his majorityvote victory in the North Carolina primary, suggested here tonight the existence of a kind of Carter coalition that could propel him into the White House.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Yankees, preseason, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. (TelevislonChannel 11, 8 P.M.

title: 1ST GRADE EXEMPT IN LOUISVILLE BUSING
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 23 (UPI)A Federal district judne today ordered about 10,000 first grade pupils entering school next September exempted from courtordered busing for desegrgation in th LouisvilleJefferson County school systm.

title: Military Analysts. Consider the Deterrence Options the U.S. Has Against Cuba
description: Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's warnings to Cuba against further international military adventures have raised the question of what the United States could actually do to deter such actions. The United States will not accept further Cuban military interventions abroad, Mr. Kissinger said in Dallas Monday night. Earlier in the month he advised the Cubans to act with great circumspection because our actions cannot always be deduced from what we did in Angola.

title: STUDENTS SUPPORT DEFIANT PRINCIPAL
description: Students boycotted classes at Long Island City High School in Queens yesterday in support of their suspended principal, Dr. Howard L. Hurwitz. Dr. Hurwitz was suspended Monday by School Chancellor IrvIng Anker for refusing to readmit a student who, the principal said, had a record of serious misbehavior.

title: Papal Birth Stand Found to Hurt Church
description: Overwhelming rejection by the Roman Catholic laity in the United States of the 1968 papal ban on artificial birth control has led to drastic declines in religious devotion and annually costs the church nearly a billion dollars in income, according to a survey of Catholic attitudes released yesterday by the National Opinion Research Center.

title: Lawyer With Miss Hearst as 2 Probation Officers Start Questioning That May Affect Her Sentence
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 23 Two Federal probation officers began interviewing Patricia Hearst today for a presentencing report on the 22yearold convicted bank robber whose coercive persuasion defense was not accepted by the jury.

title: Kareeba: Jamaica's Uniform
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica  Fourteen years after independence from Great Britain, Jamaican men have been liberated from the tyranny of jacket and tie. The Kareeba, the styled, openneck, overthepants shirt and matching trousers suit has become the universally accepted dress for formal occasions, work and leisure wear.

title: WagePrice Controls in an Election Year
description: WASHINGTON, March 23As it reads now, the HumphreyHawkins Full Employment Bill would convey the President no authority to regulate prices and wages. Indeed, it would not even mention wageprice guidelines, much less controls. This is no inadvertency. At one point, according to labor and Congressional sources, Democratic drafters contemplated standby authority for price controls. But George Meany, president Economic the A.F.L.C.I.O., would not have it. Analysis Having participated on the Nixon pay board for several months it 197172, Mr. Meany has come to be as ardent an opponent of controls as, say, Gerald R. Ford.

title: Moslem Gunmen In Beirut Advance In Christian Areas
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Wednesday, March 24Moslem militiamen, bolstered by strong help from Palestinian guerrillas, advanced yesterday into downtown sections here traditionally held by Christian Phalangists.

title: The Crew Cut: It's Inching Its Way Back
description: The crew cut will rise again. Or so say a few good men in crew cuts. They say this totally off the tops of their heads, mind you. Almost no one in the world of hair agrees.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Hockey, Basketball Standings

title: LeftWing Guerrillas a Force in Argentine Factories
description: CORDOBA, Argentina, March 23Argentina's leftwing guerrillas, once a terrorist middleclass elite, have emerged in recent months as a major force in the factories.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 3:30 P.M. to discuss Middle East.

title: American Termed Political System Monarchical
description: MEXICO CITY, March 23A casual remark by the United States ambassador to Mexico suggesting that this country's political system is monarchical has provoked a wave of official indignation and sparked demands in leftist circles that he be declared persona non grata.

title: Early Udall Backers Angry Over Ouster as Delegates
description: On a cold January night, when Morris K. Udall was just one of many Democratic Presidential hopefuls, a group of West Siders, talking of peace marches and protest days gone by, gathered to start a grassroots UdallforPresident organization.

title: RIFLE GROUP LOSES LOWER MAIL RATE
description: WASHINGTON, March 23The National Rifle Association, which in recent years has regularly prevailed in its struggle to prevent the passage of Federal gun control legislation, finally lost a fight today.

title: House Budget Chief Urges More Spending Than Ford
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 Representative Brock Adams, Democrat of Washington, who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, proposed today that the Federal Government spend $412.8 billion next year, $18.6 billion more than President Ford recommended.

title: Federal NoFault
description: After years of controversy, the Senate is moving toward a vote on a bill to establish Federal standards for nofault automobile insurance. Nofault is a reform that, if properly carried through, would serve the interests of millions of motorists better than the prevailing hodgepodge of personal liability suits.

title: Pistons Down Knicks As Money, Lanier Star
description: The Detroit Pistons have a play they call No. 12. Eric Money, the playmaker; made good use of it, especially in the second half last night and the payoff was a muchneeded 122116 victory over the Knicks at Madison Square Garden.

title: Bgatlis
description: ADELMANAnne, In Miami Beach, Fla., on Mar. 23, 1976. Beloved mother of Robert, Edward, and Jordan and cherished grandmother of four. Services Thurs., 9:30 A.M., at The Riverside, 1920 Alton Rd., Miami Beach, Fla.

title: TV: Dance in America
description: Twyla Tharp, the choreographer, meets Dance in Americ.a, the public television series tonight at 9, and the result is something of an artistic standoff. More than half of the hour (about 35 minutes) on WNET/13 Is devoted to a history of popular dances in the 1930's and 40's. The rest concentrates exclusively on Miss Tharp's Sue's Led, a work that refers directly to those dances with wit, admiration and superb technique.

title: M.T.A. Will Hold A Hearing Tonight On L.I. Bus Fares
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has scheduled public hearing in Mineola for tonight on a proposed simplified fare structure for Nassau County buses.

title: STUDENTS SUPPORT DEFIANT PRINCIPAL
description: Students boycotted classes at Long Island City High School in Queens yesterday in support of their suspended principal, Dr. Howard L. Hurwitz. Dr. Hurwitz was suspended Monday by School Chancellor Irving Anker for refusing to readmit a student who, the principal said, had a record of serious misbehavior.

title: Priest Who Deplored Luxury Is Reinstated
description: ROCHESTER, March 23 (AP) A Roman Catholic priest who was suspended from his duties last January after refusing to live in a rectory he considered too luxurious was reinstated today and transferred to smaller slumarea parish. The priest, the Rev. James Callan, was reinstated by Bishop, Joseph Hogan of the Roches, ter Diocese.

title: Kennecott Gets Haiti Rights
description: PORT AU  PRINCE, Haiti, March 23 (UPI)The Haitian Government has granted the Kennecott Copper Company exploration and exploitation rights to a large tract on the north side of this mountainous Caribbean nation, President JeanClaude Duvalier announced in a television speech last night. The concession convers all mineral; found in the are. He added that the Government would receive 5 percent of gross receipts, a 15 percent royalty on profits and 10 percent on stockholder dividends.

title: About the Yankees
description: The Yogi Berras edged the Whitey Fords, 76, in the sixinning intrasquad game. The Berras were the beneficiaries of the nowalk, nostrikeout rule because Chris Chambliss hit a threerun homer in the sixrun third after Tippy Martinez actually had struck him out. Berra's troops got another break in the same inning when Kerry Dineen singled home a run after fouling out. Catfish Hunter and Ken Brett both pitched two easy innings. George Steinbrenner 3d spent 15 minutes before the workout explaining his policy on long hair. Tonight's opening exhibition game with the Mets will be televised by Channel 11 at 8 P.M. Besides Thurman Munson, Rick Sawyer, a righthanded pitcher, agreed to contract terms, leaving the Yankees with seven unsigned players.

title: French Yacht Is First to Finish
description: PORTSMOUTH, England, March 23 (AP)The French yacht Pen Duick VI, skippered by Eric Taberly, appeared a sure winner after crossing the finishing line first today in the Rio de Janeiro to Portsmouth Gold Tankard race. Pen Duick VI was thought to be about 1.000 miles ahead of her nearest rivals and was expected to win on handicap when the final placings are worked out after the slower boats arrive in about two weeks, race officials said.

title: RHODESIAN LEADER BARS BRITISH PLAN
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 23Prime Minister Ian D. Smith today rejected as extreme Britain's proposals for legalizing Rhodesia's independence based on black majority rule.

title: CRIME FIGURE TIED TO MELLON CASE
description: Karen Boyd Mellon, whose two daughters were abducted in Brooklyn last week, rented her Bath Beach apartment through a real estate agency with close ties to Joseph Colombo and other organizedcrime figures, it became known yesterday.

title: BEN COLD
description: Ben Gold, founder and president of Ben Gold Associates, a firm specializing in restaurant aid resort advertising, died yesterday at his home. He was 76 years old and lived at 155 West 68th Street.

title: New YorkRelated Issues Continue Price Advance
description: Prices of New Yorkrelated bonds and notes continued to advance yesterday, helped by the growing conviction that the state was well on its way in overcoming its financial problems. Aiding this conviction was the news yesterday that the Court of Appeals in Albany had upheld the constitutionality of the plan to grant $750 million to aid New York City and the Municipal; Assistance Corporation.

title: CANDIDATES BUY FEW TV ADS HERE
description: The campaign roadshow has arrived here, but so far it has meant little to the ordinary television viewer.

title: FORD SEEKS CHANGES IN SCHOOLLUNCH LAW
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) President Ford sent to Congress today a bill to change the Federal school lunch program, cutting off food aid to what the Administration termed nonneedy children at a yearly saving of $900 million.

title: Dr. Carl Binger, 86, Pioneer In Psychosomatic Medicine, Dies
description: Dr. Carl A. L. Binger, a psychiatrist, died Monday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 86 years old.

title: People Angered and Alienated by Government, Poll Shows
description: New Jerseyans polled by The New York Times expressed anger with the state government and alienation from it.

title: FORD SIGNS A BAN ON BIAS IN CREDIT
description: WASHINGTON, March 23President Ford signed into law today legislation prohibiting banks, retailers and others from discriminating on the basis of age, race, color, religion or national origin in the granting of credit.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Tuesday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Technical difficulties in compilation of data may have caused inaccuracies in some prices and volume figures In tables of trading for the New York and American Stock Exchanges published yesterday In The New York Times.

title: KEPONE PRODUCERS SUED BY VIRGINIA
description: RICHMOND, March 23 (AP) Virginia has filed a $3.5 million suit against the producers of a pesticide ingredient, Kepone, saying they polluted state waters and violated state laws by discharging industrial wastes into the waters without permission.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: Since November 1974, when Consumers Union announced that rodent hairs, moth wings and insect parts had shown up in samples of almost all the brands of tuna it had tested, three major packers of tuna in the United States have joined the Federal fish inspection program.

title: FORD SUGGESTS BILL ON EAVESDROPPING
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP)The Ford Administration unveiled today legislation limiting bugging and wiretapping in intelligence Investigations within the United States and said the measure had broad bipartisan support.

title: White Sox Win Opener From Pirates On 2 NinthInning Errors by Helms
description: BRADENTON Fla., March 23 (UPI)The Chicago White Sox took advantage of two ninthinning errors by Pittsburgh's third baseman, Tommy Helms to score four unearned runs and gain a 62 victory over the Pirates in the exhibition season opener for both teams.

title: Beame Names Panel to Study Ways to Aid Amex Expansion
description: Mayor Beame appointed yesterday a highlevel panel of city officials to study ways to assist the American Stock Exchange expand its operations in New York City.

title: Udall Pledges Billions in Transit Aid
description: The other day, Represeritative Morris K. Udall tramped the streets of New York wearing a lapel button decorated with a big apple and the words I love New York. Back again this week, he once again painted himself as a firm friend of a fiscally shaky city in crisis.

title: Senate Leaders Map Plan To Revive Election Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 23Senate leaders of both parties reached agreement today on a compromise bill to resuscitate the Federal Election Commission, preserve much of its present independence and make other changes in the campaign law.

title: Clearing house Banks Given Board's Minutes
description: Confidential minutes of the most recent meeting of the Emergency Financial Control Board have been sent, even before their release to the public, to the lawyers for New York's clearinghouse banks.

title: Armco Unit Sets Steel Price Rise Of 4.5c a Pound
description: The Armco Steel Corporation said yesterday that its advanced materials division planned to raise the price of flat rolled stainless steel by 4.5 cents a pound effective with shipments of April 5. The company also said its base quantity would he reduced to 20,000 pounds from the previous 40.000 pounds.

title: Shipping / Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Rail Accord Fails As Clerks Bar Pact
description: A fragile agreement that the Sout barn Railway had accepted for its acquisition of 460 miles of road of the bankrupt Penn central Railroad collapsed yesterday when the Brotherhood of Railway and Airline Clerks continued to refuse to agree to labor condiLions proposed by Secretary of Transportation William T. Coleman.

title: Advertising
description: With the results of survey research being used increasingly in business, politics and government the time has come for some form of auditing that will give people faith in the numbers.

title: Court Curbs Federal Suits On Defamation by Officials
description: WASHINGTON, March 23Over a strong dissent by three Justices, the Supreme Court ruled today that the Constitution gives citizens only limited protection and recourse against public officials who defame them.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Tuesday. London: Morning fixing $133.20, down

title: City U. Board Backs Plan by Kibbee
description: The Board of Higher Education will advise the Emergency Financial Board today that it is prepared to accept the bulk of the controversial Kibbee Plan for consolidating and restructuring the City University, sources in the board reported yesterday.

title: John Loftus, First Jockey To Win the Triple Crown
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., March 23 (AP)John Loftus, who became the first jockey to win racing's Triple Crown, on Sir Barton in 1919, died of a heart attack in TriCity Hospital Saturday after surgery. He was 80 years old.

title: Matsushita Plans a 3Year Drive
description: In hopes of making its own name as familiar as the name of its products, Matsushita Electric Industrial, Japan's largest manufacturer of consumer electric and electronic products, is preparing to initiate a threeyear advertising, public relations and promotion campaign that will cost about $1 million in the first year.

title: 26 Horses Die in Fire at Narragansett
description: PAWTUCKET, R. 1., March 23 (UPI)At least 20 thoroughbred horses today were confirmed destroyed in a windswept fire last night that destroyed two large stables at Narragansett Park race track. The count is now up 26, John McCarthy, a track spokesman, said. Two horses succumbed while receiving treatment. Workers searched through piles of charred rubble, once the 300footlong buildings, looking for dead horses that either were trapped when the holocaust erupted or panicked and returned the burning buildings in the confusion.

title: About the Mets
description: Orr the sixth day of the delayed spring workouts, everybody was in camp except Jesus Alou, who was having visa complications back home in the Dominican Republic. The squad numbers 35, and 10 will be out before the move north in two weeks. Dave Kingman Slew New York for dental work, but was expected back Florida when the team opens the fifteengame exhibition schedule tonight in Fort Lauderdale against the Yankees.  John Milner was in unifprm, but will skip the quick round trip because of a slight back strain. Manager Joe Frazier will start the first five exhibition games with the pitchers who could become his big five Jerry Koosman against the Yankees, Tom Seaver against St. Louis tomorrow, Jon Matlack against Los Angeles. Craig Swan against Detroit and Mickey Lolich against the Dodgers.

title: Israelis Close Arab Area In March for Slain Boy
description: ABU DIS, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, March 23Several hundred Arabs joined in a somber procession through the streets of this tiny village outside Jerusalem today to mourn the death of an Arab boy shot by an Israeli soldier during a demonstration last week.

title: Amex and OTC Show Price Rises; Trading Moderate
description: Prices moved higher in moderate trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market.

title: Pact Is Reported as Multiyear
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 23Thurman Munson, a white towel draped around his suntanned neck, emerged from the rented trailer Gabe Paul uses as his office at Fort Lauderdale Stadium and wearily stooped into the driyer's seat of Paul's rented gray Toyota.

title: REAGAN TOPS FORD IN N. CAROLINA FOR FIRST TRIUMPH IN A PRIMARY; CARTER EASILY DEFEATS WALLACE
description: RALEIGH, N. C., March 23Ronald Reagan upset President: Ford and Jimmy Cartel trounced Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama tonight in the North Carolina Presidential primary.

title: I Books of The Times
description: Whatever Suzanne Gordon means by loneliness, her conception of it has enabled her to do a number of useful things in her absorbing journalistic survey, Lonely in America. First, it has allowed her to evoke experiences of loneliness through sensitively drawn wordportraits of composites familiar to all of usthe middleaged man trying to adjust to the shock of divorce; the young man waking up to the fact that the love and revolution of the 1960's have not brought about the millennium the woman in the home for mature people discovering that the years after retirement are not always golden, and the twicedivorced woman in her late 40's trying to buy companionship from what Miss Gordon aptly calls the loneliness business. Second, has permitted her to analyze the social dynamics that are increasingly producing such typesthe rising divorce rate that leaves in its jetstream lonely children and bewildered adults; the breakdown of sense of community in the United States that is contributing to the rising divorce rate; the social transience that is destroying our sense of community and the technological culture that is turning people into interchangeable parts.

title: Japan Seeks Motive in Crash Into Lockheed Agent's Dome
description: TOKYO, March 23  An actor in erotic films who told friends he was not afaid to die made a spectacular attempt to kill Lockheed's former secret agent here today, and the police appealed to the public for an information that might help explain his motive.

title: Inquiry on Dr. King Death Finds No Plot or U.S. Role
description: WASHINGTON, March 23The Justice Department's civil rights division, after a fourmonth study of Federal records relating to the assassination of the Rev. Dr, Martin Luther King Jr., has found no evidence of government complicity or of a tangible conspiracy in the black leader's death, according to department sources.

title: Presidents of 2 Raceways Deny Financial Gimmicks to Cut T axes
description: Their responses came after the State Commission of Investigation charged that the State, Racing and Wagering Board was lax in providing Albany with information on the true financial picture of the tracks.

title: U.S. Offers a Plan For Big Tariff Cuts
description: GENEVA. March 23  The United States today presented a formula at the world trade negotiations here under which industrialized countries would cut their tariffs as much as 60 percent.

description: Pro Transactions

title: Field Marshal Montgomery Dead at 88
description: LONDON, Wednesday, March 24  Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, the most famous British soldier of modern times, died early today, the Ministry of Defense announced. He was 88 years old.

title: FEDERAL BANKS LOSE ROUND ON TERMINALS
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI)The United States Court of Appeals held today that national banks must comply with state laws before establishing remote computer hookups in supermarkets and elsewhere.

title: HORACE D. GILBERT, HEADED MPB CORP.
description: Horace D. Gilbert, a pioneer in industrial miniaturization, died Friday in Los Angeles. He was 65 years old and lived there and in Keene, N.H., and Vienna.

title: Dispute Over Blanda Marks Kapp Suit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 23  A squabble over the qualifications of George Blanda to give an opinion on Joe Kapp prevented the defense from formally concluding its case today in Kapp's antitrust suit against the National Football League.

title: CHARLES ZIMMERMAN
description: Charles E. Zimmerman, president of Consultants & Designers Inc., a subsidiary of the Greyhound Corporation, died Monday at United Hospital of Westchester, Port Chester, N.Y. He was 59 years old and lived in Harrison, N.Y.

title: Budget and Critics Slow Caso's Pace
description: Ralph G. Caso was 60,000 feet above the ground as the aircraft shifted into supersonic speed. Far below him, the coasts of England and France resembled a page in a miniature Atlas.

title: Gibson's Door Splintered As Crowd Invades Office
description: NEWARK, March 23Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's bodyguard put a revolver to a Councilman's face today when the Councilman broke open the locked door to the Mayor's orivate office.

description: WASHINGTON, March 23Over a strong dissent by three Justices, the Supreme Court ruled today that the Constitution gives citizens only limited protection and recourse against public officials who defame them.

title: Job Fears Cited in Jersey Bus Accord
description: TRENTON, March 23An 84 centanhour wage offer over, two years and fears of the possible loss of jobs and pensions were given today as rea, sons that members of the Amalgamated Transit Union rejected their leaders recommendations last night and voted to accept Transport of New Jersey's latest contract proposals.

title: Risk Students Are Not So Risky
description: Williams College in Massachusetts has concluded that an experiment in accepting certain kinds of risk students as a fixed 10 percent of each entering class has been a success that is worth continuing.

title: Kissinger's Vague Warnings
description: WASHINGTON, March 23Secretary of State Kissinger's warnings to the Soviet Union and Cuba against further military intervention in Africa make good political headlines, but it would be helpful if he would tell the country how he proposes to carry, them out.

title: Bonn Drive Against Spies Also Catches the Innocent
description: BONN, March 23  Walter Bhm was the chief of a labor union office in Bonn, a respected member of the suburban community of Buschhofen, and a grateful refugee from East German Communism  until Nov. 11, 1974.

title: House Budget Chief Urges More Spending Than Ford
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 Representative Brock Adams, Democrat of Washington, who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, proposed today that the Federal Government spend $412.8 billion next year, $18.6 billion more than President Ford recommended.

description: CERTNERJoel. Killed at the ego of 71, our beloved Joel would have been 31 today. Mother, Dad, Neon); and Jerry.

description: HALIFAX, Nova ScotiaPerhaps what Intrigued most about Philippa Monsarrat's cooking classes in Halifax were her admonishments about classes in breadmaking.

title: GOVERNOR ASSAILS SOME BUDGET CUTS AS NOT FEASIBLE
description: ALBANY, March 23Governor Carey warned today that the cuts the Legislature made last week in his budget requests for state agencies and departments were unworkable and counterproductive and could make it impossible for us to do the job of running the state.

title: Flomosexual Cites Pentag on View To Back Fight Against Ouster
description: A Navy ensign, who is contesting an administrative board's recommendation for his discharge as an acknowledged homosexual, said yesterday that a Defense Department statement declares homosexuality in and of itself is not cause for mandatory discharge.

title: U.S. Officials Call Manufacture of Offshore Nuclear Plants Safe
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 23Members of the technical staff of the Nuclear regulatory commission testified today that manufacturing the world's first floating nuclear power plants here, the first two of which have been proposed for operation off Atlantic City, would have no serious adverse environmental impacts on Jacksonkville.

title: CAPITAL LOSES MOVE ON VOTE IN CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, March 23The House of Representatives rejected today a move to extend voting representation in Congress to the District of Columbia for the first time since the District was created in 1790.

title: Bridge
description: The open pair champion ship, which concluded the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals in Kansas City, Mo., Sunday, was won by two players new to national honors.

title: STATE'S CITY LOANS UPHELD BY COURT
description: ALBANY, March 23 The State Court of Appeals today approved the constitutionality of $750 million in emergency loans that the state extended to New York City last fall, thereby reinforcing one of the buttresses to the city's shaky finances.

title: A NUCLEAR PLANT CLOSED UPSTATE
description: A nuclear plant near Oswego, N.Y., was shut clown Monday because of a leak in a water cleanup system, similar to others found last Friday and last November.

title: Argentina's Top General And Likely Its Next Chief
description: Lieut. Gen. Jorge Rafael Videla was named Commander in Chief of the Aregntine Army last August after leading a revolt against predecessor  Rejected an appeal by dissident air force officers during December uprising that he form military government  called instead for constitutional solution to growing disenchantment with President Isabel Martinez de Pern  Seen chatting amiably with Peronist ministers earlier the week even amid rumors he would lead coup  Though associated with antiPeronist faction during intraarmy clash in early 1960's, maintained distance from more outspoken antiPeronist generals in recent years  Highly respected and popular among military men, cultivated lasting friendships during career teaching young officers at Military College, Argentina's West Point  Son of infatry colonel  Born Aug. 2, 1925, in Mercedes, large provincial city in Buenos Aires Province  1944 graduate of Military College, where two of seven children now cadest  Hardmuscled, spare, with large black mustache and prominent nose that gives severe look  Smiles easily and regarded as easy and gracious conversationalist  Roman Catholic and strongly antiCommunist, views Marxist concept of class conflict as divisive and threatening to national unity  As Commander in Chief put Argentina on war footing in first time this century for campaign against leftwing guerrillas  Described by military colleague as man with high moral principles who hates corruption.

title: Braniff Penalized $300,000; $3,000 Fine Set for Hammer
description: Braniff Airways has agreed to a record civil penalty of $300,000 resulting from failure to report an illegal $40,000 contribution to the 1972 reelection campaign of President Richard M. Nixon and from a $1 million scheme to hide ticket discounts, the Civil Aeronautics Board announced yesterday in Washington.

title: Jackson's Slate Is Facing Loss of 35 Delegates in State
description: Some 35 JacksonforPresident delegates face removal from the New York State ballot or shunting aside into an uncommitted listing, Secretary of State Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday.

title: Jackson Stresses Jobs to Brooklyn Students
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington brought his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination back to New York City yesterday with renewed insistence that the overriding issue facing the voters in the state's April 6 primary election is jobs.

title: Maria Muldaur Offers Songs In Varied Styles at Bottom Line
description: Maria Muldaur is a big star, in pop music these days, but she hasn't always had it easy since her emergence a couple; of years ago from her postjugband anonymity. Her peculiar1 little soprano with its sharp register break can sound a little mannered, her attempts at, jazz singing sometimes falll short of their models, and her appearances in huge concerts. this observer once saw her at the 45,000seat Roosevelt Sta dium in Jersey City dilute the charm she exerts close up.

title: Metropolitan Museum, Counting Its Visitors, Says It Has Been a Great Boon to the City
description: The origins of the possessions of the Metropolitan Museum of Art have been fully cataisigued, but until now the provenance of the visitors to the institution has gone Unstudied.

title: 106 U.S. Lawyers Appealing to Tito To Free Attorney
description: President Tito of Yugoslavia has been petitioned by 106 prominent American lawyese to release Srdja Popovic, a Belgrade lawyer sentenced to a year in prison on March 10 for statements made in defense of a client.

title: Four Who Use the Walls to Make a Sceneand a Career
description: It was to be a simple paint job for the bathroom. But no sooner had Annie Baker and David Wolman picked up their brushes than it was decided that what the bathroom really deserved was a neon  bright four  walled mural, based on Lord of the Rings by John Tolkien, their favorite fantasy.

title: WARNING TO ITALY BY BONN REPORTED
description: PARIS, March 23A West German warning to Italy that it had to act to stop the flight of capital if it expected further German financial aid, was behind a harsh economic program adopted by Italy last week a high European financial official reported today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Sanford L. Engelhardt; 43 years old, a former official of the city's Human Resources Administration, pleaded guilty to a bribery charge involving $13,000 that he received for giving favored treatment to a construction company. A few hours after he was charged with eight bribery counts and a taxevasion count, Mr. Engelhardt made his guilty plea to one count of attempted bribe receiving, which carries a sentence of up to four years in prison.

title: 75 INVADE OFFICE OF MAYOR GIBSON
description: NEWARK, March 23Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's bodyguard put a revolver to a Councilman's face today when the Councilman broke open the locked door to the Mayor's private office. Anthony Carrino, Councilman from the North Ward, had led a shouting crowd of about 75 of his constituents into the Mayor's office shortly before noon to protest the appointment of an outoftown resident as the Police Department precinct captain in their district.

title: Joffrey Ballet Reliving N.Y. Export, Op. Jazz
description: Jerome Robbins's N.Y. Export. Op. Jazz was created for Italy's Spoleto Festival in 1958, and it was the perfect dance expression of its time. It was West Side Story without the West Side and without the story. Somehow it encapsulated the feel and manners of a dislocated generation  gang warfare and gangbangs, the rhythmic patterns of a new tribal society, young lovers totally lost in a flurry of apparent communication and solitary partings.

title: Rhodesian Leader Rebuffs British Proposal on Rule
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 23Prime Minister Ian Smith today rejected as extreme Britain's proposals for legalizing Rhodesia's independence based on black majority rule.

title: Some Heavenly Cheeses, And a Bacon Minus Nitrite
description: As we all too often find out, new does not always mean good where food products are concerned. But for a change, this group of new or newly discovered cheeses, bacon, cakes and charcuterie are well worth the buying and eating.

title: Hubbell in Hospital
description: CASA GRANDE, Ariz., March 23 (UPI)Carl Hubbell, the 72yearold Hall of Famer, became ill at the San Francisco Giants training camp today and was taken to a local hospital. Dr. James Wagoner said Hubbell would undergo a hernia operation tomorrow. Hubbell, now director of player personnel for the team, had a 253154 career wonlost record for the Giants.

description: Officials of the United States Customs Service warned yesterday of an art fraud scheme involving fake Mayan artifacts from Guatemala intended to produce $35 million. But in giving details of the conspiracy said to include at least 12 individualsthe officials would provide no names and stressed that no arrests had been made.

title: Bicentennial Events To Have French Flair
description: WASHINGTON. March 23 The Statue of Liberty is a hard act to follow.

title: People in Sports
description: Andy Messersmith, the Los Angeles Dodgers star pitcher who became a free agent recently, may not find it easy to get a team to meet his terms. The Cincinnati Reds said yesterday they had rejected a $1.5 million deal offered by his agent. The Reds said the proposal included a bonus and a fouryear, nocut contract. It came from Herb Osmond, Messersmith's agent, in a phone call from Los Angeles.

description: PARIS, March 23  Determined to broaden its appeal and support; the French Conimunist Party has announced a new publicity and recruitment campaign that goes far beyond anything ever tried by France's nonCommunist parties in the way of modern political merchandising.

title: Notes on People
description: Dr. Louis M. Hellman, the New Yorker who since 1970 has been family planning chief of the Federal Department of Health, Education and Welfare, was named yesterday to head the department's Health Services Administration. This adds the Indian Health Service and other community and professional services to his responsibilities as Deputy Assistant Secretary for population affairs. Dr. Hellman has been in frequent judicial and legislative skirmishes for advocating publicly funded birth control, abortion and sterilization services for the poor.

description: A bubble burst in Brooklyn the other day during galeforde winds. It has happened before and the owners of such tennis centers consider such incidents hazards to the trade, although they give assurance that there is no danger to anyone.

title: $6.4 Billion Foreign Aid Bill ls Voted by Senate, 5231
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP)The Senate passed a $6.4billion foreign aid appropriation bill today for the 15 months of the fiscal year ending Sept. 30. The 5231 vote sent the measure to a conference with the House, which approved a $5.4 billion total on March 8.

title: Zoo Plays Matchmaker To Elands Without Elan
description: Food proved the main attraction for a big male eland yesterday at the Central Park Zoo when he was put in a large outdoor pen for the first time with a recently acquired female, 19monthold Ginny.

title: Papal Birth Stand Found to Hurt Church
description: Overwhelming rejection by the Roman Catholic laity in, the United States of the 1968 papal ban on artificial birth control has led to drastic declines in religious devotion and, annually costs the church nearly a billion dollars in income, according to a survey of Catholic attitudes released yesterday by the National Opinion Research Center.

title: Moslem Gunmen Capture Downtown Beirut Areas
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Wednesday, March 24Moslem militiamen, bolstered by strong help from Palestinian guerrillas, advanced yesterday into downtown sections here traditionally held by Christian Phalangists.

title: Rizzo's Liberty
description: The temporarily successful effort last week to prevent publication of The Philadelphia Inquirer was a serious blow against the First Amendment rights of every American. The incident provided warning of the way totalitarianism might come to this country if the defenders of freedomregardless of their political orientationrelaxed their vigilance.

title: SOUTHERN SOUGHT BY MARQUETTE CO.
description: The Southern Industries Corporation said yesterday that it had received an unsolicited offer from the Marquette Company of Nashville, Tenn., to take over Southern by offering $28 a share. Directors of SouthMerger ern said they had News considered the offer and declined to recommend their approval because they deemed it insufficient.

title: REAGAN TOPS FORD IN N. CAROLINA FOR FIRST TRIUMPH IN A PRIMARY; CARTER EASILY DEFEATS WALLACE
description: RALEIGH, N. C., March 23Ronald Reagan upset President Ford and Jimmy Carter trounced Gov. George C. Walt lace of Alabama tonight in the North Carolina Presidential primary.

title: About NewYork
description: I grew up in hairdressing, said Joseph Weir. My mother was a hairdresser. She always told me, Joseph, if you're going to make it in hairdressing, you've got to make it in 20 years. She meant that after you reach a certain age you may have the technical ability but you don't have the appeal for clients.

title: Russians Report Fusion Using Electron Beams
description: Soviet experimenters have reported producing the first fusion reactions induced by converging electron beams on fuel pellets. The achievements adds one more candidate to the competing approaches for extraction of nuclear energy by fusing small atoms into bigger ones.

title: Market Place
description: Interest rates on corporate bonds have declined enough this year to raise a new concern for investors. The high  yielding bonds they bought in 1969, 1970 and 1971 may be called out from under them as corporations try to cut costs.

title: People in Sports
description: It is sure to cause controversy, but that's nothing new to Muhammad Ali. The world heavyweight champion was narrow choice over Joe Louis as the best fighter in the Greatest Athletes of All Time poll. All his place in a poll of 500 sports editors, writers and broadcasters conducted recently by Cutty Sark. Louis, a close second, was followed by Jack Dempsey, Sugar Ray Robinand Jock Johnson.

title: In Argentina's 2d City, Coup Was No Surprise
description: CORDOBA, Argentina, March 24A few hours before the military coup that toppled President Isabel Martinez de Pe ron's Government, a group of businessmen gathered as usual for drinks at the bar of the Hotel Crillon.

title: College Results
description: College Results

title: Argentina at a Glance
description: VITAL STATISTICSArgentina, with an area of 1,070,000 square miles, is about onethird the size of the United States. It occupies the major portion of South America south of the Tropic of Capricorn. It is bordered on the east by the Atlantic Ocean, on the west by Chile and on the north by Bolivia. Paraguay. Brazil and Uruguay.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In the next few months a showdown will take place in Rhodesia on which the United States and Great Britain will be tempted to spend countless resources. I write to suggest that this would be foolish and would ultimately strike another blow to the position of America in the worlda blow which the West could not afford to suffer during the current expansionist phase of Russian Communism.

title: DayCare Center Delay
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)The House has agreed to postpone until July 1 the effective date for child daycare centers to meet new Federal staffing standards.

title: Memorial Seruires
description: Memorial Seruires

title: Christian Forces in Beirut Lose More. Ground to Moslem Gunmen
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Thursday, March 25  Christian militiamen lost more around yesterday to their Moslem and Palestinian opponents as Syrian mediators sought to find a hasi for a new ceasefire in Lebanon's 11month civil war.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW SHARP GAIN
description: Prices rose sharply yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market as trading accelerated.

title: Business Records
description: Business Records

title: Chess:
description: There is no doubt that the most unnerving task in the game is defending against a mating attack. A slip against any kind of attack is bad enough, but when the king is involved, there may be no second chance for recovery.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: ORLANDO, Fla.Gene Wells. 158 pounds, Orlando, knocked out Sammy Ruckard, 150, Spartanburg, S.C., 10 rounds.

title: Rockefeller Talks With Shah
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 24 (UPI)Vice President Rockefeller and the Shah of Iran held talks today on an island in the Persian Gulf. Mr. Rockefeller arrived here yesterday and went to Kish Island, where he was greeted by Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlavi and senior members of his Government. He is scheduled to remain in Iran until tomorrow.

title: Curbs Sought for MedicareMedicaid Costs, but Not for Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The Senate Finance Committee is preparing new legislation that would restructure the administrative and payments systems within the Medicaid and Medicare health insurance programs, but leave benefits and eligibility untouched.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The three commanders of Argentina's armed forces took office in Buenos Aires as a governing junta 10 hours after overthrowing and arresting President. Isabel Martinez de Pern The only resistance was a brief shooting incident at a union headquarters. Numerous Peronist union leaders and political figures were being arrested. Mrs. Pern who refused to resign under military pressure, was flown to a provincial resort. The immediate reaction of workers, most of whom are Peronists, was calm and noncommittal. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: LEGAL FEES VOTED FOR ATTICA POLICE
description: ALBANY, March 24  The State Assembly passed a bill today to reimburse $153,000 in legal fees incurred by state troopers and correction officers investigated for lawlessness in retaking the prison at Attica following the riot there in September 1971.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DFATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO (AFORE> 4.3311 UNTIL S:J0 P.M, IN REGIONAL OFFICES CO A.M. TO 4:20 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRI.
