title: STATE UNIVERSITY INCREASES TUITION
description: The trustees of the State University of New York yesterday approved tuition increases for more than 145,000 (students that range from $100 a year for undergraduate resident students to $1,200 for medical students from out of state.

title: City Bars Cash Advances To City U. for Its Payroll
description: City officials said yesterday that the City University would likely exceed its new monthly budget ceiling set by the Beanie administration and have insufficient cash to meet its $20 million payroll next Wednesday. a plan still not in place, city official ia clearly pointed to the payroll as a possible source of pressure on the university.

title: ISRAEL COMPLAINS ABOUT CRITICISM BY U.S. AT TIT U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Israel complained to the United States officially today over the criticism of Israeli policy in occupied territories voiced yesterday in the United Nations Security Council by William W. Scranton, the chief American delegate.

title: Money
description: Money

title: High Court Grants Blacks Retroactive Job Seniority
description: WASHINGTON, March 24In a landmark civil rights ruling, the Supreme Court decided today, 5 to 3, that blacks who were denied jobs in violation of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 must be awarded retroactive seniority once they succeed in getting those jobs.

title: Making of Nuclear Plants Backed by Jersey Utility
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla,. March, 24The Public Service Electric and Gas Company of Newark Urged the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's atomic safety and licensing board today to license the manufacture of the world's first floating nuclear power plants.

title: The Three Who Will Govern Argentina
description: Named Commander in Chief of the Argentine Army last August after leading a revolt against predecessor  50yearold son of infantry colonel  graduate of Military College, Argentina's West Point, where two of seven children are now cadets. Roman Catholic and strongly antiCommunist, views Marxist concept of class conflict as devisive and threatening to national unity  as Commander in Chief put Argentina on war footing for first time this century for campaign against leftwing guerrillas  described by military colleague as man with high moral principles who hates corruption.

title: Sleeper in Medicaid Bill Is Protested
description: Dr. Robert P. Whalen, the State Health Commissioner, has appealed to Governor Carey to find some way around a sleeper amendment in the Medicaid budget bill that would transfer the ratesetting function to a body he described as provider oriented.

title: Simplest Chores Hard For the Handicapped
description: Need a new appliance? Have to buy a gift? Just go to the store and browse until you find the right purchase. Simple? Not for the handicapped and elderly who tire easily, whose disabilities restrict them from the shopping excursions most of us take regularly. The Easter Seal Society has made this necessary activity possible through its free wheelchair program for shoppers, which provides wheelchairs without charge at shopping centers across the state.

title: Urban Coalition Offers Plan on Housing Decay
description: To stem further housing decay here and rehabilitate buildings already deteriorated, the New York Urban Coalition proposed yesterday the creation of two new public benefit corporations a Consumer Housing Corporation and a Housing Trust Fund.

title: PRINCIPAL DEFIES COURT IN QUEENS
description: Dr. Howard L. Hurwitz, the principal of Long Island City High School in Queens, defied a court order yesterday and remained in his officewhere he has been since 4 A.M. Tuesdaydespite his suspension byi School Chancellor Irving An ker.

title: Adirondack Storm
description: Publication of the Adirondack Park Agency's twovolume report on its achievements and problems is well timed. The impressive account should be required reading in Albany, where the Legislature will soon have to deal with two attempts on the agency's lifeone to kill it outright and the other to drain its powers so drastically that it might as well he abolished.

title: SECRECY LABELING IS FOUND LIMITED
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The number of Federal officials with the power to stamp Government documents top secret, secret or confidential has declined by more than threefourths over the last four years, according to an interagency committee responsible for reducing the volume of classified information within the executive branch.

title: 33 CASES SETTLED IN S.I. EXPLOSION
description: Court settlements totaling $11 million were reached yesterday in 33 cases involving death and personal injury in an explosion and fire at a liquefiednaturalgas tank on Staten Island in 1973.

title: Campaigns Against Washington Termed Racism by Humphrey
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Senator Hubert H. Humphrey charged today that Presidential candidates running against Washington are practicing a disguised new form of racism. But he denied that his remarks were directed at Jimmy Carter.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Wednesday, March 24. 65th day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Payments Overseas Listed By Northwest and Offshore
description: Two more companies yesterday disclosed that they had made questionable payments overseas.

title: HIGH COURT LIMITS MILITARY RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Drawing a sharp distinction between the rights of civilians and those of military personnel, the Supreme Court ruled, 5 to 3, today that persons in the armed services have no right to be defended by a lawyer at a summary courtmartial even though they may be sentenced to as much, as 45 days in confinement.

title: The Sports Scoreboard
description: The Sports Scoreboard

title: Uphill Fight for Reagan, Carter Despite North Carolina Victories
description: RALEIGH, N.C., March 24Ronald Reagan's upset victory in North Carolina, which surprised even his closest advisers, leaves him with a steep uphill run toward the Republican Presidential nomination. By winning here after bowing to the President in the first five primaries, Mr. Reagan gave renewed hope to his supporters and improved his chances of raising the money needed to keep fighting. But the political arithmetic in some of the former California Governor's own strategic decisions put him at a profound disadvantage.

title: Reagan Will Seek To Seize Initiative In Race With Ford
description: LOS ANGELES, March 24Ronald Reagan will attempt in a television address next week to redefine the contest with President Ford for the Republican Presidential nomination, Mr. Reagan's strategists said today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The three commanders of Argentina's armed forces took office in Buenos Aires as a governing junta 10 hours after overthrowing and arresting President Isabel Martinez de Pettit The only resistance was a brief shooting incident at a union headquarters. Numerous Peronist union leaders and political figures were being arrested. Mrs. Perlin, who refused to resign under military pressure, was flown to a provincial resort. The immediate reaction of workers, most of whom are Peronists, was calm and noncommittal. (Page 1, Column 8.1

title: Reilly Bid for New Trial May Be Ruled On Today
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., March 24Judge John A. Speziale, is expected to issue his decision here tomorrow on the petition by 20yearold Peter Reilly for a new trial in the murder of his mother two and a half years ago.

title: Nastase Sets Back Rahim, 64, 46, 64
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 24 (AP)Ilie Nastase faltered temporarily today in his quest for the $200,000 American Airlines Tennis Games crown here, but regained his composure to record a 64, 46, 64 victory over Haroon Rahim of PaidStan.

title: BOWIE SHOW PAIRS MUM, AND ROCK
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 24 David Bowie's current show, which arrived tonight at the Nassau Coliseum here (and is due at Madison Square Garden on Friday) is by far the best Bowie show this observer has ever seen. The only one that could challenge it was the first Ziggy Stardust tour years back. Certainly the arty, overproduced, flatly untheatrical Diamond Dogs tour fell short of this, not even to speak of the fullfledged, flaccid disaster that limped into Radio City Music Hall last year.

title: HENRIETTA SAXTON
description: Henricita Sa:atm, mother of Dr. Roger Tory Peterson, the author illustrator and editor of field guides on birds and other nature subjects, died Tuesday in a nursing home in Ojai, Calif. Her age wns 96.

title: TV: Solzhenitsyn BBC Interview on Firing Line
description: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the exiled Russian writer, was interviewed on March 1 by Michael Charlton on Panorama, a publicaffairs production of the British Broadcasting Corporation. The event generated an extraordinary reaction, from widespread commentaries in the British and international press to the resignation, shortly thereafter, Pf Lord GeorgeBrown from the Labor Party. The former Cabinet official explained that the Solzhenitsyn warnings to the West made me feel I shoulddo something.

title: Sports Today
description: Columbia at Tona, 3 P.M. (Radio WKCR, 2:55 P.M.)

title: Ford Urges Flu Campaign To Inoculate Entire U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 24President Ford called today for a Governmentsupported campaign to vaccinate the entire United States population against a new influenza virtis to forestall possible epidemics next fall and winter.

title: COMPROMISE PLAN ON STATE LOTTERY
description: ALBANY, March 24Governor Carey and the Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, are reported to have reached an agreement that would break the impasse over competing Democratic and Republican bills to revamp the suspended, scandalridden state lottery.

title: Flying Ace Who Shot Down 17 Planes for Red Baron, 77
description: DE SOTO, Kan., March 24 (AP),Carl H. Schneider, a German World War I flying ace credited with shooting down 17 planes as a member of Baron Manfred von Richthofen's Flying Circus squadron, died here Monday. He was 77 years old.

title: Stocks at 3Year High
description: Stocks advanced broadly, with the Dow Jones industrial average ending at 1,009.21, highest in three years. Page 53.

title: The Pop Life
description: Paul McCartney and his band, Wings, will tour America beginning April 8 in Fort Worth, and ending May 24 and 25 at Madison Square Garden. The show will also appear at Nassau Coliseum on Long Island on May 21. There is no word yet as to when tickets will go on sale, but a tour spokesman said it would be in a few days. There will be no mail orders and tickets will be limited to six a person.

title: Bridge:
description: Some of the New York experts cbmpeting in the Spring Nationals in Kansas City, Mo., last week returned in time to compete in the Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss team championship during the weekend, but none was successful.

title: Why Is Kurt Vonnegut Jr. Smiling?
description: Last week, among literary ??? in local grottoes, one needed a stick to beat off the gossip. For instance, why is Kurt Vonnegut Jr. smiling so much? Mr. Vonnegut, who writes very funny books, is usually to be found around town looking as though Oswald Spengler had just moved in as a permanent house guest.

title: Senate Group Assails Mine Act As Too Weak to Protect Lives
description: WASHINGTON, March 24A bipartisan group of senior senators agreed today that the stringent Federal coal mine safety law they helped to write six years ago had failed to protect adequately the lives of miners or to impress the Department of Interior and many mine owners with the necessity of compliance.

title: Dow Rises 13.78 to 1,009.21; Closing Is Highest in 3 Years
description: The stock market advanced broadly yesterday in increased trading with the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks, up 13.78 at 1,009.21, closing at its best level in three years.

title: Yonkers Raceway Entries
description: Yonkers Raceway Entries

title: MERRILL ORDERED TO PAY DAMAGES
description: ST. LOUIS, March 24 (UPI)A Federal judge today ordered the Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith stock brokerage firm to pay more than $3.4 million in damages on charges of defrauding heirs of the founder of the company's St. Louis office.

title: Wallace Defeat
description: Jimmy Carter's thumping victory in the North Carolina Democratic primary was another severe setback for Gov. George C. Wallace. In winning, Mr. Carter drew only a few more votes than Terry Sanford had polled in losing four years ago. But in the interval the Wallace vote was virtually cut in half.

title: New Books
description: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Bernard Lonergan, by Hugo A. Meynell (Barnes & Noble, $25).

title: Kissinger and Visiting Turk Report Progress on Bases
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger met today with Foreign Minister Ihsal S. Caglayangil of Turkey and said progress was made toward restoring United States access to military and intelligence facilities that the Turks shut last summer.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Yonkers Raceway Results
description: Yonkers Raceway Results

title: Common Market Takes Issue With U.S. Plan for Tariff Cuts
description: GENEVA, March 24The European Economic Community complained today that a United States plan for cutting tariffs at the world trade talks here would not significantly narrow disparities between high and low rates of duties on imoorts.

title: State Gets U.S. Approval For ElectionLaw Change
description: The Federal Government has approved, as expected, the change in the New York election law that lists Presidential candidates names along with those of the delegate candidates supporting them, George Zuckerman, the head of the State Attorney General's civil rights bureau said yesterday.

title: People and Business
description: Edwin H. Yeo, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, cautioned yesterday that the United States could not be complacent about future inflation rates.

title: Sergei S. Smirnov, Wrote On War Themes in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, March 24 (Reuters)Sergei S. Smirnov, a prominent Soviet writer on war themes and an ardent exponent of Socialist realism in literature, died at the age of 61, Pravda, the Government newspaper, reported today.

title: CALLAWAY SEEKS A FORD MEETING
description: ATLANTA, March 24 Howard H. Callaway, the former Secretary of the Army who has stepped aside as President Ford's campaign manager pendling an investigation of allegations that he used his influence in Government for private gain, said tonight that he had asked for a meeting with Mr. Ford to discuss his permanent withdrawal from the campaign.

title: Senate Votes Bill to Save Election Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The Senate overwhelmingly approved tonight a compromise bill to reconstitute the Federal Election Commission and to make a wide variety of changes in the controversial campaign law. The vote was 55 to 28.

title: Saslow Appointed President of Saks; Third in 3 Years
description: Saks Eifth Avenue, the country's largest fashion specialty store chain, has appointed Robert J. Suslow as president and chief operating officer, effective June 1, it was announced yesterday by Alan. R. Johnson, chairman and chief executive officer.

title: AntiSeaIHunting Drive Is Ended in Newfoundland
description: ST. ANTHONY, Canada, March 24 (UPI)The Greenpeace Foundation ended a campaign protesting Canada's annual seal hunt today after seals and sealing fleets moved beyond the rano of the environmental group's aircraft.

title: Screen: Black History
description: In most of the films he made after his debut in 1928, Clarence Muse, a black actor whose face is much more familiar to us than his name, played faithful servants of great dignity but of little dramatic interest except as functions in the white plot. They were exceptions. In So Red the Rose (1935), Mr. Muse was cast as the leader of some rebellious slaves. In the 1931 version of Huckleberry Finn, he played Jim, though the accents of the rural South did not come easily to the collegeeducated actor.

title: Grumet to Talk With Carey Today About Nadjari
description: ALBANY, March 24Governor Carey is scheduled to go before a special deputy state attorney general tomorrow and tell why he fought to dismiss Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor.

title: U.S. Says Diplomats In Soviet Received Threatening Calls
description: WASHINGTON, March 24A State Department spokesman confirmed tonight that United States diplomats in Moscow had received a large number of phone calls, threatening retaliation for harassment of Soviet officials in New York City.

title: Stage: Woyzeck Revived
description: The most astonishing thing about Georg BLichner's Woyzeck is when it was written. It seems now to be a modern play, a precursor of the theater of the absurd or for that matter, with its vividly descriptive yet episodic structure, of the modern filmscript or, again, with its social awareness, of all those consciencestricken plays and novels of the 1930's. Yet this, the first great modern tragedy, was found unfinished on Bchner's death in 1837.

title: Companies Report Sales and Prof
description: Companies Report Sales and Prof

title: OFFICER ACCUSED IN FATALITY CASE
description: A Manhattan grand jury accused a 37yearold police officer yesterday of attempting to assault a taxi driver, who, in defense, swung his umbrella at another police officer, hit him above an eye and wounded him fatally.

title: EARLY LAB TESTS SAID TO CUT COSTS
description: A decadelong effort to have laboratory tests done before rather than after hospital admission for patients scheduled to undergo elective surgery has shortened hospital stays and checked costs, the Blue Cross Association announced yesterday.

title: Radio
description: Radio

title: NELSON. CASE, 66, ANNOUNCER, DEAD
description: Nelson Case, an announcer in radio and television for 50 years, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Doylestown (Pa.) Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in New Hope, Pa.

title: Sy Johnson Leads Colorful Readings Of His Jazz Works
description: Over the last two decades, Sy Johnson, a composer, exranger pianist and sometime jazz critic, has contributed material to the repertories of a variety of jazz bands, ranging from Count Basie's to Charles Mingus's. On Monday and Tuesday evenings he led his own jazz ensemble at the Ensemble Studio Theater, 549 West 52d Street, in a program that pointed up the bright, airy, swinging quality of his works.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A fiveday sitin by 50 studertts in the administrative building of the State University College at Old Westbury, L. I., ended after students and administration officials agreed to resolve complaints. The issues included admission policies for minoritygroup students, a bilingual program for Hispanic students, and campus housing.

title: GISCARD FORECASTS ECONOMIC RECOVERY
description: PARIS, March 24 (Reuters)President Valdry Giscard d'Estaing, fighting to restore his political prestige, said tonight that economic recovery was on the way and pledged to pursue his program of responsible reforms.

title: Christian Democrats in Italy End Congress Deeply Divided
description: ROME, March 24After an allnight session, the governing Christian Democrats ended their congress this morning, deeply divided and potentially weakened in their struggle to meet the growing challenge from the Communist Party.

title: Bartender, Beware the Smoke
description: The nation's bartenders, who for years have dealt with such hazards as rising tempers and falling patrons, have just been scientifically informed of a new one: smoke  tobacco smoke spewed out by their customers.

title: What DoYale Superwomen Find In the fob Market? Disillusionment
description: Six years ago Yale University enrolled its first undergraduate women, and the expectations of the 278 who were accepted from a pool of 2,850 applicants were high. They were widely presented as a class of superwomen, and they were highly conscious of the pressure to measure up to their image.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Aide Backs Moynihan, Praises Jackson
description: The No. 2 officer of the A.F.L.C.I.O. called on Daniel Moynihan last night to enter the race for United States Senator from New York and all but endorsed Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, for President.

title: Mayking Farin Polici
description: One unfortunate byproduct of the Kissinger era has been such a personalization of United States foreign policy that the public now forgetsif it ever knewthat crisis management is only one aspect of diplomacy.

title: Drive Seeking to Restore Nursing Homes Auditing
description: The Golden Ring Council of Senior Citizens Clubs opened a drive yesterday to restore a special auditing program for nursing homes that was cut from the state budget last week.

title: Bartender, Beware the Smoke
description: The nation's bartenders, who for years have dealt with such hazards as rising tempers and falling patrons, have just been scientifically informed of a new one: smoke  tobacco smoke spewed out by their customers.

title: Carolina Upset
description: The North Carolina primary may only have proved the law of averages.

title: Market Place
description: There has been a runup in both savings and loan and building industry stocks lately. The gain is apparently based on the hope that the highly leveraged construction industry  burdened with heavy inventories, soft demand, and tight money is slowly edging back to normalcy.

title: ISRAEL COMPLAINS ABOUT CRITICISM BY U.S. AT THE U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Israel complained to the United States officially today over the criticism of Israeli policy in occupied territories voiced yesterday in the United Nations Security Council by William W. Scranton, the chief American delegate.

title: S.E.C. REQUIRES INFLATION DATA
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted a rule today that will force about, 1,000 of the nation's biggest companies to compute and publish data showing how inflation is affecting their business. The action is seen as the first step toward an entirely new accounting system, one that breaks with the tradition of relying on historical costs.

title: Rosi Mittermaier Weighs Retirement
description: HUNTER, N.Y., March 24Rosi Mittermaier's appearance tomorrow morning at Hunter Mountain in the world series parallel slalom races for World Cup skiers may be her last in an important international competition.

title: U.S. AND CANADA RESTRICT ASYLUM
description: OTTAWA, March 24Canada and the United States have formally extended joint extradition procedures to curb airplane hijacking, terrorism and narcotics traffic.

title: GRAIN REFORM BILL ADVANCES IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, March 24  A joint meeting today; of two Senate Agriculture subcommittees approved a sweeping reform bill culling for direct Federal instutction of grain moving through all ports and 25 major inland terminal: markets.

title: Ford Urges Flu Campaign To Inoculate Entire U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 24President Ford called today for a Governmentsupported campaign to vaccinate the entire United States population against a new influenza virus to forestall possible epidemics next fall and winter.

title: PolishAmericans Mounting Counter drive Against Stereotyping
description: CHICAGOFor many thousands of Polish immigrants in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Chicago was Nowy Swiatthe New World.

title: Songs by Campbell Demonstrate Appeal For Vanishing Past
description: When Glen Campbell sings his hit recordings one after the other, their thematic unity becomes evident. By The Time I Get to Phoenix, Wichita Lineman, Galveston, Country Boy and last year's Rhinestone Cowboy all contrast a buccolic rural America with an urban and suburban life that is hollow at the core. The protagonist in the Cowboy is typical. He decries a neonandtinsel world he knows to be false, but his ambition drives him on.

title: ARGENTINE JUNTA UNDER ARMY CHIEF ASEYIES CONTROL
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 24The three commanders of Argentina's armed forces took office as a governing junta today 10 hours after overthroWing and arresting President Isabel Martinez de. Pern.

title: Tax Returns of Montoya Reportedly Being Audited
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)Internal Revenue Service sources said today than the service was auditing the income tax returns of Senator Joseph M. Montoya, Democrat of New Mexico, who is head of a subcommittee that reviews the I.R.S. budget.

title: 4 AFRICAN LEADERS MEET ON RHODESIA
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, March 24 (Reuters)Leaders of four African countries held talks here today on white minorityruled Rhodesia.

title: P.S.C. Bars Rate Rise
description: ALBANY, March 24 (UPI)The Public Service Commission yesterday denied a $57.1 million temporary electric rate Increase requested by the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation as part of its application for a $182.8 million rate rise.

title: Retail Gain for First 2 Months Is 14.9%
description: With the continuation of a high pace of consumer sales, the nation's chain stores reported a gain of 13.7 percent in sales volume in February, according to Chain Store Age magazine in a compilation of results of 36 chain organizations.

title: Transit Authority Told by State That It Must Hold Fiscal Line
description: With less than a week to go before the expiration of the transit workers contract, the Transit Authority was told by the state yesterday that it could not expect any additional money, and that it must hold all expenditures to present levels.

title: Television
description: Television

title: Celtics Thwart Bulls
description: BOSTON, March 24 (AP)Dave Cowens ignited Boston's fast break in the third period tonight and John Havlicek scored 12 of his 20 points in that quarter to lead the Celtics to a 9437 victory over the Chicago Bulls.

title: CrudeOil Imports Off in Week From Record Level
description: Imports of crude oil and petroleum products fell sharply last week from the record level of the preceding week, according to figures issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Financing of Communists Revived as Issue in Italy
description: ROME, March 24The Communist Party, which has gained strength in Italy as the party of clean hands, is having a rare encounter with scandal and facing new questions about real source of its funds.

title: Blackout Stays for Top Rutgers Fan
description: Dr. Edward Bloustein, president of Rutgers University, got as big a thrill out of the Scarlet Knights basketball team durilig the regular season as any of the enthusias tic undergraduates and alumni. He sat through most games, cheering loudly as Phil Sellers, Mike Dabney, Ed Jordan, and the rest reached the postseason tournaments undefeated.

title: Publicity. Company Cuts Ties With Iran Airline
description: Ruder & Finn, the public relations companY, has resigned the Iranian national airline account.

title: Jones Homers as White Sox Win
description: SARASOTA, Fla., March 24 (AP)Cleon Jones, the former New York Met, and Bob Oliver, an exNew York Yankee, hit home runs today to lead the Chicago White Sox to a 61 exhibition victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Knicks Lose To 76ers  By 118100
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 24 (AP)The Philadelphia 76ers, with Doug Collins getting 26 points and without George McGinnis, overwhelmed the New York Knicks, 118100, tonight in a National Basketball Association game at the Spectrum.

title: SERBAN'S COMPANY TO RETURN IN FALL
description: Andrei Serban and his experimental theater company will be returning to New York after all.

title: Harris Places Hopes on Pennsylvania
description: Fred R. Harris, the former Oklahoma Senator who says he hopes to win some delegates to the Democratic National Convention in the New York primary on April 6, made a brief visit to this city yesterday, his first in two weeks.

title: Notes on People
description: For the first time since Sir Winston Churchill retired in 1955, Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip went to 10 Downing Street to visit the Prime Minister when they dined Tuesday with the retiring Harold Wilson. Looking down on the farewell dinner, in the State Dining Room, were portraits of Lord Nelson, the Duke of Wellington and British statesmen of the past. Among the guests were four contenders for Mr. Wilson's office: Foreign Secretary James Callaghan, Home Secretary Roy Jenkins, Chancellor of the Exchequer Denis Healey and Employment Secretary Michael Foot.

title: House Plan to Cut Arms Fund By $7 Billion Disturbs President
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Presiderit Ford said today that he was very disturbed by a proposal made yesterday by a key member of Congress to cut $7 billion from the administration's proposed military budget for next year.

title: City Sanitation Unit Will Expand Roster Of Civilian Helpers
description: The Department of Sanitation hard pressed for manpower to keep the streets clean, announced plans yesterday to expand its Civilian Patrol Corps throughout the city.

title: US. DOUBTS A VISIT BY BREZHNEV IN '76
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The Ford Administration has reportedly concluded that because of the strains in SovietAmerican relations over Angola, a visit to the United States by Leonid I. Brezhnev, even to sign a new agreement limiting strategic arms, has become increasingly less likely this year.

title: Mosquito Is a Double Threat
description: HOUSTON (UPI)  Aedes Aegyptia, the mosquito species that transmits yellow fever in the Americas, also carries a virus that produces the painful and infectious human disease called dengue. At present there is no known vaccine for this disease, which produces fever, headache and a rash, and which can kill children up to 12 or

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AMERICAN ACCORD (U.S. Lines), Havre April 7; sails from Howland Hook, Staten Island.

title: Whole New Ball Game
description: DALLAS, March 24On Monday of this week, the gleaming DC9 of the Secretary of State arrivedat taxpayers expensein this Texas Republican stronghold for two days of politicking on behalf of President Ford's campaign.

title: State University Raises Tuition From $100 to a High of $1,200
description: The trustees of the State, University of New York yesterday approved tuition increases for more than 145,000 students that range from $100 a year for undergraduate resident students to $1,200 for medical students from out of state.

title: Dividends
description: Dividends

title: P.S.C. Bars Rate Rise
description: ALBANY, March 24 (UPI)The Public Service C'ommission yeslerday denied a $57.1 million temporary electric rale increase requested by the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation as part or its application for a $182.8 million rate rise.

title: Monty of Alamein
description: Something there was about MontyField Marshal the Viscount Montgomery of Alameinthat called up memories of Gen. George B. McClellan, an early commander of the Army of the Potomac in the American Civil War. Both believed in long and cautious preparation before battle, both wore their vanities upon their uniforms, both inspired their troops and the public, and both tended to blame others if the tides turned against theme.

title: MARINE TO BE OUSTED IN SHOOTING AT CAMP
description: PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., March 24 (UPI)Sgt. Robert F. Henson, who shot and wounded a recruit at this Marine Corps Training Depot, will serve only two months of a oneyear sentence but will still face a badconduct discharge, forfeiture of pay and reduction in rank.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Investors took advantage of the soaring stock market last month to redeem a record amount of mutual fund shares, figures released by the Investment Company Institute showed today. Net redemptions climbed to $309.6 million, exceeding the old record of $258.3 million for November 1972.

title: Money for U.S.I.A. Approved
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)The House approved a $337.99 million authorization for the United States Information Agency today, trimming nearly $7 million from the agency's broadcast budget.

title: 6 Men Are Under Investigation in Mellon Abductions
description: Six men, some with links to organized crime, are under investigation as possible participants in the abduction last Friday of the two daughters of Seward Prosser Mellon the Pittsburgh hanker, according to investigators in the case.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: State health officials announced in Mount Holly that all publicschool children in Burlington and Camden Counties must be immunized for measles by April 9. Acccirding to the officials, the policy had been prompted by an outbreak of measles in the two counties, where 73 cases the illness have been reported since Jan. 1.

title: GalindezSkog Bout Off Until Sunday
description: OSLO, March 24 (AP)The world lightheavyweight title fight between Victor Galindez of Argentina, the World Boxing Association champion, and Harald Skog has been postponed two days to Sunday night because the Norwegian challenger was hit and knocked down by a car last night. Erik Stenerud, the promoter, said today Skog was not hurt as seriously as it first appeared.

title: MAINE POTATOES RISE DAILY LIMIT
description: Prices of oldcrop Maine potatoes rose the daily permissible limit of 50 cents a hundred pounds yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: Stocks at 3Year High
description: Stocks advanced broadly, with the Dow Jones industrial average ending al 1,009.21, highest in three years. Page 33.

title: Jackson Pledges U.S. School Aid for City
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington pledged yesterday that, if elected President, he would lead a fight for more Federal aid to such financially hard pressed local school systems as New York City's, where cutbacks have forced the layoff of thousands of teachers.

title: British Football
description: British Football

title: Burden of Office Was Too Great
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 24 Isabel Martinez de Peron went out as President of Argentina in a midnight helicopter ride as about 100 followers, mostly women with tearfilled eyes, fluttered white handkerchiefs from the nearly empty square facing Government House.

title: No Cheers for Potvin
description: Denis Potvin has spent three seasons with the New York Islanders. He won the Calder Trophy for the league's rookie of the year in his first season and led the Islariders in points and assists in his first two seasons.

title: 1975 Had Basic Surplus In Balance of Payments
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The United States basic balance of payments showed a surplus last year for the first time in the 15 years since this measure of the nation's international transactions has been tabulated, the Commerce Departmeat reported today.

title: Gibson's Guard Accuses Councilmanof Assault
description: NEWARK, March 24Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's bodyguard filed an assault  and  battery charge today in Municipal Court against Councilman Anthony Carrino.

title: Music: Progress Report
description: Marian Hahn made her liebut at Carnegie Recital Hall in 1974 and was recognized as a young pianist of profnise. She returned to the hall Tuesday night to give us a progress report with a recital thatindicated her promise is being fulfilled. Her technique has been honed to a gleaming edge and her good schooling (she now coaches with Leon Fleisher) showed in interpretations of considerable maturity.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Hockey, Basketball Standings

title: A Little Thinking Is Fun for Children
description: Often when children's productions strive to be meaningful they end up being no more than contrived, sugary makebelieve.

title: Look Away, Dixie Land
description: DURHAM, N.C.Whatever else this Presidential year may bring, it has already disclosed one notable change in the American political map: The South is hack in the Union. It is no longer dominated by the single issue of race. Like most other parts of the country, it can be won by moderate candidates of either major party.

title: SALE TO OIL SHALE SET BY PHILLIPS
description: Phillips Petroleum Company announced yesterday that the sale of its West Coast refining, terminals and marketing properties and inventories to the Oil Shale Corporation would be completed on April 4. The assets that the Oil Shale Corporation will buy consist of a refinery at Avon, Calif., and approximately 725 gasoline stations plus related terminal and bulk plants. The total consideration involved is about $230 million and The Shale Oil Corr poration's funding has been arranged with the help of Lehman Brothers Inc., and a syndicate of banks and certain institutional investors. The Shale; Oil Corporation is also planring to resell some of the assets including 180 gasoline stations, which will be sold to the Southland Corporation.

title: Sonkisser Scores In Florida Stakes
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., March 1.4 (AP)  Sonkisser fought back to edge Proud Birdie by a head today in the $37,950 Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park. Archie Beamish was a distant third and Legendaire finished fourth in a field of seven 3yearolds, all eligible for the $125,000added Florida Derby a week from Saturday.

title: Amex Plans 2 Million Expansion Here; Making LongRange Relocation Study
description: Although the American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it would spend $2 million over the next two years to expand its facilities, it also disclosed that it was examining longrange proposals to move to New Jersey or Connecticut.

title: Bond Prices Surge As a Light Calendar Of New Sales Looms
description: The credit markets continued yesterday to move decisively toward lower interest rates, and the Treasury sold a $2.5 billion issue of 58month notes at an average vield of 7.38 percent, down from 7.54 percent on almost sipilar notes that were sold three Weeks ago. Prices of already outstanding Government, corporate and taxexempt bonds all rose sharply as Wall Street emphasized how light the schedule of bond sales would be over the next several weeks.

title: CULTURE LACKING, JERSEYANS FEEL
description: A majority of New Jersey residents polled by The New York Times are dissatisfied with the number of cultural activities in the state, enthusiastic about the entertainment, recreation and the schools, and convinced that medical care and shopping are as good in their areas as in New York City.

title: Boy Slain by an Israeli Is Buried on West Bank
description: JERUSALEM. March 24 (Reuters)An Arab boy was buried quietly in his home village near here early today, a week after he was shot by an Israeli soldier during a demonstration in the Israelioccupied West Bank of the Jordan River.

title: Baseball Talks Get A Fruitless Replay
description: Negotiators for baseball's owners and players met for five hours here yesterday and made no dent in the impasse that delayed the start of soring training for 17 days.

title: Lobby Bill Gains in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)The Senate Government Operations Committee unanimously approved yesterday, legislation to tighten a 30yearold law requiring organizations to identify their lobbyists. The committee chairman, Senator Abraham A. Ribcoff, Democrat of Connecticut, said the old law had provisions that permit lobbyists to register or not as they see fit. The new law, he said, would cover any organization that hires professional lobbyists, gets in touch with Congress frequently or organizes major lobbying efforts such as letterwriting campaigns.

title: School's BirthControl Lecture Splits Town
description: EMERSON, March 24The question whether a public school should disseminate birthcontrol information to teenagers has polarized this predominantly Roman Catholic community of 9,000 in Bergen County.

title: Bergman Tax Case Dropped in Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM, March 24Taxfraud charges against Ingmar Bergman, the worldfamous film director, were dropped today by the public prosecutor's office.

title: Narragansett Fire Under Investigation
description: EAST PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 24 (AP)The Narragansett Park fire that destroyed two stables and killed more than 20 horses is being investigated as possible arson. Duty Chief George Kent of the East Providence Fire Department said tonight that he had received an anonymous tip that the fire was set by bookmakers angry about being kicked off the track grounds. The fire broke out in a stall of one of the barns about 8:40 P.M. on Monday.

title: State Medicaid Chief Resigns in Protest
description: The state's top Medicaid oficial has resigned, charging that the $3.5 billion program is mismanaged because of basic flaws and because no one, perhaps least of all myself, is directing the program.

title: Mrs. Peron's Ouster
description: It was typical of the cynicism with which many Argentines view their country's politics that most people in Buenos Aires seemed more interested in a soccer telecast Tuesday night than in the ouster of President Isabel Martinez de Perlin by the armed forces. The script was familiar for this longanticipated coup; the only unusual aspect was that it removed the first woman head of government in the history of the Western Hemisphere.

title: Advertising
description: As some of the smart money has been predicting, Somerset Importers has decided to assign its $5 Million Johnnie Walker Red Label Scotch account to DArcyMacManus & Masius. So ends a competition that began last November and once included eight agencies.

title: Westchester to Shut ChildDetention Unit As Budget Economy
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 24Westchester County will close Woodfield Cottage, a children's detention institution, and phase out the county's Office of Civil Defense as part of an effort to cut $2 million from the 1976 budget.

title: Children in Foster Homes a Year Get Right to Preremoval Hearing
description: The Federal District Court here has ruled that children in foster care for a year or more must have a hearing before being taken from a foster home.

title: CHRISTIAN BORTH, 80, AUTOMOTIVE WRITER
description: Christian C. Borth, an automotive historian, died Monday evening in Detroit of complications following influenza. He was 80 years old and lived in Fenton. Mich.

title: Court Backs Disputed Dam Project
description: WASHINGTON, March 29The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit affirmed today a license granted by the Federal Power Commission to the Appalachian Power Company in June 1974 to build a huge hydroelectric project on the New River on the North CarolinaVirginia border.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: MRS. WILLIAM JARMAN
description: Mary, Mona Jarman of 505 Queen Anne Road in Teaneck, N.J., wife of the Rev. William J. Jarman, pastor of Park Avenueil Christian Church here, died Tuesday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck. She was 54 years old.

title: Yankees Put Mets To Rout
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 24Twelve days late and one intracity feud later, New York's professional baseball teams began their Southern season tonight. The Yankees won, 71, but the Mets didn't go away mad. innocent bystander, nevertheless, he could have acted as a diplomatic gobetween.

title: Radio Spots for John Jay College Use Political Campaign Tactics
description: The copy begins: This is a personal message for Mayor Beame and Governor Carey. When you were running for office, remember you promised to fight crime

title: Featured Now, in the Center Ring, Are Stars From Eastern Europe
description: The band plays Yankee Doodle Dandy and The Stars and Stripes Forever. Clowns dress up like Abe Lincoln, Uncle Sam and the Statue of Liberty. Showgirls wear red, white and blue starspangled costumes. But the truth is that the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus is about as American as fermented mare's milk, borscht, stuffed cabbage and csirke pap rikas.

title: JOHN H. SMOOT
description: John H. Smoot, a retired patent attorney who was a founding member of the New York Patent. Law Association, died Tuesday in Pompano Beach, Ha., where he lived. He was 79 years old.

title: Sales of New Cars Show MidMarch Rise of 42%; Volume of Chain Stores Up by 13.7% in February
description: DETROIT, March 24Domestic new car sales for midMarch were up nearly 42 percent over last year's poor levels, marking the start of the strong spring selling season.

title: Junta Members Have Long Worked Closely Together
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 24At the Roman Catholic Chapel of San Miguel, outside the Campo de Mayo military base, Lieut. Gen. Jorge Rafael Videla has been the lay reader of the Gospel text during the noon mass each Sunday since he became commander in chief of the army in August.

title: Senate Votes Bill to Save Election Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The Senate overwhelmingly approved tonight a compromise bill to reconstitute the Federal Election Commission and to make a wide variety of changes in the controversial campaign law. The vote was 55 to 28.

title: Reagan Will Seek To Seize Initiative In Race With Ford
description: LOS ANGELES, March 24Ronald Reagan will attempt in a television address next week to redefine the contest with President Ford for the Republican Presidential nomination, Mr. Reagan's strategists said today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. on Middle East.

title: Mismanagement Charged in $3.5 Billion Program Budget Unit Scored
description: The state's top Medicaid official has resigned, charging that the $3.5 billion program is mismanaged because of basic flaws and because no one, perhaps least of all myself, is directing the program.

title: Inventive Styles Of Hong Kong, In 4 Movements
description: Nobody could fault the presentation. It was splendid. Who but the Hong Kong Trade Development Council ever conceived w of commissioning a modern composer to create a symphony to support a fashion showand then keyed the clothes to the four symphonic movements?

title: High Court Grants Blacks Retroactive Job Seniority
description: WASHINGTON, March 24In a landmark civil rights ruling, the Supreme Court decided today, 5 to 3, that blacks who were denied jobs in violation of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 must be awarded retroactive seniority once they succeed in getting those jobs.

title: Vote Totals in N. Carolina
description: Following are the unofficial final vote totals in the North Carolina Presidential primary, the convention delegates awarded as a result of that primary and the overall tally of delegates chosen so far, as compiled by The Associated Press:

title: ARGENTINE JUNTA UNDER ARMY CHIEF ASSUMES CONTROL
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 24The three commanders of Argentina's armed forces took office as a governing junta today 10 hours after overthrowing and arresting President Isabel Martinez de Pern.

title: Bergman Tax Case Dronned in Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM, March 24Taxfraud charges against Ingmar Bergman, the worldfamous film director, were, dropped today by the public proseiutor's office.

title: LE MONDE ASSAILS A CRITIC IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, March 24Le Monde, France's most serious daily newspaper, has started making news about itself. A book attacking the paper for persistent leftist bias and distortion has just appeared, and Le Monde (The World) replied with a frontpage denunciation of the author, headed Notice to Readers.

title: Most Latin Countries Under Military Control
description: The military coup in Argentina brings all but two of South America's 10 major countries under military control.

title: Nets Rally to Turn Back Spirits, 106931
description: UNIONDALE, Li., March 24The sluggish New York Nets got an energy transfusiori from Ted McClain tonight to gain a 106933 victory over the Spirits of St. Louis at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Bradley Remembers Dear Monty as Giant
description: LOS ANGELES, March 24 (UPI)General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, one of the last living associates of Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, issued a brief statement today, praising Britain's World War II hero, who died early today.

title: Money for U.S.I.A. Approved
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)The House approved a $337.99 million authorization for the United States Information Agency today, trimming nearly $7 million from the agency's broadcast budget.

title: Another Bulldog That Is Worth Talking About
description: A song that has echoed across Yale Bowl for many years and frequently is heard when men of Eli gather is Bulldog. Although Cole Porter composed more than two dozen musical comedies, with many hit tunes, none has been a hit longer than Bulldog, which he wrote as a Yale undergraduate.

title: Carter Takes. Aim at Udall 11 in the Wisconsin Primary
description: MILWAUKEE, March 24With scarcely a further word about his majority victory yesterday in the North Carolina primary, Jimmy Carter plunged today into Wisconsin  back into the urban, industrial North, this time in a state where he said that he had a good chance to deal Representative Morris K. Udall a decisive blow.

title: Exhibition Baseball
description: New York (A.) 7, New York (N.) 1 (night), Boston 7, Houston 6.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WINGS OF SONG There is something reassuring about the sight of the oldfashioned upright piano inside the entrance of the Griffin (3714542), a compact restaurant with modern appointments that draws neighborhood residents and people from the United Nations area.

title: Screvane Stands Up for OTB Interstate Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)The number of race tracks may be reduced in future years, but not because of interstate offtrack wagering, Paul Screvane, head of New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation, told the House Transportation and Commerce Subcorrunittee today.

title: Preminger Plays the Advocates Devil
description: For Otto Preminger, last night's mock arbitration sponsored by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York was just thathe refused to take the mock proceedings seriously.

title: City Outdoes Itself in Redesign Of Lower Avenue of Americas
description: Something has happened to the lower blocks of the Avenue of the Americas that should have happened years ago, but didn't, and should be happening everywhere else in the city, but probably, won't. It is a complete redesign of the avenue and its related amenities, such as small parks and squares, from Canal Street to West Fourth Street, and it is so far above the usual standard of urban design in New York City that one is tempted to wonder if the city government had anything to do with it at all.

title: HART SAYS EXXON COULD BE SPLIT
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Senator Philip A. Hart, who has been trying for years to break up the big oil companies, asserted today that arguments by the Exxon Corporation in two state tax cases showed the company's production, transportation, refining and marketing divisions can stand on their own.

title: Albany Approves 3 Bills On Saving State Agencies
description: ALBANY, March 24  The Legislature approved three bills today to carry out the rescue of the state construction agencies, but it deferred the most controversial measure until Monday, leaving only three days to act before one of the agencies goes into technical default.

title: Recital
description: Jane Carlson, a pianist who has given many performances of Hindemith's Ludus Tonalis since she first played it 30 years ago, repeated the work again in a recital at the Juilliard Theater on Tuesday night. In addition to Hindemith's vast composite of a dozen fugues and linking interludes, the program included Barber's Sonata.

title: MIKI CHALLENGED IN LOCKHEED CASE
description: TOKYO, March 24The head of Japan's leading opposition party today accused Prime Minister Takeo Miki of an attempted coverup of the Lockheed bribery scandal here.

title: Burden of Office Was Too Great
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 24 Isabel Martinez de Perrin went out as President of Argentina in a midnight helicopter ride as about 100 followers, mostly women with tearfilled eyes, fluttered white handkerchiefs from the nearly empty square facing Government House.

title: TEAMSTER CHIEFS ASK STRIKE VOTE
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., March 24The leadership and bargaining committee of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters recommended to 700 local delegates today that they reject the last offer made by the trucking industry and go back to their locals and take a strike vote this weekend.

title: INDIA PLANS DRIVE TO CURB EXTREMISTS
description: NEW DELHI, March 24 (AP) The Indian Government announced today a drive against political violence.

title: Aid for Wisconsin
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)President Ford said today that Wisconsin suffered a major disaster March 1 because of severe storms, high winds and flooding, and was eligible for special Federal aid.

title: Office Renting Here Called Good Omen
description: A slight overall gain last year in the renting of Manhattan office space is being cited by some business and real estate leaders and local officials, as a bright spot in the city's otherwise depressed economy.

title: G. A. O. Report to Congress Finds Improper Recruiting by Military
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)  Improper recruiting practices by all the armed services resulted in 41,000 unqualified men and women being trained in 1974 at a cost of about $70 million Congressional investieators reported tndav Recruiting costs increased from $430 million in the last year of the draft, fiscal 1973, to $508.1 million in the last year of the allvolunteer force, fiscal 1974. Secondyear costs rose to $511.3 million, said a report released by the General Accounting Office, the auditing arm of Congress.

title: State Colleges Lack Funds for Raises
description: TRENTON, March 24The 2,700 teachers in the eight state colleges were still on the job today, but the contract they agreed to last night faces an uncertain future. The teachers, who were scheduled to strike today, agreed to accept a 7 percent raise in the 197677 school year and a 5 percent increase in the next year, but there is no money to pay for the raises yet. The new twoyear contract also provides for no layoffs and no increase in class work loads.

title: Rangers Lose,. Out of Playoffs
description: BUFFALO, March 24 (AP) Jim Lorentz, Danny Gare and Brian Spencer scored within 2 minutes 12 seconds to spark a fivegoal third period that gave the Buffalo Sabres a 73 National Hockey League victory over the New York Rangers tonight. The loss eliminated the Rangers from playoff contention for the first time since 1966.

title: C.I.A. HELD RUSSIAN WITH OSWALD DATA
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)A Soviet defector who assured United States officials that Lee Harvey Oswald was not a Russian agent was held in solitary confinement for nearly three years while the Central Intelligence Agency tried unsuccessfully to break his story, according to informed intelligence sources.

title: U.N. Group Drafts West Bank Resolution, Hoping to Avoid U.S. Veto
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 24Third world members of the Security Council and Rumania, in consultation with Arab delegations, today drafted a resolution on developemnts in Israelioccupied areas on the West Bank of the Jordan in an effort to avoid a United States veto.

title: CARETAKER SAYS HE BURNED BODIES
description: A caretaker at the community house of the religious cult operated in Brooklyn by DeVernon LeGrand, a selfstyled bishop, has sworn that he helped dispose of the bodies of two young sisters, members of the cult, by burning.

title: Hill & Knowlton Names Officers
description: Hill & Knowlton, the world's largest public relations concern, yesterday named William A. Durbin, 59 years old, chairman, and Loet A. Velmans, 52, president. Both had been vice chairmen. The company's chairman and chief executive, Richard W. Darrow, died last Saturday.

title: Lawyer Says Miss Hearst Has No Plan to Testify on Harrises
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 24 Patricia Hearst has no plans to testify anywhere against any of her former associates, Albert Johnson, one of her attorneys, said today.

title: GOLD
description: GOLD

title: Excerpts From Scranton's U.N. Speech
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 24 Following are excerpts from the text of remarks made in the Security Council yesterday by William W. Scranton, the United States representative:

title: A House Panel, on TV, Rejects Plan for Television From Floor
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The House Rules Committee, in a rare departure from established practice, allowed a television camera to cover its proceedings today and then voted to shelve, and probably kill, a proposal permitting television and radio coverage of floor action of the House of Representatives.

title: WILLIAM V. SKALL
description: LOS ANGELES, March 24 (AP)William V. Skall, who won the 1948 Academy Award in cinematography for the motion picture Joan of Arc, died Monday at the age of 78.

title: Law Proposed to Sanction Interstate Bank Expansion
description: John G. Heimann, the New York State Superintendent of Banks, announced last night that he would introduce legislation shortly to allow banks to expand across state lines.

title: Windsor Castle Funeral For Montgomery April 1
description: LONDON, March 24 (AP) Britain will provide a full military funeral April 1 for Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery of Alamein.

title: In Memoriam
description: In Memoriam

title: Wallace Openly Despairs, About His Political Future
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 24Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, his campaign in tatters, despairs openly about his political future and seems at times to be reaching out desperately, almost wistfully, for one final victory, one last measure of vindication after all his tumultuous years on the national scene.

title: Personal Finance
description: The problem of joint ownership of a family's assets by a husband and wife is often filled with complexities. But a recent decision by the New York State Court of Appeals answers one part of this problem  that dealing with joint bank accounts.

title: N. C. A. A. in Swim Today
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 24If you can't buy swimming tickets for the Olympic Games in Montreal next July, you may do almost as well at the 53d annual National Collegiate championships here at Brown University's Smith Swimming Center.

title: Books of The Times
description: While it is sad to have to say that the final volume in Anthony Powell's 12part novel, A Dance to the Music of Time, is disappointing, I have always felt that the whole affair is something of a mistake, that it gained increasing recognition out of sheer persistence more than anything else. Like Daniel Boorstin's definition of a celebritysomeone who is well known for being well knownthere are novelists who become widely recognized, even famous, by continuing to turn out mediocre books.

title: Jury to Get Kapp's Case On Monday
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 24The testimony phase of Joe Kapp's antitrust suit against the National Football League ended today, three weeks after it began, and the case will go to the jury on Monday.

title: Montgomery, Hard to Like or to Ignore
description: One winter night in Moscow, early in 1947, Walter Bedell Smith was sitting in front of the fire in his small sitting room in the American Embassy. He was then Ambassador to tne Soviet Union but for most of World War II he had been Chief of Staff to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower. He was getting tired, he said, of all this damned nit picking about Monty. The Field Marshal, he conceded, had been a difficult man to handle, but there wasn't anyone else who *could have got us across the Channel and ashore in Normandy; it was his sort of battle.

title: Miss Crowley, E. N. Black 4th Married Here
description: Eleanor Susan Crowley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney J. Crowley of New York, was married here yesterday morning to E. Newbold Black 4th of New York, secretary of the United States Olympic Committee.

title: A COOP PROPOSED AT BRONX MARKET
description: Most of the food merchants in the Bronx Terminal Market told the city yesterday that they were ready to take over the market as a cooperative if the city canceled the 99year lease of the Arol Development Corporation.

title: Aqueduct Entries
description: Aqueduct Entries

title: New Junta Imposes Prior Censorship On Nation's Papers
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 24Argentina's military authorities imposed prior censorship on newspapers here today and prevented transmission abroad of part of a television news film of a raid on a Communist Party office.

title: In the Dugout Shade With Bill Rigney
description: CASA GRANDE, Ariz., March 24In the dazzle of the desert sun, a few of the San Francisco Giants were taking extra batting practice. Bill Rigney, the new manager hired by the new owners, sat in the shade of the small gray wooden dugout. He is 57 years old now, and his hair is white as his Giant uniform. But he is as effervescent ever. When he was a second baseman with the Giants New York, he was known as The Cricket because seldom stopped talking. And now, as he watched his hitters in the batting cage, he was still talking. The thing I like, He was saying, is that the good players are taking extra hitting. I think players are more responsible now.

title: Burma's Universities Close
description: RANGOON, Burma, March 24 (Agence FrancePresse) Burma's universities closed today for the fourth One in two years after antiGovernment demonstrations by students here yesterday.

title: Charleston S.C., Will Be Spoleto, U.S.A.
description: Saying that it was a city culturally asleep and ready to be awakened, Gian Carlo Menotti announced yesterday that Charleston, S. C., had been chosen as the site for the Spoleto Festival. U.S.A. Taking place May 25 through June 5, 1977, the festival will become the counterpart of the Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy which the composer founded in 1958 and of which he is now president.

title: Bergeron Injures Eye
description: DETROIT March 24 (UPI) Michel Bergeron, the Na tional Hockey League's leading rookie goal scorer, tallied his 31st and 32d of the season before leaving the game with an eye injury tonight as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the Washington Capitals, 73.

title: Prisoners, All
description: POMONA, N.J. Correctional officers are not the villains of our penal system. Instead, prisons are nearly as destructive of the lives and minds of the captors as they are of the captives. As a former Officer, let me explain why.

title: Rail Crackup
description: Congress set a poor precedent when it let the railway unions dictate featherbedding clauses in the law reorganizing the bankrupt Northeast railroads. The result is that one key element in the reorganization plan is already being destroyed.

title: West Bank Violence Reflects Growing Discontent Among Arabs
description: JERUSALEM, March 24It was a decision by a freshman judge in the lowest court in the land in what seemed a routne case; a prayin by some Israeli youths on Temple Mount near Al Aksa. Mosque that violated standing orders against such activity. The youths were acquitted and the decision ignited the worst series of street demonstrations, general strikes and riots on the occupied West Bank of the Jordan since Israel seized the area nearly nine years ago.

title: Events Today
description: Events Today

title: Manila Signs 5Year Pact To Supply Sucrest Sugar
description: The Government of the Philippines has signed a fiveyear contract to supply the Sucrest Corporation with 650,000 metric tons of raw sugar a year, President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced yesterday in Manila.

title: Smith Dreams of Skateboards, Surf and First 19Foot Vault
description: Steve Smith just wasn't designed for the sidewalks of New York.

title: $150,000 IS VOTED FOR HOUSE INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The House's investigation into the disclosure of the report of its disbanded intelligence committee will begin questioning of witnesses next week after five weeks of delays caused by wrangling over money.

title: Es, IS REVIEWING ITS CUBA OPTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The Ford Administration announced today that contingenc:y plans for possible moves against Cuba were being reviewed, but it seemed clear from the comments of several officials that there was no urgency about the review, which was reported to have begun several weeks ago.

title: Lauda Is Choice In Coast Grand Prix
description: LONG BEACIr, Calif., March 25 (UPI)Niki Lauda, world autodriving champion, was given the best chance today to win Sunday's $250,000 United States Grand Prix West and run his string to three straight grand prix victories this year.

title: Washington Is Scored On Rail Plan for City
description: The New York State Secretary of Transportation, Raymond T. Schuler, charged yesterday that, because of Federal ineptness and inaction, New York City was in danger of becoming the only major metropolis in the nation without competitive rail service.

title: Second Thoughts
description: WASHINGTON, March 25Every time Governor Carter wins a primary election, which is quite often these days, the pressures mount on Hubert Humphrey to get into one or two of the last of the primaries.

title: Science Foundation Funds
description: WASHINGTON. March 25 (AP)The House voted today to authorize $801 million for the National Science Foundation for the year heginning Oct. 1. Funding will depend on future appropriations.

title: People and Business
description: David P. Reynolds yesterday was elected chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Reynolds Metals Company, one of the nation's largest aluminum producers. In his new post, he succeeds his brother, Richard S. Reynolds Jr., who headed the company for more than 28 years.

title: Montclair State Women Beaten
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., March 25  Immaculata, shooting 62 percent from the field in the first half, easily defeated Montclair State, 10382, tonight In a quarterfinal game of the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women basketball tournament.

title: F.B.I. REPORTS CRIME ROSE 9% LAST YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)The Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today a 9 percent increase in the nation's crime rate for 1975 compared with the record 18 percent leap recorded the previous year.

title: Angola Withdrawal Set by South Africa
description: CAPE TOWN, March 25  South Africa announced today that it would withdraw all its forces from southern Angola by Saturday.

title: RAILWAY UNIONS BAR PENNSOUTHERN PACT
description: Officials of the seven unions involved in negotiations for the Southern Railway Company's acquisition of the 460 miles of road of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad yesterday informed Secretary of Transportation William T. Coleman that they would not sign the memorandum of understanding relating to labor conditions proposed by Mr. Coleman.

title: Today's Entries at Aqueduct
description: Today's Entries at Aqueduct

title: Louis Arpels, Jeweler, 89, Dies; Formed Concern With Van Cleef
description: Louis Arpels, one of the founders of Van Cleef & Arpels, international jewelers, died at his home near Paris on Saturday. He was 89 years old.

title: Gromyko Answers Charges
description: LONDON, March 25  The Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, today ridiculed any suggestion that his country was involved in the struggle for power in Rhodesia.

title: TEACHERS STRIKE A DAY IN COLOMBIA
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, March 25 (AP)Defying state of siege; decrees, thousands of teachers in staterun schools and colleges went on a 24hour national strike today to enforce demands for better salaries and to protest government educational policies.

title: Hometown Bids Rutgers Godspeed
description: Hometown Bids Rutgers Godspeed

title: Notes on People
description: Washington's Gov. Daniel J. Evans, who was named by President Ford in January as one of eight qualified potential running mates, said yesterday he would end his political career without running for a fourth term. The 50yearold Governor announced no future plans but said he would probably not make himself available as a VicePresidential candidate or for a Federal appointment.

title: Old Neighbors See No Conflict of Interest for Callaway
description: PINE MOUNTAIN, Ga.,The old man reached down to scrape the mud from his shoes and raised himself laughing at the stranger's question.

title: Soviet Trade Staff Finds a Time Bomb Outside Off ice Here
description: A time bomb was discovered; yesterday morning by an employee of the Amtorg Trading Corporation, the Soviet trade agency, on a fire escape of the company's Lexington Avenue office, 12 hours after the police went through the, building following a telephoned bomb threat.

title: 77 Shrine Game Site Set
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 23 (AP) The Shrine EastWest game, which drew a crowd of 75,000 to Stanford Stadium in January, will he played there again in 1977, officials announced today. The college football allstar game will be played on Jan. 2, a Sunday, said Frank Busse, the game director.

title: LA STOPGAP BUDGET IS VOTED IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, March 25 (UPI)Japan's opposition parties agreed today to call off their boycott of Parliament long enough to help the Government pass a stopgap budget designed to keep the country running for 40 days.

title: Mayor's Fiscal Plan
description: Mayor Beame's revised financial plan represents the most serious effort yet to solve the city's basic problem: restoration of New York to solvency over the next two years without destroying the city in the process.

title: POST IN AGREEMENT WITH MAILERS UNION
description: The mailers union and The New York Post reached agreement yesterday on a new twoyear contract, to replace one that expired nearly a year ago.

title: Aluminum Shipments Up
description: The Aluminum Association said yesterday that net shipments of sheet and plate in January had reached an estimated 408.5 million pounds, 19.1 percent higher than a year ago. S. L. Goldsmith Jr., president, said that foil shipments at 67.6 million pounds were also 19.1 percent ahead of the yearearlier total.

title: Kennedy Center Head Acts on La Scala Unit
description: ROME, March 25Martin Feinstein, the head of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts of Washington, said here today that he had made a specific proposal to the Italian Minister of Tourism and Entertainment in an effort to salvage the scheduled appearance of Milan's La Scala Opera Company at the center later this year.

title: About the Mets
description: Joe McDonald says the Mets will feel very badly if Ron Swoboda's comeback after two years in broadcasting turns out to be a publicity stunt. It all gets back to honesty, the general manager of the Mets adds. We asked Ron and he insisted he wasn't writing a book or doing it for promotion or anything. Personally, I don't think he can play in the big leagues, but we'll let him work out with our minor leaguers and see. The Mets suffered one minor casualty while losing to the Yankees, 71, in Fort Lauderdale on Wednesday night: Bud Harrelson's left hand was jammed by the sliding Thurman Munson. The fragile shortstop worked out yesterday but did not play against the Cardinals.

title: Tests of Flu Vaccine Expected in April
description: WASHINGTON, March 25First tests in humans of vaccine against the new influenza virus are expected to begin about midApril, a Government scientist said today.

title: My Fair Lady Is Restored to Broadway in Fine Form
description: It had to be better andby and large and by George!it is. The restorationrevival seems too cold a word for such a sumptuous undertakingof My Fair Lady to Broadway took place at the St. James Theater last night. It is 20 years since Rex Harrison, Julie Andrews, Stanley Holloway and Robert Coote first danced all night, and now only Mr. Coote, as deliciously bumbling as ever, is left, and we have three new musical Shavians, Ian Richardson, Christine Andreas and George Rose.

title: Italians Win Cup Season's Last Skiing
description: HUNTER, N. Y., March 25 In summery weather that had both spectators and performers rolling up shirtsleeves, Italy captured skiing's world series today with a strong showing by their men's team for the second straight day.

title: Radio
description: Radio

title: Market Place
description: A note of asperity has begun to creep into the stock market commentary of the gold bugs, those toughminded, often conservative analysts who revere the precious metal as the last line of defense against debauched currencies and the ravages of inflation.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: Federal Reserve Statement

title: U.S. WOULD BEGIN TALKS ON VIETNARM
description: WASHINGTON, March 25A State Department spokesman said tonight that the Ford Administration was prepared to open talks with the Vietnamese over possible normalization of relations.

title: Groupers Plan for Sun and Sociability
description: OCEAN BEACH, Fire Island It was a wretched day here last Sunday, with gusty winds and piercing rains and everything else that can go wrong on a March day, but nothing could deter the three young women from the city from seeing Snug Cozy.

title: TEXACO CUTS PRICES FOR SEVERAL FUELS
description: Texaco Inc. announced yesterday that it had cut prices on all grades of tractor and diesel fuels, No. I and No. 2 heating oils and kerosene. The price decreases, which range from 0.95 cent to 1.5 cents a gallon, are applicable to resale and distributor classes of trade.

title: Hartford Work week Impasse Is Eased
description: HARTFORD, March 25The Democratic majority in Connecticut's House of Representatives decided in a closed caucus today to go only halfway with Gov. Ella T. Grasso in her bid to help balance her proposed $1.8 billion budget by lengthening the workweek for the state's 40,000 employees from 35 hours to 40.

title: Kissinger Out on a Limb
description: Secretary of State Henry Kissinger is getting himself further and further out on a limb over those 13,000 Cuban troops in Africa. First, he warned Havana and its sponsors in Moscow not to use the Cubans to intervene on behalf of the black guerrillas fighting against Rhodesia's allwhite Government. Then he reiterated the United States intention to do nothing to support that minority Government. Now he says those two stands are not contradictorybut that may be the saw you hear in the background.

title: Drop in Mental Retardation Is Termed Possible
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)Mental retardation with physical causes can be cut in half by the year 2000, but up to five million persons are mentally disturbed because of their own poverty and will be harder to treat, a Presidential commission said today.

title: SOVIET HARASSING IS CHARGED BY U.S.
description: MOSCOW, March 25  The United States has protested to the Soviet Union over the harassment of American diplomats in Moscow, including a bomb hoax and other telephone calls this week threatening reprisals for incidents against Soviet officials in New York.

title: Franjieh Abandons Palace In Lebanon After Shelling
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 25 President Suleiman Franjieh was forced to abandon the Presidential Palace overlooking Beirut today after it was hit by heavy artillery. He took refuge in a Christian stronghold 13 miles north of the capital.

title: Rocky Talks Foreseen by Teamsters
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., March 25Most teamster leaders and delegates meeting here on new contract negotiations seem agreed that this year's contract talks are the most difficult in the last several decades.

title: 14 Indicted for Plot To Smuggle Heroin From Thai Bases
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)A Federal grand jury has indicted 14 persons, including active and retired servicemen, for conspiring to use military bases and aircraft to smuggle $100 million worth of pure heroin into this country from Thailand, it was announced today.

title: Senate Turns Back 3 Attempts to Bar Concorde Landing
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)The Senate rejected today three proposals to ban the BritishFrench Concorde from landing in this country.
