description: Television

title: G.O.P.INNEW YORK LIMITS CONTESTS
description: New York backers of Ronald Reagan for the Republican nomination for President have entered only four slates totaling 12 candidates for delegates to the party's national convention in the April 6 primary, but he also has some support among delegates already designated.

title: Delmarva Peninsula Lives Through Perils of Pauline Over Railroad's Future
description: SALISBURY, Md., March 24Here comes the railroad train. There is a time bomb on the track. Will the train be blown up or will a hero come along at the last minute?

title: Navy Planning Two More $1 Liilion Carriers Amid Debate Over Their Effectiveness in a Major War
description: A handful of naval officers and civilian analysts are questioning the effectiveness of the aircraft carrier in a major conventional war, challenging the entrenched view of a Navy dominated by carrier admirals.

title: BEAME PROPOSES NEW BUDGET CUTS ENDING 8,000 JOBS
description: Mayor Beame yesterday proposed a new $821 million budgetcutting plan calling for further service reductions, the elimination of 8,000 more jobs and the, controversial shifting of more than $250 million in education and court costs from the city to the state.

title: Hornell's Hones Ride on Chessie Purchasing the Erie but Outlook Is Bleak
description: HORNELL, N. Y., March 25Railroad tracks cutting through the center of town, and the long trains that frequently use them, may annoy people in some places. But in this remote southwestern New York community, the sight and sound of trains creeping through at all hours of the day and night have been comforting for decades.

title: FEW FACE LAYOFFS IN CITY'S JOB CUT
description: Actual layoffs of municipal employees in the fiscal year beginning next July 1 are expected to amount to only a 10th of the 8,000 positions Mayor Beame proposes to eliminate in his new financial plan.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor As Congress debates the issues raised by the HumphreyHawkins legislation, our representatives should be urged to pay particular attention to the plight of our jobless youth. While the 7 percent adult unemployment figure is of itself cause for concern and seems a poignant enough issue to resolve, the youth unemployment rate of 16 to 20 percent (higher for minorities) portends equally awesome difficulties for our society. [Editorial March 19.]

title: Arbour Is Unhappy Over Tie With Kings
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., March 25 (UPI)Al Arbour, the Islanders coach, isn't happy with how his team's game ended last night against the Los Angeles Kings. He says the Kings tied the game on an illegal shot.

title: U.S. VETO BLOCKS A U.N. RESOLUTION CRITICIZING ISRAEL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 25The United States tonight vetoed in the Security Council a resolution deploring Israeli policies in Jerusalem and the occupied areas on the West Bank of the Jordan River.

title: Bridge:
description: The extraordinary feature of the two premier events in the Spring Nationals in Kansas City last week was their complete ordinariness and predictability.

title: Tariff Cuts
description: After six rounds of reciprocal trade liberalization in four decades, the United States and Europe's ninenation Common Market are down to average tariff levels of about 7 percent on industrial imports.

title: Dr. Luis Miro Quesada, 95, Published Comercio in Lima
description: LIMA, Peru, March 25 (AP) Dr. Luis Mir6 Quesada, former owner of the Lima daily El Comerclo, died today of a heart stack. He was 95 years old.

title: Stein Calls for the Consolidation Of 200 Agencies to Save Money
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein called yesterday for the consolidation of more than 200 public authorities and agencies in the state that he said made up a multibilliondollar hidden government:

title: ARABS BID TO BUY BIG PARIS HOTELS
description: PARIS, March 25In what could be the biggest realestate transaction in the history of Paris, Arab interests are negotiating to buy three luxury hotels once owned by Michele Sindona, an Italian financier whose empire collapsed in 1974.

title: State Agency Calls on Hynes to Begin Inquiry Into Boarding Homes for Aged
description: ALBANY, March 25 The Department of Social Services called today for an investigation of the state's 426 private boarding homes for the aged by Charles J. Hynes, the special nursinghome prosecutor.

title: Monitoring the Banks
description: Two months ago, disclosures in the press that scores of the nation's largest banks were on problem lists produced a wave of shock and outrage by bankersand warnings that disclosure of such secret information could lead to runs on the banks, bank failures and a choking off of lending.

title: Seaver Hurls 4 Innings As Mets Lose to Cards
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25Unsigned but untraded, Tom Seaver made his first appearance of baseball's late spring today and pitched four unruffled innings while the New York Mets were losing to the St. Louis Cardinals, 10.

title: Conrail Loses Bid For Dividend Stay
description: A special threejudge court in Washington yesterday rejected a petition of the Consolidated Rail CorporationConrailto restrain directors of the Canada Southern Railway from declaring a $60ashare dividend on its 150,000 shares of stock.

title: China Has Wide Array Of Goods at Thai Fair
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 25  China today opened the largest trade fair it has ever presented in Southeast Asia  the most tangible evidence to date of the commercial form ChineseSoviet rivalry is taking in this part of the world.

title: Bomb Kills 7 at Thai Rally
description: BANGKOK. Thailand, March (AP)A hnnih expindrd at a political rally in northern Thailand last night, killing 7 persons and wnonding 10, authorities said today.

title: Despite Urban Image, New York Is a Varied State
description: Sitting amid the clutter and noise at the Manhattan headquarters of Representative Morris K. Udall, John Marttila, a Udall campaign consultant, said that he hoped to have $300,000 available for the New York Presidential primary April 6 and a similar amount for the Wisconsin primary the same day.

title: Books of The Times
description: B. F. Skinner's Particulars of My Life Is delightful in its warm boygrowingupinsmalltownAmerica simplicity. From its charmingly anthropomorphic beginning, where we meet the Susquehanna River carving out the sickleshaped Pennsylvania valley in which Skinner spent the first 18 years of his life, to the uplifting ending, where our hero puts aside the divagations of youth and marches off to Harvard to reinvent behavioral psychology, the first volume of Skinner's autobiography unfolds like a film directed by Frank Capra. There's Spring Byington and Edward Arnold in it (Skinner's paternal grandmother, born Josephine Penn, was the sort of woman whose glassjar preserves often exploded and who liked to put birdseed between her lips so that her pet canary would kiss her; her son, B.F.'s father, was a modestly successful lawyer, whose career was eventually stymied by his inability to warm to people).

title: Veterinary College At Cornell Warned It Faces Probation
description: ITHACA, N.Y., March 25 The New York State College of Veterinary Medicine at Cornell University may be placed on probation by the American Veterinary Medicine Association because of an insufficient numbeE: of faculty memIbers and inadequate facilities.

title: Dazzling Wild Beasts at the Modern
description: Connoisseurs of upheaval think very highly indeed of the Fauve room at the Salon d'Automne of 1905 in Paris. Like the first hearing, in 1913, of Stravinsky's Rite of Spring in the same combustible city, the first showing of Fauve paintings by Matisse, Derain, Vlaminck and others was the prototypical pre1914 scandal: the moment at which primeval instincts found outlet and the old regime got its ears tweaked once and for all. Commotions of one kind or another have been a part of our cultural life ever since, but these two were what Henry James called the real right thing. Great works of art were in question; people stood up to be counted; life was never the same again.

title: JACKSON IS EDGING TOWARD THE LEFT
description: In the last few days of his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Senator Henry M. Jackson has been edging toward the left of the political spectrum.

title: Argentine Military, Firmly in Control, Eases Curbs
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 25The new military junta relaxed some restrictions today, but security forces continued to arrest Peronist militants, Communists and others suspected of subversion.

description: CAPE TOWN, March 25  South Africa announced today that it would withdraw all its forces from southern Angola by Saturday.

title: Gibson Files Charges Against Rally Leader
description: NEWARK, March 25Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson filed charges of assault and malicious damage in Municipal Court today against Councilman Anthony Carrino, who broke into the Mayor's office Tuesday at the head of a crowd of 75 protesting the appointment of a new police captain in the city's North Ward.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: With no wish to prolong to absurdity the debate on hunting that has been carried on in this column the last few years, but rather to give the matter additional historical perspective, I would like to offer some observations on the subject by Xenophon, the Greek historian and solid soldier.

title: Supporters Give Sendoff to Rutgers Squad
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, March 25Rutgers University's undefeated basketball team received a rousing sendoff today in a ceremony at City Hall on its departure for Philadelphia and the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Clues to Identity of Genetic Master Switch Grow
description: Researchers appear to be closing in on the identity of a substance that throws the master switch in embryonic development, initiating the events that lead to the formation of specialized organs and finally to a fully developed organism.

title: The Gun Dictates the Way of Life in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 25  Three armed teenagers burst into the American's apartment. Two brandished Sovietdesigned AK47 assault rifles. The other, apparently the leader, carried an American M16.

title: PERTAMINA DEBTS TOPS EARLY FIGURE
description: Indonesian Government investigators have placed the indebtedness of the state oil corporation at about $9.1 billion rather than the $3.5 billion initially announced by the Indonesian Government, according to an Associated Press report.

title: FRANK G. M'CORMICK, BEGAN YOUTH LEAGUE
description: FULLERTON, Calif., March 25 (UPI)Frank C. McCormick, a cofounder of the country's first youth baseball league in 1925, died of cancer yesterday in Sunny Hills Convalescent Hospital. He was 81 years old.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Most families know the problemsthey're what Dr. Carol Eagle, who heads the child psychiatric division at Montefiore Hospital, calls the arenas of conflict.

title: Advertising
description: Would large national advertisers who are spending millions upon millions of dollars in television be interested in a way of making sure that viewers are paying attention to their commercials?

description: College and School Results

title: Postal Officials Say They Miscalculated On Parcels Damage
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)Postal officials said today that they had not realized that their new machinery provided a new way to break up packages because they had been studying the wrong statistics.

title: ELIZABETH ROSENFELD
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., March 25Elizabeth Kaufman Rosenfeld, a civic leader here, died of cancer today at her home here. She was 70 years old.

title: Reilly Wins Retrial in Mother's Slaying
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., March 25peter A. Reilly was granted a new trial here today by a Superior Court judge who ruled that his conviction on charges of killing his mother two and a half years ago represented a gave injustice.

title: DR. MARIO LAZO
description: Mario Lazo, for 35 years a partner in a leading Havana law firm, Lazo & Cubas, died yesterday in Richmond. He was 81 years old and lived in Norfolk, Conn.

title: Hyland Bars Limit on Campaign Costs
description: TRENTON, March 25 State Attorney General William F. Hyland ruled today was unconstitutional to limit the amount of money that can be spent on races for Governor and other state office. Mr. Hyland said, however, that the state might continue to limit the amount contributed by an individual to a candidate. State law limits contributions generally to $600 a person and until now has limited spending in campaigns to 50 cents for each registered voter.

title: Conservation Unit Marks Dozen in House for Defeat
description: WASHINGTON, March 25Environmental militants fired their first salvo of the political campaign today, naming a Dozen House members they said should be defeated because of what the environmentalists viewed as poor voting records on ecological issues.

title: Vicki Got Wild Early
description: COLUMBIA, S. C.  They carried Vicki Prideaux (not her real name) out in a plastic bag. She was a goodtime girl and sometime during the night or early morning somebody cut her head offhanging by a thread, people said. It was a good thing the children weren't home. She'd left them with neighbors.

title: STATE AUDIT SCORES CARE OF RETARDED
description: ALBANY, March 25An audit of how the State Department of Mental Hygiene regulates private schools for the retarded has found that the schools are poorly supervised by the agency and given little direction in developing programs consistent with state policy. The audit of the 28 schools was done by the office of Comptroller Arthur Levitt.

title: MERLE S. JONES DIES; LED CBSTV IN 195657
description: Merle S. Jones, who retired as director, vice president and general executive of the Columbia Broadcasting System in 1968, died Wednesday in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 70 years old.

title: Mrs. Carter Carries Campaign to Harlem
description: Roslyn Carter took to the streets of Harlem yesterday, campaigning for her husband, Jimmy Carter, who is seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Champion of School Discipline
description: A 1968 dropout from Long Island City High School paid a surprise visit yesterday to his former principal, Dr. Howard Lawrence Hurwitz. To do so he had to persuade a group of par ents who were standing guard outside the principal's office to let him through. Dr. Hurwitz looked at the visitor, and immediately recalled him as George Miller, a student who had misbehaved a lot. But he was never mean, the principal told an onlooker. He never threatened anyone. The young man said he just wanted Dr. Hurwitz to know that I'm behind you all the way.

title: Red Smith
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 25Spring training was late but the fans came early and kept coming, creeping west a few car lengths at a time in a swollen stream traffic three lanes wide. At 8 o'clock last night when the Yankees and Mets joined in the rites of March, Fort Lauderdale Stadium bulged with the nexttolargest crowd this 14yearold park has ever held, and cars were still backed up at least a mile on Commercial Boulevard. With 7,256 cash customers in the stands, gates were closed and it was estimated that at least 2,000 others were turned away. Twentyfive miles down Interstate 95, another 9,347 clients were already watching the Baltimore Orioles and Cincinnati Reds in the year's first exhibition Miami Stadium. In 17 years there, the Orioles had never drawn so many during the week, although Baltimore and New York played to 2,464 one Sunday 1965 when the Yankees last performed as defending champions of the American League, Obviously, the baseball public was less reluctant to see spring training start than the club owners, who locked the players out of camp until last week.

title: Jupiter's Magnetic Tail Found to Be Huge
description: The planet Jupiter has an enormous magnetic tail, almost half a billion miles long and perhaps longer, that spans the distance between the orbits of Jupiter and Saturn, according to data returned In recent days from the Pioneer 10 spacecraft.

title: Limiting Public Jobs to Citizens Is Unconstitutional, Court Rules
description: A threejudge Federal constitutional court In Brooklyn declared unconstitutional in a 2to1 decision yesterday a state law that gives preference for employment on public construction contracts to citizens who have been residents of the state for at least 12 months.

description: Researchers appear to be closing in on the identity of a substance that throws the master switch in embryonic development, initiating the events that lead to the formation of specialized organs and finally to a fully developed organism.

title: CHICAGO JET CRASH KILLS 3, IN JURES 1
description: CHICAGO, March 25 (UPI)A four engine Jet Star crashed into an instrument landing system device while trying to take off from Midway Airport today and burst into flames, a spokesman at. Midway said.

title: Reflecting Tires Required
description: Starting May 1, bicycles sold for use in New York State must have reflecting tires, according to Commissioner James P. Melton of the State Department of Motor Vehicles. And starting the same day, bicycle replacement tires sold for use in the state also must be reflective, he said. The two basic exceptions to these requirements are bI. cycles with tires fitting wheels 16 inches in diameter or smaller, and tubular (hand sewn) tires, he said.

title: JACKSON BACKERS UPHELD BY COURT
description: ALBANY, March 25  The State Supreme Court ruled here today that 33 contested delegates in the state's April 6 primary election could still be identified on the ballot as supporters of Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington even though they missed last Saturday's deadline for filing their certificates of preference with the Secretary of State.

title: In Memoriam
description: BLANKDolly. March 26, 1970. Six long tragic years, lonely years without you. Empty my Ilfe, but the memory remains, the memory of life as it might have been, together with the wish that soon, very soon, we shall be together forever.

title: Rock Epics Sung By Elliott Murphy At the Bottom Line
description: If there were ever a paradigm for a critics darling, it would be Elliott Murphy; if rock critics were as powerful as some people think they are, Mr. Murphy would be ruling the world. Instead, the singer and song writer from Long Island, who appeared for two shows Wednesday night at the Bottom Line, has put out three records that have gone nowhere commercially and has toured erratically.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: OFF THE AVENUE What do Nathan's Famous  the new Nathan's of Fifth Avenue  and the St. Regis Lounge have in common? Singing pianists.

description: The Sports Scoreboard

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.2 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose slightly to 197.1 from 196.9 last week.

title: TIBOR KOZMA DEAD; EXMET CONDUCTOR
description: Tibor Kozma, professor of music at Indiana University since 1957 and a former conductor at the Metropolitan Opera, died Wednesday in Bloomington, Ind., after having been injured in an auto accident. He was 66 years old.

title: Yugoslav Repression
description: Marshal Tito, whose Yugoslavia once seemed a relatively free and tolerant Communist state, has innovated the Catch 22 of repression, in effect outlawing legal defense of an accused person by making it plain to lawyers that they too will go to jail if they put their oblieations to their client first.

title: Sponsors of Medicaid Bill Differ With Commissioner on Its Aims
description: The legislative sponsors of a bill to restructure the state's Medicaid program and the State Health Commissioner, who administers the program, disagreed yesterday over the intent and implications of several provisions of the measure, which now awaits Governor Carey's signature or veto.

title: An Argentine Hopes for Peace
description: CORDOBA, Argentina, March 25Elio Rojas arrived in COrdoba from a small provincial town five years ago when he was a very young man with ambitions to become a lawyer.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Few lifesigns could be more encouraging for New Yorkers than the recent spurt of new restaurants in Little Italy. In the last year, five new eating places have opened there, and a sixth, long a favorite haunt of Italianfood buffs, has reopened after a fiveyear absence. Sponsored by the Little Italy Restoration Association, and backed in part by the Small Business Administration, this renaissance is an attempt to breathe life back into the area.

title: Everyone's in the Kitchen With La Deva
description: At first glance What's Cooking? seems indistinguishable frcm any other television cooking show. An aproned hostess, in one of those cheery, pristine kitchen sets that is supposed to be in a home (but seems too tidy, too wellequipped) stands behind a freefloating cooking unit, her utensils and ingredients ready and waiting, about to launch into the howto's of whipping up a gourmet feast.

title: House Budget Panel Cuts Ford Request $500 Million
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)The House Budget Cornmitee today made its first substantial cut In President Ford's 1977 budget, voting tentatively to reduce money for foreign aid and other international affairs by $500 million.

title: N.C.A.A. Swim Summaries
description: N.C.A.A. Swim Summaries

title: Auto Makers Expanding Production
description: DETROIT, March 25The United States automobile industry, buoyed by strong sales reports in recent weeks, is adding more cars to production schedules for the next three months.

title: Mich. Tech Victor In 2d Overtime, 76
description: DENVER, March 25Michigan Tech outlasted Brown, 76, tonight in double oertime in the opening round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament. Tech is defending its title.

title: FordReagan Race: Similarity in Views
description: LOS ANGELES, March 25 A young woman giggled the other night as she greeted Ronald Reagan at a campaign rally in Green Bay, Wis., by holding up a handlettered placard that said, Reagan can chew gum and walk at the same time. The homemade sign, a reminder of the cutting remark Lyndon B. Johnson is supposed to have made once about President Ford, was supplied, the woman said, by a Reagan campaign worker. It served to symbolize Mr. Reagan's effort to distinguish his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination from Mr. Ford's.

title: Y.M.C.A. Opening An Annex in House That Morgan Built
description: When J. Pierpont Morgan built a parish house for St. George's Church on Stuyvesant Square in 1888, the act was a personal gesture by the financier to the neighborhood in which he lived and to the memory of his father  in  law, Charles Tracy, a church officer.

title: Money
description: Money

title: Amex and OTC Show Price Drops As Trading Lags
description: Profit taking yesterday depressed prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over  thecounter market in slower trading.

title: Argentine Military, Firmly in Control, Eases Curbs
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 25The new military junta relaxed some restrictions today, but security forces continued to arrest Peronist militants, Communists and others suspected of subversion.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Marvin Miller, executive director of the Players Association, charged baseball's owners today with being more concerned with league matters than with reaching an accord on a new basic agreement.

title: May Stores Lifts Profit 54.1% In Quarter and 42.5% for Year
description: The May Department Stores Company, a major nationwide chain operating 129 stores, reported yesterday profit increases of 54.1 percent for the fourth quarter and 42.5 percent for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31.

title: 6 African Countries to Get $39 Million in Arab Loans
description: CAIRO. March 25 (AP)MahMoud Riad, secretary general of the Arab League, has announced loans totaling $39 million to six African countries.

title: ARMS SMUGGLING TO JAPAN HALTB
description: TOKYO, March 25Japanese and American police have apparently broken up a transPacific gun and jewelry smuggling operation that supplied Japanese gangsters with pistols that were purchased in California and shipped here in golf bags.

title: U.S. Studies School JobBias Cases Here
description: Federal investigators have begun looking into allegations that discrimination has caused disproportionate layoffs of black and Hispanic employees by the city's school system.

title: American Can Board Backs Bid for U.S. Reduction Co.
description: Directors of the American Can Company approved yesterday a proposal to acquire the U. S. Reduction Company as a subsidiary. The proposal was approved last Monday by directors of U. S. Reduction. Under the proposal, American Can would exchange seventenths of a share of its common stock for each of the 1.8 million shares of U.S. Reduction outstanding. The 1.26 million shares requred to effect the transaction would have a value of about $44.1 million.

title: P. B. A. in Nassau Asks Court to Move On PayRise Award
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March, 25The Nassau County Patrolingn's Benevolent Association asked a State Supreme Court justice today to order, the county to comply immediately with a binding arbitration award granted to its members.

title: Detective Says He Found Mellon Girls
description: A private detective who recently retired from the New York Police Department said yesterday that he had found out where the daughters of Seward Prosser Mellon, the Pittsburgh banker, were before they were abducted. But the detective, Joseph Presti, said he had no role in their abduction.

title: La Scala, U.S.A.
description: When floods endangered the art treasures of Florence and Venice a few years ago, committees sprang up across the United States to raise funds for their rescue and American art students flocked to Italy to contribute their labors to salvage and restoration work. The floodtide of inflation and recession that has undermined the lira and Italy's economy now threatens another cultural loss that should rally another rescue program.

title: ACCORD REPORTED ON QUEENS SCHOOL
description: A compromise was apparently worked out last night in the controversy involving Dr. Howard L. Hurwitz, the suspended principal of Long Island City High School, and classes were expected to resume this morning after three days of parent and student protests.

title: Decision Arouses Expressions Of Joy, Doubts and Disillusion
description: The long fight to win a new trial for Peter A. Reilly ended yesterday, bringing with it expressions of joy, a sense of relief, and, for some of Mr. Reilly's neighbors in Connecticut, a few doubts and some disillusion.

title: Business Loans Increase $32 Million
description: Business loans at leading New York City banks rose $32 million in the week ended Wednesday for their largest increase so far this year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Udall Enjoys Wisconsin Crowds but Problems Persist
description: NEENAH, Wis., March 25Representative Morris K. Udall is not a particularly demonstrative man, but yesterday he began to show the exhilaration that candidates feel from the political adrenalin of bigger crowds and a growing volume of applause.

title: People in Sports
description: Governor Byrne of New Jersey took time out yesterday to send best wishes to the undefeated Rutgers University basketball team.

title: Hall's Nomination For Air Force Job Withdrawn by Ford
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)  President Ford withdrew today the nomination of Albert C. Hall as Assistant Secretary of the Air Force after it was disclosed that Mr. Hall had been promised a job by a major defense contractor when his Government service ended.

title: DOW SLUMPS 7.08 ON PROFIT TAKING
description: Prices and volume backed down on the stock market yesterday. But the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks closed above 1,000off 7.08 to 1,002.13  despite inroads caused by profit taking.

title: TAXFREE ISSUES SHOW RATE SLIDE
description: Interest rates on state and city bonds, as measured by the widely watched Bond Buyer index, dropped to their lowest level in more than a year yesterday as taxexempt bond prices continued to move upward. Other sectors of the creditto t markets early yesterday and then Government and corporate bonds faltered for the first time this week and prices drifted downward to close with small losses.

title: British Labor Party's Race Is Narrowed to Three Men
description: LONDON, March 25The sixman contest to succeed Harold Wilson as Britain's Prime Mininster turned unexpectedly tonight into a struggle fnvolving only three  Michael Foot, James Callaghan and Denis Healey.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The United States last night vetoed a resolution in the Security Council of the United Nations deploring Israeli policies in Jerusalem and the occupied areas on the West Bank of the Jordan River. William W. Scranton, the new United States representative at the United Nations, said the resolution was unbalanced. The 141 vote ended a debate that began Monday on antiIsraeli unrest in Jerusalem and West Bank towns. [Page 1 Column 4.]

title: McCartney Coast Dates Sell Out Unannounced
description: LOS ANGELES, March 25 (Reuters)More than 36,000 tickets to Paul McCartney's two concerts here late next month sold out within three and a half hours today, even though the concerts had not been officially announced.

title: Fred Schmertz, Who Directed Millrose Games 41 Years, Dies
description: BATON ROUGE, La., March 25 (UPI)Fred Schmertz, director for 41 years of New York's Millrose Games, the oldest indoqr invitational track meet, died today at the age of 87 after a long illness at the Baton Rouee Medical Center.

title: Hagopian Named Chief at Ayer
description: Yesterday Louis T. Hagopian, nifty golf player, super story teller and pretty good advertising man, was elected chairman and the sixth chief executive in the 107year history of N.W. Ayer ABH International.

description: Yonkers Raceway Entries

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 25Three persons standing in the warm sunshine on the sidewalk of Hamra Streetthe Fifth Avenue of Beirutwere killed at noon today when shells landed next to Shaker's Pharmacy.

description: Two stockholders supported by the American Jewish Congress sued the Eastman Kodak Company here yesterday to prevent the photography concern from holding its annual meeting as scheduled next month.

description: WASHINGTON, March 25The Continental Grain Company agreed today to an affirmative action program designed to guard against corruption in grading and handling of grain.

description: Business Records

title: Shaw Defeats Naber
description: PROVIDENCE, R. 1., March 25Tim Shaw and John Naber, two titans of American swimming, met headon tonight in the first final of the 53d annual National Collegiate championships. Shaw won in record time, but both were happy.

title: Screen: Moving and Distressing 'Juvenile Liaison'
description: Sergeant Ray of the Lancashire Constabulary hasn't the remotest resemblance to the fictional English detective who wears disgust and weariness as elegantly as his tweeds. Sergeant Ray wears shiny dark jackets with ugly yellow squares, a white shirt, a greasy tie, hair slicked back and thinnish, a black leather coat that makes his bulk look brutal.His disgust and weariness come out as violence, barely repressed and sometimes not even that; as cunning, quite unrepressed and showing through. He is the head of a three-member squad set up to deal with truant, shoplifting or otherwise unmanageable children in Liverpool. He is the central figure in a moving and distressing documentary, "Juvenile Liaison," being shown at the Film Forum, 15 Vandam Street.It is a film that is far more intelligent than its viewpoint. This, in a documentary, is praise: It does not restrict the viewer to its own conclusions.The viewpoint is clear enough. We see the sergeant, huge and menacing, cross-examine an 8-year-old Indian girl at her school. Her teachers say she has a consistent record of pilfering things from her schoolmates' bags and desks. Continually hinting that he can take her down to the police station if she doesn't tell the truth, he badgers her about an apple, about some missing pencils.It is a painful sight: This big, ugly man reducing a frail and lovely little girl to incoherence and tears. And yet she is, as it turns out, a liar and a thief. She has produced, around her, all kinds of small chaos, small injustices: She has embedded them in the minds of the children around her. They have lost apples and pencils, the little securities of childhood, and have found no recourse.The movie stresses the disproportion between the tiny miscreants and their large and strident pursuers. There is an immensely affecting scene where a policewoman snarls and scolds at a fat adolescent girl who has been shoplifting. She batters at her: Isn't she ashamed? Doesn't she think of her parents? Does she want a criminal record?' The great balloon of a girl sits stolidly and silently and then, as the buzz-saw voice goes on, tears squeeze from her eyes. And she admits, most touchingly, to one real ambition: She wants to be a prison warden. "Not a chance," the policewoman says.There are other, similar scenes. The film makers show the threat of brutality rather than real brutality, though at one point Sergeant Ray drags a 15-year-old boy  who has beaten his mother  out of bed by the hair.The intended message is that the youth squad is a blind and cruel response by society to its errant children. Sergeant Ray's explanation  that by making a show of firmness, by making it clear to the children what will happen if they don't reform, some are saved from later, serious involvement with the law  is treated as a rationalization.Maybe so. But as we watch these ill-prepared, harassed, unequipped, desperately tired officers go about their job, a troubling sympathy grows up for them. In these working-class, often fatherless homes, Sergeant Ray, coming from the same class, uses far more patience, far less violence than the fathers themselves might have used.The sergeant and his colleagues believe in what they are trying to do, even though they have no illusions about their success. They are medical corpsmen, sent out to treat the wounds of social dismemberment with splints.They are rough and sometimes mean, but they are also heroic. The film does not see the heroism, but it lets us see it. It sees the entrapment used by the police officers on the children; it lets us see the entrapment in which the officers find themselves.In the harshest scene, Sergeant Ray feigns to arrest a little boy and sits with him in a jail cell to show him what it is like. The film stresses the child's terror and the barbarity of the device. But what we really see is two people in jail  the boy and the policeman  companions in frustration and helplessness.

title: White Sox Drop Bid for Messersmith
description: SARASOTA, Fla., March 25 (UPI)  The Chicago White Sox have withdrawn their fouryear, $750,000 offer to the freeagent pitcher, Andy Messersmith, the club announced tonight.

title: Israel Reports Arab Died After Beating
description: JERUSALEM, March 25A 34yearold Arab from Hebron who was severely beaten by Israeli soldiers during a demonstration there yesterday has died of his injuries in Hadassah Hospital here, according to a communiqu tonight by the army spokesman's office.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: BEAME PROPOSES NEW BUDGET CUTS ENDING 8,000 JOBS
description: Mayor Beame yesterday proposed a new $821 million budgetcutting plan calling for further service reductions, the elimination of 8,000 more jobs and the controversial shifting of more than $250 million in education and court costs from the city to the state.

title: Jews of Charleston Look Fondly Upon the Past
description: CHARLESTON, S. C.  Reform Judaism recently issued its first revised prayer book in half a century, but there was little notice of it here in the synagogue that refers to itself as the cradle of reformed Judaism, and, according to its rabbi, even less interest in using it.

title: Trading in Doom
description: WASHINGTONThirty years ago, when Hiroshima and Nagasaki were freshly imprinted on the mind of a warweary world, Bernard Baruch presented the United Nations with our nation's plan for peacefully harnessing the atom. We are here to make a choice between the quick and the dead, he admonished. That is our business.

title: Memorial Services
description: GLASSLlillan. Memorial services will be held on Sunday, March 28, 12 noon, at Weiss & Son Funeral Home, Prince St. and Northern Blvd., Flushing, Queens.

title: Diamond Figueroa's Battlefield
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, FN., March 25Life with the marines in Vietnam, Ed Figueroa has found in the last year, was safer than life in American baseball parks.

title: WNBC Schedules a TV Special In Response to Critics on Gas
description: WNBCTV has scheduled 90minute news special, The Great Gasoline Debate, on Saturday, April 3, as a followup to its controversial fivepart series on the oil industry broadcast last month on Newscenter 4, the evening newscast.

title: Japan's Reading Craze At a Peak in Recession
description: TOKYO, March 25  The aisles were crammed with bodies struggling to move in the crush. Occasionally a door opened to admit fresh air. But anyone leaving was replaced quickly.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two men charged with discharging hazardous asbestos particles into the air when they demolished a Kearny factory pleaded not guilty to the charges in Federal District Court in Newark. The men, Vernon E. Chevalier Jr. and George Collins, affiliated with the D. and V. Wrecking Corporation of Sayreville, entered their pleas before Judge H. Curtis Meanor.

title: 4 African Leaders End Zambia Talks On RhodesiaCrisis
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, March 25 (UPI)  Four black African Presidents ended their meeting on Rhodesia today without any hint whether guerrilla warfare against Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's white minority Government will be stepped up.

title: Saigon Rationing Gasoline; Black Market Is a Target
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 25 (Agence FrancePresseThe authorities have imposed gasoline rationing in the Saigon region.

title: TV: Camera Three Offering Anatomy of a Song
description: Camera Three, CBSTV's Sundaymorning oasis of consistent imagination, takes Stephen Sondheim this weekend through a marvelous little essay called Anatomy of a Song. As the composer of Company, Follies and A Litttle Night Music, (and as lyricist for West Side Story and Gypsy"), Mr. Sondheim has securely established himself as the most outstanding composer in the contemporary musical theater.

title: House Panel Bars Subpoena on Banks
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)The House Government, Operations Committee hacked; away today from a confrontation with the banking industry by rejecting an appeal for a subpoena to obtain Federal regulatory records on two large New York banks.

title: Mothers March to Protest Elimination of 9 Crossing Guards in South Orange
description: SOUTH ORANGE, March 25  More than 100 mothers and children demonstrated at Police Headquarters today to protest the elimination of nine school crossing guards.

title: Franjieh Abandons Palace In Lebanon After Shelling
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 25 President Suleiman Franjieh was forced to abandon the Presidential Palace/overlooking Beirut today after it was hit by heavy artillery. He took refuge in a Christian stronghold 13 miles north of the capital.

title: S.I.C. Says City's Prosecutors Improperly Disclose Information
description: The State Investigation Commission blamed prosecutors offices in New York City yesterday for a substantial percentage of improper disclosures of information on grand jury investigations.

title: City U. Plan to End Major Study In Languartes Evokes Protests
description: The proposed elimination of major programs in foreign languages except Spanish at some of the City University's senior colleges would deprive students of needed communication skills and cultural experience, supporters of language study at the university asserted yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The State Consumer Protection Board heard testimony from more than 20 witnesses about ways to improve landlordtenant relations. The allday hearing, at 270 Broadway, was the fourth held by the board on the subject. Most of the witnesses suggested changes in the standard lease used by most New York City landlords, which would strengthen tenants rights and make the language more comprehensible to the layman. The board plans to make recommendations to the Legislature within 60 days.

title: Reserve Report
description: Reserve Report

title: Kissinger and 3 Senators Meet on Egypt Arms Issue
description: WASHINGTON, March 25Secretary of State Henry A.1 Kissinger and three Senators have become engaged in negotiations to see whether a formula can be found to avoid a clash between the Ford Administration and Congress over the lifting of the military embargo against Egypt.

title: Killer Who Claimed ?? To Hang for Two Others
description: BOISE, Idaho, Match 25 (UPI)Thomas Creech, who contended during his trial that he had killed 42 persons, was sentenced today to die by hanging for two slayings that he insisted he did not commit.

title: Sydenham's Demise Is Result of Age And Deterioration of City's Economy
description: Sydenham Hospital, in a more favorable fiscal climate, might have been patched up and saved in order to keep the municipal hospital system intact.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $1.1 billion, up 6 percent from the yearearlier $1.04 billion. Retail store sales totaled $12.5 billion, up 14 percent from $10.1 billion. adjusted rate of 3.4 percentsomewhat below the 4.5 percent  to  7.5 percent range sought for the year between the end of 1975 and the end of 1976.

title: Chileans Arrest A Radio Executive And Plan His Exile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 25 (AP)Chile's military Government said today that it had arrested the gerreral manager of a radio station and would exile him to a remote community near the Peruvian, border.

title: Theater
description: In Acrobatics, two old friends, both having recently ended affairs with men, meet after a long absence. The girl, played by Joyce Aaron, is impulsive and is negligent about her personal appearance. The woman, played by Jacqueline Barnett, is apparently less given to whim. She is more attractive, although severe in manner.

title: Hopes of Hornell Riding On Chessie Buying Erie
description: Continued From Page 37 sity of jobs has been emphasized and completion of the Southern Tier Expressway, the first major highway linking the remote communities in this northern Appalachian region with other areas of the state, is expected soon.

title: Toronto to A.L.
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 25 (UPI)The American League will expand to 14 teams tomorrow with Toronto being awarded a franchise for the 1977 season, it has been learned. The action by the American League will mean it has beaten the National League to the Canadian city after both leagues announced their intention establishing franchises in Toronto during a meeting last Saturday in New York. A Seattle team will also be added next season in the American League.

title: 37 JUDGES JOIN SUIT FOR A PAY INCREASE.
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)  Thirtyseven Federal judges today joined the suit of 44 other judges seeking a 34.5 percent costofliving salary increase.

title: U.S. IS REVIEWING ITS CUBA OPTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The Ford Administration announced today that contingency plans for possible moves against Cuba were being reviewed, but it seemed clear from the comments of several officials that there was no urgency about the review, which was reported to have begun several weeks ago.

title: British Labor Party's Race Is Narrowed to Three Men
description: LONDON, March 25The sixman contest to succeed Harold Wilson as Britain's Prime Mininster turned unexpectedly tonight into a struggle involving only three  Michael Foot, James Callaghan and Denis Healey.

title: 5,000 March in Harlem Against Hospital Closing
description: More than 5,000 demonstrators marched along 125th Street yesterday in an orderly protest against the scheduled closing of Sydenham Hospital, a small municipal hospital that has become a symbol of organized resistance to fiscal cutbacks that community leaders feel are disproportionately affecting blacks and the poor in areas like Harlem.

title: About Real Estate
description: In the heart of brownstone country on the upper West Side of Manhattan, brownstone renewal has become fairly exclusively a professional's game, those close to the situation say.

title: Reilly Wins Retrial in Mother's Slaying
description: LITCHFIELD, Cont., March 25Peter A. Reilly was granted a new trial here today by a Superior Court judge who ruled that his conviction on charges of killing his mother two and a half years ago represented a grave injustice.

title: T.W.U. MAY ACCEPT A RAISE DEFERRAL
description: Matthew Guinan, president of the Transport Workers Union, said yesterday that he might be willing to agree to defer part of a raise for his 34,000 members if they got some money now.

description: Dividends

title: Banks Keep LoanLoss Defense Built Up
description: The nation's banking industry probably will continue to make substantial provisions for loan losses during 1976, according to Walter B. Wriston, chairman of Citibank.

title: JERSEY TO STUDY BUS OWNERSHIP
description: TRENTON, March 25Alan Sagner, the State Commissioner of Transportation, said today that a study of commuter bus service would begin soon to determine if the state should own the buses or they should be operated by private carriers.

title: Braves Trounce Cavaliers
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, March 25 (UPI)Bob McAdoo, Jim McMillian and Randy Smith combined for 86 points, including 28 in the fourth period, to spark the Buffalo Braves to a 10994 National Basketball Association victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers here tonight.

title: About the Yankees Yankees.
description: Thurman Munson, it was learned, received a fouryear contract valued at close to the $600,000 Catfish Hunter will receive over the next four seasons. However, Munson's salary in his fourth year will significantly surpass Huntets $150,000. The contract is also the nocut type, which means the catcher will be paid even if he is hurt during the length of the agreement. Munson was scheduled to play in the game against Atlanta but came up with a jammed finger on his throwing hand. Willie Randolph suffered bloody nose when hit by a ground ball in practice. The Braves B team won the game when Ed Brinkman, playing third, made two errors on Tom Paciorek's sacrifice bunt. First Brinkman bobbled the ball, then threw wild to first, allowing Dave May to score. Roy White doubled home the Yankee run. Dick Tidrow signed his contract, leav

title: High Court Upholds Board On Shorter School Week
description: ALBANY, March 25The state's highest court today unanimously upheld the right of the New York City Board of Education to shorten the school week by two 45minute preparation periods as part of the settlement of a teachers strike last September.

description: Article 2  No Title

title: Business Briefs
description: United States industry operated at 73.5 percent capacity during February, the same rate as in January, according to the McGrawHill Publications Company. The figure, however, was 3.5 percentage points above that for February 1975, the company's economics department said yesterday.

title: Naval Hangar Collapses
description: CORONADO, Calif., March 23 (AP)An aircraft hangar construction collapsed today at North Island Naval Station, a spokesman said. Five civilian workmen were injured, one severely, he added. The hangar on the tip of Coronado Island across San Diego Bay was an estimated 100 yards long. It was being built to hold the Navy's S3A antisubmarine warfare planes.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The United States last night vetoed a resolution in the Security Council of the United Nations deploring Israeli policies in Jerusalem and the occupied areas on the West Bank of the Jordan River. The 141 vote ended a debate that began Monday on antiIsraeli unrest in Jerusalem and West Bank towns. [Page 1, Column 4.]

title: Music
description: Leonard Bernstein was among the first to make the symphonies of Mahler as populer as those of Brahms and Beethoven, but he has not paid as much attention to the music of the symphonist many believe to be Mahler's peer. That symphonist is, of course, Anton Bruckner.

title: Josef Albers, Artist and Teacher, Dies
description: Josef Albers, the artist, who was also worldrenowned as a teacher of art and as a color theorist, died early Thursday morning in his sleep at the YaleNew Haven Hospital. He was 88 years old and had been in the hospital for observation of a possible heart ailment.

title: Nastase Advances With Usual Ploys
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 25Ilie Nastase tore up another opponent today with his tennis tantrums as he beat Dick Stockton, 36, 60, 76, and reached the quarterfinals of the $200,000 American Airlines Tennis Games along with Jimmy Connors and Arthur Ashe, who are seeded first and second respectively.

title: Civil Libertarian Building Dossier on F. B. I.
description: PRINCETON, March 25Prof. H. H. Wilson has given an undergraduate course on civil liberties for nearly two decades at Princeton University, occasionally under the scrutiny of an agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Now he is compiling heretofore secret F.B.I. files on academicians, government officials, people in the arts, and others.

title: PentUp Demand Is Cited In a Survey of Consumers

title: U.S. STUDIES TAX OF 12 INDUSTRIES
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The Treasury Department has under way studies aimed at modernizing and liberalizing the deductions for depreciation used by a dozen industries, it was learned today.

title: State's and Banks Lawyers Try to Work Out Solutions to Problems of Spring Borrowing
description: ALBANY, March 25Lawyers for the state and the major New York City banks are struggling to resolve a broad range of legal problems so they can produce a prospectus for the state's spring borrowing by this weekend, officials said today.

title: Study Disputes Data on Girls Puberty
description: Middleclass American girls are no longer reaching sexual maturity at a younger and younger age, according to a 10year study of 781 girls in a Boston suburb. The findings contradict prevailing concepts about the growth and sexual development of women.

title: About New York
description: The artgallery opening with its watery punch and elbowtoelbow crowds, is a New York institution. Few people use the occasion as an opportunity for dedicated connoisseurship. Most are content to chat with friends, while promising themselves that they will return for a second look when the gallery is quieter.

title: Murphy Leads Heritage Golf With a 66
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., March 25Bob Murphy lost it at the movies, it being a crazy pull shot that had cost him strokes, money and selfesteem. A fivehour practice session in which a friend took stopaction motion pictures revealed the causes, a lefthand grip that was too strong and an address that was too open.

title: Wrestler's Chin Withstands Ali's Lip
description: When a world heavyweight boxing champion meets a Japanese heavyweight wrestling champion, can the boxer wrestle and can the wrestler box?

title: Flyers Top Rangers, Set Record
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 25 (AP)Andre Dupont, a defenseman, blasted a low 20footer into the net to break a 11 tie and propel the Philadelphia Flyers to a 41 National Hockey League victory over the New York Rangers here tonight.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Aqueduct Race Charts

title: Hornell's Hopes Ride on Chessie Purchasing the Erie, but Outlook Is Bleak
description: HORNELL, N. Y., March 25Railroad tracks cutting through the center of town, and the long trains that frequently use them, may annoy people in some places. But in this remote southwestern New York community, the sight and sound of trains creeping through at all hours of the day and night have been comforting for decades.

title: New Exxon Policy Bars Gifts to Political Groups
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday in its 1975 annual report that the corporation had adopted a policy prohibiting contributions to political parties even when such contributions are legal.

title: Subway Ridership Levels Linked to City's Economy
description: The Transit Authority, now engaged in critical labor negotiations, made available yesterday data indicating that economic and social factorsand not fare increaseswere paramount in falling ridership on the city's subways.

title: Experts Question Inflation Drop
description: In much of the United States, spring is a fantasy in Marcha few warm days, few warm thoughts, and then the cold winter winds return. This March, the economy was fantastic. An endless chain of good news poured out of Washington. But the best news of allthe dramatic drop in the nation's inflation rate  may prove fantasy, analysts say. The United States does not appear to be in for any early return to doubledigit inflation after the virtual price stability reported this month. The Consumer Price Index for February rose at a scant 1.2 percent annual rate, down from 4.4 percent the previous three months and 9.2 percent last year.

title: Joseph Aronson, Architect And Industrial Desginer, 77
description: Joseph Aronson, an architect and industrial designer, who also designed interiors and furniture, died yesterday during a visit to Rome. He was 77 years old and lived in Totvnsend Hollow. Pine Hill. N.Y.

title: I.R.S. Says Corporations May Face Bribery Actions
description: Donald C. Alexander, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, said yesterday that legal action may soon be taken against one or more corporations that have made political payoffs or bribes.

title: Maine Potatoes Rise Daily Limit Again
description: Prices of Maine potatoes for future delivery rose the daily limit of 50 cents a hundred pounds again yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. It was the fourth limit advance in the last five sessions.

title: Concert
description: The Queens College music department has a distinguished faculty in the creative and performing fields, and on Wednesday night its members crossed the East River to celebrate the Bicentennial with a concert in Alice Tully Hall. On display were works by four composers who have taught or are teaching at the school, the late Karol Rathaus, Leo Kraft, Hugo Weisgall and George. Perle. These and other pieces were performed by faculty members and students in a pleasant academic family affair.

title: Music: Milton Babbitt
description: Milton Babbitt, a man whose prestige and power in the music world are considerable, will be 60 years old May 10, and on Wednesday night the Performers Committee for 20thCentury Music presented a retrospective concert of his compositions at Columbia University's McMillin Theater.

title: Recital
description: Irma Rogell, who gave a harpsichord recital at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night, proved to be a somewhat unconventional performer, a point usually in an artist's favor from this listener's viewpoint. She was not afraid to play from the scores, for example, in a day when prodigies of memory are standard concert fare. She dared to step to the lip of the stage to chide a noisy cougher at one point (the wrong person, but no matter). And she was quick to raise a finger and begin a piece over again when she realized she had neglected to change registration.

title: FRANCIS TYNG DIES; WRITER AND EDITOR
description: Francis Edmonds Tyng, assistant editor of The Journal of Commerce since 1965, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital, Summit, N.J., after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived at 27 Argyle Court, Summit.

title: PROTEST DISRUPTS DRUG CONFERENCE
description: Three hundred black and Puerto Rican workers from New York City drugtreatment facilities yesterday disrupted a national conference on drug abuse held by 3,000 physicians, lawyers, social workers and others.

title: Europe Turns Clock But Daylight Time Causes Some Gloom
description: LONDON, March 26 (AP)Europe is trying to save daylight time, but the experiment is producing only gloom among travel agents and tourists scrambling to coordinate time tables.

title: Richard Milhous Congress
description: Has it been duly observed that the House of Representatives, having expunged Richard Nixon to save the Republic, is now showing macabre symptoms of Nixon envy? The most telling evidence is the House's recent decision to set up its own plumbers squad, the very device which first set the master's foot on the path down Watergate Lane.

title: Top Experts Helping Guide Candidates Foreign Views
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Foreign policy advisers are a standard feature of Presidential campaigns. While the candidates change, the advisers stay just about the same.

title: FORD SCORES PLAN FOR DEFENSE CUTS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 President Ford declared here today that he would not play Russian roulette with national security by allowing Congressional Democrats to cut his military spending request.

title: ANGOLA ASKING GULF TO RESUME OIL FLOW
description: LUANDA, Angola, March 26 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Angolan Government has asked the Gulf Oil Corporation to resume petroleum production in the enclave of Cabinda immediately, without waiting for the end of negotiations with it on a new contract, the Jonnal de Angola reported here today.

title: Eric Siday, 71, Moog Composer Who Wrote Pepsi Jingle, Dead
description: Eric Siday, a composer of electronic music and such jingles as PepsiCola hits the spot died Thursday of a heart attack in his home at 390 West End Avenue. He was 71 years old.

title: 3 New York Appearances Are Planned by Humphrey
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)Senator Hubert H. Humphrey will be making at least three appearances in New York next week, but his Washington office said that should not be viewed as an attempt to get primary votes in the state.

title: HELP ON TEXTILES PLEDGED BY FORD
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 (UPI)President Ford said today that he would help keep the United States textile and clothing industry thriving in the face of foreign import competition.

title: Susan Coyle Is Bride of Donald F. Daly
description: The marriage of Susan Schladermundt Coyle to Donald Francis Daly, a vice president of Scudder, Stevens & Clark Inc., investment counsel, took place here yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Lee Belford performed the Ceremony in the chapel of the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany.

title: U.C.L.A. Is Gene Bartow's Team Now
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 26In the U.C.L.A. athletic offices last Saturday, about three dozen people were watching the IndianaMarquette game on television. Suddenly a player took an awkward shot that missed badly.

title: Inventor's New Wrench Has Speed That Varies
description: WASHINGTON, March 26One of the 1,400 inventions that were patented this week is notable for several reasons. For one thing, it is neither complex nor electronic; it is a simple mechanical device. And for another it has, according to a market estimate, about seven million potential buyers. Charles E. Annett 2d of Mantoloking, NJ., a professional engineer, was granted Patent 3,945,274 for his speed wrench. It runs up a loose nut or bolt seven times as fast as the handle is turned until the nut or bolt gets relatively tight, when the ratio goes back to normal.

title: Current Historiographical Modes, Obfuscatory in Nature, Manifest an Indifference To Quintessential Elements of Meaningfulness
description: Recent lapses in the language and methods of American historians are disquieting to those of us concerned with the future of historical scholarship.

title: Starving Baby Whale Dies
description: BOSTON, March 26 (AP) A baby sperm whale, found starving off the coast of Maine on Monday, died this morning at New England Aquarium despite efforts of a team of specialists to keep it alive.

title: Visitors From France Help Celebrate On a Revolutionary Site in Hartsdale
description: HARTSDALE, N.Y., March 26The remnants of a band of holders of the French Legion of Honor Medal succeeded today in reaching this hilly Westchester county suburb to commemorate the restoration of Odell House, General Rochambeau's headquarters during the American Revolution.

title: Congressional Vote Subsidy Bill Softened to Win More Backing
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Backers of Federal subsidies Ifor Congressional as well as Presidential candidates have softened the proposal they will present on the House floor next week in an effort to attract more support.

title: Board of G.E. Approves Utah International Deal
description: A $2 billion merger of General Electric Company and Utah International Inc. moved a step closer to completion yesterday with a vote of approval by the board of General Electric. The board of Utah International announced a similar action March 15. Agreements for execution of the merger, the largest ever, are expected to be completed in April. But still pending is the approval of the share owners of both companies and by Government agencies.

title: U.S. Invites Talks With Hanoi, Says It Hopes for Normal Ties
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Ford Administration has delivered a message to the North Vietnamese inviting discussion of all issues related to Vietnam that it says it hopes will lead to the eventual normalization of relations between the two nations.

title: Giscard's Moves Hint Tilt to the Right
description: PARIS, March 26Political and economic setbacks in the last two weeks, compounded by a mounting wave of strokes, have forced President Valry Giscard d'Estaing's Government to make a basic reappraisal of its political strategy.

title: Argentine Farmers Watch Political Weather Hopefully
description: JESUS MARIA, Argentina, March 26Farmers are usually the most contented group when la military coup takes place in Argentina and this week's overthrow of the Peronist Government has not proved to be an exception.

title: Moslems Insist Fran jieh Quit Before a CeaseFire
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, March 27Moslem leaders insisted yesterday that there could be no ceasefire in the Lebanese civil war unless their Christian opponents agreed to sweeping constitutional changes and the immediate unconditional resignation of President Suleiman Franjieh, a Christian.

title: McTear Triumphs In Florida Sprint
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., March 26 (UPI)  Houston McTear won the 100meter event at the Florida Relays today, but the Baker High School sprinter's time was a disappointing 10.3 seconds.

title: U.S. Is Said to Plan a New Approach on Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Ford Administration is planning a thorough revision of its program for dealing with international terrorism, including consideration of more flexibility on ransom lemands, Government officials have reported.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WAVE FROM THE TOP: Senator Henry M. Jackson acknowledged greetings from wellwishers while visiting World Trade Center yesterday. Article on Jackson's day, page

title: BRANIFF CONFIRMS I.R.S. INVESTIGATION
description: DALLAS, March 26 (UPI)A Braniff Airlines spokesman said today that the company was being investigated by the Internal Revenue Service, but would not speculate whether the investigation was connected with illegal political contributions and illegal rebates in Latin America.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Weak ended March 26, 1976

title: Potatoes Up Again; Week's Rise Is 13%
description: For the fifth time in six sessions, Maine potatoes for delivery in May rose yesterday by the maximum allowed on the New York Merchantile Exchange.

title: Witnesses Oppose the Closing Of Sydenham and Gouverneur
description: Before an audience that often shouted, stamped, cheered and whistled its approval, dozens of speakers testified strongly yesterday against the closing of two municipal hospitalsSydenham in Harlem and Gouverneur on the Lower East Side.

title: DOW AND YUGOSLAVS SIGN A RECORD DEAL
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 26 (UPI)The Dow Chemical Company and a Yugoslav company signed a final agreement today for the joint construction and operation of a $700 million petrochemical complex that United States officials said marked the biggest American investment in Yugoslavia.

title: Gibson Cites Symphony Hall Effort
description: NEWARK, March 26The New Jersey State Opera's company paused today during a rehearsal of Donizetti's L'Elisir d'Amore to hear a proclamation of Cultural Revitalization Day from Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson.

title: MOVEMENT SEEN IN TRANSIT TALKS
description: Transit officials close to the current contract negotiations are now saying privately that 34,000 bus and subway workers might be able to get a costofliving raise if the Transit Authority can finance it through productivity gains.

title: Assets at $3.65 Billion For Money Market Funds
description: Total assets of money market funds last month were $3.65 billion, compared with $3.7 billion in January, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. In February 1975, assets of these funds amounted to $2.53 billion.

description: tions will supervise that, he added.

title: Art: Masters of American Impressionism
description: American Impressionism is (quite literally) a sticky business. Sometimes and in some hands the allover flicker of the paint gets within waving distance of the great French precursors and initiators. Sometimes the work stays at the bottom of the heap with Finnish Impressionism, Italian Impressionism, Turkish Impressonism. And then it often happens that the work advanced as Impressionist does not merit the adjective at all, any more than a badger merits the adjective outspoken.

title: Paris Scores Soviet on Ship
description: PARIS, March 26 (Reuters)France has protested to the Soviet Union about a Soviet spy ship off the Atlantic port of Brest where the French nuclear submarine fleet is based, a navy spokesman said today.

title: 2 in LeGrand Family Held in Slaying of 2 Men in 1974
description: A son and a stepson of Devernon LeGrand, the selfstyled head of a Brooklyn church, were arrested yesterday on charges of murdering two men in February 1974.

title: U.S. AND TURKEY REACH AN ACCORD ON BASES AND AID
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The United States and Turkey reached agreement today on a new fouryear accord that will allow American military installations to reopen in Turkey In return for a pledge of about a billion dollars in American grants and loans.

description: Television

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: An indictment against Edward Dwyer, 28 years old, New Egypt, in connection with the death of William Wheeler at Fort Dix on July 11, 1974, was dismissed in Trenton by Federal Judge George H. Barlow. The indictment had said that the two men, both civilians, were driving through the military reservation without authority and were halted by a squad of basic trainees led by a sergeant. When the soldiers tried to stop the car, Mr. Dwyer jerked the wheel and drove into a tree, causing Mr. Wheeler's death, the charges had said. Mr. Dwyer's lawyer had charged that Mr. Wheeler died from a beating by the soldiers. The indictment was based on testimony by the soldiers involved.

title: U.S. AND TURKEY REACH AN ACCORD ON BASES AND AID
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The United States and Turkey reached agreement today on a new fouryear accord that will allow American military installations to reopen in Turkey in return for a pledge of about a billion dollars in American grants and loans.

title: Amex and OTC Stock Prices Rise a Bit in Moderate Trading
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market posted small gains yesterday in moderate trading.

title: CANDIDATES NAMED FOR BOOK AWARDS
description: Books in six categories have been nominated for the National Book Awards. The winners will be announced April 19 by the National Institute of Arts and Letters, which has taken over sponsorship of the awards. The nominees are:

title: to What End?
description: One serious flaw in all of the efforts to revitalize the economies of New York City and State has been the narrow focus of the individuals and agencies involved. The stress has been entirely on attracting and holding industryany industry at almost any price, just so long as it produces jobs.

title: NIGHT WATCH GOES BACK ON EXHIBITION
description: AMSTERDAM, March 26 (AP)Rembrandt's The Night Watch went back on display today after six months of careful restoration to repair damage Inflicted on the painting by a man wielding a bread knife. in an inchbyinch process calling for such concentration that he and his helpers could sometimes work only 15 minutes at at time.

title: Late Rally by Islanders Overcomes Seals, 32
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 26Thirdperiod goals by Billy MacMillan and Ed Westfall gave the New York Islanders a hardearned 32 victory over the California Golden Seals tonight and kept them only 2 points behind Buffalo in their struggle for the homeive advantage in the National Hockey League playoffs.

title: Udall, in Wisconsin, Criticizes Carter On Parity Views
description: MILWAUKEE, March 26Representative Morris K. Udall tried today to widen a possible crack in the political armor of Jimmy Carter, one of his rival candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: U.S. AND INDIA TALK OF JOINT VENTURES
description: NEW DELHI, March 26India and the United States have discussed joint business ventures in third countries, according to a communiqu issued here today at the end of two days of talks between officials of the two countries.

title: Greenwood Is Hub of U.C.L.A. Success
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 26 In the beginning there was Indiana, slapping U.C.L.A. around like a sparring partner. Kent Benson pounded away at the Bruins middle, raising welts. Scott May jabbed at them from the outside, opening cuts. It was the opening game of the season for both teams, and it was a technical knockout: Indiana 84. U.C.L.A. 64.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Despite therapy and theories, according to the Veterans Administration in Newark, obstacles to job placement are phenomenal for handicapped veterans of the Vietnam War.
