title: Amex Is Studying Trading In the Shares of Presley
description: The American Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that it was studying trading patterns in the stock of the Presley Companies, a California homebuilder licensed to produce a hydrogen converter.

title: MOVEMENT SEEN IN TRANSIT TALKS
description: Transit officials close to the current contract negotiations are now saying privately that 34,000 bus and subway workers might be able to get a costofliving raise, if the Transit Authority can finance it through productivity gains.

title: Democratic Leaders of State Senate Hope for More From an Income Tax
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, March 26  State Senate Democratic leaders sought ways today to squeeze additional millions of dollars from a state income tax if it became law. A tax package was passed by the Assembly last week and is expected to come before the Senate early next week.

title: Argentina Rulers Name Videla Junta President
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 26Lieut. Gen. Jorge Rafael Videla, Commander in Chief of the army, has been chosen president of the Argentine military junta, whose members will serve for three years, a communique said today.

title: Pacific Islanders Sentenced
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, March 26 (UPI)Seven Pacific Islanders were sentenced today to 14 years imprisonment each for their roles in a 12day drama last December in which a number of hostages were held aboard a train and three men killed. The episode was intended to publicize an eff6rt to gain independence for the South Moluccas, a group of islands in the Pacific ruled by Indonesia. They sought a commitment from the Netherlands, Indonesia's former colonial ruler, to begin a diplomatic campaign for the islands independence.

title: Grand Prix Rolls Out West to Long Beach
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., March 26At 12:48 this afternoon in front of the Thomas Cook Travel Agency, an Italian grand prix driver took an unscheduled Cook's tour of Ocean Boulevard in the downtoirn area. He came to rest safely in front of a 31story, condominium,

title: News Summary and Index
description: The United States and Turkey reached an agreement yesterday on a fouryear accord under which American military installations would be reopened in Turkey in return for a pledge of about a billion in American grants and loansabout $250 million yearly, most of it in military assistance. The accord would entirely end the American embargo on militiry aid to Turkey that followed Turkey's invasion of Cyprus in 1974, but its approval by Congress is uncertain because of concern over Turkey's lagging efforts to end the Cyprus crisis. The embargo was eased by Congress last October and it was then that the TurkishAmerican talks were begun. They ended with the agreement signed at the State Department by Secretary or State Henry A. Kissinger, and Turkey's Foreign Minister, Ihsan S. Caglayangil. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: If It Moves, Salute It
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.When the aide, stationed in the back, announced, Gentlemen, the Commanding General, the brigade and battalion commanders snapped to attention.

title: But Politics Still Fires the Electorate in Bay Ridge
description: It is the fashion these days in New York to say that politicians are corrupt and politics is futile. The citizens of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, however, one of the few Republican strongholds in New York City, seldom follow the fashions of the time.

title: Village Voters Passion Is Gone
description: The other day, when Greenwich Village was bright with March and afternoon, a young man slouched atop a tower in Abingdon Square's little playground, reading a newspaper.

title: London Ritz Is Sold; New Owners Pledge To Retain Elegance
description: LONDON, March 26The luxurious Ritz Hotel, an elegant landmark on Piccadilly, is to be taken over by the financial and business conglomerate that owns the liner Queen Elizabeth 2, it was announced here today.

title: Opinions On Safety Of Center
description: Is it safe for a woman to give birth in such an untraditional setting as the Childbearing Center?

title: The Screen: 'Sky Riders':Hang Gliders Offer Film's Only Merit
description: Hang gliders are pieces of fabric stretched over a frame. Properly manipulated they travel for miles on the air currents, giving the person hanging beneath the sensation of pure birdlike flight.The hang gliders in this movie fly as beautifully as swallows, but why use swallows to carry concrete?The money spent on "Sky Riders," which opened yesterday at the RKO 86th Street Twin Two, has obviously gone on the gliding, the photography and the stunning backdrop of the Greek coast. Judging from the results, the scriptwriters and the actors seem to have worked for next to nothing.The movie is about an American industrialist whose wife and children are kidnapped from their Athens home by a gang of political terrorists. They are taken to an abandoned monastery on a needle-shape crag.The police can do nothing, but the wife's first husband, played by James Coburn, can. Pondering the problem, he sees a couple of crows flying overhead. His eyes widen, his nostrils dilate.He finds a flying circus of hang glider riders. In just two or three days they teach him to glide, and he teaches them to fight. On a night of the full moon, they swoop in, and the moonlit swooping is authentic, difficult and lovely.There is enough shooting for two civil wars, and the terroristswho wear red T-shirts with terrorist insignia on them  are eventually chomped up. But nothing has happened to make us care much, one way or the other.The dialogue, the motivations, the politics are cardboard. The acting is unalloyed lead. After the flying, "Sky Riders" is one long, boring crash; as well as vice versa.

title: Italy's Communists Deny They Get Aid From the East Bloc
description: ROME, March 26The Italian Communist Party today described as false and ridiculous reports that it continues to receive financial aid from the Soviet Union and other East European countries.

title: Long Lines Show Why Lady Is a Champ
description: A warm, witty grande dame called My Fair Lady was back or Broadway yesterday, evoking memories of her heyday in the 1950's and basking in the splendor of new rave reviews.

title: Toronto Is Given A.L. Franchise
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 26 (AP)The American League made Toronto its 14th franchise today. It awarded the Canadian city a team for the 1977 season at a price of $7 million to its purchaser, Labatt's Brewerids.

title: Joffrey Hails Jooss With Ballet Quartet
description: The special revival of a quarter of ballets by Kurt Jossthat archetypal Jooss programThe Big City, Pavanne on the Death of an Infanta, A Ball in Old Vienna and The Green Tableis a unit program that the City Center Joffrey ballet has devised to celebrate and honor the choreographer's 75th birthday. However, the works do exist in the repertory with perfect validity outside the formal framework of an allJoost program.

title: Marcor Accepts New Mobil Merger Bid
description: The offagain onagain merger of the Mobil Oil Corporation and Marcor Inc. is on again as both companies announced today they had reached an agreement in principle for the acquisition of the retailing and packaging concern by the nation's third largest oil company.

title: GOVERNOR LAUDS BEAME'S EFFORT TO TRIM BUDGET
description: Commending Mayor Beame for his effort in devising anew, $821 million plan for cutting the city's budget, Governor Carey agreed yesterday to negotiate with him on a controversial proposal to shift sizable court and highereducation costs from the city to the state in the 197778 fiscal year.

title: Notes on. People
description: With about half the cast of A Chorus Line to be replaced April 26, Donna McKechnie, the lead dancer since the musical originally opened downtown, will be succeeded in the role by Ann Reinking, formerly of Pippin. Miss McKechnie and two other Tony Award nominees from the show, Bob Lupone and Sammy Williams, will be among 15 cast members going to San Francisco to join the new national company. Michael Bennett, the directorchoreographer, is rehearsing 60 members of the national and international companiesas well as replacements for New Yorkat the City Center after having viewed some 4,000 aspirants in this country and Canada.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was reported incorrectly in The New York Times yesterday that David C. Farrell would succeed Robert J. Suslow as president and chief operating officer of the May Department Stores Company. Mr. Farrell is currently president and chief operating officer and will continue in those posts. Mr. Suslow, who is president of the FamousBarr Company, a division of May, will become president of Saks Fifth Avenue on June I,

title: Article 3  No Title
description: THREE KILLED AT COLORADO SKI RESORT: Passenger being lowered from one of two gondolas that collided after two others fell more than 100 feet at Vail yesterday. The entire system was shut down, leaving some skiers trapped. Details, Page 54.

title: No Revolution Planned by 3 Top Reds
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 26At one point during the baseball negotiations, the owners representatives suggested that certain free agent movements would be disastrous for baseball. What would happen, they said for example, if Johnny Bench, Pete Rose and Joe Morgan would play out their options and move en masse to another team?

title: Nuclear Cost Expected To Stay Less Than
description: For the foreseeable future, nuclear power is expected to continue to be 10 to 40 percent cheaper to produce than power from coal, depending on the region, the president of the Edison Electric Institute said yesterday. He made this assertion in releasing a twovolume study pointing to Government inaction as the chief roadblock to resolving uncertainties about the nation's nuclear fuel supply and demand.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your March 10 editorials Government Oilmen vs. OPEC might benefit from an injection of realism and a wider perspective. While the idea of stockpiling undoubtedly is valid, though costly, it could bring unhappy results from unfulfilled expectations. You infer that because of the volume involved (one billion barrels) in stockpiling and a buyer's market there could be a lowering in the price of foreign oil on such a governmenttogovernment deal, leading to price cutting and hastening the demise of OPEC. This is raising a largely false hope for several inescapable reasons.

title: Beame Plans Post Of Operations Chief
description: Mayor Beame will create the post of chief of operations at the Deputy Mayor level in the immediate future, sources in the Mayor's office said last night.

title: FEBRUARY SHOWS TRADE IMBALANCE
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The United States balance of exportimport trade registered a moderate deficit in February for the second consecutive month after large surpluses in 1975, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Principal Present as Long Island City Classes Resume
description: Classes resumed yesterday morning at Long Island City High School in the presence of Dr. Howard L. Hurwitz, the school's suspended principal, after a compromise ended a threeday boycott by Queens parents and students.

title: Inside Cambodia
description: Cambodia's new Constitution and its election of a People's Representative Assembly are designed to convey the impression at home and abroad of a government of law. But they leave the country unchanged from the vast slave labor camp into which it has been shaped by its fanatical Communist leaders.

title: New Childbirth Center: Baby Born in Morning Was Home by Evening
description: Adam Sean Walsh Fitzpatrick was born at 11:22 A.M. Monday in the Childbearing Center at 48 East 92d Street.

title: ARABS SEE GAINS DESPITE U.S. VETO
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 26Arab delegates said today that although the United States vetoed a draft resolution in the Security Council last night that would have censured Israel, their cause had won a moral victory and the Palestine Liberation Organization had gained new ground.

title: Market Place
description: One hardtoswallow fact of life the stock market has had to absorb over the last couple of years is that computer stocks are no more immune to selloffs than any other issue.

title: No Stavisky Override
description: Last December, Leonard Stavisky, chairman of the State Assembly's Committee on Education, introduced bill aimed at preventing the schools from suffering an unfair share of the city's overall budget cuts. This proposal seemed to us sound in purpose, as the classrooms had already been hit with disproportionate severity by the first round of staff reductions. The measure's sponsors insisted that it would require neither the city nor the state to provide any additional funds for the schools was on this basis that we supported the Stavisky bill.

title: Planning Recovery
description: Since Governor Carey called on the Municipal Assistance Corporation three weeks ago to take on the job promoting New York City's economic recovery, M.A.C. Chairman Felix G. Rohatyn has stressed the urgency that new assignment.

title: 3 Killed as Ski Cars Fall At Vail, Colo.
description: VAIL, Colo., March 26 (UPI) Three persons were killed and nine injured today when two gondolas loaded with skiers snapped loose from their cables and plunged more than 100 feet to the slopes of Vail Mountain. Vail is the ski resort home of President Ford, who has ridden the gondola many times.

title: Bipartisan Group Urges Code of Ethics for Senate
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)A bipartisan move was announced today to require the drafting of a code of ethics and conduct for Senators and Senate employees. It would cover such issues as conflicts of interest and use of personal funds, its sponsors said.

title: Pulling Together
description: M.A.C.'s first task, in our view, is to coordinate the efforts of a host of public and private agencies which are already engaged in economic development programs at city state and regional levels. These include the State Economic Development Board, which was created only last August by Governor Carey presumably to carry out many of the same functions that have been assigned to M.A.C.; the State Department of Commerce and its energetic new Commissioner, John S. Dyson; the city's Economic Development Administration, and the City Planning Department, which was recently called on by Mayor Beame to work with E.D.A. to develop a fiveyear economic plan; the Temporary Commission for City Finances; and a large number of private groups.

title: Chances Seem Dim On House Bank Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Measures to consolidate the nation's bankregulatory agencies faced dim legislative prospects today, Congressional sources said following a caucus of the Democratic majority of the House Banking Committee.

title: Pulitzer's Garbage
description: There is a predictable pattern in schoolbook censorship: the censors have not read the book. The latest example of thinking small and carrying a big matchstick has occurred in Levittown, L.I., where school board members removed a number of titles from the bookshelves, including some assigned by teachers in literature classes. The books had no business being in the highschool library, said a board member. The taxpayers don't have to subsidize garbage.

title: George III Still Revolts Bicentennial Chairman
description: The Greenwich, Conn., library removed a picture of George III from its window yesterday after the town's Bicentennial committee chairman, Thaddeus Hopper said, It was in bad taste, very much out of place.

title: Soviet Linguist Is Ousted For a Letter to The Times
description: MOSCOW, March 26 (AP)Igor A. Melchuk, a dissident Soviet linguist, said today that he had lost his job because of a letter he wrote to The New York Times defending Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and human rights activist.

title: Poison Gas Affects Osaka
description: OSAKA, Japan, March 26 (AP) Poison gas spread through a residential area today, sending more than 140 persons to the hospital. The gas was formed when the driver of a tank truck mistakenly poured several tons of sulfuric acid into another chemical tank at a plant, prolucing chlorine gas.

title: Lebanon: People, Issues
description: THE PRESIDENTSuleiman Franjieh, a 65yearold Maronite Christian and clan chieftain from the hill town of Zghorta, was elected by Parliament in 1970 with a onevote margin. Now defying demands by Parliament and the military that he resign his office, President Franjieh has set numerous conditions for his stepping down, including a say in the choice of a successor.

title: Weekend Busy for Byrne After 10 Days in Arizona
description: TRENTON, March 26 Governor Byrne returned today after 10 days in Arizona, and almost immediately plunged into a weekend of socializing and politicking. His schedule called for him to be in Philadelphia tonight to tape a television program with Gov. Milton Shapp of Pennsylvania and Gov. Sherman W. Tribbitt of Delaware.

title: Memorial Services
description: GLASSLillian. Memorial services will be held on Sunday, March 28, 12 noon, at Weiss & Son Funeral Home. Prince St. and Northern BIvd., Flushing, Queens.

title: LORRAINE FOX DIES; ILLUSTRATOR WAS 54
description: Lorraine Fox, an illustrator who had won many awards for her work, died of cancer yesterday in Nassau Hospital, Mineola, L. I. She was 54 years old and lived at 4 Kings Terrace Road, Kings Point, L. I.

title: INTERPLAY DANCED BRIGHTLY BY CHRYST
description: There is a steady and inventive exchange between the gestures of street games and the ballet studio among the dancers in Jerome Robbins's Interplay. The City Center Joffrey Ballet gave the work an appreciative and bright performance on Thursday evening at City Center's 55th Street Theater.

title: Prosecutor Plans a Retrial Of Reilly in Mother's Death
description: WESTON, Conn., March 26State's Attorney John F. Bland said today that he expected to put Peter A. Reilly on trial again for the murder of his mother two and a half years ago. dicted yesterday in granting Mr. Reilly's petition for a new trial that a new trial before a new jury would more than likely result in an acquittal.

title: A Killing That Shocked Belfast
description: BELFAST, March 25Mrs. Wilma White sits in her living room and absently watches her yearold son crawl over the carpet. It is late morning and the sun filters into the small room crammed with new toys and birthday cards for the boy and condolence cards concerning his father.

title: Depailler's Car Is Speediest
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., March 26Patrick Depailler, who holds the course record for the race through the streets of Monte Carlo, was the fastest driver through the streets of Long Beach today as qualifying began for the first United States Grand Prix West.

title: Screen: 'Moses' Opens:Burt Lancaster Stars in TV Series Revision
description: "Moses" is a movie that appears to have been made by the yard, a bargain-basement Bibical epic that can be cut and shaped to fit any need.The film, which opened yesterday at the Ziegfeld Theater, has been put together from a lot of the same footage that went into the six one-hour "Moses" shows presented on CBS-TV last year with Burt Lancaster in the title role, with the Old Testament as source material and with additional dialogue by Anthony Burgess, Vittorio Bonicelli and Gianfranco De Bosio.Because I did not see the television series, I don't know how much of the film duplicates the small-screen shows, though I assume there are certain obligatory scenes that appear in both versions. You can't very well do six hours of Moses on television and not get around to his Red Sea venture, which is one of the theatrical feature's noisiest and most tepid highlights.The movie at the Ziegfeld makes C. B. DeMille's "The Ten Commandments" look like a work by Eisenstein. It is long and loud and so silly in some scenes that the piety in others is effectively denied. The screenplay covers the life of Moses from his birth and subsequent adoption by an Egyptian princess, to his death years later, after he had successfully led the Israelites to the land of Caanan.At its best moments, the film's style is that of Kipling's "Just So Stories" adapted to Sunday school concerns. Thus we learn how the Passover feast came to be, and we are there when Moses more or less invents the Sabbath. The film displays some power when it demonstrates the ferocity with which Moses punishes the lawbreakers, including executions by stoning some victims, by hurting others off a cliff, and by pouring molten gold into the mouth of one man who would have had the Israelites worship the golden calf.These brief but vivid glimpses of a harsh, primitive world are softened and sentimentalized by the drab direction, the woodenness of most of the performances (except Mr. Lancaster's) and by dialogue that sounds as if it had been cut out of a failed Neil Simon play. Mr. Lancaster, no longer in his first youth, has the elemental physical and emotional strength to make a fine Moses, if this were a better film.One accepts the childlike nature of Moses' people, who may witness their leader turning the Nile to blood on Monday and a rod into a serpent on Wednesday, but who still may wonder on Friday what he's done for them lately. What one doesn't accept is the language in which these doubts are spoken.Says a petulant tribesman during the journey through the wilderness when water is running short, "You said you knew this place like the back of your hand." Moses: "Will you people never cease to complain?" Irritation is the spur.This film, which is a co-production of RAI, the Italian Government-sponsored radio and television company, and Independent Television Corporation of England, a commericial company, was shot in Israel and Italy and has a cast of dozens and dozens, representing most races and creeds. The English Anthony Quayle plays Aaron, the Swedish Ingrid Thulin is Miriam, and the Greek Irene Pappas is Zipporah. Mariangela Melato, who has since become a star in Lina Wertmuller's films, has a small, sort of glide-on part as the princess who finds Moses in the bull-rushes.In addition to contributing to the screenplay, Gianfranco De Bosio is credited as the film's director, which I take to mean he was the film's traffic manager.

title: TenMile Fire in New Mexico
description: LAS VEGAS, N. M., March 26 (UPI)A brush fire ignited by sparks from a nearby sawmill destroyed an estimated 12,000 acres of range land before it could be controlled today. The blaze started late yesterday in an area just northeast of Las Vegas. Winds that reached 40 miles an hour spread the flames over an area of more than 10 miles.

title: Messersmith Given Fair Offer by Mets
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26,  The New York Mets joined the Yankees and several other teams today in the gathering sweepstakes for Andy Messersmith, the pitcher who sued for his freedom and touched off a revolution in baseball.

title: Nixon Tapes and Papers Found in Peril of Decay
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 James B. Rhoads, the Government's chief archivist, says 5,000 hours of Nixon White House tapes and some 42 million Nixon documents must be moved to better quarters or face dangers of deterioration.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: LEONARDO DA VINCI, Italian. Left St. Thomas March 24; due t2 P.M. at W.  55th St.

title: 76 Race and New Senate Chiefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 26While the behind  the  scenes jockeying is under way among Senate Democrats and Republicans to pick new party leaders next January, the outcome of the contests and the roles the new leaders will play may be shaped more by the Presidential election next November than by the dealing in the Senate clookrooms.

title: CARTER IS CRITICAL OF STATE PRIMARY
description: BUFFALO, March 26Breathing indignation over what he called a stacked, undemocratic and disgraceful primaryelection process that he had said had hurt his candidacy in the state, Jimmy Carter brought his Presidential campaign today to upstate New York.

title: Colonel Bid Fails, NetsWin, 109106
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 26 The New York Nets staved off a late Kentucky Colonel rally and what looked suspiciously like a zone defense tonight to defeat the visitors, 109106, at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Senate Panel to Study Need For a Teamsters Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)The Permanent investigations Subcommittee of the Senate's Government Operalions Committee has authorized a staff study to determine whether an investigation of the teamsters union and the Mafia should be undertaken. Congressional sources disclosed today.

title: Ernest Shepard, Pooh Illustrator, Dies
description: LODSWORTH, England, March 26 (AP)  Ernest Howard Shepard, who drew WinniethePooh in the classic stories for children by A. A. Milne, died Wednesday. He was 96 years old.

title: Solid Growth
description: Help of the kind New York City's battered economy does need is provided by the decision or the American Express Company to anchor 5,800 jobs in and around its newly dedicated world headquarters in the financial district. That decision is an expression of faith both in the city's ability to conquer its fiscal crisis and fortify its position as a capital of commerce, communications and culture. This is the direction in which New York must look for solid growth.

title: Dance: Tharp Premiere
description: Seven years ago, when Twvla Tharp's company appeared at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with a piece called Group Activities, so few people attended that you could have fitted the entire audience onstage.

title: Turmoil in the Schools.
description: What may on the surface appear to be a matter of purely local concern, a conflict between a defiant high school principal in Queens and the Board of Education officials who have suspended him is actually symbolic of a larger, national issue. The question how to maintain discipline In the schoolshas come to be the central educational issue in the public mind across the country.

description: Representatives of the midtown arearesidents as well as businessmencalled on the Legislature yesterday to pass a bill that would mandate jail sentences of up to 90 days for prostitutes and enable the police to arrest pimps for loitering.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two youths were arrested in the killing of a 61yearold taxicab driver early Tuesday morning on the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Drive. The suspectsNelson Maldanado, 17, of 292 Baruch Place, and Orlando Perez,. 19, of 668 Water Streetwere charged with homicide and robbery. The victim, Bigdomino Rodriguez of 359 West 35th Street, a father of three children, was hailed in midManhattan. When he was ordered to stop, Mr. Rodriguez speeded up his cab, which then crashed into two other vehicles. Just before they fled, the suspects fired a 22caliber pistol at the cab driver, the police charged.

title: Nastase Ousted From Tourney For Behavior in Tanner Match
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 26Ilie Nastase, the rambunctious Rumanian, was defaulted out of the $200,000 American Airlines Tennis Games today after another of his vocal and stalling performances in a quarterfinal match he was losing to Roscoe Tanner.

title: Mental Patient Held in Slaying Of Puerto Rican Socialist's Son
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 26A young mental patient was arrested today as a suspect in the murder of the son of Juan Mari Bras, the secretary general of the Puerto Rican Socialist Party and a candidate for the governship.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 26 (Reuters)  When Vietnam's first nationwide general elections in a generation are held on April 25 there will be a choice between candidates, the official press has reported.

Gibson's office on Tuesday at the head of 75 demonstrators from the North Ward.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 (UPI)President Ford indicated today that Ronald Reagan might be acceptable as his Republican VicePresidential running mate.

title: 3 Crash Victims Identified
description: CHICAGO, March 26 (UPI)The bodies of three persons were identified today following the crash of a fourengine Lockheed JetStar business plane that skidded down a runway and burst into flames on an attempted takeoff from Midway Airport yesterday, killing the three and leaving a fourth critically burned. The dead were identified as James Fugate, 45 years old, the pilot, of Calif., George Erman, vice president of International Aircraft Service Company of San Jose, Calif., and Theresa Mahood, of Northbrook, Ill.

title: Senate Unit Seeks Lockheed Records

title: Keep Rolling

A nationwide cutoff in overtheroad truck movement would swiftly force many businesses to close and add a vast new army to the 7 million unemployed.

PETERSBURG BEACH, Fla., March 26The early findings of two lungcancer studies suggest that new approaches to detection and treatment can significantly increase the chances of surviving this usually fatal disease. They were described today at the opening of the American Cancer Society's annual seminar for science writers.

title: Books of The Times
description: Toward the close of the 1952 Presidential campaign and of John Bartlow Martin's definitive biography of Adlai E. Stevenson, the author quotes a speech by Dwight D. Eisenhower's runningmate, Richard M. Nixon: Stevenson himself hasn't even backbone training, for he is a graduate of Dean Acheson's spineless school of diplomacy which cost the free world 600 million former allies in the past seven years of Trumanism. Mr. Nixon has suffered a change or two in the estimation of his political party and country. Mr. Stevenson, as another Presidential campaign arrives 24 years later, remains the beau ideal of Democratic, liberalism more than any candidate since Franklin D. Roosevelt. All the skills that Mr. Martin brought to the art of investigative reporting in the responsible years of magazine journalism following World War II are put to use in his big Stevenson biography. He is, first of all, ruthless but not careless with small details; next, he takes details and builds them into a structure of facts; finally, the interpretation of his subject, derived from many sources, becomes the property of the reader rather than of the author. This transference is quite unlike much of the new journalism and semibiography, which often depends on fixed notions, psychoanalytical justification and stylish clairvoyance. Leon Edel, Henry James's Boswell, set finer guidelines: The biographer may be as imaginative as he pleasesthe more imaginative the betterin the way he brings together his materials, but he must not imagine the materials.

title: American Express Dedicates Building, Citing Its Faith in City
description: With mutual congratulations, a buffet luncheon and allusions to the city's fiscal crisis, Governor Carey, Mayor Beame and Howard L. Clark, chairman of the American Express Company, dedicated the company's new 40story headquarters building at the foot of Broad Street yesterday.

title: Angolan Bids U.N. Council Ash South Africa to Pay for Damage
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 26Angola urged the Security Council tonight to demand that South Africa pay compensation for damage resulting from its intervention in the Angolan civil war.

description: PHILADELPHIA, March 26 Indiana was an overwhelming favorite of the nation's college basketball coaches to beat the University of California, Los Angeles, tomorrow in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. And the Hoosiers also were the choice to take the title in the championship game Monday night at the Spectrum.

title: Yonkers Cancels Its $100,000 Pace
description: The $100,000 Yonkers International Pace, which was to be worth $50,000 to the winner, has been snubbed by foreign horsemen and was canceled yesterday. All the owners of the top five Australian and New Zealand horses who were invited refused the track's invitation for the May 1 event.

title: People and Business
description: Although the Ford Motor Company earnings were off 10.5 percent last year, the company's two top officers both got 14 percent pay raises, the proxy statement mailed from Detroit to shareholders along with the company's annual report disclosed yesterday.

title: CRITICS OF REGIME INDICTED IN SEOUL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 26A former opposition candidate for the presidency and 17 other persons were formally indicted today on charges of violating an emergency decree banning criticism of the South Korean Constitution.

title: JACKSON STRESSES HIS ENERGY VIEWS
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington took a subway ride to the World Trade Center yesterday to emphasize his demand for a national commitment to energy independence.

title: Montgomery Breaks 200 Freestyle Mark
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 26In the 200yard freestyle final in the National Collegiate swimming championships tonight were Tim McDonnell. who set the American record last year: Bruce Furniss, who broke it in the trials this afternoon, and Tim Shaw, who broke three world records last year. None of them won.

Only minor injuries were reported in the scuffle involving 200 teachers and 25 policemen armed with clubs.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The United States and Turkey reached an agreement yesterday on a fouryear accord under which American military installations would be reopened in Turkey in return for a pledge of about a billion in American grants and loansabout $250 million yearly, most of it in military assistance. The accord would entirely end the American embargo on military aid to Turkey that followed Turkey's invasion of Cyprus in 1974, but its approval by Congress is uncertain because of concern over Turkey's lagging efforts to end the Cyprus crisis. The embargo was eased by Congress last October and it was then that the TurkishAmerican talks were begun. They ended with the agreement signed at the State Department by Secretary o: State Henry A. Kissinger and Turkey's Foreign Minister, Ihsan S. Caglayangil. [Page 1, Column 1.]
