title: Business Briefs
description: Wall Street securities firms made ptiolic yesterday a series of proposals to lessen the impact of a transfer tax levied on stock transactions by New York State. The conclusion remains inescapable, said Edward I. O'Brien, president of the Securities Industry Association, that the New York State stock transfer tax places marry securities firms doing business in this state at a competitive disadvantage compared with those operating elsewhere.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was reported incorrectly in The New York Times yesterday that David C. Farrell would succeed Robert J. Suslow as president and chief operating officer of the May Department Stores Company. Mr. Farrell is currently president and chief operating officer and will continue in those posts. Mr. Suslow, who is president of the FamousBarr Company, a division of May, will become president of Saks Fifth Avenue on June I.

title: Green, at 135, Leads By Shot Over Irwin
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S. C., March 26Consider the plight of Hubert Myatt Green.

title: Soviet Rebuffs U.S. Charge On Embassy Harassment,
description: MOSCOW, March 26 (AP)Soviet officials have reiected United States charges that a telephone harassment campaign and bomb scare at the American Embassy this week were officially sanctioned, informed sources said today. But United States officias did not withdraw their charges. About 70 telephone calls were viported to have been made to the homes of 23 em bassy officers, many in the middle of the night, from Monday through Wednesday.

title: $305,000 in Aid Is Going To Local Police, Agencies
description: ALBANY, March 26Governor Carey announced today that local police agencies would share $305,000 in state and Federal aid under a new program to reduce traffic accidents caused by speeding and drunken driving.

title: United Brands Omissions
description: BOSTON, March 26 (Reuters) The United Brands Company said today that, because of indenture restrictions, quarterly dividends have not been declared on the $1.28 Series A cumulative convertible preference stock, the $3 cumulative convertible preferred stock and $3.20 Series B cumulative preference stock. The last payments an these preferreds were made to September 1974.

title: Chase Realty Trust Holders Fail to Vote Revamping
description: BOSTON, March 26  The longawaited annual meeting of the financially troubled Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust was adjourned here today after the election of trustees until April 20 after management reported that too few shareholders had voted on three controversial proposals to restructure the trust. Many shareholders simply refused to vote.

title: Moslems Insist Franjieh Quit Before a CeaseFire
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, March 27Moslem leaders insisted yesterday that there could be no ceasefire in the Lebanese civil war unless their Christian opponents agreed to sweeping constitutional changes and the immediate unconditional resignation of President Suleiman Franiieh a Christian.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: REPRESENTATIVES John W. Wydler, Republican of Garden City, and Jerome A. Ambro, Democrat of East Northport, normally miles apart in political philosophy. now are leading the fight fur extensions of the 1972 revenuesharing law that has pumped billions of Federal dollars into state and local governmentsincluding $88.5 million in Suffolk County and $98.5 million in Nassau County.

title: New Sounds From An Old Instrument
description: Although he considers himself both a composer and a performer, it is as an experimenter with the flute that Harvey Sollberger is now making his mark. Sollbergerr has expanded the potential of the traditionally puretoned flute into an instrument capable of producine new kinds of sounds.

title: Guide to Metric Wisdom
description: STUTTGART, WEST GERMANY IN The New York Times (Feb. 7), you reported in progress in converting to the metric system in New Jersey on road signs. This jrompts me to worry about what the speed signs will say.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: CALYPSO, Kerr. Lett Rotterdam March 19; due 8:3D A.M. at W. 55th St.

title: History Lesson In Jazz
description: To the astonishment of some of its members, the New Jersey Historical Society is going to celebrate the Bicentennial and the 75th anniversary of the Society's Women's Branch with something that is not usually associated with such a staid organization: a jazz concert.

title: An Annual Report with Room for Critics
description: Cyclops Corporation, a Pittsburgh specialty steel producer, lets some critics have their say in its annual report. Comments of eight outsiders including an economist, an investment analyst, a shareholder, customers, and I. W. Abel, president of the United Steelworkers Union, were printed in the 1975 report.

title: Marian Doyle Rogoff, 52, McCannErickson Nurse
description: Marian Doyle Rogott Miner industrial nurse with McCannErickson Inc., the advertising agency; for 20 years, died yesterday of cancer in Andover, Mass. She was 52 years old and lived in Peter Cooper Village.

title: AntiSoviet Violence Here Upsets Jews in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, March 27The harassment of Soviet officials by Jewish militants in New York has upset not only Soviet authorities but also some Soviet Jews on whose behalf the actions have allegedly been conducted.

title: Minnesota Six Takes Title in Upset
description: DENVER, March 27The University of Minnesota upset the defending champion, Michigan Tech, 64, before 5,311 fans tonight at the Denver University Arena and captured its second National Collegiate hockey title in the last three years.

title: City Council Schedules 3 Committee Meetings
description: The City Council will meet at City Hall on Tuesday at noon. It has also scheduled three committee meetings during the week, as follows:

title: TV VIEW
description: This season's television object of most intense attention has undoubtedly been Rich Man, Poor Man, the 12hour dramatization of Irwin Shaw's novel. An interesting story was, given a good production and a firstrate cast of several very impressive new faces surrounded by veterans doing guest star turns. The result, while falling somewhat short of great art, was generally far better than average television fare. And, just to complicate matters, it was extremely successful for ABCTV in the audience ratings.

title: Nations Off the Beaten Track
description: Do you hear the siren call of faraway places with strangesounding names? Do you yearn for a vacation off the beaten track, away from the madding tourist crowds? The Micropatrology Society may be able to help; it has the facts on some of the world's most far  out destinations, with strangesounding names to match.

title: THE ZEAL OF IVIAURICE NADJARI
description: When Maurice Nadjari walks down a street in New York, strangers come up and wish him good luck. In Bronx coops and on the East Side of Manhattan, people speak of him as a rare honest man making a lonely fight against the crooks and the political bosses. Last January, after Governor Carey tried to dismiss him as Special Prosecutor. The Daily News took a poll. Of those with an opinion, 55 percent thought Nadjari should stay on the job indefinitely; 77 percent disagreed with Carey's statement that his record as prosecutor was poor.

title: Scholastic Stars Include King
description: Six players from New York State are among the 90 selected to the allAmerica high school basketball team, announced today by Parade Magazine.

title: CASINOS IN LAS VEGAS STARTING TO REOPEN
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. March 27 (UPI)Picket lines were withdrawn and 15 hotel casinos that account for up 40 percent of the state's gaming revenue were reopening for business today after a 17day strike.

title: Fewer Buses, Angry Riders
description: FOR those in New Jersey who depend on local bus service to get to work, go shopping or make social calls, the economics of the day are forcing radical changes in modes and methods of transportation.

title: Fordham's Weaver Takes 7Mile Run
description: Tim Weaver, a 22yearold Fordham University senior, won the sevenmile run sponsored by the Road Runners Club of New York in Central Park yesterday. Weaver, covered the distance in 35 minutes 14 seconds, finishing about 300 yards ahead of Bob Braille, a 20yearold, Bucknell sophomore. Braille was clocked in 35.52.

title: Editors Choice
description: FAMILY FEELING, by Helen Yglesia.., (Dial Press, $8.95.) Fine novel about a woman, defined in the totality of her relationships.

title: The Battle Over Eavesdropping
description: THERE are more than six million telephones in New Jersey, and on any given day the chances are that someone, could be listening in on calls made on any one of them. It could be the Federal Bureau of Investigation or the state police, armed with a court warrant authorizing a telephone tap; however, it is more likely to be the telephone company, or any one of 1,200 other concerns and Government agencies that use monitoring and listening devices as part of their daytoday work. It could be a lelephone company supervisor, making cure an operainr is answer ing questions correctly and politely. It could be a super. visor at Eastern Airlines, checking on how reservation clerks give out information on flights. Or, it could be the Internal Revenue Service or the state's Division of Motor Vehicles.

title: BEAME ALARMED AS TRANSIT TALKS REACH STALEMATE
description: Mayor Beame met with the three, mediators in the stalemated transit negotiations yesterday and later described the situation as grave and very disturbing.

title: PEOPLE
description: IN the planning for the continuing education curriculum next fall as the State University at Stony Brook is course called The Real Adams Family. And if you suspect that the title implies some criticism of The Adams Chronicles unreeling on the Public Broadcasting Service, Peter Shaw says you're right. Mr. Shaw, an associate professor of English at Stony Brook, is the author the wellreceived The Character of John Adams, published this month by the University of North Carolina Press. Professor Shaw says television has concentrated on the moments in the family history that we don't have records about the feelings that the Adamses had at births, deaths and family tragedies. His course, he says, will use the family history to concentrate on the family's view of itself.

title: Carey and Legislature Remain at Odds on the Budget
description: ALBANY, March 27With the end of the state's fiscal year only four days away, Governor Carey and the Legislature remain at odds on some key bills affecting both the budget and the state construction agenciesbills that Mr. Carey's office wants enacted before the year is out.

title: Some science, some speculation
description: The premise of this book by anthropologist Edward Hall is that our inventions, institutions, language, indeed our culture, have gained a life of their own and have overwhelmed us so that we are no longer able to express ourselves fully. As the title suggests, the book exhorts us to journey beyond culture in order to be free. While this is hardly an original notion, it is certainly provocative and, being an admirer of the author's previous books, I looked forward to reading what he had to say. Unfortunately, I was sorely disappointed.

title: Letters: The Joys of Taking a Slow Boat
description: To the Editor: To John Brannon Albright's article about freighters in the Notes Column (Travel Section, March 7), I should like to add a few enthusiastic words about the pleasures of this type of travel.

title: 4 Are Killed as 7 States Are Hit by 24 Tornadoes
description: A total of 24 tornadoes toughed down in seven states Friday and early yesterday killing four persons, injuring more than 60 and leaving parts of several towns in scattered rubble, The ASsociated Press reported.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Aqueduct Race Charts

title: Habitat
description: The United Nations Conference on Human Settlements, to be held in Vancouver in May, will address the universal problems of the built worlda monumental assignment. Habitat, as the meeting is called, is to be the urban equivalent of the Stockholm U.N. conference on the natural environment in 1972.

title: Neighbors, And How to Ignore Them
description: ISEE you have a very active social life. a 300pound neighbor remarked to me at the April P.T.A. meeting.

title: SNOWBIRD IN TEE SPRING
description: Velveteen.

title: W. M. Kincaide And Gail Griffin Plan to Marry
description: Gail Georgia Griffin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Griffin Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and William Mark Kincaide of Washington, plan to be married on June 19. Announcement of their engagement was made by the prospective bride's parents.

title: The Carter Coalition
description: On the night of Jimmy Carter's victory over George Wallace in the North Carolina Democratic primary, Senator Henry Jackson paused while campaigning in Brooklyn to say:

title: Peyser's Race Against Buckley Is Uphill
description: ALBANYPeter A. Peyser is undaunted. Never mind that nobody recognizes him in the Colonie Mall, or that the security officers have asked him to leave because they do not allow soliciting of any kind, even for votes.

title: Changing citizens into leaders and matter into energy
description: The classic example of a Presidentmaker is Louis McHenry Howe. Francis Russell's chapter on him opens with the asthmatic Howe lying on the floor of his sweltering Chicago hotel suite directing the strategy of the Roosevelt forces at the 1932 Democratic convention. More than two decades earlier the ugly and misshapen Howe had married his fortunes to those of a young state senator with a dazzling smile and a distinguished name. Even at that time Howe had seen in Franklin Roosevelt a President in the making through whom he could exercise the power that he would never be able to achieve on his own. The critical moment had now arrived, and Howe, gasping for breath, was guiding the efforts to get Roosevelt the twothirds majority which had to be achieved on the fourth ballot, or the Presidency might be lost forever.

title: A Show Becomes a Political Windfall
description: The CBS telecast at 9 P.M. this coming Thursday and Friday of fielter Skelter, a two  part docudrama about the Manson family's murder of the actress Sharon Tate and six other ??? in Las Angeles in the summer of 1969, raises significant questions about the relationship between television entertainment and electoral politics.

title: The New York Times Book Review
description: The New York Times Book Review

title: An Inadequate Zalrnen
description: There's a scene in Elie Wiesel's Zalmen or the Madness of God that apparently won't work no matter how you stage it, and since the scene goes straight to the heart of the play its brief failure is fatal. A company of foreign actors touring Russia asks permission to attend Yom Kippur services in a village synagogue. The Jewish community is so small and so isolated that it can scarcely believe its ears: I had begun to think that in this godforsaken town we were the last Jews on earth, a member of the council murmurs. Zalmen, the local rabbi's hoptoad of a sexton, takes on prophetic stature whenever the two men are alone: he urges the aged, philosophically resigned rabbi to shake off his torpor and speak out to the strangers during his sermon, thereby relighting the flame Jewish unity throughout the world. The act is rash to the point of madness because a commissar and guards will be on hand; they will be heard from later.

title: Births
description: Lynn and Steve Joyfully announce the birth of Stacy and Andrew's sister, Marni Elyse, on March 21. Grandparents are Roslyn and Dave Letkowltz and Helen and Moe Axelrad. Greatgrandmother Is Sarah Beckerman.

title: The Forgotten Questions
description: WASHINGTONIt is one of the oddities of this Presidential election that almost everybody complains about the quality of the candidates, and yet nobody asks them what sort of men and women they would choose to help them govern the country.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: It is a very long time ago now that Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur were given total liberty by a studio to make a certain number of films exactly, as they wanted to make them, unsupervised, whereupon the two irrepressible individualists released an ad in the trade papers with their new, and most conscientious, byword writ large on the wall behind them: What is the audience doing all that time?

title: For Best Performing Shelter
description: HOLLYWOODWhen the film world's annual Academy Awards are presented tomorrow night, there won't be any Oscars bestowed for motion picture financing.

title: Bunge Offices Here Reported Linked to Grain Record Manipulation
description: WASHINGTON, March 27A former bookkeeper for the Bunge Corporation, under questioning by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has linked the company's New York headquarters with the manipulation of records used to cover excess grain in its inventories, according to a report by two agents.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The uncertainty over the split ownership status of the Salmon Building at 11 West 42d Street has been resolved.

title: Two Soviet Literary Journals Debate Whether Legendary Achilles Was a Forebear of the Russians
description: MOSCOW, March 27Two Soviet literary publications have squared off to trade barely veiled insults over a notion that Achilles, the Greek hero of Homer's Iliad, might have been a princely forebear of the Russians.

title: The Bulls Return to the Art Market
description: Ten days ago at a Parke Bernet auction, a Gauguin painting sold for $1.4 million the second highest price on record for an Impressionist or postImpressionist work. It was one of a number of sign's in recent weeks that the international art market is recovering after a disappointing period of declining prices.

title: Dennis Lazar to Wed Kathy Friedman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Murray Friedman of Roslyn Harbor, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathy Pamela Friedman, to Dennis Steven Lazar, a lawyer with the estate and tax department of the Internal Revenue Service men's fashion footwear. Mrs. Friedman is vice president of the concern. The prospective bridegroom's father is president of Friendly Wines and Liquors in Brooklyn.

title: Wheeling Through Wales
description: As everybody knows, Wales is hilly. On learning that my husband and Icity bikersplanned a fall vacation there, biking, our friends all mentioned this.  Wales is hilly. But trips, like love, stand outside reason. We had our hearts set on biking in Wales.

title: Yanks Beat Royals In Brett Bros. Act
description: FORT MYERS, Fla., March 27The Brett Brothers put on an act today that was worthy of a much larger stage, Yankee Stadium, perhaps, But they had to be content to do it before a tiny although appreciative crowd of 3,645 in this rapidly growing city on Florida's west coast.

title: Hotels Sold Out
description: MONTREAL  Tickets for most events in next summer's Olympic Games here are still available, but hotel and motel rooms are sold out.

title: High Court Rule Stirs School Boards
description: HARTFORD, March 27 Thirtyfour towns in Connecticut face the prospect of long and contentious debate following the decision by the United States Supreme Court last Monday upholding a ruling in Federal Court here requiring that the principle of one person, one vote be applied to representation on regional school boards.

title: STUDENTS ATTEND CLASS IN U.S. COURT
description: Fifty high school students have learned a lesson about American justice by visiting a Federal appeals court here, listening to the arguments in an immigration case and writing their own decisions as if they were the judges in the dispute.

title: TOWN MEETINGS THRIVE IN CAPITAI
description: WASHINGTON, March 27The tousled head of Henry Steele Commager, the historian, and the clipped bangs of authordiplomat Clare Boothe Luce bent cosily together as they shared coffee and conversation on a blue damask loveseat in the Green Room of the Kennedy Center.

title: Regazzoni Takes Coast Race Pole
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., March 27In this land of the freeway the streets of downtown Long Beach are beginning to _exact their toll.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Al McGuire One of a Kind
description: To the Sports Editor: Jimmy Breslin's sterling portrayal of Al McGuire was a source of great pleasure for me. McGuire is a unique personality to be sure; he is one college basketball coach who views the game from the proper perspective. His tenacity of purpose does little to inhibit his uncanny ablility to relate to his ballplayers and make the game fun. McGuire's adamant refusal to permit Marquette basketball to assume lifeanddeath proportions is a singular manifestation of his broadened horizons. Breslin's allusion to McGuire's heightened perception of the black man's plight provides an even more impressive example of the latter's openminded philosophy. All of this, buttressed by his enviable coaching record, makes Al McGuire one of a kind.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet certainly needs no apologias. In its comparatively brief life, it has achieved a great deal: a special school of dancing, the development of Gerald Arpino as a major American choreographer and the special understanding of the relationship between classic ballet and moderndancethat miraculous balance. But even if the Joffrey Ballet had achieved none of this, it would still be worth its salt, it would still amply justify its existence. Why? Simply through the adoption and rehabilitation of a major choreographic artist, the 75yearold Kurt Jooss. Jooss, when Joffrey met him, was almost a ghost from the past. To be sure, his pacifist masterpiece, The Green Table, was in repertories all over the world. But the work threatened to submerge Jooss with kindness, to play, Pagliacci to his Leoncavallo! Joffrey changed all that.

title: The NuclearPower Debate
description: THREE years from now, the Long Island Lighting Company's first nuclear power station, the Shoreham plant, schdeduled to begin supplying electricity to homes and businesses. The new nuclear plant will produce electricity at significantly lower cost, and in a manner more compatible with the natural environment, than the other available generation alternatives coal or oilburning plants. Shoreham's operation will mean savings of hundreds of millions of dollars in future electric bills for Lilco customers, cleaner air to breathe for all Long Islanders and a dramatic reduction of our community's reliance on undependable foreign fuel sources.

title: Bigger and Better? A New Racquet For Tennis Fans
description: WHEN the seismograph readings are charted a few years from now, the epicenter of an earthquake just beginning to shake the tennis world will turn out to have been Princeton.

title: SHOW DEPICTS LIFE OF POLAND'S JEWS
description: Some 400 rare photographs depicting the richness and vitality of various phases of Jewish life in Polish towns, cities and hamlets before their destruction by the Nazi regime are on exhibit at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street.

title: Grain Surpluses Are Building Again
description: Four years ago, the Soviet Union precipitated a revolution in America's biggest industryagricultureby buying up 700 million bushels of United States grain.

title: Defense No Longer Problem to Cosmos
description: The New York Cosmos meet the Tornado in Dallas today in a preseason game that has been sold out. The Cosmos have an abundance of defenders this season. which has, forced competition for starting positions on a team that is gaining popularity because of the presence of Pele.

title: Peking Is Reported to Be Moderating Its Campaign of Attacks on Rightists
description: HONG KONG, March 27The campaign against socalled rightists in China appears to have shifted into a more moderate phase, with fewer stri dently worded attacks and new calls in the Chinese press to turn the controversy into what would be a relatively innocuous study movement.

title: ARTS RIND DRIVE CALLED OFF BY CITY
description: A $7 million to $10 million emergency fund drive to support the city's crisisridden cultural institutions, publicly announced last December by Martin E. Segal, chairman of the city's Commission for Cultural Affairs, has been called off.

title: GARDENING
description: SPRING has long been the favored season season for planting woody plains in the northern half of the United States. The temperature and moisture are ??? for establishing plants and the plants themselves are ready to burst forth from their winter dormancy.

title: Giving Books an F
description: IN the shopping centers, in the candy stores, the skin magazines are posted at eye levelnaked bodies slung in all positions all vicarious sex for a handful or coins.

title: Best Seller List
description: General

title: Design
description: Ours is a nighttime apartment, Lisa Taylor says, really wonderful for entertaining, which is important for me as far as my Job is concerned. The Smithsonian Institution's only woman director (she heads the soontobeopened CooperHewitt Museum of Decorative Arts and Design in New York City) asks a great deal of her Fifth Avenue residence. In addition to providing an elegant back ground for official social activities, it must also function as a comfortable environment for her family.

title: The Statue of Liberty
description: Illustrated. 224 pp. New York; The Viking Press. $14.95.

title: Meredith Monk's Tapestry of Music and Dance
description: Meredith Monk, whose new music  dance  theater event, Quarry, begins Friday at the La Mama Annex, has called her works operas, operaepics, theater cantatas, live movies, composite theater, nonverbal opera, visual poetry, image dance and mosaic theater. Miss Monk started her professional life as a dancer, however, and most of the time she has been reviewed by dance critics.

title: Business Builds Its Political War Chest Legally
description: What began as a slow but steady stream of corporate political action committees formed last year following a landmark ruling by the Federal Election Commission is turning into a torrent.

title: It Has Occasionally Been Tried, but a State of Siege Is More Normal
description: BOGOTA, ColombiaWhen President Alfonso Lpez Michelsen came to office in August, 1974, Colombia was, or at least seemed to be, a rare example of democracy resisting a corrtinental trend toward autocracy. But a combination of factors has changed matters in Colombia since then, and now Latin America's fourth most populous nation now seems about to follow its neighbors on the road to outright authoritarianism.

title: Three comic writers
description: In the early morning of Nov. 13, 1916, H. H. Munroa small, thin, tightlipped English corporal, standing in a shallow craterwas heard to shout: Put out that bloody cigarette. An instant later German shrappel hit him. The worst and cruelest practical joke was left to the end, Munro's death was as incongruous as that of his witty, cynical hero Comus Bassington, Graham Greene once wrote. But was It so incongruous? Few of his characters would say bloody, but one can hear Munro's voice. He died, true to himself, just as he lived: a patriot Tory, in the service of his country, he had volunteered at the age of 44, he refused to ask for a commission.

title: New Hands Take Over A Bankrupt Throttle
description: Conveyance Day is near. That's April 1, when Conrail takes over the estates of the Penn Central and a half dozen lesser bankrupt railroads and begins remodeling rail transportation in 17 states in the Northeast and the Midwest.

title: GOV. MILLIKEN SIGNS BILL CURBING PCB'S
description: LANSING, Mich., March 27Legislation banning in Michigan the manufacture and sale of polychlorinated biphenyls, the toxic industrial chemical, and sharply restricting their use was signed into law this week by Gov. William G. Milliken.

title: A Correction
description: Through a misreading of a court document, It was incorrectly reported in last Sunday's Issue of The New York Times that Bill Bradley of the New York Knickerbockers had an Income from endorsements in three seasons (190070, 197374, 197475) for which such a figure was given.

title: Council Presses for StreetDrinking Ban
description: A strong effort to override Mayor Beame's veto of a City Council bill that would ban drinking of alcoholic beverages on city streets was promised yesterday by Council members who had voted for the bill and by community groups that had supported it.

title: Yankee Box Score
description: Yankee Box Score

title: Of Things To Come
description: Samuel R. Delany is the most interesting author of science fiction writing in English today. No one else has managed to put the spacedefying, timedenying adventure story to such high purposein novels like Empire Star (1966) and The Einstein Intersection (1967)without sacrificing the narrative drive that made such stories appealing in the first place. His writing has always been experimental in the best sense: he poses a problem, embeds it in a familiar sf context and then bombards it with highenergy language to see what particles of insight he can dislodge. By the very nature of this technique, Delany is bound to be more successful in some books than others. In last year's Dhalgren, the high purpose was more evident than the narrative drive. TRITON (Bantam, paper, $1.95) is his most controlled, and therefore his most successful, experiment to date.

title: Only his fiction lacked imagination
description: Back in the days when the Society for the Suppression of Vice rode tall in the saddle and the friendly neighborhood candy store pushed pornography instead of pot, whole generations of randy schoolboys would exercise their ingenuity and spend their allowances collecting the grimy volumes of Frank Harris's My Life and Loves. Bought under the counter and read under the counterpane, Harris's scabrous memoirs seemed heady stuff at the time. But now that it is readily available in a handsome Grove Press edition, who is prepared to wade through its 983 pages of turgid lubricity and dubious anecdotes?

title: ART VIEW
description: Few exhibitions on the crowded Bicentennial calendar have been as eagerly or as apprehensively awaited as the show of 200 Years of American Sculpture that has now come to the Whitney Museum of American Art, Here was a subject badly in need of clarification and redefinition, and here was the obvious occasion for taking a fresh look at it. Sculpture has come to occupy a larger and larger place in American art, yet no coherent and uptodate history of American sculpture exists. A number of recent developments, moreoverthe revaluation of both folk art and academic art, the rediscovery of significant figures as different as Augustus SaintGaudens, Elie Nadelman and John Storrs, and most important, perhaps, the radical revision of the idea of sculpture that has been proffered in so much of the art claiming to be sculpture In the last decade or morehas made the need of a new historical perspective more urgent than ever,

title: KATHARINE W. BENTLEY
description: Katharine Woodford Bentley, wife of Warner Bentley, retired founding director of the Hopkins Center for Performing and Visual Arts at Dartmouth College, died Friday in Hanover, N.H. She was 73 years old and lived In Norwich, Vt.

title: The sound of movie music
description: Through the late summer and fall, on the set of Robert Altman's new movie, Buffalo Bill and the Indiansthe story of Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show in the 1880's with a cast that includes Paul Newman, Joel Grey, Burt Lancaster and Geraldine Chaplinall the music is being recorded live, on location in Calgary, Canada. The composer, Richard Baskin, has been up there for three months with cast and crew, working in the back room of the Buffalo Bar at a funky, old upright piano, hammering out the score. He writes the music, just as he did for much of Nashville, as the picture is being shot. The music, this time, mainly background and not songs, and relies on a 15piece brass band. Yet each character in the moviefrom Wild Bill Cody to Annie Oakleyhas a musical theme, and onethe impresario, played by Joel Greysings a song based on a poem the composer found in an old newspaper of the period. Everything is done spontaneously and very quickly, says Baskin, somewhat frazzled from the pressure of producing music so fast. I'm the only one who works this way.

title: Exhausting, Fragmented, Irrational, Superficial, etc.
description: WASHINGTONPhase one of this primary season has ended, and whatever else it has done, lit has convinced many of those who have trudged from New Hampshire to Vermont and Massachusetts to Florida to Illinois to North Carolina that the system must have been designed by a madman.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on motion to refer resolution relating to the importance of sound relations with the Soviet Union to the Foreign Relations Committee, which passed, 54 to 31, March 22.

title: Communists in Italy Content To Gather Power Slowly
description: ROMEItaly's Communist Party, the largest in Western Europe, has scored another success by gaining control with the Socialists of the local administration of Latium, the populous region that includes Rome itself. And so, once again, the party finds itself with an opportunity to demonstrate that Communists know how to govern and to build on its reputation of efficiency and responsibility.

title: Encounter: The Dwarf Beggar of Santa Rosa
description: Beggars seek impact. Sympathy is not their chief toolthat emotion is too easily put aside. The most success, ful beggars produce fear, and we pay to be away from them. So it was for me with the beggar of Santa Rosa; I quickly dropped a coin in a filthy claw but it did not end there.

title: Roger Howrigan MAR. 26APR. 15
description: Roger Howrigan MAR. 26APR. 15

title: Japanese Swords Craftsmanship as High Art
description: In his introduction to the catalogue of the current exhibition at Japan House, Hornma Junji, chairman of the Society for the Preservation of Japanese Art Swords, says that It is sincerely hoped that all of those who are coming to see the exhibition will intuitively appreciate the dignity, beauty, depth, as well as the purity, of the Japanese swords on display, without caring too much about any lack of technical knowledge about the, swords.

title: The New Partnership of the Banks and New York State
description: ALBANYA year has passed since the extraordinary afternoon last spring when New York City officials opened the comptroller's strongbox to examine bids placed by banks on the sale of city bonds, and found, to their bewilderment, nothing inside.

title: TV VIEW
description: According to Proverbs (26:14): As the door turneth upon its hinges, so doth the slothful upon his bed. Actually, it was a chaise longue, connived at by some plastics manufacturer to look like the corpse of a zebra. I was turning upon it the other Monday afternoon when the children came home from school, as If from the scene of an accident, threw their coats and notebooks at me, and switched on the TV set so that it might warm up while they pulled watermelons, potato sticks, Gatorade and leftover mucilage out of the icebox.

title: Once More in Academe, Purists vs. Utilitarians
description: Utilitarians and their enemies are at each other's throats again do American colleges and universities.

title: Dokes Captures Heavyweight Title
description: MIAMI, March 27 (AP)Michael Dokes, a silver medal winner for the United States in the PanAmerican Games, won the National Golden Gloves heavyweight title tonight by beating Woody Clark of Miami.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Among my uncles was one who could remember being born. I have heard him describe the blessed event, including the expression of rapture on his father's face.. This same uncle later fought with the Marines in France during the First World War and was shot right between the eyes by a German soldier, which made my uncle so angry that he immediately drew his own pistol and dispatched the German to kingdom come.

title: Where the Dancing Is: Asbury Park's Stone Pony
description: SOUTHSIDF JOHNNY and the Asbury Jukes were in full cry the other night at the Stone Pony here, belting out the sort of danceable South Side Chicago blues, rhythm and blues and rock that they've been purveying for more than a year.

title: Rev. Dr. Samuel Wasson, Presbyterian Leader, 67
description: The Rev. Dr. Samuel Carson Wasson, who retired three years ago as president of the Presbyterian Ministers Fund, died Friday in Broomall, Pa. He was 67 years old and lived in Rosemont, Pa.

title: French Communist Party Is Reported to Accuse Soviet of Being Soft on Capitalism
description: PARIS, March 27  The French Communist Party has delivered a sharp criticism of Soviet failure to exploit the worsening crisis of capitalism in a letter to other Communist parties, according to a report in Le Monde today from its Moscow correspondent.

title: ASSEMBLY STALLS SAVINGS BANK BILL
description: ALBANY, March 27  The fate of a bill to allow savings banks to continue checking privileges is at least temporarily in question as a group of Democratic Assemblymen move to link the bill with a requirement that banks create a substantial fund for socallec highrisk mortgage loans.

title: BRIDGE
description: Adults speaking to children are careful to use simple language and make sure they are understood. Expert bridge players are not always so carefulthey tend to assume that their partners are equally expert and will be able to understand their esoteric vocabulary. When this leads to disaster, as it often does, they scream loudly about their partner's technical incompetence without realizing their own inability to communicate.

title: 3 Stars, No Waiting
description: THE rubric at the right, adapted from the Miguide, that indispensable Koran of Frenchmen and those pursefree enough to visit France these days, molls that Craig Claiborne, the ??? editor of The New York Times, and Pierre Franey, his associate and ??? chef of Le Pavillon in Manhattan, operate a ??? ??? restaurant, one with a particularly fine ambience and, above all, one that ??? the very best meals  repasts that are worth a special trip to savor.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: LET me say at the outset that I am being very careful not to advocate anything like a taxpayers revolt, that I caution against any illegal withholding of taxes. Nor do I plead to be excused from paying my taxes, despite the many misgivings I have about where my tax money goes.

title: Memorial Service Today For Eric Siday, Composer
description: A memorial service for Eric Siday, a composer of electronic music and the bubbling tune for the Maxwell House coffee pot will be held at noon today at the Riverside Memorial Chapel.

title: Caso Decries Rising Cost Of Health Care and Relief
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 27Declaring that welfare and medical assistance costs mandated by the higher levels of government are driving their counties to the verge of bankruptcy, Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive, said that Nassau's expenditures for health services increased by 5,500 percent between 1950 and 1974.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: One for the Money
description: Since their introduction in the late 1960's, the costs of buying and operating fleets of giant widebodied jets that doubled passenger capacity to 350 or 400 per plane helped push several airlines close to the financial brink. But Braniff International Corporation couldn't be happier with its investment in the jumbo.

title: Signs His Work
description: AS a young art snr dent at Ohio University, Kevin Doherty developed some definite and somewhat unusual, ideas about art and artists.

title: Benjamin F. Meisner, 85, Invented Electronic Organ
description: MIAMI, March 27 (UPI)Benjamin Franklin Miessner, inventor of an electronic organ electronic piano and other musical and radio equipment, died at, his home Thursday at the age of 85.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Bridge Fans Vie in Bergen
description: ALMOST all of New Jersey's topranked contract bridge experts are at Montvale High School this weekend, looking for a pot of gold at the end of rainbow. The pot of gold is the Bermuda. Bowl, emblem of world team supremacy, and the road to, it might seem almost infinite in length.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor: Hurrah! Harold C. Schonberg's perceptive comments on the Celebration of Contemporary Music recently held at Juilliard rang sweetly in the ears of this composer. One could not help but groan at the sight of the program for this series, because it simply reinforces the feeling of young composers that the universities have a stranglehold over the public outlets for contemporary music.

title: Lois Mackenzie Is Wed
description: Lois Ann Mackenzie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Mackenzie of Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L. I., was married at noon yesterday to Peter Charles Grygotis, son of Mr, and Mrs. Peter M. Grygotis of Normandy Beach, N. J. The pastor, the Rev. Stanert L. Dransfield, performed the ceremony In the Old First Presbyterian Church in Huntington.

title: College and School Results
description: College and School Results

title: NEWS GROUP SCORES INQUIRER PICKETING
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)  The nation's largest association of journalists condemned today the picketing in Philadelphia that threatened publication of The Philadelphia Inquirer earlier this month.

title: Sports Today
description: Start of the United States Grand Prix West, at Long Beach, Calif.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
description: Aqueduct Jockeys

title: Only 14 Cases Have Been Tried Under the 1974 Law
description: WASHINGTONUnited Stales Imports of a product called specialty steel, stainless and other highalloy steels, amounted to $200 million last year, or twotenths of one percent of the country's annual imports of $100 billion of things that range from raw materials to finished automobiles.

title: Notes: Two Nights for The Price Of One
description: A newly established program gives guests in selected hotels and motels a second night's lodging free of charge if they have paid the Bicentennial Year sum of $19.76 to gain membership in a club called TECCO (for Travel, Entertainment Club Corporation). The directory TECCO supplies its members lists 270 hotels and motels in 43 states and some foreign countries, principally Canada and Mexico, that have contracted to honor the club card. A membership fee will be payable each year.

title: Best Sellers
description: Best Sellers

title: BEEF PRICE TREND IS MOVING LOWER
description: CHICAGO, March 27Supermarket shoppers who have been enjoying slightly lower beef prices this month should continue to do so, at least until early summer, though what they buy may not be quite as fat as they have had before. The country's cattle feeding lots, where ranch animals are fattened to choice and prime grade weights, are now full again for the first time in more than a year.

title: Obseruations on the Mores Of a Social SubGroup
description: The Arvee are found usually in national and state parks, private campgrounds, places called KOA (which may have a religious or political significance) andoff seasonin backyards. The social anthropologist Mede R. Pershun has been missing since April 1, 1975, when he was observed streaking from a campground in the Midwest shouting Sheraton! Plaza! St. Regis! For several months he had been engaged in a field study of the social subgroup he chose to call Arveethe owners of recreational vehicles. I have attempted, in the following article, to present his observations and findings. It is based upon Pershun's notes and tapes, which were discovered by a distraught cleaning woman in a California Holiday Inn shortly after the professor's disappearance.

title: Fashion
description: Designers both here and in Paris have enthusiastically endorsed the tunic for spring and summer. The tunic may be as casual an elongated shirt or as dressy as an anklelength fall of crepe de chine. It looks newest when it's lean and uncluttered, with slits at the sides. This season the tunic is usually shown over pants, but the more adventurous wearer might slip it on over skirts or culottes. Come the first hot spell of summer, we may see tunics over bathing suits, or even over nothing at all.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Mail. Every time the postman calls, he brings a handful of press releases. Most deserve only a scanning, a few seem worth following up to discover what lies behind them. Two of the latter kind, received this week:

title: Born Again
description: This is a difficult book to review in that one cannot remain detached from it. Perhaps the best tribute that can be paid to it is that it is impossible to judge it solely as a book: one necessarily becomes involved with a human being named Chuck Colson. Before I was halfway through, I was alternately cheering him on in his peculiar pilgrim's progress and groaning over his multiple stupidities.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Article 7  No Title

title: Black Officials Here Show No Fervor for Candidates
description: None of us are really emotionally involved with any of our candidates, Representative Charles B. Rangel asserted. We're committed, but it's with a small c.

title: The White Supremacists Have the Strongest Military Forces
description: If southern Africa drifts into war, the conflict will involve guerrillas, regular troops, mercenarie and armed civilians who are prepared for a conflict that is likely to range from helicopterborne assaults to the single shot in the night through a farmhouse window.

title: STAMPS
description: Plate block collectors, still struggling with what to do with a block of 50 flag stamps, may soon find themselves an endangered species and perhaps even a vanished species.

title: Daniol Schorr's Mother Dies
description: Tillie Godiner Schorr, mother of Daniel Schorr, the CBS News broadcaster, died Friday in Monteflore Hospital, the Bronx. She was 84 years old and lived in the Hebrew Home for the Aged, Riverdale, the Bronx Mrs. Schorr was the widow of Louis Schorr, a realestate man She leaves another son, Alvin executive director of the Community Services Society of New York; a brother, Haftali Godi, ner: a sister, Ethel Finkelstein and five grandchildren.

title: Dance: Phoebe Neville, True Original
description: Someone is always about to be throttledusually from the rearin Phoebe Neville's dance pieces. She is an authentic Gothic spirit, with the wit to make the outrageous seem credible in her highly theatrical works. She is an original.

title: Gary Myers Jr. to Wed Victoria Bauer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond W. Bauer of Westfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, victoria Margaret Bauer, to Gary Catterton Myers Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Myers of Greenbelt, Md. A July wedding at the Presbyterian Church In Westfield is planned.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Early this month the Metropolitan Opera announced its repertory for next season, and it was almost as if somebody over there were bucking for the Legion of Honor. In Rudolf Bing's day, the repertory was overwhelmingly Italian, and the Italians were overwhelmingly represented by Verdi. French opera was down to a minimum. In a repertory of over 25 operas, there might have been two that were French.

title: Radiation Benefits, Risks In Breast Cancer Debated
description: ST. PETERSBURG BEACH, Fla., March 27  The use of radiation to detect and treat hreast cancer, both the subjects of intense controversy among medical experts, was discussed here yesterday at the American Cancer Society's seminar for science writers.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Donald S. MacNaughton's criticism of the press The Businessman Versus the Journalist (March 7) must have raised gales of Homeric laughter in the newsrooms across the country.

title: Montreal Olympics: A BillionDollar PhotoFinish
description: MONTREALPicture yourself planning a dinner party and then falling asleep six hours before the guests are due to arrive.

title: Jackson Says Carter Seeks To Excuse a Loss in State
description: BUFFALO, March 27Senator Henry M. Jackson, in one of his strongest attacks on rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, accused Jimmy Carter today of, whining and trying to find  an excuse in advance for a potential loss in the April 6 New York State primary election.

title: New Role for Old Urban Houses: Hair Salons
description: WORCESTER, Mass.The current fascination with a simpler way of life appears to hove spread to the salons in this central Massachusetts city, where, in recent months, several proprietors of haircutting establishments have abandoned conventional facilities to move their shops to the more intimate and elegant, surroundings of some of the city's spacious old homes.

title: ART VIEW
description: Much of the best art of this century is the work of late developers: men and women who felt their way around the world, and around art, before starting on the work for which they would become known. This is especially true of the American artists who came to the fore in the late 1940's, and it is conspicuously true of Tony Smith, whose sculptures are now on view at Fourcade, Droll Inc.

title: Neighbors Grow Their Best Vegetables By a Dam Site
description: When the Federal government moves in to plan flood prevention programs, the community leaders often become nervous for there is talk of dams and other retarding structures that could alter the life of the town. But in the community of Bloomfield, Conn., the story has a happy ending. The region now has a 224acre floodwater storage basin with assorted multiple uses not the least of which is a community garden.

title: Law to Aid Nonsmokers
description: LANSING, Mich., March 27 (AP)Michigan restaurants will have to set up nosmoking areas by April, 1977, under a bill signed into law by Gov. William G. Milliken. The law, signed Wednesday, requires restaurants seating at least 50 persons to post signs in the areas and seat patrons in them on request.

title: Eatery to Go
description: Hong Kong, wellknown for its exports, has come up with a new one to intrigue the budding entrepreneur and delight the lover of Oriental food. It is a prefabricated Chinese restaurant, entirely equipped including the fortune cookies.

title: SHOP TALK
description: AS the saying goes: For want of a nail, the shoe was lost  For want of a shoe, the horse was lost  And so went the rider, the battle, the kingdom and all.

title: Trees, And How to Save Them
description: THE man came down his rearporch steps and strode toward me across the big, shady yard. When he walked up to where I stood in the lane, trying to focus a camera, he asked: Why are you taking the back of my house?

title: The Nation
description: The chairman of the House Budget Committee has proposed that the Federal Government spend more next year than President Ford wants it to, but less than many House Democrats, including some members of the committee itself, wish. The chairman's recommendations rather than Mr. Ford's request are expected to give Congress's debate over spending its shape.

title: Concert: College Choir
description: The Hamilton  Kirkland Choir from Hamilton College and Kirkland College in Clinton, N.Y., made its New York debut at Town Hall on Friday night under the direction of Lee Spear. The Hamilton men and Kirkland women make up an ensemble of more than 50 choristers. The thoroughness of their training was apparent as they performed an extensive and demanding program of sacred works from memory. Among the composers represented were Tallis, Gibbons, Purcell, Billings, Ives, Berkeley, Halsey Stevens and Randall Thompson.

title: Shoals for the European Float
description: WASHINGTONThere has been a currency crisis of sorts in Europe this year and the French franc has once again dropped out of the European joint float. Does it all make any difference to this country? Does it matter to the future of that amorphous thing called the international monetary system"?

title: The Region
description: The tenor of the relationship between New York City and its financial overseers, Governor Carey and  the statedominated Emergency Financial Control Board, has changed perceptibly. The city is trying to play a more aggressive role than it has been In determining its own future. However the relationship alters, for both sides the task remains the same: to cope with the fact of the city's poor financial condition by cutting back the services and amenities residents have come to depend on.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: April 2 Eastgate Dunes Centre, MG Car Club night rally; start at Convention Hall, Asbury Park, N.J. Registration: 6:30 P.M., first car off 7:30. Information: Denny Gallagher, phone (201)7750900 days and (201)5311496 evenings.

title: Food
description: If it is possible to hazard a general statement about a subject as varied as Italy's fish cookery, it is that one coast, the Adriatic, yields the finest fish, while the other, the one facing the islands and the African continent beyond, the most unusual and imaginative dishes. This is not as paradoxical as it may seem. The flavor of the fish from Adriatic waters is so fine that there is no temptation to do much with it except to husband it safely past the cook's hands and onto the table. That is why from Venice to Bari most fish is grilled, fried, boiled, made into soup and, basta, nothing more.

title: The Nightmare Of Crib Death
description: STONY BROOK SANDI BOSHAK left her threemonthold baby napping on the patio one afternoon and went inside to set the table for dinner. She came out a few moments later and picked the baby up. She noticed blueish marks on his lips. She took off his hat, saw that his head, too, was discolored. Her baby was dead.

title: ACCUSED OFFICIAL GETS HEALTH POST
description: Nicholas Scoppetta, the Commissioner of Investigation, said last week that he was reviewing the case of Al Schwarz, an assistant health commissioner who was accused by two state commissions of coziness with nursinghome operators.

title: Necessary Veto
description: Of all the regions in the world where a spark could ignite a general conflagration and even a SovietAmerican nuclear war, none is more dangerous than the Middle East. The search for a provisional settlement between the Arabs and Israel has been given higher priority by the United States than all but one or two international issues and the same should be true of the United Nations, whose vocation is peace.

title: Endpaper
description: It happened in Chelm, a city of fools. Where else could it have happened? On a winter morning in the community house Gronam Ox, the wisest man of Chelm, and his five sages, Dopey Lekish, Zeinvel Nitwit., Tritel Fool, Sender Donkey and Shmendrik Numskull, sat at a long table. All six looked tired and had red eyes from lack of sleep. For seven days and nights they had been thinking about a problem which they could not solve. The treasury of Chelm was empty. For many weeks Gronam. Ox and his sages had not received their salaries.

title: Delegates Doodle as Procedural Details Skiw Down Progress at the U.N.'s Law of the Sea Conference
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 27The 1,200 participants from 156 countries laboring over a future treaty on the uses of the oceans and the seabed seem at the end of two weeks to be struggling against a common enemyboredom.There is too much nitpicking, complained a Scandinavian naval officer after a committee spent two days haggling over the wording of a single treaty article.

title: John Denver Pop Music's Wholesome Guru
description: R's very easy to criticize John Denver. So easy, in fact, that even John Denver does it. I have a tendency to sing sharp, the nation's bestselling pop singer says, lounging on a couch recently in a V.I.P. room at the Denver Airport, I'd like my voice to be more resonant think it's a little thin. I'd like to have a wider range. I'm not a great singer. I'm not a great songwriter.

title: Pollution Talks Asked
description: YOKOHAMA, span, March 27 (AP)The City of Yokohama has demanded that the Government negotiate with the United States for drastic cuts in air pollution on American military bases. Mayor ichio Asukata made the demand this week after city officials examined 7 of 10 United States

title: The Gemini Contenders
description: Dead of night, Salonika, Greece, December 1939. A vault is being moved from its ancient monastic hiding place to protect it from the Nazis. It is loaded on a train for shipment to northern Italy. There, a rich and powerful padrone, Savarone FontiniCristi, one of the leaders of the antiFascist movement, will safeguard it. In the vault is a document that could rock the foundations of the civilized world and change the destiny of mankind. Its implications, it is hinted, could make the holocaust pale by comparison.

title: Susan Martell to Wed Stephen Baird May 22
description: Mr. and Mrs, Norman Martell of Wyomissing, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Carol Martell, to Stephen White Baird of New York, a personnel officer with the First National City Bank.

title: Alan Delahoy Fiance Of Jessica Kennedy
description: Poppy M, Kennedy of Matawan, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Jessica Ellen Kennedy, to Alan Edward Delahoy, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Delahoy of London.

title: Bloustein's Standin Gets a Hand
description: A POSTER in Dr. Henry R. Winkler's office has a quote, above a picture of Winston Churchill, that reads: Let Us Go Forward Together. Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, the Rutgers University president, is in the hospital, and Dr. Winkler and the university's central admmistrativr staff are trying to do just that.

title: ADULT EDUCATION LAGGING IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, March 27After four and a half years a project extending educational opportunities to employees in France has bogged down, largely because of an apparent lack of interest among the potential beneficiaries.

title: Assembly Unit Urges Dismissal of Racing Board
description: An Assembly investigative unit called yesterday for the dismissal of all three members of the Racing and Wagering Board, accusing them of failure to regulate the harness racing industry and of blocking audits of the tracks.

title: Gets Athletic Post
description: MANHATTAN, Kan., March 27 (AP)John (Jersey) Jermier, an assistant athletic director at Iowa, was named athletic director of Kansas State University today. Jermier will be the first director of athletics under the schools merger of men's and women's athletics.

title: Wilma Rudolph Lends Grace to Reunion
description: The tall lithe woman who won three gold medals at the 1960 Olympic Games in Rome was gracefully making her way through the offices of the Public Broadcasting Service in New York one day last week, reminiscing with friends and fans about what she describes as, the most glorious days in her life. At 36 years old, Wilma Rudolph has managed to keep the youthful look and the charm and grace that made her the darling of the 1960 games.

title: The Tennis Clinic
description: Do you get a pain in your elbow when you play tennis? Aching shoulder or back? A sore wrist or a sprained ankle? The best thing to do is try to prevent such ailments, according to a leading tennis doctor.

title: Mindy E. Meislich Engaged to Marry
description: Mindy Ellen Meislich and Jan Charles Harrow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton B. Horrow of Philadelphia, plan to be married next spring. Their engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. Estelle K. Meislich and Dr. Herbert Meislich of New Milford,. N.J.

title: World News Briefs
description: LISBON, March 27 (Reuters) Two people were wounded by gunfire during a clash between Maoists and Communists in central Lisbon early today, the police said. Two more were injured by flying stones.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Tom Seaver of the Mets gives an example of how his militancy during the playerowner dispute failed to harm.his image: My boss from Sears called me during all of this and asked me if I wanted to work down here. He was concerned that I had no income.

title: Sing a Song of Oscar
description: At tomorrow night's Academy Award ceremonies. there will he awards for film music in three categories. The categories, and the nominations in each category:

title: Brown on Maryland Ballot
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 27 (AP)  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. will get his first test as a Presidential contender in the May 18 Maryland Democratic primary, his campaign manager said today. Mr. Brown's name was put on the Maryland ballot by Secretary of State Fred Wineland, who wrote that he had decided the California Governor was a generally advocated candidate.

title: The Athlete's Mind Versus Starting Gun
description: I stood there, not quite comprehending, as The StarSpangled Banner was played. To the spectator, this anthem was sentimental and symbolized everything that the athletes stood for. In reality for the athlete, it stood for pure hell. Hell in the sense that it meant the start of another national swimming meet and the end of just one more year of pain.

title: Two novels
description: A young woman, Jane Claire, is consumed by interest in Paul Tagliatti, an artist whose shadowy, alienated life, prodigious drinking, sexual promiscuity and true accomplishments have caused his work to increase in value exponentially since his death, supposedly in a violent argument with a drunken Mexican. At a retrospective exhibition of his work, Jane meets Wexford Bone, the preeminent collector of Tagliatti paintings. Because she is knowledgeable, as well as enthusiastic, Bone hires her to do research on Tagliatti, cataloguing the man's art and filling in the blank spots in his biography. But as she soon discovers, Bone may have less academic motives for his curiosity. It seems that eight Tagliatti paintings, worth approximately $2 million, have never been accounted for, and other people are pursuing them as avidly as Bone.

title: Indiana, Michigan In N.C.A.A. Final
description: Rutgers was routed by Michigan, 8670, and its 31game winning streak was snapped in the semifinals of the National Collegiate basketball tournament.

title: Nun Tells Conference Gospels and Doctrines of the Church Are Not Bars to the Ordination of Women
description: More than 600 Roman Catholic nuns, only a handful dressed in traditional habits, broke into sustained applause yesterday when Sister Elizabeth Carroll of the Religious Sisters of Mercy told them that neither the Gospels nor the central doctrines of the church excluded women from the ordained ministry.

title: London Bomb Explosion Injures 80 at Exhibition Hall
description: LONDON, March 27 (AP)A twopound bomb concealed in a trash bin exploded today at a London exhibition hall crowded With about 15,000 people injuring 80 persons, Scotland Yard reported.

title: MOSLEM ALLIANCE IN LEBANON GAINS MOUNTAIN AREAS
description: JIWAR ALHAWZ, Lebanon, March 27Moslem and leftist forces are on the move along the steep, rocky slopes of these mountains 15 miles east of Beirut in a slowmoving but crucial battle that is probably more important than the fighting in Beirut.

title: Richardson to Lead Bribe Investigation
description: LA CROSSE, Wis., March 27 President Ford said tonight that he would establish a Cabinetlevel commission to examine the problems raised by corporate bribes and other payments made abroad by American companies.

title: ELSIE B. ROBINSON
description: Else Berger Robinson, for more than 30 years a teacher of history at Erasmus Hall High School, Brooklyn, died Tuesday in Tticson, Ariz. She was 67 years old and lived in Coolidge, Ariz.

title: BRIDGE
description: ONLY a handful of contractbridge players from Long Island attended the Amerscan Contract Bridge League's Spring National Championships, which ended in Kansas City a week ago, and they were not expected to win any major titles.

title: Gymnast Posts Perfect Mark
description: A marvel of exactitude from the time she performed on the vaulting horse for a perfect mark of 10, 14yearold Nadia Comaneci of Rumania lead the way yesterday in the qualifying round of the American Cup interrtational gymnastics competition.

title: Michigan Broadens Job Law
description: LANSING, Mich., March 27 (AP)Gov. William G. Milliken has signed a bill that prohibits discrimination in employment based on marital status, height or weight. The new prohibitions are added to sections of the law that forbid discrimination based on race, color, religion, national origin, sex, ago or ancestry.

title: They're Off, Con Brio, to Europe
description: WHEN I went to high school they didn't do that, mused Rafael R. Barreda.

title: 91 Shot Captures Westchester Mile
description: While fresh horses from the South helped produce some of the season's largest fields, a winter resident named Double Edge Sword won the $56,950 Westchester Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: The selling of a candidate
description: It is two days before Christmas in a film studio in a Philadelphia suburb. On the screen above an editing console, Jimmy Carter appears in a pool hall in a small Florida town, smiling and shaking hands. The picture freezes, then the film is reversed. The Carter smile shrivels on the screen and the outstretched hand is yanked away. The candidate walks backwards at rapid pace, as if pulled by a string.

title: Elizabeth Miller Bride Of Geoffrey N. Brint
description: In St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church here yesterday afternoon, Elizabeth Fain Miller, daughter of William Dawes Miller of New York and Southampton, L. I., and the late Celeste Fain Miller, was married to Geoffrey Nigel Brint, son of Frederick D. Brint of Bath, England, and, the late Dorothy Mead Brint.

title: Tigers Rout Mets; 4th Straight Loss
description: LAKELAND, Fla., March 27 A fiverun first inning, at the expense of Craig Swan, was all the Detroit Tigers needed today to deal the Mets their fourth straight defeat, 105. The Mets have not won an exhibition game this spring.

title: Scholastic Stars Running for Olympics
description: Houston McTear, who many believe wilt become the first high school athlete to make the United States men's Olympic track team since 1968, may find that he's not the only such athlete on the About American squad. Track and McTear, the Baker Field (Fla.) High sprinter Who is coholder of the world record of 9 seconds for the 100yard dash, is the nation's leading scholastic runner. But several others have recently emerged as candidates for, at least, the United States trials.

title: Much of It Is a Matter of Keeping Up Appearances
description: PARISFrance's Finance Minister, JeanPierre Fourcade, offered gracious thanks for the honor when he was asked recently about France's apparent role as leader, or bridgehead, of the industrialized nations in their relations with the developing countries.

title: Paper backs
description: C. S. LEWIS: A Biography, by Roger Lancelyn Green and Walter Hooper. (Harcourt/Harvest. 53.95.) An affectionate biography of the shy, rather oldfashioned Oxford and Cambridge don best remembered for his writings with an evangelical Christian flavor and for his fanciful Hernia stories.

title: Radical Sport Movement ReExamined
description: Whatever happened to the radical sport movement of the late 60's? At that time, a threatened boycott of the 1968 Olympic Games by black American athletes and the televised blackpower demonstrations on the victory stand dramatized in a novel way that international sport had existed in bondage to one ideology or another for many years, and that an athletic minority no longer found this role worthy.

title: Radio
description: Metropolitan tenor; Prof. Charles Ludington.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: A TRADE DEFICIT OF $140.8 MILLION was reported for the United States in February following a deficit of $282.1 million in January. The Commerce Department also said the basic balance of payments last year was in surplus by $1.4 billion  New car sales in the second 10 days of March were up 42 percent from yearearlier levels to 249.231 units and manufacturers are planning to increase their production schedules  McGraw Hill Publications reported that United States Industry operated at 73.5 percent of capacity in February, unchanced from January.

title: FILM VIEW; Would You Let Your Sister Invest in a Plot Like That?
description: Ray Stark? Carlo Ponti? Sam Spiegel? Dino de Laurentiis? Roger Corman? Francis Ford Coppola? Harry Saltzman? Joe Levine? Tom Laughlin? Which one do you want to be? The name of the game is Movie Mogul or, Would You Let Your Sister Invest In a Movie Like This and, If You Would, How Much Money Do You Think The Movie Would Make?

title: Robert Roy Jr. Fiance Of Catherine D. Ward
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Fordham Ward of Morris Plains, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catharine Dyer Ward, to Robert Howell Roy Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Roy of Gladwvne. Pa.

title: Wolves in Yugoslavia
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia March 27 (Reuters)  Packs of hungry wolves attacked several villages in southeast Yugoslavia, killing 60 sheep, 15 cows and several horses and donkeys, the Belgrade newspaper Politika has reported. Hunters killed more than 10 wolves in one pursuit and two in another.

title: Commodore Plan Is Key to the City's TaxAid Strategy
description: The city administration's program to spark an economic resurgence by granting substantial tax relief or favorable leasing arrangements to major new commercial and industrial development projects will receive its first test next ??? when the Board of Estimate votes on a proposal to reconstruct the Commodore Hotel at Lexington Avenue and 42d Street.

title: Carlin Vickery, James Capalino Planning Bridal
description: Carlin Borden Vickery, who is in her third year at the New York University School of Medicine, and James F. Cepalino of New York, executive assistant to Representative Edward I. Koch, Democrat of New York, plan to be married in December.

title: Two Vessels Make Maiden Voyages Here
description: Maiden voyages in the port are becoming less frequent as seaborne trade is conducted by modern and large ships. Two new vessels, the cruise liner Calypso ana the automobile carrier Hoegh Trigger, are among the rew. The Calypso is due here this afternoon to start a twomonth series of cruises. The Hoegh Trigger arrived last week to deliver 2,400 Volkswagens.

title: Ft. Lee Tract Unused
description: A 14acre tract of land that could solve Fort Lee's budget problems sits like an open wound just of the approach to the George Washington Bridge, its weedgrown lots an ugly reminder of one of the borough's most sensational business scandals.

title: Eggs Against Influenza
description: President Ford's proposal for mass influenza innoculations won't strain the nation's hens, who would be asked to give up 50 to 100 million eggs for the cause.

title: ExPresident in Manila Bids Parliament Meet
description: MANILA, March 27The only surviving former President of the Philippines came out openly today with a pledge that he would pursue all legal means to restore democracy and freedom to Filipinos by calling upon the Parliament to convene following a period of martial law under President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Ann McNamara to Wed Marschall Smith in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. James W. McNamara of Rye, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann McNamara, to Marschall Imboden Smith, son of Col. Lowell B. Smith, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Smith of Paoli, Pa.

title: Maine Spring: Season Of False Promises
description: My Wife, in most ways a most admirable woman, possesses one disturbing fault: she has no patience with Maine spring. In recent years I've been cajoled into leaving the state for three weeks during what she refers to flatly as The Mud Season; or, if we happen to be away, into extending our absence until the Maine winter has conceded defeat.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Carey yesterday appointed a physicist, N. Richard Werthamer, as the $47,800ayear chairman the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority. Mr. Carey also announced the appointment David Sive as a nonsalaried member of the authority's board.

title: Scenic Tours for Bikers
description: Following are two New Jersey trips from Bicycle Tours In and Around New York, by Dan Carlinshy and David Heim, tragstrom Company, 450 West 33d Street, New York, N. Y. 10001.

title: RARE PLANTS HELD UNUSED RESOURCE
description: There is a kind of hedge in Central America whose nutritious leaves taste like spinach.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Every writer has his stylistic peculiarities, to greater or lesser degree. In two recent cases, the stylisms leap right from the page and attack the reader. In STATELINE by John van der Zee (Harcourt Brace Javanovich, $7.95) the stylisms are in the punctuation. Van der Zee simply refuses to use quotation marks, and this takes a little getting used to before the reading pace becomes normal. In the case of A WITCHDANCE IN BAVARIA by Noah Webster (Doubleday, $5.95) the peculiarities are in the adverbial part of the writing.

title: ASTRONAUT'S PACK AIDING RESEARCH
description: Although the backpack that Neil A. Armstrong wore on the first walk on the moon lies forlorn among the historic debris at Tranquility Base, a duplicate of one component of that pack has emerged as a surprising but important element in Mr. Armstrong's newest adventure.

description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., March 27  Roscoe Tanner upset Arthur Ashe and Jimmy Connors brushed aside Bjorn Borg today in the semifinals of the American Airlines Tennis Games at Mission Hills Country Club here.

Snyder of Westfield, became the bride of Bruce C. Williams. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl J. Williams of Lafayette Hill, Pa.

Judge James Stern of Philadelphia's Common Pleas Court performed the ceremony at the Whitemarsh Valley Country Club in Whitemarsh, Pa.

title: In Memoriam
description: COHENAnnelte Rose (nee Goldberg). March 24, 1959. In cherished and loving memory of our dearly beloved mother and grandmother. Always In our hearts, sadly missed.

title: Banned Authors Answer Back
description: ASCHOOL committee has denounced some books againout in Levittown this time. One of the books was mine. I hear about unAmerican nonsense like this twice a year or so. One time out in North Dakota, the books were actually burned in a furnace. I had to laugh. It was such an ignorant, dumb, superstitious thing to do.

description: LOS ANGELES, March 27The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors voted this week to study what impact a withdrawal from the Federal Social Security system might have on county finances.

title: VICTOR A. BENNETT
description: Victor A. Bennett, founder and former president of the company that bears his name, an international advertising and public relations firm here, died yesterday in Rutland (Vt.) Hospital, after having been injured in an auto accident March. 17. He was 69 years old and lived in Dorset Vt.

title: For young readers
description: Many blind children in the 812 age group look forward each year to this anthology of children's literature from the Braille Institute of America. Braille books are so expensive to produce that children usually have to borrow them. Expectations costs $10 a copy to produce. Through donations from civic groups and individuals the book is provided as an outright gift to any legally blind child. It may be the only book many actually own.

title: Climbing Into The Roots
description: The opening poem of Reg Saner's new, and first, book is about hiking in the high Rockies. One section goes:

title: POLITICS
description: THREE months ago, Judith Hope, then the outgoing Supervisor of East Hampton Town, made the long lump from the East End to Albany when she was named Governor Carey's appointments secretary, also known as the Governor's patronage dispenser.

title: Stuart Scott Jr. Fiance of Miss Mulrenin
description: The engagement of Suzanne Mulrentn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Mulrenin of Osterville, Mass., to Stuart Scott Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Scott of New York and Dorset, Vt., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: The Rockefellers
description: Your fortune is rolling up, rolling up like an avalanche! Frederick T. Gates, the first manager of John D. Rockefeller'S vast business and philan, thropic enterprises, wrote heatedly to his patron at the time of the dissolution of the Standard Trust in 1911. You must distribute it faster than is grows; If you do not, it will crush you, and your children, and your children's children.

title: The Director's Approach Two Views
description: I've been sneaking up on this second career, this directorial thing, over the years, said Edward Albee. I started directing with The Zoo Story, American Dream and The Sand Box, in revivals, as early as 1963. I've even directed a couple of other people's playsI did Howard Moss's The Palace at 4 A.M. in East Hamptonand of course I did Seascape on Broadway last season.

title: Labor Fighting to Retain Edge in Election Outlays
description: WASHINGTON, March 27Organized labor is fighting a stubborn and sometimes camouflaged battle to retain a major political Weaponthe right to spend unlimited. unreported amounts of money from union treasuries to support candidates.

title: AntiPollution Effort Backfires
description: The Boating Pollution Cona trol Committee was formed few years ago by a group of Manhasset Bay boatmen who were trying to find an alternative to the holdingtank requirement for boats. And they succeeded. But successs has boomeranged in Manhasset Bay.

title: Italy Confiscating Ransoms to Deter Kidnappers
description: ROME, March 27The Italian police have decided to try new weapon to thwart kidnappingthey are confiscating the ransom money gathered by the victim's relatives.

title: Marion Whitlock Bride of Robert Frost
description: Marion Shepard Whitlock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Whitlock Jr. of Waterford, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon in New London, Conn., to Robert Haywood Frost, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradford R. Frost. also of Waterford. The Rev. Ralph E. Merrill performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Harkness Chapel at Connecticut College.

title: Patricia Egan to Marry May 29
