description: Gymnastic Summaries

title: Emmylou Harris Gives Concert; Singing More Straightforward
description: Emmylou Harris hag her growing legions of fans and more power to her and to them But her concert Saturday night at the Beacon Theater only confirmed what this observer, normally a hopeless sucker for just this Fort of women cruintryrockpop sinning has felt for some time. Miss Harris has her incontrovertible charms, but her voice seems ultimately too limited and her style too mannered for deeply satisfying effect.

title: U. S. High School Gymnast Tops World Stars
description: Bari Conner, an Illinois high school student who did not expect to beat some of the world's best gymnasts, did just that yesterday. He won the American Cup international gymnastics competition at Madison Square Garden.

title: G.O.P.Chief Vows Fight Over Conflicts Mandate
description: ALBANY, March 28Conflictofinterest regulations may be an applepie issue in politics these days, but to at least one top state official, a recent ruling by the state's Board of Public DiscloAlbany sure was more Notes like pie in the face. The sevenmember board told George Clark that he would have to resign from one of his two positionsas Republican county leader of Brooklyn or his $35,000ayear post as deputy executive director of the State Insurance Fund. The hoard denied Mr. Clark's appeal for an exemption from a regulation that forbids a state employee earning $30,000 or more from holding a political office.

title: Korean Investment Studied
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 28 (Reuters) An American economic mission arrived here today on a threeday visit to explore possibilities of increased investment in South Korea's petrochemical, banking, electronics and machinery Industries.

title: Candidates Support Campaign for Jews in Soviet
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington and Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona, Democratic Presidential hopefuls, ate a breakfast of stale bread and sardine scraps yesterday at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: Many Civil Servants Draw Higher Income as Retirees
description: When combined with Social Security benefits, pension plans for New York City and State employees provide many retirees with net income after taxes that is greater than the income they took home during their last working year.

description: British Football

title: Senate May Offer Its Tax Plan Today
description: TRENTON, March 28Democratic leaders of the State Senate may disclose their version of the proposed state income tax tomorrow. The Senate President, Matthew Feldman of Bergen County, met with three other top Democrats at New Brunswick on Friday to try to revise the bill approved by the Assembly, to add about $50 million to the revenue it would raise.

title: N.C.A.A. Final On Tonight
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 28 Johnny Orr, the Michigan basketball coach, said today, I'm getting tired of congratulating Bobby Knight [Indiana coach].

title: Radio
description: Radio

title: Kissinger's Warnings on Africa
description: WASHINGTON, March 28Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has surprised even some of his supporters by his persistent campaign to warn Cuba and the Soviet Union that the United States will not accept further Communist military intervention in Africa. Although virtually no one in Washington seems to believe that Congress would permit a United States confrontation with Cuba because of what the Cubans might do in Rhodesia, Mr. Kissinger has avoided ruling out any speculationeven the most bellicose.

title: Nixon on His Knees
description: WASHINGTONNixonhatred, that most profitable of media exploitations, reaches a crescendo this week with (1) the glorification on film of reportersturnedmindreaders Woodward and Bernstein, and (2) the publication Of their latest journafiction, which purports to be an account of the fallen President's last days in the White House.

title: Soetaert in Goal, Rangers Win, 42
description: The Rangers took a look at the future last night at Madison Square Garden. And if a 42 victory over the floundering Kansas City Scouts counts, the future bodes at least an improvement over a bleak present.

title: Deadlock in Ulster Angers Militant Protestant Forces
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 25In a grimy building on East Belfast's Newtonards Road, the militant Protestants of the Ulster Defense Association are charting their future in a mood of anger and puzzlement.

title: The Sports Scoreboard
description: The Sports Scoreboard

title: Reagan's Problem: New Ways to Persuade
description: Taken in the context of national and even Southern regional sentiment as it emerges from the second New York Times/CBS News national survey of the 1976 campaign, Ronald Reagan's upset victory over President Ford in the North Carolina primary last Tuesday appears to constitute an aberration. Mr. Ford was the Presidential choice of almost twothirds of the 529 Republicans around the country whose views on the campaign were sought in the poll. Mr. Reagan ran behind the President by about the same margin in the South, indicating that North Carolina did not typify regional sentiment.

title: Fairfield Entertains Its 10,000th Visitor From Foreign Land
description: WESTPORT, Conn., March 28 When Miriam Tlili stepped off the Penn Central train this morning, she became the 10,000th international visitor to Fairfield County, participating in a hospitality program that has been going on for 18 years.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The United States Attorney's office in Newark has started a fullscale investigation into possible irregularities surrounding the construction of deteriorating sections of Interstate Highway 287 in New Jersey. United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein said his office had ordered Federal engineers to take core samples of pavement and roadbeds to determine if contractors performed their work according to Federal and state standards.

title: Jackson Running at a Hard Pace Here
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson campaigned tirelessly from one side of the metropolitan area to the other yesterday, scattering promises of full employment and aid to the cities, declaring his liberalism, and making frequent jabs at Jimmy Carter, one of his two main rivals in the state's Democratic Presidential primary election.

title: U. S. Reports Gains in Its Campaign Against Improper Payments
description: WASHINGTON, March 28The Government believes it is making progress in a broad campaign it has mounted against improper payments by American corporations.

title: Issues 76: The Economy
description: The economic disorders of recent years  particularly the rapid inflation of 197374 and the deep slump of 197475insure that economic issues will play a major part in the 1976 Presidential election campaign. The most difficult problems facing the candidatesand the nationare to decide what the principal economic issues really are, to set priorities for their solution and to find means of dealing with seemingly contradictory problems without aggravating one at the expense of another.

title: The Managers Must Stand Trial
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 28 From this day forward, Sparky Anderson was saying, 24 managers in the major leagues would have to stand trial. He wasn't referring to the task of putting a team together in half the time usually allowed for spring training, although that is a burden that even he feels. The manager of Cincinnati's world champions has fewer problems than his lodge brothers, but he still worries about finding room for the right players on a 25man squad. Not only have the Reds added the useful outfielders, Mike Lum and Bob Bailey, to a team that already had George Foster, Cesar Geronimo, Ken Griffey, Mery Rettenmund and Ed Armhrister, but there are four or five rookies who cannot be protected they are farmed out again, and mistakes could he costly. That wasn't the test he referred to, though, and he wasn't talking about knowing when change pitchers. He was talking about handling 25 men so they would have some allegiance to the team.

title: Kissinger and Others of Cabinet Level Expected to Join Richardson
description: WASHINGTON, March 28The White House said today that a formal announcement and details would be made some time this week about the creation of a Cabinet level task force to Investigate the misconduct of American corporations overseas.

title: H.U.D. OVERRULES FT. LEE ON RENTS
description: FORT LEEThis borough's rent control ordinance, the toughest local rent law in the state, has been overruled, as it applies to one highrise apartment building, by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, and other apartment owners are getting ready to seek similar Federal action.

title: MAGAZINE REPORTS 1975 HEARST MOVES
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 28 (AP)Patricia Hearst had left William and Emily Harris, soldiers in the self  styled Symbionese Liberation Army, artd planned to flee to the East Coast in the weeks before Miss Hearst's arrest, according to Rolling Stone magazine.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Hopes for an early ceasefire in the Lebanese civil war faded after the failure of meetings yesterday in Damascus between President Hafez alAssad of Syria and Kamal Jumblat, the pivotal figure in the leftistMoslem alliance in Lebanon. Leftist forces, who believe that they have the military advantage, increased their pressure on two fronts, provoking sharp fighting.

title: Celtics Take Title; Top Knicks,10094
description: BOSTON, March 28After a game John Havlicek looks a little more worn. He breaths a little heavier, he doesn't get downcourt as quickly, his playing time has been cut and his left knee is aching. But his importance to the Boston Celtics has not diminished.

title: Turkish Official Praises New Accord With the U.S.
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 28 (Reuters)Deputy Prime Minister Turhan Feyzioglu today described the new joint defense agreement between Turkey and the United States as a great victory for the shapers of Turkish foreign policy.

title: Udall Proposes Programs To Reduce City's Burdens
description: Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona, declaring himself the most urbanoriented of the candidates for the Democratic nomination for President, has proposed an array of Federal programs to ease New York City's financial burdens and stem urban blieht.

title: On Threatening Cuba
description: In testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee last week, Secretary of State Kissinger appeared to be playing down the notion of any imminent crisis with Cuba and the Soviet Union over military intervention in Africa or elsewhere. But if, as he said, there is no urgent situation at this moment that requires a crisis decision, the Administration would be welladvised to halt the public psychological warfare campaign it has been carrying on recently against Cuba in particular.

title: TRUCKERS VOTING TO CALL A STRIKE
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., March 28 (AP)Early results, of weekend voting by 400,000 teamsters indicated overwhelming authorization for a strike that could bring trucks across the nation to a halt, union officials said today.

title: 1,524 Queried by Phone Under Random Choice
description: The New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from March 18 to March 24 with 1,524 adult men and women across the continental United States.

title: Egypt Replaces Heads Of Major Newspapers
description: CAIRO, March 28 (AP)New directors for Egypt's major press and publication houses were announced today, replacing twin brothers Ali and Mustafa Amin, who were removed from the helm of the masscirculation newspaper Al Akhbar.

title: 2 Share First Place in the Met's National Auditions
description: John Carpenter, a 29yearold tenor from Natchitoches, La., shared first place yesterday iA the annual Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions and was offered a contract by the opera.

title: Shrinking Constitution
description: In a significant ruling last week, the Supreme Court raised higher than ever the barriers against hearing constitutional civil rights and civil liberties cases in Federal courts. It thus continued its now clearly defined policy of diminishing the role of the Federal court system as the bulwark of the rights of American citizens.

title: Newark Symphony Hall Reopens With L'Elisir
description: NEWARK, March 28Symphony Hall, a 50yearold, rather cavernous auditorium a few blocks from City Hall, has not normally upstaged the events that take place in it. But tonight, for the final performance of the New Jersey State Opera's 10th anniversary season, it was the hall and not the opera or the performers that was the real star of the show.

title: Caballe, Pavarotti Make Met Toheme A Memorable Night
description: Montserrat Caball and Luciano Pavarotti in La Bohme made Saturday night a Metropolitan Opera night to temember. Theatrically knowing, vocally stirring, visually matched, the operatic superstars galvanized the audience into repeated ovations that may have held up the stage action, but certainly sparked a gala atmosphere.

title: Surge in Potato Futures Prices Is Upsetting Farmers
description: There was another mysterious surge in Maine potato futures prices last week, which further widened the gap between the cash market and that for produce deliverable through this May.

title: WORLD'S POPULATION REACHES 4 BILLION
description: CIIICAGO, March 28 (AP)The world's population passed the four billion mark today, according to the population clock at the Museum of Science and Industry.

title: Richard M. Warshauer Marries Miss Dobrin
description: Rosalind Dobrin, daughter of Mrs. Lionel D. Dobrin of New York and the late Mr. Dobrin, was married yesterday afternoon to Richard M. Warshauer, editor and publisher of the Eastside Courier, a Manhattan weekly newspaper. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: Advertising
description: Just a little over a month after Lever Brothers announced it would be moving some of the advertising buying responsibilities out of its agencies, Norton Simon Inc., the country's 23d largest national advertiser, announced plans to do the same.

description: At the Jewish Community Center of West Hempstead, L.I., yesterday afternoon, Diane Sonia Daniel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt Daniel of New Hyde Park, L.I., was married to Lawrence A. Greenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Greenberg of Asheville, N.C. Rabbi Abraham M. Moseson performed the ceremony.

title: Richard Arlen, Actor, Dies; Star of First Oscar Film
description: NORTH HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 28 (UPI)  Richard Arlen, a silent screen actor who made the transition to talkies and starred in Wings in 1927, the first motion picture to win an Academy Award, died here today at the age of 75.

title: BIG SPREAD FOUND IN EYEGLASS COSTS
description: New Jersey prices for the same type or eyeglasses vary by as much as 350 percent and for the same kind of prescription drugs by as much as 300 percent, according to the findings of a survey made public yesterday at the State Consumer Affairs Division.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The first of seven Turboliners being built by Rohr Industries for the New York CityAlbanyBuffalo run arescheduled to be delivered to Amtrak in July, State Transportation Commissioner Raymond T. Schuler reported Mr. Schuler also expressed hope that track and signal imr provements in the Empire Corridor would he kept on schedule so that the new fivecar Turboliners might be used at their potential 125mileanhour speed as soon as possible.

title: Bulgaria Set for Congren
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 28 (UPI)Bulgaria gave its capital a final sprucing up today for its 11th Communist Party Congress, a weeklong event that diplomatic sources said was expected to be without surprises. Todor. Zhivkov, leader of the Bulgariaian Zommunist Party, will highlight the opening ses.sion tomorrow with a report on his country's development during the last fiye years.

title: An Act Derby Winner
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 28 (AP)An Act withstood the closing bid of Double Discount, a long shot, today and won the $157,700 Santa Anita Derby as Telly's Pop, the favorite ran out of the money.

description: The reaction to our articleand some subsequent commentsabout broccoli di rape continues unabated hut, prayerfully, may these be the final words on the subject.

title: TWO JEWISH GROUPS CRITICIZE SCRANTON
description: Two leaders of Jewish organizations yesterday sharply criticized William W. Scranton, American representative at the United Nations, for exaggerations and harshness in his remarks last week concerning Israel's occupation of the West Bank.

description: TEL AVIV, March 28Israel this weekend deported to Lebanon two Arabs who were candidates for mayor in two West Bank cities, and the action drew criticism from a supreme court justice, leftwing political parties and in the press.

title: SURGE BY CARTER ON NATIONAL BASIS INDICATED IN POLL
description: Former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia appears to have translated his primary victories into an extraordinarily broad and diverse base of support by Democrats all over the country, according to a national poll completed last week by The New York Times and CBS News.

title: Transport Workers Union Was Born and Achieved Its Maturity on the City's Subway and Bus System
description: They are motormen and conductors, bus drivers and mechanics, maintenace men and thangemakers, inspectors and porters. They are the  city's bus and subway workers.

title: Theater: Medal of Honor Rag Relives Trauma of Vietnam
description: A man suffers a psychotic moment in battlehe breaks through a membrane of his existence, he is literally traumatized. He goes berserk. He does just the terrible things, those almost mythic feats of violence and killing, that society has trained him not to do. And society rewards him with a medal. His friends are dead, he is paralyzed with survivor guilt, and yet society still insists on giving him a medal. In the case of Dale Jackson it was the Medal of Honor.

title: 3 in House Charge Scare Tactics Are Used on the Defense Budget
description: WASHINGTON, March 28Three Democratic members of the House Armed Services Committee complained yesterday that the Administration was trying to spook the American people into approvirl a higher military budget by telling goblin stories about the Soviet military threat.

title: in Southern Africa
description: If the most probable locale for the next crisis remains southern Africa, Americans have to understand that this area offers formidable obstacleslogistical, political, moralfor any effective American action to counter Cuban involvement. Fortunately, the black governments and black liberation movements in the area have said they do not wish nor envision Cuban military action in either Rhodesia or Namibia (SouthWest Africa).

title: MANSFIELD WARY OF AFRICA MOVES
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (Reuters) Mike Mansfield, the Senate Majority leader, said today that Cuban intervention in Africa was not the responsibility of the United States but that of European nations that once had colonies on the continent.

title: Analysts Favor Trucking Industry's Outlook
description: A strike threat overhanging the trucking industry has not dimmed Wall Street's optimistic view of the industry's financial prospects. Trucking, which suffered severely during the recession, has been recovering briskly but faces a potential roadblock in Wednesday's expiration of the contract with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: French University Students Defiant Over Government Reforms and jobs
description: GRENOBLE, France  The mood f nervous defiance that has spread rapidly in recent weeks among France's 850,000 university students is pervasive here on the suburban campus at Grenoble University.

title: Edwin Franden Dakin, 77, A Writer and Publicity Man
description: Edwin Franden Dakin, writer, editor and publicrelations executive, died Friday at his home in Covington, La. He was 77 years old.

title: Swiss Driver Wins
description: Clay Regazzoni of Switzerland drove a Ferrari to victory in the first United States Grand Prix West at Long Beach, Calif. Page 41.

title: Notes on People
description: Under the Presidential order for reorganization of the intelligence community, Vice Adm. Daniel J. Murphy was named yesterday by George Bush, the director of Central Intelligence, to be deputy director for relations with other intelligence agencies. Lieut. Gen. Vernon A. Walters of the Army has been C.I.A. deputy director for several years, and will continue in that post.

title: Miss Hearst Is Back in Court to Face State Charges
description: LOS ANGELES, March 29Patricia Hearst began in a heavily guarded state courtroom here today what could be another long legal ordeal.

title: REAGAN GETS TIME ON TV TOMORROW
description: LOS ANGELES, March 29NBC reversed Itself today and announced it would provide 30 minutes of network prime time Wednesday for a paid political address by Ronald Reagan.

title: KISSINGER IS TOLD TURKS PACT FACES ROUGH SLEDDING
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger was warned on Capitol Hill today that the new TurkishAmerican bases agreement would face very rough sledding in Congress unless it was accompanied by significant progress toward a Cyprus settlement.

title: Tremor Hits Virgin Islands
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 29 (UPI) Electricity Was knocked out in parts of the United States Virgin Islands early today by a tremor that Occurred less than an hour after a major earthquake south of Panama, the United States Geodetic Observatory at Cayey reported. It said that the tremor, which could have been related to the larger quake, was felt at 1:16 A.M, in all three of the Virgin Islands.

title: TROTSKYITE PARTY ASSAILS POLICE
description: The Socialist Workers Party Asserted yesterdaY that the New York Police Department had failed to press investigations of bombings of its offices over the years, and it called for opening police files to determine whether there were Any links with admitted Federal Bureau of Investigation burglaries of Party offices here.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: TORM ALICE (Torm), Algiers April 13 and Alexandria 23; sails tram 23d St., Brooklyn.

title: About the Islanders
description: Although Ralph Stewart sprained his ankle about six weeks ago In practice, it has not healed. He will wear hard cast beginning today. Dave Lewis is still out with sprained ankle.  As an additional security measure following crowd harassment of the Minnesota team in recent game, Nassau Coliseum workers raised the glass around the visiting players bench by four feet. Before last night's game Reggie Leach of the Flyers had scored 22 goals in 23 games.

title: Small Towns Losing Their Post Offices, and ZIP Codes, Along With a Sense of Identity
description: GOOCHLAND COURT HOUSE, Va.  23078 is going. 23159 is gone. 21761 is not for long. They are not apt to be remembered in ballad or song.

title: 9 Roles Uncertain In N. H. L. Playoffs
description: With only six days left in the National Hockey League's regular season, one would expect that the 12 teams that will be involved in the playoffs would be resting and scouting their fu ture opponents. Despite just three or four games left however, the only certainty seems to be that Montreal, Philadelphia and Boston will receive byes in the first round.

title: Surgery or Suicide
description: On a recent night on a quiet street in Greerrwich Village a group of middleclass New Yorkers forms and grows rapidly around a man who has just been helped from the sidewalk and Is standing befuddled, shaking his head. He is a doctor who had just been mugged at the doorway of his handsome brick town house.

title: ALASKA GAS LINE COULD BE DELAYED
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)The Interior Department, in a final environmental impact statement, said today that it might be a good idea to delay its decision on whether to permit construction of a 5,580mile natural gas pipeline from northern Alaska to the lower United States.

title: Radio
description: 87:25 A.M., WNYCFM. Scaramouche, Sibelius; Fantasy for Piano, Debussy; Symphony No. 2, Borodin.

title: Postal Service Trims Costs to Avoid Rate Rise
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI)The United States Postal Service is trimming its operating costs to avoid considering another rate rise until next year, Postmaster General Beniamin F. Bailar said today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Congress indicated yesterday to Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, who testified before the House International Relations Committee, that apprbval of the new Turk: ishAmerican bases agreement was doubtful if Turkey made no significant progress toward a Cyprus settlement. title: JUSTICES DECLINE TO REMOVE CURB ON HOMOSEXUALS
description: WASHINGTON, March 29The Supreme Court ruled today, 6 to 3, that states may prosecute and imprison people for committing homosexual acts even when both parties to an act are consenting adults and the act occurs in private.

title: Brezhnev Absence Noted At Bulgarian Party Parley
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 29The Bulgarian Communist Party opened its 11th congress here today with praise for Leonid I. Brezhnev as the most highly esteemed statesman of our age, but to the surprise of many the Soviet leader was absent.

title: Sugar Futures Off On Philippines Deal
description: Sugar futures dropped sharply on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange after an announcement that a second major company, the Great Western United Corporation, had signed a longterm agreement to buy Philionine sugar.

title: Arol Pays Part of Rent on Bronx Market
description: The Arol Development Corporation has paid the city $247,526.71 in rent for the nearly five years that it has occupied the Bronx Terminal Market, according to official records.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FREE VERSE Elizabeth Culbert and David Ferguson are the poets being presented tonight at 7 o'clock in the free series of readings at the New York Public Library's Donnell Center, 20 West 53d Street.

title: Seismic Risk at Nuclear Sites Studied
description: Extensive geological investigations of the Hudson Valley region around the Indian Point nuclear power station, which have just come to light, are expected to influence both the design and placement of future nuclear electricity plants in the thickly populated. East.

title: Bank Suspension Extended
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) The temporary suspension of trading in securities of the Farmers Bank of the State of Delaware has been extended through April 6, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today.

title: Pacers Publicist Stricken
description: INDIANAPOLIS (AP)Bip Marvel, the Indiana Pacers publicity director, was listed in serious condition Monday at Methodist Hospital following a heart attack last night.

title: Leah Parker, ExDirector Of Training for Girl Scouts
description: Leah Parker, former director of training of the Girl Scouts of America and, from 1962 to 1970, a field representative of the National Commission on Social Work Careers, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 75 years old and lived at 220 East 18th Street.

title: INSPECTORS CLOSED COAL MINE 64 TIMES
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 29 (UPI)  Federal inspector closed the Scotia Coal Compaly mine 57 times in six year, and state inspectors closed it seven times in the same period, it was reported today.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Nets Defeated by Spurs; Nuggets Gain A.B.A. Title
description: SAN ANTONIO, March 29 (AP)James Silas scored 33 points and four other Spurs were in double figures tonight as San Antonio stopped the New York Nets, 116101, in an American Basketball Association game.

title: Concorde Makers Agree to Complete Initial Series of 16
description: PARIS, March 29 (UPI)The British and French transport ministers left unanswered today the question of future production of the Concorde, their joint $3.1 billion supersonic transport project.

title: ARGENTINE CHIEF, VIDELA, SWORN IN
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 29Lieut. Gen. Jorge Rafael Vickla took the oath of office today as Argentina's 39th President and then swore in a Cabinet of six officers and two civilians.

title: Respect, Title for Hoosier 3
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 29 They filed into their locker room at halftime one by one, and sat silently in their places. They listened as their coach told them that they had to play harder and that they had to work harder. And then their coach left, and they began to talk among themselves. They began to talk about the fact that their teat, Indiana, was trailing Michigan, 35.29, in the National Collegiate basketball championship game.

title: Leif Eid, 67, Correspondent For NBC News Until 1966
description: Leif Lid, an NBC News correspondent for three decades until his retirement in 1966, died Sunday in St. Croix, V. I., where he had lived for the last five years. He was 67 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: More than 30 Queens College students took over the school's administration building yesterday to protest proposals to impose tuition at the City University. Leaders the school's student association ordered administrators, faculty members and secretaries to leave the top 11 floors of the Academic II tower. The sitin began at 3 P.M. and was continuing early today.

title: HELPWANTED INDEX GAINED IN FEBRUARY
description: An improvement in the employment picture is indicated by a substantial increase in [helpwanted advertising, the Conference Board said yester day. In February, the board's helpwanted advertising index rose by six points, or 6.9 percent, over the January level and was 17 points over the Feb ruary 1975 level, a gain of 22.3 percent.

title: In Memoriam
description: MILLERJulia de Boer. My beloved Mom, born In Philadelphia, many years ago. Left me on March 26, 1965, Green is my memory today, like It happened yesterday. Lee de Boer Miller.

title: Recital
description: Any series of recitals by visiting organists presents at least one serious, problem. The organ is an implausibly complicated instrument that a performer, even a great one, simply does not sit down to and play with utter confidence. A great many rehearsals are generally required before a player feels at home with an unfamiliar organ, far more so than would be the case with a pianist or violinist.

title: Maine Congressmen Challenge Army's Choice of a Belgian Gun
description: WASHINGTON, March 29The United States Army announced today that it intended to buy $30 million in Belgian light machine guns for its tanks.

title: Advertising
description: Sabena Belgian World Airlines has gone to television advertising for the first time, which isn't that big a deal. What is a big deal, though, is the way the carrier, through its agency, Ries Cappiello Colwell, is zeroing in on the affluent suburbs of New York and Philadelphia with a newspaper and directmail campaign.

title: Zarb Relaxes Stand On Heavy Fuel Oil
description: WASHINGTON, March 29Frank G. Zarb, the Federal energy administrator, gave the East Coast a compromise on heavy fuel oil today as he sent to Congress the initial proposal in what he outlined as a stepbystep elimination of price and allocation controls for petroleum products.

title: Amex and OTC Show Price Drops; Trading Is Slower
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market drifted lower in slower trading.

title: Opel Increases Prices
description: RUESSELSHEIM, West Germany, March 29 (UPI)Adam Opel, the General Motors Corporation's West German subsidiary announced today price increases of an average of 4.7 percent for its wide range of automobile models. The new prices will go into effect tomorrow.

title: Rookie Bats In Winning Run
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., March 29The Pittsburgh Pirates, it seems, turn out second basemen the way Jack Nicholson turns out awardwinning movie roles.

title: Newark Dispute Echoes in Senate
description: TRENTON, March 29  A dispute in Newark spilled onto the floor of the State Senate today.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Museum of Modern Art has acquired two early American films, The Life of Moses, a 1909 movie, and picture dealing with women's rights, from the State Film Archive of Czechoslovakia.

title: About the Yankees
description: With Thurman Munson out with a bad finger, Rick Dempsey has become the team's ironman. He has caught the last five games and a total of 50 consecutive innings. He was probably the happiest to see yesterday's 14inning game end.  Graig Nettles hit a towering 400foot homer that cleared the 25foot centerfield wall.  Sparky Lyle struck out all three batters he faced. Tug McGraw, who pitched a scoreless two innings for the Phillies, has an advertisement on wheels for his comic strip, Scroogie. He Calls it his Scroogie van. Five of the comicstrip characters are painted on each side of the van, and the license plate reads PETS 45 for the name of Scroogie's team and Tug's uniform number.

title: Passing the Bucks
description: Let's legalize bribery and keep America prosperous. It is the sensible solution to a nasty problem.

title: Coleman Seeks CommuterAirline Aid
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)The Ford Administration asked the Congress today to give Federal subsidies to unregulated commuter airlines for the first time to insure that small towns across the nation continue to have scheduled air service.

title: BALL AND PAVANE DANCED BY JOFFREY
description: The restoration of Kurt Jooss's work to a current generation of dance audiences is a major coup for the City Center Joffrey Ballet. Over the weekend the company showed the two ballets that it revived his season, with a few cast hanges.

title: City Payments Subsidize 6 Cheap Hotels on Bowery
description: New York City spends close to $600,000 a year subsidizing six Bowery flophouses where derelict men receive a night's lodging in tiny, poorly ventilated and often filthy cubicles.

description: Hockey, Basketball Standiras

title: Issues 76: Energy
description: The term of the next President will in all likelihood bridge the transformation of this country from a carefree squanderer of energy, as it long has been, into an acutely energyconscious society of the kind that rising costs and scarcity are forcing it to become.

title: EMELINE N. EDWARDS, FORMER TIME EDITOR
description: Emeline Nollen Edwards, who had been a special assistant to the late Henry R. Luce, cofounder of Time Inc., died of cancer Sunday in San Francisco. She was 65 years old and had lived in San Francisco since her retirement from Time Inc. in 1967.

title: Who Gets Walloped?
description: They don't have the wallop we have. That was the answer given by Matthew Guinan, leader of the city's unionized transit workers, when asked why his members should not follow the noincrease pattern set earlier this month in pay negotiations covering state employees.

title: People in Sports
description: With a cast on her left wrist and a sprained left ankle, Martina Navratilova did not seem an ideal center of attraction for yesterday's announcement of Family Circle Magazine's $100,000 women's tennis tournament, April 28 at Amelia Island, Fla.

title: 4 IN ZEBRA KILLING, SENTENCED TO LIFE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 29 (AP)Four Black Muslims convicted of the socalled Zebra murders and assaults on whites two winters ago were sentenced today to life in prison.

title: Zambian Calls on Britain To Use Force in Rhodesia
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, March 29 (Reuters)  President Kenneth D. Kaunda said today that British military intervention would he the best answer to the Rhodesian problem, but that in the meantime blacks should begin a sabotage campaign.

title: Colby Defends Schorr In Release of Document.
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 29 (UPI)William E. Colby, the former Director of Central Intelligence, says that Daniel Schorr should not be punished for releasing a secret House report on United States intelligence operations.

title: FUNDS ARE VOTED IN SCHORR INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, March 29The House overwhelmingly voted today funds for its investigation into the unauthorized publishing of the House Intelligence Committee report in The Village Voice, rejecting protests by liberal members that the inquiry would spread to disclosures about the document by other news organizations.

title: Kissinger Calls Account of Nixon Talk Indecent
description: WASHINGTON March 29 (AP)Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that published accounts of his meeting with President Richard M. Nixon the night before Mr. Nixon resigned were distorted and inaccurate and show an indecent lack of compassion.

title: Indiana Wins Title
description: Indiana won the National Collegiate basketball title by defeating Michigan, 8668, last night at Philadelphia. Rutgers lost, 10692, to the University of California, Los Angeles, in the thirdplace game. Details on page 25.

Murphy was named yesterday by George Bush, the Director of Central Intelligence, to be deputy director for relations with other intelligence agencies. Lieut. Gen. Vernon A. Walters of the Army has been C.I.A. deputy director for several years, and will continue in that post.

title: Elderly Assail Income Tax As Democrats Seek Change
description: TRENTON, March 29While Senate Democrats wrangled over possible amendments to increase the yield of the Assemblypassed state income tax, the proposal came under fire today from groups for the elderly and others.

title: Nlennin's Voices Is Given Premiere
description: Peter Mennin has been more visible of late as president of the Juilliard School than es a composer; but he continues to practice diligently the, craft that first brought him to attention. Mr. Mennin's Voices, which was given its first performance on Sunday evening by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, represents somewhat of a departure from the Mennin works with which one is familiar. Although by most standards he would be considered a conservative composer, Mr. Mennin flirts here with some moderately advanced devices.

title: FORD THREATENS A DEFENSE VETO
description: WASHINGTON, March 29President Ford threatened today to take the unprecedented step of vetoing any defense spending bill passed by Congress that he deemed inadequate to safeguard the nation's security.

title: Escargots for the Grackles
description: RYE, N.Y.It all began on a modestenough scalea few scraps of stale bread thrown on the ground for the sparrows and the jays whenever there was a hard freeze or snow cover. The response exceeded our expectations. It was soon to become apparent that we were not merely catering to an acquired taste. The sad truth is that the welfare state is indigenous to suburban life, and the longing for repose and a guaranteed annual wage are not the exclusive property of any one species.

title: STATE LOSING WAR ON CIGARETTE TAX
description: A ranking city police officer told a state task force yesterday that police efforts to hall the widespread sale of untaxed cigarettes had done little more than solidify organizedcrime's control of the cigarettebootlegging industry.

title: THOUSANDS HAIL KING IN ANDALUSIA
description: SEVILLE, Spain, March 29Tens of thousands of Seville residents gave King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia a cheering welcome today as the royal couple arrived to start a weeklong tour of Andalusia, Spain's most depressed region.

title: Chess:
description: Mikhail Tal of Latvia, a former world champion, has defeated the Swedish grandmaster Ulf Andersson in an eightgame match held in Stockholm. In this exceptionally closefought series, Tal scored with an ingenious mating attack in the fifth game; the other games all ended in draws.

title: Dow Off by 6.06 to 997.40 As Trading Pace Slackens
description: The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled below the 1,000 level yesterday as stock prices declined in the second slowest trading session of the year. After climbing last week to a 38month high, the bluechip indicator dropped 6.06 points to 997.40.

description: The prize for victory in the last battle was the 38th. National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship for the undefeated Hoosiers.

title: TV: Two for Thought
description: For anyone suffering from a hangover of Academy Award trivialities, tonight's schedule contains two rather substantial entries: A Third Testament, the first of a sixpart series with Malcolm Muggeridge, the British journalist, exploring the times and writings of Christian thinkers (St. Augustine, Pascal, Blake, Kierkegaard, Tolstoy and BonHoeffer), and Liberty, the second 90minute installment in an NBC News series keyed to the Bicentennial and the themes of Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Happiness.

title: Pay Scales in City Found Higher Than in Suburbs
description: New York City businessmen pay substantially higher wages than businessmen in the suburbsaverages of up to 9 percent more for whitecollar work and 21 percent more for blue  collar work  the New York office of the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

description: Directors of the Canada Southern Ralrway, a solvent leased line of the Penn Central system, yesterday voted an extraomdinary dividend of $60 share.

title: Algoma Will Raise Prices On Structural Steel by $11
description: The Algoma Steel Corporation announced in Toronto yesterday that it planned to raise prices of structural steel by $11 a ton April 11. This would be about 4 percent. The company, which is the largest Canadian producer of structural steel, said buyers had been.

title: Theater: Play Mas, an Acid Parable
description: This acid parable about political reality and illusion in the newly independent bits of colonialempire dances on two points of light.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption in the late editions of The New York Times yesterday incorrectly identified Stewart L. Udall, former Secretary of the Interior, as his brother, Representative Morris K. Udall.

title: City Austerity to Lessen in Election Year
description: The fiscal and political implications of Mayor Beame's newly revised austerity plan converge in one highly interesting feature: that in the plan's, final, third year  the 1977 mayoral election yearMr. Beame wants to hold down dramatically the level of job closings and other painful cuts by passing on to the state government more than half of that year's required deficit reduction.

title: City Subsidizes 6 Hotels on the Bowery
description: New York City spends close to $600,000 a year subsidizing six cheap Bowery hotels where derelict men receive a night's lodging in tiny, poorly ventilated and often filthy cubicles.

title: Helping New York
description: Several parents and their children wait outside the little medical office at one end of the large Nevins Day Care Center in Brooklyn. check an average of 20 children from 2 to 5 in the afternoon.

title: ALVIN I. KAMBER
description: Alvin I. Kamber, associate director of the Yeshiva University high schools died yesterday at his home, 110 East 81st Street, Brooklyn. He was 48 years old.

description: YANKEES (A)

title: Bridge:
description: Teams led by Sam Stayman of New York City and Harold Lilie of Woodmere, L.I., qualified for the district Grand National final in play at the New York Hilton Hotel Sunday.

title: Great Adventure Stresses Love
description: Great Adventure in Jackson, N. J., is more than an amusement park with lots of rides. Its new management believes this and believes it because management sampled the opinions of people who have visited there.

title: FORD THREATENS A DEFENSE VETO
description: WASHINGTON, March 29President Ford threatened today to take the unprecedented step of vetoing any defense spending bill passed by Congress that he deemed inadequate to safeguard the nation's security.

title: THREAT OF STRIKE IS BOON TO HOTELS
description: If transit workers strike on Thursday morning, hotel rooms in the city will be as scarce as subway cars.

title: Forest Service Seeks Cause of the Skiing Accident at Vail That Killed Four
description: VAIL, Colo., March 29Eight United States Forest Service officials, including the chief safety officer from Washington, searched today for the cause of the gondola accident at the Vail ski resort that killed four persons and injured eight.

title: Sadat Arrives in West Germany On the Start of a European Tour
description: BONN. March 29 (Reuters)President Anwar elSadat of Egypt began a fivenation European tour here today, seeking arms and cash in the West following his break with the Soviet Union earlier this month.

title: Staggered Work Hours Urged if Transit Halts
description: Alfred Eisenpreis, the City Economic Development Administrator, met with representatives of major concerns yesterday to discuss staggered working hours in Manhattan's central business district in the event of a transit strike. The aim is to help traffic.

title: Yonkers Raceway Entries
description: Yonkers Raceway Entries

title: Psychiatrist Finds Big Rise In Deaths Linked to Valium
description: A Chicago psychiatrist says that a growing number of drug deaths are linked to the tranquilizer Valium, which he said is prescribed by some doctors as casually as aspirin, the Associated Press reported.

title: A Transit Raise Linked To Productivity Savings
description: David L. Yunich, chairman of the Transit Authority, said yesterday that a costofliving raise for transit workers paid for by productivity savings would provide a possibility of a settlement in the current contract talks.

title: Brazil Rail Crash Kills 2
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 29 (Reuters)Two people were killed and 38 injured when a commuter train and a sau Paulo express train crashed mar hero this rooming, a spokesman for the railroad system said.

title: 25 Choir Members Robbed
description: TOLEDO. Ohio, March 29 (UPI)Two gunmen wearing ski masks robbed abotit 21 members of the choir at the First Baptist Church here last night. The police said that one of the men held the choir members at gunpoint and the other collected wallets, watches and rings. About $900 in valuables was taken, they added.

title: islanders Rout Flyers, 51
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 29A dazzling show of strength in every aspect of the game enabled the New York Islanders to defeat their arch rivals, the Philadelphia Flyers, 51 tonight in Nassau Coliseum. Should the twa teams meet again this spring it most likely will be in the final round of the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: City to Use $5.5 Million Federal Grant To Rehire 205 Officers Until June 30
description: Using a $5.5 million Federal grant, the Police Department will rehire 205 police officers who were laid off during the fiscal crisis, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said yesterday.

title: Jackson and Udall Attack Carter as Insensitive to City
description: Jimmy Carter was attacked last night as insensitive to New York City's fiscal tribulations by his two major rivals in the New York primary election.

title: McDonald Sees Star on Pact
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29Tom Seaver, the most worrisome holdout in the history of the New York Mets discussed his contract with the management again today but did not sign it though the, Mets denied that they were close to trading him to the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 29Final arguments and the judge's instructions to the jury in Joe Kapp's antitrust suit against the National Football League were postponed until tomorrow. Judge William T. Sweigert decided to take more time for legal research and inchambers conferences with the lawyers.

title: Democrats Broaden Convention Access
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)Planners for the Democratic National Convention voted today to give all the party's members of Congress, governors and lieutenant governors access to the convention floor next July.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)A top Treasury Department official said today there was a strong likelihood that oilexporting nations will not increase oil prices this spring. Assistant Treasury Secretary Gerald L. Parsky added that the threat of another effective oil embargo has diminished considerably.

title: Rembrandt Found in74 Going on View in Utrecht
description: BRUSSELS, March 29A previously unknown Rembrandt painting will go on display Wednesday in the Diocesan Museum of Utrecht in the Netherlands.

title: A Poll for Udall Indicates He's Gaining in Wisconsin
description: Polls conducted for Representative Morris K. Udall indicate that in the last two weeks he has come from far behind and has nearly overtaken Jimmy Carter in the Wisconsin Presidential primary, one of Mr. Udall's political advisers said yesterday.

title: A Summary of Actions Taken by the United States Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Hartford Insurance Group and the Prudential Property and Casualty Insurance Company received rate increases on automobile policy premiums from the State Department of Insurance. Hartford received an average increase of 33.3 percent according to the Insurance Commissioner, James J. Sheeran. The new rates go into effect April 15.

title: Union Cuts Tie With Stein Unit On Study of Waste by State
description: ALBANY, March 29The Albany region of the union representing state employees today withdrew its support from an investigation that it was sponsoring jointly with Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein, Democrat of Manhattan, into waste in state government.

title: LEON CARR
description: Leon Carr, composerlyricist and arranger who wrote the commercial See the USA in Your Chevrolet, died Saturday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 65 years old.

title: Navy Contract to Sperry
description: The Sperry Rand Corporation announced yesterday receipt of an $81.4 million Navy contract for fire control systems and associated equipment.

title: Herman Michelson, Editor On The World, Dead at 79
description: Herman Michelson, who was Sunday editor of The World when it closed in 1931 and editor of The End of The World, a book about the event, died of cancer yesterday in a hospital in Bath, Me. He was 79 years old and had lived in Westport, Me., since his retirement in 1965.

title: Trades Help Suns Rise to Contention
description: Paul Westphal, whose profile is one that might appear on a boy scout calendar, may have righted all past criticism of Jerry Colangelo, the Phoenix Suns general manager. Since the Suns came into Pro existence in the 196869 season of the National Basketball Association, Colangelo has been questioned about his dismissal of coaches, the signing of Connie Hawkins and Charlie Scott, the loss of Paul Silas to the Boston Celtics, the trading of Gail Goodrich to the Los Angeles Lakers and some of his draft choices.

title: Amerada Cost Advantage Ended by New F.E.A. Rule
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)The Federal Energy Administration today adopted new rules to reduce a competitive advantage enjoyed by the AmeradaHess Corporation in the residrial fuel oil market.

title: Senate Votes Alcoholic Aid
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)The Senate passed today a bill to extend for three years the Federal program to assist in the treatment and prevention of alcoholism. If fully funded by later appropriations, the total cost, including grants to the states, would be 5755 million. The measure now goes to the House.

title: Finland's Seamen Strike
description: HELSINKI, Finland, March 29 (AP)Finland's 17,500 seamen today began a strike that will shut down all Finnish passenger and cargo ships the minute they dock in home ports. The seamen are demanding more pay for work on Sundays and at night.

title: Dance: Unusual Way With a Style
description: The other afternoon at the City Center Joffrey Ballet I saw a program that started with Jerome Robbins's Interplay, which dates from 1945 and ended with Twyla Tharp's Deiice Coupe II, which goes back to last year. And between them they represent almost a perfect history of American dance.

title: People and Business
description: Daniel J. Haughton, who was ousted recently as chairman and chief executive officer of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, blames the system and not himself for his company's payoffs to foreign political leaders to promote Lockheed's airplane sales.

title: U.S. Trial Starts Here for 3 On Police Corruption Charges
description: A retired police sergeant. Frank King, and two suspended detectives, Ronald P. Heffernan and Jack Matarasso, went on trial yesterday on charges of conspiring to use illegal wiretaps to shake down narcotics suspects.

title: Quadriplegic Wins $1 Million in Taxi Accident
description: A 33yearold electrician who became a quadriplegic as a result of an automobile accident in 1969 was awarded $1 million yesterday in one of the largest settlements ever negotiated in the state in an auto collision case.

title: Americans Said to Spend Ninth of Income on Health
description: CHICAGO, March 29 (UPI)The average American family spends more than a ninth of its earnings for health care, and the amount is rapidly rising, according to The American Medical News.

title: British and French Delay On New Concorde Output
description: PARIS, March 29 (Reuters)Britain and France postponed today a decision on whether to build more Concorde supersonic airlines.

title: Suit Opposing Oct. 6 Cutoff For Primary Voting Killed
description: A Federal district judge dismissed yesterday a suit challenging a New York State law requiring voters to have been registered by last October 6 to be eligible to vote in the April primary here.

title: Japanese Color TV Sets Face Trade Act Inquiry
description: WASHINbTON, March 29The International Trade Commission opened the way today to possible restraints on imports of color television sets from Japan by announcing its first major investigation under a hitherto obscure provision of the 1974 trade law.

title: TOY MAKER PLANS A MOVE TO BRONX
description: Miner Industries Inc., a leading toy manufacturer, announced yesterday it was moving its homeentertainment division from Pennsylvania to the Bronx and would create 250 jobs there.

title: Miss Hearst Is Back in Court to Face State Charges
description: LOS ANGELES, March 29Patricia Hearst began in heavily guarded state courtroom here today what could be another long legal ordeal.

title: Music: Mehta Leads Philadelphians
description: It was Zubin Mehta's first local appearance since the annoucement of his appointment to the New York Philharmonic. So a lame audience went to Carnegie Hall last night to see him at the helm of the Philadelphia Orchestra in Mahler's Second Symphony, the Resurrection. Mr. Mehta and late romantics, especially Mahler, are supposed to have a symbiotic relationship. One could see why, last night.

title: DR. C. RANKIN BARNES
description: Rev. Dr. C. Rankin Barnes, secretary of the house of deputies of the general convention of the Episcopal Church from 1947 to his retirement in 1961, and former canon of St. Paul's Cathedral in Los Angeles, died Friday in a convalescent home in San Diego. He was 85 years old.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Congress indicated yesterday to Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, who testified before the House International Relations Committee, that approval of the new TurkishAmerican bases agreement was doubtful if Turkey made no significant progress toward a Cyprus settlement. [Page 1, Col. 5.]

title: Land Use Expert Urges Curb on Zoning
description: WASHINGTON, March 29State legislatures are going to have to develop equitable regional planning for population distribution and the housing of all income groups or the courts will, a prominent jurist in the field of land use predicted last week.

title: Senate Votes Bill On a Fishing Zone 200 Miles Off shore
description: WASHINGTON. March 29The Senate agreed today to compromise legislation extending United States fisheries jurisdiction to 200 miles.

description: Dividends

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. on Angola.

title: Bicentennial Attractions
description: Although the highlights of the Bicentennial celebration will come on the Fourth of July other observances have been scheduled or are alreedy under way. ries of local communities in libraries and institutions throughout the city.

title: Carter Says He Regrets Comment on Humphrey
description: ROANOKE, Va., March 28 (AP)Jimmy Carter said today that he regretted having said last week that Senator Hubert H. Humphrey was too old to be President.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Rise at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: FARM LOAN ISSUE OF 1.5 BILLION DIE
description: The Farm Credit System announced plans yesterday to sell $1.5 billion of securities to refund $773 million of maturing issues and to raise $714 million of additional money for loans to agriculture. The announcement came as the credit markets settled into a quiet stability that contrasted sharply with the strong advance in prices early last week. The Treasury sold bills at its weekly auction yesterday at rates slightly higher than a week earlier, and the Federal Reserve took no action in the money market either for itself or for any of the accounts it handles:

title: Open Interest
description: Open Interest

title: Oil Concerns Fight Bill for Divestitures
description: WASHINGTON, March 29The Shell Oil Company has sent marketing executives to talk to filling station operators. The Atlantic Richfield Company has made and shown a 33minute film to 4,000 of its dealers.

title: North Vietnam Demands U.S. Fulfill Its Promise of Postwar Aid
description: PARIS, March 29The North Vietnamese Government, replying to an American request for talks about normalizing relations, demanded today that the United States fulfill its promise of postwar aid.

title: Tearnter Head Said to Favor National, Not Selective, Strike
description: DETROIT, March 29Frank E. Fitzsimmons, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, seeking to put maximum pressure on the trucking industry in the negotiations for a new contract, has told union leaders he favors a nationwide strike rather than selective strikes, according to union sources.

title: Upset Is Averted By Miss Morozova
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 29 (AP)Olga Morozova of the Soviet Union warded off a threat from young Mima Jausovic of Yugoslavia, winning by 62, 46, 76, in the first round of the $75,000 Virginia Slims of Philadelphia tennis tournament today. Miss Morozova trailed by 24 in the third set.

title: John Cogley Dies at 60; Expert on Catholicism
description: John Cogley, former religious news editor of The New York Times whose writing interpreted one of the most turbulent periods in American religious history, died last night of a heart attack in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 60 years old.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts; 1976, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Monday, March 29. 70th day. Weather clear, track fast.
description: Aqueduct Race Charts; 1976, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Monday, March 29. 70th day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Theater: Women's Work
description: In Croon, upstairs at the Performing Garage, women talk about women, but the play is addressed to everyone in the audience. It has considerable to say, most of it comic, not only about the motherdaughter relationship the core of the work, but aoout all relationshipsparucularly the roots of family conflict.

title: Problems of Aged Mentally Ill Held Difficult Despite Gains
description: CHICAGO, March 27 Thirty years ago, Anna O'Connell says, she lived at the Traemore Hotel, an exclusive rooming home for young women.

title: Memorial Seruites
description: ANDREWSCatharine Simpson. Died March 76th. Memorial service March 30th, 11 A.M., Cathedral of St. John the Divine, St. Martin's Chapel.

title: In Scotland's Outer Hebrides, the Defenders of Gaelic Still Hope to Have the Last Word
description: STORNOWAY, Outer Hebrides, March 24  In the fiercely Calvinist churches of these islands, in pubs, where a beer is served with a shot of whisky, and in the homes, around fires of sweetsmelling peat, the language they sneak is Gaelic.

title: Woolworth Quarter Profit Up 92%
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the quarter and year ended Jan. 31, with profits up 92 percent for the quarter and 65 percent for the year.

title: 2 Jersey Highways May Go Unfinished
description: TRENTON, March 29State transportation officials expressed doubt today that the missing links in two major interstate highways would ever be completed.

title: Colgate and Cook Disclose Payments Called Questionable
description: WASHINGTON, March 29The ColgatePalmolive Company today joined the long list of companies that have disclosed questionable foreign payments, while Cook United Inc. became one of the first to admit payments for nonpolitical purposes in this country.

title: U.S. Plans Clearinghouse On CancerCausing Agents
description: ST. PETERSBURG BEACH Fla., March 29The director of the National Cancer Institute said ktoday that he was setting up a national clearinghouse on cancercausing agents in the environment.

title: U.S. Plans Clearinghouse On CancerCausing Agents
description: ST. PETERSBURG BEACH Fla., March 29The director of the Naticihal Cancer Institute said today that he was setting up a national clearinghouse on cancercausing agents in the environment.

title: Rutgers Season Finally Ends On Plaintive Note in Defeat
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 29 The game was over and lost. The season was over, too. But maybe it was salvaged. Maybe Rutgers, in losing to the University of California, Los Angeles, tonight regained some of the respect it had lost in being devastated by Michigan two days ago. Maybe.

title: Tactical Air Missile. Is Tested by the Navy
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)The Navy said today that its Tomahawk cruise missile made its first flight yesterday from a plane. The tactical weapon traveled about 70 nautical miles after being launched from an A6 attack plane off the California coast.

title: The Stavisky Bill
description: The real Issue behind the present controversy over the Stavisky bill is how best to protect the quality of public education without scuttling the city's fiscal rescue plan.

title: SALE OF REFINERY SOUGHT BY PASCO
description: Pasco Inc., an integrated oil company 55.5 percent owned by Studebaker  Worthington Inc., asked the Federal Trade Commission yesterday to approve its proposed sale of a Wyoming oil refinery and other assets for $78 million. In Washington, the F.T.C. said that the purchaser in the latest deal would be a newly formed company, the Sinclair Oil Corporation, owned by the Little America Refining Company and an affiliate, Holding's Little America.

title: U.S. Proposes to Fine Utility for Not Keeping Unstable ExEmployee Out of Nuclear Plant
description: WASHINGTON, March 29The Government has proposed fining a Pennsylvania utility $8,000 after the company's security force failed to apprehend a disturbed former employee who entered the protected area around the utility's nuclear reactor.

title: Cuba, in Security Council, Hails Outcome in Angola
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 29Cuba declared in the Security Council today that the victory by Angolan revolutionaries had raised new hopes among the millions of men and women who are oppressed in southern Africa.

title: VOTE BOARD BILL CLEARED TO HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, March 29A bill to reconstitute the Federal Election Commission barely survived a confused and contentious session of the House Rules Committee today.

title: Israeli Arab Dies in Riot on Strike's Eve
description: JERUSALEM, Tuesday March 30An Israeli Arab was killed last night and seven were wounded in violent street demonstrations and rioting in small village in the western Galilee, a police spokesman announced this morning.

title: MYRTLE K. BARTLETT
description: STAMFORD, Conn., March 29Myrtle Kezar Bartlett, chairman of the F.A, Bartlett Tree Expert Company, died to day at the age of 86. She lived at 125 Prospect Street.

title: LOWER LENDING RATE ON HOME LOANS SET
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) The Government announced today a reduction in the maximum rate that lenders can charge people using Governmentinsured loans to buy their homes.

title: Beame Offers SchoolAid Compromise
description: ALBANY, March 29Mayor Beame held out the prospect today that funds cut from the school budget could be restored in 197748 as a possible compromise on the disputed Stavisky bill, which earmarks a fixed proportion of the city expense budget for public schools.

title: 13 AIRLINES GUILTY ON PACIFIC REBATES
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (Reuters)  Thirteen United States and foreign airlines that fly the Pacific were found guilty in San Francisco today of giving illegal rebates to passengers and freight customers, the Justice Department announced here.

title: CHARLES B. BOLTON
description: Charles Bingham Bolton, a civic leader in Cleveland despite a paralyzing swimming accident that had confined him to a wheelchair since he was 18, died Sunday at his home in the suburb of Lyndhurst, Ohio. He was 66 years old.

title: Taiwan Leaders Attend Funeral for Lin Yutang
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 29 (AP)President Yeh Chiakan and Prime Minister Chiang Chingkuo attended funeral services for Lin Yutang, one of modern China's foremost scholars and authors.

description: Deaths

title: Stram's Son to Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 29 (UPI)Stu Stram, son of the New Orleans Saints coach, Hank Stram, has signed a letter of intent to play football at the University of Louisville, the head coach, Vince Gibson, said today. Stram is a 5foot10inch, 180pound quarterback from Shawnee Mission, Kan.

title: The Right to a TobaccoFree Job
description: An employee of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company who had sued her employer on charges of denying her a work place free from injurious and toxic substances has been temporarily granted the right to work in an environment free from the tobacco smoke that she said made her sick.

title: HeadOn Crash Kills Couple
description: MUNCIE, Ind., March 29 (AP) Mickey A. Sumner, 27 years old, was driving to meet his fiancee, Deborah Darlene Bricker, yesterday and she was driving to meet him when their autos collided headon. Both were kiled.

title: Car Pools, Staggered Work Hours, Relaxed Parking Rules Among Steps

title: RETAIL CHAINS VIE FOR GRANT STORES
description: Competition has developed among some of the country's biggest retail chains to take over many of the closed East Coasts stores of the W. T. Grant Company, which ended goingoutofbusiness sales Saturday.

title: Hussein Here for Talks On Peace in Middle East
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI)King Hussein of Jordan arrived today for two days of talks with President Ford and Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger in which they will review efforts to bring peace to the Middle East.

description: A new 26month contract covering 8,000 workers employed by 100 concerns represented by the Metropolitan Lithographers Association, was announced yesterday.

description: In the discussion over the advantages of investing in a careful selection of stocks designed to mirror the performance of a leading market index, the argument is made that such an index fund would inevitably lag in a bull market, as would the indicator it was designed to copy.

description: From Castle Clinton to City Hall, from river to river, in what was the city's Colonial harbor and mercantile area, New Yorkers on July 4 will remember the 200th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence with a day of ceaseless entertainment, folk music, historical readings, ethnic foods and festivals and sidestreet concerts.

title: Jackson Sharpens Attacks To Stem Carter's Advance
description: UTICA, March 29Senator Henry M. Jackson campaigned across upstate New York today, sharpening along the way his attacks on Jimmy Carter, one of his two active rivals in the state's April 6 Democratic Presidential primary election.

title: A Police Van for Bobby Wilkerson
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 29Suddenly, he was down and not moving, and the whistle blew. Wilkerson, somebody said. He looks like he's hurt. Bobby Wilkerson, 6foot7inch senior guard for Indiana, had been sideswiped accidentally across the left temple by an elbow attached to Wayman Britt of Michigan in the opening minutes tonight's National Collegiate Athletic Association championship game. Collisions under the basket happen often and players skid across the glossy floor, but almost always they get up. Bobby Wilkerson wasn't getting up. His left leg was flopped over his right his closed and the back leg, eyes were his head was flat on the floor near the baseline in front of the Indiana bench. The trainers and the doctors were around him now and Bobby Knight, the Indiana coach, walked out his quick stride, his arms pushing back the sides of his redplaid jacket. Bobby Knight glanced down, winced and walked away toward the bench. Not long after that, Bobby Wilkerson lifted his head and it appeared that he was about to get to his feet.

title: Cuckoo's Nest Wins Top 3 Oscars
description: HOLLYWOOD, March 29Jack Nicholson, bypassed for an Academy Award four times before, won an Oscar tonight for his role as a rebel in a mental institution in One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest.

description: The Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union are approaching the final hours in their critical negotiations for a new contract, but legal and fiscal constraints have set new limits on a settlement.

description: David L. Yunich, chairman of the Transit Authority, said yesterday that a costofliving raise for transit workers paid for by productivity savings would provide a possibility of a settlement in the current contract talks.

description: Richard L. Morgan, senior partner in the Wall Street law firm of Reynolds, Richards, LaVenture, Hadley & Davis, died Saturday of a heart attack in Port Chester, N. Y. He was 63 years old and lived in Rye, N. Y.

description: A series of tornadoes struck parts of Arkansas and Mississippi yesterday, killing at least 10 persons, injuring nearly 250 and trapping others in building wreckage the authorities said.

title: Jackson Declares Himself Truest Friend of Cities
description: His record in Congress shows, according to Senator Henry M. Jackson, that he is urban America's truest friend among the candidates for President. On thy record, nothing else forget talkon my record, am the candidate by performance, Mr. Jackson said during an interview with four New York Times reporters.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your March 12 editorial Boycott Backsliding concluded that the Ford Administration may be moderating its strong opposition to discriminatory actions against American citizens or firms as a result of the Arab boycott of Israel. This conclusion is without justification. The Administration continues to oppose any discrimination against United States citizens or firms on the basis of race, religion or ethnic background, and the Department of Commerce's Export Administration Regulations unequivocally forbid such conduct.

title: Bangkok Will Ask Met to Return Idol
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 29The Thai Government plans to ask the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York to return or exchange a S300,000 bronze statue of the Buddhist deity Avaloki teshva ra.

title: NonStop Punch
description: In terms of the city's recovery, the adverse effects of higher transit labor costs would spill over into every other part of the budget in the form of me too adjustments for police, fire, sanitation and all other municipal employees. The austerity figures submitted to the Emergency Financial Control Board last week by Mayor Beame make no allowance for a penny of wage increase in any of these areaswhether in the form of direct or deferred boosts in wages and benefits or of costofliving adjustments.

description: A thief who takes religious literature and leaves health pamphlets has been preying on Catholic parishes in the Buffalo area.

description: WASHINGTON, March 29Frank G. arb, the Federal energy administrator, gaye the East Coast a compromife on heavy fuel, oil today as he sent to CongresS the initial proposal in what he outlined as a stepbystep elimination of price and allocation controls for petroleum products.

title: STRONG RECOVERY SHOWN IN MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, March 29The Government's composite index of leading indicators of the economy ticked upward again in February in another signal that the recovery from the recession was still going strong, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Find Fewer of His Own Art Works Than Expected
description: PARIS, March 29  After ear's labor a team of experts has completed the inventory of Pablo Picasso's collection of his own works and found, according to reliable information, that it comprises 1,500 paintings, 3,000 drawings and 600 pieces of sculpture.

title: Spain Arrests Five; Pats Curbs on Press
description: MADRID, Tuesday March 30 (Reuters)  The Spanish Government last night arrested five major opposition leaders, banned press conferences and warned newspapers not to publish opposition views.

title: A Lawsuit Against Kodak On Boycott Is Adjourned
description: A lawsuit backed by the American Jewish Congress to prevent the Eastman Kodak Company from holding its annual meeting was adjourned here yesterday by United States District Judge John M. Canella until April 5. No reason for the adjournment was given.

title: Washington Subway Opens for Business With Large Crowds
description: WASHINGTON, March 29More than twice the expected number of farepaying passengers rode the short, ihitial section of Washington's new subway system, the Metro, today.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of 1.5 million common shares of the Inland Steel Company, at 49 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation.

description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 29An Atlantic County Freeholder today denounced the Public Service Electric and Gas Company for its plan to operate the world's first floating nuclear power plant here in the face of united local opposition.

title: Samuel L. Gold, Directed Yonkers Hospital Relations
description: Samuel L. Gold, director of community relations for Yonkers General Hospital following his retirement in 1974 as assistant vice president of Deltown Foods, died Sunday in the hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 44 Jennifer Lane in Yonkers.

title: JUSTICES DECLINE TO REMOVE CURB ON HOMOSEXUALS
description: WASHINGTON, March 29The Supreme Court ruled today, 6 to 3, that states may prosecute and imprison people for committing homosexual acts even when both parties to an act are consenting adults and the act occurs in private.

title: Strangulation Held Accident
description: HOLYOKE, Mass., March 20 (AP)A 7yearold boy found hanging from a fire escape at the Holyoke Armory was accidentally strangled, according to a medical examiner's ruling. Ralph E. Sanborn, son of Carol A. Sanborn of Holyoke, died last Saturday shortly after he was found with his head caught between rungs on the fire escape, the police said. The medical examiner, William Dean Jr., ruled that the buy had died of brain injuries caused by accidental strangulation.

title: Pakistan Politician Seized
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, March 29 (Reuters)A prominent opposition politician, Hanif Ramay, former chief minister of Pakistan's heavily populated Punjab Province, was arrested under emergency regulations here tojday for allegedly making an objectionable speech to a workcrs meeting in Lahore on Jan. 9. He was reported to have denounced Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto and the ruling Pakistan People's Party.

title: Monticello Head Busy With Plans
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y. March 29S. Harvey Fosner, the new president of Monticello Raceway, has some longrange plans for this Sullivan County track. Long range, that is, for a 66yearold man who retired from Roosevelt Raceway at the age of 65 and moved to Florida, until he got the call to return and help run Monticello.

description: Betty Ford captured the hearts of the American fashhion industry last night.

description: To cope with an alarming number of thefts from the rnailp of city pension checks, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin will institute next year a system in which money will be transferred electronically directly to bank accounts of retired persons.

title: Bill to Rescue State Housing Unit Gains!
description: ALBANY, March 29Moving to forestall a technical default at the state Housing Finance Agency, the Senate approved today a $10.1 million appropriation to make up a deficiency in the agency's reserve fund caused by the 10monthold strike by tenants in Coop City in the Arnny.

description: BOGOTA, Colombia, March 29 (AP)Social unrest and kidnappings are Increasing in Colombia as the civilian Government struggles to bring inflation under control and cope with strikes.

title: High Risks In the Sonbelt
description: When Gov. Jerry Brown of California confided his Presidential candidacy to a few reporters in his office one night, he was careful to term himself a native son rather than a favorite son. That may have been more than just a calculated ambiguity as to whether he would run only in California, or in other states as well; in fact, the climate does not seem good this year for favorite sons.

description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)  Representative Richard Bolling, Democrat of Missouri, has been designated vice chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, said today.

title: 20 Die in India Bus Crash
description: NEW DELHI, March 29 (UPI) A bus crashed into a tree today near Hoshiarpur, 250 miles north of here, killing 20 persons and injuring 40, the Samachar press agency reported.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption in the late editions of The New York Times yesterday incorrectly identified Stewart L. Udall, former Secretary of the Interior, as his brother, Representative Morris K. Udall.

description: MADRID, March 29 (AP)A team of American broadcasting executives arrived in Madrid today to begin negotiations for permission to continue Radio Liberty's broadcasts to the Soviet Union from Spain.
